title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: I(SAAC) B(ASHEVIS) SINGER: COCKADOODLEDOO  In all lands... there is male and female. Everything is paired, from the fly to the elephant, from the Rooster on High to the ordinary cock. It is true that cluckcluck is... not the same as cockadoodledoo, but a hen, too, is not to be sneezed at.

title: A Supermarket Tests a Vocal Checkout
description: EDGEWATER PARKCustomers at the Pathtnark supermarket in this Burlington County community were not just imagining things when cashiers seemed to be ringing up their purchases without using their hands.

title: Red Tide Poses Threat to Bathers Again
description: TRENTON  Despite an abnormal amount of rain, the three things that bathers at Jersey shore resorts yearn for  warm weather sunny skies and a gentle, but invigorating, sure  have already made their presence known this season. But it could be a mixed blessing.

title: Betsy Weaver Bride of Physician
description: WESTON, Mass., June 30In St. Peter's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Betsy Weaver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Weaver Jr. of Weston and Nantucket, became the bride of Dr. Frederick Allen Connell. He is the son of Howard Connell of New York and Remsenberg, L. I., and Mrs. Alfred W. Bressler of New York.

title: Lamas blowing long trumpets on a monastery roof in central Tibet. Picture was taken about 1937.
description: NEWARK  The Newark Museum, which already owns one of the country's leading collections of Tibetan art and documents, has received a major gift of Tibetiana from Mary Pyne Filley Cutting of Bernardsville.

title: Banker Leads Double Life as Catholic Deacon in Brooklyn
description: Charles A. Postler, 49yearold father of six, is leading a double life.

title: Troubles Besetting Reform Sheriff in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 30In the municipal elections here in the fall of 1971, San Franciscans voted in as sheriff Richard D. Hongisto, a 34yearold criminologist who advocated vast and radical reform in law enforcement.

title: Soviet Is Seeking to Convince Arabs of Continued Backing
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30The Soviet Union, faced by rising Arab criticism of its accommodation with the United States, has started an information campaign to reassure the Arabs of continued support in the Middle East conflict.

title: '73 Bear Market: Looking for a Pattern
description: It was a wretched first halfyear for stocks and bonds, with the securities markets slogging their way doggedly past one problem after another.

title: Hooton of Cubs Also Gives Up 5 Safeties
Newark Airport, Area's Oldest at 45, Facing a Rebirth
description: NEWARK, June 30Newark Airport, the New York area's first commercial airport when it opened 45 years ago, will have something of a rebirth a month from now.

title: Defense Unit and State Push End of Pollution by Military
description: TRENTON  New Jersey environmental officials and the Department of Defense are negotiating to end pollution of the state's waters by sewage discharges from nine military installations.

title: AMEN II, $51 VICTOR IN CINEMA HANDICAP
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 30 (AP)Amen II, a 241 choice, led a trio of longshots into the money today and won the $86,100 Cinema Handicap for 3yearolds at Hollywood Park.

title: Two sides of a modern disaster
description: Far from defiant crowds chanting Hell, no! We won't go! and equally far from bright recruitment posters and manly patriotic urgings, it was in the still, uneasy backwaters of individual minds that the decision formed: to go, or not to go, to Vietnam. That is one revelation of these two very different books. Neither James Strahs nor Tim O'Brien thought the war was right, or wanted to fight it. That Strahs wound up fleeing the draft through a haze of England, Spain, India and Canada, while O'Brien succumbed to it and fought in the terrifying minesown paddies of Pinkville, had by both men's accounts almost nothing to do with principle.

title: News Summary and Index
Ann Miller Is Married
description: PORTOLA VALLEY, Calif., June 30Miss Ann Elizabeth Miller, daughter of Arjay Miller, dean of the Stanford Graduate School of Business, and of Mrs. Miller of Woodside, was married here this morning to James Howard Olstad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Olstad of Cashton, Wis. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gerard Brennan of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Dearborn, Mich. The bride's father is a former president of the Ford Motor Company in Detroit.

title: Anker and Local School Boards Begin New Roles
description: The 288 recently elected members of the city's 32 community school boards will take office today, beginning a new chapter in the threeyear history of school decentralization here.

title: For people who have everything: more knowledge and less consensus
description: Contemporary industrial society is opaque, almost formless. Its main currents are contradictory, its changes often bewildering. It is ap... propriate that a book that claims to depict a new historical situation should have large elements of ambiguity, even confusion. This, however, is not just another book. Its author is an intellectual's intellectual, as influential amongst the scholars and the more sophisticated in public affairs and business as his Harvard colleague, John Kenneth Galbraith, or his ideological antagonist, Herbert Marcuse. When Daniel Bell declares that society has changed, it does not follow that it has done so. But it does follow that people will think it has.

title: The man of Cries and Whispers
Ellen Cohen and David F.Steitt To Be Married in September
description: Miss Ellen Gail Cohen plans to be married in September to David F. Stein, whose father was a corecipient last year of the Nobel Prize in chemistry.

title: Morales Declared Winner Of Garden Mat Exhibition
description: The world wide wresting federation heavyweight champion, Pedro Morales, was declared the winner after George (The Animal) Steele suffered a deep cut on the forehead in their exhibition match last night at Madison Square Garden before 20,987 fans.

title: G.O.P. Is Optimistic on Caso
description: MINEOLA, L. I.The newest candidate for the post of Nassau County Executive is not causing the county Republican party any anxious moments.

title: Two Sides in Northern Ireland May Share Power in Wake of the Election
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 30Despite some discouraging factors there is now chance that representatives of Northern Ireland's Protestant and Roman Catholic communities will agree to share political power for the first time in the modern history of the British province.

title: Rare Eclipse Sweeps Across Width of Africa
description: ABOARD THE CANBERRA, in the Atlantic off Mauritania, June 30Today in one of the longest eclipses of modern times the moon's shadow swept across the entire width of Africa. Scientists on this ship off the African coast and elsewhere along its path worked frantically to record the event, and on the mainland native populations gazed aloft in wonder and, perhaps in some cases, trepidation.

title: Do We Really Know What Baroque Music Is?; Music
description: IF you want to provoke what sounds like a 3 A.M. catfight, try locking a dozen baroque music specialists in a room to argue over what baroque music is, how it should be performed, and on what instruments. Roughly, and that probably would be the right word, the assembled scholars and performers might agree that the historical boundaries could be drawn so as to cover much European music composed from the beginning of the 17th century to the middle of the 18th century. After that, however, areas of agreement would be discover.

title: Blacks (All Two) Thrive as Commercial Brokers
description: Four years ago, Harold Robinson was an accountant with Cross & Brown Company, one of the city's larger commercial real estate brokers.

title: Hanoi Reports a Drought Is Serious'in 5 Provinces
description: HONG KONG, June 30 (AP)A severe drought has affected parts of North Vietnam and the crop condition is very serious to critical in five provinces southof Hanoi, North Vietnam's Communist party newspaper has retorted.

title: Truce Unit Officers to Guide Hunt for 2 Missing Canadians
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 (UPI)Leaders of the International Commission of Control and Supervision agreed today to send highranking military officials to coordinate the search for the two missing Canadian peaceteam members believed detained by the Vietcong.

title: Radio
2 Sections In Brooklyn To Get Aid In Housing
description: The Crown Heights and Bushwick sections of Brooklyn are among five neighborhoods in the city proposed for inclusion in a new city program designed to save housing in socalled transitional neighborhoods.

title: Crafts Fair Is Set For Peters Valley
description: PETERS VALLEYCraftsmen will exhibit their wares and demonstrate for the public at the Peters Valley Craft Fair on July 28 and 29.

title: Air Force Academy Concedes Injuries at Mock P.O.W. Camp
description: DENVER, June 30The United States Air Force Academy, seeking $244,000 to build a new mock prisonerofwar camp, acknowledged yesterday that 15 cadets were hospitalized in 1971 while attending the present camp.

title: Paterson's Fleet Honors Sub Inventor
description: PATERSON  Not many cities, even those on the ocean, own a submarine. But inland Paterson, a dozen miles from the nearest navigable salt water, boasts two. Both are historic and both are on public display.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The formidable outer coverings of certain delectable natural foods, among them the quahog, or hardshelled clam, and the oyster, defy the clumsy thrusts of the novice harvester who, in desperation, often attacks them with a hammer or a tire iron.

title: IRISH DERBY GOES TO WEAVER'S HE
description: DUBLIN, June 30 (AP)Weaver's Hall, a 33.1 shot, charged through the straightaway today and won the Irish Derby by VA lengths at The Curragh today, rewarding those holding sweepstakes tickets on him with $125,000 apiece. Ragapan, 72, was second to the Irishowned colt, while Bouy, 4.1, finished third, 1 lengths farther back.

title: Soviet Opens Rail Ferry
description: MOSCOW, June 30The Soviet Union has announced the inauguration of a railroad ferry in the Far East between the Siberian mainland and the island of Sakhalin.

title: the traveler's world
description: GREEN BANK. W. Va.Deer Creek Valley in West Virginia is fresh, green upland plateau completely encircled by high Allegheny Mountain peaks, about 25 mileswest of the border with, Virginia and only a short whoop and holler from the upper reaches of the Greenbrier River. ?? settlers of the territory, toiling actress the Blue Ridge of Virginia and then up the eastern face of the Alleghenies, must have been delighted when they broke out into the valley, recognizing that the solid ring of mountains would shelter them against intruders and weather. They dipped into their AngloSaxon vocabulary to call their settlement Green Bankgreen for the foliage, bank either for the rampart of mountains that encircled them or for the high location of their upthrust valley.

title: SHOW AWARD WON BY BELLE HEATHER
Sarafan to Head State Racing Board
description: Lacking agreement among the state's racing interests on the appointment of a chairman to the new State Racing and Wagering Board, Governor Rockefeller yesterday selected Bertram D. Sarafan, a longtime friend, to fill the post on an interim basis.

title: With a View Toward Assessing the Facts
description: BORDEAUX, FranceThe phenomenal development of the mass media has revolutionized politics. Not simply because propaganda and biased news can be so simply and widely disseminated, but by the very fact of the availability of so much information. Every day, via radio, TV and print the citizen is flooded with, thousands of messages. (We will not complicate the argument by trying to figure out the differences in the ways the three media affect us.) Thus, we have to realize that the individual retains only a small proportion of these messages. European analysts have found that the average newspaper reader retains about 10 per cent of the, political news he reads. That is. probably, fortunate; if he remembered it all, he would go

title: Criminals At Large
description: Joyce Porter is not the only British writer who features wacky Scotland Yard detectives. If you respond to her Inspector Dover series, then take a look at A FILE ON DEATH by Kenneth Giles (Walker, $5.95). Here, too, is another pair of Scotland Yard operatives, Chief Inspector Harry James and Sergeant Honeybody. Honeybody is awfully close to Porter's Inspector Doverbut there is all the difference between the Giles and the Porter books.

title: Deborah Macy Becomes Bride
description: MENDHAM, N. J., June 30 Miss Deborah Wright Macy, daughter of Mrs. Josiah Macy Jr. of Morristown and the late Mr. Macy, was married here this afternoon to Francis Pelzer Maybank, son of Mrs. G. Kirkwood King and Joseph Maybank Jr., both of Charleston, S. C. The Rev. Charles Ring, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Phillip Watters.

title: Airline Fares in a Holding Pattern
description: Monday, Aug. 13, is a date heavily circled an many a Corporate calendar  particularly in the offices of major United States airlines. That's the day President Nixon's current price freeze expires, and the nation's air carriers are likely to be early in line seeking a rise in passenger fares.

title: Shirley Sparks Engaged
description: BEDFORD, Mass., June 30 Miss Shirley Lillian Sparks, a registered nurse at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, plans to be married in September to Dr. Peter Denes Kent, a resident in surgery there. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Earl C. Sparks Jr. of Belford and Green Hill, R. I, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs, Eugene Kent of Bayside, Queens, New York.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: DOES anyone remember Katharine Hepburn as Jo? Why is it that in recent years, when writers such as Stephanie Harrington in Does Little Women Belittle Women? (June 10) mention the film, Little Women, it is always the JuneAllysonasJo version?

title: Picnic pickeruppers
Jazz Ferry Launched With a Toot Suite
description: Jazz on a Staten Island ferry, originated last summer by the Newport Jazz Festival, will be a weekly event this summer. The first of 15 weekly jazz cruises on the ferry John F. Kennedy took off from South Ferry on Wednesday evening and carried 1,000 paying customers up the Hudson to the George Washington Bridge, returning at 11 P.M.

title: A young man pursued by demons
description: Clarence Major and Ishmael Reed are the mavericks of the new black poetry. They do not simplify their poems to make them easily accessible to the people. Nor do they simplify their novels. No, Major's second novel, is not an easy book. It makes one wonder where he will find readers for this brave but often confusing work. It is also surprising that a new black publisher struggling for survival should choose to publish so esoteric a book.

title: Trumpeter First to Finish Newport to Bermuda Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 30 (AP) The 40foot trimaran Trumpeter, owned and piloted by the newspaper publisher Philip Weld of Gloucester, Mass., was the first craft to ) finish toddy in the fourth biers nial NewportBermuda multihull race.

title: The Great Spitball Controversy
description: According to a secret report leaked to The Times, Gaylord Jackson Perry, the Cleveland operative, threw 30 spitballs against the New York Yankees Friday night.

title: Travel Notes: If You're Ill Abroad...
Imports, the Lifeblood of Japan
description: TOKYO  After years of mounting successful export drives, Japan is on the verge of adopting a major new import strategy intended to assure the nation of reliable sources of vital supplies.

title: To William Inge: An Homage
description: IT was sometime late last winter when Barbara Baxley, a friend and brilliant performer in two of my plays, called me to tell me that William Inge, with whom she had once had a tender romance, and to whom he was probably closer than almost anyone else outside his family, had, fallen into a desperate situation.

title: Volunteer Youths For Aged Sought
description: NEW SHREWSBURYYoung volunteer drivers and assistants are being sought to help the elderly and ill this summer in what is known as the Mobile Meal Program. The volunteers are needed to substitute for young mothers and other winter workers who are now involved with their children and seasonal family obligations.

title: The Livestock Population Explosion
description: CHICAGOMuch has been said of the world population explosion and the concomitant rise in the demand for protein. What is now becoming apparent is that the craving for protein has resulted in an exploding world livestock population that is competing with the human race for foodstuffs, particularly grains and soybeans.

title: Five Shows to Mark Weekend As Season Goes Into Full Cry
Scalpers at Wimbledon Enjoying a Field Day
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 (Reuters)Scalpers today described this year's Wimbledon tennis championships as the most profitable.

title: Pop
description: WOODY HERMAN is an incredible man, a dedicated and enthusiastic jazz artist who refuses to grow old. Indeed, such is the chemistry between the durable Milwaukee maestro and young talent chat overy few years he emeages with a polished, pulsating, powerhouse big band recruited from conservatory classrooms and college lab and stage bands.

title: Three Masked Men Attack and Terrorize a Bronxville Stockbroker and His Wife in Attempted Robbery
description: Three masked men, one armed with a pistol, attacked New York stockbroker and his wife in their Bronxville mansion early yesterday in an abortive robbery that the victims said was reminiscent of the terrorization in the movie A Clockwork Orange.

title: MACKINAC COLLEGE LEASED AS RESORT
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., June 30Mackinac College, wholly owned subsidiary of the Rev. Rex Humbard's Cathedral of Tomorrow, has signed lease and management agreement with Ski and Shore Properties, Inc., of Charlevoix, Mich., to operate its facilities here on the island as a hotel and resort complex.

title: SMUT MAKERS CALL BUSINESS VIABLE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 30In the major pornography producing centers of Los Angeles and San Francisco, the Supreme Court's latest ruling on obscenity was met this week with concern and anger but also with the promise that the business was not dead.

title: BINGHAMTON AWARD CAPTURED BY CARINA
Dave Anderson
description: At this point in time, the Nixon Administration has fumbled, its football credibility, too.

title: Nixon on Radio Today Will Discuss Economy
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 30 (Reuters)President Nixon will discuss the state of the United States economy in a radio speech to the American people tomorrow, the Western White House announced today.

title: Special Tourism Unit Named
description: ALBANY June 30 (UPI)Governor Rockefeller today appointed an interdepartmental committee to give top priority to promoting the nation's 200th anniversary in the overseas vacation market. The committee will be headed by the state's Commerce Commissioner, Neal L. Moylan.

title: Nancy C. Vallentine Wed to Accountant
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 30Miss Nancy Constance Vallentine and Edward L. Sinclair Jr. were married here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church by IS Rev. Jon Freeberg.

title: Miss Mary Schaff Married in Illinois
description: WINNETKA, Ill., June 30 Miss Mary Gladding Schaff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Haynes Schaff Jr., was married here this evening to Winfield Newton Burdick 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Newton Burdick Jr. of Northfield. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence E. Schwarz performed the ceremony in the Winnetka Congregational Church.

title: Dr. Isadore Snapper, 84, Dies; Educator, Researcher, Lecturer
description: Dr. Isadore Snapper, medical researcher and diagnostician, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 4 Park Avenue.

title: They Still Come to Coney to Forget
description: Arriving in Coney Island by subway these days you can catch a fleeting glimpse of the Cyclone and Wonder Wheel in the open spaces between highrise apartment buildings. Once this view was panoramic, and these two giants silhouetted against the sky dwarfed everything around them.

title: Letters: It Looks Like A Sugar Loaf, You Oaf
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Candace Waters, Michaal Schuller Marry in Maine
description: SOUTHWEST HARBOR, Me., June 30In the Mount Desert Congiegational Church here this afternoon, Miss Candace Waters and Michael Cal. laway Schuller were married by the Rev. Kenneth C. Brookes and the Right Rev. Frederic C. Lawrence, retired Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts and the bridegroom's greatuncle.

title: You Have to Be Forgotten to Be Rediscovered
description: THAT consoling old adage which claims that art is long and life, comparatively, is brief seems to be confirmed by two recent exhibitions. The first is a retrospective show of paintings, watercolors and drawings by a rediscovered 19thcentury American painter, William Trost Richards at the Brooklyn Museum through July 29.

title: News of the Camera World
description: RESPONDING to the steadily increasing demand for XLtype movie cameras which can take indoor pictures under available light conditions (without need for floodlights), at least two more manufacturers have recently introduced Super 8 cameras with this capabilityparticularly when used with the. newer high speed films such as Kodak's ASA 160.

title: Mrs. Barbara D. Bedford Affianced
description: MIAMI, June 30  Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Dahl have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Barbara Dahl Bedford, to John William Jacobs, son of Mrs. Hirsch Jacobs of Forest Hills, Queens, New York, and Miami Beach.

title: Red Leaves
description: To the Editor:

title: Anderson: We Have to Make Our Own Acts of Courage
description: WHEN a hotshot moviemaker from abroad visits Hollywood he naturally makes it a point to meet the People in Power So who is it that Lindsay Anderson, the British director of This Sporting Life and If..., trembles with joy at the thought of meeting? James Aubrey? Joe Levine? Ross Hunter? Rona Barrett?

title: The opposite of soup is nuts; Opposites; Written and illustrated by Richard Wilbur. 39 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $3.75. (Ages 8 to 12)
description: It's enchanting to think of a dinner table, such as Richard Wilbur's, where a game called Opposites is played; but a great deal more fortunate for all of us that this game has been winnowed, culled and preserved in a book called Opposites, complete with the poet's amusing drawings.

title: General Disturbed By Aerospace Gap
description: One of the nation's foremost experts on research and development, retiring after a 33year military career, had some disturbing things to say fast week about the future of the aerospace industry and the way weapon systems are produced.

title: Transportation News Page 13 In the Sports Section Today
AIKEN, $7.60, WINS TROT AT YONKERS
NASTASE IS UPSET BY MAYER OF U.S.,
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 30Incredibly, Ilie Nastase has been beaten at Wimbledon.

title: Nastase's Conqueror Finds Time for Tennis and Study_
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 (Reuters)  Alex (Sandy) Mayer, the 21yearold New Jerseyan who upset Ilie Nastase of Rumania in the Wimbledon tennis champipnships today, is, a cool young man and one of the few amateurs, playing the bigtime circuit.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH selfadhesive vinyl materials (those with a pressuresensitive adhesive on the back) are by no means new, most people are only familiar with the well known brands of light gauge 18inchwide material that practically every hardware and houseware store carries in stock.

title: Walk Mile for Health Day Is Saluted by the President
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif:, June 30 (AP)President Nixon, who came out recently for slower car driving, also put his personal. Stamp of approval on observa tion of Walk A Mile for Health Day tomorrow.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: A couple of weeks ago, asked our research department to do a quick and rough study to see if I could prove a point. I wanted to find out what advertising campaigns came to people's minds on an unaided basis.

title: Today's Jazz
description: Following is a schedule of today's events in the Newport Jazz Festival  New York:

title: Elmer Layden Dead
description: CHICAGO, June 30 (UPI)Elmer Layden, the 160pound fullback in the storied 1924 Four Horsemen backfield at the University of Notre Dame and former commissioner of the National Football League, died this evening at a hospital here. He was 70 years old.

title: Summit Perspective
description: Rhetorically, the cold war seems to be over. President Nixon and General Secretary Brezhnev used every verbal device in their power not only to demonstrate their mutual personal regard but also to strengthen SovietAmerican cooperation and friendship. A Martian visitor would never have guessed that Richard M. Nixon built his political ladder to the White House on the strength of his antiCommunism or that Leonid I. Brezhnev has publicly denounced predatory American imperialism on innumerable occasions in the past.

title: A tacky world from top to bottom
description: Why was the war legal but certain kinds of massage illegal? asks an unlikely political assassin in this comedy of urban desperation. Why can we afford, morally, the guns of official violence and not the butter of private carnality? If it is all right for governments to act out their illicit fantasies, why shouldn't ordinary people? In other words, what would happen if people's dreams came true, if wishing would make it so? Mark Harris gives a superficially wacky answer to this question in a highly plotted story about 24 hours in the lives of several ordinary people who attain their extraordinary suppressed desires.

title: Photography
Chess: The BoldPlaying Taimanov Conies Out Swinging Again
Elizabeth Johnson Has Nuptials
description: ALPINE, N. J., June 30In the Alpine Church this afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Townsend Johnson became the bride of Edward Padelford Taft. The Rev. Nelson Bennett of the Methodist Church in Mendham, performed the ceremony. There was a reception at the Englewood Field Club.

title: Winning Compromise
description: Employing its ultimate weaponthe power of the pursewith extraordinary determination, Congress has extracted concessions from the President that substantially restore its eroded constitutional role in the warmaking process as well as contributing to the prospects for ultimate peace in Indochina.

title: Son Born to Mrs. Meyer
description: A son was born June 4 to Mr, and Mrs, Edward Meyer of Scarsdale, N. Y., in Doctors Hospital, Mrs. Meyer is the former Miss Elizhaheth Barnett., Her husband is a groupproduct manager for the BristolMyers Company. The child has been named Andrew Douglas.

title: The Unnatural History of the Nanny
description: Eli de Rothschild once remarked that when he was in a German concentration camp he could tell at glance which of the Frenchmen there had been brought up by an English nanny. They sat calmly, their bed spaces neat, their clothes folded. The selfdiscipline imposed by nanny morality, backed by maxims such as A place for everything, and everything in its place, was strong enough to maintain orderly habits, even in the most trying of circumstances. So the men sat still on their bunks, utterly prohibited by early training from improving survival odds by fighting for a better space or an extra blanket. Perhaps they were immobilized too by another nanny saying, the Catch22 of the nursery world: Those who ask don't get; those who don't ask don't The English upper classes have always been very good at getting rid of their children. Jonathan GathorneHardy, in his entertaining and original study of one of their more successful solutions to the problem of offspring, begins his history of the nanny with a brief survey of past AngloSaxon attitudes to childhood. In the 16th and 17th centuries, for example, child swapping was commonly practiced between households of equal social standing. At the age of six or seven the little, defective adult, sodden with original sin, in GathorneHardy's phrase, was dispatched to be socialized among strangers, rarely seeing his natural parents, for whom naturally enough he therefore felt no affection. The disadvantage of this system of childraising by remote control was that one had, often, in return, to harbor someone else's child. And there was still the awkward initial phase when the infant was generally thought too

title: The Region
description: After 23 years as the seemingly eternal controller and budget director, more accomplished with the slide rule than with the soapbox, Abraham D. Beanie emerged from the shadows of City Hall last week as a hot prospect to be New York's 105th Mayor.

title: Valerie Ives Mixter Planning Marriage to Carroll Cavanagh
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 30Mr. and Mrs. David M. Mixter have announced the engagement of Mrs. Mixter's daughter, Miss Valerie Ives Mixter, to Carroll J. Cavanagh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Cavanagh of East Norwalk.

title: New Jersry
description: ACTORS CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East Orange "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Aug. 4). $3.50$3.90; students, $2$2.90. (201) 675.1881.

title: Residents Of Suffolk Still Use Detergents
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L. .For the last two years, Mrs. Pat Harper, wife of private investigator and for??tier police detective, has been breaking the spirit of not the letter of the law. She has been doing it in the interest getting her family's wash

title: Verardi Is Seriously Injured In Spill at Calder Track
description: MIAMI, June 30 (AP)Frank Verardi was seriously injured today in the third race at Calder when his horse, Russian Steppes, clipped the heels of Turnip and fell on the first turn.

title: News of the Rialto
description: RAILERS against the meaninglessness of much of our contemporary musical theater may be able to take a rest next season. There's a musical on the way that promises adventure, comedy and theme of no little import: Can there be an end to war when there is so much violence lurking within ourselves? The musical is called Shenandoah and is based on the 1965 movie of the same name. If your memory needs a bit of jogging, it starred James Stewart as father caught in the tragic whirlpool of the Civil War.

title: Seeing the Sinai in a RollsRoyce
description: EILAT, IsraelIf you want to ride around the Sinai Desert in RollsRoyce, the same Sinai Desert where Moses traveled on foot for 40 years, see Al Womark in Eilat. You can't miss him, he's got the only RollsRoyce Phantom in Israel.

title: Tristate Officials Seek to Cope With Imminent Railroad Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The threatened shutdown of the Penn Central railroad and the Nixon Administration's proposed massive pruning of unprofitable passenger and freight service on five other bankrupt railroads serving New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, have mobilized the metropolitan area's transportation officials in an effort to forestall an economic blow to the region.

title: Malaysia, North Korea Link
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 30 (AP)Malaysia announced the establishment of diplomatic relations with North Korea today and said negotiations with China for similar ties had begun.

title: 9 Die as Storms Touch Off Floods in Northeast States
description: At least nine persons were reported dead, including five children in Pennsylvania and Vermont, in the aftermath of storm that slashed yesterday from Canada to the Carolinas, leaving behind a trail of flooded homes and streets.

title: Come On, and Bring the Kids
description: IN the nineteenthirties, little girls longed to be stars in movies like Shirley Temple. In the forties, they longed to be like Margaret O'Brien. In the seventies, little girls long to be on television, like Big Bird. The two daughters in our householdMaria, 6, and Catherine, 3, are no exception. They watch Sesame Street on TV daily they read Sesame Street books nightly; weekends, they and their Sesame Street puppets put on performances for neighbors and guests with the help of their father who is the ablest Cookie Monster on our block They are also given to inquiring regularly, Why can't we be on Sesame Street?".

title: Social Security Increase Is Approved by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Congress approved today a 5.6 per cent increase in Social Security benefits, effective next June 1, for some 30 million Americans. The legislators then began a weeklong Fourth of July recess.

title: Pipeline Bill Sponsored
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Twentyone members of the House Interior Committee cosponsored a bill yesterday to authorize the transAlaska oil pipeline. Representative John Melcher, Democrat of Montana, introduced the measure. He is chairman of a House Interior subcommittee handling Alaska pipeline legislation.

title: Skylab's Next Crew Will Stress Exercise
description: HOUSTON, June 30The second threeman Skylab crew said today they planned to exercise regularly during a 56day mission to guarantee that they will have no problems in readapting to earth's gravity.

title: Jean Katherine Baldridge to Wed
description: LAWRENCE, L.I., June 30 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Connell Baldridge have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Katherine Baldridge, to Benjamin Stephen Bilus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Bilus of Plainfield, N.J.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE DISCOUNT RATE was raised by the Federal Reserve Board from 6 per cent to 7 per cent, the highest since 1920. The board also raised reserve requirements to tighten credit further.... The Government embargoed exports of soybeans and cottonseed and the meals and oils extracted from them. The move caused wide concern Europe and Japan.... The University of Michigan's latest index of consumer sentiment has fallen 16 per cent since the end of 1972, but people indicated they would continue a high level of purchasing durable consumer goods.

title: N.E.A. Convention to Weigh Merger
description: PORTLAND, Ore., June 30Some 9,000 teachers gathered here today for a convention that will determine whether there will be any immediate movement toward the forging of a single, powerful organization for their profession nationwide.

title: London Paper Asserts C.I. A. Engineered the Coup in Greece
description: LONDON, Sunday, July 1The Observer said today that it has found evidence that the Central Intelligence Agency engineered the 1967 military coup in Greece and is using secret knowledge of Premier George Papadopoulos's wartime collaboration with the Nazis to maintain control of the regime.

title: Harness Race Hall of Fame To Enshrine Hodgins Today
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., June 30 (AP) A Canadian drivertrainer, Clint Hodgins, will become the 18th person to be installed in the United States Harness Writers Living Hall of Fame.

title: Guitar Explosion Attracts the Young
description: No guitars actually exploded at the Newport Jazz Festival's hyperbolically entitled Guitar Explosion concert yesterday afternoon at the Wollman Amphitheater in Central Park. But it was still a pleasant affair, both in itself and.as an indication of the variety of sounds a guitar can produce and the variety of styles in which it can be played.

title: The Second Crash
description: On Sept. 11, 1970, the Wall Street brokerage house of Hayden, Stone did not collapse. And so it did not take down with it Wall Street's other major firms, or precipitate the quick loss of hundreds of.millions of investment dollars, or throw major corporations into bankruptcy and put those of us who do not play money games out into the street to queue up for bread. The Second Crash did not happen. But Charles D. Ellis's account of how it might have is worth reading if only to discover how close to calamity we came on that September day.

title: Toros Defeat Cosmos, 2.1, In Soccer League Game
Bridge
description: The laws of bridge impose a curious double standard on its devotees. On the one hand players are expected to dismiss from their minds all information they may derive from hesitations, intonations and mannerisms of their partners, setting a high ethical standard that some players of world class unfortunately fail to achieve.

title: YOUNG GET FARMS IN SASKATCHEWAN Province Eases Purchases to Keep Them on Land
description: REGINA, Saskatchewan, June 16Other regions may be engulfed by problems of population explosion and urban sprawl. But the province of Saskatchewan in the heartland of the Canadian prairies is different.

title: This Week's Maxim: Safety Is No Accident
description: Safe Boating Is No Accidentthat was last year's slogan for National Safe Boating Week. This year, buoyed, but not complacent, over the marked reduction in the number of boating.fatalities recorded in 1972, boating officials have planned a vigorous campaign for the week, which starts today and lasts through next Saturday. They're using the same slogan.

title: Fighting Is Also Raging Close to the No. 2 City
description: KOMPONG SPEU, Cambodia, June 30Strong rebel forces began an offensive today, driving close to this provincial capital and engaging GoVernment troops at half a dozen other places around Phnom Penh.

title: Pornography: The moral question is nonsense
description: The new popularityand profitabilityof hardcore sex on page and film has resulted during the past, year in legal hassles over movies like Deep Throat and now in a Supreme Court decision designed to give local prosecutors a freer hand in protecting us from the obscene and the pornographic. I wish I knew why.

title: Red Sox Rained Out Again
description: BOSTON, June 30 (AP)The Milwaukee Brewers and the Boston Red Sox were washed out of a scheduled game for the second time within 24 hours today by a steady rain that imIndatecl Fcriwny Park,

title: Ireland's LongTerm Hope
description: DUBLINAt no point in the past five years (since the latest North Ireland troubles erupted) has public sympathy for the I.R.A. been at such a low ebb in the Republic nor has hostility. toward it among the vast majority been so intense.

title: Hospital Expanding Heart Center
description: ROSYLN, L. I.  A small hospital here that pioneered open heart surgery more than a decade ago will open a new $10million facility this week.

title: L. H. McKeon Weds Miss Twichell
description: KENSINGTON, Conn., June 30  Miss Barbara Stow Twichell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Stow Twichell was married here this afternoon to Lewis Herndon McKeon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton Felch McKeon of Conway, Mass., in the garden of her parents home.

title: The Nation
description: CHICAGODoors crumbling under the weight of policemen. Unkempt officers, some fresh from stops at local bars, ransacking homes, breaking furniture and shouting obscenities while holding terrified families at gunpoint.

title: Matthau Has A Secret
description: WALTER MATTHAU can be ferociously funny fellow Yet his new funny sounding movie, The Laughing Policeman, is said to be a serious drama, and his next film will be far from laughing matter. It's called The Whitewash Conspiracy, and it will focus on the assassination of a future President of the United States. England's Peter Smalley has written the original screenplay, Hugh Hudson will direct, and Jud Kinberg will produce for Paramount.

title: State Supervises Parachute Jumping
description: ALBANY, June 30Add to the modes of transportation supervised by the State Department of Transportation something new  parachute jumping for fun.

title: Mrs. Carol Strauss Bride of Accountant
description: ST. PAUL, June 30Mrs. Carol Blessing Strauss of White Bear Lake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs.Henry A. Blessing of Rock Island, Ill., was married here this afternoon to William H. McGaughey Jr. of Minneapolis. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McGaughey of New York, Milford, Pa., and of Washington.

title: Rodeo Cuts College Pro Gap
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., June 30The national intercollegiate rodeo final. held last week at Montana State University, proved that the breach between the college and professional levels may be narrower in rodeo than in any other sport.

title: Cyclists Celebrate 100th Year of Prospect Park
description: Fifty celebrants on bicycles turned out one evening last week to honor the 100th anniversary of the completion of Prospect Park. But the park, they learned, had never been completed.

title: God, Please Release the Sun!
description: AKJOUJT, Mauritania, June 30Tourists cheered and applauded when total darkness engulfed the desert here this morning but the black African and Arab nomads faced the east and chanted, Allah, Allah, Allah, Tlass esshems, or God, God, God, please release the sun.

title: I.R.S. Bolsters Its Local Staff As Price Checks Enter Stage 2
description: The Internal Revenue Service this week will double the force working in the New York area on the economicstabilization program as the agency's priceceiling operation enters its second phasechecking the legality of current prices.

title: Jersey Is Home To Teddy Wilson
description: HILLSDALE  Teddy Wilson is a fulltime Jerseyan these days, for the famous jazz pianist is both residing and working in the state.

title: Linda's Chief Beats 3 Saranac Rivals
description: Linda's Chief was the big star in the main race at Aqueduct yesterday, the $55,250 Saranac. Neil Hellman's speedy sprinter demonstrated that the mile distance was exactly to his liking and he romped to a 3length triumph over the Hobeau Farm's Step Nicely.

title: Weekend WarriorsPut Shoulders to the Wheel
description: Every so often it helps to remember that not all of motor racing consists of superstars like Mark Donohue and Richard Petty running on superspeedways like Indianapolis and Daytona. The lesser guys and tracks form the base of the racing pyramid, and they genuinely earn their claim to public support. The current cases in point are two programs for weekend warriors next Friday and Saturday at Lime Rock, Conn., and on July 14 and 15 at Pocono International Raceway in Pennsylvania. Both programs are classified as nationals of the Sports Car Club of America  usually 10 races of 30 minutes each  and both will have fields of about 250 entries.

title: Betty Brody Married To Steven R. Poliakoff
description: SUMTER, S. C., June 30At Temple Sinai here tonight, Miss Betty Susan Brody, who expects to graduate in December from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, was married to Steven Raymond Poliakoff, a graduate of Cornell University and a medical student at North Carolina. Rabbi A. Magidovich performed the ceremony.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Long Island Lighting Company announced yesterday that it would purchase a 525acre tract on Long Island Sound north of Jamesport, L. I., as a possible site for a nuclear generating plant. The property, owned by the CurtissWright Company, includes 498 acres in the town Riverhead, zoned for industrial use, and 27 acres in the town of Southold, zoned for farminng purposes.

title: FRITZ ROTHENSTEIN
description: Fritz Rothenstein, executive vice president and a director of the Globe Shipping Company, died Friday night at his home. He was 77 years old and lived at 80 Central Park West. He leaves his wife, Cecilia.

title: AIRPORT SECURITY REMAINS AN ISSUE
description: A tug of war between the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor and the airline industry over cargo security at the three metropolitan area jetports was stalled last week when a court in Newark held a case between them in abeyance until September.

title: SHOP TALK
description: DENVILLEThe stores in Denbrook Village, the small, smart shopping center that opened here last January, provide the unhurried, friendly services that only owneroperated establishments seem able to give.

title: The New Movies
description: A TOUCH OF CLASS, directed by Melvin Frank, got 8 favorable reviews (Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; Judith Crist, New York; William Wolf, Cue), 4 mixed (Vincent Canby, Times; Rex Reed, News; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Penelope Gilliatt, New Yorker) and 2 negative (Joseph Gelmis, Newsday Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service).

title: Russian Recalls Wartime Rescue of 2 U.S. Airmen
description: MOSCOW, June 30Where are you, Dick and Charles? A Russian wants to know, now that it is apparently safe again to talk about SovietAmerican friendship.

title: Music Mailbag; John Wayne Is Relevant (And So Is Julie Andrews)
description: To THE EDITOR:JACK HIEMENZ'S review of John Wayne's America, Why I Love Her album (June 17) told me nothing about John Wayne and his admittedly oversimplified version of the American Dream I didn't already know; it did, however, reveal Mr. Hiemenz as an ideologue every bit as narrow and Pavlovian on the Liberal side of the ledger as he accuses Mr. Wayne of being on the Conservative side.

title: School Is Out but Ouster of Principal Remains an Issue
description: Summer vacation began last week for the city's public school students, but parents in Brooklyn's District 14 are determined not to let their anger over the ouster of a black acting principal fade with the school year.

title: REPORT ASSESSES MUNICIPAL UNIONS
description: The Economic Development Council of New York says unions of municipal employes here are so strong, city officials are finding it easier to accede to union demands than to oppose them and face the dangers of work stoppages, adverse political feedbacks from the indignant general citizenry, and electoral retaliation by public employes and their supporters.

title: Gov. Reagan Sets Nov. 6 Election On Plan to Limit State Spending
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 30Gov. Ronald Reagan this week set Nov. 6 as the date for a statewide vote on an amendment to the California constitution that he has proposed as a means of controlling state spending.

title: And Now Death in Venice Sings
description: BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S new opera, Death in Venice, which had its premiere at the Aldeburgh Festival on June 16, is one of the most taxing assignments the composer has ever set himself. The vulgar simplification that Luchino Visconti in his film imposed on Thomas Mann's wonderfully subtle and manylayered story is not calculated to appeal to a man of Britten's acute literary perception and, in fact, he had not seen the film at the time he composed the score. His Death in Venice is in no sense the opera of the film. It is an ambitious and accomplished attempt to embody in music book that is in itself a masterpiece. Whether this scrupulousness of intent makes the result a successful or even effective is another matter.

title: BRITISH RACE WON BY NORTHEASTERN
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 30 (AP)Northeastern University came out tin top in a spirited battle among leading United States areWS in an international rowing regatta today. But a formidable Soviet contingent took the major prize of the day.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE extraordinary move by the Federal Government to control exports of two of the country's major farm products was designed to control prices without actually controlling themby blocking off the growing demand from abroad and thus increasing the supply available for consumption at home.

title: BOCES to Discuss 2 Rejected Centers
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I.  Stung by the overwhelming rejection of its plan to build two occupational and special education centers in eastern Suffolk, the Board of Cooperative Educational Services will meet shortly to decide whether to resubmit the propO:,a1 to voters.

title: Soldier Fiance Of Julia Gettys
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Miss Julia Martin Gettys, daughter of Representative Thomas S. Gettys and Mrs. Gettys of Rock Hill, S.C., and Washington, plans to be married July 28 to Pvt. Bruce Myatt Burchett, who is serving with the Army Judge Advocate General's office at Fort Meade, Md. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman G. Burchett of Durham, N.C. The ceremony is planned for the First Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church in Rock Hill.

title: Lag in a Volunteer Force Spurs Talk of New Draft
description: WASHINGTON, June 30One of the boldest policy and political gambles of the Nixon Presidency  the abandonment of the draft and total reliance on young civilian volunteers for a nearly 3millionman military forceis six months old today. And it is in trouble.

title: New Ship Symbolizes Hopes for the Old Navy Yard
description: The christening yesterday in the Brooklyn Navy Yard of the largest merchant ship ever built in the United States, the 230,000ton tanker Brooklyn, was overshadowed by the announcement on Friday that 22 acres of the Navy Yard would be rebuilt into, a $35million industrial park.

title: Watergate
Performers Bring Series to Hampton
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.In the last seven years Albert Sharp has visited Europe more frequently than he has New York City. But like many other former city residents who have settled in exurbia, Mr. Sharp, a painter, misses some aspects of city life that country living does not usually provide.

title: Arthur Daley
description: At a Much faster rate than had been believed possible, Henry Aaron keeps drawjug ever closer to the once sacred and supposedly untouchable Babe Ruth home run record of 714. Although the majority of the more koowledgeable calculators had project a target date of late June or early lily, next year as the likeliest time for Henry to complete his moonshot, a revised: schedule is now imperative. Since he is levier than two dozen short Of the magic mark at this point tit the season, it is conceivable that he Couldmake it late this year or within the first month of the 1974 season.

title: Bad Start Foils Bid for Record
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., June 30"Here he comes, they murmured as Secretariat stepped calmly into the paddock along a tawdry carpet of green concrete.

title: An Isle of Funkiness in a Plastic Sea
description: CHALET SUZANNE, an inn and restaurant near the geographical center of Florida, is the kind of place a traveler might come upon accidentally if he got lost after a wrong turn off the Sunshine State Parkway a few miles north of Lake Wales; Or, conceivably, he might come upon it intentionally if he had spotted Chalet Suzanne soups on a gourmet food counter and decided to trace them to then; source. In either case, he would find himself wandering among pink, green, yellow and orchid Spires, steeples, sharpgabled roofs, courts, balconies and moonfaced clock tower and wondering whether the Florida sun had finally got him,

title: Daughter to Mrs. Berman
description: A daughter was born June 6 at University Hospital here to Mr. and Mrs. Martin M. Berman of New York. The child has been named Kimberly Miriam. Mrs. Berman is the former Miss Elyse Dee Melnikoff. Mr. Berman is the Emmy Awardwinning producer of the WABCTV News specials Willowbrook and Migrants: Dirt Cheap.

title: Largest Offshore Oil Tank Reaches Destination in North Sea
description: The world's largest offshore oil storage tank, an oval concrete box with a capacity of a million barrels, has reached its destination, the Ekofisk oil field in the North Sea.

title: Is the NaturalGas Industry Competitive?; Congress Questions Contention That It Is
description: WASHINGTON  Is the naturalgas producing industry essentially competitive or noncompetitive?

title: Vietnamese Practice Rinksmanship
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30The South Vietnamese have taken up roller skating.

title: Education
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court, which had raised the hopes of conservatives days before with, its crackdown on obscenity, sent them plummeting again last week by cutting off the most recent attempts to rescue private schools rith public funds.

title: The Life of Ivy ComptonBurnett
description: In one of Ivy ComptonBurnett's novels, a burial service is conducted by some children: O dear people, we are gathered together. Dearly Beloved Brethren. Let us pray. Ashes and Ashes. Dust and Dust. This our brother. Poor little mole! Until he rise again. Prayers of the congregation. Amen. Elizabeth Sprigge's The Life of Ivy Compton Burnett bears the same relation to a biography that this quotation bears to the Prayer Book burial service. The children's effort is, however, a shade more forgivable, since the subject is a mole and the speaker is 3 years old.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
Headliners
description: As Representative Otis C. Pike of Suffolk County pointed out, it was the first time in more than a decade that the House Armed Services Committee, working in tandem with the military, had lost an issue on the House floor. The issue: flight pay for 5,000 deskbound officers of colonel rank or above. Under a law passed last year, such pay$245 month for a colonel and navy captain and $165 for a general or admiralwas banned effective June 1. Buffeted by heavy lobbying, the Senate and the Armed Services Committee voted a postponement until Jan. 1. But Representatives Pike and Les Aspin of Wisconsin convinced the Hous'e to reverse the committee's decision. Much of the credit was given Mr. Pike's satiric plea describing the dangers of flying desk: If the IN basket is continually loaded on the starboard, or righthand, side of the desk, and the OUT basket is continually empty on the port, or left hand, side of the desk, wood fatigue sets in, the landing gear tends to buckle and the whole fuselage crashes down on your feet.

title: William Peltz, Neville Bryan Marry Upstate
description: PAWLING, N.Y., June 30Miss Neville Johanna Farquharson Bryan was married in Christ Church here this afternoon to William Hun Peltz. Rev. William Glenesk, pastor of the Village Presbyterian Church in New York, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Ralph Lankier of Christ Church.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: First FreshAirFund Campers Arrive and Hope for Lot of Fun
description: FISHKILL, N.Y., June 30Gregory Jones, a studiouslooking 12yearold who was reading about the Mets, put down his newspaper to explain why he was going to camp.

title: Janet Bush Fiancee Of Dr. Irwin Light
description: FREEPORT, L I., June 30 Miss Janet Leslie Bush, executive assistant in the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, plans to be married July 15 to Dr. Irwin Joseph Light, professor of pediatrics, obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.

title: Liza's place
Tennessee Five Opener
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 30 (AP)Tennessee will open its basketball, season. Nov. 30 against North Texas State, then play four more home games before going on the road, Athletic Director Bob Woadruff announced today.

title: He Keeps Riding for a Dream
description: Until a few months ago, W. Dennis Murphy never thought he would see the Gladstone, N.J., headquarters of the United States Equestrian Team.

title: Seeking to Serve Term, Man Finds Jail Door Shut
description: For the third time yesterday, 30yearold Elemir Missig tried to begin serving a sentence in the Queens House of Detention but was refused admission by the Department of Correction.

title: Football Cometh Before the Fall
description: The first National Football League training camp will open. Sattirday when the New England Patriots will accept 67 alleged players at their University of DIIassachusetts camp in Amherst, Mass.

title: Student Weds Helen Halpin
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 30Miss Helen Ann Halpin, who graduated last month from Skidmore College with honors in biology and chemistry, was married here this afternoon to Frederick Keyes Schauffler, who graduated last month from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. The Rev. Grant Morrill performed the Episcopal ceremony ,at St. Bede's Chapel.

title: Bizarre invention, a translation without an original
description: In the weird dialectics of progress in art, every advance of modernism incurs a sense of loss, heightening of nostalgiaand quite rightly too, for older forms have usually satisfied something the new equations leave out. The attack on melody and harmony in advanced music.contributed to a resurgence of folk and rock and country music, just as the triumph of abstraction in painting led eventually to Pop Art and now a new realism in which exploitation, selfirony, decorativeness and nostalgia mingle uneasily with fresh ways of seeing.

title: Secretariat Scores Again: 9Length Chicago Victory
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., June 30The sovereign Secretariat led the hit parade in Illinois today with the supremely unruffled competence he displayed earlier in New York, Maryland, Kentucky and New Jersey. In his first visit to Middle America, the colt who wears racing's Triple Crown came, was seen, and he conquered  conquered the hearts of Arlington Park's biggest crowd in three decades, and conquered the three colts that opposed him in the Arlington Invitational.

title: Bridal in Roxbury For Sharon Dunn
description: ROXBURY, Conn., June 30 Miss Sharon Elizabeth Dunn, daughter of Mrs. Bertrand Anthony Dunn of Danbury and the late Mr. Dunn, was married here this afternoon to Gerard Adrian McAllister Etzel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Joseph Etzel of Manhasset, L. I. The Rev. John M. De Zinno performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Tanzania Reports New Raids by Burundi
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 30The Tanzanian Government said tonight that seven people had been killed and an unknown number wounded in an attack by Burundian troops on villages in the northwestern part of the country.

title: Carol F. Paine, Violinist, Wed
description: POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., June 30Miss Carol Frances Paine and Juan Ruben Ramirez of Boston, violinists and graduates of the New England Conservatory of Music, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Marshall L. Smith performed the Presbyterian ceremony, in the nondenominational Union Church, which the bride had chosen because of its stained glass windows by Chagall and Matisse.

title: John Firestone And Susan Paul To Be Married
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 30  Miss Susan Cleaveland Paul and John Davis Firestone plan to be married in the First Scot's Presbyterian Church here on Aug. 18.

title: COLSON IS ACCUSED OP IMPROPER USE OF HIS INFLUENCE
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Charles W. Colson, former special counsel to the President, and one of his former aides in the White House repeatedly attempted to influence the Labor Department in an effort to aid the Nixon Administration's reelection drive, highly reliable sources have charged.

title: StrifeTorn Park Slope Pays Tribute to Police
description: The police, who came under fire on recent nights as Puerto Ricans and Italians clashed in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, got a pat on the back from both groups yesterday.

title: July
description: So now it is July and summer, and a man doesn't have to wall and shield himself from the season. He may even feel like a partner in summer's achievements, though definitely a junior partner. He planted thOse rows of lettuce and beets and radishes, didn't he? But if he gets too arrogant, a July thunderstorm puts him in his place.

title: Brazil Wins in Soccer
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, June 30 (AP)  Brazil's touring World Cup championship soccer team beat Scotland, 10, today when a Scottish defender, Derek Johnstone, inadvertently kicked the ball into his team's goal.

title: Two Gunmen in Bronx Rob Bar and Its Eight Patrons
description: Nine persons, including an offduty transit patrolman, were held up yesterday in Bronx tavern by two gunmen and robbed of $1,000 in jewelry and $2,300 in cash.

title: Bar on City U. Students Upsets Private Colleges
description: The veto by Governo last week of a bill that would allow the City University of New York to assign new students to private colleges in Brooklyn has left educators and politicians close to the project apprehensive as well as disappointed.

title: David Cooke Fiance Of Susan B. Gregory
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 30 Miss Susan Burness Gregory and David Bainton Cooke, who received bachelor's degrees in foreign affairs from the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service, plan to be married here in September.

title: ExhaustTest Gear Sits Idle
description: TRENTONGovernor Cahill's decision to postpone mandatory exhaustemission inspections in New Jersey has left service stations, mechanics and car dealers saddled with $2.6million in special testing equipment for at least the next seven months.

title: 2 Are Attendants Of Miss Neaher At Her Wedding
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The, Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Rosemary Neaher, a member of the staff of the National Security Council, to John M. Niehuss, who is counsel to Charles DiBona, special conconsultant to the President for energy matters. Msgr. James F. Montgomery performed the ceremony.

title: Susan Davis Bride Of Albert Cantril
description: WILTON CENTER, N. H., June 30Miss Susan Bradford Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Bradford Davis of Wilton Center and Wolfboro, was married here this afternoon to Albert H. Cantril of Washington, an independent consultant in political and social research there.

title: Numismatics
description: ONE of the two, or possibly three, surviving specimens of the storecard token issued by a New Orleans hardware merchant in the 1830's has been sold at auction for $1,575.A survey of leading token specialists confirms that this is far and away the highest price ever recorded for any merchant token. There are pieces of equal or even greater rarity (i.e. only one specimen known) in transportation, political, Civil War and other token fields, but pone has so far produced this kind of bidding action.

title: Speech by Kennedy At Wallace Tribute Awaited in Alabama
description: DECATUR, Ala., June 30Organizers of a Fourth of July rally, at which Gov. George C. Wallace will receive a patriotism award and Senator Edward M. Kennedy will be the main speaker, are expecting as many as 50,000 people to attend.

title: Coriolanus Goes On Drew Boards
description: MADISON  Coriolanus is one of Shakespeare's most difficult and, therefore, rarely produced plays. The hero, an antidemocratic Roman patrician, is almost impossible to portray sympathetically to modern audiences. The action is diffuse and talky, full of crowd scenes and battle action.

title: Rowland Sylvester Jr. Weds Susan Cronan
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 30  Miss Susan Warnock Cronan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Shaw Cronan of Old Greenwich, was married here at noon today to Rowland Emerson Sylvester Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. R. Emerson Sylvester of Auburndale and Point Independence, Mass. The Rev. George A. Pera performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: AIRPORT SECURITY REMAINS AN ISSUE
description: Waterfront A tug of war between the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor and the airline industry over cargo security at the three metropolitan area jetports was stalled last week when a court in Newark held a case between them in abeyanoe until September.

title: Stephanie Lee Becomes Bride
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 30The chapel at the Marymount Academy here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Stephanie Kristine Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Lee, to Robert James Hanson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Hanson of Rye.

title: The New Play
description: THE FAGGOT, a musical by At Carmines, got four favorable reviews (Clive Barnes, Times; Allan Wallach, Newsday; William Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Mary Campbell, AP), one mixed (Jack Gayer, UPI) and three negative (Douglas Watt, News; Jerry Tallmer, Post; Martin Gottfried, Women's Wear).

title: The King's Crown Hotel Will Close Down Today
description: The King's Crown Hotel on Morningside Heights will close today to make room for housing for Columbia University students.

title: PEDICTED LOG TEST IS WON BY KIERNAN
Veto of FiscalOffice Funds Angers Legislature
AROUND THE
description: Be alert for ticks on the South Shore, of Long Island, especially in open wetlands. Check pets daily; wear protective clothing and use insect repellent frequently.... Continue fruit tree and rosebush spray. ing, especially for fungus control.... Pinch back tall, leggy annuals.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly four years ago, Senator Charles E. Goodell, New York Republican whom the Nixor administration subsequently helped defeat at the polls, proposed what was then a novel piece of legislation. would have set a date to cut off all funds for United States military activity in Indochina. He found few cosponsors.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Point of View article by Robert T. Dormer entitled Rent System Is Valid, But Flaw in Formula Sets M.B.R. Too High [June 17] focuses attention in the wrong area and creates the false impression that excess profits will result from the implementation of the Maximum Base Rent formula. Its theoretical approach overlooks today's realities.

title: Suzanne Sklar Wed to Stephen Simons
description: SHREVEPORT, La., June 30 Miss Suzanne Irene Sklar was married here this evening to Stephen Lloyd Simons of New York. Rabbi Richard Zionts performed the ceremony in the chapel of Temple B'nai Zion.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayOx Ridge Dressage, Ox Ridge Hunt Club, Route 124, Darien, Conn. All dressage, training level through Grand Prix. 9 A.M.

title: PAINTERS PROTEST ON CITY CONTRACTS
description: Officials of the painter, union and a painting contractor complained last week that some contractors on projects for such public agencies as the Board of Education and City Housing Authority were failing to pay prevailing wages and supplements as required by state labor law.

title: Emily Rauh Is Married To Joseph Pulitzer Jr.
description: CINCINNATI, June 30Miss Emily S. Rauh, curator of the St. Louis Art Museum, was married here today to Joseph Pulitzer Jr., editor and publisher of The St. Louis PostDispatch. There were 35 members of both families in attendance at the ceremony, performed by Mayor Theodore M. Berry at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Rauh, parents of the bride.

title: ETCHELLS22 HONORS ARE TAKEN BY BASS
Our Continent: A Fragile, Precious Child
description: The basic truths about government that our people should remember and act on are:

title: Revenue Sharing: How It Aids Poor and Rich in Varied Ways
description: ESSEX FELLS  Here in this small, affluent community, where the prices of homes range from $50,000 to $150,000, the town fathers used the bulk of their Federal revenuesharing funds to purchase a $5,300 wood chipper, a machine that grinds up fallen twigs and branches.

title: BRITTANY SPANIEL TAKES TOP AWARE
description: NORTON, Mass., June 30 Ffynant in Welsh means by the brook. So Ch. Ffynant's Revelation, a Brittany Spaniel, was right at home when he was named the best in a field of 1,042 at the Hockamock Kennel Club Show early this evening.

title: A Zoo on Wheels Will Tour Bergen
description: HACKENSACKThe Bergen County Park Commission's traveling zoo will make six Sunday visits to county parks.

title: Catherine Rohan Is Bride
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., June 30  Miss Catherine Rohan, director of financial and corporate relations for the Amrep Corporation a New York communitydevelopment company, was married here this afternoon to Stephen Price, a film editor for 60 Minutes, the CBS News program. The Rev. W. Winfield West performed the ceremony in the Oceanport Methodist Church. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Rohan of Streator, The bridegroom, whose former marriage ended in divorce, is the son of the Rev. Frederick C. Price and Mrs. Price of Red Bank.

title: Gardens
description: FERNS are primitive foliar plants which first appeared on the earth about 300 milion years ago. During the Intervening years they have never produced any flowers and consequently have borne no seeds.

title: Statistics on 6 Lines Serving the 3 States
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The following are statistics on the six bankrupt railroads that serve the tristate area the Penn Central, ErieLackawanna, Lehigh Valley, Jersey Central, Reading and Boston & Maine.

title: Miss Rossbach Fiancee of J. F. Stebbins
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Rossbach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Richards Rossbach, to James Flood Stebbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore E. Stebbins of Syosset, L.I.

title: Crown Heights Gets a 239Unit Coop
description: Crown Gardens, a 239unit cooperative project, is the first new apartment complex in the Crown Heights Section of Brooklyn in several decades. The development, on Nostrand Avenue between Carroll and President Streets, includes a 15story tower that contains 155 apartments and a garden court enclosed on three sides by fourstory townhouses. The first two floors of the townhouses contain twobedroom apartments.

title: Army Deepening River Lane to Kearny
description: KEARNYThe Hackensack River's shipping channel will be deepened from Newark Bay to a point just north of this Hudson County community, thus making Kearny possible site for a containerport. But the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and some local officials say they have no interest in establishing such a port here.

title: The Central Question
description: What did the President know, and when did he know it? This is the question put before the Senate Watergate committee by its ranking Republican, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., of Tennessee. There is only one man who can give the conclusive answer.

title: Jazz for the Dawn Patrol Gets 5Borough Event Off
description: They reclined on foam rubber pillows and sipped wine and soft drinks amid the fashionable decor of the saxophonist Ornette Coleman's Artist House at 131 Prince Street.

title: Opportunities For the Young
description: LCOKING for highlevel performance opportunities for young musicians, the Concert Artists Guild has followed the path of many other organizations and turned to a church. This fall the Guild, which is headed by Leonard Altman, will begin a series of chambermusic programs at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, which nestles comfortably among lawns, shrubbery and trees at 120 West 69th Street. The church seats approximately 260 people and is described as having excellent acoustics (it has been used for recordings). There will be 14 concerts, presented on the first and third Sundays at 4 P.M. from October through May, with the exception of December. The young professionals, who will be paid, will have a chance to tackle a repertory removed from the standard solo literatureworks such as Debussy's Trio for flute, harp and viola; Schuller's Quartet for Four Basses; Michael Haydn's Divertimento in G; Spohr's piano and wind Quintet; Janacek's Youth Suite, and so on. The series is even looked upon with favor by Carnegie Hall, which is associated in the project.

title: Uruguay's Army and Policemen Move to Break General Strike
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 30 (UPI)The Uruguayan Government used armed troops today to break up a general strike protesting against the closing of Congress, and it ordered the country's largest labor organization disbanded and its leaders arrested.

title: Soviet in MineralExport Drive
description: The United States for the first time in its history is beginning to feel rawmaterial shortages, while the Soviet Union for the first time in its history is speaking of exploiting its natural resources for the export market.

title: Drugs and Car Deaths
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., June 30 (AP)  Investigators say they have found evidence of drugs in the bodies of nearly 28 per cent of 410 fatally injured automobile drivers in the last two years. The Midwest Research Institute, under sponsorship of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, is making a study of drug abuse in automobile accidents.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Two major real estate concerns here have merged to form a new national organization.

title: Miss Glimcher Plans Nuptials
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., June 30 Dr. and Mrs. Melvin J. Glimcher have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laurie Hollis Glimcher, to Hugh Auchincloss Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Auchincloss of Ridgewood, N. J., and Manchester, Mass.

title: Triumph in Sculls Earns Dietz a Trip To Henley Regatta
Gary Hall Marries
description: CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP)Gary Hall, 23 years old, a silver medalist in Olympic swimming in 1968 and 1972 married Mary Keating, 21, of Cincinnati, in St. Peterin.Chains cathedral today,

title: Pam Horvitz Bride Of Tony Schneider
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, June 30Miss Pam Susan Horvitz was married here this evening to Milton Sam Schneider, assistant to the president of W. R. Grace Properties in NeW York. Rabbi Daniel Jeremy Silver performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. S. A. Horvitz, the bride's grandmother.

title: Citizen Troop to Patrol Park
description: MORRISTOWN  Morristown National Historical Park is forming a volunteer horse patrol manned by older citizens.cruiting men and women 60 years old and over for a wide range of volunteer activities in hospitals, daycare centers, recreation areas, museums, libraries and camps. It is expected that 200 senior volunteers will eventually be on duty in the county.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: While we are casting around to find some positive use for the Watergate adversity, we should not neglect its value as a lesson in management. These melancholy events could not have happened without a disintegration of the management processes.

title: PEKING TIGHTENS REINS ON BUILDING
description: HONG KONG, June 30The wide latitude in starting construction and industrial ventures given to Chinese provincial and local authorities during the peak years of the Cultural Revolution is being curbed.

title: Jeanne E. Stockman Is Bride Of Frank Hamilton 3d on L. I.
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 30  Miss Jeanne Elizabeth Stockman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Stockman Jr. of Locust Valley. was married here this afternoon to Frank Watrous Hamilton 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Jr. of Mendham, N. J.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Slow Start for Mosquitoes
description: NEW BRUNSWICK New Jersey's mosquitoes have already begun to bite, but, according to Daniel M. Jobbins, who has been studying the state's mosquitoes for more than 40 years, it appears that the worst infestation will come early in September.

title: Berra Is Safe at Home for the Time Being
description: Nobody has played a harmonica on the New York Mets bus yet. But Yogi Berra is hearing plenty of other echoes of 1964 these days as his team falls apart in the West. The Mets, everyone agrees, are hurt and going no place fast. Next question: Where is Yogi headed in the debris?

title: A Tour for the Fourth of July, Fitting to These Troubled Times
description: BY a quirk of fate, the most serious political scandal in our nation's history appears to be approaching its climax on the eve of holiday that many Americans regard as our most patriotic day"the Fourth of July. Surely, the specter of Watergate should lessen no citizen's love of country, and yet this coincidence may well subdue the style or manner in which thoughtful Americans will choose to celebrate the Fourth this year. To many this coming Wednesday will be a time for sober reflection, not breast, beating it will also be a time for contemplation of the roots of freedom.

title: Troubled Catholic Schools Seeking Ways to Survive
description: CHICAGO, June 30The nation's Roman Catholic parochial schools, spurred by serious financial difficulties and this week's Supreme Court decisions outlawing several important forms of state aid, appear on the verge of a new and somewhat precarious period sure to change the education of almost four million children.

title: Special Tourism Unit Named
description: ALBANY June 30 (UPI)Governor Rockefeller today appointed an interdepartmental committee to give top priority to promoting the nation's 200th anniversary in the overseas vacation market. The committee will be headed by the state's Commerce Commissioner, Neal L. Moylan.

title: Mangan Gains 3d Round Of Martin Tennis Tourney
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 30 John Mangan of the Manursing Island Club, Rye, N.Y., the defending champion and seeded No. 1, gained the third round of the Westchester County Tennis League's 42d annual Paul Martin Memorial tournament today,

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
Sihunouk Says That No Negotiations Are On
description: BUCHAREST, June 30Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the ousted Cambodian Chief of State, denied today that either his government in exile in Peking or members of the Khmer Rouge guerrilla movement inside Cambodia were engaged in negotiations with representatives of the Government of President Lon Nol or with any outside power.

title: Wigs for hot weather
description: One of the summer beauty problems many women take seriously is that of coping with hair which has given up its good shape to heat, humidity and summer sports. An obvious solution is a wigthe new ones all have the latest haircuts. By fall, a woman might even decide to adopt the wig's cut for her own hair.

title: Efforts to Protect the Sources of ournalists Stalled by Watergate Revelations,
description: WASHINGTONThe Watergate revelationswhich many believe to have been the press's greatest triumph in recent yearsironically have stalled, probably for some time to come, yearlong Congressional efforts to protect journalists from enforced disclosure of their confidential sources.

title: Miss Waterhouse, Teacher, Marries
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., June 30Miss Deborah Bradley Waterhouse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Richard Waterhouse Jr., was married here this afternoon to Robert Gunther McCullam Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McCullam of New Providence. Canon Richard Hardman performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Melissa Anne McCoy Married To the Rev. Russell David Cox
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 30Miss Melissa Anne McCoy and the Rev. Russell David Cox were married here this morning in St. Mark's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Grant A. Morrill. The Revs. Gary Kriss, Carl Buffington and Craig Casey, assisted. The bridegroom is on the church's staff.

title: Morris Sailing Trophy Is Captured by Robin
The Rock And the Hard Place
description: President Nixon has got himself, as the old saying goes, between a rock and a hard place.
