He is permitting himself no convincing means of refuting what Senator Howard Baker called the mindboggling testimony. of John W. Dem 3d; but if that testimony allowed to stand, it pictures Mr. Nixon as guilty of precisely the kind of high crimes and misdemeanors that require impeachment.

title: COLUMBIA CLOSING ITS URBAN CENTER But Seeks to Replace It With New Minority Program
description: Columbia University has named a task force to develop a plan under which the institution will have a comprehensive program in urban minority affairs to succeed the Urban Center set up in 1967 with Ford Foundation funds.

title: CHEMICAL AGENTS FOR TEETH SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The nation's dental researchers are working on chemical agents to prevent tooth decay and gum diseases because they now real. ize that rio amount of brushing alone will ever really do the job.

title: Musicails Used to Be for Singing, Not Agonizing
description: JOHN PHILIP SOUSA really had an advantage over Al Carmines. He knew how the plot went.

title: Be Mad, Ladies, But Don't. Be Muddleheaded
description: AN enormous amount of time and effort is devoted nationally to analyzing the fact that a lot of nonsense can be found on television. Occasionally, just occasionally, some time and effort might be devoted to the fact that a lot of nonsense is written about television. Venturing a hesitant start, I shall restrict my targets to a couple of articles that have appeared in this section of The New York Times.

Hurley of Millbrock, N. Y. The Rev. Donald G. Timone performed the ceremony.

title: COMPANIES'
description: Unions and their members here are said to face an increasingly serious problem as conglomerates take over local concerns here and in some cases transfer operations to sites where they can hire nonunion labor at substantially lower wages.

title: MRS. KNELLER
description: OBERLIN, Ohio, June 30Margaret Ann Truslove Kneller, mother of Dr. John W. Kneller, president of Brooklyn College in New York, died yesterday at the Welcome Nursing Homer here. She was 87 years old.

title: A's Win and Regain First,. Jackson Hits Pair
Middlesex Racer Recalls Indy 500
description: EAST BRUNSWICKThis bustling Middlesex County community will be well represented when the Schaefer 500, one of the country's major automobile races, gets under way in Long Pond, Pa., today.

title: He Builds Career as DoItYourselfer
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I.  Two years ago Bill Schremp looked over his friend's new $1,200 sofa and said he could make one like it for $100. He did. Then he went on to make a dining room table, a Parsons table, a coffee table, a bedframe with builtin shelves and a kitchen counter.

title: Watch Your Fingers Wins
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 30 (AP)  Barbara Smith sent Watch Your Fingers into the lead going into the turn and won the $3,700 Warwick Purse by 2/g lengths today at Narragansett Park. The winner coyered 5 furlongs in 0:50 2.5 and paid $3.60 for $2 to win.

title: The five and dime empire
description: An obvious peril in writing corporate history is a tendency to be uncritical. This absence of balance is distressingly noticeable in John P. Nichols's book about the F. W. Woolworth Company. Skyline Queen and the Merchant Prince is an attempt to bring together the stories of New York's Woolworth Building (the queen), Frank Winfield Woolworth (the prince), the fiveanddime stores and one of the largest retailing organizations in the world. It simply doesn't work.

title: Chile: Hard Times
description: Under the Marxist regime of President Salvador Allende, Chilean democracy is surviving despite the kind of political and economic stresses that by now might well have wrecked the democratic system in the United States. In the teeth of Chile's worst economic crisis since the Great Depression, with serious food shortages, production difficulties and inflation this year running at an annual rate of 247 per cent, Allende's Unidad Popultar coalition led by the Communists and socialists increased its Congressional representation in last March's critical parliamentary elections. The U.P. still is, however, a factionridden minority coalition of six parties, as it was when President Allende was elected in 1970 with only 36 per cent of the vote and a plurality of 1.4 per cent.

title: As Company Goes, So Goes Manville.
description: MANVILLE  When one crosses the bridge from Finders into this borough of 13,500 residents, he immediately becomes aware that the major attraction Is the huge plant of the Johns Manville Products Corporation, which dominates Main Street from the boundary to the business district. Johns Manville, which employes 3,500 area residents, has been the bread and butter of this Somerset County town for many years. And, although residents dispute the thought, if the industry should ever leave, the community would have insurmountable problems. The Talk of Manville

title: Recordings
description: OTTO KLEMPERER's recordings of Die Zauberflote and Don Giovanni, both with allstar casts, were released in this country by Angel in 1964 and 1967 respectively, and both were conspicuous failures with critics and public alike. Objections centered primarily on the German conductor's broad, exaggerated tempos, especially when compared to the more febrile and alsO relatively more standard readings of such maestros as Bohm and Giulini.

title: Chimney Rock Lake Is Sought for Park
description: BRIDGEWATER TOWNSHIPChimney Rock Regervoir, a 150acre lake that overflowed into widespread flood damage several years ago, may become part of 641acre public park in the Watchung Mountains area of Somerset County.

title: Linguists Aid Hospital In Caring For Patients
description: GREEN BROOK  Raritan Valley Hospital is providing its nonEnglishspeaking patients with a service designed to help them communicate their needs to attending doctors and nurses.

title: Kramer Revisits 1960's Rock
description: Amazing. There was the audience, longhaired, restless, predominantly denimed, singing White Christmas in the middle of Madison Square Garden. And all at the request of Billy J. Kramer, British singer who had no real distinguished success in this country in his heyday (the early nineteensixties).

title: Daughter to the Lundens
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 30  A daughter was born June 5 to Mr. and Mrs. James A. Lunden at the Greenwich Hospital. The child has been named Nicole Alix.

title: Sandra M. McCullough Is Engaged
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 30Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. McCullough have made; known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Margaret McCullough, to Chariton Henry Chatfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Chatfield of Cincinnati and Amagansett, L.L

title: Ghastly things happen in Cornwall Coombe
description: Reviewing Harvest Home is essentially an exercise in futility: people are going to buy it by the truckload, and presumably read it, no matter what is said about it. It is only Thomas Tryon's second novel, but his first was such a smashing best seller that he got $625,000 for the paperback rights to this one before its hardcover publication. He is so big that his fame reaches into unlikely corners of American life. When the Book Review asked me to review Harvest Home, I called Western Union to wire acceptance. was connected to an operator in New Jersey, to whom gave the address and the message; Send on the Tryon. she said. 'The Other.

title: It's Eel Season on Raritan
description: CALIFON  Whenever the moon is dark this summer, young fishermen will be lining up on the Main Street bridge over the placid south branch of the Raritan River. Their quarry? Eels.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The booming textile business in the Far East has brought a reversal in the flow of man made fibers. Countries that once shipped quantities of their fiber output to the United States are now buying practically all the fiber they can get from this country.

title: MISS BAUGH, 18, LEADS BY 2 SHOTS
Indians Lose to Stottlemyre, 73 White Stars
SMUT MAKERS CALI BUSINESS VIABLE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June In the major pornography ducing centers of Los Angeles and San Francisco, the Supreme Court's latest ruling on obscenity was met this week concern and anger but with the promise that the ness was not dead.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:AS for secrecy, writes Walter D. Bannard (He Comes to Praise the Met, June 17), that's a crime only to journalists.

title: Enigma at The Bank Of England
description: LONDON  Gordon Richardson has been a mover and shaker in the world of finance for more than a decade, yet as he becomes Governor of the Bank of England today his views on all the major economic issues vexing Britain are as unknown as if he had been conducting his affairs from a Tibetan lamasery.

title: Theater in London
description: LONDON. THE World Theater Season has just completed its tenth and final year at the Aldwych Theater with the Zulu Macbeth, and Peter Daubeny, who has been running the Festival ever since he first conceived it, is among those on the birthday list receiving knighthoods from the Queen. Sir Peter's honors are richly deserved, for the appearance on Britain's shores of companies from all over the world has been of incalculable value to those concerned about the possibilities of the theater.

title: Israel to Aid Scientists
description: JERUSALEM, June 30 (Reuters)The Israeli Cabinet has decided to set up an interdepartmental council to deal with the rapid influx of immigrant scientists. The aim is to provide suitable employment for thousands of immigrant scientists and prevent a brain drain of Israeli intellectuals for lack of suitable opportunities in this country.

title: A Supertanker Christened in Brooklyn
description: With a beer party and more than a little pride, 5,000 officials and shipyard workers gave the supertanker Brooklyn a sendoff yesterday at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Susan Stanton Bride Of Denis J. Rickard
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 30 Miss Susan Jane Stanton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Stanton, was married here this afternoon to Denis John Rickard, son of Mrs. James E. Rickard also of Fairfield, and the late Mr. Rickard. Msgr. Thomas Henahan performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Assumption Roman Catholic Church.

title: Brigantine Geese Shipped to Florida
description: OCEANVILLE  The Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge, 20,000 placid acres within sight of Atlantic City's teeming shoreline, gave up 200 of its Canada geese last week. The birds were not sent to local supermarkets but, instead, to Florida, where they will ultimately become the prey of hunters.

title: Parochial Schools Confident In Spite of High Court Ruling
description: Last Monday's Supreme Court rulings against further public aid to churchrelated schools does not seem to have left parochial school officials in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island too depressed.

title: FUNDS RELEASED FOR YOUTH CORPS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Department of Labor complied with a court order today and released $239million in funds nationwide for the Neighborhood Youth Corps summer program.

title: DOOLEY FOUNDATION WILL AID CAMBODIA
description: The Thomas A. Dooley Foundation has signed a contract with the Cambodian Government to supply medical and professional aid to Cambodia.

title: USSERY WINS FIVE AT LIBERTY BELL
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 30Caesar P. Kimmel's Lover John scored a ninelength victory in the $23,012.50 first division of Dragoon Stakes at Liberty Bell race track today.

title: The Hills Are Alive With The Sound of Mozart Just 40 Miles From N.Y.C.
description: I AM sittingalong with 1,100 other music buffsin a square sunken garden that appears to be a miraculous survival from the 18th century. The walls are lined with dark, fragrant trees and the floor is carpeted with thick green grass. Around the edge of the garden runs a partial ceiling of dustypink tentingpropped up on tall gray poles resembling medieval spears. Several hundred yards behind me is the entrance to this outdoor theater, a massive 18thcentury wroughtiron gate flanked by two stone horse heads that are the work of Malvina Hoffman. At the opposite end of the garden stands an open pavilion of pink marble columns topped by pointed Venetian arches forming the backdrop for a mediumsize orchestra. The air is fresh and cool with a hint of rain that will never arrive. (During the second piece on the program, a single star appears in the sky and there is an audible sigh of relief from the audience.) The music is Mozarta graceful serenade, a concerto for clarinet, one for French horn, and the familiar, robust Haffner symphony. After intermission, I stroll back to the gate and discover that the acoustics are still good at a considerable distance from the stage. If I continue through the gate and turn left, I will eventually arrive at a rambling twostory Florentine villa that could have been built by one of the Medicis. Are we in the Tuscan hills? The Veneto campagna? The private garden of a Salzburg schloss? Not at all. This is Caramoor, a baronial Westchester County estate consisting of a main house (the villa), 10 satellite cottages, the Venetian theater and 150 landscaped acres of lawns, garden and woodland. AlEuropean, I am, in fact, only 40 miles north of New York City. Moreover, have arrived at this enchanting and totally unAmerican spot by chartered bus.

title: B. B. King's Blues Barn Creates Echoes of Past
description: B. B. King's Blues Barn kept the blues"the mother tree with many branches in King's apt phraserolling for three hours on Friday at Philharmonic Hall. And continuouslyeven when King, the master of ceremonies, on stage throughout, announced his fellow bluesmen, he kept the music noodling away quietly in the background.

title: Coach Decries Soccer in Greece
description: ATHENS, June 30The Greeks have switched from politics to soccer and they love it. They play it, they talk about it and they watch it on television. It has become their favorite pastime. When a soccer game is on television the city streets, normally packed with cars and people, are deserted. Despite all this fanaticism and devotion, however, soccer hasn't progressed here at all, at least when it comes to representing the country on the national level. The Greeks appear apathetic about good showings of their national team. They appear to be interested in the individual teams they support when they compete within the country for the league title or the national cup. This has made the job of the Greek coaches of the five national teams virtually unbearable.

title: Marsh Wins Scottish Open By Six Strokes With 286
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 30 (UPI)Graharn Marsh of Australia posted his first British victory today in winning the Scottish open golf tourney. He had a total of 286 for the four rounds and won by six strokes.

title: Dark side up
description: A few weeks ago, a Norwegian who had served in the antiNazi underground saw a newspaper photograph and thought he recognized an American O.S.S. officer he had worked with during the war and had known only as No. 96.

title: Waterloo Is Looking to '76
description: BYRAM TOWNSHIPWhat we're trying to create here is a combination Sturbridge and Tanglewood, said Percival H. E. Leach, cofounder and codirector of Waterloo Village, the restored historic hamlet on the banks of the Musconetcong River.

title: Arlington's Other Race Is Won by Last Home
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., June 30 (AP), Last Home took the lead in midstretch and went on to win the $63,300 Matron Handicap on Secretariat Day at Arlington Park.

title: Device Alerts Area To Possible Floods
description: SCOTCH PLAINS  Here where the Green Brook meanders down from the foothills of the Watchung Mountains, a peculiarlooking device  it has two white boxes at either end of a fourfootlong tube  sits on the west bank of the muddy waterway.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Matto Wins Elkton Purse
description: STANTON, Del., June 30 (AP)  Matto, ridden by Hector Pilar, won the Elkton Purse by six lengths today at Delaware Park: He was clocked in 1:42 25 for the mile and returned $6.60 for $2 to win.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: GAMBLING IS ISSUE FOR AUSTRALIANS
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 26television program showing illegal gambling casinos in Sydney and charging that city policemen had been paid off by the operators has touched off a lively public controversy involving the highest state officials.

title: Jean M. Clavin Marries
description: In St. Anselm's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn yesterday morning, Miss Jean Mary Clavin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Clavin of Brooklyn, became the bride of Donald M. Cole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Cole, also of Brooklyn. The Rev. Lewis H. Maynard performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Revs Daniel Browne and Robert Gillen,

title: Death as a Metaphor Is Dead
description: The sixties saw apocalyptic criticism assimilated into middleclass culture. In hindsight, it isn't clear whether the apocalypse did not in fact occur, or whether it happened every single day. What is clear is that we have beaten the metaphors of dying literally to death.

title: Parents in Newark Assisting Teachers
description: NEWARK  Educators in many countries are putting increasing stress on the maxim that education, like charity, begins at home. In Newark, that insight has become a key feature in the Federallysupported effort to improve the schooling of children deemed educationally deprived.a variety of summer activities for thousands of children. Starting this month, there will be primary and bilingual reading centers in 29 schools, special classes for socially maladjusted, emotionally disturbed or mentally retarded children, a followup, reading program on the secondary level, a theater workshop for ninthgraders interested in a career on or behind stage, field trips and summer camps.

title: Lavinia C. Gordon Wed to Student
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., June 30  The marriage of Miss Lavinia Cargill Gordon to Daniel Creighton Churchill took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Aaron Manderbach of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Prince H. Gordon, parents of the bride. Mr. Churchill is the son of Creighton Churchill of Portland, Me., and New York, and Mrs. James Farley of Cornish, N. H.

title: Joanne Staats Blackwell Is Bride

description: The office of Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had set up an Office of Education Performance Review, a compromise version of his proposed inspector general for education, and that Daniel Klepak, his special assistant and a career administrator, would head it.

title: Lenore A. Muscio Wed
description: BALTIMORE, June 30Miss Lenore Ann Muscio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. U. V. Muscio of Old Brookville, L. I., and Richard D'Adamo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip D'Adamo of East Newmarket, were married here this morning in the chapel of the College of Notre Dame of Maryland by the Rev. James Reid of Fordham University. The bride's father is president of the Muzak Corporation and is a board member of the Fedders Corporation and the United Medical Society (Blue Shield). The bridegroom's father is County Commissioner of Dorchester.

title: Sixth Graders in Nassau Follow the Geometric Path of Buckminster Fuller
description: GREAT NECK, L. I. A group of 35 sixthgraders at the Kensington Johnson school here recently completed a threemonth project in which they built a geodesic dome from raw materials. A geodesic dome is a sphere with no internal supports.

title: An Old Fire Truck Rejoins the Parade
description: BELLPORT, L.I.  They asked me to jazz up the axes and picks,.. said the dynamic Emily Rich Underhill matteroffactly, as she unhooked a freshly painted ax from the 1893 hookandladder fire truck that she had helped redecorate this past winter.

title: New Law Aims at Oil Spills
description: TRENTONThe threat of a major oil spill in New Jersey waters, heightened by new industrial Remands for a deepwater oil port off the state's coastline, has inspired new legislation designed to make petroleum companies fully responsible for any environmental damage involved in a spill.

title: YearRound Living in a Summer Colony
description: YORKTOWN, N. Y.Julie and Paul Green, home from eight hours work in their Bronx stationery store, tucked their two small children into bed and then zipped themselves into a blue mosquitoproof tent in the backyard, where they talked in the twilight.

title: Parking Site At College Is Sought For Queens
description: Queens College and Plan. ning Board 8 are asking the city and state for funds to construct what would be the largest underground parking garage in the city.

title: Denise M. Panettiere Is a Bride on L.I.
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., June 30 Miss Denise Merle Panettiere, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bart R. Panettiere, was married here this morning to GeorgesPhilippe Vergnes of Bonnieux, France, son of Mrs. Adolphe Vergnes of Villelaure, France, and the late Mr. Vergnes. The Rev. Allan Placca performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Queens Democrat Is Closer to Being Mr. D. A.
description: When Nicholas Ferraro was a little boy in the Astoria section of Queens, his, mother used to say, to him:

title: Is America burning?
CUNNINGHAM EXCELS IN TRACK MEET HERE
description: Tyrone Cunningham of the Manhattan Flight Kings Was a triple winner in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior track and field championship yesterday at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: Miss Virginia Ewart Is Bride Of Peter Constable Maxwell
description: Miss Virginia Anne Ewart and Peter Constable Maxwell were married yesterday afternoon at the Chapel of Our Lady at Alresford House, Old Alresford in Hampshire, England. The Rev. David Morland, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony. The Very Rev. Basil flume, the Abbot of Ampleforh gave an address.

title: Harvard Nine 90 Victor
description: RAMINI,Italy, June 30 (UN)  HarVard College defeated Bernazzoll, 9.0, today in the second game of a quadrangular baseball match, Harvard will meet Renanda of Rimini tomorrow in a contest for first place, while Montenegro And Bernazzoli play for third place.

title: Dance
WELFARE RENTS SHOW RISE HERS
description: The rent costs of welfare clients were reported last week to be rising here at an accelerating tempo this year, with rents now ranging up to an average of $121 a month for a family of four in privete housing.

title: Royal Chocolate Wins Queen's Plate
description: TORONTO, June 30 (AP)Royal Chocolate, a 231 shot ridden by Ted Colangelo, came from out of the pack heading into the backstretch today and won the Queen's Plate by about six lengths at Woodbine.

title: Wendy L. Ensinger Marries in Suburb
description: PELHAM, N. Y., June 30 Miss Wendy Lee Ensinger, daughter of Mrs. William B. Ensinger and the late Dr. Ensinger, a physician in practice here, was married this afternoon to Thomas Richard Carley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine F. Carley of Douglaston, Queens. The Rev. William C. Schram performed the ceremony at the Huguenot Memorial Church.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The high cost to American business and industry of alcoholism among employes has caused a growing number of companies to take action.

title: Deborah van Roden Is Married
description: MEDIA, Pa., June 30Miss Deborah Jarden van Roden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard van Roden, was married here this afternoon to Sheffield Joseph Halsey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Halsey of Ossining, N. Y., and Sea Island, Ga. The Rev. Michael J. Campbell performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Ad Campaign to Save Robins
description: CLEVELAND, June 30 (AP)Members of the International Fund for Animal Welfare have begun a campaign to stop the killing of thousands of robins in Canada's Maritime Provinces.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, June 30 (AP)Foreign Minister Abba Eban said today that Tunisia had failed to follow up on President Habib Bourguiba's proposal to meet an Israeli representative for talks about peace in the Middle East.

title: Met Games This Week
description: TodayAt Chicago (2). TomorrowAt Montreal. TuesdayAt Montreal, night. WednesdayAt Montreal, night. ThursdayAt Montreal, night. FridayAtlanta at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. SaturdayAtlanta at Shea Stadium, 2:05 P.M. TodayCleveland at Yankee Stadium, (2), 1, P.M. TomorrowBoston at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. TueidayBoston at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. WednesdayBoston at Yankee Stadium, (2), 1 P.M. ThursdayBoston at Yankee Sta. dium, 2 P.M. FridayAt Minnesota, night. SaturdayAt Minnesota.

title: U.S. TEAMS SEARCH FOR MISSING G.I.'S
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, June 30The teams searching for clues to the fate of the more than 1,300 Americans missing in action in Indochina have run into serious problems and their work has been painfully slow.

title: U.S. Polo Team Triumphs
description: MIDHURST, England, June 30 (AP)  Greenhill Farm, an American polo team led by James Sharp of Tulsa, Okla., won the Summer Cup, today with a 54 victory over England's Cowdray Park. The Americans, with two goals on handicap; took a 40 lead on goals by Harold Harry of Thiscott, Tex. and Tommy Wayman of Burbank, Okla. After Cowdray Park ran off three goals, Wayman scored again  from 40 yards.

title: PIRATES TRIUMPH OVER EXPOS, 5 TO I
Sunday Observer
description: Is it all right to be a little dismayed by the propaganda successes being enjoyed by the bicycle and smallcar lobbies? The bicycle is a fairly pleasant machine for limited uses by a few people, but claims that it can substitute for the automobile as a device for moving people around town are grossly overstated.

title: Child Unit Here Plans Preventive Aid
description: City officials are planning to set up immediately a number of experimental programs they believe will markedly reduce juvenile crime and misbehavior as well as the need to remove neglected and abused children from their parents.

title: Columbia Names Griffin Coach of Freshman Five
description: Mike Griffin, who was an assistant basketball coach at Columbia from 1967 to 1970, will return to the university next fall as freshman coach after serving three years in a similar position at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

title: Judith Anne Baldwin Is Bride Candace Waters, Of Steven Batchelor Hubbard Michael Schuller
description: GROSSE POINTE, Mich., June 30  Miss Judith Anne Baldwin was married here this afternoon to Steven Batchelor Hubbard. The Rev. Arnold A. Fenton performed the ceremony, in Christ Episcopal Church. A reception was held at the Country Club of Detroit.

title: Rain Threatens Pocono 500 Race
description: LONG POND; Pa., June 30Weather permitting, the United States Auto Club's second 500mile, race of the season will start at 1 P.M. tomorrow on. the 2mile Pocono International Raceway. The race for Indianapolistype cars carries a purse of $300,000 plus approximately $60,000 in accesawards.

title: Daughter to Mrs. Juceam
description: MANHASSET, L. I., June 30  A daughter was born June 20 to Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Juceam at the Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park. Mrs. Juceam, the former Miss Eleanor Pam, is executive assistant to the president of Queensborough Community College in Bayside, Queens. Her husband is with the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. The child has been named Jacquelyn Brooke.

title: Hospital in Suffolk To Get $3Million
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport is the first hospital to take advantage of a twoyearold county loan program. The Suffolk Legislature recently approved a $3million loan to the nonprofit, voluntary hospital, enabling it to increase its capacity from 68 beds to 90 beds and to update its plant and facilities.

title: Newport Jazz
description: It was, of course, the advertised reunion of the original Benny Goodman Quartet Mr. Goodman, Teddy Wilson, Lionel Hampton and Gene Krupathat made Friday night's program at Carnegie Hall the earliest advance sellout of the Newport Jazz Festival. This was obviout from the cheers that greeted them when they emerged on the stage (which was partly filled with an overflow audience) and that were sustained all through their performance.

title: Stamps
description: IN a tribute to the advances in electronics which have so greatly extended the range of man's senses and achievements, the United States is commemorating in a new issue some of the milestonesfrom Marconi's turnofthecentury spark coil to the transistor that set the stage for the Space Age.

title: Wide Effort Reported for Peace Accord In Cambodia by the End of the Summer
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Top Administration officials have told members of Congress and newsmen in recent days that wideranging diplomatic efforts were going on to promote political settlement in Cambodiahopefully by the end of the summer.

title: That Was No Ballplayer,That Was His Wife
description: Their average age is 25, they glow with healthy madeinU.S.A. good looks and they live in comfortable homes in Westchester, New Jersey, Long Island and Connecticut. Not very much distinguishes them from thousands of other young wives and mothers across the country except that with their wedding bands comes membership in an exclusive club: Met Wives.

title: HERMAN YUCHT
description: PATERSON, N.J., June 30Herman Yucht, a partner in the New York accounting firm of Fred Landau & Co., died today at Barnert Memorial Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 425 18th Avenue.

title: SPECTATORS JAM  VILLAGE INUIT Eclipse Provides an Almost Mystical Experience for Tribesmen and Tourists
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 30 A band of sunburned scientists amateur astronomers, tourists and African tribesmen shared an almost mystical experience this afternoon when they witnessed the total eclipse of the sun on the banks of Lake Rudolph in northern Kenya.

title: Cost of Borrowing Is Raised by Japan To Fight Inflation
description: TOKYO, June 30Japan decided today to raise the official discount rate by two quarters of a percentage point to 6 per cent per year. The new rate will go into effect Monday.

title: Mailbox: Integrity First
description: To THE EDITOR: The Times's article entitled House Crime Group Reports Wide Fixing of Races (June 26) is an unfair, sweeping indictment of a sport which has spent many millions of dollarsnot to protect its image, as alleged by the House Crime Committee but to protect the integrity of racing and the public which supports this widely accepted sport.

title: The Good Word: No Snob Like a Snubbed Snob
description: If you ever got the boot from the classic English cad, the rubberfaced bully whose hands crawled on the social ladder while hfs feet kicked, Evelyn Waugh was your natural enemy. Waugh wasn't just a harmless classromantic like Wilde or Fitzgerald, pressing his velvet suit and his epigrams for a desperate assault on the capital. He was the real belching, sneering thing, with all the foul manners of the world's great Power Centers.

title: Field for Schaefer 500
description: Row OnePeter Revson, Rodondo Beach, Calif., Gulf McLaren, 190.648; Al Unser, Albuquerque, N.M., Viceroy Parnelli, 190.567; Mario Andretti, Nazareth, Pa., Viceroy Parnelli, 190.164.

title: Art
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. IT Is a hard fact of criticism, although neither principle nor a policy, that the more damning the review, the easier it is to write and the more fun to read. This being the case we are in for a dull session today, since if there is anything wrong with the National Gallery's new exhibition, Prints of the Italian Renaissance, I can't find it The only imaginable reservation would have to come from someone who doesn't like early Italian engravings in the first placea form of blindness, however, that the exhibition should cure. Surely not even the most familiar prints have ever looked more beautiful than they do here.

title: Nixon Hopeful Over BritishIcelandic Fishing Dispute
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 30 (Reuters)  President Nixon expressed hope today for an early settlement of the dispute over fishing limits between Britain and Iceland, but emphasized the neutrality of the United States in the matter.

title: The Court's Impact On Movies
description: The Supreme Court handed down today a new set of guidelines on obscenity that will enable states to ban books, magazines, plays and motion pictures that are offensive to local standards, even if they might be acceptable elsewhere.... States may punish the printing or sales of works which appeal to prurient interest in sex, which portray sexual conduct in a patently offensive way and which, taken as whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value'....

title: DizzyStill King of Bebop
description: IT has been 30 years since Dizzy Gillespie blew his trumpet in the legendary Harlem jam session that spawned bebop and changed the i direction of jazz. In all that time, the man once known as the king of bebop has rarely missed a beat.

title: Brooklyn Mother Accused Of Beating Her Son to Death
description: A 28yearold mother of four children was held yesterday without bail in Brooklyn Criminal Court on a charge that she had beaten her 7yearold son to death with a leather belt.

title: When Muni Wore Chains and Bogart Wore a Black Hood Movies
description: ON Wednesday, we'll be celebrating the Fourth of July, and so will the Museum of Modern Artwith a showing of Jimmy Cagney's rousing 1942 movie, Yankee Doodle Dandy. But there will be more than patriotism on MOMA's mind that day, for Yankee Doodle Dandy is just one of 207 films made by Warner Brothers to be screened between July 4 and Nov. 18 in honor of the studio's 50th birthday.

title: Allende's Position Appears Stronger in Aftermath of Chile's Abortive Revolt
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 30In the aftermath of yesterday's abortive coup by part of an armored regiment, President Salvador Allende Gossens appeared to have greatly bolstered his political position.

title: ULSTER SNIPER KILLS A SOLDIER ON PATROL
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 1 (Reuters)A British soldier was shot to death in the Roman Catholic area of Ballymurphy today, the first soldier killed in two months and the 190th since strife broke out in Northern Ireland four years ago.

title: Drunkenness Law Changed
description: BOSTON, July 1 (AP)Public drunkenness ceased to be a crime in Massachusetts today. Drunkenness now is considered a disease, and the police now have four options in dealing with an inebriate: he can be taken home, or to a detoxificadon center, or to a hospital, or can be held in protective custody at a police station.

title: NATASHA BOSKOVIC
description: Natasha Boskovic, a ballet teacher here who was a prima ballerina of the Royal Yugoslav Ballet in the nineteenthirties, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital following a heart attack. She was 62 years old, the wife of Ljubisa Vido, a former Yugoslav officer, and lived at 375 Riverside Drive.

title: Miss Sherwin Wed To Nathan Garland
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., July 1  Miss Patricia Bess Sherwin was married here this afternoon to Nathan Jay Garland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Garland of Chicago. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Sherwin of Great Neck.

title: Men's Suits Fail to Measure Up in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Whatever became of the Soviet economic reform, the one that was supposed to give the customer what he wants?

title: $95,000 Is Donated To Assist Programs In Cultural Field
description: Six foundations and one Federal agency have contributed total of $95,000 to the Museums Collaborative, Inc., an affiliate of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, for free summer programs in 12 cultural institutions in the five boroughs.

title: LUTHERANS FACE ORTHODOXY FIGHT
description: ST. LOUIS, July 1An ecclesiastical struggle will culminate next Friday when the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod convenes in New Orleans.

title: ROY F. LAWSON, 80, ARCHITECT, DEAD
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1Roy Frank Lawson, an architect who was a leader in the city planning of the historic area of Philadelphia and who designed Independence Mall, died yesterday in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He, was 80 years old and lived in Radnor.

title: IRAQ DEFENSE AIDE SLAIN BY PLOTTERS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 1 The Defense Minister of Iraq was shot dead and the Interior Minister was wounded today in what the statecontrolled Baghdad radio described as an assassination engineered by the chief of internal security. Two police officers were also killed.

title: Today's Jazz Events
description: Following is a schedule of today's events in the Newport Jazz Festival  New York:

title: Bridge: 2 Combinations Stand Out As Obvious Opening Leads
description: For a player who has to choose an opening lead, there are two combinations that stick out like a sore thumb. One is an aceking, and another is a kingqueenjack. If you have one of these, it is hardly ever necessary to look any further.

title: Newman: Cool Jazzman
description: The tenor saxophonist and flute player David Newman moved coolly through two concerts at Carnegie Hall on Saturday  the wandering jazzman. The concerts, sponsored by Atlantic Records, were headlined by Donny Hathaway.

title: U.S. Nine Wins Finale
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 1 (UPI) Ed Bowman singled home Mark Barr in the bottom of the ninth inning today to give the United States Collegiate AllStars a 10 victory in the finale of a sevengame series with the Japanese AllStars. The United States team won the series five games to two.

title: CASPER IS VICTOR AFTER TWO YEARS
description: CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) Billy Casper swept past Bruce! Crampton and ended the long est, most dismal slump of his career with a charging victory today in the Western open golf tournament.

title: Beatrice Beach tied to Yoram Szekely
description: RYE, N. Y., July 1  Miss Beatrice Audrey Beach, a candidate for a doctorate in Soviet education at Columbia University, was married here this afternoon to Yoram BenHaim Szekely, who is in charge of developing the undergraduate library for the State University College at. Buffalo. Judge Isaac Rubin of the Rye City Court performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Easton Beach, father andstepmother of the bride.

title: Youth Gangs and Their Crimes Are on the Rise
description: Standing and sitting around a large table, the leaders of seven youth gangs some of them looking wary, some hostile, negotiated peace treaty the other day in the East 21st Street offices of the Police Department's Manhattan South headquarters.

title: British Family Sails Globe in a Catamaran
description: PLYMOUTH, England, July 1 (AP)A British gardener, his wife and their two children arrived here today after a 19month, 25,000mile sail around the world in their 30foot catamaran.

title: Cathy Rasher Is Bride of Mark Bathurst
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., July 1Miss Cathy Sue Rasher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Rasher of Mount Vernon, was married here this afternoon to Lieut. Mark Alan Bathurst, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Verne Bathurst of Fairfax, Va. Mount Vernon City Judge Irving B. Kendall performed the ceremony at the Briar Hall Country Club.

title: New Jersey Sports
INDUSTRY PLEDGES PAYOLASTUDY AID
description: The professional association of the recordings industry pledged yesterday that it would cooperate fully with any investigating bodies looking into alleged payola practices within the record business.

title: BRANDYWINE RACE GOES TO DARTSUM
description: STANTON, Del., July 1 (AP)Seymour Rose's Dartsum, ridden by Manuel Cedeno, accelerated through the stretch en route to winning the Brandy.. wine Turf Handicap today at Delaware Park. The winner's share was $19,175 from a gross purse of $29,500.

title: SCIENTISTS MEET ON SOLAR ENERGY
description: PARIS, July 1  Several hundred scientists from three dozen countries have gathered here for a conference on what many of them consider the woefully belated effort to make the sun, solve the earth's impending energy crisis.

title: MEDICAID PATIENTS FACE NEW CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) A Government proposal to be published tomorrow would require nearly four million Medicaid recipients to pay small enrollment fees and would allow states to impose the first patient costsharing in the program of medical assistance to the needy.

title: Leftist Group Says G.O.P. Aid Aimed at Democrats
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1Members of the Peace am Freedom party, a leftwing splinter group in California, sa they received secret funds fron Republicans last year to finance some of their campaign: and drain votes from the Democrats.

title: (Reprinted from yesterday's Ate editions.); Trumpeter First to Finish Newport to Bermuda Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 30 (AP) The 40foot trimaran TrumPeter, owned and piloted by the newspaper publisher Philip Weld of Gloucester, 1Mass., was the first craft to finish today in the fourth biennial NewportBermuda multihull race.

title: Newfoundland Captures Cape Cod Best in Show
7 SEW CLASSES TO MRS. BOYLEN
2 Groups to Challenge Hospitals That Resist Ruling on Abortion
description: Already begun in nine states, lawsuits to compel public hospitals to perform abortions, are being planned for the rest of the country.

title: STORE SALES RISE BY 14.4%, FOR MAY
Europeans Fear BoomBust Cycle in U.S.
description: PARIS, July 1The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, warning that economic policy will be put to a crucial test over the next 12 to 18 months in the United States, has urged Washington to consider adopting more flexible fiscal arrangements to keep things on an even keel and granting the President some extra, although limited, powers to deal with the problem.

title: Cubs Gain Split of 65 Contests on 3Run Belt
Bolshoi Bits and Pieces Often Jewels
description: The Bolshoi Ballet dancers at the Metropolitan Opera House are giving us bits and pieces, but some pieces are bigger and better than others. For their second program of the season, they presented on Saturday afternoon a complete and excellent second act from Giselle, the entire opera divertissement, Walpurgis Night and a different bill of highlights that compared favorably in both dancing and choreography with the one on opening night.

title: INTEREST RATES EXPECTED TO RISE
description: Interest rates climbed last week, some to their highest levels since early 1970, but they still have not risen as high as the markets seem to expect.

title: Blumenthal Plans 6Week Drive for Endorsements
description: While most voters probably will he paying attention to anything but municipal politics, the November mayoral election could well be settled in the next six weeks. That's about how much time Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, the Manhattan Democrat who is. the Liberal par tY mayoral nominee, has to lay the groundwork for a possible duplication of Mayor Lindsay's feat four years agowinning on the Liberal party line because the majorparty candidates were splitting the moderate and conservative vote.

title: Taiwan Is Buoyed by a Booming Economy in an Uncertain World
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The stable and flourishing domestio situation on Taiwan is in marked contrast with the uncertain international future facing this subtropical island 120 miles off the China coast.

title: 7 SHOW CLASSES TO MRS. BOYLEN
Red Smith
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, III., July 1In Canada this is Dominion Day and it coincides this year with the annual Potato Blossom Festival in Grand Falls, New Brunswick, where Ron Turcotte was foaled 31 years ago. Turcotte usually gallops horses on Sunday but he took this one off to return to the hometown and be hailed as the most prized local product outside of the Restigouche salmon and the pomme de terre. Town and Provincial authorities raised him to this pedestal because of his ability to ride as fast as Secretariat can run.

title: At Pratt, Accent Is on Latin
description: Three young bands played some very good Latin jazz and Latin pop in Pratt Institute's Memorial Hall on Saturday afternoon as part of the New York Musicians Five Boroughs Jazz Festival; but almost no one but friends and relatives heard them.

title: Industry in Rural South Sets U.S. Pace in Growth
Israeli Attache Shot Dead At Home Near Washington
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  An Israeli military attach was shot to death just after parking his car in the driveway of his home in a Washington suburb early this morning.

title: Petitioner to U.N. Nears End of 450Mile Trek
description: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., July 1 (AP)  Mrs. Catherine Hellwig marched 10 more miles under a hot sun today on her trek from Buffalo to New York City to dramatize the plight of 1,300 American servicemen still listed as missing in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Workers at Giant Chilean Mine End Their 10Week Walkout
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July (Reuters)Workers at Chile's giant El Teniente copper mine voted today to end a 10weekold strike that has cost the country some $70million.

title: No Parking Sometimes
description: With a flourish of publicity, twenty policemen have been assigned to the midtown area, each accompanied by a superior officer, with orders to issue a daily total of 2,000 summonses for parking violations. Is someone saying that police officers must have highranking chaperones to make sure that they do their job? And experience suggests that illegal parkingasusual will return as soon as the special enforcement ends. There should never be a quota on the number of summonses issued; the penalty should simply reflect the number of violations.

title: Happy Fans Savor Dixieland on Ride Up the Hudson
description: There is no doubt about it: New Orleans and Dixieland jazz makes people happy, and the passengers on yesterday's Hudson River Boatrides of the Newport Jazz Festival gave every indication of being very happy indeed.

title: ISRAELI DOCTORS SEEKING REFORMS
description: JERUSALEM, July 1  A strike by Israel's 6,000 doctors, now in its 25th day, has closed clinics all over the country and prompted calls for a fundamental reexamination of the nation's system of socialized medicine.

title: Yankee Go Home Lyle and Beene
Peterson Captures French Grand Prix After Scheckter and Fittipaldi Collide
description: LE CASTELLET, France, July 1 (UPI)A collision knocked the two leading cars out of the French Grand Prix today leaving Ronnie Peterson of Sweden clear to speed to victory. It was Peterson's first Grand Prix triumph.

title: House Unit Drops Limit on Courts for Secret Data
Saigon Reports 3 Attacks By Reds on Central Coast
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1 (UPI)The South Vietnamese command reported three Communist attacks today against Government units along Vietnam's central coast in what a Saigon spokesman said was the worst of weekend ceasefire violations.

title: Transfer of Patients Blocked by Strikers AtWyckoff Hospital
description: Striking nonmedical employes of Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn used picket lines yesterday to block the transfer of 78 patients from an annex to the hospital's main building three blocks away so that nonmedical services might be consolidated.

title: MARIO LABROCA, 76, ARTISTIC DIRECTOR
description: ROME, July 1.  Mario Labroca, a composer, conductor, writer and critic who served as artistic director of leading Italian musical institutions, died at his home here today. He was 76 years old.

title: N.E.A.SpeakerDenounces Shanker Over Racial Split
New England Fights Flooding as Waters Recede
MARY MILLS WINS BY SHOT WITH 217
description: ATLANTA, July 1 (AP) Mary Mills survived a sixway battle on the final nine holes today and sank a onefoot putt at the 18th for a par and a onestroke victory over 18yearold Laura Baugh and three tour veterans in the $30,000 Lady Tara golf classic.

title: French Driver Is Killed
description: LE MONT DORE, France, July 1 (AP)A French driver, Daniel Rouveyran, 33 years old, was killed today when his Formula One March left the road during a hill climb here and exploded after hitting some rocks.

title: Middlesex Stores'
description: NEWARK, June 26The New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit student corporation affiliated with Ralph Nader, recently completed two surveys of Middlesex County, one a fivemonth comparison of food prices and supermarket facilities, the other.a report detailing illegal baitandswitch advertising practices. Both were conducted by Rutgers students under the supervision of Ken Janoff, a senior in the school's premedical program.

title: IRAQ DEFENSE AIDE SLAIN BY PLOTTERS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 1 The Defense Minister of Iraq was shot dead and the Interior Minister was wounded today in what the statecontrolled Baghdad radio described as an assassination engineered by the chief of internal security. Two police officers were also killed.

title: Stockbroker Who Fought Burglars Denies Heroism
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July I'm not Audie Murphy, but I believe in fighting if you have a chance, said Charles H. Brunie, explaining today how he had battled three masked intruders from his sun porch to his back kitchen door early yesterday morning.

title: Montana Town Profits on Historic TKO
description: SHELBY, Mont.  For 50 years, businessmen here have been making hay out of 1923 promotion that was colossal financial flop. This week they will mark the disaster's golden anniversary.

title: Morgan Sets Indonesia Deal
description: The Morgan Guaranty International Finance Corporation, wholly owned subsidiary of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, has lin nounced it will acquire, subject to Federal Reserve Board approval, a 36 per cent interest in a new investment bank to be formed in the Republic of Indonesia.

title: Miss Kaufman Bride Of Howard C. Coan
description: MILWAUKEE, July 1At Temple EmanuEl B'ne Jeshurun here this afternoon, Miss Suzanne Kaufman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence. W. Kaufman, was married to Howard Charles Coan, son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Coan of Mamaroneck, N. Y. Rabbi Dudley Weinberg performed the ceremony.

title: Institutions Aid Youthful Options Exchange
description: CHICAGOInstitutional investors, accused of helping to drive the small shareholder from the marketplace, are now, being lauded for nourishing the nation's newest securities marketthe Chicago Board Op tions Exchange.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HONOLULU, July 1 (AP)Ken Norton of San Diego retained his. standing as No. I. contender in the World Boxing Association's heavyweight division, according to the W.B.A. ratings issued today. Norton will face the W.B.A.'s No. 2 contender, Muhammad Ali, in a return bout at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., Sept. 10.

title: Stockbroker Who Fought Burglars Denies Heroism
Police Terror
description: Last January the residence of William Pine in Winthrop, Mass., was broken into by fifteen burly men, wielding shotguns and terrifying the family. The intruders, turned out, were not burglars but state and Federal narcotics agents who had staged their noknock raid the wrong address. Mrs. Pine commented: I didn't know police operated like that in America.

title: DEMOCRATS PLAN A CAMPAIGN CODE
description: The scurrilous literature that embarrassed the BeameforMayor runoff campaign would be controlled and the general election campaign coordinated under an agreement being fashioned by the city's three frequently feuding dominant Democratic leaders, according to one of them.

title: Dick Sadler Dismissed As Foreman's Manager
description: HAYWARD, Calif., July 1 (UPI)The heavyweight boxing champion, George Foreman, has dismissed his manager of four years because he wants to handle business matters himself with help from his mother and a friend.

title: Bet Expert Who Doesn't Bertram Daniel Sarafan
description: The interim chairman of the new State Racing and Wagering Board is a toughminded career public servant who says he has never made a bet or bought a lottery ticket in his life. The appointment of Bertram D. Sarafan on Saturday, for what is not expected to be a lengthy tenure, caused few ripples in state circles. I think I got it because I was the only one home to answer the phone, the 60yearold chairman of the State Liquor Authority said.

title: Foyt Takes Schaefer 500; Only 7 of 33 Cars. Finish,
N.E.A.Speaker Denounces Shanker Over Racial Split
It's Rollins To Jarrett To Right On!
description: The Saturday evening Newpqrt Jazz Festival concert at Philharmonic Hall started in high gear and accelerated from there, ending up with something absolutely extraordinary. it was a distinguished evening of musicmaking, by criterion.

title: Horseshoe Contest Is Won by a Woman
description: MIDDLESEX, July 1Horsej shoe pitchers from the Middle Atlantic states gathered in! Mountain View Park here today and found that the men, who dominate the sport, hold! no monopoly on skill and endurance.

title: GAR WOOD RACE WON BY MISS BUDWEISER
description: DETROIT, July 1 (AP)Miss Budweiser won the first Gar Wood Trophy Race on the Detroit River today by churning the 15mile course at an average speed of about 102 miles an hour. The unlimited hydroplane had a top lap speed of 102 m.p.h.

title: Cargo Ship Rams Barge As It Awaits Fuel Off S.I.
description: Moving through dense fog in the Upper Bay off Staten Island yesterday morning, a cargo ship crashed into a barge that was about to take on fuel from tanker laden with 11 million gallons of chemicals, kerosene and jet fuel.

title: Europeans Fear BoomBust Cycle in U.S.
description: PARIS, July 1The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, warning that economic policy will be put to a crucial test over the next 12 to 18 months in the United States, has urged Washington to consider adopting more flexible fiscal arrangements to keep things on an even keel and granting the President some extra, although limited, powers to deal with the problem.

title: AvantGarde at Midnight
description: All the well established forms of jazzmainstream, bebop, Dixieland, postwar modern"were put on clear notice early Sunday morning: Run for cover. The avantgarde has arrived!

title: Legal Aid Talks Cut Off; Strike Will Begin Today
description: A strike by lawyers who work for the Legal Aid Society was scheduled to begin this morning following the collapse of last minute mediation efforts.

title: New Honda Engine Can Meet U.S. AntiPollution Rules
description: TOKYO, June 30We saw the pollution problem in Los Angeles back in the 1950's, and we knew that sooner or later Japan would have the same problem. Thus beganin the words of the Honda Motor Company's production director Hideo Sugiurathe development of a nearly pollutionfree engine that will go into production next fall.

title: Economist Found Seeds Of Slides in Profit Itself
description: Wesley Clair Mitchell, who was a professor of economics at Columbia University and a founder of the National Bureau of Economic Research, is widely regarded today as the father of modern analysis of booms and recessions in business. His classic monograph, Business Cycles and their Causes, from which the following excerpt was taken, was published by the University of California Press in 1913. It represented the first systematic description of the forces that lead to business expansions and contractions.

title: HAROLD WERNHER, HOST TO THE QUEEN
description: LONDON, July 1Sir Harold Wernher, an industrialist, racehorse owner and close friend of the Royal family, died today at Luton Hoo, his home in Bedfordshire. He was 80 years old.

title: NoFault Insurance Aide
description: John G. Day has been appointed New York State Deputy Superintendent of Insurance and will help to plan the state's nofault automobile insurance, which is to go into effect Feb. 1. Mr. Day was formerly special counsel on auto insurance and compensation to the Department of Transportation in Washington.

title: AID FOR PRISONERS IN VIETNAM URGED
description: LONDON, July 1Amnesty International today published a report on civilian prisoners in South Vietnam and called for urgent international pressure to obtain their release.

title: Haunted Frazier Returns To RinginLondonTonight
description: LONDON, July 1  Joe Frazier, who used to be heavyweight champion of the world, will try to begin his comeback tomorrow night, very far from home and friends.

title: Nathan Levine, 77, Head Of Bell Taxi Fleet, Is Dead
description: Nathan Levine, president of Bll Transportation System, one of the city's larger taxicab fleets, die dyesterday of heart failure at Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 19 Buckingham Road, Tenafly, N. J.

title: Possible Tropical Storm
description: MIAMI, July 1 (UPI)The National Hurricane Center said that a low pressure system centered about 500 miles north of the Dominican Republic was kicking up gale winds today and could develop into the season's first tropical storm.

title: First BlackControlled Bank Is Opened in Newark
Evelyn de Rothschild, Banker, Marries Victoria Lou Schott
description: Miss Victoria Lou Schott was married here last evening to Evelyn de Rothschild of London, son of Mrs. Anthony de Rothschild of Ascott, Wing, Buckinghamshire, England, and the late Mr. de Rothschild. Rabbi David Seligson performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Schott, parents of the bride.

title: MISS BUDWEISER TAKES GAR WOOD
description: DETROIT, July 1 (AP)Miss Budweiser won the first Gar Wood Trophy race on the Detroit River today by churning the 15mile course at an average speed of 102 miles an hour.

title: Robin Greenwald Wed to Psychologist
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., July Miss Robin Carol Greenwald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Greenwald of Garden City, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Gerald Paul Koocher, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Koocher of Cambridge, Mass. Rabbis Robert S. Widom and Meyer Miller officiated at Temple Emanuel.

title: Minor Fire Halts Cruise of Homeric
description: The 26,000ton passenger ship Homeric, which sailed from New York for a West Indies cruise on Saturday, will return to port this morning after what was termed a minor fire in her galley.

title: Modest Hope for Ulster
description: The results of the election for a new Northern Ireland Assembly provide modest hopes for moving the bitterly divided province toward workable government and peace. Altogether, the political forces willing to bury old differences and share power on a proportional basis across, sectarian lines will control more than twothirds of the seats in the 78member Assembly.

title: COLSON SAYS DEAN MISLED PRESIDENT ABOUT WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 Charles W. Colson, the former White House aide, said today that President Nixon had complained to him of not being told the truth about the Watergate scandal even after John W. Dean 3d hadsupposedly disclosed all the facts to the President.

title: Nixon Signs Social Security Increase
SURVEY DISCLOSES GAINS FOR BLACKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 1There has been dramatic improvement in the last decade in the economic situation of black Americans who are working, study released by the Brookings Institution today concluded.

title: Blumenthal Plans 6Week Drive for Endorsements
description: While most voters probably will be paying attention to anything but municipal politics, the November Mayoral election could well be settled in the next six weeks. That's about how much time Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, the Manhattan Democrat who is the Liberal party mayoral nominee, has to lay the groundwork for a possible duplication of Mayor Lindsay's feat four years agowinning on the Liberal party line because the majorparty candidates were splitting the moderate and conservative vote.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Late last winter, a couturier opened a chic bistro here that was reviewed under the caption: The Place Looks GreatBut the Food Is Another Matter. We are relieved to learn from its press representative that the place has nonetheless attracted the most impressive clientele in town, as the attached list will support.

title: Newport Jazz
description: Like a bright sun blinding drivers emerging from dark tunnels, there was a burst of musical energy on the Alice Tully Hall stage Saturday night that struck the audience so fast and so forcefully that some in the small crowd chose to leave quickly.

title: U. S. Aides Believe China Has Met Snags In Developing NuclearArmed Missiles
description: WASHINGTON. July 1 China is continuing to make fairly rapid progress in the development of nuclear warheads, in the opinion of Defense Department and Atomic Energy Commission officials, but she appears to have run into technical difficulties in developing the missiles to deliver them.

title: Order and Chaos
description: ALDEBURGH, EnglandIt is noon when Billy Burrell's boat comes in. The men haul her up on the stony, beach and unload the baskets of fish. There are already half a dozen customers waiting at Billy's small but for the freshcaught sole and skate.

title: Troy Says Police Pledge To Add Overtime Work
description: A very high source in the Police Department has promised that policemen will be assigned one day of overtime every two weeks, starting soon, City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. said yesterday.

title: Chang Shihchao Is Dead; Veteran Chinese Politician
description: HONG KONG, July 1 (Agence FrancePresse)  Chang Shihchao, a veteran Chinese politician, who arrived here on May 25 amid rumors that he was to negotiate peace with representatives of Taiwan, died today at age of 92, the Hong Kong branch of the Hsinhua press agency said.

title: P.O.W. Hinted a Suicide
description: DENVER, July 1 (UPI)  An incomplete autopsy report indicates that Abel Larry Kavanaugh, former prisoner of war accused by a senior officer of collaborating with the enemy, committed suicide, according to a source within the coroner's office.

title: U.S. Five Wins in Shanghai
description: TOKYO, July 1 (AP)A United States collegiate allstar men's basketball team beat a Shanghai team, 9661, today but the John F. Kennedy College Patriettes lost, 6354, to Shanghai women's squad, the official Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, reported.

title: Youth Gangs and Their Crimes Are on the Rise
Wyckoff Hospital Strikers Block Transfer of Patients
description: Striking nonmedical employes of Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklynused picket lines yesterday to block the transfer of 78 patients from an annex to the hospital's main building three blocks away so that nonmedical services might be consolidated.

title: Racism, Ethics and Rights at Issue in Sterilization Case
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 1 Lonnie and Minnie Relf have never known the good life.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Cheryl Crawford Collection, consisting of thousands of theater items, has been acquired by the Theater Collection of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. Gathered during nearly half a century of theatrical activity by the producermanager, the collection includes correspondence, business records, photographs of many productions, original scripts, financial statements, scrapbooks and stage designs.

title: Troy Says Police Pledge To Add Overtime Work
description: A very high source in the Police litepartment has promised that policemen will be assigned one day of overtime every two weeks, starting soon, City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. said yesterday.

title: Possible Tropical Storm
description: MIAMI, July 1 (UPI)The National Hurricane Center said that a low pressure system centered about 500 miles north of the Dominican Republic was, kicking up gale winds today and could develop into the sea , son's first tropical storm.

title: Books of The Times
description: Everyone agrees that the Museum of Modern Art is the greatest institution of its kind in the world. And everyone not permanently afflicted with utopian delusions knows that great institutions are built at a high cost in human sacrifice. No matter how lofty its aims, no matter how beneficent its services, no matter how essential to our lives the results may be, even the greatest of institutions prospers by consuming its own most creative minds. To implement a noble objective, it is necessary to have a functioning bureaucratic structure, and it is only a matter of time before the structure (and its attendant politics) first modifies and then dominates the objective. The momentum of this change may be temporarily softened or delayed, but it cannot be permanently forestalled. Success, even more than failure, exacts a heavy toll.

title: Mrs. Rose Carlebach Dies; Led Housing Council Here
description: Mrs. Rose Goldman Carlebach, chairman of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council and of the housing committee of the Officers Service Committee in World War II, died yesterday in her apartment in the Sherry Netherland Hotel. She was 78 years old and the widow of Herbert L. Carlebach, a member of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS FREEZE EFFECTIVE IN HOLDING PRICES
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 1President Nixon said today in a nationwide radio address that prices were being held stable under the temporary freeze he ordered 18 days ago and we are determined that prices will continue to be held.

title: ENZO DELL OREFICE
description: Enzo Dell Orefice, coach and accompanist of Enrico Caruso from 1910 to 1913, died Friday in St. Barnabas Home for Chronic Diseases, the Bronx. He was 86 years old and lived in the Ansonia Hotel.

title: TENANTS REVIVE STRIKE IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, July 1 (AP)  The nation's longest public housing rent strike, which ended last April 3 after three years, appeared to be resuming today.

title: ORIOLES'
description: DETROIT, July 1 (UPI) Manager Earl Weaver of the Baltimore Orioles today called the umpiring team headed by John Rice the worst umpiring crew I've seen in all my years fin baseball.

title: This Rock Festival Is Just That
description: GILSUM, N. H. When people here talk about rock festival they mean thatrocks.

title: Parents Occupying P. S. 208 See Local Control at Stake
description: For the parents who have been occupying the auditorium of Public School 208 since school ended last Wednesday, the issue is simple: They want the right to pick the principal of the East Flatbush school.

title: CITY TO EXTEND BAN ON PARKING
description: The city's two top traffic officials said yesterday that the twoweek experimental crackdown on parkers in the midtown area had produced good results.

title: Ruth L. Tershel Bride of T. N. Mirvis
description: In the Lincoln Square Synagogue last evening, Miss. Ruth Lynn Tershel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Tershel of Flushing, Queens, was married to Theodore Neal Mirvis, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Allan Mirvis of. Hampton, Va.

title: Nancy Mitford, Author, Dead; Satiric Novelist and Essayist
description: LONDON, July 1  Nancy Mitford, the prolific essayist, novelist and historian whose writing was enlivened by satire and a firm British aristocratic perspective, died yesterday at her home in Versailles, France. She was 68 years old.

title: Israeli Attache Shot Dead At Home Near Washington
Anthenagoras, 71, Victor In $125,200 German Derby
description: HAMBURG, Germany, July (UPI)Anthenagoras, a 71 outsider, set a record today in winning the 104th German Derby.

title: Connors NowWimbledon CoFavorite
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 1The Wimbledon tennis tournament, bereft of 70 pros by a boycott and deprived of its topseeded player by one of the most amazing upsets in its history, was searching today for a winner of suitable stature.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Tenants in some 300,000 rentstabilized apartments yesterday became eligible to renew expiring leases under the rentincrease ceiling established by the city on July 1972.

title: Howard of Jersey Plans Energy CoverUp Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) The chairman of a House energy panel said today that his subcommittee would hold hearings to determine if the energy crisis was really an energy coverup.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There has been a great deal of emotionalism surrounding the Alaska pipeline issue, particularly in light of the socalled energy crisis. Both the President and the Secretary of the Interior are pressing Congress to approve a specific route for the pipeline immediately.

title: Edlefsen, Jeanne Evert Win Southern Net Finals
description: RALEIGH, N. C., July 1 (AP) Topseeded Tom Edlefsen and Jeanne Evert captured the singles titles today in the Southern tennis championships.

title: Dick Sadler Dismissed As Foreman's Manager
description: HAYWARD, Calif., July (UPI)The heavyweight boxing champion, George Foreman, has dismissed his manager of four years because he wants to handle business matters himself with help from his mother and a friend.

title: The Zionists Pay $875,000 For 34th St. Headquarters
description: The Zionist Organization of America has announced that it has bought a fivestory building at 4 East 34th Street to serve as its new national headquarters.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A white marble angel from the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer in Flatbush, Brooklyn; has taken up residence in the austere sanctuary of the Flatbush Presbyterian Churchfor the two congregations have combined.

title: Advertising: Social Security
description: A major task of the Social Security Administration is effectively communicating with the 94million Americans whose lives it touches.

title: Updating the Census
description: The framers of the Constitution considered accurate population data of such importance that they provided for a decennial census. At that time, the information was needed primarily for allocating membership in the House of Representatives and for apportioning taxes. The Constitutional Convention assumed that population growth and change would be slow enough that fresh data every decade would be adequate.

title: Woman Is Killed by IRT Train Alter IND Rescue
description: A 31yearold woman was killed yesterday afternoon when she jumped or fell under a subway, train in the Times Square IRT station. Less than three hours before, she had been pulled to safety by policemen after a train passed over her as she lay between the rails of the subway track one block away, the police reported.

title: De Vries Wins in Belgium
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, July 1 (UPI)Jan De Vries of The Netherlands, riding a Kreidler, regained the lead in the 50cc motorcycling world championship standings with a victory today in the Belgian Grand Prix.

title: Minor Fire Hails Cruise of Homeric
description: The 26,000ton passenger ship Homeric, which sailed for a West Indies cruise on Saturday, will return to port this morning after what was termed a minor fire in her gallery.

title: Pollution in Italy Is Traced to Shift to the Cities
description: ROME, July 1Large popu!atoll, shifts from rural districts to the expanding metropolitan areas and particularly to the seacoasts during the last decade have contributed to dramatic deterioration of Italy's environment.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS FREEZE EFFECTIVE IN HOLDING PRICES
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 1President Nixon said today in a nationwide radio address that prices were being held stable under the temporary freeze he ordered 18 days ago and we are determined that prices will continue to be held.

title: JAPANESE RESERVES FALL $669MILLION
description: TOKYO, July 1 (Reuters)Japan's external reserves fell to $15.2billion at the end of June, down $669million from the previous month, the Finance Ministry announced over the weekend.

title: 3 Injured by Firecracker
description: PALMDALE, Calif., July (UPI)Three young men who wanted to get a threeday lead on the Fourth of July were hospitalized in serious condition today when their oil drum firecracker exploded prematurely. Joseph Ruccione and Theodore Bolick suffered burns and fractures. Darrel Zydyk had second degree burns over much of his body.

title: Drop in Polio Immunization Seen Conducive to Epidemic
description: ATLANTA, July 1 (AP).A public health official warned today that immunization against polio was dropping to a level that might permit epidemics to recur in the United States.

title: Soaring Economy Is Sparking Debate Over Its Consequences and Duration
description: At the midpoint of 1973, the American economyis at the crest of a roaring booma boom, however, that appears to carry within Itself the seeds of thenext business slowdown.

title: Pagels Wins 4th Title in Row In Great South Bay Sailing
description: WEST BABYLON, L.I., July 1  Billy Pagels of the Wet Pants Sailing Association captured his fourth straight Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association men's championship today. Earlier this season, Pagels won the association's singlehanded title for the fourth time in five years.

title: Walpole Sued on Suicide
description: BOSTON, July 1, (AP)The mother of an inmate who cornmiteted suicide last January at Walpole state prison has filed a $2.3million suit against a former Walpole superintendent and three correction officers. Lawyers for Mrs. Matilda Giedymin, mother of Joseph Shesnula.vich Jr., filed the suit in United States District Court on Friday.

title: Prague Is Slowly Improving Western Ties, Ending Isolation Begun in 1968
description: PRAGUE, June 29  On a recent evening in Mlada Boleslav, a garrison town for Soviet troops 35 miles northeast of Prague, a dozen young privates in neat new uniforms stood behind a big iron gate of a headquarters compound and peered at Czechs passing by. The Czechs seemed not to notice them.

title: Miss Seiler Marries Here
description: In the Fifth Avenue Synagogue here yesterday afternoon, Miss Jane Seiler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Seiler of Manhattan, became the bride of Munir Saltoun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haron Saltoun of Rochester.

title: Terry Fischgrund Has Nuptials
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 1 Miss Terry Fischgrund and Warren Steven Kriedman were married here this afternoon in the garden at the home of the bride's parents, Mr, and Mrs. Herbert B. Fischgrund. Rabbi Leonard Poller of the Larchmont Temple performed the ceremony.

title: FEWER POOR AND RISE IN INCOME REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)The number of Americans officially living in poverty dropped by more than one million last year while the purchasing power of families rose, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: ShakeUp In ShangriLa
description: WASHINGTON  Republican National Chairman George Bush sat next to me at a showing of the remake of Lost Horizon, James Hilton's fantasy about a perfect society where people of goodwill could live lives of extraordinary duration and happiness.

title: HISPANICS AND POLES CLASH IN BROOKLYN
description: Two large antagonistic crowds of Hispanic and Polish extraction were confined to opposite street corners by the police last night following an ethnic barroom brawl in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: Jersey City Councilman Holds Own SwearingIn
New Test for Police Applicants Will Aid Minority Candidates
description: The city has asked a New York consulting concern to prepare new tests for prospective policemen that would incorporate equalemployment requirements for minority aplicants.

title: N.A.A.C.P. MEETS, FACING NEW FIGHT
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 1The fight over school integration is an old theme for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, but it will be a prominent issue as the organization opens its 64th annual convention here tomorrow.

title: Cambodian Troops Battle Communists With Lighter U.S. Support
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 1 (UPI)Communist and Cambodian Government troops battled north and southwest of Phnom Penh today, with the Government troops receiving lighter than usual United States air support.

title: Personal Finance
description: The era of electronic money has been quietly moving closer in recent weeks. It is a vision that many bankers cherish  computers automatically depositing salary checks directly to the depositors bank accounts, then paying their bills for rent, mortgages, loan installments, insurance premiums, charge accounts, and other items.

title: Bradley Inaugurated As Los Angeles Mayor
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1 (UPI)Thomas Bradley, after taking the oath as the first black Mayor of Los Angeles, said today in his inaugural address that the chance given him says more about this city's decency and sense of fairness than 100 speeches,

title: Roundup: Pirates Win Twice, Streak Goes to 5
description: Just one week ago, the Pittsburgh Pirates were in last place in the National League's Eastern Division, nine games out of first place, and seemingly in no mood to make a defense of their division title.

title: HAMPTON HOUSES OPENED IN HARLEM
description: Lionel Hampton Houses, a 355unit apartment complex on Eighth Avenue and 131st Street, Was opened officially yesterday With a rousing parade, an elaborate cornerstone laying ceremony and an hour's worth of speechesmost of them heaping praise upon the jazzman who put up some of the money to get the project going. Mr. Hampton, smiling and sweating profusely under a midafternoon sun that melted the tar on the street, modestly referred to the towers around him as a small step to bring needed lowincome and moderateincome housing to central Harlem.

title: Toronto Routs Veracruz, 70
description: TORONTO, July 1 (Canadian Press)The Toronto Metros routed the touring Veracruz soccer team of Mexico, 7.0, before 6,224 fans today. The seven goals set a game record for the Metros and its was the third consecutive shutout for their goaltender.

title: COLSON SAYS DEAN MISLED PRESIDENT ABOUT WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 Charles W. Colson, the former White House aide, said today that President Nixon had complained to him of not being told the truth about the Watergate scandal even after John W. Dean 3d had supposedly disclosed all the facts to the President.

title: George Cooke Jr., 73, Dies; ExHead of Princeton Fund
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 1George J. Cooke Jr., retired executive director of the Princeton University Fund, who subsequently was president of the American Alumni Council, died today at his home on Ettl Farm. He was 73 years old.

title: International Panel Seeks Basic Accounting Standard
description: Accountants from nine countries have formed a committee to recommend basic accounting standards that could be accepted internationally, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants announced over the weekend.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HIS BAG Bob Sparks intends to make the first transAtlantic solo balloon flight sometime this month, from Bar Harbor, Me., to northern France. This week, however, he and his balloon will be spending time only as high as the 12thfloor rooftop of his outfitter, Abercrombie & Fitch, 45th Street and Madison Avenue (6823600).

title: There Are Plastic Gnomes in Washington
