description: LONDONConscious though I am that the American political structure is as different from the. British political structure as chalk from cheese, the Watergate inquiry terrifies me when I watch it on my TV here in London. It confirms all my suspicions that there are too many men in the world, and that this is not a good thing.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commis. sion is urging the 118 New Jersey municipalities that dump garbage in the Meadowlands to develop newspaper re cycling plans. The move was urged in letters the commission sent over the weekend.

title: City Dancers Essay New Dream Roles At Season's Finale
description: For the last weekend before going to its summer home in Saratoga Springs, the New York City Ballet introduced a flurry of cast changes in Midsummer Night's Dream at State Theater. The results were mixed.

title: U.S. Polo Team Defeats English Squad to Win Cup
description: MIDHURST, England, July (AP)  Langham, a polo team from the United States, won the Duke of Sutherland Cup today with an 861/2 victory over Jersey Lilies, a local team.

title: That Home on the Range Is Bobby Hull's
description: WINNIPEG, ManitobaJoanne Hull is kind of glad her husband is millionaire even if he doesn't act like one.

title: Four Seeded Players Gain In Martin Tennis Tourney
A Thesis That Impeachment Is Here and How
description: Although the United States is still junior among nations, its Government, with a continuous existence of nearly two centuries, is the oldest on earth. The fact of such survival in the face of colossal changes in its technological, social, and economic environment is proof of an astonishing power of adaptation. This may give us confidence that our nation and Government will once again manage, in one way or another, to adapt successfully to the crise de regime, as the French would call it, that the Watergate affair has become.

title: Quake Hits Sitka, Alaska; Minor Damage Is Reported
description: PALMER, Alaska, July 1 (AP) The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration observatory said an earthquake struck today about 100 miles northwest of Sitka. Minor damage was reported.

title: Northeastern Rows to 2d Place
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, July 1 (AP)Northeastern University's varsity eight, the American sprint champions, finished second to a formidable Soviet Union crew today at an international rowing regatta.

title: Registration Will Begin For Summer Youth Jobs
description: Amalia Betanzos, the city's Commissioner of Youth Services, says the city will be able to hire 30,000 youths under funds now available for the summer Neighborhood Youth Corps, with hopes for 20,000 more depending on Federal legislation now before Congress.

title: Washington Crew Victor; Long Islander 3d in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, July 1 (AP)The eightoar crew from the University of Washington took its division of the second rowing championship of the Americas today, skimming 2,000 meters under a heavy rain as the meet ended.

title: Deep Discontent, Material and Spiritual, Is Being Voiced Openly in Rumania and Ceausescu Is Target
African Envoys Say U.S. Aid on Drought May Be Too Little
description: WASHINGTON, July 1With a severe drought threatening starvation for at least six million people in the subSaharan region, African diplomats are questioning whether the $24million in American assistance in the form of food grain and its transportation is enough.

title: An Imaginative Approach
description: One thing the new generation in jazz has to offer, judging by the first program in a series called JazzThe New Generation that the Carnegie Hall Corporation is presenting at Carnegie Recital Hall during the Newport Jazz Festival, is a fresh, imaginative approach to basically familiar musical styles.

title: Miss Chananau Wed to Lawyer
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 1Miss Rosalind H. Chananau and Robert H. Beck, 1970 graduates of Cornell University, were married at Beth El Synagogue here this afternoon. Rabbi Morris Berman performed the cere. mony, assisted by Rabbi David J. Golovensky.

title: NIXON'S LAND POLICY CALLED INEQUITABLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The Nixon Administration's policy of disposing of surplus Government lands is grossly inequitable, a report on shelter and surplus lands charged today.

title: Vientiane Plan Is Reported Turned Down by Pathet Lao
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July (Reuters)The Vientiane Government has proposed to the proCommunist Pathet Lao that the two sides form a coalition government with a neutral premier and two deputy premiers, a source close to the Government delegation to the talks said here.

title: Food Price Inflation
description: The case for stronger Government action to halt the worst inflation of the postwar era had become overwhelmingboth economically and politicallywhen the Administration ended its disastrous Phase 3 program two weeks ago. But its new price freeze has hit the economy at a time of much more rapidly rising demand with less idle capacity than when the first freeze was imposed during the late summer and early fall of 1971. Economic conditions are very different today from those of the earlier periods, President Nixon said yesterday. The rules of Phase 4 will, therefore, have to be different.

title: 2 Flatbush Congregations Unite for Survival
description: A white marble angel from the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn has taken up residence in the austere sanctuary of the Flatbush Presbyterian Church.

title: Grantham, Linebacker for Jets, Retires and Joins Radio Crew
description: Larry Grantham, the New York Jets lightweight linebacker who hit like a heavyweight, yesterday announced his retirement as a player and the start of his career as a radio broadcaster. An original member of this football franchise in 1960, Grantham will help broadcast the Jets games this season on WOR radio with Marty Glickman, the playbyplay an. nouncer.

title: People and Business
description: W. Joseph Biggers has been named president and chief executive officer of American Business Products, Inc. He succeeds Henry Curtis, who will continue as chairman and chairman of the finance committee of the Atlantabased printing company.

title: INJURED PUPIL GIVEN RIGHT TO SUE SCHOOL
description: TRENTON, July 2 (AP)A state appeals court ruled today that the City of Passaic might be sued by a student who suffered permanent bone damage when he cut. himself on a rusted fence surrounding his public school.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry Set Into Deal Involving Cohen Goren Firm
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered formal hearings today on staff charges of manipulation and other fraudulent practices against Cohen Goren Equities, Inc. and seven other New York brokerage firms.

title: A LATE HOME RUN AGAIN SINKS METS
CALLEY MOVE DENIED BY MILITARY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) The highest court of military law turned down today at tempts by attorneys for First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. to make the Government disclose any White House involvement in the investigation of the My, Lai slayings.

title: Mrs. King Says 60 Women Are in New Association
description: LONDON, July 2 (Reuters)Mrs. Billie Jean King said today that the new Women's Tennis Association had 60 leading players as members.

title: Reviving the Court
description: The sorry plight of the International Court of Justice, long widely ignored and now openly defied by Iceland and France, adds urgency to a new effort in Congress to ease, if not to eliminate entirely, previously imposed reservations regarding the United States own acceptance of the court's jurisdiction.

title: Chess: Russia's Hopes for Future Now Riding With Karpov
WEICKER OPPOSES NIXON SUBPOENA
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who has been sharply critical of the Nixon Administration over the Watergate affair, said today that he did not believe the Senate Watergate Committee should try to subpoena President Nixon.

title: Peking Avoids Any Celebration Of the Party's 52d Anniversary
description: HONG KONG, July 2  The 52d anniversary of the Communist party in China came and went yesterday without any celebrations of the event, suggesting that the party may still not have recoVered from the disruptions caused by the disappearance of its deputy leader, Lin Piao, and the persisting aftereffects of the Cultural Revolution.

title: Uruguayan Workers Defy Army And Continue a General Strike
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 2 (Reuters)Most of Uruguay's workers refused today to end a fiveday general strike, presenting President Juan Maria Bordaberry's militarybacked regime with serious problems.

title: Louis J. Russell Is Dead at 61; Investigator for Hiss Trial
description: Louis James Russell, who served as chief investigator for the House unAmerican Activities Committee during its investigations into domestic Communist influence, died in Washington, yesterday after a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

title: REPLY IS SEATED
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 2President Nixon will speak out on charges that have been made against him in the Watergate case after the select Senate committee completes the current phase of its hearings, Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, said today.

title: Ahumada Triumphs In U.S. Ring Debut, Stops Carroll in 8th
description: Jorge Ahumada, an Argentine lightheavyweight, was successful in his first fight in the United States as he scored a technical knockout over Hal Carroll of Syracuse in the eighth round of their scheduled 10round bout at the Felt Forum last night.

title: Equity Financing
description: First International Bancshares announced yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a secondary offering of 500,000 common shares to be sold by certain shareholders through Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith, Goldman Sachs & Co. and Dominick & Dominick, Inc. The company will not receive any of the proceeds ,of the offering. First International Bancshares closed at 433A, up 1/4, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)The Government has quietly shelved a proposal that could have allowed mortgage interest rates to rise and fall according to the state of the economy, it was learned today. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board confirmed that the idea of variableinterest rate mortgages, introduced with much fanfare a year ago, had been dropped.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION

title: Ranger Rookie Injured
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 2 (UPI)Steve Foucault, a rookie relief pitcher for the Texas Rangers, broke his left shoulder today in an outfield collision with Coach JackleMoore during pregame warmups. Foucault and Moore were catching fly balls when they collided.

title: Censure of Lawyer for Likening Judges to Whores Is Reversed
description: The Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that a prominent New York criminal lawyer should not have been censured by the Appellate Division of the. Supreme Court in Manhattan for remarks likening some judges to whores who become madams.

title: 2 DEBENTURES SET By GULF &
description: Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., reported yesterday that it expected to issue a total of about $87million principal amount in two series of new 30year, 7 per cent subordinated debentures as a result of exchange offers made for its own securities.

title: HAROLD V. VENHO
description: GLEN ROCK, N. J., July 2Harold V. Venho, a television director for the National Broadcasting Company, died Friday in the Valley Hospital in Ridge wood, after a long illness. He was 46 years old and lived here.

title: Real Estate Blues
description: I had always thought it would be an awful thing to be President of the United States, writes a man from Iowa, but I am having second thoughts since reading about the household improvements President Nixon has had Installed in his California and Florida houses. In fact, am now thinking seriously about announcing my candidacy for President, since I have read somewhere that the Secret Service takes a protective interest even in mere candidates.

title: Laurens Hammond Dies at 78; Invented Electric Organ in 30's
description: CORNWALL, Conn., July 2Laurens Hammond, inventor of the electric organ, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 78.

title: Allende's Bid for Siege Powers Rejected
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 2 (AP) The lower house of Chile's Parliament tonight refused to heed President Salvador Allende Gossens's warning that the country was on the border of a new civil war, and rejected his call for a state of siege.

title: Radio
Ethnic Fighting in Greenpoint Ends as 2 Sides Talk
description: The streets in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn were calm last night following a closeddoor meeting between Polish and Puerto Rican community leaders during which both sides agreed to discuss the differences that had led to gang fights over the weekend.

title: 171 Civilians Given First Police Orders
description: One hundred seventyone civilians were inducted into the New York City Police Department yesterday and promptly tasted their first dose of paramilitary discipline.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 29112
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win 325. Tickets with all live numbers scrambled in $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second end third, the third end fourth or the fourth and fifth win 32.50.

title: Fire Rages Out of Control In Wilderness of California
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., July 2 (UPI)  Firefighters roped themselves together like mountain climbers today to battle raging brush fire as it spread to rugged, sheer cliff country in the San Jacinto wilderness area.

title: Nicos Vardinoyiannis, 42, Dies; Shipowner Donated to Nixon
description: ATHENS, July 2  Nicos Vardinoyiannis, a shipowner who amassed a fortune within a decade and whose $25,000 contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign cornbined with a United States Navy oil supply contract came under Congressional investigation this year, died of a heart attack today. He was 42 years old.

title: Doctors Find Pattern of Birth Defects Among Children of Alcoholic Mothers
description: Doctors in Seattle have identified a pattern of serious birth defects among children born to women who are chronic alcoholics.

title: FREEZE ON PRICES HELD INEFFECTIVE
Correction Officer Is Held As Head of Cocaine Ring
description: A correction officer assigned to guarding prisoners in the detention pens of Criminal Court and State Supreme Court in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday as the leader of a ring that allegedly operated a $1millionayear business in cocaine.

title: Poker Night, $2.60, Takes Aqueduct Mile
description: Poker Night of the Hobeau Farm was the real good thing on yesterday's Aqueduct program. The 21,783 fans in attendance on the first day of the reduced admission price policy were quite aware of the filly's potential, and they backed her almost as if she were Secretariat in the feature for fillies and mares.

title: McIntire Asks F.C.C. to Reconsider Lifting of His Radio License
description: COLLINGSWOOD, July 2The Rev. Carl McIntire, fundamentalist pastor of the Bible Presbyterian Church here has petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to reconsider a ruling to put his controversial radio station offl the air Thursday.

title: The Right to Die
description: Renewed discussion of euthanasia has been aroused by two recent dramatic incidents. In one, a young man was accused of fatally shooting his brother who had been paralyzed in a motorcycle accident and who had begged for death; in another, a physician has been charged with the wilful murder of a cancer victim who was in comatose state and was believed to have two days most to live.

title: R.I. SAVINGS BANK TO CHANGE STATUS
description: The Old Stone Savings Bank, Rhode Island's largest mutual savings bank, with assets of $648million, announced plans to convert itself into a stockholderowned commercial bank.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Yanks'
Stocks Fall in Slow Day On InterestRate Climb
CON ED DROPS BID FOR ATOMIC PLANT
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 2The Consolidated Edison Company has abandoned its plan to build a nuclear power plant on Da vids Island in Long Island Sound a half mile from New Rochelle.

title: SURVEY HAILS PRESS ON WATERGATE ROLE
description: By 56 to 18 per cent, a majority of Americans believe that if it had not been for the press exposes the Watergate scandal would never have been uncovered, the Louis Harris survey reported yesterday.

title: Supreme Court Divided But Still Unpredictable
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Supreme Court's record for the term that closed last week reflected a bench divided ideologically and politically and moving overall toward a more conservative posture but with its members still unpredictably independent on some major social issues.

title: HOSPITAL DRIVERS SCORED IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, July 2 (UPI) An Essex County grand jury returned a presentment today, citing an astonishing number of cases in which ambulance drivers at Martland Hospital used narcotics, were intoxicated on duty and were shockingly inefficient.

title: Fighting Restrained Along Cambodian River
description: PREK KDAM, Cambodia, July 2  Government and Communistled troops looked curiously at each other from opposite banks of the narrow Tonle Sap River here today, but both sides held their fire, apparently to avoid civilian casualties.

title: TOP PEKING ENVOY IN U.S. WILL MEET PRESIDENT FRIDAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Huang Chen, China's senior diplomat in Washington, will fly to San Clemente for talks at the California White House with President Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger on Friday.

title: Food Prices in Manhattan Highest of Five Boroughs
description: The cost of feeding a family of four increased by only onetenth of 1 per cent in the city last week. At the same time, a comparison of food prices in the five boroughs by the Consumer Affairs Department showed that they were highest in Manhattan.

title: G.O.P. UNIT TIGHTENS CAMPAIGN FINANCING
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)  The Senate Republican Campaign Committee said today that it was implementing strict new campaign financing rules, including a ban on cash contributions in excess of $25.

title: SAIGON IS EXPELLING JAPANESE REPORTER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2 (UPI)The South Vietnamese Government has asked the chief Saigon correspondent for Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's leading newspapers, to leave Vietnam because his paper carried an editorial saying Saigon was holding political prisoners.

title: NATIONAL KINNEY BIDDING FOR URIS
description: The Uris Buildings Corporation has a new suitor.

title: ATLANTA N.A.A.C.P. GIVEN ULTIMATUM
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 2 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People moved today to force one of its strongest local units, the Atlanta branch, back into line on the organization's school integration policy.

title: END OF DRY SPELL BOLSTERS CASPER
description: Tom Weiskopf, Chi Chi Rodriguez, Lou Graham and Homero Blancas are members of a United States Ryder Cup golf team for the first time, according to the compilation that ended Sunday. But the squad's happiest member is Billy Casper, who earned a place for the seventh time.

title: Claremont Stables Get 2Year Reprieve From the Bulldozer
description: The Claremont riding stables, Manhattan's only such enterprise will be around for at least two more years, Parks Commissioner Richard Clurman said yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, July 2 (UPI)Vasily Stankovich, one of th favorites, was ousted from the world fencing championships minutes after competition started today. The Soviet Union's 1971 world champion, who was ranked sixth on last year's world list, lost two of his matches In the men's foils qualifications and dropped out as 12 others advanced to the semifinals.

title: Avis Planning Acquisition
description: Avis Rent A Car System, Inc., has reached agreement in principle to acquire AllState Vehides, Inc., a New Yorkbased carleasing concern.

title: I.T.T. Elects an Officer
description: Richard Hodgson was elected, yesterday as a corporate senior vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. He had been vice president and product group managerelectronic, illumination and instrumentation products since July 1969. Mr. Hodgson'] joined I. T. T. in September,1968.

title: MRS. FELICIA ESPOSITO
description: Mrs. Felicia Visone Esposito, mother of Meade Esposito, the Kings County Democratic leader, died yesterday in Brookdale Hospital. She was 90 years old and the widow of Giuseppe Esposito who founded Pep's Restaurant in Brooklyn, which she carried on after his death until her retirement in 1971. She lived at 9515 Avenue M in Brooklyn.

title: Bridge: A System for Responding To a Strong Club Opening
description: Strong club systems have proliferated in recent years, and nearly all of them agree that the strong artificial opening bid needs about 17 highcard points, give or take a point. But there is a wide divergence of view about the best way to respond, with a sharp division between those favoring natural responses and those preferring artificial controlshowing responses.

title: 2 New Combos Display Wares
description: The title of the Newport: Jazz Festival's New Generation series at Carnegie Recital Hall might seem to suggest a dual purpose: to present young jazz musicians and to give a public forum for experimental approaches to jazz. Sunday night's concert fulfilled the first purpose but did not really even try to fulfill the second.

title: Lindsay Signs Realty Tax Bills That Answer State Criticism
description: Bills designed to help insulate the city's tax commission from political pressures and to prevent secret deals to reduce real estate assessments were among five measures signed into law by Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Sale
Another Defends the Inquisitor
description: LONDONThere are times when really do believe that Bernard Levin should stick to music. Yesterday was such an occasion, when he demonstrated with his usual writing grace and artistry that he knows less about Southern politicians and politics than the delights of Miami's kosher rest taurants.

title: Continental Is Cited
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)  The Continental Grain Company, which handled more than half of last year's big sale of United States grain to the Soviet Union, has been charged with filing incomplete and inaccurate reports on some 1972 futures trading activities, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Spaniards Indignant on E.E.C. Trade Offer
description: MADRID, July 2The European Economic Community has just made an offer to Spain for the establishment of a free trade zone  an offer that has provoked more indignation in political and business circles here than has been seen in years.

title: U.S. MINESWEEPING FINISHED IN 3 PORTS
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 2 (Agence FrancePresse)The North Vietnamese press said today that Hanoi had received word from the United States that it had completed minesweeping at the entrances to the ports of Haipong, Hon Gai and Cain Pha.

title: In the Borscht Circuit of a Headier Day It's Mostly PriceSqueezed Egg Farms
description: SWAN LAKE, N. Y. These are the men who sowed the corn that fed the roosters which woke the sons who picked the beets which made the borscht in the house that Jake built.

title: First Tropical Storm 800 Miles Off Florida
description: MIAMI, July 3 (AP)A subtropical low pressure system dawdling 800 miles east of Cape Kennedy picked up strength tonight and spawned tropical storm Alice, the first of the 1973 hurricane season, the National Hurricane Center said.

title: A LIVELY FOURTH SHAPES UP HERE
description: Hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers are expected to trek to crowded beaches and quiet country places tomorrow to laze in the sun or drowse in the shade, independent for day on a midweek Independence Day.

title: Arthur Daley
description: When Elmer Layden's grandson became a candidate for his grammar school football team, the coach was duly impressed, but only by the boy's ancestry, You know, of course, said the somewhat awed coach, that your grandfather was one of the Four Horsemen of Notre Dame. Little Elmer looked puzzled. As soon as he returned home he went straight to the font of all knowledge.

Anderson as special United States Representative in the Panama Canal treaty negotiations. Mr. Anderson, former Treasury Secretary in the Eisenhower Administration, has been involved in the canal negotiations for the last nine years.

title: Conference at Helsinki: The Facts in Brief
description: OBJECTIVESThe Russians and their allies, who proposed it in the first place, would like the conference seal the div;sion of Europe and, in a general EastWest summit meedng this fall, to pronounce the formal end the cold war with declarations of mutual nonaggression, expressions of cooperation in economic, industrial and cultural affairs, and assurances of willingness to reduce military tensions. The Western countries would like to use the Soviet enthusiasm for the conference to get major and specific concessions from the Eastern bloc.

description: GOSHEN. N, Y., July 2There is a hig old oak tree at the head of the stretch, its bark resembling an elephant's hide. According to legend, Messenger grazed here in 1801.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2 (UPI)  Efforts were made twice today to obtain the release of two Canadian truce observers who disappeared Thursday and are believed to be in Vietcong hands.

At last year's festival, the highlight of his concert at Carnegie Hall was Aura, a dazzling Rumanian beauty with a voice that was astonishing both for its range and its sustained sensuosity. On Sunday night, this time at Philharmonic Hall, Mr. Ellington's special treat, was Alice Babs, a Swedish singer who was the sensation of Mr. Ellington's Second Sacred Concert when he performed it several years ago at the Cathedral Church of St. John the

title: KENDALL DEBEVOISE OF LAW FIRM DEAD
description: Kendall B. DeBevoise, a senior partner in the law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan, died here yesterday. He was 59 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

description: FORT WORTH, July 2  A Federal jury has cleared the General Dynamics Corporation of charges that it conspired to defraud the Air Force of $114,000 in costs of faulty metal plates for the F111 fighterbomber.

description: PLAINVIEW, L. I., July 2 Heating oil began flowing today through a 23mile pipeline, immediately dropping the price to thousands of customers by nearly a half cent a gallon.

description: DETROIT, July 2 (UPI)The KelseyHayes Company said today that the International Harvester Corporation would make the KelseyHayes computercontrolled, antiskid braking systern standard equipment on its heavy trucks in 1974 and that the Ford Motor Company would offer the equipment on some of its 1975 trucks. Diamond Reo also has agreed to use the KelseyHayes equipment.

description: Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell denied yesterday any foreknowledge of an alleged plan to discredit Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco four years ago, a lawyer who interviewed him said,

description: NEW DELHI, July 2 (AP)The Indian Government announced today that it would repatriate 440 Pakistani prisoners of war on medical grounds.

description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Panel Studies Savings Account Interest Ceiling
description: The nation's largest banks, acting in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's decision late last Friday to increase the discount rate to 7 per cent and to increase the reserves that banks are required to hold against their deposits, yesterday increased their prime rate. This minimum interest rate on large business loans went up to 8 per cent from 734 per cent.

description: Mr. William Cairns

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Originally scheduled for publication last month, The Asian Journal, a record by the late Thomas Merton, the Trappistpoetpriest, of his trip to the East in 1968, has been postponed until July 16, according to its publisher, New Directions.

F.H.A. Orders Its Field Offices To Suspend Horne Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) The Federal Housing Administration ordered its field offices today to suspend issuing home mortgages.

title: A New Cabinet Is Formed By the Lebanese Premier
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 2 (AP)  Premier Takkieddin Solh formed a new Lebanese Cabinet tonight, ending a 10day Government crisis.

title: Mr. Colson Throws A Curve
description: Anything Charles Colson wants to happen immediately, it is safe to assume, would be good for (a) Richard Nixon and (b) Charles Colson, maybe even in that order. So let us look again at Mr. Colson's assertion in Sunday television interview that the most important thing in the Watergate matter is for the American people to know immediately whether Mr. Nixon was involved in the June 17, 1972, breakin at the Democratic National Committee offices, and its subsequent coverup.

title: Books of The Times
description: The delights of Daniel J. Boorstin's approach to American history should be familiar to readers by now, especially those who have read the first. two volumes of the trilogy that is now complete with the publication of The Americans: The Democratic Experience. (The first volume, subtitled The Colonial Experience, appeared in 1958; the second, The National Experience, which carried Mr, Boorstin's epic through the Civil War, came out in 1965.) All the same, before I get down to quibbling over Mr. Boorstin's unusual technique, let me celebrate some of those delights as they manifest themselves in this final volume. There is, to begin with, the concreteness of his narrative. He does not write history that alludes obliquely, or flash evidence like a prestidigitator doing card tricks. No, when Mr. Boorstin takes up, say, The Decline of the Miraculous as theme of the last hundred years or so, and gets down, more specifically, to the Leveling of Times and Places, he goes straight to the gut of detail. Time and Place suggest to him first of all the matter of food; and before we have had time to absorb this odd.step of logic, he is off and telling us the story of Gail Borden, who, when he learned of the horrendous Donner Party incident (in which a group of starving transcontinental emigrants committed cannibalism), set about to perfect some form of portable food, and, after failing to sell the American public on the idea of meat biscuits, came up with you've guessed it!  Borden's condensed milk.

title: On Maclison Avenue, Women. Take Stand In Middle of the Road
description: There are perhaps fewer than 10 of them in the whole city and now, after years of either struggling or sailing their way to the top, they sit in fancy, imaginative offices that offer the very best views of midtown Manhattan.

title: The Ballet
description: If you simply cannot bear to see children on ,a stage and have no interest in the process by which ballet dancers become ballet dancers, then the programs billed as Bolshoi Dance Academy at the Metropolitan Opera House are not for you.

title: Saline Water Bill Signed
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 2 (UPI)President Nixon signed a bill today authorizing an outlay of $9.1million to carry out the Interior Department's saline water program for the fiscal year that began yesterday. The objective of the program is to develop processes and methods of desalting sea and brackish waters.

title: PODELL IS TARGET OF U.S. INQUIRY
description: A grand jury is investigating Representative Bertram L. Podell of Brooklyn in a Federal case involving an alleged conflict of interest.

title: Review Board Votes to Exempt Nassau Coliseum From Taxes
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 2The Board of Assessment Review ruled here today that Nassau County's $28million Veterans Memorial Coliseum at Mitchel Field should be granted tax exemption on the basis that it is public property used for public purposes.

title: Parking Campaign Effect In Midtown Areals Varied
description: The Police and Traffic Departments formally began their crackdown on illegal parking in midtoWn Manhattan yesterday with evident success in about third of the 180squareblock target area but with poor reAlas in the rest,

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your June 22 editorial Collapsing Pennsy, that bankrupt railroad is accused of being back on Capitol Hill, rattling its tin cup for Federal cash to keep the trains running. While the acuteness of the Pennsy's financial crunch is acknowledged, The Times goes on to observe that giving its trustees a big bundle of Government funds would merely unlock the Treasury vaults for an endless drain.

title: Miss Goolagong, Chris Evert and Mrs. King Win
Jipcho Becomes Second Fastest Miler With 3:52 Race,
description: STOCKHOLM, July 2 (UP1): The world steeplechase recordholder, Ben Jipcho of Kenya, became history's second fastest miler tonight when he was clocked in 3 minutes 52 seconds at an international track and field meet.

title: LEE BARKER DEAD; DOUBLEDAY AIDE
description: LeBaron R. Barker Jr., senior consulting editor for Doubleday & Co. and the book publisher's executive editor since 1945, died yesterday of a heart attack at New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 222 East 71st Street.

title: SLIDE CONTINUES IN DOLLAR VALUE
description: PARIS, July 2  The beleaguered dollar continued to decline today on foreignexchange markets still jittery over West Germany's revaluation of the mark against a European bloc of currencies on Friday.

title: Grandsons Held In TortureBeating Of Woman Upstate
description: An 87yearold woman was held captive in her home for 18 hours over the weekend, severely beaten and burned by three youthstwo of them her grandsonsand finally escaped to a neighbor's house in the upstate hamlet of Tyrone in the Finger Lakes region, the police reported.

title: Aide Says 11 May Have Been Sterilized
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) An official of the Office of Economic Opportunity said today that as many as 11 girls who are minors might have been involuntarily sterilized by a federally funded birth control clinic in Montgomery, Ala.

title: InsuranceContractAwarded
description: The Insurance Company of North America disclosed yesterday that it had won a Government contract to service the sale of Federal crime insurance in 11 states and the District of Columbia. It outbid the Aetna Life and Casualty Company in five states and the District and the American Universal Insurance Company in Rhode Island. Aetna outbid the industry last March. in servicing sales in New Jersey.

title: Richmond Bank Rate Raised
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday that it had approved action by the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond increasing its discount rate to 7 per cent from 61/2 per cent. The Richmond bank was the only one of the 12 regional reserve banks that did not join when the increase was initiated last Friday.

title: Wilson Songs Stand Out
description: Joe Lee Wilson sings with his soul exposed for everyone to see and hear, and he draws the best efforts from musicians playing with him. The Rene McLean Sextet infuses modern jazz sounds with new and old classical strains that give the music elegance. The Ken McIntyre Quartet mixes funky blues with postJohn Coltrane jazz that educates listeners without frightening them away. The Aboriginal Music Society is exciting in its group approach to performing as a tribal unit of music makers. And Hannibal is definitely an engaging excursion into the possible futures of jazz.

title: Frazier Floors Bugner, Takes Decision
description: LONDON, July 2  Joe Frazier won his first fight tonight since losing his heavyweight championship last January. But his 12round decision over Joe Bugner may have done more for his opponent's reputation than for his.

title: HUMANITIES AGENCY NAMES 36 FELLOWS
Summer Play Streets Open With Games and Parade

description: BUCYRUS, Ohio, July 2 (AP) Two escapees from Marion Correctional Institute were captured today after a chase that left a deputy sheriff dead. Robert T. Hershberger, 31 years old, of Akron, and Richard W. Osborn, 31, of Newarksurrendered in a house after tense negotiations with several state highway patrolmen and county deputies.

title: Police Foil Largest Bribe; 6 Held in $250,000 Offer
description: City and Federal officials announced yesterday the indictment and arrest of six men, five of whom were arrested on drugdealing charges last April, for allegedly conspiring to bribe two police undercover agents with up to $250,000.

title: Container Company Struck
description: CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)The Container Corporation of America said today that 18 of its 87 plants had been struck by The United Paper Workers International.

title: MAY LOSSES PARED BY MEMBER FIRMS
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that member firms lost $38.5million in May, or about $1million less than the firms lost in April.

title: Aerosol Cold Remedy Recalled Following Deaths of 18 Users
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Food and Drug Administration ordered today the recall of all stocks of a widely sold aerosol cold remedy after learning of 18 deaths associated with use of the product since 1968.

title: Special Iraqi Tribunal Will Try Security Chief in Coup Attempt
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 2 (AP)The Baghdad radio announced today that Iraq's security chief and his accomplices in the attempt to overthrow the Govemment would be tried soon before a special tribunal.

title: Spain Suspends Three For Wimbledon Boycott
description: BARCELONA, Spain, July 2 (UPI)The Spanish Tennis Federation today suspended three top players who had joined a boycott of the Wimbledon tournament.

title: ScrapMetal Export Controls Imposed; Limited Soybean Shipments Resumed
4 Armed Suspects Seized After a 47Cent Holdup
description: BAY CITY, Mich., July (UPI)Three juveniles and one adult armed with pistols, rifles and a sawedoff shotgun held up a Bay City paper boy. Saturday night while the. youth was on his route.

title: People in Sports: Tigers Change Convict's Stripes
description: Billy Martin, the manager of the Detroit Tigers, went to Southern Michigan Prison in May and found a prospective fencebuster. The Tigers announced yesterday that they had signed Ron LeFiore, who served three years on a robbery charge, to a minor league contract. He has been assigned to the Clinton, Iowa, club of the Midwest League.

title: Principal Ties Protest to Ignorance of His Record
description: Norman Desser, whose appointment as principal has led to a sitin at Public School 208 in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, said yesterday that he thought that the reason for the protest was that the parents were unfamiliar with him and his record.

title: White House Unit Explains MixUp on Nixon Signature
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 2The White House press office said today that President Nixon had not yet signed the bill increasing Social Security payments by 5,fi per cent, as it reported erroneously yesterday, but that he would do so shortly.

title: Claremont Stables Get 2Year Reprieve From the Bulldozer
description: The Claremont riding stables, Manhattan's only such enterprise will be around for at least two more years, Parks Commissioner Richard Clurman said yesterday.

title: $108,000 in Public TV Grants To Aid Minorities at Stations
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting has announced minorityhiring grants totaling $108,000 to six public television and three public radio stations.

title: 13 MORE FOOD SPOTS TERMED VIOLATORS
BECHTEL COMPANY SIGNS SOVIET PACT
description: MOSCOW, July 2  One of America's leading engineering and construction concerns, the Bechtel Corporation of San Francisco, today signed a broad agreement on technology transfer with the Soviet Government.

title: TowTruck Driver Won't Give Up
description: What is a Police Department towtruck operator do when he is unable to tow away cars? This is what one did yesterday simply to make himself a useful part of the midtown traffic crackdown.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION

title: 2 CRIME FIGURES EXPECTED TO TALK
description: TRENTON, July 2Two men who have spent more than two years behind bars for refusing to answer questions about organized crime posed by. the State Commission of Investigation are ready to break their silence, according to sources close to the commission.

title: Heath and Cosgrave Hold Talk As New Ulster Effort Is Begun
description: LONDON, July 2The Prime Ministers of Britain and Ireland met here today at the beginning of a new phase in the effort to work out a political solution for Northern Ireland.

title: MOD TOLL IS 11 IN THE NORTHEAST
description: Crews in the Northeast began clearing away tons of mud left yesterday from weekend floods that inundated lowlying towns, and caused millions of dollars worth of damage.

title: U.S.Soviet Oceanographers Share Both Vodka and Ideas
description: The largest of the Soviet Union's fleet of oceanographic research ships steamed into New York harbor yesterday in a quiet show of good will and handsacrossthesea science.

title: DOLLY MADISON FILES A BANKRUPTCY PLAN
description: Dolly Madison Industries, Inc., of Philadelphia, has filed a plan for reorganization in the Federal Court of Eastern Pennsylvania, Monroe Corbin, trustee, said yesterday.

title: W. B. DINSMOOR, 87, AN ARCHEOLOGIST
description: ATHENS, July 2Prof. William Bell Dinsmoor, an archeologist who devoted a lifetime to the study of ancient Greek architecture, died today in a hospital of a stroke. He would have been 87 years old July 29.

title: IndianPakistaniStyle Food From an Athlete Turned Chef
description: Earlier this year, Shahid Alam went out and celebrated his 29th birthday a little differently. He opened his own restaurant.

title: Over 100,000 Seek Youth Corps Jobs
description: More than 100,000 youngsters seeking summer Neighborhood Youth Corps jobs have been registered here thus far, Amalie Betanzos, the city's Commissioner of Youth Services, estimated yesterday.

title: NEWSMAN TESTIFIES TO ATTICARIOT JURY
description: WARSAW, N. Y., July 2A Buffalo television newscaster answered 21 questions in an hourlong appearance this afternoon before a grand jury investigating the September, 1971, Attica prison uprising, thus purging himself of a contempt citation and avoiding a 30day jail sentence that had been imposed last Thursday.

title: Savage, Indy 500 Driver Dies of May 30 Injuries
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 2 (UPI) David Earl (Swede) Savage, who used to say my accidents have made a better driver of tile, died today of burns and injuries suffered in a flaming, walltowall crash during the Indianapolis 500mile auto race on May 30.

title: Israelis in U S. Get Tighter Security
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Federal Bureau of Investigation, as part of its effort to solve the murder of an Israeli military attache early yesterday, was reported today to be looking for a lightcolored car that was said to have sped from the area shortly after the shooting.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: What one police supervisor called a discretionary crackdown on illegal parking in a 180block area of midtown Manhattan began with mixed results. Early returns indicated that many people had left their autos home.

title: TOP PEKING ENVOY IN U.S. WILL MEET PRESIDENT FRIDAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Huang Chen, China's senior diplomat in Washington, will fly to San Clemente for talks at the California White House with President Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger on Friday.

title: Chotiner and Rebozo Cited As May Donors to Gurney
description: MIAMI, July 2 (AP)Senator Edward J. Gurney received $20,800 for his 1974 campaign rom contributors who included C. G. Rebozo, a friend of President Nixon's, and Murray Chotiner, a former Nixon adviser, The Miami Herald said today.

title: Spain Suspends Three For Wimbledon Boycott
description: BARCELONA, Spain, July 2 (UPI)The Spanish Tennis Federation today suspended three top players who had joined a boycott of the Wimbledon tournament.

title: Democratic Prankster of Yore Takes Part of Watergate Blame
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Dick Tuck, the Democrat accused by President Nixon's supporters of having originated dirty tricks in American politics, is prepared to assume a share of the responsibility for the Watergate scandal.

title: Roundup: Aaron and Clyde Big Hits
description: Henry Aaron is 39 years old and is approaching the end of a brilliant major league baseball career. David Clyde is 18 years old and is beginning what appears, to be a brilliant career.

title: One Briton Calls It a Senatorial Inquisition
description: LONDONI have just come back from ten days or so in America, where I watched a good deal of the Senate inquiry into the Watergate affair; the proceedings are being carried live and in full on television, with generous repetition in the evenings. I do not know what sort of viewing figures the business is getting, but it must certainly run into millions, perhaps tens or scores of millions. And it. is just about the most scandalous violation of every standard of justice to take place in a free society since the Southern gentry abandoned lynching as their favourite outdoor. sport.

title: Eclipse Gazers Puzzled By Evanescent Shadows
description: ABOARD THE CANBERRA, at Sea, July 2One of the most unusual manifestations of a total eclipse of the sunthe sweep of shadow bands across the landscape just before and after the eventremains as puzzling as ever following an airborne effort to explore its cause.

title: BRIG. JOHN MORRISON
description: Brigadier John Morrison of the Salvation Army, manager of the Ten EyckTroughton Memorial Residence for business women at 145 East 39th Street, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, on train from Philadelphia to New York. His age was 61.

title: END OF DRY SPELL BOLSTERS CASPER
description: Tom Weiskopf, Chi Chi Rodriguez, Lou Graham and Homero Blancas are members of a United States Ryder Cup golf team for the first time, according to the compilation that ended Sunday. But the squad's happiest member is Billy Casper, who earned a place for the seventh time.

title: New Tire Process Developed
description: AKRON, July 2 (UPI)The Firestone Tire & Rubber Company said today it had developed an improved process for making steelbelted radial tires. The new process makes the tires on a single stage machine instead of the two machines currently used.

title: Colby Says He Would Curb C.I.A. in U.S. and Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 William E. Colby said today that as Director of Central Intelligence he would insist that the Central Intelligence Agency refrain from domestic investigations and curb its involvement in secret wars overseas.

title: Spread Over Half Mile, 15 Give Dance on Roofs
description: Fifteen dancers, spread out over halfamile of Sofro rooftops Sunday afternoon, used dancer's semaphore to create a mysteriously beautiful happening.

title: Opening to the West?
description: The European Security Conference opens formally Helsinki today, and it is hardly a secret that most Westerners expect little or nothing of importance to emerge from its deliberations.

title: Inventories, New Orders And Shipments Increase
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Manufacturers inventories, new orders and shipments rose in May, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: RAHWAY, July 2While trackandfield events will be held in many communities Wednesday in observance of Independence Day, bicycle races will provide the main attraction here.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Boeing Company received a $130.7million Air Force contract for the third production round of the shortrange attack (SRAM), it was announced yesterday.

title: The Commuter's PATH
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, its failure to do anything meaningful about the bistate area's worsening mass transportation crisis, seems grow increasingly indifferent to the plight of the commuter.

title: Cutback of U.S. Pilots Flying For C.I.A. in Laos Is Reported
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 2 (UPI)A sharp cutback in the number of American charter pilots flying for the Central Intelligence Agency and other United States Government agencies in Laos is under way, according to wellinformed sources here.

title: Five Couples Celebrate the Pas de Deux at Spoleto
description: SPOLETO, Italy, July 1 Dance is taking a prominent part in Gian Carlo Menotti's 16th Festival of Two Worlds here, and American dance is paramount.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DANCE The American Ballet Theater was founded in 1940, which makes it one of the more senior citizens in the world of American dance companies.

title: Con Ed Drops. Plan for an Atomic Plant
BODIES OF WIDOW AND SON FOUND
description: MAURICE RIVER TOWNSHIP, N, J., July 2  An 80yearold widow and her 50yearold married son, who lived next door, were found dead in the kitchen of her small bungalow in this rural southern New Jersey community, the state police reported today.

title: Bridge:
description: Strong club systems have proliferated in recent years, and nearly all of them agree that the strong artificial opening bid needs about 17 highcard points, give or take a point. But there is a wide divergence of view about the best way to respond, with a sharp division between those favoring natural responses and those preferring artificial controlshowing responses.

title: Officials Ask Delay in Pennsy, Liquidation
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 2Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania asked a Federal judge today to delay plans by trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation company to liquidate rail assets in their effort to avoid a rising tide of red ink.

title: Legal Aid Strike Leader Karen Faraguna
description: Karen Faraguna remembers vividly her first day as a Legal Aid Society lawyer in September, 1971.

title: MRS. JOSEPH MALSKY
description: Mrs. Nellie Karpinski Malsky, secretarytreasurer and former vice president of Local 32 J, Building Service Employes Union, died Sunday in White Plains Hospital, She was 70 years old and lived in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: U. S.Soviet Oceanographers Share Both Vodka and Ideas
description: The largest of the Soviet Union's fleet of oceanographic research ships steamed into New York harbor yesterday in a quiet show of good will and randsacrossthesea science.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Exxonoperated gasoline stations on the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway removed all limitations on gasoline sales yesterday.

title: Twists of CaMbodian Politics Put a Pact in Doubt
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 2Standing on the tarmac of the Phnom Penh airport is wrecked MIG17 jet fighter plane sent by the Russians to help Prince Norodom Sihanouk against neighboring Thailand and South Vietnam, allies of the United States.

title: Futures Up Limit
description: All wheat and corn futures rose the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel in active trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Newcrop soybeans and byproducts were bid up sharply.

title: Correction Officer Is Held As Head of Cocaine Ring
description: A correction officer assigned to guarding prisoners in the detention pens of Criminal Court and State Supreme Court in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday as the leader of a ring that allegedly operated a $1millionayear business in cocaine.

title: 400 Legal Aid Lawyers Go On Strike for Better Pact
description: More than 400 Legal Aid Society lawyers went on strike yesterday, forcing courts here to hire dozens of private lawyers for the day to represent indigent defendants.

title: Amtrak Plans to Discontinue 2 LongHaul Trains Aug. 2
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Amtrak announced today that it planned to discontinue operation Aug. 2 of two of its long distance trainsthe National Limited, between New York and Kansas City, Mo., and the Floridian, between Chicago and Florida.

title: Struck Hospital Helpedby Volunteers
description: At Wyckoff Heights Hospital in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday, the nonmedical employes who have been on strike since Friday were circling the hot pavement in front of the entrances, chanting.

title: EDWARD H. NIGRO, 54, DEL WEBB EXECUTIVE
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 2 (AP)Edward H. Nigro, president of Del Webb Hotels International, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Houston. He was 54 years old.

title: Police Foil Largest Bribe; 6 Held in $250,000 Offer
description: City and Federal officials announced yesterday the indictment and arrest of six men, five of whom were arrested on drugdealing charges last April, for allegedly conspiring to bribe two police undercover agents with up to $250,000.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 1,500 members of Local 455 of the International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers went on strike yesterday against the Allied Building Metals Industry.

title: LEVITT SEES STATE FISCALLY WELL OFF
description: The state's financial picture was brighter in the first quarter of this year, Controller Arthur Levitt reported yesterday.

title: READY TO CONFER, GROMYKO ASSERTS
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 2 (AP)Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said today that the Russians stood ready to discuss broadening human and cultural contacts session, was the first big

title: Soviet Drafting a New Citizenship Law
description: MOSCOW, July 2The Soviet Union has quietly begun to draft a new citizenship law that may have a profound impact on some of the controversial practices now being applied to emigrants, particularly Soviet Jews.

title: Notes on People Woman Chaplain Piped Aboard
description: With Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, Chief of Naval Operations, and Rear Adm. Francis Garrett, Chief of Naval Chaplains, looking on, 32yearold Lieut, (jg.] Florence Dianna Pohlman was sworn in as the first female chaplain in the armed forces of the United States. Lieutenant Pohlman, of La Jolla, Calif., who was ordained into the Presbyterian ministry last weekend, will report for eight weeks of indoctrination at Newport, R. I., followed by a stint at the Naval Training Center in Orlando, Fla. Her goal in the Navy: To serve the Lord Jesus Christ.

title: Suspect With Hostage Killed
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 2 (AP) The police shot and killed an armed robbery suspect in a city park this morning after a 30minute standoff in which they tried to persuade him to release a woman.hostage, a spokesman said. The police said that Jerry Wayne Tatum, 35 years old, of Oklahoma City, had threatened repeatedly to kill the woman, then stepped an arm's length from her and gave officers their. first chance to shoot.

title: OntheJob Democracy
description: Last month, when a multinational Swiss corporation announced plans to abolish the jobs of nearly half the work force at a watch factory it owns in Francethe Lip Company in Besanconthe workers seized the plant and continued to turn out watches, selling them at cutrate prices.

title: Colby Says He Would Curb C.I.A. in U.S. and Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, July 2William E. Colby said today that as Director of Central Intelligence he would insist that the Central Intelligence Agency refrain from domestic investigations and curb its involvement in secret wars overseas.

title: 10 Policemen Deny CoverUp in Killing
description: Ten policemen pleaded not guilty yesterday to departmental charges of trying to cover up evidence in the fatal shooting of an alleged pimp by a fellow officer during a midtown altercation in 1971. Their departmental trial was then set for July 23 and, meanwhile, they remain on duty.

title: TV Grants Given to Aid Minority Pupils
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The United States Office of Education has announced the awarding of five grants totaling more than $11.3million to nonprofit groups to produce television material to help reduce educational disadvantages of minority groups.

title: National League
description: Wednesday, July 4, 1973

title: RECORDBREAKER: EXPOS 19, METS 8
description: MONTREAL, July 3Parents shielded their children's eyes from the sight. Someone suggested Channel 9 in New York should rate the showdouble X. United States customs officials might refuse to let the malefactors back across the border as an embarrassment to the country.

title: American League
description: Wednesday, July 4, 1973

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: DOWN

title: 3 INQUIRIES BEGIN ON STERILIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Investigations by at least three Federal agencies, including the Justice Department, have begun into Governmentfunded birth control programs that include sterilization.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland announced yesterday that he planned to divorce his wife of 32 years to marry another woman, but Mrs. Barbara Mandel vowed to remain in the Governor's Mansion in Annapolis until her husband comes to his senses completely.

title: 7 FORMER P.O.W.'S FREED OF CHARGES OF AIDING ENEMY
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The Army and the Navy dismissed charges today against seven enlisted men accused by an Air Force colonel of misconduct and collaborating with the enemy while they were held as prisoners of war by North Vietnam.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A threejudge panel of the Appellate Division Superior Court reversed yesterday a lower court decision ordering two Cumberland County hospitals to perform elective abortions on two women.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nonmedical employes, at Wyckoff Heights Hospital yesterday continued their strike of the main facility and its annex, the Bethany Pavilion, both in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. The 400 employes, who walked out Friday, are protesting the hospital's failure to pay retroactive pay due them. Meanwhile, the hospital functioned with the aid of volunteers and other personnel such as clerical staff. Only emergency cases were admitted.

title: ENZYME INJECTION AIDS 2 PATIENTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Doctors at the National Institutes of Health have counteracted the effects of a genetic abnormality by giving two patients injections of the enzyme that their own bodies do not make properly.

title: Russell Hires Bryant
description: SEATTLE, July 3 (UPI)Emmette Bryant, 33 years old, was signed by Coach Bill Russell today as assistant coach with the Seattle Supersonics of the National Basketball Association. Bryant was assistant coach at Columbia University last season.

title: Betty Grable Dies
description: Betty Grable, the dancing and singing star of a score or more of Hollywood musicals in the nineteenforties, is dead of lung, cancer in Santa Monica, Calif. Page 18.

title: Black Clergy Group Supports Kawaida
description: NEWARK, July 3  An interdenominational group of black clergymen visited the site of Kawaida Towers here today to declare support for the controversial $6.4million housing project and for Imamu Amiri Baraka, leader of the black nationalist organization that is sponsoring the project.

title: Policeman Killed Settling Family Spat
description: CAMDEN, July 3A 29yearold Camden policeman was shot and killed with his own revolver on a Camden street last night when he intervened in an argument between a man and his wife.

title: Shanker, Addressing N . E. A., Denies He Used Racist Tactics
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 3 Albert Shanker defended himself here today against charges that he and his 70,000member New York City teachers union had indulged in racist tactics.

title: Student Day Proclaimed
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 3 (UPI)President Nixon yesterday declared Nov. 14 as National Student Government Day.

title: WATERGATE DATA OF TWO CRITICIZED
description: SAN DIEGO, July 3 (AP) Representative Bob Wilson, Republican of California, said today that H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, former White House aides, exhibited erratic memories in testimony before a Congressional inquiry.

title: The Dollar's Tribulations
description: The dollar is regarded all over the world as a sick currency. But what is the nature and cause of its sickness? There are mysteries and paradoxes to unravel in any effort to answer the question. Obviously the dollar is weak in the money markets of the world. On Monday it dropped a full percentage point. Yesterday it staged a technical recovery but then it fell again. Moneymarket watchers still fear a further weakening of the dollar.

title: 2 Reputed Mafiosi Are Freed After Agreeing to Talk
description: TRENTON, July 3Two reputed Mafia figures were released from the Yardville Correction Center today after they had agreed to tell what they know about organized crime to the State Commission of Investigation,

title: SOVIET PROPOSES CHARTER TO GUIDE EUROPEAN NATIONS
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 3 The Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe opened today with a proposal by the Soviet Union for a new charter of relations among all European states and a general EastWest summit meeting by the end of this year to end what remains of the cold war.

title: Panama Asks for Renewal Of Canal Talks, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) Panama has asked for a resumption of negotiations on the future of the 500squaremile Canal Zone, the State Department announced today.

title: Applications for Jobs in the C.I.A. Have Declined
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI)  The Central Intelligence Agency has received fewer applications for employment since the Watergate scandals erupted, but the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Secret Service report no change in the rate of applications.

title: JOHNSON O'CONNOR, APTITUDE TESTER
description: Johnson O'Connor, a pioneer in aptitude testing who founded the Johnson O'Connor Foundation here, died Monday in Mexico City where he had been conducting research, according, to associates. He was 83 years old and lived at 381 Beacon Street, Boston.

title: Ziegler Scores Articles in Press On Nixon Estate as Malicious
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 3  President Nixon's press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, angrily denounced today as malicious, illfounded and scurrilous, newspaper articles that he said suggested wrongdoing in the purchase of the Nixon estate here.

title: First Place, and the Livin Is Easy
description: About the time Candy Cummings was inventing the curveball, one of baseball's deeper thinkers formulated the Independence Day Theory, which holds that as a pennant race goes on July 4, so it will go at the end of September. If this has not quite become an article of faith in the years since then, it has held true often enough to suggest that the team standings on July 4 can be a fairly reliable guide to the order of finish. For example, a visitor said to Ralph Houk yesterday, look at your record for last year. On July 4 the Yankees lost to Oakland and were in fourth place, six games back of the leaders. They finished the season in fourth place, six and a half games back. Does that suggest anything about this season? What was our wonlost record a year ago? the manager asked.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES OFF DAILY HITS
description: Prices of oldcrop soybean futures dropped the daily limits yesterday following the announcement of export controls regulations the day before. The newcrop beans were down 25 to 27 cents a bushel. Oldcrop limits are 80 cents on the spot July and 40 cents on August and September contracts.

title: 4to3 Ruling Finds Carnal Knowledge Obscene in Georgia
description: ATLANTA, July 3 (AP)The Georgia Supreme Court has upheld the pornography conviction of an Albany man based on a June 21 decision of the United States Supreme Court saying that local community standards rather than national standards may be considered.

title: Two Former Ministers Seized in Greece
description: ATHENS, July 3The Greek Government arrested two former Cabinet ministers today, linking them with the Greek Navy's abortive coup in late May.

title: Golda Meir, Candidate, Puts In Day With Voters
description: ROSH PINNA, Israel, July 2A camouflaged Israeli Air Force helicopter lifted off the pad at Tel Aviv, skimmed north over the flat coastal plain and began climbing toward this mountain town overlooking the Sea of Galilee. Buckled into a hard canvag seat designed for a paratrooper, 75yearold Premier Golda Meir spent the 40minute flight reading diplomatic cablegrams and napping.

title: 3 Israelis Warn Slayers Of Aide Will Be Punished
description: TEL AVIV, July 3 (Reuters)  Israel's Defense Minister, Chief of Staff and Air Force commander all pladged today that the slaying of an Israeli military attach in the United States would not go unpunished.

title: Roundup: No Glory in Perry Bros. Confrontation
description: There was a baseball game in Cleveland last night that had the ingredients for fratricide. The opposing pitchers were uaylord Perry, the 1972 Cy Young Award winner from the Cleveland Indians, and his older brother, Jim, of the Detroit Tigers. Gaylord, 34 years old, and Jim, 36, are righthanders.

title: A.T.&T. ORDERS CABLE FOR PACIFIC NETWORK
description: Three suppliers, two of them subsidiaries of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, were given orders yesterday to start producing cable for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $180million Pacific Ocean communications network.

title: State High Court Quashes Model Cities Job Project
description: The State Court of Appeals has ruled illegal a Model Cities program aimed at getting jobs for blacks and Hispanic persons in the city's uniformed services by bypassing normal Civil Service procedures.

title: HERBERT SCHELL OF N.A.M.IS DEAD
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 3 Herbert H. Schell, a retired textile leader who had been a director of the National Association of Manufacturers, died Sunday at his home, 31 Cathedral Avenue. He was 81 years old.

title: CreditMarket Yields Advance; Rate on Federal Funds Declines
Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 2 Charged in Kidnapping
description: CHICAGO, July 3 (AP)A Federal grand jury charged two men today with kidnapping a drug company executive, Melvin Zahn, who escaped unharmed from men who held him for $1.5million ransom. Those indicted are George Ferris, 52 years old, and William Calhoun, 48. Mr. Zahn, 34, escaped from a house where he was held. He was abducted June 25.

title: 2d U.S. Health Aide Resigns in Protest On Cut in Services
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) Dr. Gordon K. MacLeod, director of Health Maintenance Organization services, today became the second Federal health official in a week to announce his resignation in protest against Nixon Administration reorganization of health services.

title: LeftWing Leader Confirms Reports Of G.O.P. Funding
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July (AP)John Haag, a Peace and Freedom party leader, said today that reports of secret Republican contributions to leftwing candidates were true.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ONAMEX AND OTC
description: Despite a late rally, prices on the American Stock Exchange were down again yesterday in continued light trading.

title: Minor Leagues
JAPAN'S EXPORTS ROSE 3% IN JUNE
description: TOKYO, July 3 (UPI)Japan's exports in June showed a 34 per cent increase over the corresponding month in 1972, totaling $2.37million on a letterofcredit basis, the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan said today.

title: N.E.A. CHIEFS ASK TALKS ON MERGER
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 3 The leadership of the National Education Association called on the rival American Federation of Teachers today to begin talks this fall on merging the two powerful organizations and got a cautious but generally warm reception from A.F.T. officials.

title: Thousands of Poor in Argentina Seek Aid, as in Old Peron Days
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 3 Please stay in line, compaeros, please stay in line, bellowed a man with a bullhorn to several thousand poor, unemployed, homeless or sick Argentines waiting to enter the Ministry of Social Welfare for emergency aid of all sorts.

title: Mets Records
description: PITCHING

title: U.S. Gives $130,000 to Support Drug Testing in Harlem School
description: Cautioning that there must be a firm determination to protect the constitutional rights of children involved, Representative Charles B. Rangel announced yesterday that Federal funds had been provided for voluntary urinalyses to uncover drug abuse among pupils in Harlem school.

title: Goodrich Realty Seeks Recrion; A greement in Principle Reached
description: The Goodrich Realty and Development Group, Inc., a New York real estate, construction and management company, has reached an agreement in principle to acquire the assets of the Recrion Corporation for $53million cash, securities of Goodrich Realty and the assumption of Recrion's liabilities, it was disclosed yesterday. Recrion owns and operates the Stardust and Fremont hotels and casinos in Las Vegas, Nev. Goodrich Realty and Development, which had been privately owned until January when it acquired General Mortgage Investments, had total assets on March 31 of $35million.

title: SOVIET PROPOSE CHARTER TO GUIDE EUROPEAN NATIONS
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 3 The Conference on Security ant Cooperation in Europe openec today with a proposal by the Soviet Union for a new charter of relations among all European states and a general EastWest summit meeting byrthe end of this year to end what remain of the cold war.

title: Brazil 43 Soccer Victor
description: DUBLIN, July 3 (AP)Brazil, the world champion, led by Paulo Cesar's two goals, beat, Ireland, 43, tonight in an ex1 hibition soccer match before) 30.000 fans at Lansdowne Stadium.

title: Eugene Wolsk Weds Judith Licht
description: The marriage of Miss Judith Carol Licht to Eugene V. Wolsk, a Broadway producer, took place last evening at the Top of the One Club, One Lincoln Plaza. Rabbi Avraham Soltes performed the ceremony.

title: 2 Reported Mafiosi Are Let Out of Jail So They Can Talk
description: TRENTON, July 3Two reputed Mafia figures were released from the Yardville Correction Center today after they had agreed to tell what they know about organized crime to the State Commission of Investigation.

title: Lightning Halts Power In Montreal and Quebec
description: MONTREAL, July 3 (UPI) A bolt of lightning that struck the Government hydroelectric plant knocked out power in twothirds of Quebec Province tonight, including the cities of Montreal and Quebec, and trapped thousands in subways, elevators and rushhour traffic.

title: UNION LEADER DIES IN VIETNAM PRISON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3A Vietnamese labor leader, arrested over two months ago along with five other union officials, has died in prison, Vietnamese and American sources said today.

title: Liquor Clerks Strike Set
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (UPI) The executive council of the Retail Clerks Union voted last night for a strike that will close all state liquor stores Thursday. Wendel Young, president of the union, said the state had jumped the gun and ordered the liquor stores closed today one day before the July 4 holiday. He said the main issue was job security.

title: Back to Sihanouk?
description: The Administration is making the worst of its bargain with Congress which permitsbut does not legalize justifythe continued bombing of Cambodia in return for an Aug. 15 cutoff of funds for United States military activity throughout Indochina.

title: Hockey Transactions
Senators Will Recall Dean On Nixon Estate Purchase
description: WASHINGTON, July 3John W. Dean 3d will be recalled by the Senate Watergate committee this fall to testify about President Nixon's personal financial dealings in his purchase of his $1.5million estate in San Clemente, Calif., the committee's chief counsel said today.

title: How It Was in Bay Ridge a Long Time Ago
description: My father was born in Brooklyn in the days of streetcars and horses before the First World War. That was more innocent time for Brooklyn and the country. It was very countrified in those days, he said. There were dirt roads in Flathush and the Vitagraph Studio made silent pictures in littleknown section called Greenfield. Forgotten movie stars like Clara Kimball Young and Harry T, Morey hung out in Koster's General Store, The word wiretap had not been invented.

title: DOLLAR OFF AGAIN IN HEAVY TRADING
description: PARIS, July 3The dollar came under late selling pressure today and again touched new lows in European foreignexchange markets.

title: Golda Meir, Candidate, Puts In Day With Voters
description: ROSH PINNA, Israel, July 2A camouflaged Israeli Air Force helicopter lifted off the pad at Tel Aviv, skimmed north over the flat coastal plain and began climbing toward this mountain town overlooking the Sea of Galilee. Buckled into a hard canvas seat designed for a paratrooper, 75yearold Premier Golda Meir spent the 40minute flight reading diplomatic cablegrams and napping.

title: Roundup: No Glory in Perry Bros. Confrontation
description: There was a baseball game in Cleveland last night that had the ingredients for fratricide. The opposing pitchers were Gaylord Perry, the 1972 Cy Young Award winner from the Cleveland Indians, and his older brother, Jim, of the Detroit Tigers. Gaylord, 34 years old, and Jim, 36, are righthanders.

title: Sihanouk Almost Regrets Rejecting U. S. Aid
description: PREDEAL, Rumania, June 29 Prince Norodom Sihanouk, reviewing the recent history of Cambodia in a conversation, finds the classic dilemma of Scylla and Charybdis the closest likeness.

title: SOVIET STUDYING NORTHERN LIGHTS
description: MOSCOW, July 3In an unusual space experiment, a Soviet sounding rocket, rising more than 100 miles above the earth, has injected a beam of electrons into the upper atmosphere to produce an artifical display of the Northern Lights, a wellknown but little understood natural phenomenon.

description: The Chase Manhattan Bank confirmed yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board ordered it in April to divest itself of a 13.77 per cent interest in the Standard and Chartered Banking Group, Ltd., London, a major International bank with assets of more than $6.3billion.

description: OTTAWA, July 3 (Canadian Press)The Vietcong have said they would help look for the two missing Canadian truce observers if Canada would declare that the men were not on iduty when they disappeared last Thursday, the External Affairs Department said today.

description: ALBANY, July 3A challenge to the constitutionality of the State Commission of Investigation was turned back today by the state's highest court, clearing the way for the commission to pursue its planned investigation into alleged corruption in the Albany Police Department.

description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)  Congressional investigators are requisitioning tax records of some 200 persons to affirm or deny Watergate testimony that the White House tried to use the Internal Revenue Service to harass foes and reward Nixon Administration friends.

title: People in Sports: Offer For 715 Ball Is $100,000
description: Since it seems to be only a matter of when rather than if Hank Aaron hits home runs No. 714 and 715 to tie and break Babe Ruth's record, speculation has begun on how much those two baseballs will be worth. Aaron says it's news to him but there is a report that an offer of $50,000 has been made for No. 714 and $100,000 for No. 715. Aaron hit No. 694 on Monday.

description: CHICAGO, July 3 (AP)University of Notre Dame football personalities from the Knute Rockne era to the current coach, Ara Parseghian, attended the funeral today of Elmer Layden, the fullback of the famed Four Horsemen backfield.

description: Because the first Fourth of July so ringingly proclaimed the young American Republic's faith in itself, each Independence Day becomes an important opportunity renew that faith. In reaffirming the ideals and hopes struck so eloquently in Independence Hall, we rededicate ourselves to those basic strengths.

description: TEHERAN, Iran  It an, the land of the ancient Persian empire, is striving for a modern role as a military and economic power at the crossroads of Europe and Asia.

description: Yogi Berra Sand his ailing army were in Montreal yesterday while the Yankees were swinging again in the Bronx, leaving the Mets fans in town to mourn the somersault of fortune that had finally made the Yankees first and the Mets last.

description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 3Gen. George S. Brown, who directed the American air war in Southeast Asia in the late nineteensixties, will be nominated by President Nixon to be the new Air Force chief of staff, the Western White House announced today.

description: EAST HILLS, L. I., July 3 Harry Rosenberg, a labor and tax lawyer, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday in his office, 114 Old Country Road, Mineola. He was 58 years old and lived here.

title: FRENCH BOYS CHOIR SINGS AT PARK MALL
description: The French National Boys Choir managed to give an enjoyable account of itself in its American debut on Monday at the Central Park, Mall, but it had to overcome several obstacles. The sun was hot on the band shell stage, the performers were tired after a delayed flight and were shuffled about in midconcert for the benefit of a television crew, and the amplification proved downright poisonous.

title: $200,000 in Jewels Stolen
description: NATICK, Mass., July 3 (AP) Four masked gunmen robbed a discount catalogue showroom of more than $200,000 in jewelry today after pistol whipping the store manager, Arthur Scopio, 27 years old of Pawtucket, R. 1.

title: PAYMENTS FLOW TO WEIS CLIENTS
description: Customers of Weis Securities, Inc., the brokerage house now in liquidation, have already recovered $47.5million in cash and securities, it was disclosed yesterday.

description: The State Court of Appeals has ruled illegal a Model Cities program aimed at getting jobs for blacks and Hispanic persons in the city's uniformed services by bypassing normal Civil Service procedures.

title: 4to3 Ruling Finds Carnal Knowledge Obscene in Georgia
description: ATLANTA, July 3 (AP).The Georgia Supreme Court has upheld the pornography conviction of an Albany man based on a June 21 decision of the United States Supreme Court saying that local community standards rather than national standards may be considered.
