Bridge: Some Good Plays Will Lose While Bad Ones Will Gain
description: Justice is not something one should expect from the game of bridge, any more than from the game of life. On many occasions good plays will lose, or at any rate fail to gain, and bad plays will gain, or fail to lose.

title: Film: 'Oklahoma Crude':Kramer Directs Scott and Faye Dunaway
description: "Oklahoma Crude" is Stanley Kramer's least solemn movie since "So This Is New York," the very funny but financially unsuccessful adaptation of the Ring Lardner novel that marked Kramer's debut as a film producer in 1948 (and is still one of my favorite comedies). It is less solemn than even "It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World," that behemoth of a slapstick comedy, which Kramer directed as well as produced. In the context of such Kramer works as "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner," "On the Beach" and "Judgment at Nuremberg," his new film is virtually a tonic, but maybe I'm letting myself get carried away."Oklahoma Crude" is Stanley Kramer, the director-producer, working very hard doing his damndest, as a matter of factto entertain us with the kind of fiction that Edna Ferber used to write with such an easy touch that clich was gentled into something approaching true style.The story is set in the great Oklahoma oil fields some time before World War I, when American free enterprise was the purest form of piracy. The characters include a headstrong, tempestuous beauty named Lena (Faye Dunaway), who looks ravishing in long johns, trainman's boots and a dirty face, and who hates men; Lena's father, Cleon (John Mills), a charming ne'er-do-well; and an oil field drifter named Mase (George C. Scott), who signs on for cash to help Lena fight the Pan-Oklahoma oil trust (which wants to take Lena's well away from her) but who stays on when he falls in love with her.Marc Norman's original screenplay (which was later turned into a novel) is not exactly wall-to-wall with surprises, but part of the appeal of such fiction is the anticipation of scenes we know to be obligatory, such as the one in which Lena admits that, after all, she is a woman. It is also necessary that someone important to the plot be killed in the showdown fight with the villains, and that, just when all hope has gone, the gusher be brought in with a whoop and a holler and with everyone standing around the rig getting marvelously drenched in the sticky stuff. Suspense is never a matter of what, but of who and when.The variations that "Oklahoma Crude" works on the familiar formula are largely the work of Scott. It is a broadly comic performance, beginning with lots of double takes, protestations of offended dignity and expressions of horror at the thought of violence, even though we know that the character will turn out to be true blue and brave, or Scott would not be playing it. The performances of Miss Dunaway, Mills and Jack Palance, who plays the chief oil company villain, are more conventional but still quite classy under the ordinary circumstances.Kramer's approach to sheer entertainment, as it is to important and timely subjects, is rather plodding if not truly solemn. Moments of high spirits and good humor are not particularly convincing, and there is such a fondness for shots of beautiful sunrises that I suspect he wishes the movie had more than just a message about the value of individual integrity. Still, compared to his other recent films, "Oklahoma Crude" comes very close to being refreshing, a medium-big and brawling adventure film.

title: Exchanges to Close
description: All United States securities and commodities exchanges will be closed today in observance of Independence Day. Banks and most Governmental offices also will be closed, while the postal service will operate on a holiday schedule.

title: Peking Source Says Kissinger Is Planning to Visit Next Month
description: PEKING, July 3 (Agence FrancePresse)Henry A. Kissinger will visit Peking next month, a very reliable source said here today.

title: Pennsy's Liquidation Plan Advances in U.S. Court
description: Federal Judge John P. Fullam authorized the trustees of Penn Central yesterday to file their plan of reorganization and liquidation with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Fast Traffic, Clean Air
description: Now that the Environmental Protection Agency has accepted this state's traffic control program, New Yorkers can anticipate the price they will have to pay for cleaner air. Considering the enormity of the city's traffic and the advantages of reducing iteven apart from any question of air qualitythe price will be high but by no means prohibitive.

title: Betty Grable Dies
description: Betty Grable, the dancing and singing star of a score or more of Hollywood musicals in the nineteenforties, is dead of lung cancer in Santa Monica, Calif. Page 18.

title: LEGALAID STRIKE GOES ON UNABATED
description: Legal Aid Society lawyers picketed courthouses around the city again yesterday, refusing to handle cases and giving no sign as to when their strike, which began Monday, might end.

title: ELEVATOR CRISIS IN CITY PROJECTS
description: A health emergency was declared yesterday in all New York City Housing Authority projects as a result of the refusal of elevator repairmen to work overtime. The situation has left 400 of 3,000 elevators out of service.

description: The contention by Arthur Ashe, treasurer of the Association of Tennis Professionals, that most members appeared to be opposed to World Team Tennis, a new concept of sixplayer teams representing 16 cities, was disputed by the W.T.T. president yesterday.

description: Suddenly it's July, which means two of the country's biggest dragracing meets are coming this way.

title: The Road Away From Bigotry

title: Major League Box Scores

Big Brush Fire on Coast Is 80 Per Cent Contained
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., July 3 (UPI)  Firefighters guided by aerial television pictures of California's largest brush fire of the season struggled today to close the last few miles of its perimeter. The fire, believed to have been started by children playing with fireworks, was declared 80 per cent contained today in more than 10,000 acres. Officials said that full control was several days away.

title: News Summary and Index

description: Absolute independence is an illusion: unrestrained selfassertion would lead man on a road back to the jungle. Independence is a state of relative freedom from domination within boundaries drawn by tradition, the culture and the laws of society.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TASK FOURTH New York City in Revolutionary days consisted chiefly of lower Manhattan, and that's where the Glorious Fourth is being celebrated vigorously today from 1 P.M. to 9:30, in the area south of Fulton Street.

title: Angry Crowd Broken Up; Bomb Tossed Under Car
description: A crowd of 400 angry residents of a predominantly Italian neighborhood in Lower Manhattan near Chinatown was dispersed by the police last night amid what they said was growing tension with Hispanic youths from nearby housing projects.

title: Annual Police Drive Nets Some Venders Of Illegal Fireworks
description: Five men were arrested yesterday by the police of the Fifth Precinct at 19 Elizabeth Street on charges of selling fireworks. The arrests were part of the Police Department's annual preFourth of July drive against fireworks, the sale or possession of which are misdemeanors.

title: GOSHEN RACE WON BY JOANNA'S TIME
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., July 3 (AP) Joanna's Time won the $16,185 Debutante Stakes during the second day of Grand Circuit harness racing today at Historic Park.

title: MORDAUNT HALL, WROTE OF SCREEN
description: Frederick Wentworth Mordaunt Hall, who in 1924 became the first regularly assigned film critic of The New York Times, died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 94 years old and had been living in the Lynwood Nursing Home.

title: Suspect Is Indicted in Slaying of Coxson
description: CAMDEN, July 3 (AP)A Philadelphia man sought here in connection with the slaying of seven persons in Washington last January was indicted today by the Camden County grand jury on 11 counts stemming from the June 8 killing of Major B. Coxson, an unsuccessful mayoral candidate here.

title: Jipcho Runs Second Fastest Steeplechase
description: STOCKHOLM, July 3 (AP) In a tremendous effort, Ben Jipcho of Kenya ran the second fastest 3,000meter steeplechase race in history, outdueling Anders Gaederud of Sweden today in an international track meet.

title: Quintana in Oil Venture
description: The Quintana Refining Company, a newly formed unit of the Quintana group of companies, and the Howell Company, both based in Houston, have agreed to form a joint venture in domestic oil refining. The letter of intent calls for Quintana Refining to acquire from Howell a 50 per cent interest in its recently reactivated Corpus Christi, Tex., refinery to join Howell in expanding the facility. Financial details were not disclosed.

title: C. K. Chatterton, an Artist Of Ashcan School, Dead
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 3C. K. Chatterton, an artist who was professor of art at Vassar College from 1915 to 1948, died Sunday in a nursing home here. He was 92 years old.

title: Germans at Turtle Bay
description: The Security Council's unanimous recommendation United Nations membership for East and West Germany had been taken for granted for so long that it commanded scant attention around the world. However, the Council's action, which is certain to be ratified by the General Assembly this fall, would have been unthinkable even a few years ago.

title: George Macready, the Villain In Many Plays and Films, Dies
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 3 (AP)  George Macready, a character actor who portrayed the villain in a number of films of the nineteenforties and fifties, died yesterday at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. He was 63 years old.

title: AIR FORCE OFFICER IS SUING ACADEMY
description: DENVER, July 3  An Air Force captain, who was abruptly removed from his teaching job at the Air Force Academy after he complained to Congressmen about the school, filed a suit in Federal District Court here today charging that Academy officials had conspired to violate his rights.

description: At a stormy session yesterday marked by shouted accusations of cheating and lying, Dr. Seymour P. Lachman was elected president of the city's Board of Education for the coming year. title: Allende to Form New Cabinet, Excluding Military Men
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 3 (AP) President Salvador Allende Gossens said tonight that would form an allcivilian Cabinet, reversing a trend toward greater military participation in his leftist Government. Earlier in the day the 15member Cabinet resigned to give the President a free hand in choosing new ministers,

title: 7 FORMER P.O.W.'S FREED OF CHARGES OF AIDING ENEMY
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The Army and the Navy dismissed charges today against seven enlisted men accused by an Air Force colonel of misconduct and collaborating with the enemy while they were held as prisoners of war by North Vietnam.

title: RELAXING OF FREEZE ON FOOD. EXPECTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The food industry may be put under a slow thaw from the 60day price freeze perhaps within two or three weeks, the Nixon Administration disclosed today.

title: July 4, 1973
description: The Fourth of July is that day on which Americans traditionally celebrate not only the birth of our country but the continuing success of an enduring experiment in constitutional democracy.

title: Jury Inquiry Slated On Charge Dropped In Arrest of Fannin
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 3A grand jury inquiry into the dismissal of drunken driving charges against Senator Paul J. Fannin, a Republican, has been ordered by the Maricopa County prosecutor.

title: Karel Ancerl, Conductor, Dies; Toronto Symphony Leader, 65
description: TORONTO, July 3 (AP)  Karel Ancerl, music director and conductor of the Toronto Symphony Orchestra, died today at the age of 65. He had been ill for some time, and last season had had to curtail appearances as a guest conductor.

title: U.S. SOYBEAN CURB DECRIED IN TOKYO
description: TOKYO, July 3 (Reuters) Japanese soybean importers and oil crushers were thrown into confusion today by the 50 per cent cut in United States soybean exports, which, they said, ignore Japan's position as a traditional cash buyer.

title: A CAMPAIGN STUDY HELD UNNECESSARY
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The; Fair Campaign Practices Committee questioned today the need for establishing President Nixon's proposed commission on Federal election reform.

title: OldTime OneDay Fourth To Get New Angles Here
description: Spoiled by a string of newfangled, threeday holiday weekends, Americans will have to reach back and remember how to make the best today of a plain, oldfashioned, oneday national holiday.

title: BRITAIN TO LET SHIPS RETURN ICELAND FIRE
description: LONDON, July 3 (UPI)British warships have been given permission to return fire against Icelandic gunboats harassing trawlers fishing in disputed waters off the coast of Iceland, the British Navy said today.

title: Record Year Is Seen for the Aluminum Industry
description: Thanks in part to the boom in the steel industry, high prices for copper and heavy demand for packaging, the aluminum industry appears headed for a record year.

title: 3 INQUIRIES BEGIN ON STERILIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Investigations by at least three Federal agencies, including the Justice Department, have begun into Governmentfunded birth control programs that include sterilization.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Diamond International Corporation announced yesterday that it intended to purchase up to 100,000 shares of its common stock and that such purchases may be discontinued at any time. The company's stock closed at 29, down  on the New York Stock Exchange. There are about 11,926,500 shares. outstanding.

title: West Coast Monument Planned for Bicentennial
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The group that promoted Honor America Day three years ago is now planning to erect a sister monument to the Statue of Liberty on the West Coast for the nation's bicentennial.

title: Cahill Orders the Prosecution Of CompensationPanel Judge
description: TRENTON. July 3 (AP) Governor Cahill announced today that he had ordered James J. Bonafield, a suspended Workmen's Compensation judge, prosecuted on charges that he had surreptitiously maintained a private law practice while a judge.

title: Briefs On The Arts
E.P.A. Study Calls Autos Chief Polluters of Water
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) A study carried out for the Environmental Protection Agency concludes that cars are primary polluters of water. Biospherics, Inc., of Rockville, Md., an independent research concern, said in a report issued yesterday by the E.P.A. that pollutants spread on roads by autos befoul rivers and streams almost as much as municipal sewage.

title: 3 CHILDREN DROWNED IN AREA ACCIDENTS
description: Three children drowned in the metropolitan area yesterday. On Staten Island, 18monthold Sean Boyle drowned in three feet of water in a pond behind his family's home at 272 Cornelia Avenue in the Princess Bay area. The child's mother, Mrs. Marion Boyle, reported him missing from the house at 6:30 P.M. He was found in the pond about 20 minutes later by a neighbor, Members of a police emergency unit tried to revive him, but he was dead on arrived at Richmond Memorial Hospital.

title: The Suntan Question: Is the Ritual Worth It?
description: It goes on all year now, this tanning of the skin, at least for all those who can get to a ski resort or to the Caribbean. But summer, naturally, is the real season; this is when anyone can get in on it simply by stretching out in one's backyard or on one's roof or at a nearby beach.

title: Policeman Killed With Own Gun Trying to Settle Family Quarrel
description: CAMDEN, N. J., July 3  A 29yearold Camden policeman was shot and killed with his own revolver on a Camden street last night when he intervened in an argument between a man and his wife.

title: Hughes in Spanish Venture
description: FULLERTON, Calif., July (Reuters)The Hughes Aircraft Company has formed a joint venture, called Comco Electronica Corporation, with Compania de Electronica Communicaciones of Spain, to bid on Span's airdefense modernization program known as Combat Grande. Combat Grande is a system being obtained by the United States Air Force for the Spanish Government and will automate Spain's manua lairdefense system.

title: UTILITY ANNOUNCES ATOMIC APPLICATION
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company announced yesterday the filing of an application with the Atomic Energy Commission for building a $1billiori nuclear power plant in Lancaster, Pa. The big utility also reported it had entered into $100million fuel contract for several previously announced nuclear units.

title: ELEVATOR CRISIS IN CITY PROJECTS
description: A health emergency was declared yesterday in all New York City Housing Authority projects as a result of the refusal of elevator repairmen to work overtime. The situation has left 400 of 3,000 elevators lout of service.

title: 76 Bicentennial Plans Cut Back as Mood Shifts
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The United States will celebrate its 200th birthday three years from tomorrow, but in a far more modest manner than wat originally anticipated.

title: Southampton Policemen Strike, But Who Knows the Difference?
Pitney Increases Holding
description: PitneyBowes, Inc., the postagemeter maker, said that it had increased its stake in PitneyBowesAlpex, Inc., to 64 per cent from 50 per cent in return for additional financing to the electronic systems company. The Alpex Computer Corporation of Danbury, Conn., holds the remaining stock interest.

title: WERNER TO BE CITED AT YONKERS TRACK
description: YONKERS, July 3  Sacher Werner, one of metropolitan New York's most popular harness racing drivers, will be honored in special ceremonies at Yonkers Raceway on Wednesday evening, July 18.

title: West Coast Monument Planned for Bicentennial
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The group that promoted Honor America Day three years ago is now planning to erect a sister monument to the Statue of Liberty on the West Coast for the nation's bicentennial.

title: People and Business
description: Seymour Milstein was named president of the Uris Buildings Corporation yesterday, a day after the National Kinney Corporation acquired 54 per cent of its stock. He succeeds Harold D. Uris, 68 years old, whoalong with the estate of his late brother, Percy, and certain other stockholderssold the shares to National Kinney: Robert H. Less, chairman of Uris, continues as chief executive oficer.

title: COURT UPSETS CURB ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) A threejudge panel ruled unconstitutional today a law that bars Social Security benefits to illegitimate children who were born after the father reached age 65.

title: A Meter Thief Takes The Change and Runs
description: WILDWOOD, July 4 (AP)  The heads of 31 parking meters have disappeared in this resort town in the last seven days, and the police are wondering how the thief operates.

title: Orchard Beach on Holiday Is a Puerto Rican Fiesta
description: It is about six miles from the sweltering, littered streets of the South Bronx to the cooling sea breezes and littered sands of Orchard Beach, and for thousands of Puerto Rican families, the 45minute, 70cent subway and bus ride is the only way to beat the heat.

title: Cutting Narcotics Treatment Programs
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The Nixon Administration has instituted changes in its antidrug programs, with increased emphasis on domestic and foreign enforcement efforts and less emphasis on preven7.tion and rehabilitation.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: Daughter of Nixon Says He Considered Resigning
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 4Mrs. David Eisenhower says that her father, President Nixon, considered resigning over Watergate, but his family talked him out of it. Thefamily felt that resignation would be an admission of wrongdoing, and that he was needed in the Presidency, she said.

title: U.S. Gaining in South Korean Export Drive
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A United States export drive to overcome an imbalance in trade with South Korea has begun to show some successbut it still has a long way to go.

title: MRS. FREDERICK DELL
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 4 Mrs. Grace Merritt Dell of 142 Garth Road, a former concert pianist, died today in Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. Her age was 86. She was the widow of Frederick C. J. Dell, director of exhibits for the American Transit Association.

title: GASSUPPLY RISK SEEN LESS SEVERE
description: Government officials and oil industry executives celebrated the Fourth of July this year with a slight sigh of relief as the threat of summer gasoline shortages across the nation appeared to be less severe than feared during late May and June.

title: Wyckoff Employes End Hospital Strike
description: Nonmedical employes at Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn agreed yesterday to end a strike that had begun Friday and to return to work this morning,

title: 40,000 at Religious Parley
description: PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP) Some 40,000 persons jammed Three Rivers Stadium today for the opening of the 1973 international assembly of Jehovah's Witnesses.

title: SAKHAROV ATTACKS THE SOVIET SYSTEM
description: STOCKHOLM, July 4Andrei D. Sakharov, father of the Soviet hydrogen bomb, has issued an indictment of Soviet society in an interview published in a Swedish newspaper.

title: Officer Tries in Vain to Save Woman in a Burning Auto
description: An offduty police officer made a vain effort yesterday morning to save a woman trapped in her burning car on the Henry Hudson Parkway. The victim was identified as Stefanie Lyon, 25 years old, of 825 Riverside Drive.

title: 4 KEY NIXON AIDES REPORTEDLY CITED
description: A status report from the original Watergate prosecutors to the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, recommends the indictment of four former White House and Nixon campaign aides for conspiring to obstruct justice, CBS News reported last night.

title: U.S. Affirms That Kissinger Will Visit China Again
description: SAN CLEMENTE. Calif., July 4Henry A. Kissinger will go to Peking in late July or early August to confer with Premier Chou Enlai, White House officials said today. The Kissinger trip, which has been planned for some time, will be one of the subjects discussed when Huang Chen, head of the Chinese liaison office in Washington, meets here Friday with the President and Mr. Kissinger, Mr. Nixon's adviser on national security. The Chinese official is expected to arrive here tomorrow evening to confer with President Nixon at his office, beginning at 11 A.M. Friday. The talks between Mr. Nixon and Mr. Huang are expected to include overall ChineseAmerican relations following the recent agreements reached between President Nixon and the Soviet party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev. Negotiations for a settlement of the war in Cambodia also) are expected to be discussed, as well as a possible trip to the United States by Mr. Chou. Informed surces said that Mr. Kissinger, in the interest of a Cambodian settlement, might confer with Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodian leader, who now lives in Peking. It will he Mr. Kissinger's sixth trip to Peking.

title: JULIUS KESSLER
description: Julius Kessler, a retired master electrician, died of emphysema on Monday at his home, 4853 44th Street, Woodside, Queens. He was 70 years old.

title: The Theater: A Haunting Caretaker
description: Harold Pinter's The Caretaker, as unrelenting and as haunting as ever, is back in an Off Broadway production by the Roundabout Theater at 307 West 26th Street. In the play (seen at preview), the enigmas remain and the atmosphere continues ominous and threatening. And what the play is about can scarcely be reduced to story line.

title: The First Japanese Hotel In City Opens Next Week
description: The first Japaneseowned hotel in the city will open next Wednesday, aimed at the steadily increasing numbers of Japanese businessmen, art buyers and tourists who are making a growing impact on the American travel market.

title: OffDuty Probationary Officer Suspended in Harlem Shooting
description: An offduty probationary officer was supended from duty yesterday after shooting and wounding a man during a fight outside a Harlem bar.

title: Uruguay Regime Takes Firm Measures Against General Strike
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 4The militarycontrolled Government of President Juan M. Bordaberry took firm action today to try to end the general strike that has paralyzed this capital for a week.

title: Mauritanians Reassured on Eclipse
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania, July 2The Mauritanian Government is conducting an educational program to assure mostly illiterate population that the total solar eclipse two days ago could be predicted by scientists.

title: C.B.S. WILL STUDY NATION'S HISTORY
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday plans for 13 onehour earlyevening primetime family specials on major themes of American history as its contribution to the nation's bicentennial celebration in 1976.

title: Capital Host For 9 Days Of Folk Life
description: WASHINGTON, July 4He was just standing there watching, tugging at his red, white and blue teeshirt, when all of a sudden this big, jolly bricklayer scooped him up into the miniature construction site and thrust a trowel into his hand.

title: Publisher Fills Post
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 4 (AP)The appointment of Don Miller as vice president of operations of the Express Publishing Company has been announced by Charles O. Kilpatrick, publisher of the San Antonio ExpressNews. Prior to his appointment, Mr. Miller was assistant to the president of HarteHanks Newspapers, owners of Express Publishing.

title: West Orange Engineer Named Shriners'
description: Jacob A. Wingerter of West Orange was elected Imperial Potentate of North American Shriners at the organization's annual convention in Atlanta. A professional engineer with offices in Newark, Mr. Wingerter is a member of Temple Salaam in Livingston. In his new post, he will lead in planning activities for 900,000 Shriners and spend much of the coming year visiting the 172 Shrine temples and hospitals in North America.

title: JAZZ AND PARADES HAIL THE 4TH HERE
description: In front of Castle Clinton at the Battery, in Trinity Church, at the South Street Seaport and at the Federal Hall National Memorial, New Yorkers marked the 197th birthday of the United States yesterday with music, dancing, theater and demonstrations of Colonial crafts as they participated in the citysponsored July 4th in Old New York.

title: CAN ADIAN UNIONS TURN NATIONALIST
description: TORONTO, July 4The floormounted and goldtrimmed American flag stands in the middle of the snug, West Toronto office of the Retail Clerks International Union, which has its headquarters in Washington. It is one of many international unions here facing breakaways by dissident members in the growing row in Canada over foreign control of the country's largely UnitedStatesbased labor movement.

title: MAJOR MEAT PLANT CLOSES IN MICHIGAN
description: DETROIT, July 4 (UPI)The second largest meat packing company in Michigan closed today and the head of the biggest packing plant in the state said that it might also shut down because. our company is being caught in an impossible squeeze.

title: NERVE GAS TO STAY IN DENVER AREA
description: DENVER, July 4  Three years after assuring Colorado officials that it would move or destroy all nerve gas at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal, the Army now says it plans to stockpile quantities of the deadly chemical agents there indefinitely.

title: Irish Sculler Wins Henley Heat, Becomes Choice With Dietz Out
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, July 4 (UPI)American crews, deprived of the top sculler, Jim Dietz, still managed to row to a string of victories today in the Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Newport Jazz
description: Almost 100 of the jazz musicians who are gathered here for the Newport Jazz Festival went out to Queens yesterday afternoon to take part in the official dedication of Louis Armstrong Memorial Stadium, formerly the Singer Bowl, on what would have been the trumpeter's 73d birthday.

title: U.S. COURTS ACTING TO END DISPARITY IN PRISON TERMS
description: A broad effort to end the irrational and disparate sentencing of defendants in the Federal courts in New York, Connecticut and Vermont  in part by experimenting with such innovations as threejudge sentencing panels  was announced yesterday by the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals here.

title: Television
Access of Minority Outsiders To Madison Beach Is Disputed
description: MADISON, Conn., July 4Forty blacks and Puerto Ricans, most of them children, were turned away from the town beaches here today because, town officials said, they did not have passes.

title: A MILLION ESCAPE POVERTY BRACKET
description: WASHINGTON, July 4More than a million people last year rose out of the ranks of Americans officially listed as living in poverty.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M.

title: Desert Vixen Takes $57,650 Oaks at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 4Mike Hole duplicated a standin role for Jorge Velasquez today by riding Desert Vixen to victory in the $57,650 Monmouth Oaks at Monmouth Park when the New York jockey's helicopter failed to arrive in time.

title: JAZZ AND PARADES HAIL THE 4TH HERE
description: In front of Castle Clinton at the Battery, in Trinity Church, at the South Street Seaport and at the Federal Hall National Memorial, New Yorkers marked the 197th birthday of the United States yesterday with music, dancing, theater and demonstrations of Colonial crafts as they participated in the citysponsored July 4th in Old New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Under the pressure of the energy crisis there are plans to multiply the number of atomic plants by a factor of twenty or more and to increase the size of the plants as well.

title: New Low Is Touched By Dollar in Europe
description: PARIS, July 4  The dollar's value again sank to new lows against Europe's leading currencies today, but then recovered most of its loss, as pressure on the United States intensified to support the dollar with reserve assets.

title: Notes on People
description: If you were thinking of sending a wedding present to Prineess Anne and Lieut. Mark Philips, why, go right ahead. Ordinarily,, Britain's royalty spurns such gifts from strangers, but Buckingham Palace is rescinding the rule for the November wedding. Palace sources say every gift will be acknowledged and each will be seen personally by the bride and bridegroom. Naturally, everything will be screened by security employes.

title: KENTUCKIAN VICTOR IN COAST HANDICAP
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 4 (UPI)  Preston Madden's long shot, Kentuckian, had the first nose on the wire today as less than a halflength separated the first four horses in the 34th running of the $84,150 American Handicap at Hollywood Park.

title: ExOiler Set to Testify on 71 Bribe Offer
description: DENVER, July 4 (AP)Jerry Sturm, a retired National Football League player, said today he expected to be called before a Federal court grand jury to testify about a $30,000 bribe offered him to shave points on three games.

title: Issue and Debate
description: One of the biggest conservation battles the East has known is over the Tocks Island Dam and National Recreation area near the water gap on the Delaware River between Pennsylvania and New Jersey. It has embroiled conservationists, industry, the Federal Government and Pennsylvania and Delaware.

title: Southampton's 4th Goes Off Without a Sputter
description: Special to The New York TimesSOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 4 The bands, floats, fire engines and color guards rolled down flagdecked Main Street on schedule today for the annual Fourth of July paradethe marchers, drivers and watchers oblivious to the absence of four regular members of the village's 11man Police Department.

title: Delaying of Iraqi Leader's Planet Reportedly Upset Plans for Coup
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 4  jraq's former chief of public security had planned in a coup Saturday to seize or assassinate President Ahmed Hassan alBakr and Vice President Saddam Hussein with the goal of taking power in Baghdad, according to informed Arab diplomatic sources and newspapers here today.

title: Church at Wounded Knee Burns in Suspected Arson
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., July 4 (UPI)The white, highspired Roman Catholic church that became a symbol of the 71day occupation of Wounded Koee burned to the ground late last night. Indian policemen said today that arson was suspected.

title: The Dance
description: LEE, Mass., July 4  A special sense of excitement and a soldout house marked the opening of the twomonth season at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here last night. Under the new Management of Walter Terry, the dance critic and the festival's acting director, the institution has embarked upon a policy of both preserving the 40year tradition of its founder, the late Ted Shawn, and exuding a fresh kind of international glamour.

title: U.S. Tells Police in Atlanta To Speed Hiring of Blacks
description: ATLANTA, July 4 (UPI)  Police Chief John Inman has been asked in a letter from the Justice Department to expedite the hiring of blacks for the city police force.

title: U.S. COURTS ACTING TO END DISPARITY IN PRISON TERMS
Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 19671

title: Allende Abrogates Curbs Imposed After Revolt
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 4 (UPI)President Salvador Allende Gostens today called off emergency decrees giving the armed forces the job of policing the country and returned it to full civilian rule. The emergeny situation followed the abortive military uprising Friday.

title: 2 MOVIE THEATERS RAIDED IN PASSAIC
description: PASSAIC, July 4  In a steppedup campaign against, pornography, the Passaic County police yesterday raided two theaters here showing Xrated movies, seized the films and arrested five persons, including Georgina Spelvin the star of The Devil in Miss Jones.

title: Fed Had Unusual Ground For Rejecting Bank Deal
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The Federal Reserve Board has rejected a proposed nonbank acquisition by a bank holding company on the somewhat unusual ground that it might tend to weaken the major bank controlled by the holding company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The first Japaneseowned hotel in the city will open next Wednesday, aimed at the steadily increasing numbers of Japanese businessmen, art buyers and travelers who are making a growing impact on the American tourist market.

title: U.S.French Undersea Project Will Explore Rifting Processes That Are Widening the Atlantic Ocean
description: ABOARD THE CANBERRA at sea, July 4With a dive into the black gorge that bisects the Atlantic, the French bathyscaphe Archimede will initiate an adventurous FrenchAmerican project this summer to explore what many scientists consider the basic process responsible for shaping the earth's surface,

title: SAIGON IS MOVING REFUGEES TO GET BROADER CONTROL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2The Saigon Government is greatly expanding its territorial control by moving tens of thousands of refugees into vast stretches of no man's land where the Vietcong have roamed freely for years.

title: Lynner Duo in Net Final
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 4  Paul Lynner and John Dunn, the firstseeded team, defeated Joe Struhl and Alan Berk, 76, 63, in the semifinals of the Long Island senior doubles championship at the, Shore Tennis Club today. Dick Lewis and Martin Elkind beat Ladislav Hecht and Vic EImaleh, 64, 63.

title: Watergate Panel Hints Mrs. Mitchell Stay Out
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)The Senate Watergate committee has reportedly dropped a hint that Mrs. John N. Mitchell not attend the Watergate hearings next week when her husband, the former Attorney General, testifies.

title: Convicted State Judge Asks New Trial
description: Former State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst of Suffolk County, convicted of bankruptcy fraud, has charged in an application for a new trial that he could have purchased his freedom from prosecution for $50,000 by dealing with certain intermediaries who represented themselves as acting on behalf of a former United States Attorney General and deputy attorney general.

title: Happy Birthday
description: LONDON, July 4Someone once proposed to Thomas Jefferson a celebration of his birthday. The only birthday which I recognize, he said is that of my country's liberties.

title: PHNOM PENH ROAD TO SEA CUT AGAIN
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 4 (UPI)The Cambodian command announced today that the road connecting Phnom, (Penh with the sea had again cut by Communist troops.

title: Saluting American Song Gershwin, Porter and Other Melodies Pour Forth at a Jazz Evening
description: For those whose complaint about jazz has been I can't hear the melody, the Newport Jazz Festival offered a fourhour Salute to the American Song on Tuesday night at Philharmonic Hall that was melody in excelsis, The works of some of America's greatest song writersGershwin, Rodgers, Porter, Ellington, Waller and others were played by such toplevel jazz musicians as Earl Hines, Dave Bruheck, Gerry Mulligan, Art Hodes, Rahsaan Roland Kirk and the Modern Jazz Quartet and sung by four jazzwise singers, Al Hibbler, Teddi King, Sylvia Syms and Mabel Mercer.

title: Canada's Mounties, Now Under Criticism, Hailed by Queen on 100th Anniversary
description: REGINA, Saskatchewan July 4Queen Elizabeth led a, rich and colorful 100th birthday celebration for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police today at a time when the venerable force finds itself newly a center of some controversy.

title: Screen:' Cleopatra Jones' Treks to Drug Netherworld
description: Tamara Dobson, the former model who plays the title role in "Cleopatra Jones," is black, beautiful and very, very tall (6 feet 2 inches), which may explain the rather expressionless look on her face. It's as if she were monitoring the world from the top of the Empire State Building on a smoggy day.Cleopatra is a special Government agent who's into drug-busting. "My jurisdiction extends from Ankara, Turkey, to Watts Tower," she explains at one point. She's also a karate expert, drives a souped-up Corvette and wears wigs of Korean hair and a lot of odd clothes that seem to be made out of fur tails. Naturally, she drives men wild, mostly, I suspect, because she is there, like Mount Rainier.The movie seems to want to be a James Bond sort of adventure in black drag, but it's more reminiscent of "Batman," especially with Shelley Winters having a high old time of it playing a character named Mommy, an underworld boss with a fondness for young girls and, apparently, for sweets."Cleopatra Jones" opened yesterday at the De Mille and 34th Street East Theaters.'Cleopatra Jones' Treks to Drug Netherworld

title: 2 Unwed Mothers Backed By Court on School Posts
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., July 4 (AP)A Federal District Court said yesterday that a school system could not refuse to hire women merely because they were unwed mothers.

title: City Welfare Rolls Drop 3, 362, Eighth Monthly Decline in Row
description: A May decrease of 3,362 persons in the city's welfare rolls the eighth consecutive monthly declinewas announced yesterday by Jule M. Sugarman, Human Resources Administrator.

title: Business Briefs
description: David Berger, counsel for the Penn Central Company, yesterday called on the Attorney General of Pennsylvania to petition the United States Court of Appeals for an immediate stay of an order by Federal District Court Judge John P. Fullam authorizing trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad to file their plan of liquidation with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Issue and Debate
description: With the voting on the Administration's proposed Trade Reform Act, expected in the House of Representatives in the next few weeks, one of the oldest issues in American historythat of trade policywill get a fresh shaking out.

title: Vatican's Overtures to East Stirring Disquiet in Church
description: ROME, July 4Only 25 years after Pope Pius XII pronounced his famous  and largely futile  excommunication of atheistic Communism, the Vatican seems intent on conciliating MarxistLeninist governments.

title: West Skeptical on Soviet Draft at Parley
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 4 The Foreign Ministers of France and West Germany warned today against unrealistically high expectations for the 35member Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, while the Soviet Union published its outline of what it hoped the conference would accomplish.

title: Compassionate Example
description: The decision of the Army and Navy to dismiss misconduct charges against seven former prisoners of war is a wise and compassionate act, although tragically too late for an eighth accused enlisted man who took his life while awaiting the outcome of the Pentagon review.

title: Blaze on a Coast Mountain May Take Weeks to Control
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., July 4 (UPI)A stubborn brush and timber fire burning since Saturday on the steep slopes of Mount San Jacinto may take several weeks to control, forestry officials said today.

title: SAIGON IS MOVING REFUGEES TO GET BROADER CONTROL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2The Saigon Government is greatly expanding its territorial control by moving tens of thousands of refugees into vast stretches of no man's land where the Vietcong have roamed freely for years.

title: Hurricane Loses Strength, Heads for North Atlantic
description: MIAMI, July 4 (UPI)Hurricane Alice plowed toward the North Atlantic with weakening winds today after brushing past the resort island of Bermuda.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Emaciated Blues Show Up Along Coast
description: Emaciated bluefish are attracting a good deal of attention from New Jersey to Cape Cod this summer.

title: Psychic Group to Seek Lost Continent
description: ENCINO. Calif., July 4An expedition of oddly assorted explorers will leave New York by plane tomorrow for the Gulf of Cadiz, southwest of Spain, where they believe that psychic vibrations out of the void of milleniums will guide them to the Lost Continent of Atlantis.

title: Vacations Cut Sweden's Health Care
description: STOCKHOLM, July 4Elective surgery and medical examinations have come to a virtual standstill in Sweden as hospital officials have closed hundreds of wards and a few hospitais in a traditional practice that stems from the sudden migration of Sweden's population for the summer.

title: A Group in Greece Asks Guarantee of a Fair Vote
description: ATHENS, July 4  A group of civic leaders opposed to the militarybacked Government asked today for guarantees that the referendum of July 29 on the abolition of the monarchy would be conducted fairly.

title: Today's Jazz Events
description: Following is a schedule of today's events in the Newport Jazz Festival  New York:

title: Chase Agrees to Be Agent For Bank of China in U.S.
description: HONG KONG, July 4  The Chase Manhattan Bank will represent the Bank of China in the United States under an agreement concluded by David Rockefeller, Chase Manhattan chairman, during a 10day visit to China.

title: Value of Farm Land Rises
description: HARRISBURG, July 4. (UPI) The real estate value of farm land in Pennsylvania increased by 20 per cent from March, 1972 through March, 1973, the said yesterday. Quoting United States Department of Agriculture statistics, a state spokesman said the increase was the secondhighest in the nation, exceeded only by Wisconsin's 21 per cent increase.

title: Brooklyn Synagogue Blaze Is Laid to Arsonists
description: A fire that heavily damaged a black Israelite synagogue in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday was the work of arsonists, according to Chief Fire Marshal Edwin H. Sheppard.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WEST ORANGE, July 4What could be more exciting to an athlete than winning an Amateur Athletic Union national championship and a gold medal at the PanAmerican Games? For Richie Sofman, its the chance to wrestle in the Maccabiah Games.

title: Morris Advertising Is Closing Its Shop
description: While Leonid I. Brezhnev, Soviet Communist party leader, was here visiting with President Nixon, Edward E. Spitzer, vice president of Nadler & Larimer, was there visiting Soviet ad agencies. It was sort of an unplanned cultural exchange.

title: Bridge: A Virtuous Declarer Seeks Extra Chance in Line of Play
description: Whether virtue is its own reward at the bridgetable is a debatable point. The virtuous declarer, for example, works hard to uncover a line of play that will give him a slight extra chance. The slight extra chance does not come up, and the other declarers, playing more routinely, achieve the same score. The virtuous one must be content with the thought that he has outplayed his rivals, although he has not outscored them.

title: Soaring Interest Rates
description: Shortterm interest rates are skyrocketing. On Monday the nation's largest banks boosted their prime rate the minimum charge to their best business customers from 7 per cent to 8 per cent. When 1973 began, the prime rate ranged from 5 to 6 per centwhile the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Arthur F. Burns, his capacity as head of the Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends, was twisting bankers' arms to keep the rate down.

title: SHELBY G. FELL
description: ROSSMOORE, N. J., July 4 Shelby G. Fell, a retired inustrial engineer and a former Mayor of Westfield, died yesterday in Princeton Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived here.

title: 2 MOVIE THEATERS RAIDED IN PASSAIC
description: PASSAIC, N. J., July 4In a steppedup campaign against pornography, the Passaic County police yesterday raided two theaters here showing Xrated movies, seized the films and arrested five persons including Georgina Spelvin, the star of The Devil in Miss Jones,

title: KENNEDY SPEAKS AT WALLACE FETE
description: DECATUR, Ala., July 4 Senator Edward M. Kennedy flew into the Deep South today to portray Gov. George C. Wallace and himself as fellow warriors against those who used the people's power to strike at the rights of the people.

title: PURGING OF AN AIDE OF LIN PIAO VERIFIED
description: HONG KONG, July 4The dismissal of Lung Shuchin, a close associate of Lin Piao, from positions that made him the leader of the Communist party, the administration and the military forces in China's big Sinkiang region in Central Asia, was confirmed in messages received today from Urumchi, the region's capital.

title: WYCKOFF STRIKERS RETURNING TO JOBS
description: Nonmedical employes at Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn agreed yesterday to end a strike that had begun Friday and to return to work this morning.

title: Roundup: Cardenas Proves TigerTamer for Indians
description: Leo Cardenas has bounced around the major leagues for 14 seasons. Unlike many other glove men, the seasoned shortstop carried a respectable hat to the plate. In nine years with Cincinnati he averaged 261. In four years with Minnesota and California he batted .251.

title: Miss Evert, Mrs. King in Tennis Final
Pupils Make Their Cookbook A Class in Linguistics, Too
VIETCONG TO AID IN SEARCH FOR 2
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4 (Reuters)  The Vietcong promised today to help look for the two Canadian truce observers who disappeared last Thursday while visiting an area about 40 miles northeast of Saigon.

title: GROUP FOR BLIND WARRING ON BIAS
description: The president of the National Federation of the Blind vowed yesterday that the organization would not falter or back up in its campaign to stop discrimination against blind people solely because they could not see.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The story of two of Gerrit Thomas Rietveld's decadesold pacesetting chair designs has a familiar ringboth made it to museums long before they were accepted in the marketplace.

title: She's Found Gold in Memories of Snowflakes, Gulls, Even Chicken Wire
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.Some people think chicken wire belongs on farms. Franci Young, one of this town's growing number of secondstage career women, thinks it belongs on the dinner tablenot literally, just in the design of china.

title: KENNEDY SPEAKS AT WALLACE FETE
description: DECATUR, Ala., July 4 Senator Edward M. Kennedy flew into the Deep South today to portray Gov. George C. Wallace and himself as fellow warriors against those who used the people's power to strike at the rights of the people.

description: NEW DELHI, July 3India and Pakistan are stepping up their military rivalry and involvement in the Persian Gulf and the Middle East.

title: Robert Williams Jr. Dies; ExHead of Callaway Mills
description: Robert D. Williams Jr., retired president of Callaway Mills, Inc., died Tuesday night at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Westchester County commuters stranded by the closing of Grand Central Terminal between 1:30 A.M. and 5:30 A.M. can get taxi service at group rates beginning July 10, the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade announced yesterday.

title: 60 Yachts Start in Light Air In 27th TransPacific Race
description: LOS ANGELES, July 3 (UPI) The winds were light as a fleet of 60 crossed the starter's buoy today and set out on a 2,225mile race from Los Angeles Harbor to Honolulu. Officials for the 27th transPacific yacht race said the winds should pick up by Friday.

title: Blacks Role in American Revolution Depicted in Vivid Washington Show
description: This Fourth of July is yours, not mine. You may rejoice, I must mourn... What to the American slave is your Fourth of July? I answered: A day that reveals to him, more than all other days in the year, gross injustice and cruelty to which he is the constant victim. To him, your celebration is a sham; your boast of liberty, an unholy license . . . your prayers and hymns, your sermons and thanksgiving . . . are mere bombast, fraud, deception, impiety and hypocrisy.

title: TROOPS QUELL RIOT IN BELFAST PRISON
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 4 (Reuters)Fifteen prisoners and several guards and soldiers were injured today in a brief riot at the prison outside Belfast where about 700 men are detained in connection with the violence.

title: FOUR GET AWARDS FOR PUBLIC WORK
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The American Institute of Public Service announced today its first four awards for distinguished public service.

title: For 540 Americans the Fourth Was a Hot and Hilly Foot Race
description: ATLANTA, July 4  Five hundred and forty Americans celebrated the 197th birthday of the United States today by running down Peachtree Street under a blazing sun. An estimated 523 of them finished an allotted course 6.1 miles, and ended the day in triumph.

title: 3 KILLED IN CRASH OF PRIVATE PLANE
description: TOLLAND, Conn., July 4A light plane crashed into an unoccupied house early this evening, killing all three men in the aircraft.

title: News Summary and Index
description: White House officials announced that Henry A. Kissinger will go to Peking in late July or early August to confer with Premier Chou Enlai. The trip will be on the agenda when Huang Chen, head of the Chinese liaison office in Washington, meets with President Nixon in San Clemente, Calif., tomorrow. Mr. Nixon and Mr. Huang are expected to discuss overall ChineseAmerican relations in light of recent agreements reached by the President and the Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev. [Page 1, Cols. 13.]

title: 60 Naturalized at Monticello
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 4 (AP)  Sixty persons from 21 nations were naturalized as American citizens today in ceremonies under they oaks at Thomas Jefferson's home, Monticello. More than 1,100 persons watched the naturalization ceremonies as Federal District Judge Ted Daton received the petitions and swore in the new citizens.

title: Flash Flooding Hits Maine, Vermont, New Hampshire
description: Flash flooding hit Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine yesterday for the second time in a week, swamping areas still soggy from severe floods last weekend, The Associated Press reported.

title: N.E.A. MERGER STEP HARED BY SELDEN
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 4 David Selden, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said today that he welcomed a proposal by the leadership of the rival National Education Association for talks on merger between the two organizations.

title: Nixon, in Quiet Holiday, Holds Staff Conference
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 4 (AP)President Nixon spent a quiet Fourth of July holiday at the Western White House, getting in a morning round of staff conferences and spending time with his family.

title: Elevator Crisis Worsens In City Housing Projects
description: The breakdown of elevators in city housing projects worsened yesterday, with 21 highrise buildings  four more than on Tuesday having no elevator service at all.

title: Miss Jacobs Bride Of S. M. Grossman
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., July 4 Miss Nancy Louise Jacobs, daughter of Associate Justice Nathan Leonard Jacobs of the State Supreme Court and Mrs. Jacobs, was married here this afternoon to Stanley Merrill Grossman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Grossman of Forest Hills, Queens, New York. Rabbi Samuel Cohen performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Bremer's Brother Guilty
description: MIAMI, July 4 (AP)William A. Bremer, whose brother, Arthur H. Bremer, was convicted of the attempted assassination of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, pleaded guilty yesterday to 178 counts of fraud in the operatidn of three weightreducing salons. William Bremer faces a maximum prison term of 49 years and fines totaling $102,500. Several hundred women said that after they had paid to join the salons they found the doors locked and all the exercise equipment removed.

title: Daughter of Nixon Says He Considered Resigning
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 4Mrs. David Eisenhower says that her father, President Nixon, considered resigning over Watergate, but his family talked him out of it. Thefamily felt that resignation would be an admission of wrongdoing, and that he was needed in the Presidency, she said.

title: Chase Agrees to Be Agent For Bank of China in U.S.
description: HONG KONG, July 4  The Chase Manhattan Bank will represent the Bank of China in the United States under an agreement concluded by David Rockefeller, Chase Manhattan chairman, during a 10day visit to China.

title: Ecology Unit Sends Dean Data to Court
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Opponents of Big Sky of Montana hope to halt construction of the $20million recreational complex as a result of disclosures last week in the Senate Watergate hearings.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Inaugurated as the Mayor of Camden on Monday, Angelo J. Errichetti let it be known yesterday that he had filed a suit against the Department of Housing and Urban Development to force the release of $8.9million in Federal funds for an urbanrenewal project.

title: DR. JULIUS HOLLO
description: Dr. Julius Hollo, an internist specializing in pulmonary diseases, died Tuesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 141 East 88th Street.

title: New Jersey Stores Feeling Grape War
description: NEWARK, July 4A new skirmish is being fought in Nevi Jersey in the national war between supermarkets and the United Farm Workers. At issue are Western table grapes, which are beginning to come into , the markets in quantity.

title: News Summary and Index
description: White House officials announced that Henry A, Kissinger will go to Peking in late July or early August to confer with Premier Chou Enlai. The trip will be on the agenda when Huang Chen, head of the Chinese liaison office in Washington, meets with President Nixon in San Clemente, Calif., tomorrow. Mr. Nixon and Mr. Huang are expected to discuss overall ChineseAmerican relations in light of recent agreements reached by the President and the Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev. [Page 1, Cols. 13.]

title: FULL POCKET WINS $58,750 HANDICAP
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 4Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Bensinger's Full Pocket thrilled many in crowd of 15,169 at Liberty Bell Park today when he defeated Dan Lasater'sBrick Door by neck in the third running of the $58,750 Firecracker Handicap.

title: Books of The Times
description: AFTER. By Robert Anderson. 342 pages. Random House. $6.95. STARTING OVER. By Dan Wakefield. 29r, pages. Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence. $7.95. I came from that generation that was programed to connect, explains Christopher Larsen, the somber protagonist of the playwright Robert Anderson's first novel, After. It is just about the most penetrating thing that Larsen has to say in a narrative overly fond of such words as infinitely, desperately, incredibly, and terrible (as in terrible need). Nor is Chris Larsen ever very clear about what, or whom, he is trying to connect with, or disconnect from. After begins as a devoted husband's memorial to a wife who has just died of cancer. It then wanders into the account of the widower's affair with a young actress whoironicallyhas just become the first winner of an award set up in honor of the beloved deceased. Then, rather late in the game, it turns out that all was not so devoted between Larsen and his late wife. There were love letters from Larsen, written to an actress when his wife's own acting career was getting him down. And now, what with the other actress's messy divorce proceedings threatening to bring these letters to light, Larsen must do a little explaining to his standoffish son, his new young lover and all the friends who always thought the Larsens marriage ideal. It is as if a meandering story had suddenly made up its mind to be about the illusion and reality of a marriage, when it is much too late to be about anything in particular, except the hero's confused attempts to make connections....

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: ARGENTINE PLANE WITH 74 HIJACKED
description: LIMA, Peru, Thursday, July 5 (AP)One or more hijackers took over an Argentine airliner yesterday and forced it to land in three South American nations en route to Cuba. Late last night the plane took off for Panama with 25 persons reported aboard.

title: A Conservative Town Marks the Holiday
description: OCEAN GROVE, July 4 This citadel of social, religious and political conservatism paid homage today to country, God and flag and heard Governor Cahill extol Ocean Grove as a symbol of all that is best in America.

title: Riva Ridge Sets World Mark, Joins $1Million Class
It Rains, but Watergate Weicker Shines As Crowd at Parade Pours on the Praise
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 4Perched atop the back seat of a Buick convertible, Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who became an instant celebrity during the Watergate hearings, proved to be the major attraction today at the sodden 25th annual P. T. Barnum Festival rainorshine parade.

title: Clinics Seen Developing New Talent for Judging
Cruel Hoax in Greece
description: The referendum scheduled by Greece's military rulers for July 29 will give voters an even narrower choice than first indicated.

title: BROTHER OF KILLER SLAIN IN BAR CLASH
description: LAKE WORTH, Fla., July (AP)John M. Whitman, 24 years old, whose brother killed 16 persons in the University of Texas tower incident, was shot to death after a quarrel at a bar here last night.

title: Dr. Abdel aIBazzaz, 60, ExPremier of Iraq, Dead
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 4 (UPI)  Dr. Abdel Rahman alBazzaz, who served as Iraqi Premier for 11 months in the nineteensixties and later was sentenced to prison for espionage, died last Thursday in Baghdad, the Iraqi Bar Association said yesterday. He was 60 years old.

title: CONNECTICUT TO GET 25 OFFICES FOR OTB
description: A contract for constructing five minitrack and 20 conventional offtrack betting offices in Connecticut within the next. 10 months has been signed by the American Totalisator Company.

title: U.S. Wimbledon Final
description: Chris Evert and Mrs. Billie Jean King will meet tomorrow in the first allUnited States women's tennis final at Wimbledon since 1957. Miss Evert beat Mrs. Margaret Court and Mrs. King I overcame Evonne Goolagong in the semifinals yesterday.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
FIRECRACKER 400 WON BY PEARSON
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4 (UPI)David Pearson drovehis 1971 Mercury to a six length victory over Richard Petty in the 15th annual Firecracker 400 race today.

title: $7Million in City Cash Reserve Kept in InterestFree Accounts
description: The city administration carries $7million as a cash reserve in 22 banks, usually long untouched but without bearing interest, in what city officials said this week had been in part a tradition, recognizing bank services for the city, and in part a community aid.

title: Orchard Beach on Holiday Is a Puerto Rican Fiesta
description: It is about six miles from the sweltering, littered streets of the South Bronx to the cooling sea breezes and littered sands of Orchard Beach, and for thousands of Puerto Rican families, the 45minute, 70cent subway and bus ride is the only way to beat the heat.

title: Major League Leaders
description: By The Associated Press

title: Gallup Finds More Would Now Back Bid by McGovern
description: President Nixon's margin of victory over Senator George McGovern in the 1972 Presidential election would have been far smaller if the contest had been held in late June this year, a Gallup Poll released yesterday indicates.

title: ExOiler Set to Testify on '71 Bribe Offer
A Cap Over The Wall
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Senator Edward Kennedy went to Decatur, Ala. a city named after the man who said our country, right or wrongto salute Gov. George C. Wallace, to begin to put the DeMocratic party back together, and to toss his cap over the wall of race.

title: British Couple Is Saved After 117 Days on Lifeboat
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (AP) The rescue of a shipwrecked English couple who drifted for 117 days in a lifeboat in the Pacific was reported by the Coast Guard today.

title: Chess: If Facing a Gambit, Beware  This Gift Horse Has Pyorrhea
description: If you dare to accept gambit, be sure you know what you are getting into. The pace of the game has got to be altogether different from that of normal positional contests: The gambiteer has to strike hard with sharp play to make use of his advantage in development, while the defender must be ready for difficult, radical maneuvers to survive sudden attacks while keeping the booty.

title: Markets Closed
description: All United States securities and commodities exchanges were closed yesterday in observance of Independence Day. Banks and most Government offices also were closed, while the Postal Service operated on a holiday schedule.

title: Narcotics Worth $3Million Publicly Burned in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4 (Reuters)Three million dollars worth of what was believed to be almost pure heroin went up in a cloud of oily black smoke in a Saigon street today in the biggest public drug burning ever.

title: East Side Factions Blame Each Other for Violence
description: ItalianAmerican residents of a Lower East Side housing development and black and Puerto Rican members of a youth gang blamed each other yesterday for two nights of disorders that shattered a long period of relatively peaceful coexistence.

title: N.A.A.C.P. OFFICIAL DOUBTS JOB GAINS
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 4 Herbert Hill, labor director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has challenged recent reports of black economic progress and charged that minorities have lost ground in skilled jobs in the building trades.

title: YANKEES DOWNED TWICE, 21 AND 10; LEAD IS 2 GAMES

description: WANTAGH, L. I., July 4Francis H. Dunne, senior vice president in the Chase Manhattan Bank's bank operations department  owner securities handling group, died yesterday, apparent of a heart attack. He was 43 years old and lived here.

title: Riders Complain New Cabbies Have Trouble Navigating City
description: An increasing number of taxi passengers in the city are complaining that driversparticularly young ones  don't seem to know the local geography too well these days. But nothing much can be done about it, city officials say, because of a shortage of drivers.

title: Personal Finance: AfterDivorce Cost
description: More than 800,000 divorces a record number  split American families into two households in 1972.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Unless the Mets and the Braves reach the playoffs this seasonand a quick glance at the standings will show you how ridiculous a supposition that isHenry Aaron will be paying his last visit to Shea Stadium over the weekend. I can't think of anyone in baseball right now who is more important than Henry, because he keeps advancing with painstaking steadfastness toward a date with destiny: the breaking of Babe Ruth's home run record of 714.

title: WEST INDIES GROUP SETS UP A MARKET
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 4 (Reuters)  The prime ministers of Trinidad and Tobago, Barbados, Guyana, and Jamaica today signed a treaty establishing a community and common market.

title: Symposiums Dig Into Black Music/Jazz
description: Newport Jazz Festival discussions on the black music prove in daily symposiums at Lincoln Center's Library and Museum of the Performing Arts that talking about the music is almost as exciting as listening to it.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: DIARY OF A SHINJUKU BURGLAR, a Japanese film, with English subtitles, directed by Oshima, at the First Avenue Screening Room.

title: Ballet Theater Offers Eclectic Works
description: American Ballet Theater is fiercely proud of its eclectic repertory, and no clearer demonstration of that variety could be offered than the opening program on Tuesday night at the State Theater. It comprised four ballets in almost as many styles, with bravura classical, hybrid modern and traditional character dancing rubbing shoulders in friendly contention. The results for the most part looked very good.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 4 (UPI)A man renovating his house in suburban Balmain has found more than $250,000 (Australian) from the ransom paid two years ago by Qantas Airlines in a bomb hoax, the police said today.

description: In The First and Essential Freedom, on the American Broadcasting Company network tonight at 8 o'clock, A.B.C. News reviews the history, past and present, of freedom of the press in this country.

title: GOING OUT Guider,
description: MOIST HOIST What with all the rain that has been coming down, it could be unseemly to talk of places where the water comes down in sheets. But there are several manmade waterfalls about town that endow our concrete canyons with a pleasantly noisy, damp beauty, particularly since they are usually features of tiny parks. The newest is in Exxon Park, the newly named paved and narrow park between 49th and 50th Streets west of the Avenue of the Americas behind the Exxon Building in Rockefeller Center. It's 21 feet high and 54 feet wide and the recirculated water is pumped at 2,800 gallons a minute. Nearby, at 3 East 53d Street, is the 20foothigh falls of Paley Park, a delightfully shaded enclave, that is about 40 feet wide and achieves its scenic beauty from a 1,800gallonaminute recirculation. Little Greenacre Park, on 51st Street, between Second and Third Avenues, has falls that rise 30 feet and cascade down to a pretty little threelevel sitting area. Way downtown, at 90 Washington Street, corner of Rector Street, are the 20foot falls of the Bank of New York, not a park but a watery punctuation in a concrete canyon,

title: Common Market Aide Set For U.S. Soybean Parley
description: BRUSSELS, July 4  Pierre Lardinois, the European Economic Community commissioner responsible for agriculture, will fly to Washington this weekend for talks on the United States Government's temporary 50 per cent reduction in exports of soybeans and derivitive products. He is expected to discuss future prospects with Earl Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, and George P. Shultz, Treasury Secretary.

title: Lead Shot, Steel Trap
description: If man's inhumanity to animals Were not almost as great as his inhumanity to man, Congress would unhesitatingly pass two measures now before it which should have been passed literally decades ago. One is designed to save two to three million birds ,from needless death each year, not directly at the hands of hunters, but indirectly, senselessly, slowly and agonizingly from ingesting the lead shot that hunters have already expended.

description: JUly 5, 1973

title: People in Sports: Trevino in Tune in Troon
description: I am . . . said Lee Trevino, when asked whether he thought the wind would bother him in Scotland next week when he defends his British Open title,  . . . the world's best wind player.

title: RETAIL SALES UP 6.4% EAST MONTH
Long Legislature Ends
description: AUGUSTA, Me., July 4 (AP) The longest legislative session in Maine's history adjourned early today just six months and a day after it began. Maine's lawmakers were at the Capitol for 108 working days.

title: 8 Hurt in 2 Bus Mishaps
description: NEWARK, July 4 (UPI) Two buses skidded on the New Jersey Turnpike in two accidents near northbound exit 14 late yesterday and early today, injuring eight persons, the police said, A Domenico bus, from Bayonne bound for New York, skidded into a car at 11:50 P.M., injuring both drivers and four passengers. A Transport of New Jersey bus bound for New York skidded from the center lane into a car in the left lane at 12:20 A.M. also injuring both drivers.

title: American League
description: Thursday, July 5, 1973

title: DAVID GOTTLIEB, 59; HEADED NEWS CHAIN
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa, July 4 (AP)David K. Gottlieb, president of Lee Enterprises, Inc., and nationally known in the newspaperresearch field, died at his home here today. He was 59 years old.

title: Fireworks Maker Killed
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 4 (AP)  A 15yearold boy was fatally injured when chemicals he was mixing for homemade fireworks exploded yesterday in a backyard shed. Randy McGhie, died today of internal and head injuries and burns over half his body, according to a spokesman at Santa Clara Valley Medical Center.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
Young Revelers Quelled
description: BRISTOL, R. I., July 4 (AP) The police used tear gas last night to sweep Hope Street of an unruly young mob of Fourth of July revelers. The trouble began about 11 P.M. when large groups of youngsters hurled beer bottles and cherry bombs at the police.

title: WILLIAM S. SCHERMAN
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 4William S. Scherman, a retired executive of Carl Henry, Inc., a New York mailorder concern, died here today. Mr. Scherman, who lived at 42 Glenorchy Road, was 88 years old. He was a brother of the late Harry Scherman, founder of the BookoftheMonth Club.

title: Vatican's Overtures to East Stirring Disquiet in Church
description: ROME, July 4Only 25 years after Pope Pius XII pronounced his famous  and largely futile  excommunication of atheistic Communism, the Vatican seems intent on conciliating MarxistLeninist governments.

description: Several big stores, including Korvette, Arnold Constable and S. Klein, made holiday hay yesterday by staying open and drawing large crowds to special Fourth of July sales.

title: The Obscenity Ruling, Pro and Con
description: OXFORD, Ohio  The Supreme Court's historic decision to permit tighter state controls of pornography will be greeted with spasms of indignation from most intellectualsand with sighs of relief by most Americans. The former will see visions of Comstockery blighting the land; the latter will see opportunities to curb some of the most disgraceful cultural trends in American history.

description: KINGSTON, N. Y., July 4 William T. McCarthy, who retired in 1971 as a news editor of The Daily News in New York after 28 years on the newspaper's staff, died today in the Benedictine Hospital. He was 65 years old and had lived in Phoenicia since his retirement.

title: Miss Clifford Bride of D. F. Eaton
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 4Miss Joanne Elizabeth Clifford and Douglas Field Eaton were married here this afternoon. Mr. Eaton is an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York and his wife is a lawyer associated with the New York law firm of Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates.

title: U.S. Tells Police in Atlanta To Speed Hiring of Blacks
description: ATLANTA, July 4 (UPI) Police Chief John Inman has been asked in a letter from the Justice Department to expedite the hiring of blacks for the city police force.

title: Pops Series Is Off to a Fine Start With Cole Porter
description: The annual Evening at the Pops series, beamed in from Boston by the Public Broadcasting Service, got off to an excellent start last night at 9:30 over WNET/Channel 13 with an hour of Cole Porter's music.

title: Stacey Howard, Gary Robinson Wed in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, July 4Miss Stacey Ann Howard, daughter of Bailey K. Howard of Chicago and Beverly Hills, Calif., and Mrs. Frankie C. Howard of Chicago, was married here this afternoon to Gary Edward Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rubin Robinson of Chicago and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Louis Binstock performed the ceremony in the Grand Ballroom of the Drake Hotel.

title: Beyond the Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  President Nixon's price freeze June 13 was supposed to help the Administration get a leg up on combating the unexpected 1973 burst of inflation.

title: Army's Planned New Tank Assailed as Too Expensive
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The Army, after going back to the drawing board, has come forth with plans for a new battle tank that will cost almost as much as a tank Congress canceled in 1971 because it was considered too expensive.

title: Italian Crisis Nearing End As Socialists Back Rumor
description: ROME, Thursday, July 5 (AP)  The Italian Socialist party announced today that it would take part in a centerleft coalition Cabinet led by Premierdesignate Mariano Rumor. The decision virtually ended Italy's government crisis, which began three weeks ago.

title: Sands Point School, Sued by Parents In a Qualifications Dispute, Is Sold
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., July 3 The Sands Point Country Day SchoolFetsch Academy, a private school here that is involved in litigation instituted by parents who contend that the school failed to live up to its statements that it accepted only gifted children, has been sold.

title: Navy Under Pressure to Widen Fighter Competition
description: The Defense Department is under, growing pressure to include additional planes, among them two lightweight lighters being built for the Air Force, in its, projected competition for a lowercost Navy fighter.

title: 4 KEY NIXON AIDES REPORTEDLY CITED
description: A status report from the original Watergate prosecutors to the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, recommends the indictment of four former White House and Nixon campaign aides for conspiring to obstruct justice, CBS News reported last night.

title: Mr. Gromyko's Charter
description: The European Charter proposed by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in opening the Helsinki Conference on Security and Cooperation was so framed as to enshrine for all time the inviolability of Communist expansion into midEurope.

title: REFORM SCHOOLS LIMITED BY COURT TO DELINQUENTS
description: In a major victory for critics of the juvenilejustice system here, the state Court of Appeals has struck down the practice of placing children who are accused of no crime in reform schools with children who have been convicted of such crimes as murder and robbery.

title: Time Inc. Set to Acquire Temple Industries Unit
description: Time Inc. has executed a definitive agreement to acquire Temple Industries, Inc., through an exchange of stock valued at about $153million, according to yesterday's announcement by Andrew Heiskell, chairman of Time Inc. and Arthur Temple, chairman of Temple Industries.

title: Notes on People
description: Meeting scheduled: At 11 A.M. today in San Clemente, Calif., between Dr. Michael DeBakey, the Houston heart specialist, and President Nixon, who seeks the doctor's impressions of a recent visit to the Soviet Union. Dr. DeBakey's name appeared on the White House enemies list made public last week. Asked if Dr. DeBakey were the first enemy to be asked to visit the President, the deputy White House press secretary, Gerald L. Warren answered: I have already said all I am going to say about that. On previous occasions when the list was raised, Mr. Warren's reply has been No comment.

title: Dining Out In New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Women to Golf on Island
description: GRAND ISLAND, N. Y., July 5 (UPI)The $40,000 Marc Equity classic begins here tomorrow at the twoyearold River Oaks Country Club. The field will include such leadinggolfers as Mrs. Judy Rankin, Mrs. Susan Maxwell Berning, Susan Little, Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge and Mrs. Donna Caponi Young. The course is on an island in the Niagara River, near Buffalo.

title: Its Ambiance and Food Are a Passage to India
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Kleindienst and Dean Part In DeCarlo Case Queried
description: WASHINGTON, July 5Senator Henry M. Jackson charged today that Richard G. Kleindienst and John W. Dean 3d had bypassed normal procedures and safeguards in arranging executive clemency for a highranking organizedcrime figure, Angelo DeCarlo, af ter he served 19 months of a 12year sentence.

title: Rwanda at a Glance
description: GEOGRAPHYRwanda is a small, landlocked central African nation bounded by Zaire, on the West, Uganda on the north, Tanzania on the east and Burundi on the south.Rwanda's 10,166 square miles are marked by sharply defined hills intersected by deep valleys in the south and the rugged Virunga volcano chain in the north.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
