title: $500,000 to Be Spent to Renovate Lion House at Central Park Zoo
description: A $500,000 renovation of the Lion House at the Central Park Zoo  with simulated natural habitats and glass windows replacing the barred cages of lions, tigers, balloons and gorillas  is being planned by the Friends of the Zoo, a volunteer committee of the New York Zoological Society.

title: WALLACE GOBETZ; HEAD OF N.Y.U. UNIT
description: Dr. Wallace Gobetz, director of the Testing Center at New York University since 1952, died of cancer Thursday. He was 56 years old and lived at 540 East 22d Street, Brooklyn.

title: MONEY EXCHANGES IN UPROAR ABROAD AS DOLLAR SLIDES
description: BONN, July 6  Turmoil broke out on the foreignexchange markets today as the dollar fell to new lows for the ninth consecutive day.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Halifax, Nova ScotiaDave Downey, 162 pounds, Halifax, outpointed Royal Dale, 161, Cincinnati, 10 rounds.

title: The Champions, American Style
description: For a few years, Teddy Brenner had a tank of tropical fish in his office.

title: Letters to the Editor
Canadian Ordered to Leave
description: MIAMI, July 6 (UPI)Geza Matrai, a Canadian convicted of assaulting the Soviet Premier, Aleksei Kosygin, in Canada two years ago, has been ordered to leave the United States within 10 days or face deportation. An earlier petition for political asylum had been denied.

title: Cartridge Television Lists Its Assets and Liabilities
description: Cartridge Television, Inc., yesterday listed assets of $18.6million and liabilities of $29million in its petition for a debt arrangement filed in Federal District Court here under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company, which is 32percentowned by the Avco Corporation, explained that difficulties in introducing its Cartivision home videoplayer system had substantially exhausted its funds.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday refused to order two Cumberland County hospitals to provide abortions for two women who said they would have to outside the county if the hospitals refused to help them. The Supreme Court issued a onesentence opinion that upheld a ruling Tuesday by the Appellate Division of Superior Court, the state's second highest court.

title: WINE TALK A Look Back at One Year Of Writing About the Vine
description: One year and 40,000 words ago, Wine Talk began on an experimental basis Was there enough going on to sustain a weekly column? Would there be any reader interest? No one was sure. Fiftytwo weeks later it appears that those fears were groundless.

title: Martin Friedheim, ExAide Of City for Urban Planning
description: GROTON, Vt., July 6Martin B. Friedheim, who recently had been appointed director of Planning and Coordination for the state of Vermont, died last Saturday at his home here. He was 35 years old and recently had moved here from New York.

title: Bridge: The Obscure Delayed Double Can Be Helpfulto Declarer
description: An obscure bid for many players is the delayed double, made by a player who at his first turn passed an opening bid made on his right. Whether such doubles are for penalties or for takeout depends on the opener's rebid.

title: More Grenades Related to Arms Ring Are Found in Lockers at Bus Terminal
description: Six hand grenades were found in two lockers in the Port Authority Bus Terminal here yesterday, and the police said they were part of a shipmerit from which an underground weaponssupply ring sold 11 other grenades to a police undercover man in the East Village on Thursday.

title: New U.S. Consulate Office Raises Flag in Leningrad
description: MOSCOW, July 6For the first time since the Bolshevik Revolution, the American flag was raised today over an American mission in Leningrad, the former imperial capital of St. Petersburg and now the second city of the Soviet Union.

title: First Profit Expected for Britain's Nationalized Steel
description: LONDON, July 6  In couple of weeks the British Steel Corporation is expected to announce that it has made its first profit since it began operations in 1967.

title: Gravediggers Union Ends 27Day Strike
description: The 27day strike of cemetery workers in the metropolitan area was ended yesterday with a settlement reached only a matter of hours before the leader of the 1,700man striking union was to be jailed for continuing the walkout.

title: British Subway Sale Set
description: Keyser Ullmann Holdings, Ltd., London, announced yesterday it planned to sell its Central and District Properties, Ltd., subsidiary to Town and City Properties, Ltd., for $248.3million cash.

title: Black Gets Navy Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (Reuters)The Navy today named Rear Adm. Samuel Gravesly as commander of its cruiserdestroyer Group Two, the biggest fleet operation post ever assigned to a black.

title: People and Business Manhattan Shirt Picks Grethel
description: Henry Grethel, a 41yearold apparel executive, has been named president of the Manhattan Shirt Company. He succeeds William J. McKenna, who was appointed to the newly created post of chairman and continues as chief executive officer.

title: Coin Turnstile, Out of Use 20 Years, Returned to Service in Subway Test
description: The Transit Authority, which abandoned coinoperated subway turnstiles 20 years ago, put one in operation yesterday in a Queens station in a test that it hopes may speed the way for rushhour passengers.

title: Milburn Sets World Mark for 110Meter Hurdles
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, July (AP)Rod. Milburn of the United States set a world record in the 110meter hurdles with a time of 13.1 seconds tonight, onetenth second better than the old mark which he shared.

title: Mets Escape NoHitter In 9th, but Lose by 20
description: The Mets straggled back to New York last night after their memorably bad trip and were greeted by a Shea Stadium crowd of 37,266 persons and a righthander from Kansas named Ron Schueler  who deepend their woes by pitching the Atlanta Braves to a 20 victory.

title: Tornado Wins in Soccer, 21
description: ATLANTA, July 6 (AP) Rich Riddles and Ilija Mitic scored tonight as the Dallas Tornado posted a 21 North American Soccer League triumph over the Atlanta Apollo.

title: State Court Overturns Law on Suspicious Loitering
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the state law prohibiting suspicious loitering was unconstitutional because it was vague enough to depend upon the whim of the policeman.

title: Mongolia Still Has a Few Lamas, But Mostly as a Negative Example
description: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia,  Communist governments usually take care to preserve the most damning evidence left behind by the rulers they overthrow. In Moscow they have the Kremlin to demonstrate the opulence and decadence of the czars. In Peking the Forbidden City stands witness to the luxurious lives of the emperors. And in Ulan Bator, capital of what is now the Mongolian People's Republic, they have the palace of the Living Buddha, the last Great Khan of Mongolia.

title: MERRILL LYNCH ACCUSED BY UTAH Mishandling of University's Fund AllegedDenial Made
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 6 (UPI)The Utah Attorney General's Office today accused the brokerage house of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., of mishandling a Utah State University investment fund.

title: Moorhouse Wins 2 Races And Leads Penguin Sailing
Veterans Work Group Helps Taiwan
Books of The Times
description: THE EDUCATION OF BLACK FOLK. The AfroAmerican Strukgle for Knowledge in White America By Allen B. Ballard. 173 pages. Harper & Row. $6.95.

title: A Chinese Opera Staged With English and Verve
description: There are those who will ask, unknowledgeably, What's new in Peking opera? Those who know will answer, What could possibly be new? The surprising possibilities are gaily underscored, at La Mama, 74a East Fourth Street, where Chinese opera is being done, through next Thursday, in a delightful short take, only one hour, that is thoroughly comprehensible to Western eyes and ears. The Return of the Phoenix has been reworked by Tisa Chang for a cast of five that gives the illusion of being a musical comedy cast of, well, dozens.

title: Pentagon Halts Program That Cost $67Million
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) The Pentagon virtually killed today a program on which $67.5million had been spent to develop a decoy to enable B52 bombers to confuse Soviet radar.

title: Japanese Upset by U.S. Soybean Curbs
description: TOKYO, July 6We are really angry at Nixonsan, Hiroshi Higashimorl, SecretaryGeneral of the Japan Oilseed Processors Association, said today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BENEFIT Grambling College is a small black college near Shreveport, in northern Louisiana, known for a student body of talented athletes, among them Willis Reed, the Knicks basketball player. Its only other known representation in New York is through the Queens Alumni of Grambling College. That borough is apparently the most congenial for Grambling grads.

title: CITY IMPLEMENTS WORKRELIEF PLAN
OSCAR BRYANT FRAZER
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 6Oscar Bryant Frazer, a retired lawyer and former executive vice president of the South Puerto Rico Sugar Company died yesterday in the Inglemoor Nursing Home. He was 87 years old and lived at 388 Morrow Road.

title: U.S. Studies Alleged Offer To Fix Judge's Conviction
description: An alleged offer to fix bankruptcyfraud charges against former State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst of Suffolk County for $50,000 has been under review since last July by the Justice Department, a Federal prosecutor disclosed yesterday.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: BUFFALOSigned Jim Lorentz, forward to multiyear contract.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, July 6 (Reuters)The 235strong American team in the Maccabiah Games arrived today aboard two airliners The contingent is the biggest foreign entry in the games, in which some 1,800 athletes from 30 countries will compete in 20 events beginning Monday.

title: Business Briefs
description: ORLANDO, Fla., July 6 (UPI)A Federal District Court Judge today took the passport of Glenn W. Turner, whose embattled empire is under fire at home and abroad.

title: Amie Amizich, 51, Cards 66 to Take Two  Stroke Lead
description: GRAND ISLAND, N. Y., July 6, (UPI)  Amie Amizich, relaxed because I don't need the money that badly, shot sevenunderpar 66 today to ake the firstround lead in the $35,000 Marc Equity classic.

title: Mrs. Monica Ronan's Wedding To Bruce Nourie Is Held Here
description: Mrs. Monica Vinado Ronan, daughter of Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman and chief executive officer of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and Mrs. Ronan of New York and Easthampton, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Bruce Leo Nourie, director of personnel for the M.T.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Nourie of Little Compton, R. I., and Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: Smith Seeded No. 1
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., July (UPI)  Stan Smith was seeded No. 1 for the $60,000 United States pro tennis championships scheduled for July 1622 at the Longwood Cricket Club. Other seeded players, in order, were Arthur Ashe, Marty Riessen, John Alexander, Cliff Richey, Dick Stockton, Roscoe Tanner and Tom Gorman.

title: Sham Out for 6 Months With a Fractured Leg
description: Sham, the 3yearold colt who chased Secretariat in the Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Belmont Stakes, will be out of the running for six months following surgery yesterday for a fractured right foreleg.

title: Sailors Volunteer for Gonorrhea Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  A medical research team gathering information about possible methods of controlling venereal disease recruitedlame 1,900 volunteers for Ole project among the sailors of an aircraft carrier on liberty in a Philippines port town, the Navy disclosed today.

title: Damage to Bandshell Shifts a Met Concert
description: Because a city bandshell was damaged last Wednesday while being moved to the Bronx, the Metropolitan Opera's final outdoor concert tonight at 8:30  Johann Strauss's Die Fledermaushas been moved from Cunningham Park in Queens to Louis Armstrong Memorial Stadium (the former Singer Bowl) in Flushing Meadows Park.

title: Radio Station Loses Plea
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (UPI)  A petition seeking the reopening of WXUR, the Rev. Carl McIntire's radio station, was denied here today by Federal Judge Clifford S. Green. The conservative minister's station, in Media, Pa., went off the air at midnight yesterday under orders of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Teather, 56, Found Dead After Fire in Bedroom
description: A 54yearold Manhattan man was found dead yesterday after firemen extinguished a fire in his bedroom at 40 First Avenue, near East Second Street. Officials said that detectives and fire marshals had begun an investigation.

title: Man, in Jail Two Days a Week, Accused of LunchHour Rape
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 6A man who has been spending his days off in jail in an unusual sentence for assault and robbery was charged here today with raping a 53yearold woman while on his dinner break from the allnight job that his jail term was designed to allow him to keep.

title: Baseball Transactions NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: METSSigned Christopher Ryba and Paul Dyer, pitchers chosen In freeagent draft.

title: Getty Will Is Probated
description: LOS ANGELES, July 6 (UPI) George F. Getty 2d, eldest son of J. Paul Getty, left $10,000 in his will to his father, reputed to be the world's richest man. The will, admitted to probate today, also left $50,000 to his former wife, Gloria, and the remainder to their three daughters. The total amount of, the estate was not disclosed. Mr. Getty, 48 years old, died June 6. A coroner's autopsy indicated he had succumbed to an overdose of barbituates and alcohol.

title: Sir Dalrae Heads Field
description: CHICAGO, July 6 (AP)Sir Dalrae, winner this year in 10 of 13 starts, heads a field of nine tomorrow night in the opener of the $160,000 United States Pacing Championship series at Sportsman's Park. The series includes three races over Sportsman's fiveeighths mile track; Aug. 10 at Roosevelt Raceway's halfmile oval and Sept, 8 at Hollywood Park's mile track. Each carries a $50,000 purse.

title: ISRAELI AIDE LISTS ARAB TERROR PLOTS
description: TEL AVIV, July 6Maj. Gen. Aharon Yariv, adviser to Premier Golda Meir on countering terrorism, said today that more than 70 per cent of Arab overseas terrorist plots during the past 15 months had failed.

title: Redman Industries Signs An Acquisition Agreement
description: Redman Industries, Inc., has signed an agreement under which Pacific Western Mobile Estates, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Hallmark Group Companies, will acquire all of Redman's Mobile Home Park properties.

title: $72,000 for Seat on Board
description: A membership on the New York Stock Exchange was sold Yesterday for $72,000, unchanged from the last sale on July 2, the exchange said.

title: 700 Blind People Protest for Added Accrediting Role
description: More than 700 blind people from across the country participated in a demonstration and march yesterday in midtown demanding a greater voice in deciding which training schools for the blind should receive accreditation.

title: Rutgers to Spend $15Million On Newark Campus Projects
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 6 Rutgers University announced today a $15.4million building program for its urban Newark campus and the appointment of Miss Claire Waller Nagle as chairman of its board of governors. Miss Nagle is the first woman to hold the post.

title: Friday Night's Baseball Box Scores
175 Children Wait While Bus Driver Keeps Court Date
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 6A funny thing happened to 75 children on their way to Jones Beachthey wound up outside the Nassau County Court here.

title: Goss, Fernandez At Forum Today In 12Round Bout
description: Sammy Goss, the junior lightweight boxer from Trenton, will risk a 10fight winning streak this afternoon when he meets Jose Fernandez of New York in a 12round contest at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: Rhodesian Rebels Kidnap 278 at Mission
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 6African guerrillas kidnapped 278 people last night, most of them black school children, from a Roman Catholic mission in northeastern Rhodesia and headed With them toward the nearby Mozambique border.

title: LATE EDITOR'S SON GETS PROBATION
description: HACKENSACK, July 6  Stephen Caldwell, who with his parents and four men were arrested March 13 at the Ridgewood home of the late Robert N. Caldwell, an assistant editor of The Record of Hackensack, was placed on probation yesterday after pleading guilty to distributing marijuana.

title: New Books
description: A File on Death, by Kenneth Giles (Walker, $5.95). Humorous political intrigue.

title: VAN PELT. INJURED, OUT OF STARS GAME
description: EVANSTON, Ill., July 6 (UPI) Brad Van Pelt, the New York Giants top draft choice, from Michigan State, has been scratched from the lineup of the July 27 College AllStar game because of a chipped bone in his left foot, doctors at the AllStars training camp said today.

title: Minor Leagues
description: By The Associated Press

title: Boning Knife Linked To the Slaying of 5
description: NEWARK, July 6  The police investigating the murders of five persons here uncovered a bloodstained butcher's boning knife today that they said could have inflicted the kind of puncture wounds found on the bodies.

title: Antiques: Busy Needles
description: Somehow in the decade since the current American flirtation (or is it a fixation?) with needlework began, some of the most exciting early stitchery sources have remained under wraps in private collections and museums.

title: MRS. GEORGE HOTCHKISS
description: WASHINGTON, July 6Mrs. Margaret Woodbury Hotchkiss, formerly of Flushing, Queens, and Saltaire, L. I., widow of George Burton Hotchkiss, professor of marketing at New York University from 1927 to 1950, died here Sunday at the age of 87. She lived in Cleveland.

title: Chinese Envoy Sees Nixon After a Kissinger Meeting
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 6President Nixon met today with Huang Chen, China's representative in the United States, in what appeared to be an effort to reassure Peking that the recent summit meeting with Leonid I. Brerinev did not disturb the building of better relations with Peking.

title: KROGER EARNINGS ROSE IN QUARTER Sales Register 14.5% Gain Results for Half Off
description: The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest supermarket chain, showed some improvement in earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended June 16, according to the report issued yesterday from its Cincinnati,) Ohio, headquarters.

title: Newport Jazz
description: The Newport Jazz Festival's announced Salute to Ella Fitzgerald at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening turned out, in the realization, to be more of a salute by Miss Fitzgerald to herself.

title: NEWARK OFFICER IS SHOT IN HOLDUP
description: NEWARK, July 8  A 40yearold police sergeant was shot in the head with his own revolver shortly before 8 o'clock this morning when he interrupted the holdup of an elderly garage attendant in this city's Central Ward.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: PLEASE GIVE. GIVE FRESH AIR FUND.

title: FLOWER CHILD FIRST IN FINALE AT GOSHEN
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., July 6 (AP) Flower Child, owned by Samue Huttenbauer of Cincinnati, won the $13,800 Pitan Cup today or the last day of Grand Circuit harness racing at Historic Track.

title: 2 SURVEYS REVISE SPENDING OUTLOOK
description: While the Government and McGraw Hill Publications agree that spending for capital outlays will increase this year, they disagree on the degree of this increase.

title: Television
PACIFIC COAST LEAGUE THURSDAY'S GAMES
Rhodesian Rebels Kidnap 278 at Mission
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 6African guerrillas kidnapped 278 people last night, most of them black school children, from a Roman Catholic mission in northeastern Rhodesia and headed with them toward the nearby Mozambique border.

title: Dance: London Surprise
CITY IMPLEMENTS WORKRELIEF PLAN
BREMER SENTENCE UPHELD BY COUNT
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 6 The Maryland Court of Special Appeals upheld today the 53year sentence of Arthur H. Bremer, who shot Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama and three other persons at a political rally May 15 last year.

title: Saigon Reports Heavy Fighting Continues Near City of Konturn
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 (UPI)The Saigon command said today that heavy fighting was continuing near the Central Highlands city of Kontum.

title: Minor Leagues
AN EMIGRATING JEW IS QUERIED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, July 6A Soviet Jewish scholar whose case has aroused interest in the West has been given permission to emigrate to Israel after previous refusals. But his joy was shortlived.

title: EEATHE AT BIG A TO JULIE BE QUICK
description: A change in tactics brought about a victory for Gerald Bernikow's Julie Be Quick in the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday. Bill Boland, who trains the 3yearold filly instructed Tommy Walls to take it easy with her. Take her back and relax. Then whip her lefthanded approaching the finish.

title: I.T .T . Repayment to Aides For Political Gifts Alleged
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which is being investigated for its 1972 political activities, allegedly devised a systematic plan to extract campaign contributions from its executives and then reimburse them with company funds as early as 1960, according to documents filed in United States District Court here.

title: Son of Late Editor at Record Gets Probation on Drug Count
description: HACKENSACK, July 6Stephen Caldwell, who with his parents and four men was arrested March 13 at the Ridgewood home of the late Robert N. Caldwell, an assistant editor of The Record of Hackensack, was placed on probation yesterday after pleading guilty to distributing marijuana.

title: RONSON TAKEOVER IS BARRED BY COURT
description: The Ronson Corporation, fighting a takeover hid, disclosed yesterday that a New Jersey Federal court had granted the company a preliminary injunction to prevent Liquifin, A.G., of Liechtenstein from proceeding with a tender offer to buy up to 52 per cent of Ronson stock.

title: E.P.A. Relaxes Pollution Rules for Plane Engines
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  The Environmental Protection Agency laid down airpollution standards for aircraft engines today that are less stringent than it originally proposed in December.

title: AIRLINE DISCLOSES ILLEGAL DONATION TO 72 NIXON DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 American Airlines admitted today that it illegally contributed $55,000 in company funds to President Nixon's reelection campaign early last year. The airline thus became the first corporation voluntarily to acknowledge an illegal political contribution in the Watergate investigation.

title: DR. JOSEPH TURNER, MT. SINAI OFFICIAL
description: Dr. Joseph Turner, who was director of Mount Sinai Hospital from 1928 to 1948, when he became a consultant to the board of trustees, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 1150 Park Avenue. He was 81 years old.

title: American Freed in Argentina; Ransom to Leftists Undisclosed
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 6An American executive who was kidnapped June 19 on the way from his office to his suburban home was released today by leftwing guerrillas.

title: NORTHEASTERN U. IN HENLEY FINAL
Elevator Repairmen End Job Action at City Projects
description: A job action by 350 elevator repairmen that had left more than 400 elevators out of service in city housing projects ended last night after union and city negotiators reached a tentative agreement on a formula for a labor contract to replace one that expired a year ago.

title: Boning Knife Tied to 5 Newark Slayings
description: NEWARK, July 6  The police investigating the murders of five persons here uncovered a bloodstained butcher's boning knife today that they said could have inflicted the kind of puncture wounds found on the bodies.

title: GOVERNOR MAY GET TRANSIT ON AGENDA
description: Governor Rockefeller is strongly inclined to place the city's transit fare, along with a transportation bond issue for next November's election, on the agenda of the State Legislature's special session this month, Albany sources reported yesterday.

title: Police at White House Arrest 4 Praying Nuns
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Four nuns were arrested in the White House today when they left a tour just before it ended, knelt and began praying.

title: I .T .T . Repayment to Aides For Political Gifts Alleged
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which is being investigated for its 1972 political activities, allegedly devised a systematic plan to extract campaign contributions from its executives and then reimburse them with company funds as early as 1960, according to documents filed in United States District Court here.

title: Communists in Tokyo Push a New Image
description: TOKYO, July 6Thunderous drumbeats made heads turn this morning on the busy streets of Tokyo's crowded Chuo Ward, where more than 45,000 lower  middle  class households occupy cramped apartments above a welter of family shops, small business offices and oneroom factories.

title: Missouri Turkeys Checked
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)The Agriculture Department said today that 120,000 turkeys grown in Missouri were being withheld from the market because of possible contamination by POB or polychlorinated biphenol, a chemical used in industrial products.

title: Hart Homer Helps Yanks Defeat Twins Again, 52
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 6  With Fred Beene pitching at his best and his worst and Jim Ray Hart benefiting from a taste of Minnesota magic, the Yankees defeated the Twins, 52, tonight and halted their longest losing streaking in two months.

title: Looming Shortage Expected to Make Lox a Luxury
description: The specter of a lox shortage looms over the country, according to retailers, curers and packers, who agree that most prepared salmon may soon be in extremely short supply as a result of heavy buying by Japanese and Europeans.

title: A Mechanical Reader for Tolls Is Patented
description: WASHINGTON, July 6A mechanical reader that was patented this week for a Massachusetts company examines labels pasted on car windows and decides whether the motorists can pass without paying additional tolls.

title: Mets Records
U.S.Urging Phnom Penh To Show It Can Survive
description: WASHINGTON, July 6Defense Secretary James Schlesinger said today that, with American bombing Cambodia scheduled to end by Aug. 15, it was now up the Government in Phnom Penh to demonstrate that it had the inner strength and discipline to survive.

title: MARTLAND DENIES JURY'S CHARGES
description: NEWARK, July 6Officials at the Martland Medical Center declared today that a grand jury presentment charging that the hospital's ambulance service was shockingly inefficient and hazardous was erroneous and outdated in its allegations.

title: STOCKTON GETS 63 FOR 132 AND LEAD
description: MILWAUKEE, July 6 (AP) Dave Stockton shot the best round of his career, a nineunderpar 63, to take the secondround lead today by three strokes in the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament.

title: The Two Koreas
description: The Government of South Korea has moved wisely accept the idea that both Korean states should be allowed to participate in the deliberations of the United Nations General Assembly this autumn.

title: Sports Today
description: Pocono 500 auto race, at Pocono International Raceway, Long Pond, Pa. (TelevisionChannel 7, 5 P.M., tape).

title: A Policeman Is Shot As He Tries to Halt Holdup in Newark
description: NEWARK, July 8A 40yearold police sergeant was shot in the head with his own revolver shortly before 8 o'clock this morning when he interrupted the holdup of an elderly garage attendant in this city's Central Ward.

title: Soviet Concedes Failings In RuralArea Schooling
description: MOSCOW, July 6The Soviet Union, which prides itself on having one of the world's best school systems, conceded today that rural children, who make up half the school population, were often getting a substandard education.

title: DepartmentStore Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales last week totaled an estimated $900million, up 12 per cent from the yearearlier $803million. Total retailstore sales rose to $9.93billion, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $9,031,000,000.

title: Chilean Escudo Revalued
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 6 (Reuters)The Chilean Central Bank devalued the escudo against the socalled travelers dollar by 45.8 per cent. The new rate, which does not affect exports, quotes the dollar for Chileans traveling abroad at 775 escudosa rise of 355 escudos from the previous level.

title: Scientists Improvise Heart Device at Sea
description: By WALTER SULLIVAN Special to The New York Times

title: Notes on People
New Jersey Sports He's Back to Par
description: SHORT HILLS, July 6Eddie Famula, the 37yearold professional at the East Orange Golf Club, once spent 86 straight days in a hospital bed. But Famula, who battled ileitis and assorted intestinal disorders for three years, didn't use the time to think about golf. As his weight dropped from 160 pounds to 102, he had important things to consider.

title: CommodityPrice Index Up 1.7 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 173.3 this week from 171.6 last week.

title: Joe E. Brown, Comedian Of Movies and Stage, Dies
description: BRENTWOOD, Calif., July Joe E. Brown, the beloved elasticmouth comedian, died at his home here today. He was 80 years old.

title: DeBakey Visits Nixon, Denies He's an Enemy
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 6 (UPI) Dr. Michael DeBakey, the Houston heart specialist, visited President Nixon today and later told reporters that he was mystified that his name had appeared on the White House enemies list.

title: Pekingese Is Best In Field of 1,183 In Kenilworth Show
description: DURHAM, Conn., July 6  Ch. Dagbury of Calartha, a Pekingese, was named best in show in a field of 1,183 dogs at the fourth annual allbreed event of the Kenilworth Kennel Club of Connecticut at the Fairgrounds today.

title: BRUCE C. HOPPER OF HARVARD DIES
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 6 Dr. Bruce Campbell Hopper, a member of the Harvard faculty from 1930 to his retirement in 1961, died yesterday at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: GUIDELINES FOUND ON STERILIZATION Discovered in a Warehouse Physician Disputes O.E.O.
People in Sports: Feller Cool to Spitball
description: Bobby Feller, the Cleveland Indians' former great pitcher, says he suddenly is being besieged by young players curious about how to throw a spitball. Part of the reason is attributed to the controversy over whether or not Gaylord Perry of the Indians uses saliva or a greasy substance to make his pitches do strange tricks.

title: Lindsay Backs Plan For Con Ed Plants Within City Limits
description: The Consolidated Edison Company would be allowed to build relatively small fossilfueled power plants of 200,000 to 300,000 kilowatts within city limits under a new program backed by the Lindsay Administration and the Public Service Commission.

title: GUIDELINES FOUND ON STERILIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 Twentyfive thousand copies of guidelines that a physician says might have headed off the sterilization of children by an Alabama clinic were discovered today in a Federal warehouse. The Federal Office of Economic Opportunity had insisted they were distributed in 1972.

title: For Fail, Everything but Sweater Shoes
description: All a woman needs to be well dressed these days are a sweater, a raincoat and a pair of pants, according to Yves Saint Laurent, fashion's guru of the moment.

title: New N.E.A. President
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 6 Riding in a limousine the other night after taping a television debate with oJnathan Kozol, the radical education critic Mrs. Helen D. Wise was told by a member of the staff of the National Education Association, You're a public relations man's dream. You dominated. Mrs. Wise paused for a moment before answering reflectively, No, I didn't. In the first part he did much better. She frowned for a moment, then began chatting jokingly about the rigors of adjusting to the time difference between East and West Coasts. The incident illustrates qualiities that those who know her well say Mrs. Wise has in abundancerealism, pragmatism and resilience.

title: Secrecy Is Clouding American Moves on Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 President Nixon's recent statement that delicate negotiations were underway to end the conflict in Cambodia has produced considerable speculation and skepticism in Washington, but very little solid information.

title: Lindsay Backs Plan For Con Ed Plants Within City Limits
Ontario Blast Kills 1, Hurts 8
description: PORT BURWELL, Ontario, July 6 (AP)  One man was killed today and eight were injared in an explosion at an offshore oilandgas drilling rig near this Lake Erie community.

title: U.S. is Cool to Bhutto's Bid For New Military Supplies
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  The State Department responded coolly today to comments by President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan indicating that he planned to ask President Nixon to resume the sale of military supplies to his country.

title: Faith Rosen Affianced
description: BRIGHTWATERS, L. I., July 7  Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Rosen of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Faith Rosen, to Andrew M. Chertoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Chertoff of Brooklyn, N. Y. The wedding will take place Aug. 12. Miss Rosen is a student at Syracuse University, where her fianc is a secondyear law student. He is a graduate of Brooklyn College.

title: Is That Why Will Wrote All the World's a Stage'?
description: I SOMETIMES wonder how many of Shakespeare's very greatest speeches we owe to nothing more than the demands of stage mechanics. The thought popped into my head again the other evening as I sat nervously watching the rainclouds over the Delacorte in Central Park. The play was As You Like Itthrough July 21and Raul Julia, as Orlando, had just lowered the ancient pistol he'd been pointing at Duke Douglass Watson. The Duke had promised the starving Orlando food, Orlando had declined until he could fetch his faithful, and now too feeble, retainer, old Adam. His servant must be fed first.

title: Caste System Results
description: NEW DELHI, July 7 (Reuters)The Indian caste system cost 78 lives when passengers on a stranded bus refused to share the same rope to haul themselves to safety.

title: TWIXT CAPTURES LIBERTY HANDICAP
Senate Unit Votes to Ease Curbs on Election Funding
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The Senate Rules Committee, meeting in secret session shortly before Congress recessed last week, voted to strip two key enforcement requirements from the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, Congressional sources disclosed today.

title: College Parking Fees Rise
description: BOSTON, July 7 (AP)The University of Massachusetts trustees have approved a parking plan for the Amherst campus calling for increased fees at some lots. The plan calls for a $5 registration fee and varying fees at different lots around campus.

title: Rose Anne McCabe Is Bride of Edward LeBreton 3d
description: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., July 7Miss Rose Anne Amo McCabe, daughter of Mrs. M. Ambrose McCabe of New City and the late Mr. McCabe, was married here this afternoon in St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church to Edward Francis LeBreton 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. LeBreton Jr. of New Orleans. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. William Dennen, assisted by Msgr. William Flannery.

title: Photography
description: NIORE than anyone active in photography today, John Szarkowski has broadened and perhaps subverted conventional notions of what an art photograph is, and in his brilliant, delightful, perverse and beautiful new book, Looking at Photographs (distributed by New York Graphic Society, $15), he has given another three  quarter turn to the screw.

title: Home Improvement New Products For the Handyman
description: A NUMBER of new products that should prove of interest to homeowners and doityourselfers in general have been introduced in recent months. Among these are:

title: UGANDA HALTS PLANE OF PEACE CORPSMEN
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 7 (Reuters)more than 100 American Peace Corps volunteers were camping out at the Entebbe, Uganda, Airport tonight after their charter flight from London to Bujumbura, Burundi, was ordered back to Entebbe after a refueling stop there.

title: Rushing toward a footnote in history
description: WASHINGTON. As John Dean emerged this spring as a leading protagonist in the cosmic drama called Watergate, and even after his dramatic testimony before the Ervin Committee, he seemed to me to remain a shadowy figure, without background, without depth. Much was written about what he had done, and he demonstrated before the Ervin Committee that he is cool, articulate and cough, but little was said about who he was, or what he was. He had rarely been in the news, preWatergate, and yet he had lived in Washington a dozen years, one of a thousand bright young men scrambling for a place in the political sun. What follows is based on talks with some of his old friends, acquaintances, classmates, colleagues and rivals, some of whom liked him, some of whom didn't, but none of whom ever imagined that thisreserved, polished, ambitious young man would someday be locked in a fight to the finish with the President of the United States.

title: Virginia Guest Bride of T. J. Harlan
description: RED BANK, N. J., July 7 In the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon, Miss Virginia Claire Guest and Thomas James Harlan, 1972 graduates of Elizabethtown (Pa.) College, were married by the Rev. Dr. Charles S. Webster.

title: Belle Igleheart Plans Wedding To C. Chandler Hagey on Oct. 6
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., July 7 The engagement of Miss Belle Smith Igleheart to C. Chandler Hagey has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James Bridwell Igleheart, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Graham Hagey of Tryon, N. C. An Oct. 6 wedding is planned here.

title: Education
description: PORTLAND, OreFran Fruzen, a delegate from Wisconsin, was speaking at the 111th annual meeting of the National Education Association in support of New Business Item 54. This item was drafted to put the N.E.A. on the offensive, he said. This proposal allows the N.E.A. to act, not react. A few moments later, when cheering, waving delegates gave the proposal their overwhelming approval, it did indeed seem that the association, sensing new unity in its ranks and new strength in its leadership, had at least moved past the defensive in its long and bitter battle with the American Federation of Teachers over merger of the two organizations.

title: European Settings on L.I. Are Her Stock in Trade
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I.The palatial estates still scattered along Long Island's North Shore are providing the settings for movies, commercials and fashion layouts, through the efforts of a former model turned architectural talent scout.

title: U.S. AllStar Five Wins
description: HERTFORD, England, July 7 (UPI) An American Amateur Athletic Union basketball team made up of allstar high school players scored an overwhelming, 13260, victory over Hertfordshire last night.

title: Marian Larkin Engaged
description: MIDDLEBURY, Conn., July 7Dr. Charles L. Larkin Jr., a surgeon, and Mrs. Larkin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Russel Larkin, to Kimball Prince of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donough Prince of Francestown, N. H. A Sept. 15 wedding is planned. The prospective bridegroom, who served as a lieutenant in the Navy's specialwarfare group in Vietnam, is vice president of Sports Investors, Inc.

title: New Arts Directory
description: A directory of performing professional and amateur talent in Brooklyn is being compiled by the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association to aid organizations in need of performers and to assist the organizations in finding storage and rehearsal facilities.

title: Colonels of A.B.A. Purchased Again By Kentucky Group
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 7 (UPI)The Kentucky Colonels of the American Basketball Association, sold to a Cincinnati group less than a month ago, have been resold to Kentucky business intrests for an estimated $2million, it was announced today.

title: Taiwan in Limbo
description: Taiwan in Limbo

title: REV. JOSEPH DAWSON
description: CORSICANA, Tex., July (UPI)  The Rev. Joseph M. Dawson, a trustee of Baylor University and founder of religiousstudies program in churchstate relations at the school, died yesterday. He was 94 years old.

title: Airborne Missile Launched
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif, July 7 (UPI)The Air Force launched a Minuteman intercontinental missile yesterday from an EC135 aircraft near this base, a military spokesman said. The missile, directed from a control center in the aircraft, was launched by a Strategic Air Command airborne missile combat crew from the Fourth Airborne Command Control Squadron from Ellsworth Air Force Base, S. D.

title: $500,000 in Gold Stolen From Company in Queens
description: With secondstory tools as sophisticated as an electronic shortcircuiter and as unsubtle as a sledgehammer, a team of burglars broke into a supposedly burglarproof preciousmetals supply house in Queens before dawn yesterday and made off with $500,000 in gold.

title: Public Intoxication Abolished as Crime Under a Maine Law
description: AUGUSTA, Me., July 7Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis has signed into law a bill that abolishes public intoxication as a crime in Maine and adopts a comprehensive plan for treating alcoholics and intoxicated persons.

title: First Step Taken on a Rail Link to Newark Airport
description: NEWARK  That longtalked  about fiveminute train ride out to Newark International Airport has at last reached the stage of test borings prior to track construction.

title: Psychiatric Patients Given Chance to Rate Their Own Progress Toward Recovery
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I.  An Innovative program in which the psychiatric patient has an important role in solving his own problems is being evaluated at the Brunswick Hospital Center here.

title: Historic Site Is Chosen For Westchester Show
A Shore Retreat in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY A Shangrila for squatters. poor man's shore retreat. A last frontier. By whatever description, it lies tucked away beside a small inlet off the Hudson River, with the twin towers of the World Trade Center hovering in the background.

title: Child to Mrs. Rabhan
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Nathan B. Rabhan June 25 in Beth Israel Hospital. The child has been named Rachel Meredith.

title: Music: Bach Opens Tanglewood Fete
description: LENOX, Mass., July 7The Boston Symphony Orchestra opened the 37th Berkshire Festival last night and drew an audience of 7,811, the largest openingnight attendance Tanglewood has registered.

title: Indian Name Is Urged For Kit Carson Park
description: TAOS, N. M., July 7 A campaign has been started in this northern New Mexicotourist area to change the name of Kit Carson Memorial State Park so as to honor a Taos Pueblo Indian who died in a Japanese prisonerofwar camp in World War II.

title: Wilkins Urged to Help Find If Blacks Are Inferior
description: STANFORD, Calif., July 7 (UPI)William Shockley, the Nobel Prize winner, has urged Roy Wilkins, the black leader, to cooperate in research to determine whether blacks are genetically inferior to whites.

title: Miss Salembier Fiancee
description: PELHAM, N. Y., July 7 Mr. and Mrs. Pierre H. Salembier have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Ramsdell Salembler, to Nicholas J. Fitzgerald, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. J. Fitzgerald of Katonah.

title: VOICEPRINT ISSUE AT THREAT TRIAL
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 7 A San Francisco lawyer who once thought that taped voice prints were as accurate as fingerprints will go to trial here Monday hoping to prove that voice prints are a long way from being accepted science.

title: IRAQ EXECUTES 23 FOR COUP ATTEMPT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7  The Baghdad radio announced the execution today of 23 persons accused of having attempted to overthrow the Iraqi Government last weekend.

title: Letters: A Woman's Bike Is a Hangup
description: To the Editor: Edwin Barber's June 24th article, Biking Through Burgundy and Pushing 40 (But Not M.P.H., You Understand), was a pleasing sequel to Steve Sherman's story (April 8) on crossing the United States by bike. We hope similar features will be found in your pages regularly.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Most editorial comment on the Watergate hearings has neglected to discuss an important question: the relationship of the Ervin committee hearings to the Constitution.

title: Kodes Captures Wimbledon Crown; Mrs. King 60, 75 Victor in Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 7The Wimbledon tennis title went to a Sovietbloc nation for the first time today as Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia won from Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union, 61, 98, 63, over 107 minutes.

title: Helen Pomerantz Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Pomerantz of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Mae Pomerantz, to David Brian Pudlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Pudlin of New Milford, N. J. The couple expect to graduate next year from the University of Pennsylvania Law School. Miss Pomerantz received bachelor's and master's degrees from Pennsylvania. Her fianc is a Yale College graduate.

title: Stockton Soars to 71, Still Leads by 2 Shots At Milwaukee on 203
description: MILWAUKEE, July 7 (AP) Dave Stockton, seeking his first victory since 1971, turned back the challenge of Bob Goalby with a 71 and retained a twostroke lead after the third round of the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament today.

title: BridegroomtoBe Is Shot In Pushing Match on S.I.
description: A bridegroomtobe was shot and critically wounded just after midnight Friday by a man with whom he had become involved in a pushing match in a lounge in New Dorp, S. I., the police reported.

title: the traveler's world
description: PETERSBURG, W. VA.  The Potomac Highlands of West Virginia, comprising the mountainous northeastern corner of the state, are a long reach from the polluted river that runs past the Watergate, and up here the two branches of the Potomac and their shallow feeder creeks and forks run clear and cold over rocks and through deep trout pools. The mountains overlooking this network of streams reach up to the highest point in the state, Spruce Knob at 4,863 feet, and the long, green views to distant ranges that break open at each turn and switchback are more than a newcomer expects from a state preconceived as equal parts of stripmining and Appalachian poverty.

title: Cicadas
description: The shrill sounds of the cicada, or harvest fly, are now heard, sounds that start as a hum, rise to a stridulent shriek, then die away. It is a sound you can't miss in the country; in the city park it can be one of those rare insect noises that pierce the mechanical din of traffic. It will continue on hot afternoons for a few weeks, as different broods of the insects appear. Then it will die away into relative quiet until crickets and katydids begin to sound off in a month or so.

title: City Council Panels Set Open Sessions for Week
description: Committees of the City Council will hold the following public hearing and open meeting this week at City Hall.

title: Raceway Is Site Of Black Rodeo
description: FREEHOLD  The American Black Cowboy Association will bring its socalled Black Rodeo to Freehold Raceway on July 20 and 21. Proceeds from the performances will aid Urban Leagues throughout the state.

title: LANDLORDS COSTS UP SHARPLY HERE
description: Landlords of the city's 300,000 rentstabilized apartments have experienced a 51 per cent increase over the last six years in the costs involved in maintaining and operating their buildings, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Birth Rate Trends
description: There have been so many surprises in the area United States birth rates during the nineteenseventies to date that caution has become instinctive for demographers dealing with these data. The precipitous decline during 1971 and 1972 quickly changed the focus of much popular discussion from the old theme of population explosion to the new theme of a possible approach to zero population growth. But now the latest data are beginning to suggest that the decline in births may bottoming out and that, conceivably anyway, a new demographic period may be in the offing.

title: How Low Can Those Price/Earnings Ratios Go?
description: What's the matter with the stock market? In six months the DowJones industrial average has fallen nearly 200 points. At the same time, the stocks of newer and smaller companies have fallen by even greater percentages. Nevertheless, corporations are reporting record high earnings almost every day.

title: Helsinki Conference
description: HELSINKI  The Foreign Ministers of 35 nations gathered in a modern concert hall here last week. They all made speeches about how important it was to end the cold war and lay the basis for Europe's future security. But they disagreed fundamentally about how to accomplish this.

title: Reorganization Is Planned By International Red Cross
description: GENEVA, July 7 (Reuters) The International Committee of the Red Cross has announced a reorganization to make its work more effective.

title: The House With Clock in Its Walls
description: Lewis is fat, uncoordinated and insecure. He is also freshly orphaned, which makes his story possible, for he has been sent to live with his Uncle Jonathan in a Charles Addams house where magic of all sorts is the norm. The previous tenants of the house, Isaac Izard and his wife Serenna, now deceased, were evil wizards who before they died set in motion a scheme to end the world by means of an enchanted clock they had hidden somewhere in the walls of the house. Its ticking can be heard in every room, but its whereabouts remain elusive. Lewis, trying to impress a machismatic new friend with contraband knowledge, raises Serenna from the dead on Halloween night, and she attempts to push the scheme to its final conclusion. She is of course foiled by Lewis in the end.

title: PRAGUE IS PROUD OF COLLECTIVES
description: MODLETICE, Czechoslovakia, June 29For Czechoslovakia's peasants, the car has replaced the cow as a symbol of status and wellbeing in the village. The Communist authorities are enormously pleased by the change, for political as well as economic reasons.

title: G.A.O. ASKS ACTION TO BAR OIL SPILLS
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Criticizing Federal practices guarding against oil spills, the General Accounting Office today urged stronger inspection and regulation of offshore oil operations.

title: Czechoslovak Star Shows Tenacity, Agility on Grass
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 7Ironically Jan Kodes, the new Wimbledon men's singles champion, considers grass a poor substitute for clay in tennis.

title: Dieter von Hennig Weds Mrs. Binkley
description: HOUSTON, July 7In the chapel of the Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Mrs. Sue Ann Binkley, widow of Richard Warren Binkley, was married to Dieter Herbert von Hennig by the Rev. Charles M. WyattBrown.

title: News of the Screen
description: Third World Cinema, an independent company organized to make films and television subjects and to train minoritygroup members, will start production next month on its first movie, Claudine.

title: Fink Scores Twice to Lead Cosmos Over Metros, 3 to 2
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., July 7 The New York Cosmos defeated the Toronto Metros, 32, tonight at Holstra Stadium before 4,011 spectators in North American Soccer League action.

title: Red Sox Down White Sox, 73, And Trail in East by 1 Games
What's At the Movies?
description: PLAYTIME, directed and written by Jacques Tati and starring Tati, got 4 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Penelope Gilliatt, New Yorker; Judith Crist, New York; William Wolf, Cue), 3 mixed (Kathleen Carroll, News; Howard Kissell, Women's Wear; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service) and 3 negative (Archer Winsten, Post; Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; John Simon New Leader).

title: Two Cruise Mishaps Cost $2Million
description: The two costly freak happeningsan outbreak of gastroenteritis and a kitchen fire that put two cruise ships out of commission temporarily last week produced revenue losses in excess of $2million.

title: GEORGE MARCUS
description: George Marcus, a United States Customs supervisor here, died Friday in University Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 9851 Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: No Progress Reported in Strike By City's Legal Aid Attorneys
description: Efforts to end the strike by lawyers against the Legal Aid Society continued yesterday without reported progress.

title: Star Says Women's Track Has Way To Go
description: Francie Larrieu admits women's track and field has come a long way, in the United States, but adds, we still have a long way to go.

title: Who Makes Music and Where
Theft Suspect, 15, Chased and Caught By Passing Driver
description: A 15yearold suspected purse snatcher was caught on the Upper East Side early yesterday by a passerby who chased him four blocks in a car and then grabbed him as the police converged on the scene.

title: AROUND THE
ExCollege Aide Sentenced
description: PORTALES, N. M., July 7Gene W. Harrell, former vice president and controller of Eastern New Mexico University here, was sentenced this week to two concurrent twoto10 year state prison terms on charges of embezzlement of university funds to which he had pleaded guilty.

title: Cambodia
description: After years of trying, Congress has reasserted a measure of its war powers: President Nixon has promised to stop the bombing in Cambodia Aug. 15 and not to resume it unless authorized by Congress. The cutoff date creates a strange situation.

title: Current Best Sellers
description: 1. THE WINDS OF WAR. Wouk. A vivid, if Lanny Buddish, replay of the events that led to Pearl Harbor Sundayobserved, in global terms, by a career officer, U.S.N.

title: Lower Yields Expected
description: IRENE, Ill., July 7Water was still standing in the low corners of many Illinois fields today, but corn and soybean plants were up out of the drying ground and off to a good start.

title: Nuptials of Virginia J. Callan And John Baxter Held on L.I.
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 7  Miss Virginia Jean Callan, daughter of Mrs. George Milholland Wheatley and the late Andrew Thomas Callan, was married this afternoon to John Hanley Baxter, son of Mrs. Raymond Stanley Baxter Jr. of Manhasset and Mr. Baxter of Washington.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: Right Now: Vincent DePaul Draddy, board chairman of David Crystal, Inc., and Ben Shaw of Donald Brooks, Inc., fashion houses, are the guests, Channel 9, 9:30 A.M.Like a Constant Spring: Film biography of the late patriarch Athenagoras, Channel 2, 10 A.M.

title: Peter Tcherepnine Weds Miss Harris
description: Miss Jessica Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Barclay Harris of London and East Grinstead, Sussex, England, was married in London yesterday to Peter Tcherepnine, son of Alexandre Tcherepnine, Russianborn composer and pianist, and Mrs. Tcherepnine of Paris and Bach, Switzerland. The Rev. Michael Fortunatto performed the ceremony in the Russian Orthodox Church, Ennismore Gardens.

title: For a Renter or a Homeowner There Are
description: Owning a house means freedomto turn up the stereo, to put up wallpaper, to come and go as you please in your own castle. It means never having to worry about running out of quarters for the washer or dimes for the dryer. It means a backyard to sun in, a mail slot big enough for all your magazines, a basement and attic to fill as you will. It means privacy, closeness to nature, control over your own life.

title: The World
description: The day will come when oil will be used as the ultimate weapon in the battle, Libya's mercurial leader, Col. Muammar el Qaddafi warned the Western oil consuming nations in May. Within a month he converted the threat into action, nationalizing Nelson Bunker Hunt, an American company that accounts for 10 per cent of Libya's oil production.

title: The tenant may have trouble finding where the buck stops. The homeowner knows it stops with him
description: Renting as a way of life offers a maximum convenience, affords relief from responsibility and shifts many of the frustrations of daytoday living to a landlord specifically equipped to cope with them. True or false?

title: Bridge
description: It is perhaps a pity, therefore, that objective tests of bridge ability have fallen into desuetude. For some 40 years various organizing bodies set up par contests. Deals were specially prepared to test the bidding and playing ability of competitors. Some points were awarded for bidding to a good contract, a few for making the right opening lead, and most for good play, or perhaps defense. The contract to be played, and the opening lead, were predetermined, and the actual bidding and lead were disregarded if necessary. But some sensitive experts were not prepared to put their reputations on the line and the contests were difficult to organize, so they disappeared nearly a decade

title: Infant Deaths Tied to Poor Health Care
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The infant death rate in New York City could probably be cut by a third if adequate health care was universally available and used, scientists have concluded from a study covering all the births in the city in 1968.

title: Saving Gas
description: To the Financial Editor:The illustration accompanying William D. Smith's Detroit's Dilemma: Gas Hogs or Fuel Savers (June 24) showing fuel consumption differences between large and small cars is most telling. Some of the small cars get even better gas mileage.

title: Headliners
description: The message of felicitations from one President to another started out innocuously enough. Said Uganda's erratic President Idi Amin to President Nixon: On the occasion the 197th anniversary of independence of the United States of America, I convey to you, your Government and all your people greetings and good wishes. . . . But then General Amin went on to criticize the United States for being prone to interfering in the internal affairs of others and to conclude by wishing President Nixon a speedy recovery from the Watergate affair. Washington was not amused. Having withdrawn its Ambassador over previous Amin insults, Washington will not now send a new one.

title: Kristen Talbott Fiancee
description: TOWSON, Md., July 7The engagement of Miss Kristen Hazel Talbott to Thomas Kittredge Sawyer, son of Dr. and Mts. Wilbur H. Sawyer of Scarsdale, N. Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Talbott Jr. An August wedding is planned. Miss Talbott will study at the Columbia University Graduate School in the fall. Her fianc is attending the School of Dental and Oral Surgery of Columbia. His father is professor of pharmacology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia.

title: Lutheran Synod President ReElected
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 7 The Rev. Dr. Jacob A. O. Preus, the embattled 53yearold president of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod, won reelection to a second fouryear term today at the church's biennial convention here.

title: Outlandish outlands
description: By Thomas Sheehan/Puzzles Edited By Will Weng

title: Criminals At Large
description: The America Ned Calmer portrays in THE AVIMA AFFAIR (Doubleday, $6.95) is definitely preWatergate. Today, with all the investigations in progress and the White House on the defensive, a new feeling is sweeping the country; and if dirty things have been poked outt of dark corners, at least the democratic process is doing the poking. In this book, to be sure, some optimism is expressed at the end. But for most of the way things look very, very had for our future.

title: Lee Brennan Bride of Kevin Kidd
description: ATLANTA, July 7  Miss Lee St. Clair Brennan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Trainer Brennan, was married here this afternoon to Kevin Gillmore Kidd, son of Adm. Isaac Campbell Kidd Jr., U.S.N., and Mrs. Kidd of Washington. Msgr. John McDonough performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Christ the King.

title: More Chic
description: ROMEThe geology of Italian politics has changed and a new readjustment of forces is starting to emerge. For two decades the country has been governed by creeping anarchy, moving with glacial pace and relying on an overstuffed bureaucracy to keep things going.

title: NewRule Pares HomeLoanFee
description: TRENTON  Those planning to buy a home or take out a loan for some other purpose might save money if they delay closing the deal for about 30 days, according to state officials.

title: Cove Spiced With Latin Flavor
description: GLEN COVE, L.I.  Fireworks and the fiery footwork of a Latin dance company combined here in an Independence Day celebration with a somber purposeto translate the rhetoric of liberty and fraternity into reality for the city's HispanicAmericans.

title: Numismatics
description: THE 1974 edition of A Guide Book of United States Coins  better known as the Red Bookis now being distributed to coin dealers, book shops and coin and hobby counters in department stores.

title: Suzanne Boyd Bride Of R. J. Kelly, Lawyer
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 7 In Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Suzanne Harris Boyd was married to Raymond Joseph Kelly. The Rev. John L. Durkin performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Boyd Jr. of Ridgewood. Her father is vice president of the Lansdell Company, Hackensack, road construction.

title: Miss Hansbury Bride of Reporter
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 7Miss Christine Alexandra Hansbury and William Dunn were married here this afternoon in St. Mary's Abbey at the Delbarton School. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gerard Lair.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Over the last 25 years, the United States and Japan have had a big brotheryounger brother relationship, one in which Japan's actions have largely deferred to America's pOlicies and practices. Japan has prospered under this arrangement, its security has been guaranteed, and we are grateful for it.

title: Making their way through small troubles
description: Ruth Prawer Jhabvala's novels of the contemporary Indian scene have for some time now been earning her a considerable reputation in England. The case has been different in America. Whether it is that India can never be quite the subject of interest to Americans it seems, eternally, to be to the English or whether it is that the leisurely play of character and observation native to this sort of sensibility falls on resisting ears here (I do not for a moment believe it), or some other thing, it is hard to tell; but she is much less known in this country. Travelers is Mrs. Jhabvala's 10th work to be published in America, the sort of novel that establishes itself, from the first pages, with that peculiar assurance it is sometimes given to ripened art to have. (In considerable measure, that assurance has been there right along, notably in the story collections, An Experience of India, Stronger Climate, Like Birds, Like Fishes.)

title: Sally A. Helies Has Nuptials
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., July 7  Miss Sally Ann Helies, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Helies of Roxbury and Point Lookout, L. I., was married here this afternoon to James Forsht Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Walker of Lock Haven, Pa. The Rev. John M. DeZinno performed the ceremony in the Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church.

title: 2 More Mets Hurt in 98 Loss
description: The starcrossed Mets got Cleon Jones hack yesterday, but lost George Theodore and Don Hahn after the two outfielders collided while the Mets were losing a tumultuous game to the Atlanta Braves, 98.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Yank Games This Week
description: TomorrowAt Chicago, night.

title: Ads of Goodyear and Firestone Held Misleading by Safety Unit
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The Center for Auto Safety wants the Federal Trade Commission to charge the country's largest tire manufacturers, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, with false advertising.

title: RAN SULLIVAN, 84, EXFORD OFFICIAL
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 6 Ray H. Sullivan, a retired vice president of the Ford Motor Company, was found dead here today in his room at the Mohican Hotel, where he had lived for about a year. He was 84 years old.

title: ShuttertoStitch Designer
description: TRENTONWhen Mrs. Bernard J. Gross moved east from Chicago two years ago, she brought with her a remarkable talent.

title: Television This Week
Darrell Harvey Weds Robin Bailey
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 7  Miss Robin Anne Bailey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Bailey, was married here this afternoon to Henry Darrell Harvey, son of Mr. and Mrs: Eldon Harvey Jr. of Stonington. The Rev. Kenneth E. Hulme performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Academic Achievement Crowns A Peaceful Year at Morris High
description: It was a year of unusual acalemic achievement at Morris High School in the South Bronx, one of the most povertystricken areas of the city.

title: Diplomat's Murder
description: WASHINGTON  The Ambassador said what no one else here has said officiallyabout the killing of Col. Yoief Alon: The frontiers of Israel are:everywhere. The hands of those who tried to kill him in the air have reached him here.

title: Stamps
description: STAMP collectors, still trying to get used to Sri Lamka (Ceylon) and Zaire (once Belgian Congo), have some new names to get used to in the Caribbean as the shrunken British Empire shrinks some more.

title: POLL SHOWS 71% FEEL NIXON KNEW
description: Seventyone per cent of the American public believe that President Nixon either planned or knew about the bugging of the Democratic National Committee offices in Washington, or was involved in a coverup of the incident, according to a nationwide Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: CAMBRIDGE, MASS., IS VICTOR IN ROWING
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 7 A crew from Cambridge, Mass., made up of Harvard and Massachusetts Institute of Technology oarsmen, won the elite race for lightweight eights by two lengths in the Independence Day regatta today on a calm Schuylkill River.

title: Richardson Names Aide
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)  Attorney General Elliot L. Richardspn has chosen Dr. Wallace Mendelson of the government department at the University of Texas as a special summer assistant to research constitutional issues, the Justice Department said Thursday. His research will focus on issues involving the separation of powers.

title: EQUITATION SWEPT BY MISS WITZLER
And Giving Shanker Attention
description: PORTLAND, Ore.At the end of a long day in which the venerable National Education Association took a cautious but historic first step toward accommodation with the upstart American Federation of Teachers, Albert Shanker, head of the federation's (and organized labor's) biggest local union, was asked about the hostility at the N.E.A.'s convention toward the New York delegation in general and Al Shanker in particular.

title: Puskas Notes Changes In Europe Soccer Scene
description: ATHENS, July 7Ferenc Puskas frowned when asked why Hungary had failed to qualify for the World Cup in West Germany next summer and why attendances had dropped considerably in Hungarian soccer games.

title: Dance
description: THE Bolshoi Ballet is back In townor at least part of it. The full Moscow company last visited New York in 1966 at the Old Met. Indeed it closed the Old Met. Now it is returning for the second time to the New Met, and, as before, it has brought us a concertparty program.

title: Children View Life on Farm
description: CLINTON  So many people would come up our driveway from the highway to let the children see the animals that about three years ago I put up an admission sign at our entrance. It really all began in selfdefense to protect our privacy.

title: Mills Plans to Quit If Illness Continues
Jazz in Review
description: New York's next generation of jazz musicians was put on display by the Newport Jazz Festival Friday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall in a program called Youth and Jazz. To anyone listening to the young people who make up the Jazz Interactions Workshop Orchestra, the Jazzmobile Workshop Orchestra, the Brooklyn Boroughwide Chorus and Band and the AllCity High School Jazz Orchestra, it was evident that there will be good jazz and good jazz musicians here for years to come.

title: Fatal Crash of Jet Linked To BurnedOut Panel Light
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The crew's preoccupation with a burnedout landinggear light probably caused the crash of an Eastern Air Lines jumbo jet in the Florida Everglades last December, the National Transportation Safety Board has reported.

title: Turcotte Views Commercialism With Bridled Enthusiasm
description: Dear Mr. Turcotte, the letters from the publishing companies begin, would you consider writing your autobiography for us?

title: Jazz Is in Liturgy OfNewark Church
description: NEWARKThe pastor of the Memorial West United Presbyterian Church has spent the last week at the Newport Jazz Festival in New Yorknot simply as a jazz fan (which he is) but at the specific direction of his church as part of a twoweek study leave.

title: U.S. Jury to Study Illegal Drug Raids
description: CHICAGO, July 7The Department of Justice will soon open a major new Federal grand jury investigation into the illegal Government drug raids in Collinsville, Ill., and their aftermath.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock and bond markets continued to skid last week on increased fears that the Federal Reserve's tighter credit policy would produce such high interest rates that the economy would be thrown into recession.

title: Russian Who Saved Two U.S. Fliers in 1944 Can Expect Letters
description: CHICAGO, July 7Alek sandr Pobozhi of Tyndinsky, U.S.S.R., will be getting a letter soon from Charies H. Robson of Indianapolis, one of two American airmen he rescued from a mountain forest in Siberia in 1944.

title: ORDER TO DEFROCK MAKARIOS VOIDED
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 7 (UPI)A major synod of the Eastern Greek Orthodox Church has ruled that the order to defrock Archbishop MakMakarios, the President of Cyprus, by three Cypriote Bishops was anticanonical and therefore void and inactive, a spokesman for the Church of Cyprus said today.

title: NewDirection Rams on the Mark
description: FULLERTON, Calif., July 7 The Los Angeles Rams, with a new coach and a new quarter back, open summer training camp tomorrow with 50 players, mostly rookies, scheduled to report.

title: SCHLEE QUALIFIES FOR BRITISH OPEN
description: TROON, Scotland, July 7(AP) John Schlee, a professional, and Danny Edwards, a 22yearold amateur from Oklahoma State 1University, were among the Americans qualifying today for the British Open golf tournament, which gets under way Wednesday over Troon's 7,064yard layout.

title: TransMississippi Golf Will Start Tomorrow
description: HUTCHINSON, Kan., July 7 (UPI)The defender, Ben Crenshaw looms as the man to beat when the TransMississippi amateur golf tournament opens its sixday grind Monday on the par70, 6,382yard Prairie Dunes Country Club course.

title: Rider Increases Resident Charges
description: TRENTONRider College has increased its room and board charges by $100 in an effort to reduce to $250,000 a projected $700,000 deficit for 197374, Dr. Frank N. Elliott, the school's president, has announced.

title: Fluoridation Looms As Campaign Issue
description: TRENTON  The Republican and Democratic candidates for Governor are expected to take opposing positions on the mandatory use of fluoride in New Jersey's water supplies.

title: Yankee Records
Cheryl Flom Engaged To Mitchell I. Quain
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 7 Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Flom have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cheryl Linda Flom, to Mitchell I. Quain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Quoin of Yonkers.

title: 4 Die in Calcutta Riot
description: CALCUTTA, India, July (Reuters)The police shot to death at least four food rioters there tonight after railway police seized 20 bags of smuggled rice Ifrom a train at a suburban station. Factory workers demanded immediate sale of the rice and fighting broke out when they were refused.

title: TWO TIED AT 142 IN BUFFALO GOLF
description: BUFFALO, July 7 (AP)Betty Burfeindt and Mary Lou Crocker overcame winds of 30 miles an hour today to tie for the lead after secondround play in the $35,000 Marc Equity golf tourney. Their scores were 142, four under par.

title: Washington Voters Petition for Ballot OnLegislators'Pay
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., July 6 (AP)Washington voters have called for a ballot showdown on pay increases for legislators and other elected state officials.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Remarkable. Seven articles by seven housing experts [So the U.S. Wants New Housing Policies, June 24], and barely a word about the people who are to build the needed housing.

title: Printmaker Takes His Art to Artists in the Hamptons
Child to the Penkowers
description: ANNANDALE  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., July 7A daughter was born June 19 to Dr. and Mrs. Monty N. Penkower in the Northern Dutchess Hospital.

title: Bravo, Chaplin! Bravo, Tati!
description: CHARLIE CHAPLIN'S Monsieur Verdoux, made 1947, and Jacques Tati's Playtime, made over period of years and completed in 1967, are two of the greatest screen comedies of all time and they are now in firstrun theaters here. For Monsieur Verdoux, the engagement at the Paris makes a return. The Tati film, which is now at the Festival heater, is being seen in New York for the first time, apparently because the distributor was not terribly enthusiastic about it when the film was acquired four or five years ago, especially after it was rather poorly received in its native France.

title: Yes, Rock Can Sometimes Save a BadMovie
description: IF Lindsay Anderson's O Lucky Man! proves anything, it's that contemporary rock music can save films, as well as the conglomerates that own the film companies. Last year, the record division of Warner Communications outgrossed the film division and it's a safe bet that Warner Bros. Records could make more money from the O Lucky Man! soundtrack LP than the movie company will from the film itself.

title: G.l. AID IS BARRED TO ART STUDENTS
description: Eightyfive Vietnam veterans enrolled at the Art Students League here for up to two years will no longer be able to use their G.I. Bill benefits at the school under new regulations of the State Education Department that went into effect a week ago.

title: VendingTruck Curbs Asked For Suffolk and Hempstead
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.  Suffolk County is considering a total ban on icecream trucks on its streets because of the deaths of two children last month who were killed when they darted from behind trucks and were struck by passing vehicles.

title: A German's Inflation
description: BONNPeter Blaeser, 38 years old, is manager of a company that ferries people and cars across the Rhine River. Like other Germans, he has to grapple with inflation. How is he doing?

title: Databanks in a Free Society
Yorty Outspent by Bradley In Coast Mayoralty Race
To Become a Star, All You Need Is One Good Rival
description: IT was just a year ago today. She danced up a storm as Odette/Odile in Swan Lake. Midway through the third act, stunned by her virtuosity, the audience burst into cheers and applause and stopped the show for several minutes. Afterwards, her fans, some bearing gifts, serenaded her at the stage door of the New York State Theater with Happy Birthday. Barely a month later, her first New York Giselle was rewarded with a 22minute ovation, floral bouquets by the armfuls, confetti and blossoms tossed from the galleries, and the wry observation from Clive Barnes that the event seemed more like a coronation than a performance.

title: Peach Growers See an Average Crop at Record 72 Price
description: CLAYTON  The state's peach growers are anticipating an average crop of some 2 million bushels this summer, but the price of the fruit is expected to stay at the record high it reached during last year's disastrous harvest.the 250 major growers in the state.

title: Sunday Observer
description: For a long time I used to slip into my graveside face whenever one of those earnest clods with the sociological cast of mind asked if I was aware that one of every three marriages ended in divorce. They enjoy spoiling your day, people like that, and the sooner you give up and look miserable, the faster they will move on to the next victim.

title: Comley Named Hockey Pilot
description: SAULTE STE MARIE, Mich., July 7 (AP)  Richard Comley was named hockey coach today at Lake Superior State College, where he earned allAmerica status as a hockey player in 1968.

title: Arlene Stein Married
description: UPPER MARION, Pa., July 7Miss Arlene Stein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Stein of Port Jervis, N. Y., was married here tonight to Robert Ginsburg. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Ginsburg of Huntingdon Valley and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Martin Berkowitz performed the ceremony in Temple Adath Israel. The bride's father is a dentist in Port Jervis. Her husband's father is a physician and artist.

title: Blueberry Outlook Called Good
description: TRENTON Prospects for the 1973 New Jersey blueberry crop are good, Secretary of Agriculture Phillip Alampi reported last week.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: APART from its mammoth political problems, the Nixon Administration is facing rather formidable difficulties in the effort to create a feasible and equitable Phase 4 in its twoyearold pricestabilization program.

title: WIGG'S BAR WINS CAPE COD CLASS
News of the Real Trade
Rwandan General Asks For Unity in Wake of Coup
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July (Agence FrancePresse)  Maj. Gen. Juvenal Habyarimana, the top man in the military coup in Rwanda, promised ousted politicians their freedom today provided they kept out of politics for the time being and devoted themselves wholeheartedly to the development of the country.

title: French to Sing in E. Hampton
