description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.A choral group of 118 teenagers from Epinal, France, will open a 30city tour of the United States and Canada at the high school here Friday

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Japan Fishermen Dump Catch in Pollution Protest
description: MINAMATA, Japan, July (AP)Fishermen dumped about five tons of fresh sardines in front of the main gate of a chemical company today to protest what they said was contamination of the seas by wastes from its drains.

title: More Georgian Aides Fall In a 9Month Soviet Purge
Donna McKenna Wed
description: BABYLON, L. I., July 7 Miss Donna Therese McKenna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas X. McKenna of West Islip, was married here this evening in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, to William Vincent Cooney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cooney of Newport, R. I. The Rev. Edward J. McQuillan performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. The bride's father is a partner in Freiday & Co., specialists on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: NILS PELTZMAN
description: BLAUVELT, N. Y., July 7Nils Peltzman, owner of the Blauvelt Pharmacy, died of a heart attack Thursday in the Nyack Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived at 264 North Greenbush Road.

title: I Could Swear I Saw Sparks Fly From His Eyes
A House Member Tells About Mushy Memories Found in Watergate Inquiry
description: SAN DIEGO, July 7  The House Armed Services Committee has been frustrated by what one of its members called the mushy memories of key witnesses whom it has questioned about the Central Intelligence Agency's involvement in the Watergate affair.

title: Lakes Weed Problem Eased
description: TRENTONThick and entangling, water weeds are usually discomforting to swimmers and ensnaring to boatmen. To ease this problem, the state has completed a program of aquaticvegetation control on six more New Jersey lakes so affected.

title: Log Skippers to Get a Champion
COLSON SAID TO TELL OF A CONSPIRACY
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) Charles W. Colson, the former White House aide, was quoted in an interview published today as saying that he tried unsuccessfully to penetrate a wall of silence and of conspiracy last winter to find out the truth about Watergate and tell President Nixon.

title: Deaths
SHOP TALK From Rags to FirstQuality Fabrics
description: PACKANACK LAKE Longtime customers of The Rag Shop Mill Outlet Store may have noticed that irregulars, which used to make up the bulk of the stock, have been largely replaced by a firstqality fabrics and seconds.

title: School Integration Lagging in Queens
Unfortunately most workers don't have concave heads
description: When Peter J. (Pistol) Brennan was up for confirmation before the Senate Labor Committee, Senator Edward Kennedy asked him what proposals he had for overcoming worker alienation and low job morale. Brennan's suggested remedy was to bring in some gogo girls to entertain male workers. If it is women, we bring in men to dance.

title: Better Nursing Care Sought
description: TRENTONNew Jersey is engaged in an effort to improve nursinghome care for poor patients.

title: Movie Mailbag Mary Poppins? Yes, Sir
description: To THE EDITOR: IN reply to Vincent Canby's attack on Walt Disney's Mary Poppinswe agree that the realities of life should be shown in movies, but there is also a place for fantasy. If the London of Mary Poppins  the slums, child labor, drugswere made real, the spirit of the books from which the movie was taken would have been destroyed.

title: John S. Kitchen And Eve Bartle To Be Married
description: Miss Eve Marie Bartle and John Scott Kitchen plan to be married on Aug. 25. Mr. Kitchen has been named a deputy attorney general of New Hampshire in Concord.

title: STAFF UNIT VOTES TO STRIKE CITY U.
description: The Professional Staff Congress, representing the 16,000 faculty and staff members of City University of New York, has voted nearly fourtoone to strike Oct. 1 if it is still without a contract.

title: ONE SIAMESE TWIN DIES IN OPERATION
description: One of a pair of Siamese twin girls born three months ago in Brooklyn died during emergency surgery yesterday morning. The surviving twin, identified only as Baby A, remained in critical condition in the neonatal unit of the borough's Downstate Medical Center.

title: Recordings Is the Best of Boulez Ahead?
Brink's Sued in 68 Case
description: BOSTON, July 7 (AP)An armored car messenger, who was dismissed in 1968 after $1.1million was stolen from the truck he was assigned to, has sued for reinstatement to his job and all back pay. Richard E. Haines, 46 years old, of Tewksbury, worked for Brink's Armored Car Service for 13 years before the robbery; His suit said he was improperly ousted for allegedly failing to perform certain acts which would have allegedly prevented a successful robbery from tating place.

title: Peking Is Stressing Latinized Alphabet in Sinkiang
description: HONG KONG, July 7  Peking is intensifying efforts to spread the use of a new Latinized alphabet for the languages of more than four million people and concedes that a major motivation is antiSoviet.

title: The Creative Influence of Teriade
description: PARIS. THE astonishingly creative influence of Triade, one of the most discerning and inventive publishers of the century, is amply conveyed in the current exhibition at the Grand Palais, where it remains until Sept. 3. Until now, for many People, the name of this essentially retiring man had evoked a vague editorial figtire on the periphery Of the great artistic movements in France. By tracing his career through the reviews and books he published, this exhibition shows the extent to which Triade not only opened up new possibilities for the best painters of his day but brought literature and the visual arts into a richer unity.

title: VOICEPRINT ISSUE AT THREAT TRIAL
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 7 A San Francisco lawyer who once thought that taped voice prints were as accurate as fingerprints will go to trial here Monday hoping to prove that voice prints are a long way from being accepted science.

title: INMATE ALLOWED TO SUE A GUARD
description: A prisoner has won the right to sue a guard who allegedly assaulted him in a cell at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men, known as the Tombs.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The fourday workweek is a growing phenomenon among American companies.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE WHOLESALE PRICE INDEX rose in June to 136.7 per cent of the 1967 average from 133.5 per cent in May. . . . The Government banned exports of scrap metal excess of 500 tons for the rest of this year. Rules for exporting soybeans were modified to permit shipment 50 per cent of orders on hand June 15. Controls on exports of cottonseed and soybean oil were lifted, but the Government imposed controls on 41 additional farm Commodities.

title: Kid Porn v. the Burger Five
description: You are Pat Average Garrett, sheriff of Swamp Statistic, West Garble, D.C. You are probably unyoung, unpoor, unblack, Protestant, with 2.5 children the real majority. Although 10 per cent of you is over 65, your median age is 28.1. You are, according to Chief Justice Burger, neither particularly sensitive nor totally insensitive. But you're the boss now, buddy! It's sundown, and Kid Porn hasn't boarded the train for Las Vegas. Kid Porn, instead, is exposing himself in front of the saloon. You whip out your Burgergun and go bangbang. Kid Porn is dead. Community standards are safe again.

title: Music
description: NOW is the time of year, at this children's hour between the darkening of last season and the daylight of the next one, when music critics seem driven by son preternatural force to meet and lecture one another about their sins. It is the time of seminars and panels and institutes, solemn gatherings in which acolytes attempt to wrench from their employed elders all the secrets of a craft whose skills are assumed to be transmittable.

title: Stockholder Dissent
description: The frail and colicky movement to reform the American corporation through stockholder action seems to be emerging into a state of cantankerous health.

title: Accused POW's
The Sinking Dollar
description: The danger of another world monetary crisis has grown intense. Some foreign officials believe it is already here, and could degenerate into a more severe economic wrench than the world has known since the nineteenthirties.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1973, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Mexico City's Glistening New Subway Is the Pride of the People
description: MEXICO CITY, July 7 Jorge Espinoza Ulloa is in rather enviable minority group. He runs a subway system that suffers virtually no complaints from passengers, no vandals who scribble their names on walls, no thieves who lie in wait for the unsuspecting, no noise from screeching cars andperhaps most importantno deficits.

title: Insanity in Criminal Behavior
description: Overcome by the complexity of insanity as a defense in crime, the Administration has decided, as a part of a new criminal code, to solve it by abolishing insanity altogether. Instead of allowing the psychiatrist to examine the defendant in order to determine his mental condition at the time of his crime, it has suggested that he only shall determine whether the defendant had criminal intent. The reason for abolishing insanity is, in the words of President Nixon, to curb unconscionable abuse of the insanity defense by criminals.

title: KNICKS ANNOUNCE PRESEASON SLATE
description: The New York Knickerbockers have announced an eightgame preseason schedule, with three of the games slated at Madison Square Garden.

title: Miss Evelyn Victor Becomes Affianced
description: GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 7 Mr. and Mrs. Royall Victor of Glen Head and Contoocook, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Adele Victor, to Roger Wheeler Sanborn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Colby Sanborn of Boscawen, N.H.

title: Some Ships Evade Tuna Fishing Curb
description: SAN DIEGO, July 7  A growing practice of transferring vessels of the American tuna fleet to foreign registry has prompted new Government measures aimed at combating large scale overfishing and outofseason fishing In international waters of the eastern Pacific.

title: EUROPE URGES U.S. TO ACT ON DOLLAR
description: BONN, July 7  Europe's monetary officials are urging the United States to do something to arrest the precipitous fall of the dollar in the international exchange markets before the currency crisis leads to a serious international recession.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: God bless those ladies of East Flatbush (Feminism in the $12,000ayear family by Susan Jacoby, June 17)! Those of us in the slinky vanguard, as one of them puts it, who have fought so long and so hard to gain the equality of choice which they now pursue, proudly salute their progress. Neither their daughters nor ours will have to beg for permission to live their lives to their most gratifying capacities.

title: H.E.W. Cap the Knife Goes To Work
description: WASHINGTONWhen Caspar W. Weinberger was confirmed by the Senate as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare last February, 10 angry Democrats refused to vote for his appointment.

title: Hearing on a Suit to Oust Estate's Trustee Postponed
description: HOUSTON, July 7 (UPI)A hearing on a suit filed by two foster sons of Jacques Mossier, the late millionaire financier, to out Candace Mossier Garrison as trustee of the estate has been postponed indefinitely.

title: RUN BY A'S IN 8TH TOPS ORIOLES, 54
description: BALTIMORE, July 7 (AP) Reggie Jackson and Deron Johnson hit home runs and Sal Bando hit a tiebreaking single in the eighth inning tonight as the Oakland A's beat the Baltimore Orioles, 54.

title: JOGGING, 41, FIRST ON AQUEDUCT TURF
description: With Angel Cordero giving an excellent demonstration of horseback riding, Philip Wise's Jogging sped to victory in the $58,200 Tidal Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT GIVES ERVIN COMMITTEE FORMAL REFUSAL
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 7  President Nixon formally notified the Senate Watergate committee today that he would not appear personally before the committee in any circumstances to defend himself against charges that he participated in the coverup of the Watergate burglary.

title: MOST OF CAPTIVES IN RHODESIA SAFE All but About 20 Seized by Guerrillas Return
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July  Most of the 282 children, teachers and nurses captured by black African guerrillas in a raid on a Roman Catholic mission station in northeastern Rhodesia on Thursday were reported to be safe tonight.

title: Any More Grain Deals?
description: It was one year ago today that President Nixon announced the massive sale of grain and soybeans to the Soviet Union, one of the fruits of his visit to that country a month before.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
A's Extend Wiliams's Pact
description: BALTIMORE, July 7 (AP)The Oakland A's announced tonight that the contract of Manager Dick Williams has been extended through the 1975 baseball season. The A's also said that Wes Stock, Iry Noren, Vern Hoscheit and Jerry Adair have been rehired as coaches for 1974.

title: Veronica Lake, 53, Movie Star With the Peekaboo Hair, Dead
Rescuer of Youths From Religious Sects Faces Trial
description: Ted Patrick, who acknowledges helping parents rescue young people from various religious groups, is scheduled to stand trial Wednesday in Manhattan Criminal Court in a case involving the alleged attempted abduction of 21yearold Daniel

title: CAR SAFETY HEAD SOUGHT BY NADER
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, accused the Secretary of Transportation today of letting a headless auto safety agency drift into a state of paralysis.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONHow does a manager get a full week's work out of his employes when it is a warm, lazy summer and many of them would rather take the day off and go fishing?

title: The Talkers
Boating Education Is Urged
description: TRENTON  For just $3, anybody can get a license to cruise on New Jersey's waters. But today, as Safe Boating Week ends, state officials want to change that.

title: Otto Klemperer, Conductor, Dead at 88
description: Otto Klemperer, one of the century's great masters of the German musical repertory, died Friday at his home in Zurich, according to wire services. He was 88 years old.

title: The Historian as Ghost
description: The way we view past events will always hinge on two basic components the data itself and the individual who interprets it. The former is never sufficiently full, the latter never sufficiently neutral. Like all professional historians, I think it's essential to try to increase the amount of data through basic research, and to try to contain our biases when interpreting the data. But unlike many of my colleagues, I don't think we sufficiently admit the biases we're already aware of, nor show sufficient interest in uncovering those we may not be aware of.

title: Will the Brownies Get to Sing?
Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 260 bookstores in .110 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Home Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column.

title: Gwendolyn E. Stevenson Wed to C. Oumar Thiam
description: Miss Gwendolyn Eugenia Stevenson, daughter of Mrs. Eugenia A. Stevenson, newly appointed Liberian Ambassador to West Germany and former Liberian Consul General here, was married yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, to C. Oumar Thiam of Dakar, Senegal, a graduate student at the Sorbonne.

title: Tiny Engines Propel GoKarts at 100 M. P. H. on Coast Speedway
description: ONTARIO, Calif., July 7 From its sloping aerodynamic front end to the wind spoilers in the rear, the racing car brought here this week by Richard Burman, a California truck driver, looked as if it had been created to run against A. J. Foyt or Bobby Unser at Indianapolis.

title: Barbara L. Long Is Betrothed To Donald William Baker Jr.
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 7 Miss Barbara Louise Long, who is studying for a Ph.D. in anthropological biology at Harvard University, plans to be married in October in Cambridge, Mass., to Donald William Baker Jr., a candidate for a master's degree at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

title: Turtle Bay Residents, Fighting M .T .A. Rail Plan, Heartened by Killing of Proposed Bridge Over Sound
description: The demise of the proposed RyeOyster Bay bridge was good news in Turtle Bay. Not that the bridge would have had any direct impact on Manhattan's East Side, but Turtle Bay residents were greatly encouraged in their own fight against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to kill a plan for a new Long Island Rail Road terminal under Third Avenue.

title: Sally I. Rising, Steven L. Dean Marry on L. I.
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., July 7 Miss Sally Isbrandtsen Rising, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Rising Jr. of Glen Head and Brightwaters and a granddaughter of the late Hans J. Isbrandtsen, founder of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., steamship line, was married here this morning to Steven Lance Dean, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Dean of Colton, N. Y.

title: In 75th Year, Totowa Gets Into Swim of Things
description: TOTOWA  For many years, this Passaic County borough had a wide reputation as a recreational center because of the number of day camps and private cabana clubs that occupied space high in the hills on the western end. People came by car from great distances to take advantage of the facilities and the natural breeze that caressed the area on the warmest days. But local residents seemed to lack their own outlet, and they used to look with envy at the outoftowners who were enjoying themselves.

title: Eviction Notices Prepared For Stroudsburg Squatters
description: SCRANTON, Pa., July 7The United States Government now has the legal tool it needs to force the eviction of 171 squatters from land in the Tocks Island dam and recreation area along the Delaware River near Stroudsburg.

title: Old AllStar to Play
description: ST. LOUIS, July 7 (AP)Two of the greatest major league baseball hitters, Joe DiMaggio and Ted Williams, will play in the July 22 AllStar reunion game here. They will he joined by Luke Appling, Bob Feller, Elston Howard and others. The game marking the 40th anniversary of the first AllStar game. will be played, before a National League contest between the Cardinals and the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: National League
description: Sunday, July 8, 1973

title: Senator Tunney's Bill Is Ready for Main Bout
description: In an effort to explain a major piece of legislation and certainly the most significant one having to do with sports in the history of the Congress, Senator John V. Tunney plans to hold a press conference here Friday.

title: Do the Media Coveror Createthe News?
description: IN Anatomy of a News Story, a recent. hourlong documentary on the Columbia Broadcasting System, C.B.S. News engaged in a form of selfexamination, which we hope to do more of in the future. The experiment provided simply an account how one particular news story was covered by one news organization.

title: Shah of Iran to Visit Nixon
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 7 (Reuters)The Shah of Iran and Empress Farah will make a state visit to Washington from July 24 to 27, the Western White House announced today.

title: Marcos Finds Problems Persisting
CAPILLARY STUDY FOCUSES ON TOES
description: STOCKHOLM July 7  A Swedish doctor has found a new use for an old instrumentthe microscope. With it he is peering into toes to benefit patients suffering painful leg damage from severe arterosclerosis and diabetes.

title: A Correction
description: It was incorrectly stated last Sunday that the new Heart Center at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L. I., would open last week. The center is to open Aug. 1.

title: L.I. Town Acts to Cut Auto Race Noise Level
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I. It's a constant, steady drone like a swarm of bumblebees all around the house. Mrs. Gary Lake lives in Noyac about a mile away from the Bridgehampton race circuit. In a few weeks the nagging noise that she hears three times a week when the track is open for events or practice may disappear, curtailed by an ordinance passed last Tuesday by the Southampton Town Board.

title: American League
description: Sunday, July 8, 1973

title: Computer Will Coordinate Events for 76 Bicentennial
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The American Revolution Bicentennial Commission inaugurated this week, a $2million computer system to coordinate events for the 1976 celebration.

title: From Repair Man To Violin Maker
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.,  Vincent O'Brien, who once operated an auto body repair shop in Brooklyn, says he is the only O'Brien in the world making violins.

title: Rudolph Designs a Jewish Sanctuary on L. I.
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L.I. Unique, honest, a vanguard structure  Rabbi Stanley Wernick is uncertain how best to describe the sanctuary that Paul Rudolph, the widely acclaimed and controversial architect, has designed for the Jewish Center here.

title: Miss Morgan, Peter Folsom Plan Nuptials
description: Rear Adm. Henry S. Morgan Jr., U.S.N., of Seoul, Korea, and Mrs. Morgan of Washington and Stonington, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Morgan, to Peter Lincoln Folsom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lincoln Folsom of Delray Beach, Fla., and Centerville, Mass.

title: U.A.W. Gift to Trinidad
description: DETROIT, July 7 (UPI)The president of the United Auto Workers, Leonard Woodcock, said this week that the union had donated a $20,000 fully equipped mobile health clinic trailer to serve the village of Matlot and nearby communities on the north coast of Trinidad.

title: Improved Surgery Helping Horses Live to Race Again
description: The faces were grim on concerned friends of the patient as they gathered around him in the recovery room after the twohour operation, but the doctor was smiling.

title: JOB PLAN PUSHED AT MODEL CITIES
description: We're not going to let up on this, there's got to be a change, said Model Cities Administrator Joseph B. Williams, reacting to a State Court of Appeals ruling last week striking down one of his most cherfished programs.

title: U.S. Post in Thailand Filled
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, (UPI) Maj. Gen. Thomas W. Mellen of the United States Army has been named the commander of the Military Assistance Command in Thailand, the command announced today.

title: Travel Notes: Dutch Airlines Rated Safest
description: FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL, an independent British magazine concerned with air travel, has published the results of a survey of the safety records of all the commercial airlines in the 15 leading nations in terms of air traffic. Nations are ranked according to the number of deaths occurring for each million flights by all of the commercial airlines in that country. The survey covers the decade from 1963 to 1972. The five nations with the best safety records were: the Netherlands, with a rating of zero (which means no reported deaths); Australia, 19.6; Belgium, 38.4; Scandinavia (all Scandinavian countries were grouped together for the purposes of this survey), 38.6; and the United States, 45.3. A few countries at the bottom of the list were far removed from those with the best safety records. The poorest performances were made by Japan, 262; France, 290; India, 475, and a country in the Middle East which Flight International did not name, 1,516.

title: Will Independence Spoil the Bahamas?
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas  When Columbus landed in these parts in 1492, he and his men were greeted as though they were some kind of deities by the naked Arawak Indians. They [the Indians] went running from house to house ... with loud cries of Come! Come to see the people from heaven!  Columbus reported, obviously flattered. Travelers go for that sort of thing.

title: Marines Join Army Test To Encourage Reservists
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The Marine Corps has joined the Army in testing a reduced drill requirement for reservists in an effort to encourage enlistments.

title: Women Act to End Police Force Bias
description: EAST BRUNSWICKThe East Brunswick Women's Caucus has filed a complaint against the local Police Department, charging that its hiring practices exclude women. The complaint was filed late last month with the State Division of Civil Rights.

title: Powerful and Severe Musician
description: In his last days, Otto Klemperer on the podium was a sight that commanded awe, pity and terror. All but crippled, this massive man would slowly make his way to the front, seat himself, look at the orchestra with the permanent scowl that brain operation had left him, and commence beating time with huge fists.

title: New and Recommended
description: ANTOINE BLOYE, by Paul Nizan. (Monthly Review, $6.95.) A Marxist novel about workingclass France, written in 1933 by a young French Communist and long considered a masterpiece.

title: Tennis's Tricky Shot
Alice's Restaurant One More Time
description: COULD it be? Knowledgeable nostrils on the lawns of Tanglewood last summer picked up almost forgotten fragrances: freshly made cabbage borscht, meatfilled piroshki, tacos. Memories fastened onto an older, simpler age, say around 1965, when a Brooklynborn, selfconfessed female delinquent was becoming a genuine allAmerican folkrockpoptype heroine, a gastronomic guru for the Berkshires. It was the era of Alice and Ray Brock's converted church near Stockbridge, Mass., and the beginning of the world's best known cinemastyle eating placeAlice's Restaurant.

title: What Became Of the Music In Musicals?
description: ITS now 30 years since Rodgers and Hammerstein's Oklahoma! revolutionized musical comedy by converting it into something called lyric theater. Some of us who lived through the transition have never ceased regretting the fact.

title: Arthur Daley
description: If the barren wastelands of the dour and forbidding links at Troon on the west coast of Scotland hold no appeal for most of the contestants in this week's British Open golf championship, the exuberant Lee Trevino thinks they are absolutely peachy. Troon is hard by the Firth of Clyde and the weather has scarred it with dunes, scrubs and desolation. But to Trevino the course will be as familiar Sports as if it had been lifted from his native Texas. of That's why he is so unusually confident of retaining his twicewon British Open title.

title: Gary Young Is Fianc Of Wendy Lowenthal
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 7Miss Wendy Lowenthal and Gary Young, who are in their second year at the Brooklyn Law School, plan to marry Sept. 1, Dr. and Mrs. Martin Lowenthal have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollis Young of Paramus.

title: Brezhnev's Visit Hailed in Soviet. Poetry
description: MOSCOW, July 7Rarely is a Soviet foreignpolicy success complete until it has been crowned with flights of poetry. Soviet craftsmen got to work on the NixonBrezhnev summit, meeting, and one of them has come .up with a paean to the Soviet leader's trip to the United States called The Grand Mission.

title: Acrostic puzzle
description: Guess the words defined below and write them over their numbered dashes. Then transfer each letter to the correspondingly numbered square in the pattern. Black squares indicate word endings. The filled pattern will contain a quotation reading from left to right. The first letters of the guessed words will form an acrostic giving author's name and title of work.

title: Inflation's Pinch Tightens
description: Inflation is beginning to roll back living standards in many countries. The pinch is greatest on food as consumer demand continues high on nonessential items and some countries are experiencing a new economic upsurge. A canvass of the state of inflation in major world regions, completed by New York Times correspondents, indicates that the malady is getting worse and apparently becoming chronic in most of them.

title: Presbyterians Schism, But No Bitterness
description: The big American Protestant churches are like the major political parties: They are loose confederations in which internal divisions between liberals and conservatives often tend to be more severe than differences between competing groups as a whole.

title: E.C.A.C. in Trouble?
Jamaica Subway Under Way
description: The roar and shadows of the Jamaica Avenue Elevated line may continue to plague local residents and businessmen for some time, but its rattling lifespan is expected to come to an end shortly after work on two new subway mutes nearby is completed in 1975.

title: Telling Time
description: By Norma Skurka

title: Alva Cottrell Has Nuptials
description: RED BANK, N. J., July 7 Miss Alva Joyce Cottrell and Eric Bennet Perkins were married here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Charles Webster, the senior minister.

title: A.E.C. Plant in Oak Ridge Schedules Layoffs of 980
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 7 Layoffs totaling about 980 are planned at the Y12 plant, one of the three major nuclear plants in Oak Ridge, Atomic Energy Commission officials announced yesterday.

title: RESERVES AND GUARD ACT TO WOO BLACKS
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 7 (UP) The Armed Forces Reserves and the National Guard are stepping up efforts to attract blacks, both to enlist and as civilian employes, the chief of the National Guard has announced.

title: They used to throw it out
description: Nobody has ever climbed down all those miles into the bowels of the earth to see it in its murky natural state, and hardly anybody ever gets a look at the finished product, either, as it gets boiled and cracked and blended and piped and tanked and finally burned up in the secret confines of all our engines. Gasoline's movements through oil field, refinery and filling station are a hidden, practically unnoticeable flow.

title: The Nation
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  The South got a new cause celebre last week when the Department of Justice and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare began investigating a federally funded familyplanning clinic here that sterilized 11 girls, all minors, 10 of them black and some retarded.

title: Communists Push Cambodian Troops Closer to Capital
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 7 (UPI)Cambodian Government troops under heavy attack by Communist forces withdrew from two positions and left a third unit isolated in the crumbling defensive perimeter south of Phnom Penh, reports from the area said today.

title: The Merger Game
description: If business mergers, like marriages, are supposed to be synergisticoffering more benefits to the partners than they could expect to derive individuallywhy does the Federal Government challenge some mergers and not others?

title: Blind Man Breaks Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The blind operator of a New Mexico snack bar was granted one of the few exceptions to the Administration's 60day price freeze yesterday. The Cost of Living Council said that Richard Fernandez would be allowed to increase from 201 cents to 25 cents the price of soda pop at his snack bar in Albuquerque to offset wage increases for two handicapped employes.

title: TAIPEI ATTACHED TO ITS U.S. ENVOY
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 7For the eighth year, the toast at the American Embassy's Fourth of July reception for Chinese Nationalist officials and other dignitaries this week was intoned in the soft Alabama drawl of Ambassador Walter P. McConaughy.

title: Deborah Baylis Is Bride
description: LEWES, Del., July 7Miss Deborah Baylis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Burton Baylis of Rehoboth Beach, was married here this afternoon in the Bethel United Methodist Church to James Postles Hammond 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hammond Jr. of Milford and Rehoboth Beach. The Rev. A. Edward Dougherty performed the ceremony.

title: CITY CAUTIONED ON USE OF DEBT
description: The Citizens Budget Commission warned yesterday of a growing tendency by the city's authorities to use longterm debt allowed under the capital budget for cnstantly increasing amounts of the city's daytoday operating expenses that should be financed by the expense budget.

title: Ive accomplished a few big sculptures
description: SACHE, France. You could call Jean Davidson, who came to get me at the Tours railroad station, the Home Secretary of Calder's kingdom. He is also Calder's soninlaw, having married his eldest daughter, Sandra, in 1955, after a few simple questions and positive answers, in Calder's words. Calder remarked during the wedding lunch: Two vague people who got together to lead an even vaguer existence.

title: Elizabeth Knights Detective
description: LONDON, July 7 (Reuters)Queen Elizabeth II today knighted the detective who was her bodyguard for 17 years. The former Commander Perkins now becomes Sir Edward Perkins. He retired this week at the age of 65.

title: Rough Going on the Ohio
description: MADISON, Ind., July 7 (AP) One boat sank and two others threw their drivers into the Ohio River today during program of limited hydroplane racing, a part of the 26th Madison regatta. No one was injured.

title: JAMES GILLIGAN
description: James Gilligan, who retired 10 years ago as a senior partner in Gilligan Will & Co., stockbrokers, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in West Caldwell, N. J.

title: Maccabiah Games: A Somber Occasion
description: TEL AVIV, July 7 The quadrennial Maccabiah Games, which bring together leading Jewish sportsmen of the free world, will open Monday evening in the Municipal Stadium of Ramat Gan, a suburb of Tel Aviv.

title: Nixon Names Garrett to Head S.E.C.
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 7 (Reuters)President Nixon, as expected, announced today his intention to nominate Ray D. Garrett, a Chicago lawyer, as the new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Norman Biltz, 71, Is Dead; Realty Developer in Nevada
description: RENO, July 7 (UPI)Norman Biltz, a financier, developer and major political figure in Nevada for several decades, died Tuesday at the age of 71.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO LEAD SOVIET IN SCIENCES
description: MOSCOW, July 7 (Reuters) Dr. Philip Handler, president of the United States National Academy of Sciences, said here this week that American science was a cut ahead of Soviet science but the distance between them was not very great.

title: Art
description: BAD boys who deny their culpability until confronted with irrefutable proof of their misbehavior always promise to be good boys when caught in the act and scolded. They can be very appealing in their repentance, but nobody can be blamed for maintaining waitandsee attitude toward their reformation. Even if they mean what they say when they say it, it is often true that bad boys will be bad boys, unable to resist the next temptation when it comes their way, and ready to fib again about having yielded to it. A repentant but chronic fibber cannot be pardoned on the spot. He has to be put on probation, and that is exactly where the Metropolitan Museum is right now, following the release of its longawaited White Paper at a press conference on June 26.

title: F.T.C.STUDY LINKS SHORTAGE OF GAS TO PROFIT MOTIVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  A staff study by the Federal Trade Commission says that the nation's petroleum shortage is the product of anticompetitive practices fostered by Government regulations and manipulated by the major oil companies to protect their profits.

title: Architecture
description: OUR preservation correspondents are always with us. They make cogent, passionate case, more often than not with pictures. And they range from Harvard professors to the man, or woman, in the street.

title: Passport of Wife Of Newsman Lifted After Trip to Hanoi
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 7The State Department has withdrawn the passport of a member of the press party that flew to Hanoi on March 29 to witness the release of the last group of American prisoners or war held by North Vietname. The passport of Le Lieu Browne was withdrawn last month and she was issued a temporary threemonth passport pending legal resolution of the case.

title: U.S. Asks Maine to Resume Hearings on Oil Refinery
description: AUGUSTA, Me., July 7The United States State Department recommended yesterday that the Maine Board of Environmental Protection resume hearings on the Pittston Company's application for an oil refinery at Eastport.

title: Music as Therapy Aids Handicapped
description: TEANECKMusic as therapy for handicapped children has added a new dimension to Lowell Zimmer's lifeand to the lives of the children he teaches.

title: NO BENEFIT FOUND IN IMPOUNDMENT
description: WASHINGTON, July 7A research team at the University of Florida has concluded that President Nixon's refusal to spend more than $8billion in Federal funds for domestic projects did not measurably reduce inflation but did contribute to unemployment.

title: Child's Body Found'in River
description: The partly decomposed body of a child about 2 or 3 years old and clad only in a diaper was found yesterday in the Hudson River near the 79th Street marina. The police of the 20th Precinct said it was not possible to determine immediately the child's sex. The body was taken to the Medical Examiner's office for an autopsy.

title: Swiss Lets Car Do the Talking
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga., July 7There are two reasons why Hans Wiedmer is one of the quietest drivers on the 1973 circuit of the Canadian  American Challenge Cup. One is that, being rather shy, he feels comfortable hanging in the background. The other is that unlike most well  educated Swiss, he speaks only German. Wiedmer's command of English amounts to little more than a smattering, although he was able, a month ago, to summon up enough English to express his annoyance with Canadian taxing procedures. That was on June 10, when this relatively unknown driver placed second in the opening CanAm of the season at Mosport in Ontario. Wiedmer's share of the purse was $11,000, and the Canadian tax people skimmed 15 per cent off the top, leaving him with $9,350.

title: James Ryan Fiance Of Alison Barber
description: ALPINE, N.J., July 7Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Barber Jr. of Alpine and Blue Hill, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Lloyd Barber, to James Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Ryan of Tenafly. A January wedding is planned.

title: Criminologist, 36, Is Given Heart of Accident Victim
description: MADISON, Wis., July 7 (AP) Fred Auby, 36 years old, of Rockford, Ill., had a heart transplant today at University Hospitals here, a hospital spokesman said. Mr. Auby, who is a criminologist, suffered from degenerative heart muscle disease.

title: Catherine Doten Lewis Betrothed
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., July 7 Miss Catherine Doten Lewis, a research assistant at Rockefeller University in New York, plans to be married here Sept. 1 to Owen Robert Floody, who is studying for a Ph.D. in physiological psychology at Rockefeller as a graduate fellow.

title: Bemo Takes American Derby as Our Native, My Gallant Are Out of Money
description: CHICAGO, July 7 (AP)  Bemo, owned by the Hickory Tree Stable of Mrs. J. P. Mills of Wilmington, Del., charged from behind to win the $114,400 American Derby at Arlington Park today.

title: Polygamy for Ugandans
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 7 (Agence FrancePresse)Uganda men are to be allowed an unlimited number of wives under certain conditions, according to a decree signed here this week by President Idi Amin. The polygamous marriages are to be contracted under customary law in accordance with tribal regulations, including parental consent and payment of bridal doweries.

title: Legal Aid
description: More than 400 Legal Aid Society lawyers went on strike in New York City last week, and they weren't very lawyerlike at all They picketed the courthouses; they refused to argue their clients cases; they wore huge redwhiteandblue placards over their jeans and Tshirts; they rallied in Foley Square and cheered lustily as speaker after speaker shouted the old union cry that unity is strength.

title: 10 New Trustees Elected By Citizens Budget Unit
description: The Citizens Budget Commission, the civic group that monitors municipal finances, has elected 10 new trustees to its board. William S. Renchard, chairman, said the new officials were:

title: State Adopts Abortion Rules
description: TRENTON  The state's Health Department has adopted guidelines to regulate hygiene and safety in the performing of abortions. The rules, which cover the first 12 weeks of pregnancy, are not mandatory and they avoid the sensitive questions of Medicaid support for abortions and whether hospitals can be required to provide the service.

title: Today's Jazz
description: Following is today's schedule for the Newport Jazz FestivalNew York: 8 P.M., Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, LI., Jazz and Soul on the Island. Duke Ellington and Orchestra; Ray Charles and Orchestra; Donny Hathaway; Tito Puente; Aretha Franklin.

title: Triplets Graduate as Top 3 Scholars
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.When it comes to sibling rivalry, William, Robert and James Bain are experts. Identical triplets, the youths recently graduated as the top three scholars from the local high school with Jim and his 94.550 average barely edging Bob (94.500) and Bill (94.388) to lead the 160member senior class. They finished elementary school in the same order.

title: Private Ohio College to Be Taken Over by StateSupported School
description: OXFORD, Ohio, July 7 Some people here think it may have been a portent when this town's only movie theater changed its name recently, shortening it from the Miami Western to the Miami so that it would fit on a new, sleeker marquee.

title: 8 Are Attendants Of Betsy Godley In Woods Bridal
description: MORRIS, N.Y., July 7 Miss Betsy Godley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Godley of New Canaan, Conn., was married here this afternoon to James C. Sargent Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sargent of New York.

title: World News Briefs Soviet Emigrants Arrive in Vienna
description: VIENNA, July 7 (Reuters) Dmitri M. Segal, a Soviet Jewish scholar who fought a long battle with Russian authorities for permission to emigrate, has arrived in Vienna on his way to Israel.

title: Qaddafi Giving Egyptian Leaders Foretaste of Difficulties Under a Merger
description: CAIRO, July 3Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, is giving the leaders of Egypt a foretaste of how difficult it may be for them to live with him if the planned merger between the two countries takes place.

title: Chess: Tal's Bleh! Start No Worse Than Larsen's Ugh! Finish
description: I was not ill; it was my nerves. That was the explanation Mikhail Tal gave for his horrendous start, losing to Eugenio Torre of the Philippines and Guillermo Estevez of Cuba in rounds 2 and 3 of the Leningrad Interzonal.

title: Coal Mine Fatalities Down 36.6% From Totals in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) Coal mining fatalities totaled 53 during the first half of 1973, a 36.9 per cent drop from the same period last year, the Bureau of Mines has revealed.

title: Brouhaha Over Rukus and U. S. Agency
description: COLLECTORS of Ryukyu Islands issues are up in arms over the recent seizure by the U.S. Secret Service of a simulation of a Ryukyu stamp that had been produced in Japan to combat artificially stimulated inflation in the value of the bona fide issuethe 3cent Shureimon (Gate of Courtesy) stamp of 1958.

title: Movies What Hollywood Has in Store for 1974From Supermen to Snakes
description: HOLLYWOOD MOVIES are always full of last summer's ideas, last spring's jargon. Even the shoddiest major studio black exploitation film with an 18day shooting schedule takes almost six months to move from the producer's first Write me a film about a black pimp in Hawaii to the last reel of film unspooling in a theater. For a respectable movie, what is seen on the screen was most often written a year and a half earlier. It bears some relation, of course, to current facts and fantasies, but there is a subtle distortion.

title: From France to chagall, 86, With Many Happy Returns: a Museum
description: NICE, France, July 7On the hillside overlooking the Mediterranean amid cypresses, olives and eucalyptus trees and beds of blooming lavender, thyme and rosemary. France celebrated Marc Chagall's 86th birthday today by giving him a museum.

title: Mildred Lunn Sawyer Is Bride of Eric G. Robinson
description: SOUTHWEST HARBOR, Me., July 7Miss Mildred Lunn Sawyer and Eric Gordon Robinson were married here this afternoon in St. John the Divine Episcopal Church by the bride's greatuncle, the Rev. Henry Lewis of Palo Alto, Calif., and Southwest Harbor.

title: Pioneer, Bound for Jupiter. Is 2d to Cross Mars Orbit
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., July 7 (AP)  Jupiterbound spacecraft Pioneer 11 has crossed the orbit of Mars, only the second spacecraft to perform the feat, control headquarters say.

title: Warson Triumphs Upstate
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., July 7 (AP)Warson, a 5yearold roan gelding, outran Fun Luvin Woman in the stretch today to win the feature race by a neck at Finger Lakes Race Track. Blues Count was the show horse in the 11horse field. The winner covered the six furlongs in 1:13 15 and paid $6.80, $4.20 and $3.20.

title: Classmate to Wed Miss Valerie Mirto
description: Miss Valerie Catherine Mirto and Robert Joseph Rothschild, who are studying for master's degrees in business administration at St. John's University and who work for the Chase Manhattan Bank, plan to be married in January.

title: News of the Stage
description: The Times Square Theater Center, a facility designed by the city for the sale of tickets to Broadway and Off Broadway shows at half price on day of performance only has apparently had successfull beginning.

title: Peter Morse Is Fiance Of  Martha Parke Ford
description: GROSSE POINTE SHORES, Mich., July 7  Miss Martha Parke Ford, a greatgranddaughter of Henry Ford, founder of the Ford Motor Company, and of Harvey S. Firestone, founder of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, plans to be married in the fall to Peter Christopher Morse, who is with Lehman Brothers, investment bankers in New York.

title: Witnesses Baptize 1,597 at Assembly
description: With clocklike precision, 1,597 Jehovah's Witnesses were baptized by total immersion yesterday in two 24foot plastic and Fiberglas pools set up for the occasion in Macomb's Dam Park adjacent to Yankee Stadium.

title: F.H.A. Foreclosures Scored
description: Federal housing officials have been told by residents of several Brooklyn neighborhoods that a Federal Housing Administration requirement is having a severely negative effect on their areas.

title: A.H.S.A. to Capitalize On Washington Rating
description: A major change in the status of two horse shows on the fall indoor circuit was announced yesterday by the American Horse Shows Association.

title: U.S. Men's Five Captures Final Game of China Tour
description: TOKYO, July 7 (AP)The United States collegiate allstar men's basketball team beat the Kwangtung Provincial team, 10182, but the American national women's champions from John F. Kennedy College lost to the Chinese, 6355, in the Americans farewell games in China played in Canton yesterday, Peking reported today.

title: Puerto Rico's Use Of Militia in Strike Stirs Confrontation
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 7 The calling out of the National Guard to deal with strikes by firemen and by employes of the electric power authority provoked an angry confrontation late last night in which shots were fired and tear gas canisters exploded.

title: SEARCH IS BEGUN FOR 2 CANADIANS Officers Missing in Vietcong Region for 10 Days
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 7An official search party today began looking for two Canadian officers missing for 10 days in a Vietcongcontrolled rubber plantation east of Saigon.

title: They turn on the power of Wall Street
description: Whatever happened to the Wall Street lawyer? At one point in this century these warlords of the bar composed sort of private system of justice in the United States, keeping their robberbaron clients tolerably close to the letter of the law, if not within the strict bounds of morality, and doing the legal gluework that put together our capitalistic society. One financial Brahmin (the remark is attributed, variously, to Gould, Morgan and Harriman) marveled at the wisdom of Elihu Root Sr.: I have had lawyers who have told me what I cannot do. Mr. Root is the only lawyer who tells me how to do what I want to do.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
Wood, Field and Stream
description: There is no sweeter craft than the canoe for running rivers or cruising lakes, for pushing into back country where civilization's only intrusion is an aircraft passing high overhead.

title: Heidi Rosenblum Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Rosenblum of Oceanside, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Heidi Rosenblum, to Bradley B. Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Roberts of Belle Harbor, Queens. The future bride is a junior at the Fashion Institute of Technology, and her fianc attends the New York University School of Dentistry.

title: Ancient Site Found in Egypt
description: CAIRO, July 7 (Reuters)Villagers at Salehia, about 80 miles from here, have discovered an archeological area dating back 2,000 years and plundered it for relics, the newspaper Al Akhbar has reported. Relics have been recovered from some houses in the area, including a large coffin found in a chicken shed, the paper said.

title: Students Making A Mark on Stage
description: LINCROFT  Brookdale Community College may be only a junior college, but its Drama Department has majorleague ambitions. In its second summer of repertory, it is presenting three fulllength Broadway plays in its small, but fully equipped and modern, theater.

title: Hotels Turn On the Charm
description: Houseboats, honorsystem bars and pretty DoorBelles (instead of doormen) are some of the lures hotel operators are trying these days to bring in the wellheeled businessman. By all accounts, the new gimmicks are working.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Letty Pogrebin's hackles have been raised by a passage in Animals Do the Strangest Things, dealing with women's fear of bats. She cites it as characteristic of a subtle antifeminism pervading children's literature.

title: A Wind in the Door
description: Children's literature may well be the last repository of stories which assert without embarrassment the existence of good and evil and make clear the distinction between them. think of C. S. Lewis's Narnia books, in which a believing Christian uses fantasy to convey to children the Christian message that diffficult love is the ultimate destroyer of evil. Or the books of Madeleine L'Engle, also a believing Christian, who builds her fantasy on science in The Arm of the Starfish, The Young Unicorns, and most notably, her Newbery Award winner, A Wrinkle in Time, that compelling tale of Meg Murry, her brother Charles Wallace, their friend Calvin O'Keefe, and their wrestling with the forces of evil for the life of Dr. Murry, the physicist father trapped on the inhuman planet of Camazotz.

title: Sag Harbor Tries to Preserve the Past While Welcoming the Future
description: SAG HARBOR, L.I.With plans under way for another extension of the Sunrise Highway, and the mushrooming of condominiums where potatoes and strawberries once grew, most eastern Suffolk communities have been caught in a dilemma of progress vs. preservation, but this is less so in Sag Harbor.

title: IN THE NATION
description: NoKnock Opponents Were Right

title: A Journal of The Plague Years
description: In any study of the uncharted halfworld in which American culture and American politics meet, overlap, inextricably interweave, surely no period is more disturbing, overhung with portent, than the era to which Stefan Kanfer, borrowing from Defoe and with a nod to Camus, gives the name the plague years. These were the years of the blacklist, when people variously connected with the entertainment industries as writers, directors, actors, were investigated for their political beliefs and associations and if these were thought to be directly or indirectly Communistcontrolled or inspired were deprived of their jobs or, in cases where they failed to cooperate with a Congressional investigating committee, sometimes jailed for contempt.

title: Monmouth Jockeys
Doityourself ice cream
description: Flavor combinations created by fanciers of homemade ice cream have gone beyond the standard 28 varieties, and, if current sales patterns continue, there could be an icecream freezer in every home. (The latest innovation, which will be on the market soon, is an electrically operated icecream maker that will fit into a home freezer or the freezer compartment of a refrigerator and will do away with the need for all that messy crushed ice and rock salt.) Real maple syrup is the secret to the oldfashioned goodness in the creamysmooth ice cream described here. Lime and ginger enhance the cantaloupe sherbet, which can be an appetizer or a dessert.

title: A Visit to a Bustling Vietcong City
That Thread of Uncertainty
description: The store buyers have gone home, leaving hundreds of garment companies in the Seventh Avenue area to tally their orders for the fall season.

title: Minnesota Ends Drought With 91, 62 Victories
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 7After running into problems posed by their own players in losing to Minnesota, 91, in the first game of a daynight program, the Yankees encountered a problem created by an escalator in the second game tonight.

title: Beyond Those Giddy 60's
description: ROBERT FRIED is a young artist who made his mark in San Francisco in 1967 as a top creator of psychedelicstyle posters. For the information of anyone who missed the sixties, the psychedelic style was a lush synthesis of Art Nouveau and Pop influences best realized in the medium of offset lithography, high on labyrinthine design and flashy color and, in the case of posters, low on legibility. But no one seemed to mind that. Unfortunately, the freshness of this art proved as transitory as the euphoria of the acidrock scene it ornamented. The whole thing came and went in something like five minutes.

title: All That Jazz At Coliseum
description: UNIONDALE, L. I.Jazz comes to the suburbs is the way many at the Nassau Coliseum are dubbing the concert here tonight that includes some of the biggest names in the music worldDuke Ellington, Tito Puente, Donny Hathaway, Aretha Franklin and Ray Charles.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Forming a Populist Front
description: The tableau was traditionala pair of politicians working the crowd at a smailtown fairground on July 4but the cast of characters was quite a departure from tradition, There, at The Spirit of America festival in Decatur, Ala., was Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the guest of Gov. George Wallace. Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Wallace, seated together above, are both Democrats. There the resemblance ends. But Mr. Kennedy told the crowd that despite their differences, the two men had much in common along oldfashioned populist lines: they both opposed high taxes, high interest rates and the excesses of government bureaucracy. Then, in a pointed reference to the Nixon Administration, Mr. Kennedy found another area common ground with Governor Wallace: We don't compile lists of enemies, he said, whose careers and lives are to be shattered because of their disagreement. Senator Kennedy said he spoke at the fair honoring Mr. Wallace because of their experience with political violence. Inevitably, Mr. Kennedy's appearance, and his emphasis on party unity, led to the belief that he was also publicly declaring his intention of seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination 1976.

title: American Lauds Soviet On Cleanness of Rivers
description: An American inland waterways executive who recently returned from the Soviet Union says that the Russians are doing a superior job in combating the pollution on their rivers.

title: Barnyard Animals Join Cats and Dogs at Bide  A  Wee
description: WANTAGH, L.I.A bageleating duck named Mike, a peacock, a burro and dozens of more conventional barnyard animals have taken up residence at the Lollipop Farm, a new addition to the BideAWee Animal Shelter here.

title: Evert Family's Honor Upheld By Jeanne in U.S. Tourney
description: CHATTANOOGA, July 7 (AP) Jeanne Evert won her semifinal match in the national amateur clay court tournament today, but wasn't happy about the timing.

title: Law Students Counsel Addicts
description: JERSEY CITY  Young men and women facing criminal chargesand addicted to narcoticsmay find their future legal battles somewhat less foreboding, thanks to the assistance of Seton Hall University law students.

title: Cardinals Triumph, 61; Giants Hitless Until 7th
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 (AP)  Reggie Cleveland held the San Francisco Giants hitless for six innings to pace the St. Louis Cardinals to a 61 victory today.

title: Seminary Meets at 6 A.M.
description: On 6 o'clock on a recent morning, 10 teenagers gathered in a small room at the rear of the Brooklyn chapel of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints (Mormons). They started the service by singing a hymn and then they knelt on the floor in front of their folding chairs.

title: TV Mailbag
Some in Bahamas Prefer the Queen to Independence
description: GREAT ABACO ISLAND, the Bahamas, July 4  In the years immediately following the American Revolution, people who wanted no part of the new United States came here with their slaves from Massachusetts, New York, Virginia and the Carolinas.

title: The Economy
description: WASHINGTON  The calendar is running for three men who hive what may be the most difficult job In the United States today: They must produce President Nixon's promised Phase 4 price program in time for it to take effect by his selfimposed deadline of August 12.

title: Yonkers Drivers
BENJAMIN KIMLAU
description: Benjamin Kimlau, a ChineseAmerican funeral director here from 1930 to 1971, died Friday at his home, 28 Mulberry Street. His age was 81.

title: Convenience Wins Again In Rich Vanity Handicap
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 7 (AP)  Convenience captured the $109,500 Vanity Handicap today at Hollywood Park for the second straight year. She became the second thoroughbred in 32 years of the competition to win the event two times in succession.

title: Shopping Centers
description: YONKERS  A proposal to build one of the largest shopping centers in the region was offered to this city a few months ago, and the prospect of millions of dollars in real estate and sales tax revenues such a mall would generate electrified city officials.

title: Movie Mailbag What Was Bergman Really Crying and Whispering About?
Calendar of Horse Show Events
description: TodayCape Cod, Maushop Farms, Old King's Road, Cotuit, Mass., Regular, green, amateurowner and junior working hunters; amateurowner and junior jumpers, equitation; 9 A.M.

title: CANDIDATES SEEK 2D LINE ON BALLOT
description: New Yorkers going to the polls in November to elect a Mayor and other officials will find wellknown politicians listed under strange party names.

title: The quintessential multinational telecommunications conglomerate
description: FOR a corporation conceived in deception and lawlessness  it tried to confuse itself in the 1920's with the more recognized name of A.T.&T. and entered into a cartel agreement with Ma Bell to divide up world telecommunications markets  ITT's 1972 activities reveal a halfcentury of impressive consistency. But ITT did achieve something of a breakthrough last year. Now everybody knows its name.

title: Minor Leagues
2 Young Sisters and a Brother Drown at Jamaica Bay Picnic
description: Two young Brooklyn sisters and their 16yearold brother drowned last night while picnicking and fishing with friends off the southern part of Broad Channel Island in Jamaica Bay.

title: Yonkers Results
EDUCATION FUNDS SOUGHT BY RABBIS
Miss Hollis A. McCollum Married
description: Miss Hollis Ann McCollum, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Fisher McCollum of New York and Gordon Haig McCollum of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married here yesterday afternoon to John Cornell Schenck Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schenck of Scarsdale, N. Y. The Rev. Ralph Warren performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church.

title: A Lemon, a Pear, A Sprig of Thyme
SPOTLIGHT
description: VIENNAHe looks like he could be. an ambitious middlemanagement executive for Texaco, youthful and lean, conservatively dressed, a mite stiff and formal.

title: EUNICE FUNG LEWIS
description: Mrs. Eunice Fung Lewis, a social worker and the founder of the Evangel Mission at 29 East Broadway, in Chinatown, died yesterday at her home in Rego Park, Queens. She was 83 years old, Mrs. Lewis and her late husband, Francis H. Lewis, established the mission in the midnineteenforties. The mission provides instruction in Christian evangelism to Chinese and offers a rapid method of learning English.

title: Tidbits From European Parley, Where Even Parties Can Be Dull
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July The foreign ministers of 35 countries ended the first phase of the European security conference today, formally agreeing to resume negotiations in Geneva on Sept. 18. Thirtythree of them left cursing the Maltese.

title: ROGER H. HEYLIN
description: Roger H. Heylin, former vice president and Eastern sales manager of the Hugo Bosca Company, Inc., of Springfield, Ill., a leathergoods organization, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 16 Park Avenue.

title: Steamer Clams, Though Scarce, Still Provide Taste Treat
description: The steamer scene was particularly depressing on Long Island last summer. Visions of plump clams, drenched in Mater, vanished in the wake of Hurricane Agnes. Floods have polluted Chesapeake Bay, the source of steamer clams on many restaurants. Having lost their normal supply, seafood houses throughout the New York area dug into Long Island resources, leaving fewer for the local consumer. And these at higher prices.

title: Qaddafi Tells Women Why They're Different
description: CAIRO, July 7 (UPI)  Libya's leader, Col Muammar elQaddafi said at a meeting of Egypt's leading feminists this week that women's liberation movements were no good, persons present at the meeting reported.

title: Bowsher Takes Miller Pole
description: MILWAUKEE, July 9 (AP)Jack Bowsher of Springfield, Ohio, was clocked at 106.509 miles an hour in his 1971 Ford Torino today and won the pole position for tomorrow's Miller 200mile United States Auto Club latemodel stock car race. Bobby Unser, Albuquerque, N. M., was second in a 1973 Chevelle at 106.067 m.p.h.

title: World Bank's ProfitTurning DoGooder
SEAN M'EOIN DEAD; FOUGHT THE BRITISH
description: DUBLIN, July 7 (AP)Sean MacEoin, a leader of Ireland's independence struggle against Britain half a century ago, died today in a military hospital here, He was 79 years old.

title: Under Mr. Piggy Logan's tent
description: Alexander Calder's miniature circus was the rage of drawing rooms in Paris and, later, New York, in the late nineteentwenties, but one writer saw the show's vogue as a symptom of the boredom of the wealthy. They were bored with living, they were bored with dying, butthey were not bored that year with Mr. Piggy Logan and his circus of wire dolls, Thomas Wolfe wrote in You Can't Go Home Again about a gathering in a fashionable Manhattan apartment in the year 1929. Mr. Piggy Logan, judging from the description of the performance, was pretty clearly modeled after Calder, who served as ringmaster for his circus, barking out the names of acts, moving the little wire performers through their paces and even passing out peanuts to the audience. Excerpts from Wolfe's satirization of the show:

title: Oilers Sign Nowegian Kicker
description: HOUSTON, July 7 (UPI) Finn Seemann, a Norwegian professional soccer player, signed today with the Houston Oilers of the National Football, League. Seemann will join the Oilers at their Kerville, Tex., summer training camp July 16 as a placekicker.

title: Mrs. Brand Has Child
description: EAST LYME, Conn., July 7 A daughter was born June 14 to Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Brand at the Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in New London.

title: Stewart, Knight in Final Of Pacific Western Tennis
description: EUGENE, Ore., July 7 (AP) Topseeded Sherwood Stewart of Houston moved into the final of the Pacific Western tennis tournament by ousting Steve Tidball of the United States Army, 61, 62.

title: Text of the President's Letter to Ervin
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 7 (UPI)  Following is the text of a letter from President Nixon to Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: Gardens
Dance: Erick Hawkins's Individuality
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 7Erick Hawkins clearly emerged as a choreographer and dancer of special character out of the transitional decade of the nineteenfifties. During a time when the older conventions no longer held promise for future development, and radical novelty had yet to be born, he began to find his own individual path. The Hawkins Company concert last evening at Connecticut College's American Dance Festival luminously showed his creative line.

title: U.S. STUDY SCORES CITY AID PROGRAMS
description: The combined benefits to recipients of New York City's welfare, Medicaid and eight, other public socialbenefit programs can make it extraordinarily unprofitable to work, a Congressional subcomittee reported yesterday.

title: Lisbeth Fenton To Be Married
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., July 7The engagement of Miss Lisbeth Fenton to Robert S. Grossman has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Arnold N. Fenton of Great Neck and Montauk, parents of the future bride. Mr. Grossman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Grossman of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Crenshaw Tops AllAmerica Golf
description: Ben Crenshaw, a junior of the University of Texas, became the first threetime repeater and Lance Suzuki, of Brigham Young University, became the first Tony Lema Scholarship winner to make the eightman 1973 AllAmerican college golf team. The team will he honored July 31 at the ninth annual AllAmerican collegiate golf dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: China Attacks Soviet Union On Paris Air Show Incidents
description: PEKING, July 7China has scathingly attacked the Soviet Union for an alleged spy incident at the Paris air show and the crash of the TUI44 supersonic airliner.

title: Goss and Ali Win at the Forum
description: Displaying little more emotion than they would for Sesame Street, several hundred children were among the fans at the Felt Forum yesterday for the return of weekly televised boxing.

title: The Asian Journal Of Thomas Merton
description: Thomas Merton, a Trappist monk, died in a tragic accident in Bangkok on Dec. 10, 1968. Merton was on a journeya pilgrimage, he called itto Asia to look deep into Buddhism, not as a student but to participate fully in Buddhist life, though he was a Roman Catholic priest. He had been attracted to Buddhism in his teens but during his postgraduate days at Columbia was drawn more to Catholicism and became a convert, later entering the Trappists. In the 1950's, shortly after the publication of his autobiography, The Seven Storey Mountain, his interest in Buddhism was revived, and he began a running dialogue with D. T. Suzuki and other members of oriental religions, publishing some of the material in three or four books about Buddhism and related subjects.

title: The Half Past Eight Curtain Will Positively Go Up
description: IOWE that title to the tickettaker at the entrance to one of Second Avenue's Yiddish theaters whom I asked about curthin time one night in 1932. I had an alternate title the line that a respectful stage manager spoke when Jacob P. Adler, the Sir Henry Irving of the Yiddish theater, requested the time: It will be 8:30 when you say so, Mr. Adler. For most of the actors and all of the leisurely audiences, time was not of the essence. God had made plenty of it and an evening at the Yiddish theater was an experience that couldn't be constrained by a timetable, for the play itself was only one element of the three or four hours of enchantment, of escape from an impoverished subsistence.

title: Anderson, Clayton Blossoms Out
description: HOUSTON  A medical study team, investigating the effects of diet on heart disease, came to Anderson, Clayton & Co. in the early nineteensixties with a difficult assignment:

title: Drama Mailbag Women Do Write For the Theater
description: To THE EDITOR: HERE are the women playwrights? We're here! Waiting. Had the question been Why aren't women playwrights being produced? you might have gotten some real answers.

title: LOUISE DENISON
description: CHATHAM, N. J., July 7 Louise Denison, who as L. Denison was assistant editor of Field & Stream Magazine at her retirement in 1967 after 41 years with the magazine, died in a nursing home here today. She was 78 years old and lived at 30 Weston Avenue with her husband, Willard S. Neefus, a retired farmer.

title: JOB PLAN PUSHED AT MODEL CITIES
description: We're not going to let up on this, there's got to be a change, said Model Cities Administrator Joseph B. Williams, reacting to a State Court of Appeals ruling last week striking down one of his most cherished programs.

title: U.A.W. Gift to Trinidad
description: DETROIT, July 7 (UPI)The president of the United Auto Workers, Leonard Woodcock, said this week that the union had donated a $20,000 fully equipped mobile health clinic trailer to serve the village of Matlot and nearby communities on the north coast of Trinidad.

title: Women's Mile Mark Set
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, July 7 (Reuters)Glenda Reiser of Ottawa set a world record in the women's mile today with a time of 4 minutes 34.9 seconds at the Pacific international games. The old mark of 4:35.4 was held by Ellen Tiddell of west German.

title: Miss McInerney Captures Eastern Tennis 18's Final
Ottinger Qualifies 2d Time For Volunteer 500 Race
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., July 7 (UPI) L. D. Ottinger, who qualified yesterday but was disqualified because of an underweight car, came back today to lead qualifiers for tomorrow's 13th Volunteer 500 at the Bristol International Speedway

title: Huge Wall Paintings Enliven Inner Cities
description: TRENTONWith the arrival of hot weather, a man's fancy turns to his environment. And this year, two of New Jersey's major cities are providing, primarily for the viewing pleasure of their innercity residents, huge wall paintings that may startle, amuse or perhaps just offer a splash of color and relief.

title: Louise M. Fiocchi, Bank Aide, Fiancee
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N. J., July 7Mr. and Mrs. Edward George Fiocchi of this place, Roxbury Run, N. Y., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Michele Fiocchi, to Theodore Cheff Krismann of New York. He is a son of the late Capt. Donald Walker Cheff, Medical Corps, U.S.A. and the late Mrs. Emil Krismann. He was adopted by his stepfather.

title: The American Inquisition
description: In 1955, Britishborn Cedric Belfrage, then editor of The National Guardian, was deported under the McCarranWalter Act on the ground that he had allegedly been a member of the American Communist party in the 1930's. His more immediate transgression was his refusal, in an appearance before Senator Joseph McCarthy, to say anything about his politics, past or present. This year, before returning to promote his new book, Belfrage had to petition the State Department for a waiver of his exclusion and was also required to provide a detailed itinerary of his monthlong visit, including where he lodged each night. Belfrage is now back at his home in Mexico, thereby leaving the United States that much safer from whatever danger his physical presence here portends.

title: What's New in Theater?
description: AS YOU LIKE IT, the New York Shakespeare Festival's production of Shakespeare's comedy, got five favorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Watt, News; Tallmer, Post; Sharp, Women's Wear; Sanders, ABCTV) and one mixed review (Wallach, Newsday).

title: New & Novel
description: This slight but springy entertainment is based on the conceit that an institutionalized Mongoloid child is really a clandestine genius, Waldo Benjamin is not only brilliant but wise. Ergo, he teaches himself N.B.C. English by television, and speed reading by flipping through the magazines in the dayroom. Ergo, he is able to spring himself from the Shady Glen sanitarium by age 6, and plunge into a successful career that features commodity speculation and earth shaking.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: To the Editor: Arthur Daley's June 26 article on Ernie Lombardi recalls ithe triple I saw Lombardi hit at the Polo Grounds. He couldn't have hit many in his career, and this one was memorable.

title: New Park Fees Suspended
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The Cost of Living Council announced yesterday that the Army Corps of Engineers had agreed to suspend new user fees at 149 camp sites and 16 day recreation areas in Oklahoma, Texas, Arkansas and Kansas. It said the fees were inconsistent with the price freeze.

title: Mrs. King Is Too Tired For Wimbledon's Ball
description: LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) Mrs. Billie Jean King, who won the women's singles title at the Wimbledon tennis championships and played in three other matches today, missed the traditional Wimbledon Ball tonight. She was too tired.

title: Appeal to What Spirit?
description: If Senator Edward M. Kennedy's FourthofJuly oration in Decatur, Ala., was the first gun of the 1976 Presidential campaign, as professional observers incline to think, the prospects for a politically elevating campaign three years from now are not as bright as they might be.

title: Hendrick Is Lethargic; Indian Manager Is Not
description: CLEVELAND, July 7 (UPI) A Cleveland outfielder, George Hendrick, was expected to be fined several hundred dollars by Indian officials because of lethargic play against the California Angels last night.

title: Nepal Planning to Prohibit Cultivation of Drug Plants
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, July 7 Nepal is to ban the cultivation of hemp, poppies, and other plants from which narcotics are derived.

title: Rock Sings the Blues
description: IN A most important sense, the blues represent a continuum in the history of rock; this is the river that has enriched the musical soil in which the roots of rock have grown. With the exception of a few musicians, notably Paul Butterfield, John Hammond, and Duane and Greg Allman, white American rock musicians have merely paid lip service to the black blues tradition.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayAmerican Motorcycle Drag Racing Association races at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road, Englishtown, N. J. Gates open at 1 P.M., eliminations at 4. Regular weekly pro stock drag races start at 6 P.M.

title: Albinski to Defend Crown In State Archery Tourney
description: Peter Albinski of Baldwin, L. I., will defend his state men's archery championship on July 14 and 15 at Eden, a suburb of Buffalo. His main competition is expected to come from A. Richard Hunter of Wallkill, who finished 14 points behind Albinski last year.

title: BICHON FRISE TOPS FARMINGTON SHOW
Point of View
description: SecretaryTreasurer

title: A Beauty Queen Brightens Backstretch
description: Summer jobs are hard to get, but not for a reigning beauty queen. She could model, cut ribbons at supermarket openings or preside at local fairs and picnics. The work is fun, the hours are easy and the pay is good.

title: Nivola Family Displaying Works in Bridgehampton
description: AMAGANSETt, L. I. Witty exuberance is one of the characteristics of Constantino Nivola's work, whether it be a small statue, a wall painting or one of the cement architectural decorations cast in the sand of the beach outside the Nivolas' home here. The wit and exuberance that flow from the Nivolas' family life mark the exhibit now at the Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton that includes works by Constantino, his wife Ruth and their daughter Claire.

title: Chinese and Americansa New Act in PekingAre Getting Along Splendidly in Public and in Private
Synagogue Is Opening in Deal
description: DEALThe first synagogue in this affluent shore community will be dedicated today, thus marking the culmination of a 15year effort by Sephardic Jewish residents here to have their own house of worship.

title: PATRICK M'VEY DIES; VETERAN ACTOR, 63
description: Patrick McVey, a character actor, died Friday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 435 East 77th Street.

title: Dave Anderson
description: As soon as he stepped off the team bus outside Shea Stadium, the kids surrounded him. He walked among them, signing autographs. But quickly Henry Aaron was inside the players entrance. Mother few steps and he was inside the Atlanta Braves locker room. Waiting for him were five newsmen. Outside, near the dugout, were a dozen more newsmen and several cameramen. When he appeared on the field later; the eyes of thousands followed him. It's almost always like this when the Braves are traveling. Henry Aaron has become a man of history as he approaches Babe Ruth's record of 714 home runs. He has 694 now, but he appears to be as calm as he was for so many years when he wasn't being studied.

title: New California Law Found Not Raising Divorce Rates
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 7 (UPI)The 1969 California law on dissolution of marriage has not turned the state into the divorce capital of the world as critics had predicted, the State Department of Public Health has reported.

title: Major League Averages
description: By The Associated Press

title: Bold Nix Scores by a Nose for $83.60 Upset in Lamplighter at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 7A former claiming horse named Bold Nix surprised 22,938 fans at Monmouth Park today by winning the $29,525 Lamplighter Handicap. His margin was only a nose.

title: Poverty Pockets Eroding MiddleClass Areas Here
Beauduin A Prophet Vindicated. By Sonya A. Quitsiund. Illustrated. 366 pp. New York: Newman Press. $10.
description: To some young liberals in the Roman Catholic Church who were discouraged about working from within to accomplish their reforms, Lambert Beauduin said with a wry smile, Cheer up, it doesn't kill you; I'm 80 years old!
