title: U.S. Aide Firmly Opposes Cutting Troops in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The Nixon Administration said today that it unequivocally opposed any unilateral American withdrawal of troops from Western Europe.

title: RECORDING GROUP MEETS ON PAYOLA
description: The board of directors of the Recording Industry Association of America, the trade organization of the record business, met secretly yesterday to discuss formulation of a positive plan of action to combat the mounting allegations of payola and drug use in the industry.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: A Rooted Sorrow, by P. M. Hubbard (Atheneum, $5.95). A suspense novel.

title: DRUG RAID INQUIRY BROADENED BY U.S.
description: CHICAGO, July 10The Department of Justice broadened tonight the investigatory mandate of a special Federal grand jury that will be convened July 20 to study the illegal Government drug raids on two families in Collinsville, Ill.

title: Fannie Mae Says Auction Resulted in Higher Yields
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (Reuters)  The Federal National Mortgage Association said today the average yield on both Governmentbacked and conventional mortgages rose sharply at the latest auction.

title: Movies Vie, in 6 Figures, for Best Sellers
description: LOS ANGELESAs to Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote to a literary agent in 1929, if any offer for moving pictures of his books for $20,000 or more came to you, don't hesitate to wire him as he's not satisfied with present picture offers

title: For the Madison Mall
description: The proposal to create a pedestrian mall on Madison Avenue in midtown Manhattan comes up for vote in the Board of Estimate today.

title: 6 NIXON LAWYERS HELP ON DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 10At least a halfdozen lawyers are working at the White House on President Nixon's defense in the Watergate case, either full time or nearly full time.

title: Biologists to Testify At Bon Vivant Trial
description: NEWARK, July 10, 1973 The Federal Government said today it would produce perhaps three dozen microbiologists for expert testimony in its suit in Federal District Court here seeking the destruction of 1.5 million cans of food products seized from Bon Vivant Soups, Inc.

title: 2 Firemen Are Trapped In Blaze in Bushwick
description: A threealarm fire destroyed the Good Fair Meat Market at 1729 Broadway, near Rockaway Avenue in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, last night. The fire, which broke out shortly after 9 P.M. and was brought under control at 10:22, also destroyed an adjacent threestory building that was vacant.

title: Frankfurt: Money Auction in Staccato
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 10  Six telephones were ringing at once on Dieter Henke's desk in the Frankfurt currency exchange.

title: VISITING U.S. GROUP ARRIVES IN NANKING
description: NANKING, China, July 10 (UPI)An American Congressional delegation paid a brief visit today to this East China city, the site of the last United States Embassy in China and capital of the country before the Communist takeover in 1949.

title: Kaufman Asks Costantino to Respond
description: The chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, Irving R. Kaufman, told Judge Mark. A. Costantino yesterday that the appellate judges would be pleased to receive Judge Costantino's response to the newspaper accounts of his activities.

title: Mexican Bus Plunge Kills 35
description: MEXICO CITY, July 10 (Reuters)Thirtyfive persons were killed when a bus plunged into a ravine near the Mexican City of Guadalajara, the police said here today.

title: Nixon's OneTime Strong Man Stays Mostly Serene
description: WASHINGTON, July 10What folks had wondered most about John N. Mitchell, a former strong man of the Nixon Administration, was how he would bear up before the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Mitchell Testifies He Opposed Huston's Domestic Security Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell testified today that he opposed the Huston plan for expanded domestic intelligencegathering because of its illegal aspects, and that he had made his objections known to President Nixon and H. R. Haldeman, the former White House chief of staff.

title: Deaths
DOLLAR UP AGAIN AS LINES OF CREDIT for U.S. INCREASE
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 The Federal Reserve Board announced today an increase of more than 50 per cent, to about $18billion, in its swap credit lines with other central banks under which it can borrow foreign currencies for use in defending the dollar's value in foreignexchange trading.

title: Mansfield Terms Nixon Impeachment Debatable
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, said today it was debatable whether President Nixon could be impeached for not knowing of the role of his staff in the Watergate affair, even if he had no personal knowledge of the breakin.

title: GENTILE, WITH A 209, WINS GOLF BY 2 SHOTS
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 10 John Gentile, an assistant professional at the Round Hill Club in Greenwich, Conn., won the Westchester County Golf Association's 51st open championship by two strokes today with 209 at Sunningdale Country Club.

title: G.O.P. Triumphs in Connecticut Test Election
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 10In a special election today, Merritt Comstock of Essex, Republican, won a seat in Connecticut's State Senate by a majority big enough to offer a measure of comfort to Republicans in Washington and Hartford.

title: Badillo Weighing Bid as Independent
description: State Senator Robert Garcia, a close associate and campaign aide of Representative Herman Badillo, said yesterday that there was a 5050 chance the Congressman would run for Mayor as an independent.

title: VIOLATION IS HINTED INFLORIDA TV AWARD
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 10 (UPI)A violation of a Federal conflict of interest regulation and White House intervention apparently were involved last year in the creation of a television channel in Panama City, Fla., The St. Petersburg Times said today in a copyright article.

title: Notes on People
description: On hand at the Johnson Space Center in Houston for the first full day of planning for the United StatesRussian space flight scheduled for 1975, Alexei Leonov, the Soviet cosmonaut who was the first man to walk in space, was asked if he anticipated any language problems on the joint mission. Turning to Brig. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, the United States mission commander, he asked, Translation please? General Stafford relayed the question. Cosmonaut Leonov displayed a wide grin. No problem English, he said.

title: 70,000 PATH Commuters Get Delay in Fare Increase
description: NEWARK, July 10 (AP)The 70,000 daily commuters who use the Port Authority Trans Hudson rail system have been spared a 20cent fare increase for at least another two weeks.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
2 Are Accused of Bilking W. & J. Sloane of $97,660
description: A grand jury indicted two men yesterday on charges of bilking W & J Sloane, Inc., the Fifth Avenue furniture concern, out of $97,660 in a scheme involving a bronze fourposter bed and other furniture.

title: Events Today
COURT APPROVES KAWAIDA TOWERS
description: NEWARK, July 10  Legal challenges to the construction of Kawaida Towers by North Ward residents were dismissed today by Superior Court Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman.

title: Hussein Flies to Britain
description: LONDON, July 10 (AP) King Hussein of Jordan flew ?? London today for talks ?? British Leaders on the ?? Eastern conflict, arms ?? chases and development aid.

title: Reginald Denenholz, 59, Dies; Long a Press Agent for Stage
description: Reginald Denenholz, a theatrical press agent for nearly four decades, died yesterday at his home, 130 West 47th Street, where he had been recuperating following abdominal surgery. He was 59 years old.

title: NO ONE IS ACCUSED IN LEAK ON BIAGGI
description: An official report has concluded that there is no basis to bring criminal charges against anyone known to be involved in the leak of Mario Biaggi's grandjury testimony.

title: Arrests in Light Bulb Theft
description: PITTSBURGH, July 10 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the arrest in Sharon of two men in connection with the theft of thousands of electric light bulbs valued in excess of $16,000.

title: GENOCIDE IS LAID TO LISBON'S ARMY
description: LONDON, July 10A Roman Catholic priest said today that he had received reports from Spanish missionaries in Mozambique of Portuguese Army massacres of Africans comparable to the My Lai killings in South Vietnam.

title: Haste in Eastern Europe
description: The rather synthetic good fellowship and less than fully credible mutual cordiality that President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev exhibited toward each other during the latter's visit here last month are apparently symptoms of a contagious diplomatic disease. At any rate Secretary of State Rogers seems to have developed a similar syndrome in his recent contacts with the two most unsavory of Moscow's satellites, East Germany and Czechoslovakia.

title: FESTIVAL SYMPHONY GIVES PARK CONCERT
description: On the standards of the normal concert experience, Monday night's program by the Festival Symphony Orchestra in Riverside Park approached the disastrous. It took concert officials some 50 minutes past the scheduled starting time to assemble their ramshackle portable stage, which delay in turn necessitated lopping off Mendelssohn's Italian Symphony at the end (it is promised for next Monday's concert, but at the expense of the Beethoven Seventh). The orchestra sounded underrehearsed and had continual trouble maintaining firm ensemble and intonation. The sound system was tinny, distorted and feedbackridden.

title: Market Averages
Advertising: Claimants Tee Off
description: The most confused consumer in the nation has got to be the golfer who looks to advertising to help him buy the longest ballthe golf ball that will go the farthest.

title: Records: Ivie Anderson
description: The nineteenthirties are now so far in the past that the sifting process of passing time has left Billie Holiday and Ella Fitzgerald and. Mildred Bailey as the obviously great female vocalists of the decade. But we are apt to forget that there was another singer who stood on the same levelIvie Anderson. She is not as well known as the others because almost all of her professional prominence was spent with Duke Ellington's band, singing, as a rule, one chorus of a song surrounded by solos and ensembles so fascinating that any other singer would scarcely have been noticed.

title: MITCHELL BELIEVES MEETING WAS TAPED
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) In a meeting at the White House, John D. Ehrlichman may have tried to jockey former Attorney General John N. Mitchell into a seat close to a hidden microphone, Mr. Mitchell told Senate Watergate investigators today.

title: MAINE POTATOES UP 40CENT LIMIT
description: The commodity spotlight swung to New York yesterday as the cautious traders on the huge Chicago grain, soybean and livestock markets awaited the Government's July crop report, which was issued after the close and contained few surprises.

title: Labor Department Prepares Charges in GasTank Blast
description: Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan said yesterday that his department was preparing civil citations and proposed fines against employers in connection with the gastank explosion on Staten Island last Feb. 10 in which 40 construction workers were killed.

title: Senate Excerpts From Mitchell's Testimony Before the oenate Committee on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Following are excerpts from a transcript of testimony of John N. Mitchell on the 17th day of hearings on the Watergate case today before the Senate Select Committee on to Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: Communist Leader Quits
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 (UPI) Dorothy Healey, 58 years old, longtime communist leader, resigned from the party yesterday, she said, because of its failure to allow dissent. Mrs. Healey was party chairman for Southern California for 20 years, until 1969, when she failed to win reelection after publicly opposing the Russian invasion of Czechoslovakia.

title: Despite Low U.S. Profile, Bruce's Diplomacy Is Making an Impact in Peking
description: PEKING, July 10Now we are in business, said David K. E. Bruce in his easy Virginia drawl.

title: New Sufferings Await Amalrik
description: Bonn, Washington, Paris  smiles, greetings, more smiles  hopes for peace and profitable trade. And in his own country, untelevised prisoners are educated by means of starvation; believers are kept from their prayers; forthright critics are put behind bars or cured of freethinking in psychiatric hospitals. Those once called enemies by the leadership are now called friends, while their own citizens who have spoken a daring or honest word are imprisoned or treated for their integrity and courage. Where are the bounds of a government's hypocrisy?

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 2 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 2 P.M.)

title: Rise in Milk Prices Looms as Upstate and Northern Jersey Producers Face Shortages and Mounting Costs
description: COBLESKILL, N.Y.Frank Ambrosano, a 40yearold dairy farmer, stood outside his barn next to a wagon filled with bales of rainsoaked hay. He looked out over a field of anklehigh corn, planted two weeks, after rain washed out his first planting, and a silo whose top had been blown off by high winds.

title: 6 Arrested in White House During War Protest Prayers
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) Six Roman Catholic protesters were arrested today when they knelt to pray during a tour through the White House. It was the third such incident in five days, all of them intended to protest the bombing of Cambodia.

title: A Problem for Khmers
description: In seeking a ceasefire in Cambodia, the Administration appears to be operating on the same faulty premise that has frustrated United States military efforts throughout Indochina for nearly two decades: the assumption that contending forces in the Indochina states are dominated and controlled by foreign influences and have relatively insignificant indigenous motivation or strength.

title: Regime Arrests Foes as Uruguay's Crisis Intensifies
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 10  The militarybacked Government and the opposition have hardened their positions, confronting Uruguay with her worst political crisis in decades.

title: Ervin Was Late
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) Senator J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, missed the start of the Senate Watergate committee's questioning of John N. Mitchell today because of heavy traffic. The start of today's hearing was delayed about 15 minutes because of the chairman's absence.

title: MUNITIONS BLAST KILLS 4 IN TEXAS
description: CLEBURNE, Tex., July 10 (UPI)A series of explosions ripped through a prefabricated blowout assembly bunker and a van loaded with hand grenades today at a north Texas munitions plant. Four persons were killed and 35 injuredmost of them women.

title: MITCHELL SAYS HE CONCEALED WATERGATE FROM NIXON TO PREVENT ELECTION DAMAGE; CHARGES MAGRUDER LIED, DISPUTES DEAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 10John N. Mitchell swore today that he had deliberately withheld information from President Nixon about the Watergate bugging, the coverup and White House horror stories to prevent any damage to the President's bid for reelection.

title: Search for Two Canadian Truce Aides Again Delayed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 (UPI)A search for the two missing Canadian truce obervers who disappeared in Communistheld territory on June 28 was delayed again today by continued disputes between Canadian officials and Vietcong representatives.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: About 150 sloganchanting cab drivers and owners taxi companies in Newark picketed City Hall yesterday to dramatize their opposition to city regulations. Members of the Airport Taxi Management Association were demonstrating against a city regulation to go into effect on Aug. 1 ordering all Newark cabs over five years old off the road, no matter what their condition.

title: McDaniel Loses Duel in His 1st start Since 67
description: CHICAGO, July 10It wasn't Lindy McDaniel's fault the Yankees tumbled out of first place tonight.

title: Transit Accord in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, July 10 (AP)Negotiators representing the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority an transit workers announced today that an agreement had been reached on a new contract. The agreement came last night in negotiation sessions held since an eightday transit strike ended last month.

title: Shipping/Mails
Colson Private Talks Reported Broken Off
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Charles W. Colson, former special counsel to President Nixon, has refused to give the Senate Watergate committee staff any further interviews before his public testimony, knowledgeable Senate sources said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Justice Samuel R. Rosenberg ruled yesterday in the State Supreme Court in Manhattan that despite the Ithaca Medical Center's loose, careless, improper management, the methadone clinic was a necessity and must stay open. Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz had sued to have the center, a methadone clinic at 177 East 84th Street, closed as a public nuisance. Justice Rosenberg said a reduction in cases from 500 to 300 addicts a week and a hopedfor increase in police patrols of the area would both reduce the number of addicts in the area and consequently the residents ire.

title: MODERATES LOSE SEMINARY BOARD
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 10 Conservatives in the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod took majority control today of the governing board of Concordia Seminary of St. Louis, the largest Lutheran  and the third largest Protestant  theological school in the country.

title: ALLIED CHEMICAL SHOWS HIGHER NET
description: John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, reported yesterday that operating income before extraordinary items for the second quarter was $29.4million, or $1.07 a share, up 47 per cent over operating income of $20million, or 73 per cent a share, a year earlier.

title: DUNBAR MLAURIN, LAWYER, IS DEAD
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y. July 10Dr. Dunbar S. McLaurin, a lawyer, an economist and an organizer of the Freedom National Bank and of the Universal National Bank, blackcontrolled financial institutions in New York, died today at his home, 7 Frederick Place. He was 53 years old.

title: 2 Mitchell Friends Cautious on Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 Two friends cited by John N. Mitchell as witnesses to the last toplevel talks on the Watergate bugging plan said today they were not yet prepared to resolve the dispute between Jeb Stuart Magruder's testimony that the raid was approved and Mr. Mitchell's insistence that he had vetoed it.

title: Marchi Takes a Political Tour of Israel
description: JERUSALEM, July 10State Senator John J. Marchi of New York, the Republican candidate for Mayor, toured northern Israel today as part of an unabashedly political pilgrimage.

title: 6 NIXON LAWYERS HELP ON DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 10At least a halfdozen lawyers are working at the White House on President Nixon's defense in the Watergate case, either full time or nearly full time.

title: 54 Story Hotel Expected to Revitalize Times Square
description: New York's newest and most spectacular hotel moves closer to construction with the expected announcement of the project today by Mayor Lindsay and architectdeveloper John Portman of Atlanta.

title: Car Airbag Aids Driver
description: DETROIT, July 10 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation said today that another one of its airbagequipped cars was involved in an accident, resulting in no serious injury to the lone occupant. John R. Beauchamp, 34 year old, of suburban Livonia, suffered only minor facial abrasions after his leased 1973 Chevrolet Impala hit a parked car on Detroit's West Side last night.

title: Kawaida Towers Gets Court Approval
description: NEWARK, July 10  Legal challenges to the construction of Kawaida Towers by North Ward residents were dismissed today by Superior Court Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman.

title: U.S. Planes in Cambodia Strike Communist Troops Near Capital
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 10 (UPI)American planes flew heavy air strikes north of Phnom Penh today against rebel troops pushing Government forces closer to the capital.

title: Nearby Golf Results
Article 1  No Title
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 10 (AP)Daniel Wolcott, the Chief Justice of the Delaware Supreme Court, died here tonight, apparently of a heart attack. He was 63.

title: No Longer Any B for Balanced
description: PARISThe Soviet Union's diplomatic offensive has now succeeded in altering a basic Western and, above all, United States precondition that has hitherto underlain the complex of EastWest negotiations.

title: Roundup: Evans Steals. Aaron's Act
description: Darrell Evans, Atlanta's young third baseman, lists stamp collecting as his principal hobby, according to the Baseball Register. He might have added homerun hitting. He shares the National League lead with 25.

title: Brownouts Can Befuddle Computers Wits
description: The computer, despite some indications to the contrary, is not human but it shares with man a lack of tolerance for hot, humid weather as well as brownouts and blackouts.

title: Looking Backward
description: Like a major earthquake, the Watergate scandal has transformed the political scene. But politicians, like other human beings, prefer to look backward and cling to old ways. The members of the Senate Rules Committee, in particular, seem unable to comprehend how much the ground has moved under their feet.

title: 6 Cardinals Join Secretariat
description: ROME, July 10 (UPI)Pope Paul VI appointed six additional members today to the Vatican Secretariat far nonChristians. They include an American Cardinal, John J. Wright, head of the Vatican Congregation for the Clergy and former Bishop of Pittsburgh.

title: M'NEIL UNIT IS GIVEN CONTRACT BY SOVIET
description: A $10million contract under which the Cleveland Crane and Engineering division of the McNeil Corporation of Akron, Ohio, will provide the materials handling system for the foundry of the Soviet Union's huge Kama River truck plant was announced yesterday.

title: Something's Up in Orange County
description: BERKELEY, Calif.A senior citizen of my acquaintance who lives in a mobile home park in the FullertonSanta AnaWhittier area of Orange County, the heartland of Western American conservatism, has just provided me with an unexpected reaction to the Watergate affair.

title: Dr. Clark Defended By Vice Chancellor On Holding 2 Jobs
description: The vice chancellor of the City University said yesterday that he found no fault with Dr. Kenneth B. Clark for being on the payroll of the Metropolitan Applied Research Center at the same time that he is receiving a salary as a fulltime faculty member of the university.

title: People in Sports: Beliveau Turns Down W.H.A.'s Million
description: Jean Beliveau has turned down a reported milliondollar deal to play for the Quebec Nordiques of the World Hockey Association. Beliveau, 41yearold vice president and director of corporate relations for the Montreal Canadiens, met with Paul Racine, president of the Nordiques, and Jacques Plante, the general manager, to discuss what he called a very generous and attractive offer.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
Denmark Lifts Bank Rate
description: COPENHAGEN, July 10 (Reuters)Denmark today raised her bank rate by one per cent to 8 per cent. The new bank rate will be effective tomorrow, The Central Bank announced. The rate had stood at 7 per cent since last Oct. 3.

title: STATE SENATORS WIN MARYLAND PRIMARY
description: BALTIMORE, July 10 (AP)Two Eastern Shore state Senators won their party nominations today in a primary race preceding a special election to fill the seat of Representative William O. Mills, a Repubican.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may he translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb,

title: Panel May Take Action On Getting Nixon Files
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Samuel Dash, the chief counsel of the Senate's Watergate committee, said tonight that the panel might consider taking some action in reply to President Nixon's refusal to supply voluntarily certain White House documents that the committee has asked for.

title: Nixon Names Stever Head Of Federal Science Council
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  President Nixon designated H. Guyford Stever, director of the National Science Foundation, today as chairman of the Federal Council for Science and Technology.

title: PSYCHOSURGERY CURBED BY COURT
description: DETROIT, July 10Experimental psychosurgery may not be performed on persons confined against their will in state institutions, even when such a person's consent is formally obtained, a special threejudge panel ruled today in Wayne County Circuit Court.

title: MRS. THOMAS J. O'BRIEN
description: Mrs. Margaret Hess O'Brien, wife of Thomas J. O'Brien, business manager of the New York Lithographers and PhotoEngravers Union, Local 1P, died yesterday at Westchester Square Hospital, the Bronx. She was 60 years old and lived at 1670 Metropolitan Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Football Transactions AMERICAN CONFERENCE
Mouton Rothschild Finally Gets Rating as One of the Best
description: Chateau Mouton Rothschild has been made a first growth. To the uninitiated, this might sound like a medical problem. But in the wine world it marks an event of considerable significance.

title: Patient in Silks: Wind Her Up, She Talks
description: Red Smith

title: District 1 School Board Votes to Curb Fuentes
description: The six recently elected members of the District 1 School Board on the Lower East Side have voted to curb the powers of Luis Fuentes, the controversial District 1 superintendent, and are looking into the legality of his employment contract, which has two years to run.

title: YOUTH CORPS FUND IS ORDERED FREED
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The Labor Department announced today that $239million in nationwide Neighborhood Youth Corps funds had been released to the states to provide summer jobs for poor youths.

title: Frederick M. Warburg, 75, Dies; Investment Banker, Sportsman
description: Frederick M. Warburg, the investment banker, sportsman and philanthropist, died yesterday of heart disease at Memorial Hospital in Winchester, Va., near Snake Hill, his horse and cattle farm in Middleburg. He was 75 years old and had been a partner in Kuhn, Loeb & Co., one of the country's most powerful banking firms, since 1931.

title: Those Extras on Gatsby Set Weren't Doing It for the $20
description: NEWPORT, R. I.  These rich are very starstruck, said one of the technical men, herding what he called the socials off the set of The Great Gatsby.

title: Doctors Phone Experts On Boy With Snake Bite
description: An 8yearold Queens boy was in Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center yesterday recovering from a snake bite that had physicians telephone all over the country for advice from doctors more familiar with that type of injury.

title: BOY, 13, SHOT DEAD NEAR BRONX PARK
description: A 13yearold Bronx boy was shot to death last night while walking with a friend near his home two blocks from Bronx Park. The police were questioning members of known youth gangs in the belief that the slaying may have been gangrelated.

title: Half the Detectives To Go to Precincts Under Cawley Plan
description: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley said yesterday that he was planning a major reorganization of the detective force that would put about half of the detectives back in the precincts and make detectives responsible for the first time to uniformed precinct commanders.

title: Sterilization Consent Not Given, Father Tells Kennedy's Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Lonnie Relf, his face screwed up for a moment in concentration, fixed Senator Edward M. Kennedy with a sadeyed stare and murmured: I didn't want it done and I'm still upset.

title: Next Urban League Chief
description: The board of directors of the New York Urban League has selected John Murray, vice president in charge of public affairs for RKO General Television Division, as the league's presidentelect. Mr. Murray will succeed Charles E. F. Millard, president of the CocaCola Bottling Company of New York, on Jan. 1.

title: Fire Fatal to Infant Laid To Playing With Matches
description: A 4yearold girl playing with matches set off firecrackers and a fire that killed a 10monthold baby girl in an apartment at 5 West 137th Street yesterday morning, the police reported.

title: FRANKLIN TO PAY 7% ON SAVINGS ACCOUNTS
description: The Franklin National Bank announced yesterday that it would pay 7 per cent interest on longterm savings accounts of at least $1,000 and a minimum of four years maturity. In addition, the bank said that it would raise the interest rates that it pays on other consumertype thrift accounts, in line with the new rate ceilings announced last Thursday by the Government, up to a maximum of 6 per cent. In Jersey City, the First Jersey National Bank also announced fouryear, 7 per cent accounts.

title: Health Aides Seek AllVolunteer Blood Donor System
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The Administration's top health ofnational blood policy designed ficials announced today a new national blood policy designed to achieve an allvolunteer donor system, probably within two years.

title: London Stage: In a Worst Season, Acting Is Superb
description: LONDON, July 10  New York and London have one great thing in common. With a monotony that can only be termed regular, every, year they both enjoy, as much as possible, their worst theater season ever. This is one of the few constant things in a changing world.

title: TV Fare in Alaska Is Long Delayed, Yet Is Popular
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska  The televisonprogram guides in the newspapers look just the same the familiar shows on the same nights at about the same hours as they would be in New York or Little Rock or San Diego. But it is not the same here, not by a week or two or three.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
U. S., ISRAEL WIN 12 MEDALS EACH
description: TEL AVIV, July 10 (AP)The United States, which finished second to Israel in thel number of medals won at the last Maccahiah Games, renewed the rivalry with the host country again today, each picking up 12 medals on the opening day of the 1973 games.

title: Places to Take the Children
Baseball Transactions
Senate Votes to Expand F.T.C. Power
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The Senate voted today to expand the powers of the Federal Trade Commission to combat unfair methods of competition by businesses.

title: People in Sports: Beliveau Turns Down W.H.A. s Million
description: Jean Beliveau has turned down a reported milliondollar deal to play for the Quebec Nordiques of the World Hockey Association. Beliveau, 41yearold vice president and director of corporate relations for the Montreal Canadiens, met with Paul Racine, president of the Nordiques, and Jacques Plante, the general manager, to discuss what he called a very generous and attractive offer.

title: FORD, WITH 218, IKE GOLF VICTOR
description: ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 10Mike Ford, 22yearold member of a noted Westchester golfing family, won the Ike tournament today by two stfokes.

title: MITCHELL SAYS HE CONCEALED WATERGATE FROM NIXON TO PREVENT ELECTION DAMAGE; CHARGES MAGRUDER LIED, DISPUTES DEAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 10John N. Mitchell swore today that he had deliberately withheld information from President Nixon about the Watergate bugging, the coverup and White House horror stories to prevent any damage to the President's bid for reelection.

title: SECRETARIAT BID for MARK FOILED
description: BALTIMORE, July 10 (AP)The Maryland Racing Commission refused today to change Secretariat's official time in the Preakness Stakes and thus deprived the star colt a clean sweep of speed records in his Triple Crown winning performances this spring.

title: Jenkins Rides 4 Victors At Show in Lake Placid
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 10  With $40,000 in prize money on the line, it was inevitable that Rod Jenkins would put in a firsttime appearance at the Lake Placid horse show.

title: Young Republicans Urged To Uphold Nixon on Inquiry
description: ATLANTA; July 10 (AP) The nation's Young Republicans were urged today to take a formal stand supporting President Nixon in the Watergate controversy and declaring that the Republican party is not the party of Watergate.

title: MAN SHOT TO DEATH IN BROOKLYN BATTLE
description: A 25yearold Brooklyn man was fatally shot and another man was wounded last night when a shootout erupted between two Hispanic groups outside a social club in the Wililiamsburg section, the police reported.

title: Market Place
description: More than 80 firms have failed since a new Government agency began operations designed to protect investors visvis brokers back in 1971

title: Major League Box Scores
PRICES CONTINUE TO RISE ON AMEX
description: Continuing the rally that began late Monday, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market closed higher yesterday.

title: TREVINO BANKING ON WIND FACTOR
description: TROON, Scotland, July 10If the wind blows out of the west, particularly the northwest, Lee Trevino could well win his third successive British Open golf championship.

title: Ridgway Hails Weicker for His Moral Courage
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The office of Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. made public today the text of a letter from Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, retired, former Chief of Staff of the Army, praising the Connecticut Republican for having the moral courage to restate Americanism at its best.

title: WALDHEIM WANTS TALKS ON MIDEAST
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 10Secretary General Waldhelm said today that public debate in the Security Council would not lead to an immediate solution of Middle Eastern problems.

title: New Neighbor
description: The United States has a new neighbor, the independent state of the Bahamas. Scarcely fifty miles off the Florida coast, visited by a million and a half American tourists every year, the Bahamas have ties almost as intimate with this country as Canada and Mexico, though obviously on a lesser scale. It is important to both the Bahamas and the United States that these ties remain close.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: CHASINS TO DIRECT NEW U.S.C. PROJECT
description: Abram Chasins, author, musician and former music director of WQXR, radio station of The New York Times, has been appointed director of a twoyear music and drama educational program for KUSCFM under the auspices of the University of Southern California's School of Performing Arts.

title: DOLLAR UP AGAIN AS LINES OF CREDIT for U.S. INCREASE
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The Federal Reserve Board announced today an increase of more than 50 per cent, to about $18billion, in its swap credit lines with other central banks under which it can borrow foreign currencies for use in defending the dollar's value in foreignexchange trading.

title: Tovar Gets Kneecap Surgery
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP) Cesar Tovar, infielderoutfickler of the Philadelphia Phi!lies, had a piece of fat removed from his kneecap today. Dr. Philip Marone, the team's orthopedic surgeon, operated on Tovar expecting to find a bone chip, but instead found the fat. Tovar will be out two weeks.

title: TV Pictures Dimmed At Watergate Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI)Television pictures of the Senate Watergate hearings were dimmed today when an overloaded circuit breaker twice blinked out the highintensity lights, forcing cameras to broadcast a darker than normal picture.

title: Television
description: SENATE WATERGATE HEARINGS TELEVISION

title: It UNIT REVISES DATA ON REFINING
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The merican Petroleum Instituteds Dparently stung by widespread accusations that the oil industry as brought about the gasoline Is shortage to push prices up, has If revised the statistical definions used in making weekly re orts on oil refining.

title: Argentine Guerrillas Report Executive Freed for Ransom
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 11 (UPI)A Marxist guerrilla organization said yesterday that it had kidnapped John R. Thompson, a Firestone Rubber Company executive, and that the company had paid a $3million revolutionary tax to free him.

title: General Gets New Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) Maj. Gen. Winant Sidle, Army chief of information, was named today to become the first commander of the newly created Seventh Reserve Readiness Region and deputy commander of the Fifth Army, based at Fort Sam Houston, Tex. His successor at the Pentagon will be Brig. Gen. L. Gordon Hill, now deputy chief of information, who has been selected for promotion to major general.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The General Signal Corporation reported yesterday that it had received three contracts $1125million for production of with a combined value of lautomatic controls, hydropneumatic braking systems and other components for use in Ithree major transit projects. The largest contract was from the New York City Transit Authority for automatic signaling and braking equipment along 7.5 miles of the Jerome Avenue subway in the Bronx. The other contracts were awarded by the BoeingVertol Company and tahe General Electric Com

title: Dollar Pinching U.S. Tourists in Europe
description: BONN, July 11You can see it in the face of the American tourist at Frankfurt Airport as he changes $100 for something under 240 marksbarely enough for two nights at the InterContinental Hotel, if he has the courage to deny the porter a tip.

title: Stereotypers Halt Parleys On a Newspaper Contract
description: Stereotypers Union No. 1 yesterday announced that it had broken off negotiations with the Publishers Association of New York on a new contract to replace the one that expired last March 30.

title: NIXON SEES CABINET TO DISCUSS PHASE 4
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 President Nixon conferred with his Cabinet today on the shape, of Phase 4 of the wageprice stabilization program.

title: Second Siamese Twin Dies After Surgery to Save Life
description: A second Siamese twin girl, who underwent emergency surgery July 7 to save her life, died yesterday at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: Young Republicans Choose Floridian as New Chairman;
description: ATLANTA, July 11, (UPI)Young Republicans elected today a new national chairman who described the G.O.P. as a party drawn together by the adversity of the Watergate scandal.

title: POLL FINDS PARENTS DUBIOUS ON POLITICS
description: Few parents would care to see a son enter into a politickil career, largely because they consider politics to be too corrupt, the Gallup poll reported yesterday.

title: Kerr, a Black, Is Voted Head of Police After 4 Rejections by Newark Council
description: The Newark City Council yesterday confirmed the ap. pointment of Lieut. Edward L Kerr as Police Director of this ity, making him the first black to gain that post. The vote was 5 to 3.

title: Britain Repays Loans
description: LONDON, July 11 (Reuters)The 3.5 million ($8,924million) of unsecured fiveyear loans made by the Bank of England to a number of commodity traders to cover losses arising from the 1967 sterling devaluation have now been repaid.

title: Chess. Stein's Death Deprives Soviet Of One of Its Top Players
description: SICILIAN DEFENSE

title: G.E. PROFITS ROSE 13% 9120 QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday new highs in sales and earnings fort the second quarter and first half. Reginald H. Jones, chairman, said the gains continued to be broadly based.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Eileen Farrell Sings at Park Concert
description: With Eileen Farrell on hand to close a concert with the lmmolation scene from Utterdammerung, nothing much can go wrong, and nothing much did go wrong on Tuesday night as the New York Philharmonic opened its ninth season of free programs in the city's parks.

title: Virginia Man in Fine Spirits After a Heart Transplant
description: RICHMOND, July 11 (AP)George Cavich, a 41yearold bachelor, was sitting up in bed today within 12 hours after surgeons at the Medical College of Virginia gave him a new heart.

title: ExP.O.W. Faces Divorce
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., July 11 (Al')  The wife of the first prisoner of war to step off the first plane from Hanoi has filed for divorce. She is Joan Prof ilet, wife of Navy Capt. Leo Profilet. She cited irreconcilable differences in her petition, filed I yesterday in Santa Clara County Superior Court.

title: GOOD TWIST FIRST IN OPEN JUMPING
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 11 Cheeca Farm's Good Twist; sped round the course without a fault and beat six rivals in a jumpoff to win the open. jumper time class today at the Lake Placid horse show.

title: Alleged Mafioso Convicted In Carlo Lombardi Murder
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., July 11  Nicholas Mussolino was found guilty today of murder and attempted murder in the killing last year of Carlo Lombardi, a New York underworld figure, and in the shooting of Lombardi's girl friend, Elizabeth Brices.

title: DWIGHT STONES HIGH JUMPS 76
Steam Coal Find Reported
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 (Reuters)  Early indications from widely spaced drilling in an area of South Australia indicate the presence of medium to low grade steam coal, the Utah Development Company has advised its parent company. Utah International Inc.

title: 7 Hospitals Get Federal Grants for Cancer Victims
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The National Cancer Institute announced today the funding of seven demonstration projects designed to make the best treatment available to more patients suffering from three types of cancer.

title: A.
description: Harold Frank, senior vice president and general merchandise manager of Abraham & Straus, Brooklyn, will join Macy's New York as executive vice president, merchandising, it was announced yesterday. Replacing Mr. Frank at Abraham & Straus is Julian Seeherman, who is now a senior vice president and general merchandise manager of all home furnishings.

title: White House Declines to Submit Data Sought by Nader in Suit on Milk Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, July 11At the direction of President Nixon, White House lawyers declined today, on the ground of executive privilege, to disclose the contents of nearly 100 official documents sought by Ralph Nader in a lawsuit to roll back the price of milk.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: 2 Hearing.Aid Companies Agree to Curb Practices
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Two hearing aid manufacturers and distributors have reached agreement with the Federal Trade Commission, but three cthers have denied complaints that the companies limit competition through restrictions on dealers, the commission announced today.

title: York Kildea, Bank Official, Former Music Professor
description: York Kildea who retired early this year as a regional vice president of the Chemical Bank because of illness, died yesterday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 63 years old.

title: Papadopoulos Acts to Spur Enthusiasm for July 29 Vote
description: ATHENS, July 11 (UPI)Premier George Papadopoulos sent more than 20 Cabinet ministers throughotit the country today to drum up enthusiasm for the July 29 referendum which Greeks are asked to approve the abolition of the monarchy and the establishment of a republican government with Mr. Papadopoulos as its president.

title: S. E. Sobeloff, ExSolicitor General, Dies.
description: BALTIMORE, July 11Simon E. Sobeloff, former Solicitor General of the United States and Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, died this morning at the University of Maryland Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Midwest Governors Elect Exon and Conclude Meeting
description: RAPID CITY, S.D., July 11 (AP)  The Midwest Governors Conference concluded today with the electon of Gov. J. James Exon of Nebraska asi chairman and selection of Ely, Minn., as the site of next year's conference.

title: U.S. Army Chief in Pacific Talks to Thieu and Khiem
description: SAIGON, South Vietn.arn, July 11 (UPI)The commander of American Army troops in the Pacific met today with President Nguyen Van Thieu wad Premier Tran Thien Khietrt. in talks that presumably included the forthcoming halt in American bombing of Cambodia.

title: Disposal of Illicit Paper Is Charged Here
description: An alleged conspiracy to dispose of more than $18million in stolen securities and counterfeit bonds was described here yesterday in a Federal indictment aginst a reputed Mafia lieutenant, a British lord's son and an Austiian who said he had contacts in the Vatican.

title: Undersea Safety Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, introduced today a bill requiring Federal safety standards for undersea research facilities such as the miniature submarine in which two men died last month, Mr. Hollings, chairman of the Oceans and Atmosthere Subcommittee, said that the bill was aimed to prevent recurrence of the incident in which the Sea Link became entangled in the lines of a sinket ship off the Florida coast.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Trial of Rescuer Is Postponed

title: $3.06.Billion Is Authorized By Congress for NASA
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)  Congress sent to President Nixon today legislation authorizing up to $3,064,500,000 for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Gimbel Officer to Retire
description: Samuel Nags, executive vice president and treasurer of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., announced Tuesday that he planned to retire as an officer of the company on January 31, 1974. However, he has agreed to be retained by Gimbel's as a consultant. Mr. Nass who joined the company in 1929, became treasurer in 1935 and executive vice president in 1968.

title: CHILE TELLS OF PLOT TO KIDNAP ALLENDE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 11 (AP)Rebel army soldiers who took part in an abortive insurrection late last month originally had planned to kidnap President Salvador Allende Gossens to spark a coup, an official report by the Chilean Army said today.

title: Thailand Reports Smashing International Narcotics Ring
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 11 (AP)  Thai authorities have broken an international drug syndicate with the arrest in Bangkok of three of its leaders, Pemier Thanom Kittikachorn announced today.

title: DR. EDWARD OMENN
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., July 11 Dr. Edward Omenn, a dentist, died Saturday in Tokyo, where he was attending a professional convention. He was 62 years old and lived at 65 Athens Road.

title: 2D DAY ON STAND
description: WASHINGTON, July 11John N. Mitchell, under crossexamination laced with incredulity, clung today to his sworn declaration that President Nixon had been shielded from knowledge of the Watergate breakin and its coverup.

title: COURT BARS CHANGE IN CONTRACTED FEES
description: TRENTON, July 11 (AP)A state appeals court ruled today that the Mount laurel Municipal Utilities Authority could not revise the fees it charged a housing developer because the fees had been set by contracts with private companies that were taken over by the authority.

title: Concurrent 3d Fire Tour Ruled a Violation of Code
description: The Fire Department's proposed concurrent platoon system creating a third tour of duty between 3 P.M. and midnight violates the Administrative Code, Justice Nathaniel T. Ifelman ruled in State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: 122 Killed as Brazil Jetliner Crashes Just Short of Paris Airport
description: SAULXLESCHARTREUX, France, July 11A Brazilian jetliner crashed in flames just short of Orly Airport here today, killing 122 of the 134 persons ahoard.

title: Jersey Court Bars Ending of Gasoline Franchise Without Cause
description: TRENTON, July 11The State Supreme Court ruled today that oil companies could not terminate franchise agreements with gasolinestation operators without good cause.

title: STREETCUT RULE DELAYED BY COURT
description: State Supreme Court Justice Nathaniel T. Heiman yesterday temporarily barred the enforcement of a fiveday old city law meant to prevent utility companies from digging up streets in the business district during the daytime.

title: 2 Doze Off in Driving Test
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 11 (UPI)Two college students taking part in a $200,000 state governmentfinanced study co the causes of singlecar accidents fell asleep at the wheel of their test vehicle. An observer in the vehicle, which has dual controls, took over and avoided an accident. The dozing drivers said that the possibility of their being involved in an accident had been what the study was all about.

title: Ford Raises Retail Price Of Its Capri Models 6.2%
description: The Ford Motor Company announced that it had increased the suggested retail price of its Capri models imported from West Germany by an average of 6.2 per cent, effective with vehicles invoiced with dealers yerterday.

title: 3 New Yorkers Are Feared Dead in Coast Plane Crash
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 11  Three vacationing New Yorkers including a police detective assigned to the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, were among five presumed victims in the crash of a private plane near here, the Santa Barbara County sheriff's office said today.

title: Dissident Lutherans Protest Majority Position on Bible
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 11 (AP)  Dissident Lutherans marched today in protest of their church's adoption of new creedal definitions demanding a literal view of the Bible.

title: Brezhnev Calls for an End To Tension in Middle East
description: MOSCOW, July 11 (Reuters) Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, today welcomed recent moves toward Improved relations in the world and called for an end to the tension in the Middle East.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: In Hyannis, Mass., next Tuesday the first in a series of public auctions of what is probably the most extensive private collection of waterfowl and shorebird decoys in the country will be held at the Richard A. Bourne Co., Inc. galleries.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: In Hyannis, Mass., next Tuesday the first in a series of public auctions of what is probably the most extensive private collection of waterfowl and shorebird decoys in the country will be held at the Richard A. Bourne Co., Inc. galleries.

title: Teamsters Sign Winery Pact Once Held by Chavez Union
description: MODESTO, Calif., July 11 (AP)  The world's largest winery, Gallo Brothers, signed a contract with the International Brotherhood of Teamster today for field workers who had been represented by the United Farm Workers Union.

title: Falling Power Line Kills 3
description: CARLETON, Mich., July 11. (AP)Three men were killed and a fourth injured today when a high voltage power line fell at a nearby carnival, the police said. The line fell when a roller coastertype ride cut a power line, the police said. An employe setting up the ride was killed by the charge, another was injured and two others died when they tried to remove the line from a tent,! the police said, and were electrocuted.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: The ABC's of Energy Reform
description: WASHINGTONVarious experts recently proposed assorted remedies for the oilauto energy crisis. Dr. Arthur Burns of the Federal Reserve has suggested a horsepower tax; Secretary Morton has urged the states to lower their speed limits, and Secretary Shultz has proposed voluntary car pools. My quarrel with such proposals is that they assume the petroleum crunch will diminish if we merely exercise a little selfrestraint and make some modest adjustments in our automobile etiquette. All the available facts deny the validity of such assumptions.

title: Picasso Grandson Dies; Drank Poison in April
description: ANTIBES, France, July 11 (UPI)Pablito Picasso, 24yearold grandson of Pablo Picasso, died at La Fontanne Hospital today three months after he tried to kill himself, reportedly because he had been turned away from the painter's home.

title: Satellite Launched By Russians Hints A Manned Attempt
description: MOSCOW, July 11  The Soviet Union launched today communications satellite that might be part of plans to renew the manned space program soon.

title: Cost of General's Tour Estimated at $100,000
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (Reuter)sThe retiring Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. John Ryan, is taking an aroundtheworld tour with his wife that could cost the Government $100,000, a member of Congress charged today.

title: Ballet: Pillar of Fire
description: Great ballets thrive with great casts and survive the less inspired; it is a mark of their breeding. Antony Tudor's Pillar of Fire is such a ballet. On Tuesday evening, American Ballet Theater presented it at the State Theater with a highly mixed cast.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Smith Overcomes Mexican, 63, 62; Borg, Orates Win
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 11 (UPI)  Two crowdpleasers swung into action today in the $50,000 Swedish tennis championships as topseeded Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., and Bjorn Borg, Swedish teenager, won their matches.

title: Vietcong Reject Saigon Call In Paris for Secret Talks
description: PARIS, July 11 (UPI)South Vietnam called on the Vitcong today to begin immediate secret talks on the country's political future patterned after earlier ceasefire negotiations. The Communists refused, saying the proposal was an old American gimmick.

title: City Planning U nit Acts to Speed Building of Times Square Hotel
description: The City Planning Commission Chairman, John E. Zuccotti, announced yesterday that, to expedite the construction of 2,000room hotel in the Times Square area, he has scheduled an Aug. 1, public hearing on applications for special permits.

title: Egyptian Arrives in Soviet
description: moscow, July 11 (UPI) Hafez Ismail, the national security adviser of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, arrived here today to begin what he said was a review of SovietEgyptian relations with Soviet leaders. It is his second trip to Moscow in five months.

title: Palestinians Plead Innocent In Trial on Cyprus for Raids
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 11 (AP)Seven young Palestinian guerrillas, accused of armed raids against Israeli targets in Nicosia on April 9, pleaded innocent today at the opening of their trial.

title: Excerpts From Mitchell's Testimony Before the Senate Committee on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 at a transcript of the testimony Following are excerpts from to of John N. Mitchell on the 18th day of the hearings on the Watergate case today before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential his Campaign Activities: his

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Hours are given In Eastern Daylight Time.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Mental Patients Return at 28% Rate

title: Mrs. Houghton Sets Wedding
description: Mrs. Elizabeth McCall Houghton and Walker 0. Cain, an architect, are to be married July 27 in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: A Teacher's Pets Earn Their Degrees
description: Never mind, one of these days we will make it, said Claire Andrews after she walked out of the ring at the Kenilworth dog show last week at the Fairgrounds in Durham, Conn. The we referred to the Providence schoolteacher and her Irish setter, Ch. Kimberlin Kyrie.

title: Wife Asserts Mitchell Is Completely Honest
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI)Mrs. John N. Mitchell, saying that she was phoning from Washington, where I'm staying with my husband, told United Press International early today that the former Attorney General was being completely honest with Senate Watergate investigators.

title: Drug Agents Charged in Another Raid
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 11A 27yearoldsalesman filed $1.4million damage suit toda3 against Federal narcotics agent! who allegedly ransacked hi: home, terrorized him and helc him incommunicado in a St Louis jail for more than three days in April before he was re leased without being chargec with any crime.

title: Dollar Pinching U.S. Tourists in Europe
description: BONN, July 11You can see it in the face of the American tourist at Frankfurt Airport as he changes $100 for something under 240 marksbarely enough for two nights at the InterContinental Hotel, if he has the courage to deny the porter a tip.

title: National League
description: Thursday, July 12, 1973

title: Sterilization in Alabama
description: Charges that two minor black girls were involuntarily sterilized by a federally funded family planning clinic in Montgomery, Ala., merit the intensive investigation they are reportedly receiving from three Federal agencies and a Senate subcommittee.

title: PROXMIRE BELIEVES NIXON WILL SURVIVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today there is absolutely no prospect whatever of impeachment of President Nixon.

title: NHAT BRILLIANCE FIRST IN SPRINT
description: What Brilliance scored with axpected refulgence in the 27,500 Astoria Stakes at aqueduct yesterday. The crowd pf 19,619 made Joseph Lacroix's filly the oddson choice in the 67th running of the famous stakes, and she scored by a length at a return of $3.40 for $2.

title: Bonn Aide Flies to U.S. for Talks With Nixon on European Security
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 West Germany's Foreign Minister, Walter Scheel, flew to Washington this evening for talks all day tomorrow with President Nixon and other senior Administration officials on questions of European security, particularly on the forthcoming EastWest conference on troop withdrawals.

title: At Least 2 Killed by Blaze In Paris Department Store
description: PARIS, July 11 (Reuters)At least two persons were killed when fire swept through a department store here tonight.

title: FOOD COMPANY SET TO BUY TOY CONCERN
description: The Consolidated Foods Corporation, which is continuing to expand its consumer nonfood operations, announced yesterday an agreement in principle to acquire the Knickerbocker Toy Company,. Inc., for stock valued at about $25million.

title: Colson Asserts President Did Discuss Quitting Post
description: DETROIT, July 11 (UPI) Despite White House disavowals, President Nixon did raise with his family the question of resigning from the Presidency, a former Presidential aide, Charles W. Colson, asserted today in an interview with The Detroit News. Mr. Colson said Mrs. David Eisenhower, the President's daughter, was correct in saying the subject had been raised in a family discussion.

title: Lunchtime Crowds and Music Make Wall Street a Midday Carnival
description: The pursuit of money is the daily occupation of the almost halfmillion people who spend their weekdays working in Manhattan's southern tip, except for lunch hours, when they abandon cool cash and mercurial stocks for the midday carnival on the hot streets and parks.

title: Cardinal Zerba, Law Expert At the Vatican, Dies at 81
description: ROME, July 11Cesare Cardinal Zerba, a scholarly prelate who served for 40 years in the Roman Catholic Church's central administration, died at his home here today of diabetes. He was 81 years old.

title: Senators Reject ExEnvoy For Asian Affairs Position
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today rejected the Nixon Administration's nomination of an Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs because of his close identification with Washington's policies on Indochina.

title: Diplomat With Aggressive Style
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Thursday, July 12G. McMurtrie Godley, whose nomination as an Assistant Secretary of State has been rejected by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is variously regarded by those who knew him in Laos either as a paternalistic bull in a china shop or as an oldfashioned and effective bulwark against Communism. Ambassador Godley, who ended his fouryear tour in Laos in April, is remembered by Government officials, fellow ambassadors and newsmen as a diploniat whose style at Times seemed more in keeping with the belligerent tone of the Theodore Roosevelt Administration than with the modern era of cramped caution imposed by confrontation between nuclear Man in the News

title: F. ROYAL GAMMON
description: F. Royal Gammon, retired assistant vice president of salesEastern area for the United States Steel Corporation, died Saturday in Cuernavaca, Mexico, where he had been living. He was 77 years old and had formerly lived here and in Cedarhurst, L. I.

title: Murder Charges Lodged
description: CINCINNATI, July 11 (UPI) John Henry Lamar, 37 years old, of Cincinnati, was charged with firstdegree murder in the street slaying yesterday of Wallace Smith, 44, a former world lightweight champion. Mr. Smith was shot to death when he tried to intercede between a man and woman arguing on the street.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Study Slated in Tennis Dispute

title: Hogan Expands Vote Scheme Inquiry
description: The office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that it had enlarged its inquiry into an alleged votesiphoning scheme by Republican Assembly aides and that evidence would be presented to a grand jury.

title: Bridge:
description: Bridg,. Gold and Red Points Are Lure Ce In Tomorrow's Fun City Play

title: Government Is Accused of Poor Enforcement of Laws Against Sex Bias
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 Witnesses before a Congressional committee charged today that the Government was doing a poor job of enforcing laws that forbid discrimination against women and even failed to live up to some of these laws itself.

title: SCHOOL ELECTIONS ARE HELD On L.I.
description: Voters in the Connetquot school district in Suffolk County yesterday defeated a budget of more than $18million in one of the school elections on Long Island.

title: Futures Trading Planned In Silver Coins in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, July 11 (Reuters) The International Monetary Market of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange plans to expand into silvercoin futures, Everette B. Harris, president, announced today.

title: LOCAL BANK POSTS 7.9% SAVINGS RATE
description: The National Bank of North America announced yesterday that it would pay 7, per cent for an effective annual yield of 7.9 per cent, taking into account hourly compounding of intereston fouryear savings accounts with a minimum deposit of $5,000.

title: DWIGHT STONES HIGH JUMPS 761/2
description: MUNICH, Germany, July 11 (UPI)  Dwight Stones, a 19yearold Californian who won an Olympic bronze medal here last year, returned to the Olympic Stadium tonight and soared 7 feet 6 inches on his third attempt at that height to set world high jump record. Using the flop technique, Stones bettered Pat Matzdorf's record, set July 1, 1971, by a quarterinch and brought the crowd of 25,000 to its feet.

title: Family Visits in September Proposed at Korea Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 11 South Korea proposed today that the two Koreas exchange visits of divided families in September to pay hOmago at their ancestors graves on the traditional Korean. Thanksgiving Day, which falls on Sept. 11 this year.

title: Indians Free Tuition Upheld
description: DENVER, July 11 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit ruled yesterday that Indians should continue to receive free tuition at Fort Lewis College, The Colorado Legislature had passed a law in ?.971 that said Indiansl were no longer entitled to free tuition because the school hacil moved off what had been Federal land.

title: VATICAN ASKS HALT TO SACRAMENT SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Vatican has asked the world's Roman Catholic bishops to halt the experimental practice in which children receive their first communion before making their first confession.

title: CONKLIN IS AGAINST 35C FARE ON AGENDA
description: State Senator William T. Conklin, Republican of Brooklyn and the deputy majority leader, yesterday argued against adding the city's transitfare problems to the agenda of the special session of the Legislature, stating that there was insufficient time to formulate longrange plans to maintain the 35cent fare.

title: Caldera to Meet Castro
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 11 (UPI) President Rafael Caldera of Venezuela will meet with Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba in Havana in the last half of September, Government sources said here today. President Caldera will stop over in the Cuban capital while flying from Caracas to the United Nations in New York.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Con Edison Is Told to Pay for Food Spoiled in PowerSystem Blackouts
description: The Consolidated Edison Company was ordered by the State Public Service Commission yesterday to set up a system for paying any electricity customer for food spoiled by lack of refrigeration during lengthy blackouts coused by its distribution system.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: New Soft Drink Marketed
description: Carbonated and noncarbonated types of a new highenergy citrusflavored soft drink, known as Energade, developed by its subsidiary, the Cott Cord poration, are now being marketed by National Industries, Inc., in an 11state area.

title: $100,000 Tennis Match: Bobby Riggs vs. Mrs. King
description: With his s's whistling through his teeth and his hair colored from a bottle, 55yearold Bobby Riggs, the antifeminist tennis player, agreed yesterday to meet the

title: Moscow and Peking Buy 105 Million Tons of Grain
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 The Agriculture Department released figures today showing that the Soviet Union has already ordered more than 7.85 million metric tons of United States grain for delivery by next summer. Last year, the Soviets imported 19 million tons of American grain plus 1 million tons of soybeans.

title: Insurance Unit Upheld On Its RateFormula Rule
description: TRENTON, July 11  The State Insurance Department's requirement that insurance companies include their corporate investment profits in their ratemaking formulas was upheld today by the State Supreme Court.

title: Blown Fuse Cuts Program
description: BOSTON, July 11 (AP) Network feeds to six New England area television stations were interrupted for 43 minutes last night when a fuse blew in a power panel at the New England Telephone Company's Franklin Street building downtown. A spokesman for the company said the cause was not known.

title: 2D DAY ON STAND
description: WASHINGTON, July 11John N. Mitchell, under cross examination laced with incre dulity, clung today to his sworr declaration that President Ni on had been shielded ironknowledge of the Watergate breakin and its coverup.

title: Personal Finance
description: Motorists who drive through Madison, N. J., can often see deer contentedly grazing on the clipped green grass or in clumps of woods on a 450acre estate. At a time when few private deer parks remain, it is a sight worth slowing down to watch.

title: Senate Confirms Seevers
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Gary L. Seevers to be a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. He has been a special assistant to the chairman, Herbert Stein.

title: MRS. M. P. GOODFEt.LOW
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 Mrs. Florence Haeussler Goodfellow, wife of Col. M. Preston Goodfellow, retired, who was deputy director of the Office of Strategic Services during World War II, died of a stroke here yesterday at Doctors Hospital. She was 83 years old.

title: One Day on the Front Line in Cambodia: Bombs, MachineGun Fire and Exhaustion
description: PREK THLENG, Cambodia, July 11Their voices are unemotional. Their faces show nothing but exhaustion. Their hands move swiftly and professionally as they wrap the body of a dead comrade in green plastic sheeting. They have had a lot of experience.

title: Lunchtime Crowds and Music Make Wall Street a Midday Carnival
description: The pursuit of money is the daily occupation of the almost halfmillion people who spend their weekdays working in Manhattan's southern tip, except for Lunch hours, when they abandon cool cash and mercurial stocks for the midday carnival on the hot streets and parks.

title: U.S. Says Beach Repairs Can't Start Here Until 74
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 To the skepticism and chagrin of the Lindsay administration and members of New York City's Congressional delegation, officials of the Army's Corps of Engineers said today that it could not begin to halt the beach erosion of the Rockaways before next summer, at the earliest.

title: 74 BENEFITS RISE IS SIGNED BY NIXON

title: Thai Head Discounts Halt In Training for Cambodians

title: Film: 'Cahill, United States Marshal' Stars Wayne
description: The air must be cleared. The truth can no longer be covered upno matter who is hurt. Someone must state the facts: John Wayne has reached the awkward age, which, in his case, is an official 66. When Shirley Temple became 12, there were those who said her career was over. She was too old for repeats of "The Little Colonel," but not yet old enough for politics. However, she survived, as I am sure Wayne will, but how is anybody's guess.Certainly not in things like "Cahill, United States Marshal," a tacky Western of drowsy pace in which Wayne plays the title character, a tough old law officer whose two sons, Danny, 17, and Billy Joe, 12, assist in robbing a bank when dadas is his wontis away chasing badmen. The lads, whose mother is dead, feel deprived of dad's company.It's not outrageous that Wayne should play a United States marshal or that he should be the father of two such young sons (though someone felt obliged to insert a line into the script to the effect that "we had our children late in life"). What has become increasingly difficult to accept is Wayne's peculiar physical presence.Unlike most people as they age, Wayne is not shrinking and shriveling, nor is he becoming in any way decrepit. Instead, he is swelling up like a balloon. He is not only getting bigger and rounder, he is also getting visibly lighter. He sort of floats through this movie with no heft whatsoever. He gets shot several times, and stabbed once, but he seems less indestructible than puncture-proof, automatically and wondrously self-sealing. He is a plastic man."Cahill, United States Marshal" was directed by Andrew V. McLaglen and written by Harry Julian Fink and Rita M. Fink. Perhaps recognizing the new limitations of their star, they spend a good deal of time trying to turn a conventional Western into a children-in-peril movie. Danny (Gary Grimes) and Billy Joe (Clay O'Brien), basically decent kids, of course, are terrorized by the robbers they once helped, in situations borrowed from "Tom Sawyer" freely but without wit or true sentiment.In addition to Wayne and the boys, the cast includes George Kennedy, who plays a clean-cut, nicely mannered badman, and Neville Brand, who plays Wayne's sidekick, a half-breed Indian and an excellent tracker who talks like a social worker. "You got a bad feeling about your Paw," he tells young Danny, "because he's not home every night." A line like that would have sent Huck Finn hooting back to the raft. Danny, however, begins to melt.
