description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 14  Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico, ihas urged the General Services Administration to make surplus silver available to Indian tribes whose jewelry projects are suffering from the silver shortage caused by the price freeze.

title: Food: On Beanbag Alley in Summit
description: SUMMITThe Speedy Gonzalez Superette, a food store in the heart of this affluent, attractive Union County community, is in its fourth year of serving a growing Cuban, Puerto Rican and West Indian population hereabout. Its owner, Rufino Gonzalez, a Cuban, admits that the name of the store may be a gag, but he insists that the business he has been doing is for real.

title: Phoebeann Jaeger to Wed
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 14Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. Jaeger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phoebeann Jaeger, to Anthony S. Prevlti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Previti of New Britain. A December wedding is planned.

title: M'Daniel Remembers Chicago
description: Lindy McDaniel, the Yankees 37yearold relief pitcher, won't soon forget July 10, 1973, but for remembering dates, how about May 24, 1959?

title: It's Cricket as Well as Kosher
description: GANEI TIKVAH, Israel, July 14.There was a moment, halfway between lunch and the ritual tea break, when looked as if the most improbable entry in the Maccabiah Games was about to pull off the most unlikely upset.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: opportunity is a measure of Pete Davis's concern for amateur tennis and the purpose for which his father donated the cup.

title: METHADONE CITED IN RISING DEATHS
description: Methadone poisoning appears to have caused more than three times as many deaths in 1972a total of 175as in 1971, according to a special committee of physicians appointed by the Chief Medical Examiner.

title: Panel Offers a Plan To Save Farmland
description: TRENTON  The Blueprint Commission on the Future of Agriculture in New Jersey has recommended the preservation of onefifth of the state's land for farming.

title: Edith Gallatin, W. H. Boone Jr. To Be Married
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 14 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Gerry Gallatin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Post Gallatin, to William Harrison Boone Jr., son of Mrs. William H. Boone of Plandome and the late Dr. Boone.

title: De Jesus Tops Lampkin in 12 Rounds
description: Esteban DeJesus of Puerto Rico won the American lightweight title by unanimously outpointing Ray Lampkin of Portland, Ore., in 12 rounds at the Felt Forum yesterday.

title: Dr. Berlzss Has Nuptials
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., J,uly 14  Dr. Elizabeth Ann Berliss, a fellow in child psychiatry at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Paul H. Saenger, who is with the division of pediatric endocrinology at the Cornell University Medical College.

title: Golf Course on Nixon Estate Will Cost Businessmen $200,000
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14A group of California businessmen who built a course for President Nixon on the grounds of his San Clemente estate disclosed today that their gift would amount: to at least $200,000, including its upkeep, by the time he leaves the Presidency.

title: VILLAGE DEBATES JAIL'S DEMOLITION
description: Two community groups opposed to the demolition of the former Women's House of Detention in Greenwich Village held a block festival yesterday to raise funds to publicize their efforts.

title: How George McGovern won and lost it
description: Thinking about the McGovern Presidential campaign now is like standing in an amusement park room of funny mirrors. Events that seemed small then are now enlarged, sometimes grotesquely so; matters that seemed of major proportion then are now miniaturized. Aside from the attempts, to put it as politely as possible, to tinker with the Democratic party's nominating process and the election, by the Nixon White House, consider some of the other truisms of not long ago about the 1972 election: McGovern, unlike Nixon, did not appear competent, organized, in command of his staff, and this was unPresidential. McGovern, unlike it was never clear exactly who, acted like a politician when he dumped Eagleton. McGovern was inconsistent: he changed his mind

title: Ballet: Tudor Evening
description: Although it is 23 years since Antony Tudor actually created a new work for the American Ballet Theater, his works still play an enormously important part in the company's repertory. Friday night at the New York State Theater, Ballet Theater gave a special Tudor program, consisting of a revival of Undertow, not seen in New York for some years, together with Romeo and Juliet and Pillar of Fire.

title: Hackensack Is Recalled As Hostile, Racist Town
description: HACKENSACKA former Hackensack resident who served as the first black executive assistant in the White House had mailed, in a recently published book, the ravages of discrimination here in the nineteentwenties.

title: Fiscal Plan to Revivify Newark Offered
description: NEWARK, July 14An economic development program costing about $650million, more than half to be publicly financed, was recommended for Newark today as essential to utilizing the potentials of New Jersey's largest metropolitan center and preventing its becoming the first American city to die.

title: Robbery Suspect And a Policeman Hurt in Shootout
description: An offduty police officer and a suspect in a holdup were wounded yesterday in an exchange of gunfire in a Queens liquor store.

title: MARISA REGULES, 48, ARGENTINE PIANIST
description: Marisa Regules, Argentine pianist, died Friday in St. Vincent's Hospital, after a long illness. She was 48 years old and lived at 45 East 89th Street and in Buenos Aires.

title: Miss Suzanne T. Marquard Wed to Paul A. Vernaglia Jr.
description: The Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Suzanne T. Marquard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Marguard of New York and Quogue, L. I., to Paul A. Vernaglia Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Vernaglia of Winchester, Mass. The Rev. Dr. James Seth Stewart performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Dunston Plans Bridal Aug. 25
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Fisher of the Bronx, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Fisher's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Dunston. to James A. McLaughlin, son of Mrs. James Treacy of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Battery Park City to Begin Building, But Cautiously
description: After seven years of promises and controversy, Battery Park City, the milelong city within a city on the lower West Side, will, its developers hope, begin taking shape in October.

title: Legislature Is Challenged For Stopping the Clock
description: SANTA FE, N.M., July 14A lawsuit has been filed in Santa Fe District Court challenging the New Mexico Legislature's practice of stopping the clock to circumvent the legal deadline for adjournment fixed by the New Mexico Constitution.

title: NARCOTICS AGENTS TO BE DISCIPLINED
description: CHICAGO, July 14  The Federal Drug Enforcement Adm. intstration has called two of its narcotics agents to Washington for disciplinary measures following a traffic incid. ent near here in which one irate agent reportedly drew his gun and pointed it at a truck that was delaying traffic.

title: Suburbia Learning To Fight Town Hall
description: YORKTOWN, N. Y.James Walsh is fighting Town Hall this summerjust as he did last summer and the summer before. In fact, he reflected, sipping tonic water on a hot afternoon by Mohegan Lake, I probably spend more time with McKinney's book on town law than I do with my wife.

title: Outside Directors
description: What is the tie that binds Aileen Mehle, the society gossip columnist; Dinah Shore, the singer; the Rev. Theodore Hesburgh of Notre Dame University and the Rev. Leon Sullivan of Zion Baptist Church in Philadelphia; Mrs. McGeorge Bundy and Mrs. Whitney Young Jr. and Harry Gangloff, an engineering student at Drexel University?.

title: Odd Fossil Found in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, July 14 (UPI)Soviet Georgian scientists have found in the Caucasus the fossilized remains of a three millionyearold animal with the snout of a horse and fangs, lass reports. It belonged to group of ungulates that vanished from geological records several tens of millions of years ago, the press agency said.

title: Carol Albert Bride Of Gerald J. Havlin
description: RYE, N. Y., July 14The marriage of Miss Carol Jane Albert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Albert of Rye, to Gerald Joseph Havlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Havlin of Yonkers, took place here this afternoon.

title: Even Troop Cuts Are on The Menu
description: WASHINGTONThe American dollar taking another dive on the European Money marts, the American President sipping champagne with the Russian Communist leader and, above all, the pollen of suspicion toward all Administration activities spreading from Watergate.

description: On Sept. 24, one of the largest and most resplendent passenger ships in service will sail from New York for Southampton and a dubious future.

title: Katherine Marshall Married To John Greenman, Reporter
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 14  The marriage of Miss Katherine Kellogg Marshall to John Francis Greenman took place this afternoon at the home here of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Marshall, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Almon C. Greenman of AixenProvence, France.

title: Oldest British Resident Marks 112th Birthday
description: LONDON, July 14 (Reuters) Miss Alice Stevenson received a unique present of 112 carnationsone for every year of her lifeon lig birthday this week.

title: Sun's Glows Brings Ray of Hope to Shore
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH  The hot spell last week lured the first big crowds of the season to the North Jersey shore, but boardwalk concessionaires doubt that they can recover financially from what has been described as a horrible June.

title: Book Fair Is Set For Asbury Park
description: ASBURY PARKThe 12th annual Asbury Park Book Fair will be held here July 2528. Although some of the offerings originally sold for as much as $20, all books will be sold at the single price of 25 cents.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: A sharp rally in the international value of the dollar buoyed the stock and bond markets early last week, but the dollar subsequently faltered and the other markets gave up most of their gains.

title: Australian
description: HACKENSACK  An Australian shire secretary, or city manager, has journeyed 9,135 miles from his home in the State of Victoria to Northern New Jersey. He is not here on vacation, but, rather, to study Federal funding to local governments.

title: Amusement Park Upsets Neighbors
description: To Harold Glantz, the expansion of the Great Adventure Amusement Park in the WhitestoneCollege Point section of Queens has resulted in added fun and relaxation for thousands of youngsters and adults. But to nearby residents, it has only created problems.

title: Olga Korbut's Style Not Cramped Yet
description: CH IASSO. Switzerland, July 15 (AP)Olga Korbut, the Soviet Union's triple Olympic gold medalist, is free to continue her tricky gymnastic performances, at least until November, Arthur Gander, president of the International Gymnastics Federation, said today.

title: RAIL COMPROMISE IS INCHING AHEAD
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 There was a faint scent of compromise in the air last week between the Nixon Administration and Congress over a possible colution of the Northeast rail crisis.

title: CITY IS SUSTAINED IN WELFARE CASES
description: The city has been winning 43 per cent of its claims to halt or reduce grants to welfare clients In controversial fair hearings, which recipients can demand before any changes can be made in their status.

title: Man Killed in Subway.
description: A 75yearold Brooklyn man, tentatively identified as Charles Kiessell of 1284 Halsey Street, was killed yesterday when he fell or jumped from the southbound platform of the 14th StreetCanarsie subway line at the Halsey Street station Southbound service on the line was suspended for more than an hour while emergency crews removed the body from the tracks.

title: FACULTY PROTEST IN SAN FRANCINI

title: No Decency Left
description: WASHINGTON  A vicious attack by a 33yearold Democratic lawyer, bedazzled by his moment in the limelight, upon the only witness to come before the Watergate committee with clean hands  an upright, respected, gentle human being of 59 named Richard Moore  is proof that the purpose of the Ervin committee is not to bring out the truth but to bring down the President.

title: Barbara Bluestone, Weaver, Wed
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 15Miss Barbara Louise Bluestone, a professional weaver with a studio in Copenhagen, Denmark, was married here today to Jorgen Jensen, an archeologist and curator of the bronzeage department at the Danish National Museum there. Rabbi Jerald Bobrow performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George C. Bluestone.

title: Japan Payments Show A $960Million Deficit
description: TOKYO, July 14Japan's balance of payments in June registered a large, $960million deficit, the fourth successive monthly deficit but down from May's record $1.2billion of red ink, the Finance Ministry announced over the weekend.

title: Nixon Parley Urged by Inouye, Weicker
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Two members of the Senate Watergate committee, one al Democrat and the other a Republican, urged President Nixon today to meet voluntarily with the panel to discuss allegations that he and some of his top aides had been involved in covering up the Watergate bugging plot.

title: Canadian Truce Officers Are Released by Vietcong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July I6Two Canadian officers of the Internetional Commission of and Supervision, who had been held captive by the Vietcong for 17 days, were freed yesIerday and returned to by helicopter.

title: Rogers Backs Tokyo on Pacific Talks
description: TOKYO, Monday, July 16 (AP)Secretary of State William P. Rogers endorsed today Premier Kakuei Tanaka's plan for a genera 1 AsianPacific peace conference, and he listed ways in which oilconsuming nations such as the United States and Japan can cooperate.

title: Support of Dollar Urged By French Finance Chief
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (Reuter)The dollar's value has sunk too far and the United States Government should act to bolster it, the the French Finance Minister, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, said today.

description: (UPI).Topseeded Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., easily defeated the defending champion, Manuel Orantes of Spain, 64, 61, 76, today to win the Swedish open tennis championship. For his victory, Smith received $8,000. BAASTAD, Sweden, July

Details of the pact will be announced Wednesday after meeting of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers local.

title: Cambodian River Folk Cling to Their Half of Town
description: PREK KDA1VI, Cambodia, July 14Picture a town whose two halves are separated by a river. Then picture enemy troops holding one half, sitting on the eastern bank with their guns pointing at the other half about 400 yards away on the opposite bank.

Dr. Howard Lee performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Breakers Hotel. The bridegroom's previous maryiage ended in divorce.

Jay Mechutan, Mike Engel, August Boehm, George Tornay, Marcel Friedmann, all of New York, and Bob Ryder of Caldwell, N.J., led by 27 international match points after 16 deals of a scheduled 64.

title: Port Did $23Billion Trade in 1972
description: Foreign trade through the port by ship and air boomed last year. Data made public by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey showed that in 1972 the port handled a record volume of foreign trade by weight as well as by value. Close to 61 million tons of goods sailed or flew in and out of the port, and the value of these shipments came close to $23 billion. The volume of oceanborne cargoes rose 14.3 per cent over the 1971 levels to 60.5 million tons; the volume of air cargo was up by 21.7 per cent over 1971 and reached the 421Port Notes

title: S.E.C. TAPE CONTROL OPPOSED BY KOLTON
description: The American Stock Exchange favors prompt disclosure of all securities trades, on a consolidated ticker, but firmly opposes the bid by the Securities and Exchange Commission to directly control the ticker tape's operation, according to a statement by Paul Kolton, Amex chairman, issued over the weekend.

title: Papal Infallibility Dogma Assailed Here
description: The Vatican's recent reaffirmation of papal infallibility has placed future ecumenical conversations between Roman Catholics and other Christian bodies in dire jeopardy, according to Canon Walter D. Dennis of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine (Episcopal).

title: Rafe Botts Wins Golf
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 15 (UPI)A former tour pro, Rafe Botts of Los Angeles, became the first black man to capture the Southern California Professional Golfers Association match play championship, beating Tommy Jacobs on the 35th hole of a scheduled 36hole match today. Winning this tournament means a lot to me, said the 36yearold Botts. I feel it's a major event and it's my first big win.

description: LONDON, July 15 (AP)Tom Weiskopf, winner of the British Open yesterday, was given hero's sendoff today by hundreds of cheering fans as he left London Airport for New York.

description: LOS ANGELES, July 15 (AP) Mathew G. Bender, halfbrother of President Nixon's wife, Pat, died yesterday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

Rabbi Hyman Levine performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple.

title: Koch Rallies for 1Up Victory In TransMississippi Golf
description: HUTCHINSON, KAN., July 15 Gary Koch, four holes down with 11 to play, rallied to tie the match, then sank a 16foot eagle putt on the 35th hole today to score a 1up victory over Guy Cullins of Denton, Tex., to win the 70th annual TransMississippi amateur golf tournament.

title: Paris: Attractive Festival du Marais
description: PARIS, July 12Festivals are brief and brilliant revolts staged by provincial towns against the lethargy or moroseness of their ordinary life. This perhaps is why Paris has never really been a city of festivals. With one significant as well as durable exception: The Festival du Marais. The 1973 festival, from midJune to midJuly, will have played to some 75,000 spectators. Inaugurated in 1962, the Festival du Marais has attracted roughly half a million people. The special nature of this festival must have become quite clear to anyone who, for instance, hied himself to the Place du MarcheSainteCatherine, at 6:30 P.M. on July 2, to see a young company performfree of chargeBilora a comedy by Ruzante, a Renaissance Italian playwright, and Moliere's farcical The Enforced Marriage.

title: Ideological Detente
description: At the Helsinki conference of European foreign ministers, Western spokesmen properly put much emphasis on the importance of free communications across the boundaries of the world's ideological blocs. In this same period, Congress has been considering the budgets of the Voice of America, Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe, the chief mechanisms by which this country does communicate with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. By its budgetary decisions, Congress will show whether not it places the same value on international communication that Secretary of State Rogers and other Western spokesmen did in Helsinki.

title: SCATTERED FIGHTING GOES ON IN CAMBODIA
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 15 (AP)Fighting between Cambodian Government forces and Communistled insurgents entered the fourth week today near Kompong Tuol, 10 miles south of the capital, as the insurgents attacked scattered Government outposts.

description: DETROIT, July 15 (AP)A lengthy eighth inning in which the California Angels scored five runs may have cost Nolan Ryan an American League strikeout record today but the stiffness the fireballing righthander developed during the wait wasn't enough to prevent his second nohitter of the season.

description: NEW DELHI, July 15 (UPI)Ten persons were killed and 24 others injured today when mud from heavy rains slid down a hill in a village near the Tibetan border in Uttar Pradesh state, about 450 miles northeast of here, according to the Press Trust of India.

description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) Representative Ella T. Grasso, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that she would cosponsor legislation to create bipartisan Federal elections commission to keep elections clean.

description: WASHINGTON, July 15 A recently completed report by staff members of the National Institutes of Health recommends prohibit:n,g any experiments that would prolong the life of an aborted fetus once its ultimate survival was judged to be impossible.

description: At the behest of City Councilman Carol Greitzer, a police car has been assigned to patrol exclusively in Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily to increase police visibility and protection in the daylight hours.

description: PARIS, July 15The Belgian international airline Sabena has just ordered 10 American airplanes instead of 10 French ones in a dramatic illustration of the way the devaluation of the dollar is beginning to help American sales overseas.

description: MILWAUKEE, July 15 (UPI) Bob Shaw, pitching coach of the Milwaukee Brewers, resigned today because of ha! he called restraints imposed on me by General Manager Jim Wilson.

title: Ohrenstein to Sound the First Note in Beame s Overture to the Left
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beanie will start shoring up the left this week with a series of endorsements by liberal Democratic officeholders who had opposed him in the Democratic mayoral primary. The Controller's biggest catch is scheduled to be State Senator Manfred H. Ohrenstein of Manhattan, who has been a political twin of Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, the Liberal party's mayoral candidate. For years, they have been public allies  although private rivals  and two of the leading lights in the chaos that passes for West Side reform politics.

I., July 15 (UPI)The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers ratified threeyear contract today with the Fairchild Republic Division of Fairchild Industries here, a company spokesman announced The union's 850 members will receive a 35 to 50centsanhour raise over three years. The old contract expired this morning.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 13The few Americans who visit Iraq these days are likely to find the people friendly and curious about the United States despite the interruption in official relations between Baghdad and Washington since the Middle East War of 1967.

description: WASHINGTON, July 15How many other communities across the country may, like Duluth, Minn., have possibly hazardous quantities of asbestos in their drinking water?

title: Watergate and the Law: Scandal Prompts a Call in Profession for the Teaching of Ethics
description: Whatever else the Watergate scandal ma Y mean, wherever else it may lead in debate and reform, the case has already raised disturbing questions for the legal profession. And one of the main questions, as many see it, is why there seems to be such a gap between law and lawyers.

title: UNIT SAYS PRESIDENT SHOULD SET TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI)A group of business and academic leaders proposed today that the President be empowered by Congress to raise or lower personal and corporate income taxes by as much as 10 per cent at his discretion.

title: AMEN II CAPTURES HOLLYWOOD DERBY
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 15 (AP)Frenchbred Amen 11 captured the $150,000 Hollywood Derby today, beating 10 rivals in a race whose format was copied after England's Epsom Downs feature for 3yearolds.

title: Van Morrison, Cult Hero, Carves a Blues Groove
description: Enter the cult hero: Van MDrrisott and band were Philhamonic Hall on ThursIlay, allayed before the idolatrous who had packed the house to hear him do his Ray Charlesoriented blues and to crash through, harsh and gritvoiced as ever, some of his own fine material.

title: Dietz Triumphs In 3 Elite Races In National Rowing
WOMAN HELD IN TYING OF CHILDREN TO BED
description: A 24yearold woman was arrested in the Bronx early yesterday about 12 hours after she had allegedly tied her three children to a bed and left them unattended, the police reported.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SOUTH ORANGE, July 15Usually, the only football players who can see their mistakes on instant replay are professionals. But at Seton Hall's evening football clinic tomorrow through Friday, young players from grade school through senior year of high school will have a chance watch their techniques minutes after a completed play.

title: Spitz'sFeat Is Bettered At Tel Aviv
description: TEL AVIV, July 15 (AP) Anita Zarnowiecki, Sweden's swimming star, raced today to her seventh gold medal at the ninth Maccabiah Games.

title: Botswana to Build Road to Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 15  American engineers have arrived in Botswana to construct a 186mile highway that will link the country's developing heartland with Black Africa.

title: Hussein Back From Britain
description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 15 King Hussein of Jordan and his Premier, Zaid al Rifai, returned home today after fiveday visit to London and talks with Prime Minister Heath. An official statement said that the two leaders had discussed the ArabIsraeli conflict and economic cooperation between Britain and Jordan.

title: Utilizing U.S. Agripower
description: The collapse of the dollar is threatening to force a stoppage of the world economy. Overnight, America's failure to hold the line for the dollar has spread a sense of alarm that world prosperity is about to follow the plunging dollar and the plummeting New York stock market into paralysis.

title: Transportation Bond Issue Expected
description: Politicians predicted privately yesterday that some sort of transportation bond issue would emerge from the special state legislative session that start; a week from today. Publicly they called on Governor Rocke feller to disclose precisely what he had in mind.

title: Roundup: McCovey Clouts 2 Homers To Reach Total of 401 on Career List
description: Willie McCovey, a big man with a history of doing things in a big way for the San Francisco Giants, clouted his 400th and 401st majorleague home runs yesterday to become the 15th player to reach that total. Willie Mays and Mel Ott were the only Giant players to hit more homers.

title: A Con Ed Rate Proposal Attacked as Inflationary
description: A $161millionayear rate increase for Consolidated Edison electric customers has been proposed by a state Public Service Commission examiner, with opponents contending that a new concept included in the proposal would anticipate and thereby accelerate  continued inflation.

title: Firehouse Stoned in Bronx After Dispute Over a Car
description: A Bronx firehouse was stoned late Saturday night and early yesterday morning after a dispute between a fireman and neighborhood youths who he said were sitting on his parked car.

title: DOLLAR WEAKNESS AIDS EXPORT SALES OF U.S. AIRPLANES
description: PARIS, July 15The Belgian international airline Sabena has just ordered 10 American airplanes instead of 10 French ones in a dramatic illustration of the way the devaluation of the dollar is beginning to help American sales overseas.

title: Boom Seen in Overseas Phoning
description: Richard B. Nichols, overseas vice president for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long lines department, meets here today with Nanubu Itano, executive vice president for external communications of Kokusai Denshin Denwa Company, Ltd., of Japan.

title: ARTHUR DORSEN
description: Arthur Dorsen, retired president of the Jaystone Drug Cornpany and president of the Empire City Pharmaceutical Association when it was formed in 1963, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 263 West End Avenue

title: Ryan, ExMet, Hurls 2d NoHitter
description: Nolan Ryan of the California Angels pitched his second nohitter of the season yesterday when the former New York Mets righthander defeated the Tigers, 60, at Detroit. Ryan threw his first nohitter on May 15 against the Kansas City Royals.

title: Auto Union Talks To Begin This Week Amid Complaints
description: DETROIT, July 15 (AP)The United Automobile Workers and the nation's three biggest auto makers will start contract talks this week amid an intraunion flareup over bargaining issues. Talks with General Motors start tomorrow. Talks with Ford and Chrysler begin during the next two days.

title: Captain Asserts 8 P.O.W.'s Caused Beatings by Captors
description: ATLANTA, July 15 (UPI)A former prisoner a war said today that eight American P.O.W.'s whose charges of collaboration with the enemy were dropped by the Pentagon caused the beatings of several of their fellow prisoners by the North Vietnamese.

title: Democrats to Start Work On Party's New Charter
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., July 15 (AP)Work on drafting a new charter for the national Democratic party will begin next weekend, when 100 Democratic leaders from across the country meet here.

title: Namath Passes Tests, Then Leaves for Coast
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI, July 15 (UPI)Joe Namath reported to the Jets training camp at Hofstra University today for his physical examination and received permission to leave the preseason training camp to fulfill some television commitments.

title: HENRY A. WHALEN
description: Henry A. Whalen, who organized the United Veterans of the Bronx Memorial Day parades on the Grand Concourse for 20 years, died Friday in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 56 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: 18 BOATS UNBEATEN IN LARCHMONT SAIL
Athens Warns Hoarders That They Risk Losses
description: ATHENS, July 15Greeks who are hoarding goods and foods to stave off the effects of inflation were warned by the Government today to desist or face economic ruin.

title: Bolshoi Students Take In Town  But Their Work Comes First
description: They have been doing what most firsttime visitors to New York dotaking the cruise around Manhattan Island, going to Radio City Music Hall, visiting the Bronx Zoo, getting a glimpse of the inside of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Garrett, to Head S.E.C., Adds a Will to Expertise
description: CHICAGO, July 15A man who once fancied himself as another Perry Mason in the making but became one of the most widely respected corporation lawyers of his generation is President Nixon's choice to head the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: City to Require Food Handlers To Take Its New Hygiene Class
description: Citing the recent rise in health violations reported at city restaurants, the Health Services Administration announced yesterday that it would require restaurants to send foodhandling etablishments to send representative to a special course in environmental sanitation the agency was starting today.

title: Nixon's Progress Good
description: President Nixon's doctors said yesterday that he was making good progress in his recovery from viral pneumonia at Bethesda Naval Hospital. Details on Page 19.

title: Drive for Pyle Memorial
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 15 (AP) The state Veterans of Foreign Wars organization has joined drive to preserve the Dana, Ind., birthplace of Ernie Pyle, the World War H correspondent, as a state memorial.

title: United Farm Workers and Food Chain Clash Over GrapesandLettuce Issue
description: SPARTA, July 15This rural town in Sussex County has become the focal point in a tug of war between New Jersey supermarkets and the United Farm Workers over grapes and iceberg lettuce.

title: Heavy Storm Brings 1.40 Inches of Rain To City in Morning
description: A severe thunderstorm drenched the metropolitan area early yesterday, arousing residents from their slumber but causing little other disruption of the Sunday morning routine except in some scattered localities.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Someone will buy it and wear it to go out, remarked Stephen Burrows as the model showed his baremidriff pajama In the mixture of colors that has become his sigiature. The top, knotted a.; center front, is gold on one side, teal blue on the other, and has a red inset t the back. The pants are ironze and, though the outit is meant for lounging around the house or even sleeping, there's really no good reason why it shouldn't be worn in public.

title: Coins Attract InvestorsAnd Investigators
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15A lot of the California money that used to go into the stock market is now being invested in silver coins and is supporting a new, rapidly growing industry.

title: PARKSHELL MISHAP ALTERS MUSIC DATES
description: Because of an accident involving the portable concert shell that moves from borough to borough for the New York Philharmonics summertime concerts in the city's parks, two programs in Central Park and one in Staten Island have been added to the schedule. These programs will replace some performances originally scheduled in borough parks.

title: The Claridge in Jersey Ordered to Shut Down
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 15 (AP)The Claridge Hotel, at the Boardwalk and Park Place, has been ordered closed because it lacks emergency exits.

title: JOHN J. QUINN DEAD A STATE POLICE AIDE
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 15 John J. Quinn, who retired in 1970 as deputy chief inspector of the New York State Police, was pronounced dead today in St. Agnes Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 91 Sterling Avenue.

title: A Con Ed Rate Proposal Attacked as Inflationary
description: A $161millionayear rate increase for Consolidated Edison electric customers has been proposed by a state Public Service Commission examiner, with opponents contending that a new concept included in the proposal would anticipate and thereby accelerate  continued inflation.

title: 4 DIE, 20 INJURED IN 2 AUTO CRASHES
description: Two separate traffic accidents claimed four lives and injured 20 persons yesterday in the metropolitan area.

title: Length of Military Data Fire Tied to VaultLike Structure
description: ST. LOUIS, July 15 (UPI)Fire officials said today the vaultlike construction of the giant United States Military Records Center, designed for security, was the major reason the building burned out of control for two days.

title: Mrs. Margaret Shack ford Dies; Helped Settle Refugees in U.S.
description: Mrs. Margaret Whitney Gillespie Shackford, who helped resettle more than 28,000 refugees in the United States for the United Presbyterian Church, died Saturday of cancer in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 65 years old and lived at 501 West 123d Street.

title: City Museum Seeks Historical Items, but No Shawls Need Apply
description: If you can contribute a 50yearold Teddy bear that's in good shape, men's wear from Colonial or early Federal times, or almost anything at all that dates back to New Amsterdam, you will be warmly welcomed by the Museum of the City of New York.

title: NEW POST LIKELY FOR RUCKELSHAUS
description: WASHINGTON, July 15William D. Ruckelshaus, who resigned last week as acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has been asked to take the post of Deputy Attorney General, according to informed sources within the Justice Department.

title: U.S.Israeli Air Fare Set
description: TEL AVIV, July 15 (AP) Israel's national airline, El Al, announced an agreement today with the United States Civil Aviation Board for a $385 roundtrip tourist fare between New York and Tel Aviv for groups of 10 or more persons during the off season.

title: Saigon Beggar, 10, in Tears: No Money Mother Will Beat Me
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15  Nhan is nearly 3 years old, but she is too weak to stand on her spindly legs. She sleeps most of the day, lying half naked on the grimy concrete sidewalk, oblivious to the flies that cluster on the open her head.

title: Amex to Start Up Trading in Stock Options
description: The directors of the American Stock Exchange voted quietly last Thursday to dip their toes into the hot new stock optionsputs and callsmarket.

title: A Start on Energy.
description: The Administration is inching forward in its perception of the energy crisis facing this country; at least it falling no further behind the rapidly evolving public awareness.

title: Miss Kentucky Is Black
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 11 (AP)  Miss Kentucky 1973 Lyda Lewis, 24 years old, oi Louisville, the first black win. ner in the 26 years of thc pageant. She was crowned last night by Diana Moore, Mis: Kentucky 1972.

title: U.S. AID SOUGHT FOR SCHOOL PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Educators and legislators offered their support last week to Senate bill giving Federal funds and manpower to expand and develop the community school program in the United States.

title: Books of The Times
description: MARILYN: A Biography. By Norman Mailer. 270 pages. Pictures by the World's Foremost Photographers. Grosset & Dunlap. $19.95. Deluxe edition, $50.

title: REDUCED PENSIONS ARE RECOMMENDED FOR CIVIL SERVICE
description: A special legislative committee will recommend today reductions in pension benefits for new public employes and an end to the grouping of city sanitationmen and transit workers with policemen and firemen for pension purposes.

title: MRS. DUNCAN BARR
description: Mrs. Joan Young Barr, widow of Duncan Barr, golf pro at the Rye Country Club, and mother of Mrs. William E. Tracy, several times New Jersey women's amateur golf champion, died yesterday in London. She was 74 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: Garment Center Work On Hospitality Unit Due
description: Work is expected to begin shortly on a hospitality center for outoftown buyers in the Garment District, a project financed jointly by the city and a group of leaders in the apparel industry.

title: ITCLUSKEY, FOYT WIN AUTO RACES
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich. July 15 (AP)Roger McCluskey and A. J. Foyt, two venerable and versatile pros, won twin 200mile races today before a crowd of 43,700 at Michigan International Speedway.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Shavers Breaks Jaw; Fight With Quarry Off
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., July 15 (AP)Earnie Shavers, a Warren, Ohio, heavyweight, suffered a broken jaw today during a workout with Jeff Merrit at the Grossinger Country Club.

title: Trenton Stock Car Event Is Postponed Until Aug. 5
description: TRENTON, July 15More than 1,500 stockcarracing fans huddled this afternoon in the drafty grandstand of Trenton Speedway daring to hope against the obvious, but it was a lost cause.

title: Poll Finds Majority Still Favor Return to 71 WagePrice Curbs
description: Most Americans still favor return to the strict Phase I controls of 1971 on both prices and wages, according to a Gallup Poll announced yesterday.

title: SCREENING OF JUDGES IS URGED BY ROBERTS
description: State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts said last night that candidates for judgeships should be screened by a special panel of judges, lawyers and members of local communities.

title: WALTER J. FIER ORIENTALIST, DIES
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 15 (UPI)Dr. Walter J. Fischel, professor emeritus of Semitic languages and literature at the University of California, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: Evil Precedent
description: Under the guise of solving the energy crisis, oil and regional interests are threatening to undermine the National Environmental Protection Act. A key test will take place tomorrow when the Senate votes on an amendment to a bill by Senator Jackson of Washington to ease the way for building a pipeline to carry oil from Alaska's North Slope to West Coast ports.

title: The Bear's Foot
description: STAUNTON, Va.As a very young lad, some seventy years ago, I learned to sew on the sewing machine. It was during a long convalescence from serious accident one winter on the farm. My mother was always sewing when she was not cooking or keeping house, for she made most of the clothes for the younger members of our big family.

title: Critiques Are Sought By Accounting Board
description: The Financial Accountants Standards Board yesterday called on financial executives, analysts, accountant and other interested parties to offer critiques of pronouncements of its predecessors, the Accounting Principles Board and the Committee on Accounting Procedure.

title: Beman Shoots 67 for 271 And Triumphs by Stroke
description: ROBINSON, Ill., July 15 (AP) Deane Beman shot a 67 today for a 13underpar total of 271 and won the $125,000 ShrineRobinson open by a stroke over Bob Dickson and Bunky Henry, who closed with 66's.

title: MAGAZINE PROMISES DEFENSE IN SEIZURE
description: Penthouse magazine, which features nudity, announced yesterday that it would defend venders of the periodical who might be accused of selling pornographic material under the recent United States Supreme Court ruling permitting local communities to set obscenity standards.

title: Housing Authority Is Sued To Provide Better Lighting
description: In an effort to improve protection by providing better lighting, City Councilman Morton Povman announced yesterday that he had filed a suit against the Housing Authority on behalf of 9,000 tenants of Pomonok Housing in Flushing, Queens, and the 5,000 tenants of Glenwood Housing in Brooklyn to compel the agency to rewire both developments.

title: ITCLUSKEY, FOYT WIN AUTO RACES
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 15 (AP)Roger McCluskey and A. J. Foyt, two venerable and versatile pros, won twin 200mile races today before a crowd of 43,700 at Michigan International Speedway.

title: Romney Leads Poll
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 15 (UPI)Former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development George Romney would be an overwhelming victor among Republicans to replace retiring Senator Wallace F. Bennett if elections were held now, according to a newspaper poll published today. The Salt Lake Tribune said that Mr. Romney was favored among 53 per cent of Republicans polled. Mr. Romrey has not announced a decision whether to run.

title: Tito and Ceausescu Confer
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 15 (UPI)  President Nicolae Ceausescu and other Rumanian leaders arrived on Brioni Island today for two days of talks with President Tito that were expected to center on international affairs, the Belgrade radio reported.

title: Red Smith
description: sport s of The Times

title: Radio
description: 9:0610 A.M., WQXR: Piano Personalities. Garrick Ohlsson and Morton Estria. Andante Spianato and Grande Polonaise Briltante (Op. 22), Chopin; Pneludes (Op. 32), Nos, 17), Rachmaninoff.

title: Louisiana Enshrines Three
description: ALEXANDRIA, La., July 15 (AP)Jim Taylor, the football player, Willie Pastrano, the boxer, and Tommy Bolt, the golfer, were inducted into the Louisiana Sports Hall of Famel today.

title: New Mexico Tax Is Barred On Incomes on Reservations
description: SANTA FE, N.M., July 15The New Mexico Supreme Court has ruled that the state cannot impose a tax on the reservation Income of Indians who live on a reservation.

title: COPIES OF I.R.A. BOOK SEIZED NEAR DUBLIN
description: DUBLIN, July 15  The police raided a printing plant lasti night and seized 10,000 copies of a book published by the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Bridge: Mechutan's Team Gains Lead In Fun City Regional Finals
description: Six young experts from the metropolitan area gained an early lead in the final of the Fun City regional knockout bridge championship yesterday afternoon at the New York Hilton. Jay Mechutan, Mike Engel, August Boehm, George Tornay, Marcel Friedmann, all of New York, and Bob Ryder of Caldwell, N.J., led by 25 international match points after 32 deals of scheduled 64.

title: Lowenstein Asks Inquiry Into Political Accidents
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15 Former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein, who ranked high on the White House list of toppriority enemies, has called for an investigation into a long list of puzzling incidents that have plagued his political and personal life in recent years.

title: Peace With Honor
description: LONDON, July 15Torture during interrogation, or as a disciplinary measure within prisons, is no longer even motivated by a desire to gather intelligence torture is widely used not only as an instrument of intimidation but as an end in itself in many instances torture has become no more or less than a matter of habit. prefer not to have a dead body et the interrogation center. The torture that we see the results of most frequently is [attaching] electrical wires to people's toes, or fingers, or sensitive parts of their bodies.

title: Philadelphia's Chinatown Is Threatened by Progress
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 15 Since its beginnings more than a hundred years ago with a Chinese grocery on Race Street, Philadelphia's tiny Chinatown, as closeknit as a shred of silk, has survived its early days of opium dens and bloody Tong wars, and continuing years of racial isolation and growing urban decay. Now, at the

title: Squatters Accorded Cognizance by U.S.
description: COLUMBIA, N. J., July 15Squatters on Government land along the Delaware River have won a, measure of recognition from a Federal agency.

title: National League
description: Monday, July 16, 1973

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: This department receives a flow of horror stories about bad food and worse service. It is surprising how many readers add that when they complained orally to managers they were rudely rebuffed, and when they did so in writing, they got no reply.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: CityMuseumMarks Its 50th Birthday

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Marcel Keeps Featherweight Title

title: Archbishop in Israel Plans A Fast for Arab Villagers
description: TEL AVIV, July 15 (AP)The religious leader of the Greek Catholic community in Galilee and southern Lebanon announced a fast today to try to convince Israel to allow Arab refugees to return to two destroyed villages.

title: Food Handlers Must Take New City Hygiene Course
description: Citing the recent rise in health violations reported at foodhandling establishments, the Health Service Administration announced yesterday that it would require restaurants and food stores to send representatives to a special course in environmental sanitation the agency was starting today.

title: RAGTIME IS FIRST TRANSPAC RACE
description: HONOLULU, July 15. (AP)Ragtime, a 62foot sloop from Long Beach, Calif., won the 27th transPacific yacht race early today, beating the defending champion, Windward Passage, in the closest race in the history of the 2,225mile event.

title: Lawyer Marries Miss Newmyer
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Miss Barbara Newmyer, former press representative for the Columbia Broadcasting System here, and Mark W. Johnson, a senior lawyer in the Washington office of C.B.S., were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr, and Mrs. Arthur G. Newmyer Jr. Rabbi E. William Seaman performed the ceremony.

title: Woman on Water Skis Killed
description: A 25yearold Queens woman was killed Saturday when she fell off water skis in Jamaica Bay and was struck by a passing motorboat, the police said. The woman, Mrs. Veronica Emmetsberger of 4144 76th Street, Jackson Heights, wd,s pronounced dead on arrival at Coney Island Hospital.

title: Guess Who Didn't Report
description: IRVINE, Calif., July 15 (AP) 1Duane Thomas missed the reporting deadline for veterans at the San Diego Chargers trainling camp today, but Coach Harland Svare said the controversial running back was enroute and hopefully would be in camp soon. Svare refused other comment about Thomas.

title: Retailer Stops Sales Of Watergate TShirts
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 15 (UPI)Fred 0. Meyer, the owner of Oregon's largest retail concern, has ordered a line of Watergate Tshirts removed from his company's sales floors. A spokesman for the Fred Meyer Shopping Center said yesterday that it was Mr. Meyer's personal decision and reflected his feelings about the shirts.

title: Stage: A Macbeth Beset by Demons
description: STRATFORD, Conn., July 15  Macbeth is perhaps the most startling of Shakespeare's tragedies. Images of blood, death and violence are everywhere, sleep is murdered and a particular madness, corrupted by remorse, reigns.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONIC SHORTAGES OF FOOD PREDICTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Increasing worldwide affluence and population growth will produce Chronic food shortages, rising prices and the emergence of a global politics of food scarcity.

title: Helen Hayes Aids Project To Rehabilitate 1833 Church
description: NYACK, N. Y. July 15 (UPI) Helen Hayes has donated more than $13,000 towards the restoration of a dilapidated, 140yearold church in Cold Spring, N. Y., it was announced today.

title: ARTHUR N. EDROP
description: LAKE GENEVA, Wis., July 15Arthur Norman Edrop, an artist, illustrator and advertising consultant, formerly of Haverford, Pa., died Friday here at the age of 89.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DISNEYLAND It's not enough that they are showing the great Walt Disney movies over at Lincoln Center's Tully Hall; now there's a new spate of Disney creations being showcased at the Lincoln Center Library just across the way at 64th Street, at the Amsterdam Avenue end of the center. Three things, all free, are developing there.

title: Morocco Inaugurates Dam
description: FEZ, Morocco, July 15 (UPI)  King Hassan II inaugurated a $31million dam on the Inaouene River today and announced that the Soviet Union would help Moroccan engineers build another darn on the Lucus River farther north.

title: Cox Opposes McCord Retrial, Calling Convict 'Plainly Guilty'
description: WASHINGTON, July Hi (UPI) The special Watergate prose cutor, Archibald Cox. today re jected a contention by a con victed Watergate conspirator, James W. McCord Jr., that the prosecution of his case had been so fraudulent that he should be granted a new trial.

title: DR. BREWSTER GERE
description: Dr. Brewster Huntington Gere, former head of the mathe matics department at Hamilton College, died yesterday of a pulmonary edema in McLean, Va. He was 62 years old and formerly lived in Clinton, N.Y.

title: Sadat Accuses U.S. of Seeking Delay in U.N. Debate
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 16 President Anwar elSadat of Egypt accused the United States today of trying to bring about a postponement of a dis cussion on the Middle East by the United Nations Security Council in favor of its proposa for negotiations between Egypt and Israel on the reopening of the Suez Canal.

title: Cabbie Shot to Death in Queens; Two Men Found Slain in Bronx
description: A 28yearold taxicab driver was fatally shot yesterday af ternoon when he was apparent ly held up two miles from Kennedy International Airport in the Springfield Gardens section of Queens. He was the first driver of a medallion cab to be slain since last November.

title: U. S. to Give India Aid Buildings And Negotiate Debt Settlement
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the United States Ambassador to India, has been instructed to turn over a complex of Ameri jean aid buildings to the Indian Government and to start nego tiations on a compromise settle turn over a complex of Ameri canowned rupees with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: The Old Iceman Still Plies It Cool on 56th St.
description: On the northwest corner of 56th Street, just off Ninth Avenue, stands a three wheeled cart bearing a yel low license plate that reads: Consumer Affairs, Licensed Ice Dealer, 15943. The cart is parked there every morn ing next to a rectangular object draped in heavy can vas.

title: Notes on People China Trip Is Hailed
description: There can he no doubt that this trip has been a tre mendous success, said Sena tor Warren G. Magnuson of Washington as he and seven other Congressmen ended a twoweek tour of China. You will see that it will bear fruit in the not too distant future. I am sure of that. We are de termined that our relations with the People's Republic of China should be improved and expanded as rapidly as possible.

title: JAMES F. MURRAY
description: James F. Murray, director of group sales for the New York Mets since 1962, died Sunday of a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 8739 Marengo Street, Jamaica, Queens.

title: Roundup: Gibson, Torre Do Old Tricks For Cards in Setting Back Giants, 32
description: Bob Gibson and Joe Torre put their talents together last night in Busch Stadium and the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the San Francisco Giants, 32.

title: Pakistan's P.O.W. Wives  Suffering the Stigma Of Being Women Alone
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  The neighbors of Mrs. Nasim Khan ignore her now. Mrs. Freda Shah's friends are reluctant to phone. Mrs. Naheed Badar stays home each night, yearning to see a motion picture in the city.

title: Plan for Settlement By Gypsum Makers Approved by Judge
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July (UPI)Federal District Judge. Alfonso J. Zirpoli today ap proved a $22.5million settle ment in an antitrust case involving four large manufac turers of gypsum wallboard.

title: Who's Afraid of Shanker?
description: The only question of substance be fore the recent convention of the National Education Association in Portland, Ore., was how to merge with the American Federation of Teachers without being swallowed up by its parent union, the A.F.L.C.I.O. It was clear that Albert Shanker, the presi dent of New York's United Federation of Teachers, loomed as the big had wolf who might do the swallowing.

title: INTEREST RATES PRESSING HIGHER ShortTerms Continuing to Move Up  Banks Pay More for Big Deposits BOND LIST IS STEADY Underwriters and Investors Await New Financing Scheduled This Week
description: Shortterm interest rates con tinued to press higher yester day, with banks paying nearly 9 per cent to attract large deposits for three months and between 10 and 11 for an other source of money, Federal funds.

title: A Watergate Bombshell Is Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  There's nothing like a mys tery witness to pick up hearing that's beginning to droop around the edges.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Peggy Lambert, Manuel Win in Larchmont Junior Sail
Metropolitan Briefs
description: It became a regular free show. Twentyfour times, according to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, Stephen W. Goodwin of 4808 58th Lane, Woodside, Queens, drove across the Throgs Neck and Triborough Bridges, then sped through toll gates without paying.

title: Derelicts Vex Residents Along Upper Broadway
description: The bums who inhabit the traffic islands on Broadway on the Upper West Side are a constantand sometimes hazardousnuisance, but no one knows quite what to do about them.

title: A Correction
description: On June 29 The New York Times printed the winning num ber for the June 28 New Jersey daily lottery, 00491, then in advertently reprinted this num ber in its June 30 issue. The winning number in the June 29 drawing was 62380.

title: Insurer Reports Gains
description: Sales of individual policies of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company rose 15 per cent in the first half of 1973 to $1.95million, the insurer said yesterday. It added that group life sales fell about 13 per cent.

title: Portuguese Leader Begins London Visit
description: LONDON, July 16Premier Marcello Caetano of Portugal flew in for an official visit to day heavily guarded against antiPortugese demonstrators.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Federation Asks Homeowners to Think of Backyards as Wildlife Refuges
description: Homeowners are asked by the National Wildlife Federa tion to think of their back yards as potential wildlife refuges.

title: St. Croix Defendants Fight With Marshals
description: CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, V. I., July 16 (UPI)Four of the five defendants in the Fountain Valley murder trial fought with United States marshals today before being subdued.

title: `NoKnock Drug Raids Curbed Under New Federal Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The Drug Enforcement Admin. istration issued today a new set of guidelines for Federal narcotics agents with the aim of preventing future abuses such as mistaken raids on the homes of innocent families.

title: Utility Moved Cold Gauge, Rate Rise Hearing Is Told
description: State engineers charged yes terday that Orange and Rock land Utilities had tried to jus tify a gas rate increase by mov ing its thermometer from the side of its heated headquarters building to the top of a 100foot radio tower to prove that 1972 was the coldest in 36 years.

title: AN ACCUSED PILOT BEING SENT TO U.S.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 16 (UPI)A B52 pilot charged with disobeying an order to fly a mission over Cambodia has been sent to his home base in the United States, Air Force sources said today.

title: Libya Hints She Will Seize U.S. and Other Embassies
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  The United States Embassy in Tripoli has informed the State Department that Libyan newspapers and broadcasts re port that several embassy buildings and envoys resi dences might be taken over by the Government of Col. Muam mar elQaddafi

title: Truck Driver Is Seized, $30,000 in Goods Taken
description: Three thieves stole some S30,000 in women's under garments from the ware house of the Lovable Com pany in Queens last night after abducting the concern's foreman at gunpoint in front of his home and forcing him to admit them to the ware house, the police reported.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 24874
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matchine the first and second digits the second and third the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: ForeignService Group Declines To Call Godley Case a Reprisal
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The American Foreign Service Asso ciation, which represents all State Department employes, took a middle position today be tween the Nixon Administration and the Senate Foreign Rela tions Committee over the rejec tion of President Nixon's nomi nee for Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs.

title: SIERRA CLUB SCORES U.S. CLEANAIR PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) Calling the Nixon Administra tion's latest cleanair proposals lawless, the Sierra Club said today that it would return to court seeking to nullify them.

title: Tapings in Johnson Era Both Alleged and Denied
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The White House confirmed today that nearly all of Presi dent Nixon's official meetings and telephone conversations had been secretly recorded since 1971.

title: Second Suit Filed Over Low Price of Yanks Sale
description: Mrs. Doris J. Bachman filed a second suit yesterday against the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem, its board of directors, Michael Burke and a syndicate he formed to buy the New York Yankees for $10million earlier this year.

title: NEPA in Danger
description: The National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 NEPAis perhaps the most important single piece of modern environmental law now on the statute books. That law is under attack in the Senate today in the form of a proposal by Senator Gravel of Alaska. It is impera tive that the law not be breached or undermined, and that the Gravel amendment be defeated.

title: Westinghouse Wins a Huge Nuclear Order
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yester day it had received an order for six 1.1millionkilowatt nu clear steam supply systems and fuel from five utilities in four states. Based on total generat ing capacity, this would be the largest single nuclear order placed.

title: Woman, 92, Is Mugged
description: BOSTON, July 16 (UPI)A 92yearold woman who had been confined to a wheel chair since she broke her hip several weeks ago was beaten yesterday by a man who stole 62 cents, the police said. The victim, Ernes tine Ruprecht, was reported in satisfactory condition today at University Hospital, suffering from a broken jaw.

title: SUIT LINKS FARES TO AIR POLLUTION
description: An alliance of environmental and transitrider groups an flounced the filing of a suit yesterday seeking to compel the state to stabilize transit and commuter fares to meet na tional clean air standards.

title: SHOP TALK Bikinis for Every Shape; Telephones in All Designs
description: It's no problem getting a bikini that fits at Gunn of Sweden. If there's nothing suitable in stock, Gunn Jons son will make one up for $25 in solid Banlon, printed jer sey or cotton. There is a choice of two bottoms (one cut fuller in back) and sev eral variations of the bra top.

title: Auto Talks Begin,With Plant Conditions Key Issue
description: DETROIT, July 16  Negoti ators from the United Automo bile Workers and the auto in dustry settled themselves into the plush, airconditioned of fices of the General Motors Corporation here today to listen to the often frustrated, discordant voices of the 725,000 workers who man the assembly lines.

title: JAMES F. SCANLAN
description: James F. Scanlan, who headed Network Public Rela tions, Inc., a New York agency, from 1957 to 1960, died Friday in St. Paul, where he was a publicity manager for the 3M Company. He was 51 years old.

title: Yankees Also Ahead in Games Played
description: After 31 games in 27 con secutive days, the Yankees rested yesterday while their three nearest rivals contin ued to chase them in the Am'rican League's East.

title: MORTGAGE RATES RAISED BY JERSEY; Increase to 8% Is Designed to Attract More Money Albany May Follow Suit
description: TRENTON, July 16State Banking Commissioner Richard F. Schaub today raised the in terest rate lenders may charge on mortgages to 8 per cent from 7 per cent in a move designed to attract more money to the market.

title: Bernhard Knollenberg, 80, Historian, Yale Librarian
description: OLD LYME, Conn., July 16 Bernhard Knollenberg, historian and former library director of Yale Univesity, died here July 6. He was 80 years old and lived at Parker's Point.

title: New Jersey Sports Cognac Grand Prix
description: POINT PLEASANT, July 16Mention the Hennessy Grand Prix to somebody not familiar with ocean powerboat racing and he may think both driver and boat run on cognac. Oddly, there have been enough zany occurrences on the annual worldchampionship race to warrant such notion.

title: Duane Thomas Is Suspended
description: Suspensions, sudden re tirements, holdouts and demands to be traded high lighted the pro football scene yesterday as coaches counted their seasoned players due in training camp. Duane Thomas, the evasive running back for San Diego, was suspended by the Charger coach, Harland Svare, because Thom as reported to the Irvine, Calif., camp one day late. Nobody's wandering into my camp anytime they want, said Svare.

title: Alexander's Is Unaware Of Reason for Stock Rise!
description: Alexander's, Inc., one of New York's largest retail chains, said We know of no reason for the sudden increase in price of our stock following, sizable trading in its stock yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TUNNEY ANSWERS CRITICISM OF BILL Senator Calls Statements of Opposing Athletic Groups Misinformed
description: John V. Tunney, the Demo cratic Senator from California, yesterday answered the critics of the omnibus sports bill, the Amateur Athletic Act of 1973 that he cosponsored, and the 38yearold son of the onetime heavyweight champion in effect put on boxing gloves.

title: Javits Urges Nixon Reply
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 16 (UPI)Senator Jacob K. Javits. Republican of New York, said today that Congress should and must have a re ply from President Nixon to all the charges that have been made regarding the Watergate scandal. Speaking at the 12th annual conference of the New York State Broadcasters As sedation, Mr. Javits said hr thought the President's reply should he made when the bulk of the Watergate testimony has been heard.

title: Intercontinental Life Shifts
description: The Intercontinental Life Company of Newark, voted yesterday to become the Inter continental Financial Corpora tion and cut its shares to 1.1 million from 5.5 million.

title: The New Jerusalem
description: Since gaining complete control over Jerusalem and its environs in the 1967 war, Israel has earned almost universal applause for its efforts to improve municipal services, to expand green belt areas outside the walls of the Old City and to maintain free and easy access to the holy places of three great world religions. Even the Arabs, who bitterly oppose Israel's claims to their former territories in and around the municipality, generally agree that the removal of the barriers that divided the city for two decades is an achievement that should not be reversed in any future political settlement.

title: 7 More Yachts Finish In TransPacific Race
description: HONOLULU, July 16 (UPI)  Nine yachts had crossed the finish line with two more expected late tonight in the transPacific yacht race from San Pedro, Calif., that started July 4.

title: Nepal's Premier Resigns
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, July 16 (AP)Premier Kirti Nidhi Bista resigned today, and King Bi renda Bir Bikram Shah Deva tried to appease the Premier's critics in the National Assem bly by asking its chairman to form a new government.

title: Football Transactions NATIONAL CONFERENCE
description: DALLASTrimmed 11 rookies: Ted Buck of Boise State, David Vodika of Cincinnati and Gerald Caswell, all offensive line men; Chris Gartner of Indiana and Robert Roca of L.S.U.New Orleans, both kickers; Larry Harris of Tennessee State and Zachery Rogers of Norfolk State, both wide receivers; Mike White, Minnesota deten sive back; Don Heater, Montana Tech run ning back; Larry Jones, Morehouse de fensive lineman; and Bill Ping, Indiana linebacker.

title: County Aide Urges GrandJury Inquiry On Sullivan Airport
description: MONTICELLO, July 16 John J. J. McGough, the Sulli van County Commissioner of Public Works and chairman of the County Airport Commis sion, asked District Attorney Louis B. Scheinman today to impanel a special county grand jury to investigate all phases of design, construction and op eration of the Sullivan County International Airport.

title: Mackinac Yachts Becalmed
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich.. July 16 (AP)More than 2 days after the 207 craft in the Chicago  to  Mackinac Island yacht race started, the leaders are still 25 miles from their goal. Race officials reported to night that winds had died down in the northern Lake Michigan area, becalming the entrants. Sassy, owned by Russel (Dutch) Schmidt of Grosse Pointe, Mich., was the leader.

title: Equity Financing
description: ESystems, Inc. said yesterday its directors had approved a tender offer to purchase 400,000 of its outstanding common shares at $12.50 per share. The offer will be made by an employe stock owner ship trust. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange, closed at 11 up 1.

title: Receivership Is Asked for Texas Gas Company
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 16Lo Voca Gathering Company, a subsidiary of Coastal States Gas Producing Company, was taken to court today by Attor ney General John L. Hill, who asked for an operating re ceivership.

title: Baseball Transactions AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: CHICAGOAsked waivers for purposes of un conditional release on Mike Andrews, In fielder.

title: PENSION REFORMS EXPECTED TO PASS Head of Panel Sees Albany Enacting Its Proposals
description: ALBANY, July 17The chair man of the Select Committee on Pensions said today that he was optimistic that the Legislature would approve the committee's recommendations.

title: 150 Nixon Medallions Are Sold on First Day
description: MELROSE, Mass., July 16 (UPI)A Melrose company is selling a $46 Watergate commemorative silver ingot depicting President Nixon in the three poses of See no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil.

title: A Novelist of India Reflects 2 Worlds
description: NEW DELHI, July 16  From 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. each day, Ruth. Prawer Jhabvala sits in her study and writes of India. She writes with cool, fragile precision of middle class New Delhi, of vain Cab inet ministers, searching American women, sad busi nessmen, foolish British visi tors, arrogant Indian youths and tragicomic lovers.

title: TakeOver Bid Continues
description: The British Match Corporation said yesterday that its takeover bid for Wilkinson Sword, Ltd., of Britain would remain in ef fect while the British Monop olies Commission studied the offer. Wilkinson said it had waived its previous stipulation that the $47million bid would be void if the matter had been referred to the commission.

title: CARSON INDICTED IN A MURDER CASE Civil Rights Figure Is Held for Arraignment Today
description: Robert C. (Sonny) Carson, a black activist, and seven other men were indicted yesterday on charges of killing one man and kidnapping another in re taliation for their purported robberies of a blackowned ho tel in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Jet Picture Day: Let's Have a Big . . .'
U.S. CONFIRMS PRE1970 RAIDS ON CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Secretary of Defense James Schlesinger acknowledged today that Air Force B52 bombers were secretly attacking Cam bodia in 1969 and 1970 while the United States was publicly professing its respect for that nation's neutrality in the Viet nam war.

title: Nixon Still Gaining
description: President Nixon was re ported yesterday to be pro gressing satisfactorily in his recovery from viral pneu monia at the Bethesda Naval Hospital. Details on Page 27.

title: Last of the Pages
description: The official records are obscure on the point, but from at least 1827 one or another branch of the United States Congress has relied upon small boys, or pages, to carry messages of state. A Select Committee report of 1841 explained: Members frequently take interest in a prom ising boy, or have their sympathies awakened by his orphan or destitute situation, and press the officer of the House to engage him in this service. When Henry Clay and Daniel Webster concurred, one Grafton Dulany Han son, aged nine, was appointed the first Senate page and he went on to heroism in the Mexican War.

title: DONALD DANFORTH OF RALSTON PURINA
description: ST. LOUIS, July 16 (UPI) Donald Danforth Sr., retired chairman of the board of the Ralston Purina Company died Saturday in Barnes Hospital.

title: KARL LOEWENSTEIN, AMHERST PROFESSOR
description: AMHERST, Mass., July 16 Dr. Karl Loewenstein, emeritus professor of jurisprudence and political science at Amherst Col lege, died last Tuesday in Heidelberg, Germany, while traveling in Europe. He was 82 years old and had made his home here since joining the faculty in 1936.

title: CaseFixing Linked To Koota's Office By Bond Swindler
description: WASHINGTON, July 16A convicted bond swindler has told a Senate committee of two examples of casefixing in the Brooklyn District Attorney's of fice during the tenure of Aaron E. Koota, now a State Supreme Court justice.

title: Nixon, Better, Is Reported Set to Decide on Phase 4
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) President Nixon, described today as progressing satis factorily in his fight against. viral pneumonia, was reported almost set to make final de cisions on a Phase 4 economic program.WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)President Nixon will he billed $1.75 a day during his stay at Bethesda (Md.) Naval medical Center where he is be ing treated for viral pneu monia. That is the rate for the Commander in Chief and naval officers Enlisted men pay nothing.

title: A Forthright Witness Alexander Porter Butterfield
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 It didn't surprise his mother that Alexander Porter Butter field gave Watergate inves tigators the unvarnished facts including the information that disputed conversations between President Nixon and his aides are all on tape somewhere in the White House vaults. He always stood for moral integrity and straightforward ness, said Mrs. Susan Butterfield in an interview from Tacoma, Wash., this afternoon. He doesn't like me to talk this way, but he was an Eagle Scout and he carried the Cross in church. Man in the News

title: U.S. CONFIRMS PRE1970 RAIDS ON CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger acknowledged today that Air Force B52 bombers were secretly attacking Cam bodia in 1969 and 1970 while the United States was publicly professing its respect for that nation's neutrality in the Viet nam war.

title: Paine,Webber Shows a Net Loss For the Third Fiscal Quarter
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., one of the nation's leading Wall Street brokerage houses, yesterday reported net loss of $1.25million for the third fiscal quarter ended June 30.

title: Queens Man, 80, and Son Robbed of $11,000 at Bank
description: An 80yearold man and his son, 55, were robbed of $11,000 last evening in Forest Hills, Queens, as they were about to make a night deposit at a bank on Queens Boulevard, the pol ice reported.

title: Saigon Gives Offshore Oil Rights to 4 Concerns
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16American, British, Dutch and Canadian oil inter ests won rights today to drill for oil off the coast of South Vietnam.

title: Restaurateurs Go to School for Sanitary Lessons
description: William Sheptinsky, a mid dleaged restaurant owner from Brooklyn, went back to school yesterday, to learn how to keep rats away from his kitch en, how to store food at the right temperature and how to survive the scrutiny of Health Department inspectors.

title: Golfdom's Glorious Antique
description: It was a handsome victory that Torn Weiskopf scored in the prestigious British Open last week as he made his first breakthrough into the elite with a recordequaling total of 276, But the man who stole the show was that doughty little antique, the 7Iyearold Gene Sarazen. He had arrived at Troon in Scotland as a ceremonial figure. He was to he feted and fussed over because this was the golden anniversary of his first attempt to win the British Open at this same course in 1923. In a way it was celebration of a failure. He had bombed out at Troon 50 years ago, scoring an 85 on the opening round as the winds whistled in off the Irish Sea and whipped lashing rains. He failed to qualify. But Gene was only 21 years old then and he had the resiliency of youth along with the tough competitive heart. that was to make him a golfing legend. Nine years later he was to win the British Open, the sixth of the seven major championships he was to corral. Sports of The Times

title: SOVIET OPERATING  BREEDER REACTOR First Such Facility Reported in Commercial Production
description: MOSCOW, July 16  The Soviet Union announced today, that its atomic breeder reactor, the world's first power source of its type, had gone intmcom mercial production. It had been undergoing tests since its start up last December.

title: SCHOOL TAX EDICT WILL E APPEALED Legislative Leaders to Ask Supreme Court to Review Ruling on Education
description: TRENTON, July 16  The leaders of both houses of the State Legislature said today they would appeal the State Supreme Court decision that declared unconstitutional the present system of financing public education largely through local property taxes.

title: Political Tax Audits?
description: The new Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Donald C. Alexander, is correct when he asserts the importance of maintaining public confidence in the taxcollection system. Both he and the Congressional Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation are now conducting sepa rate investigations to determine whether partisan politi cal influence was exerted on the choice of certain tax returns for exhaustive audits, as a means of embarrass ing selected enemies of the Administration.

title: China Purchases Tobacco From the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) China has purchased 440,000 pounds of tobacco from the United States worth an esti mated $500,000, according to the Agriculture Department.

title: Nantucket and the Vineyard Divide Over Preservation Plan
description: TISBURY, Mass., July 16 The islands of Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard appeared to be sharply divided today on proposed Federal legislation to limit their development in hopes of protecting their beauty.

title: Jackson Charges a Killing In U.S. Grain Sale to Soviet
description: CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) Someone made a killing in the United States grain sale to the Soviet Union, Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today.

title: Skylab Module Is Tested
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 16 (UPI)  Launching officials today carefully tested the com munications system aboard the command module that will carry three more astronauts to Skylab July 28 for an eight week space research mission. The countdown, which began last night, continued without problems.

title: Warning on Brake Problems Issued by General Motors
description: DETROIT, July 16 (UPI) General Motors said today it had begun notifying the owners of 3,100 intermediatesize cars and 5,800 mediumduty trucks of possible brake problems on their vehicles. All are 1973 models.

title: Hughes Ordered to Meet Defense Lawyers in Suit
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 16 (AP)  A Federal judge ruled today that Howard Hughes, the recluse billionaire, does not have to appear in court but will have to meet with defense lawyers in a suit brought by one of his companies.

title: 2 Canadians Call Capture Harassment
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16The two Canadian officers of the International Commis sion of Control and Supervision, freed by the Vietcong yesterday after 17 days detention, have told their superiors in Saigon that they have no doubt that the Communists had orders to arrest and mistreat them as a way of harassing the Canadian delegation to the commission.

title: Mailer and Guiles Deny Any Dispute
description: Briefs on the Arts

title: Some Are Shocked, Some Unconcerned by Report on Taping of Nixon Conversations
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Re actions ranging from shock to So what? greeted the disclos ure today that conversations with President Nixon had been bugged as a matter of White House routine.

title: Where President's Listening Devices Are Located
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Two kinds of listening de vices have been maintained for President Nixon, one kind recording telephone calls, the other monitoring room con versation, according to tes timony before the Senate Watergate committee today by Alexander P. Butterfield.

title: Lil Blow Victor Upstate
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., July 16 (AP)The meet's leading) jockey, Rudy Rincon, quided Lil Blow to a head victory over Super Amber in the $1,800, featured race at Finger Lakes Race Track today.

title: Woman Slain After Answering Doorbell in Bronx Apartment
