description: A 70yearold Bronx woman called away from the telephone to answer her doorbell was beaten to death in a robbery attempt yesterday while her sisterinlaw waited on the open phone line, the police re ported.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: A MANY YEARS AGO The styles of the nineteen twenties and nineteenthir ties are hanging on the walls of the exhibition room of the Society of Illustrators, 128 East 63d Street (TE 82560). There are 80 illustrations, drawings, paintings and so on from those years, done by 28 artists, in this eye catching show. There is so much variety that it is diffi cult to sum it all up other than to say that it repre sents, but not entirely, the

title: TANNER,STOCKTON VICTORS IN TENNIS Battrick Sets Back Gerken, Alexander Wins at U.S. Pro EventLutz Is Hurt
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., July 16 (UPI)Fourthseeded John Al exander of Australia squeezed past Jeff Borowiak of Tiburon, Calif., 64, 67, 76, at the start today of the $60,000 United States professional tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club.GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 16 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Ru mania captured the men's crown and Julie Anthony of Los An geles the women's in the Swiss international tennis champion ships today.LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 16 (UPI)Billy Martin and How ard Schoenfield, both from Cali fornia, led the advance of seed ed players today in the open ing round of the national juni or claycourt tennis champion ships.

title: Neil Simon's Wife Is Dead
description: Neil Simon's Wife Is Dead

title: Gilmour Fifth Driver To Get 3,000 Victories
description: YONKERS, July 16Wil liam (Buddy) Gilmour, a 40 yearold native of Lucan, Ontario, tonight became the fifth driver in harness rac ing history to score 3,000 victories. Herve Filion, Joe O'Brien, Del Insko and Wil liam Haughton previously reached that milestone.

title: HUGH C. LAUGHLIN, GLASS EXECUTIVE OwensIllinois Director Dies Episcopal Leader
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, July 16  Hugh C. Laughlin, retired ex ecutive vice president and di rector of OwensIllinois, Inc., died here yesterday at the age of 69.

title: 3 ROBBERS OF BANK GET 15YEAR TERMS
description: Federal Judge Mark A. Cos tantino meted out 15year pris on terms yesterday to three men convicted of the armed robbery of a Queens bank near ly three years ago.

title: MRS. GANDHI'S FOE CALLS FOR A VOTE Chief of Rightist Party Says She Has Lost Her Grip
description: NEW DELHI, July 16  The second largest party in India, Jan Sangh, today demanded a parliamentary election and said Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had completely lost grip on the nation.

title: Timely Postponement
description: The postponement of President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's scheduled visit to Washington this week because of President Nixon's illness is probably a good thing for both Pakistan and the United States.

title: Their First Taste of U.S. Was East Hampton
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.  Blandine Bedel was surprised that the tallest building she saw was only two stories high.

title: Colts Trade Smith to Raiders for Chester
Fingerprinting of Newark Pupils Put Off
description: ELIZABETH, July 16  The fingerprinting of 50 to 60 eighth grade Newark boys in a mur der investigation was delayed today, giving lawyers repre senting the youths time to op pose the order.

title: ALFRED COX, 57, DIES; FAR EASTERN EXPERT
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Alfred T. Cox, who retired in 1971 as a Department of De fense specialist on Far Eastern matters, died today at his home in Arlington Towers Apartments in Arlington, Va. He was 57 years old.

title: People and Business Grayson Joins Computer Board
description: C. Jackson Grayson, dean of the School of Business Ad ministration of Southern Methodist University and former chairman of the United States Price Com mission, has been elected to the board of the University Computing Company of Dal las, Texas.

title: Utility Moved Cold Gauge, Rate Rise Hearing Is Told
description: State engineers charged yes terday that Orange and Rock land Utilities had tried to jus tify a gas rate increase by mov ing its thermometer from the side of its heated headquarters building to the top of a 100foot radio tower to prove that 1972 was the coldest in 36 years.

title: Maccabiah Protest Bars 2 Guest Athletes
description: TEL AVIV, July 16 (AP)A protest by a United States coach and other coaches forced two Norwegian guest competi tors to quit the ninth Mac cabiah Games today.

title: BIAGGI CONDEMNS RAPECASE DEAL Assails Merola's Cutting 184 of 187 Counts Against 3
description: Representative Mario Biaggi and Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola clashed yester day over the handling by Mr. Merola's office of the cases of three rapistrobbers.

title: page="1"=Kahane Says He Proposed Bombing Iraqi Office in U.S.
description: TEL AVIV, July 16 (UPI)  Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the Jewish Defense League, said today that he had proposed to American associates that they blow up the nowempty Iraqi Embassy in Washington to draw attention to the plight of the 400 Jews he said were still in Iraq.

title: FIRST OF CHICAGO LIFTS PRIME RATE Washington Silent as Bank Equals Record at 8.5%
description: The First National Bank of Chicago, one 'f the nation's 10 largest banks with well over $13billion in assets, raised its prime lending rate to 8 per cent yesterday. The new level equals the record high for this key minimum rate on large business loans posted during the 19691970 credit crunch.

title: Williamsburg Visited
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July (AP)A delegation of 18 Chinese led by Han Shu, act ing head of the Washington mission of the People's Re public of China visited colon ial Williamsburg unannounced yesterday,

title: $206,312 Helped Beame Win Victory in Runoff
description: Contributions totaling $206, 312 were made by donors to the successful runoff primary campaign of Controller Abraham D. Beanie for the Democratic ,nomination for Mayor, accord ing to political committee state ments on file yesterday at the Board of Elections.

title: Luigi Moretti Dead at 66; Designed Watergate Complex
description: Luigi Moretti, who designed the Watergate complex in Washington, died Saturday on a yachting cruise in the Tyr rhenian Sea. He was 66 years old.

title: GROWTH SOUGHT IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (Reu ters)The Federal Open Mar ket Committee called for moderate growth in the mone tary aggregates over the months ahead at its meeting April 17, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: BOYLE'S CONVICTION UPHELD ON APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals upheld today the con viction of W. A. Boyle, former United Mine Workers president, Ion charges of illegally con tributing union funds to politi cal campaigns.

title: Derelicts Vex Residents Along Upper Broadway
description: The bums who inhabit the traffic islands on Broadway on the Upper West Side are a constantand sometimes hazardousnuisance, but no one knows quite what to do about them.

title: VICTOR S. AXELROAD
description: Victor S. Axelroad, a lawyer and adjunct lecturer in the, speech department of the Ber nard M. Baruch College of the City University since 1957, died Friday on a vacation in Edinburgh, Scotland. He was 58 years old and lived at 77 Seventh Avenue.

title: Principal Asserts Coach Threatened To Burn His Home
description: GALVESTON, Tex., July 16 (UPI)  The principal of Ball High School here said today that he received a warning in July, 1972, from Coach Joe Woolley that his house might be burned down if he didn't go along with altering the tran script of Kerry Jackson, a Uni versity of Oklahoma quarter back.

title: House Backs Food PriceRise Leeway
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The House voted today to re quire the President to permit increases in food prices when ever necessary to avoid short ages of supplies.

title: Mitchell and Stans Doubt a Fair Trial
description: Defense motions contended yesterday that massive publi city made it impossible for former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Secre tary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans to receive a fair trial on charges involving a $200,000 cash contribution to President Nixon's 1972 election cam paign.

title: Books of The Times Aquarius on GeminiII
description: In yesterday's column, certain questions and answers were posed about Norman Mailer's Marilyn: A Biography (Grosset & Dunlap, $19.95). It was suggested that the book was not written to generate money and publicity for the author, as some observers have suggested, but rather as a logical outgrowth of certain themes that have been preoccupying Mr. Mailer in recent yearschief among them women, sex and cinema. It was further argued that Marilyn is not a biography at all or even an attempt at one, but instead a meditation on certain biographical facts, a speculation on certain biographical possibilities, an attempt to mythicize a tentative reality. (For this reason, it is beside the point to tax Mr. Mailer for leaning on other people's books to accumulate his facts or to ques tion why he did not pin those facts down more energetically, especially where they relate to his rather hairraising theory of why Miss Monroe may have been mur dered). Finally, I concluded, what really matters is whether Marilyn succeeds in its own termswhether Mr. Mailer has justified the imaginative liberties he has taken with the truth of his subject's life. And I promised to deliver an answer today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Watergate and the Importance of a Free Press

title: Two Gunmen Bind A Priest and Take Collection of $800
description: Two men, described by their, victim, a monsignor as suave, wellspoken robbers, entered a church rectory on the East Side yesterday morning, bound and gagged the priest, and fled with the $800 Sunday collection.

title: TV: Dick Clark's Originality Enhances Pop Music
description: Popular musicrock and country, specialized and pop ular, soft and hardis finally beginning to make it on tele vision. The major successes, though, are generally limited to two latenight sessions carried on Fridays: the Amer ican Broadcasting Company's In Concert and the Nation al Broadcasting Company's At Midnight, which actual ly begins at 1 A.M.

title: TON OF ARMS SEIZED FROM SHIP IN DUBLIN
description: DUBLIN, July 16Policemen and troops seized almost a ton of arms, ammunition and explo sives on a British ship that ar rived here from Montreal today.

title: Great Leap Lakeward Marks Mao's 66 Swim
description: PEKING, July 16 (Reuters) Some 5,000 Chinese plunged into Peking's Kumming Lake today to mark the seventh anniversary of the famous swim of Chairman Mao Tse tung in the Yangtze River.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES CLIMB BY LIMIT
Advertising: Client Fatigue
description: There is a malady peculiar to the advertising business that can have costly reper cussion'  it's called client fatigue.

title: Meredith J. Blatt Married in France
description: Miss Meredith Jay Blatt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Blatt of New York and La Roche St. Secret, France, was married in Taulignan, France, yesterday to Andre Michel Allegri of Taulignan, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Italo Allegri. Mayor Henri Thomas performed the ceremony in the Mairie (Town Hall.)

title: 27 CAR MAKERS GET DELAY ON CLEAN AIR
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  The Environmental Protec tion Agency, which four months ago granted a oneyear suspen sion of 1975 air pollution stand ards to five American auto manufacturers, extended the suspension today to cover 27 other car makers.

title: Suspect Seized in Slaying of Westport Psychiatrist
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 16 The police said today they had arrested a 19yearold sus pect in the fatal mugging last November of a Westport psy chiatrist in the Father Panik Village housing project here.

title: FIRE DELAYS AWARD FOR CURB ON FILES
description: OVERLAND, Mo., July 16 (AP)  The Military Personnel Rec ord Center, scene of a twoday fire last week, had been sched uled to receive a fire prevention award today from the public buildings service of the General Services Administration.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Federation Asks Homeowners to Think of Backyards as Wildlife Refuges
description: Homeowners are asked by the National Wildlife Federa tion to think of their back yards as potential wildlife refuges..

title: Ballet: FirstRate Cast for 'Hoffmann'
description: Peter Darrell's balletic ver sion of Tales of Hoffmann found its second cast at the New York State Theater on Saturday night. And in some respects the second cast had the edge over its predeces sors. Yet in fairness, this is a ballet that has beenin the inevitable, financially under nourished American manner almost literally thrown onto the stage. A fulllength production that needs virtu ally weeks of rehearsal re ceives virtually hours.

title: The Bolshoi Attends 2 Parties With Jete Set
description: What do you do if you're the Bolshoi Ballet company, nearing the end of a one month tour here, and two American dance companies send out invitations for separate receptions at the same time on the same day?

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: North Texas Names Aide
description: DENTON, Tex., July 16 (UPI)Dewitt Weaver, former head coach at Texas Tech Uni versity and for three years the commissioner of the Missouri Valley Conference, was named assistant athletic director at North Texas State University today.

title: U.S. Dollar Value Shows Drop Again In Trading Abroad
description: LONDON, July 16 (UPI) The value of the dollar skidded downward again in slow trad ing in Europe, where dealers still awaited some sign that individual Governments might intervene to support it.

title: Fingerprinting of Jersey Youths Put Off
description: ELIZABETH, July 16  The fingerprinting of 50 to 60 eighth grade Newark boys in a mur der investigation was delayed today, giving lawyers repre senting the youths time to op pose the order.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Mixed at Weekly Sale
John Prinz Alters His Dancing Style To Dramatic Pose
description: Watching a dancer profound ly alter a movement style is like hearing a singer change the register of the voice. It is a mild shock but fascinating to observe. Currently, John Prinz is halfway between his former lyrical style and a new dra matic presentation, which he employed Sunday evening at State Theater as American Bal let Theater presented Rudi van Dantzig's Monument for Dead Boy.

title: Return of Adopted Child Is Ordered
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 16  A Nassau County State Supreme Court justice ordered today, that the 20yearold natural mother of a 16monthold girl should have custody of the baby even though the girl and her adoptive parents had fled the state.

title: ABRAMS SUPPORTS BEAN FOR MAYOR Bronx President Concedes Gap on Some Issues
description: Bronx Borough President Ro bert Abrams led Controller Ab raham D. Beame down the out side steps of the Bronx Su preme Court Building toward cluster of cameras yesterday, then announced that he was supporting Mr. Beame for Mayor.

title: Census Statistics Indicate Indians Are the Poorest Minority Group
description: WASHINGTON, July 16the Bureau of the Census offered statistical evidence today that American Indians are the poorest minority in the coun try.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: New York  Esteban DeJesus, 135 pounds, Puerto Rico, out pointed Ray Lampkin, 133 Port land, Ore., 12 rounds; DeJesus won American lightweight title.

title: Democrats' Bill on Strip Mining More Stringent Than Administration Proposal
description: WASHINGTON. July 16  Democrats in Congress dis closed today details of a pro posed law to regulate the enormous growth of strip mining, particularly for coal, and the measure seemed likely to stir one of the major legisla tive battles of the year.

title: Freedom of the Press in Britain and U.S.: A Contrast
Bon Vivant Accused By a U.S. Inspector Of Falsifying Data
description: NEWARK, July 16  In sworn testimony that was im mediately and strenuously chal lenged, a Government witness stated today that Bon Vivant Soups, Inc., had falsified about 20 records of its can ning operations that were turned over to the Federal Food and Drug Administration.

title: ALLEN TOP CHOICE IN ALLSTAR VOTE Murcer, Jackson, Carew, Robinson Also Repeat
description: Dick Allen, the Chicago White Sox injured first base man, was the leading voteget ter for the American League starting team in the AllStar game, according to yesterday's final returns.

title: Fishbach and Van Nostrand Win Nassau Tennis Matches
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 16Peter Fishbach of Mill Neck, seeded fifth, defeated Jim Webber of Old Westbury, 61, 62, in the first round of the Nassau invitation tennis tour nament at the Shore Tennis Club today.

title: SURPRISE WITNESS Butterfield, ExAide at White House, Tells of Listening Devices
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  President Nixon had listening devices in the White House that would have automatically taperecorded his conversations with John W. Dean 3d and other key figures in the Water gate case, a former White House aide disclosed today.

title: Lindsay Scores Transit Subsidy Plan
description: Mayor Lindsay's office said yesterday that it would be pointless for the city to con tribute to a statelocal transit subsidy plan, as Governor Rock efeller has proposed, unless it provided a longrange solution to stabilizing the subway fare.

title: 5 TOP OFFICIALS OF WALL ST. FIRM INDICTED ON FRAUD Conspiracy to Falsify Books and Earnings of Weis Charged by Grand Jury
description: The five topranking officers of Weis Securities, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange firm now in liquidation, were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of con spiracy and securities fraud.

title: Tug Sinks in Tennessee
description: JASPER, Tenn., July 16 (UPI) An Illinoisbound tugboat with a crew of eight ripped out her bottom on shoals and sank in the Tennessee River shortly before midnight. One crewman was presumed drowned.

title: Industrial Output Up Only 0.3%
BON VIVANT'S DATA CALLED FALSIFIED U.S. Inspector Testifies That He Was Told Concern Also Destroyed Records
description: NEWARK, July 16  In sworn testimony that was im mediately and strenuously chal lenged, a Government witness stated today that Bon Vivant Soups, Inc., had falsified about 20 records of its can ning operations that were turned over to the Federal Food and Drug Administration.

title: Ethyl Corp. Announces Plan To Build Plant in France
description: The Ethyl Corporation of Richmond, Va., announced yesterday an agreement to build a $4.4million alkyl alu minum manufacturing facility in Boussens, France, subject to approval by the French Govern ment of an offer by Ethyl to acquire a major interest in Produits Chimiques d'Sidobre Sinnova, S. A. of Neuilly, France, upon whose property the plant will be built.

title: A Correction
description: On June 29 The New York Times printed the winning num ber for the June 28 New Jersey daily lottery, 00491, then in advertently reprinted this num ber in its June 30 issue. The winning number in the June 29 drawing was 62380.

title: GRAY MAY LEAVE WMCA IN DISPUTE
description: GRAY MAY LEAVE WMCA IN DISPUTE Says Yankee Broadcasts Cut His Program Time

title: N.A.S.D. Proposes Change In Criteria for Active List
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., said yesterday it had sent to mem ber firms for comment a pro posal that would revise the listing criteria for NASDAQ stocks.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Emerson Electric Com pany of St. Louis, Mo., has been awarded a $17.9million contract by the Corps of Engi neers acting for the United States Postal Service. The con tract is for construction of con veyor systems for new bulk mailing handling/facilities in seven cities.

title: Relman Morin of A .P. Is Dead; Winner of Two Pulitzer Prizes
description: Relman Morin, an Associated I Press reporter who retired last year after a distinguished ca reer during which he won two Pulitzer Prizes, was found dead yesterday in his apartment, 161 East 66th Street. He was 65 years old.

title: People in Sports: Quarry Gets Bonavena as Rival
description: People in Sports: Quarry Gets Bonavena as Rival

title: Scott Asks Nixon to Offer Papers on Possible Crime'.
description: WASHINGTON. July 16, Reu tersThe Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsyl vania, called on President Nixon today to submit voluntarily to Senate investigators any White House papers that might indi cate that a crime had been committed.

title: Peronist Leftists Fear Campora's Resignation May Lead to a Triumph for Conservatives
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 16  leftwing Peronists are con cerned that Hector J. Camx0020; pora's resignation from the presidency Friday is develop ing into a triumph for con servative political forces in Argentina.

title: 3, With 80's, Finish in Tie In Women's TriCounty Golf
Liquor Store Strike Ends
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 16 (UM)  Pennsylvania's liquor store clerks ratified today a new twoyear contract and of ficially ended an 11day walk out that forced the closing of most of the commonwealth's state stores.

title: Uprising Ends at Virginia Prison
description: RICHMOND, July 16 (AP) About 100 prisoners holding out in two dormitories at the Virginia Prison Farm abandoned their rebellion today after state troopers and guards retook three cellblocks held by other in mates.

title: Soviet Vows Aid as Hanoi Chiefs Leave
description: MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 17 A highlevel North Vietnam ese delegation has concluded an eightday visit to the Soviet Union with announcement of broad new Soviet economic aid for North Vietnam's postwar reconstruction.

title: Inside Is the In Place
description: In the old days young men who wanted to meet the right kind of peo ple went to Yale. In the future, seems, they will have to go to jail.

title: Environmental Protection Unit Holds Pollution Curbs Hearings
description: CAMDEN, July 16 (AP) Paul Miller is afraid he may become an endangered species.

title: America and Europe: Balancing Accounts
description: AUSTIN, Tex.Three weeks of mov ing about Europe left these impressions:

title: Transport of New Jersey Asks Interstate Rate Rises
description: MAPLEWOOD, July 16 Transport of New Jersey, the state's largest bus company, has asked the Interstate Com merce Commission to approve rate increases on almost half of its major routes operating into New York City and Philadel phia.

title: Charge of Nixon Threat Out
description: PORTLAND, Me, July 16 (AP) A charge that a Lewiston man uttered an oral threat on President Nixon's life was dis missed today in United States District Court after a Secret Service agent testified that he was not certain that Nestor J. Simones had been advised of his constitutional rights.

title: M'ALOON OUTPOINTS MURPHY IN 10 ROUNDS
description: In charge over the last eight rounds, Danny McAloon of the Bronx scored a unanimous de cision over Irish Pat Murphy of West New York, N.J., last night in a 10round junior middle weight fight at the Felt Forum.

title: Egg Producers Seek Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) The United Egg Producers sought a Congressional inves tigation today into whether five or six major grain dealers in the United States drove up feed grain prices and thus food prices. In testimony before the House monopoly subcommittee. the organization said earnings of the major grain dealers rose 15 to 63 nor cent as feed grain prices went up 300 per cent.

title: East Germany Won't Bar Berliners From Festival
description: BERLIN, July 16The East Germans, under pressure from the West, today called off a ban they had intended to im pose to keep West Berliners out of East Germany during a Com munist festival in East Berlin.

title: Benefit Football Game Set Here on Sept. 22
description: Grambling College will play Morgan State in the annual Whitney M. Young Jr. memorial football game at Yankee Stadium on Sept. 22. The game, played for the benefit of the New York Urban League's educational programs, will he the sixth between the two colleges, both noted for the number of alumni who have gained re nown in professional foot ball. The Grambling teams from Louisiana have won the last four.

title: Wallace Sees Liberal Shift
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 16 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace said today that political leaders who have been ultraliberal see now that the center is the place to get. His comment was prompted by questions about the reaction of people in Ala bama to his appearance with Senator Edward M. Kennedy at a July 4 celebration.

title: Nixon Still Gaining
description: President Nixon was re ported yesterday to be pro gressing satisfactorily in his recovery from viral pneu monia at the Bethesda Naval Hospital. Details on Page 27.

title: Football Transactions NATIONAL CONFERENCE
description: DALLASTrimmed II rookies: Ted Buck of Boise State, David Vodika of Cincinnati and Gerald Caswell, all offensive line. men; Chris Gartner of Indiana and Robert Roca of L.S.U.New Orleans, both kickers; Larry Harris of Tennessee State and Zachery Rogers of Norfolk State, both wide receivers; Mike White, Minnesota defen sive back; Don Heater, Montana Tech run ning back; Larry Jones, Morehouse de fensive lineman; and Bill Pipp, Indiana linebacker.

title: Excerpts From Testimony Before the Senate Committee Investigating Watergate
description: WASHINGTON. July 16 Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony today on the 20th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:WASHINGTON, July 16Following are the names individuals who figured today in hearings by the Senate select committee on the Watergate case:

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Clifton Council Names New Mayor

title: Japan Urges `More Discipline In U.S. Economy at Conference,
description: TOKYO, July I6  Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira to day admonished Secretary of State William P. Rogers and other highlevel American of ficials on flaws in the man agement of the American econ omy as seen by the Japanese. The occasion was the opening of a United StatesJapan eco nomic conference.

title: Tapings in Johnson Era Both Alleged and Denied
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The White House confirmed today that nearly all of Presi dent Nixon's official meetings and telephone conversations had been secretly recorded since 1971.

title: Policyholders Held Unusually Loyal To Equity Funding
description: An Illinois official said yes terday that policyholders of the Equity Funding Life Insurance Company, which is enmeshed in a huge fraud involving the creation of fake insurance policies, appeared to be un usually loyal.

title: MORTGAGE RATES RAISED BY JERSEY; Increase to 8% Is Designed to Attract More Money Albany May Follow Suit
description: TRENTON, July 16State Banking Commissioner Richard F. Schaub today raised the in terest rate lenders may charge on mortgages to 8 per cent from 7 per cent in a move designed to attract more money to the market.

title: Chemical Producer Reassigning Some Key Executives
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. yesterday reported record sales and earnings for the sec ond quarter and first six months of this year. It also announced major management appointments.

title: US. StudentLoan Unit Schedules Stock Offering
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 The newest Governmentspon sored financial agency began operations today with the an nouncement of the offering of $105million worth of stock by the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae.

title: Poachers Feared in Treasure Hunt on Coast of Florida
description: KEY WEST, Fla., July 16 Florida marine patrolmen, whose daytoday job in cludes keeping peace be tween spiny lobster and stone crab fishermen in the Florida Keys, now are being forced to keep an eye out for treasure poachers.

title: DEFICIT FORECAST ON MEMBER FIRMS Needham, in Plea to S.E.C. for Rate Rise, Says Loss May Total $192Million
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The New York Stock Exchange appeal for a $300million in crease in fixed commission rates of member firms opened before the Securities and Exchange Commission today with an esti mate by James J. Needham, chairman of the exchange, that members losses in the tirst half of 1973 would total $192million.

title: Derby Plane Forced Down
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., July 16 (AP)A plane in the Powder Puff Derby, a transcontinental air race for women, was forced down in Iowa by a loss of power, but the pilots won a farmer's thanks for landing in his cornfield instead of his soybeans: The pilots, who were not injured, said the farmer had told them that corn was only $2 a bushhel but soybeans were $7.

title: HERMAN GREENBERG
description: Herman Greenberg, a finan cial consultant who was assist ant general manager of the American Society of Com posers, Authors and Publishers from 1922 to 1949, died yester day in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L,I. He was 77

title: TERRORISM GROUP OPENS U.N. PARLEY But Hope Is Scant for Basis for Concrete Action
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 16A committee on inter national terrorism opened a fourweek meeting here today with but scant hope among the 35 member nations participat ing that it would be able to agree upon a formula for con crete actions.

title: DASH'S PARENTS SEE HIM AS A STAR ON TV
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 16 (AP)Joseph and Ida Dash have had to change some of their routines since their son has become the star of a day time television series.

title: His Very Own Uncle Sam
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y.  think it occurred when Senator Gurney turned to Senator Ervin and accused him of harassing the witness, not questioning him, that I sensed my strong personal affection for Senator Sam, affection beyond respect, affec tion approaching family feeling. I was not merely stunned by the vilification, I was pained; as if my favorite uncle or grandfather, whom I knew to be good and just, were being slandered in full public view.

title: Lon Nol Is Said to Decline Reported Nixon Invitation
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 16Authoritative sources here report that President Nixon sent President Lon Nol of Cambodia a letter early this month inviting him to come to the United States for medical treatment related to his stroke in 1971, but that the invitation was declined, reportedly in the belief that it was a move to ease him out of power.

title: Cost Rises for U.S. Home Port in Greece
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The General Accounting Office informed Congress today that the Navy had underestimated the cost of establishing a home port for a carrier task force in Greece, partly because it had failed to ask the Greek Gov ernment whether a port near Athens would be available.

title: Justice Or Revenge?
description: During the fourday uprising at the Attica Correctional Facility in Septem ber, 1971, a total of 43 persons were killedone correction officer who was assaulted by inmates during the first minutes of the revolt, three inmates apparently murdered by other inmates during the time they held prison yard D, and 39 inmates and hostages killed by gunfire when D yard was recap tured.

title: Court Rejects Plea to Bar Judge in Sterilization Case
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 16 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit re fused today to disqualify United States District Court Judge Robert Varner of Montgomery from hearing a $5million dam age suit growing out of the sterilization of two teenaged Montgomery black girls.

title: KALMBACH'S TURN
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Herbert W. Kalmbach, a per sonal attorney and key po litical fundraiser for President Nixon, described to the Senate Watergate committee today how, during a series of secret meetings and clandestine calls from telephone booths, he raised $220,000 for the seven Watergate defendants.

title: U.S. Planes Strike At Targets 7 Miles From Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 16 (UPI)American planes struck within seven miles of Phnom Penh today in an effort to repel what official sources described as a growing threat to the capital.

title: The Wolf and Kangaroo Put on Endangered List
description: ALBANY, July 16 (UPI) The wolf and kangaroo have been added to the State De partment of Agriculture and Market's list of endangered species, it was announced to day.

title: Market Place: Average Stock Vs. Indicators
description: Many investors who check the averages periodically complain that their stocks are lower than the socalled indicators would imply.

title: CaseFixing Linked To Koota's Office By Bond Swindler
description: WASHINGTON, July 16A convicted bond swindler has told a Senate committee of two examples of casefixing in the Brooklyn District Attorney's of fice during the tenure of Aaron F. Koota, now a State Supreme Court justice.

title: Flambe Aqueduct Victor,Eclat Disqualified
description: Jorge Velasquez, among the leading riders on the New York circuit, rarely offers an objec tion against a rival jockey, but he felt himself forced to do so at Aqueduct yesterday. Riding S'gmund Sommer's Flambe in the feature race of a mile, Ve lasquez mount finished second to Eclat, who races in the silks of Robert Evans.

title: Import Curb in Trade Bill Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)The House Ways and Means Committee turned down today an effort to write major importlimitation provision into President Nixon's trade legislation.WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)The chairman of the Senate surface transportation subcommittee introduced bill today aimed at restructuring the railroad system in 18 Northeastern and Midwestern states.WASHINGTON, July 16 (Reuters)The Senate com pleted final Congressional action today on two measures suspending duties on copper and metal scrap.

title: IDA BAILEY ALLEN, COOKBOOK AUTHOR
description: Ida Bailey Allen, author of more than 50 cookbooks an other books, sales of which were estimated at 20 million copies, died yesterday in the Notre Dame Convalescent home in Norwalk, Conn. She was 88 years old and formerly lived here.

title: Jordan Breaks Off Tie With Tunisia; Bourguiba Blamed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17 Jordan broke off diplomatic re lations with Tunisia today over recent statements made by the Tunisian President, Habib Bour guiba. He described the Jor danian nation as an artificial entity and called for replacing it with an Arab Palestinian na tion.

title: Moynihan and Mrs. Gandhi Meet On U.S. Aid and Rupee Problem
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  Daniel P. Moynihan, the United States Ambassador to India, met with the Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in New Delhi to day to begin discussions on how to dispose of $840million in rupees owned by the United States.

title: 120 Miles From Capital, a Rural Uruguayan Asks, What Crisis?
description: SAUCE DEL YI, Uruguay, July 13  It's only 120 miles from Montevideo to Sauce de Yi but it's a journey to a dif ferent and distinctly calmer world.

title: 5 STATIONS CALLED IN PAYOLA INQUIRY Given Subpoenas to Appear Before U.S. Grand Jury
description: At least five radio stations in the New York area have been subpoenaed to appear before Federal grand jury in Newark that is investigating allegations of payola, drug use and organ izedcrime involvement in the record industry.

title: G.O.P. Committee, Facing Deficit, to Cut Staff 25%
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)  The Republican National Committee, facing a $1million deficit because of shrinking contributions, announced to day a 25 per cent cut in its staff.

title: The Lying Campaigners
description: Senator Sam Ervin, Chairman of the Senate committee investigating the Watergate affair and related matters, voiced the conventional wisdom on the subject recently when he said that the scandal was a result of people with financial and political power at tempting to distort the process by which Presidents are elected.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Deposed Afghan King Mohammad Zahir Shah
description: In the summer of 1968 Mo hammad Zahir Shah, then King of Afghanistan for near ly 35 years and one of the world's longestreigning mon archs, paid a personal call on his brotherinlaw and first cousin, Prince Mohammad Daud Khan in Kabul.

title: REPUBLICANS FAIL TO CUT WAGE BILL Move for Lower Minimum Is Defeated, 78 to 19
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 The Senate rejected today a Republican effort to scale down a proposed new minimum wage for nearly 47 million workers from $2.20 an hour to $2.05 an hour.

title: PHONE TAP INQUIRY IS ASKED BY F.C.C. A.T.&T. to Study Reported White House Violations
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Federal Communications Com mission asked the American Telephone and Telegraph Com pany today to investigate the reported violation of company tariffs by the White House in connection with recording de vices placed on telephones used by President Nixon.

title: A Better Mass Transit System Is Urged at E. P. A. Hearings
description: TRENTON, July 17 (AP)  Spokesmen for the Sierra Club, the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce and the Atlantic Richfield Oil Company agreed today that one way the state could reduce its air pollution would be to improve mass transportation.TRENTON, July 17  Gov ernor Cahill met today with representatives of 25 communi ties along the New York and Long Branch Railroad to dis cuss unsafe conditions of the tracks and roadbed. Mr. Cahill indicated that any state action to help the communities would not come until several legal and safety studies were com pleted, possibly within a week.

title: U.S. SQUAD TAKES GOLDMEDAL RACE Captures 9 of 10 Wrestling Finals for Total of 76 as Maccabiah Games End
description: TEL AVIV, July 17 (UPI) The United States captured nine of 10 gold medals in wrestling today to surge ahead of Israel on the final day of the Macca biah Gaines, but the host coun try defeated the Americans, 8680, in the basketball final.

title: Bahamas Supported at U.N. For Entry at Session in Fall
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 17The Committee on the Ad mission of New Members rec ommended unanimously today that the Bahamas be admitted to the United Nations.

title: French Clergy, Army Clash Over ATests
description: PARIS, July 17Two pillars of the French Establishment the church and the military are clashing over the protests of high Roman Catholic prelates against France's imminent nu clear tests in the South Pacific.MELBOURNE, Australia, July 7 (AP) French naval forces boarded the American  owned chooner Fri, which sailed into he security zone for France's planned nuclear tests, accord ng to a report today from an other vessel in the area.

title: Bill to Permit Ads On Taxis Approved By City Council Unit
description: The city's 11,800 medallion taxicabs will be allowed to carry exterior advertising under a bill approved yesterday by the City Council's Committee on Con sumer Affairs.

title: Soviet Is Said to Jail Dissident for Second Term
description: MOSCOW, July 17  Andrei A. Amalrik, a dissident author who has just completed a three year prison term for his writ ings, was sentenced to another three years today without being released after his first term dissident sources reported to night.

title: GOVERNOR PUSHES UPSTATE TRANSIT Contends State May Acquire Trackage Under Proposal Covered by Bond Issue
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 17Governor Rockefeller said today there was a very good possibility that the state would acquire upstate railroad track age under his new transit bond plan and contract with railroad companies to maintain services for small communities that had no air service.

title: Debacle in the Senate
description: In a shocking display of irresponsibility, the Senate has voted to give the oil industry an exemption from the National Environmental Policy Act with regard to the Alaskan pipeline. Since it is always difficult to combat the oil industry on Capitol Hill because it contributes to so many political campaigns and has so many strate gicallyplaced allies, the environmental forces can take some comfort from the hair'sbreadth closeness of the key vote, a tie decided in the wrong way by Vice Presi dent Agnew. But it is cold comfort.

title: Computerized Signs To Help L.I. Drivers
description: The state announced yester day that it would install computeroperated system to guide and inform motorists along a 30mile congested cor ridor including the Long Island Expressway and parallel high ways.

title: Boston Tower's Plywood Windows
description: BOSTON, July 17  Soaring 60 stories, towering over the skyline, de signed to seem to almost disappear despite its great bulk, to reflect open spaces and historic buildings, rises the John Hancock Tower, its sides covered with gleaming, reflective glass and ... plywood?

title: CONNORS UPSETS SMITH BY 63, 63 Ashe Extended in Beating Solomon at Brookline
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., July 17 (UPI) Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., upset topseeded Stan Smith, 6.3, 63, in the first round of the $60,000 United States professional tennis championships tonight.KITZBUEHEL, Austria, July 17 (UPI)Two seeded players, Bjorn Borg of Sweden and ColinLOUISVILLE, Ky., July 17 (UPI)Topseeded Billy Martin of Palo Verdes, Calif., routed Peter Osier of Ann Arbor, Mich., 60, 60, to set the pace in the second round of the na tional junior claycourt tennis championships today. Howard Schoenfield of Beverly. Hills, Calif., firstseeded in the 16's, overcame Mike Benado of, East Meadow, L. I., 62, 63.

title: Kennedy Had Tapes On Sensitive Talks
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 17 President Kennedy made tape recordings of both telephone conversations and staff meet ings in the White House, the director of the Kennedy Library said tonight.WASHINGTON, July 17  When the Shah of Iran, Pre mier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan and Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia visit President Nixon later this month, they will be the first visitors from overseas whose conversations with the Presi dent will be recorded with their foreknowledge.

title: Metals Earnings Up
description: The resurgence of the met als industry was confirmed yesterday in quarterly reports filed by the two leading metal container manufacturers, sev eral steel companies and the leading machinetool maker.

title: Pompidou: The Politician
description: PARISIf lie had to make a deci sion today on whether to run for second term as head of the Fifth Re public, President Georges Pompidou would stand for office again when his present term expires in 1976. This means, were he to regain the position, that he would remain chief of state past the age of seventy.

title: Paterson Mayor Beats Summons
description: PATERSON. July 17May or Thomas C. Rooney Jr. of Paterson, who is feuding with policemen over a pay raise, was found not guilty today of illegal parking on a side, walk on July 5.

title: Marijuana Measure Killed
description: BOSTON, July 17 (AP)The, Massachusetts Senate, after more than three hours of de bate today, killed a bill that would have removed criminal penalties for possession of mari juana in quantities of one ounce or less.

title: CITY INVESTING SETS SALE OF PACIFIC UNIT
description: The City Investing Company announced yesterday that it would sell its 50 per cent in vestment in Pacific Area Invest ments Pty., Ltd., an Australian holding company to Broken Hill Proprietary, Ltd., Australia's largest corporation.

title: Trading Suspended in Chain's Stock
description: Trading in the stock of Alex ander's, Inc., one of New York's largest retailers, was suspended yesterday pending a news an nouncement that reportedly will involve an offer to pur chase control of Alexander's.

title: G. H. WALKER &
description: G. H. Walker & Co., Inc., an nounced plans yesterday to ac quire the securities brokerage business of Laird, Inc. Both are mediumsized firms of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Rationing of Gas Ends
description: NORFOLK, July 17 (AP) Navy outlets stopped rationing gas here today after operating more than six weeks under a 12gallonacustomer limit.

title: House Allows Old Steamboat To Continue Passenger Runs
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)  The paddlewheeler Delta Queen should be allowed to continue carrying passengers on overnight voyages along the nation's rivers, the House de cided today.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: A New Game Plan
description: The center of the controversy over alleged Presidential usurpation of legis lative powers is the impoundment of appropriated funds. Although this is a timehonored practice (and fre quently a useful administrative de vice), it bears within it the seeds of abuse of Presidential powers. The power to check such abuse is not beyond the authority of Congress. Legislation with a provision for re view would enable either House to negate impoundments.

title: Excerpts From Kalmbach's Testimony Before the Senate Watergate Committee
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony today by Herbert W. Kalm bach on the 22d day of hear ings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Com mittee on Presidential Cam paign Activities:WASHINGTON, July 17Following are the names of individuals who figured today in hearings by the Senate select committee on the Watergate case:

title: WESTPORT DROPS APARTMENT PLAN New Regulation Overturned. at Town Meeting After Angry Controversy
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Wednes day, July 18  An innovative and controversial measure that would have allowed apartment houses here for the first time was defeated early today amid fears that it would have marked the beginning of the end of Westport as an affluent suburb of singlefamily homes.

title: Former Executive Loses His Lawsuit Against The Times
description: A lawsuit by a former execu tive of The New York Times who was seeking damages for stock benefits that he lost when he resigned from the news paper company was dismissed yesterday in Federal Court here.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 10353
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers In sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, The second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: MARINAS FINDING THIEVES BOLDER
description: Thefts from pleasure boats moored at marinas in the metropolitan area are stirring increasing concern because, while boats are becoming more elaborate and expensive, the police are being diverted from marine patrols to what officials consider more pressing street duty.

title: Watkins Glen: Super Road Show
description: About Motor Sports

title: Senate, 7720, Votes For Alaska Pipeline
Hugh Mulligan, Reputed Briber And Major Bookmaker, Is Dead
description: Hugh Mulligan, reputedly a major bookmaker and briber of police officials, died on Sunday in Queens General Hospital. He, was 62 years old and lived at 9009 220th Street, Queens Village.

title: Texts of Letters and Excerpts From Statements About Release of White House Tapes Involving Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Following are the texts of letters from George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury, to Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr.. chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, from President Nixon to Secretary Shultz, and from Senator Ervin to the President; and excerpts from remarks by Senators Ervin. and Howard H. Baker Jr., the committee vice chairman, all relating to efforts by the committee to gain access to the recordings of conversations that took place in the President's of fices involving the Watergate scandal:

title: A.B.C.TV at Work On Morning Show To Vie With `Today
description: The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday the appointment of Steve Mills, its West Coast vice president for entertainment, to supervise the development of a new morning TV entertainment, news and information program.

title: I Dr. Michael Cherniaysky, RussianHistory Scholar
description: Dr. Michael Cherniaysky, An drew Mellon Professor of His tory at the University of Pitts burgh and an adjunct professor at Columbia University, died Thursday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 50 years old.

title: 4 Pupils Fingerprinted As Others Balk in Inquiry
description: NEWARK, July 17  Four former eighthgrade Newark boys have already been finger printed in a murder investiga tion that has involved 50 to 160 pupils at the Martin Luther King Jr. Elementary School here.

title: F.T.C. in Reshuffle To Guard Consumer On Unfair Practice
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission announced today a major re organization of its consumer protection office in a move it said was designed to guard the public against unfair and de ceptive business practices.

title: Panel Designates Park Slope Section A Historic Area
description: A swath of nearly two dozen blocks of Victorian houses in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn was designated a historic district yesterday by the City's Landmarks Preserva tion Commission.

title: Rape Defendants Are Sentenced After Accepting Lesser Charges
description: One of three defendants in a series of rapes and robberies said to involve as many as 18 victims was sentenced yester day to a maximum penalty of 25 years in prison after plead ing guilty to first degree rob bery. He may be paroled in eight and onethird years.

title: Nader Assails Spending for Food Ads
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Ralph Nader, the consumer ad vocate, attacked advertising to day as a major contributor to rising food prices and monopo listic trends in the food in dustry.

title: Bluegrass Hitting High Note Tonight
description: The bluegrass of Kentucky may seem a long way from the asphalt of Manhattan. Nonetheless the sawing fid dles, feverishly plinking banjos and high tenor har monies of bluegrass and other kinds of traditional country music are being heard more and more these days here. And at 7:30 o'clock tonight in Philharmonic Hall, three bluegrass bands will appear in what amounts to the first major forum in years for this sort of music.

title: Corporate Profile Industry Awaits American Airline Meeting
description: The airline community will be keeping watch on the American Airlines board meeting here today for pos sible repercussions from the admission by the company's chairman, George A. Spater, that $55,000 in company funds were illegally contrib uted to President Nixon's campaign.

title: Kennedy to Be Speaker At Byrne FundRaising
description: TRENTON, July 17Sena tor Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts will be the main speaker at the Demo cratic fundraising gala Sept. 6 at the National Guard en campment in Sea Girt, James P. Dugan, state Democratic chairman, announced today.

title: French Clergy, Army Clash Over ATests
description: PARIS, July 17Two pillars of the French Establishment the church and the military are clashing over the protests of high Roman Catholic prelates against France's imminent nu clear tests in the South Pacific.MELBOURNE, Australia, July 17 (AP)  French naval forces boarded the American  owned schooner Fri, which sailed into the security zone for France's planned nuclear tests, accord ing to a report today from an other vessel in the area.

title: HENRY D. HALPERIN
description: Henry D. Halperin, retired president of the PennAkron Corporation, manufacturer of brass materials in Terryville, Conn., died Monday in Doctors Hospital. He was 78 years old and had lived in Hollywood, Fla., since his retirement.

title: DataTechnology Impact Watergate Affair Can Be Considered A Result of New Information Process
description: The highly dramatic Water gate affair can be interpreted in many waysbut one that deserves more attention than it has thus far received is to see it as a fallout of the new infor mation technology.

title: WILSON CHARGES AFRICAN ATROCITY But British Aide Questions Mozambique Report
description: LONDON, July 17 (UPI) Harold Wilson, leader of the Opposition, today denounced as a most outrageous and bestial atrocity an alleged massacre of 400 Africans in Mozambique by Portuguese troops.UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17The Portuguese mis sion here asserted today that the Rev. Adrian Hastings, a Roman Catholic priest who is to make an appearance here Friday, had an antiPortuguese bias and that his report of massacres in Mozambique was less than plausible.LOURENCO MARQUES, Mo zambique, July 17 (Agence FrancePresse)  Thousands of people demonstrated last night and early today against the campaign of accusations in Brit ain alleging Portuguese atroci ties in this East African terri tory.

title: Leftist Workers in Argentina Strike After Raid by Rightists
description: Meanwhile, Government sour ces said that the interim Cabi net would set Sept. 2 as the date for presidential elections.

title: Kalmbach Says Strangers Got $400,000 From Him
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  Herbert W. Kalmbach testified oday that, under orders from he White House, he provided $400,000 in cash three years go to men he had never seen before and whose names he still did not know.

title: Colleges Reaffirm Ties
description: AMHERST, Mass., July 17 (AP)Kichizo Niwa, the presi dent of the University of Hok kaido in Japan, concluded a threeday visit to the Univer sity of Massachusetts today as part of an ongoing affilia tion between the two schools.

title: Suspect in Nixon Threat
description: SEATTLE, July 17 (AP)A man sought by the Secret Ser vice in connection with an alleged threat to the life of President Nixon turned him self in to the Seattle police yesterday. The suspect, identi fied as Harold Kenneth Culp, was held on charges of arson connected with a hotel fire.

title: CANADIANS COOL TO SENATE'S VOTE Oil Spill Damage Feared on British Columbia Coast
description: OTTAWA, July 17  When it approved the Alaska pipe line project today, the United States Senate won no applause in Ottawa. The Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has long opposed the landandtanker route in the belief that inevitable oil spills would despoil the 500mile British Columbia coast.

title: Notes on People 2 New Names Appear on the Map of Africa
description: On maps of Africa sub stitute the name Lake Idi Amin (after the President of Uganda) for Lake Edward, the body of water along the border of Zaire and Uganda. At the same time, sub stitute the name Lake Mobutu Sese Seko (after the President of Zaire) for Lake Albert, also on the border.

title: Cambodia to Begin First Military Draft
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 17 (UPI)  The Cambodian, Government announced today that it, had decided to draft men for the armed forces for the first time since war broke out three years ago.PEKING, July 17 (Agence, FrancePresse)  Prince Noro dom Sihanouk suggested today that if the United States agreed to a solution of the Cambodian problem, it should communi cate through President Moktar Ould Daddah of Mauritania.

title: Bills Shaw Gets Eagle
description: BUFFALO, July 17 (AP)  Dennis Shaw, quarterback for the Buffalo Bills, scored an eagle at the Wanakah Country Club today. He used two woods and holed out with a No. 7 iron on the par5, 525yard fifth hole for the eagle 3.

title: Financial Help Is Sought By Rock Island Railroad
description: The Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad said yesterday it currently was seeking short or mediumterm financial help.

title: Places to Take the Children
description: Films

title: Jockeys Have to Pass Physicals With Flying Colors
description: After his heart, lungs, eyes and blood pressure were ex amined yesterday, Jack Stur geon, a weatherbeaten jock ey, made his racing debut in New York.

title: States Fair Man Is the Envy of Bureaucrats
End to Economic Controls Planned on Industry Basis
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  John T. Dunlop, the director of the Cost of Living Council, dis closed today that the Nixon Administration, which will an nounce its Phase 4 program to morrow, planned to take an industrybyindustry approach to ending price and wage con trols.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, July 17 (UPI)  Bettors still are holding 5,066 uncashed win tickets worth $11,170 on Secretariat from his victory June 30 in an invitation race at Arlington Park, it was announced today. Although there was win bet ting only, with $2 tickets returning $2.10, the race created a minus pool of $17,941.35. A track spokesman said there still were seven $50 tickets, 45 $10 tickets, 114 $5 tickets and 4,900 $2 tickets uncashed on Secretariat. The $11,170 outstanding will be thrown into the minus pool to reduce the amount the track had to provide for the minimumMACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 17 (AP)Baybea, the 12Meter yacht piloted by Pat Haggerty of Sturgeon Bay, Wis., turned in a corrected winning time of 54.72 hours and was declared the winner today of the 66th ChicagotoMackinac Island race. The Scaramouche, cap tained by Chuck Kirsch of Chicago, placed second, and third was the Ensign IV, sailed by Chester Ensign Jr. Apostle Island Yacht Club, Duluth, Minn, Sassy, skippered by E. R. Schmidt of Grosse Point, Mich., was the first boat to reach the island for the second year in a row, but her corrected handicap time made her fourth. Sassy also lost last year on corrected time.STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 17 (AP)Ameri cans captured four of five gold medals in pentathlon events today at the Paralympics, the Olympic Games for the handicapped. Participants competed in javelin, shotput, archery, 50meter swimming and 100meter track events classes based on degrees of handicap.

title: 7 Model Cities Programs Facing End in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) Seven of the 32 Model Cities programs here will be forced to close Oct. 31 because of re duced Federal financing, local officials report.

title: Senate,7720,Votes For Alaska Pipeline
Police Tow 67 Cars in Crackdown on Illegal Parking in the Village
description: The Police Department continued to crack down on illegally parked cars yester day with a ticket blitz and towing operation in the Greenwich Village area.

title: Rockefeller Undisturbed By White House Tapes
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 17Governor Rockefeller, an occasional visitor to the

title: White House Cites Executive Privilege in Withholding Nixon's Tape Recordings
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The White House cited the doctrine of executive privilege today in taking measures to prevent the disclosure of information about tape recordings of President Nixon's conversations.

title: RAISE FOR JORDAN PUT OFF BY COUNCIL Increases for Other Jersey City Aides Also Delayed
description: JERSEY CITY, July 17 (AP) The City Council delayed pro posed pay raises today for Mayor Paul T. Jordan and his chief aides, and decided that if raises were granted, they would come on the installment plan.

title: Agnew Has No Objections To His Talks Being Taped
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) Vice President Agnew said today that he had no objection to his White House conversa itions with President Nixon hav ing been secretly taperecorded by the Secret Service.

title: Mosbacher Named
description: Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., the yachtsman, Republican fundraiser and chief of pro tocol in President Nixon's first administration, was named by Governor Rocke feller as the $65,000ayear chairman of the newly creat ed State Racing and Wager ing Board. Details, Page 25,

title: Grandparents Get a Day
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 17 (UPI)The last Sunday in Sep tember will be Grandparents' Day in Arizona, by proclama tion of Gov. Jack Williams, issued yesterday.

title: Our Schools and Our Moral Values; A Village Landmark That Must Be Spared; U.S. Agents Can Be Sued; The Watergates of the Past; U.S. Economic Policy: Will They Ever Learn?; Where Fuel Is Plentiful; To Save Health and Fuel
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Mosbacher to Head Racing Unit
description: Governor Rockefeller dis closed yesterday the appoint ment of Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., the yachtsman and Repub lican fundraiser, as chairman of the newly created State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: STONES, WOTTLE PACE U.S. IN TRACK
description: TURIN, Italy, July 17 (AP) Dwight Stones, the world rec ordholder, cleared 7 feet 4 inches in the high jump today, helping the United States men gain a 6936 lead over Italy in the first day of their twoday track and field meet.

title: DEPORTATION STAY WON BY 4 GYPSIES U.S. ears Entry, But Won't Attempt to Enforce Rule
description: An immigration judge ruled yesterday that four gypsies from Poland were ineligible to enter the United States, but the Government will make no at tempt to deport them until it finds a country willing to take them in.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, July 17 (AP)  Japanese and Soviet officials signed today a memorandum under which the Soviet Union would receive $150million in United States and Japanese bank loans and supply 1.5 million tons of liquefied natural gas (LNG) over 20 years to the United States and Japan.AMSTERDAM, July 17 (Reuters)  The Netherlands will raise its bank rate to 6 per cent from 5 per cent, starting tomorrow, the central bank announced today. The rate had stood at 5 per cent since June 28.

title: Court Voids Ban on Marriages by the Merchant Marine Academy
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday struck down as un constitutional a regulation of the United States Merchant Marine Academy that prohibits marriage by cadets.

title: War Powers Test ...
description: Congressional efforts to bring Presidential warmaking under controlnot just in Indochina but in the case possible future conflictscome to the fore again as the House resumes debate today on a new war powers bill.

title: Bellmon Opposes Taping
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) Senator Henry BeIlmon, Re publican of Oklahoma, who debugged his office as Okla homa Governor, said today that he still disapproved of record ing conversations secretly. He commented to reporters on the disclosure that President Nixon had used the take recorders by saying, This ought to make honest people out of some body.

title: DAVID ROCKEFELLER BACKS SOVIET TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, urged Congress today to grant favored trading status to the Soviet Union.

title: Howard at Bat
description: New Jersey Sports Howard at Bat

title: Computerized Signs To Help L.I. Drivers
description: The state announced yester day that it would install a computeroperated system to guide and inform motorists along a 30mile congested cor ridor including the Long Island Expressway and parallel high ways.

title: The Dangling Man
description: WASHINGTON, July 17In the Wat ergate catastrophe that has engulfed him, Mr. Nixon is fighting desperately against two separate but interrelated dangers. As an individual, he has to defend himself against highly detailed charges that he is guilty of obstruct ing justice and of other crimes. As President, he has to cope with a crisis of public confidence in his Adminis tration and its ability to govern.

title: India Still Studying Goods Confiscated From Youthful Guru
description: NEW DELHI, July 17 (Reuters)The Government is still investigating the seizure of undeclared goods worth more than $80,000 from a 15year old Indian guru when he ar rived here last November, of ficials here report.

title: 2 British Soldiers And Civilian Killed By Bombs in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Wednesday, July 18 (AP)Two British soldiers and at least one civilian were killed in terrorist bomb explosions in Northern Ireland last night. At least 18 persons were reported wounded.DUBLIN, July 17 An Irish Canadian appeared before the Special Criminal Court here to day charged with importing the arms seized yesterday after a British ship arrived from Mont real. John P. D. Murphy ofScar borough, Ontario, was charged with illegally importing 17 rifles, 30,530 rounds of ammunition, 1,800 blank ammunition cases and 60 pounds of gunpowder.

title: Hanoi Skips a Saigon Parley; U.S. Dubious of Its Intentions
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (AP)The North Viet namese delegation to the joint military team investigating the missing in the Indochina. war !failed to attend a scheduled (meeting today, and the United States said this raised serious questions about Hanoi's inten tions,

title: The Nixon Tapes
description: President Nixon has been maneuvered into a danger ously untenable position, if he really means what he had his spokesman say. The secret tape recordings meetings in the President's offices are considered Presi dential papers, Mr. Ziegler has announced, and thus barred from scrutiny by the Senate Watergate investi gation.

title: Afghan King Overthrown; A Republic Is Proclaimed
description: NEW DELHI, July 17The mountainous kingdom of Afghanistan was proclaimed a republic today in a coup d'etat led by a brotherinlaw of King Mohammad Zahir

title: British Recognize Han of Government
description: LONDON, July 17 (Reuters). Britain announced diplomatic recognition of North Vietnam today.

title: New U.S. Envoy Is in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (AP)Graham A. Mar tin arrived in Saigon today to take over as United States Am bassador. He succeeds Ells worth Bunker, who left May 11. Mr. Martin's arrival was held up by the United States Senate's delay in confirming him.

title: Opposition to Pension Proposal Easing Among State Employes
description: The united opposition of pub lic employe unions to proposed changes in pension benefits for future members is apparently foundering, with police and fire units generally jubilant that they have been chosen to main tain most of their current bene fits and with other units ada mant that changes should not be made.

title: TAXPLAN APPEAL DRAWS CRITICISM Jordan Assails G.O.P. Chiefs on School FinancingMaps Plea to Supreme Court
description: TRENTON, July 17Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City today labeled as purely politi cal the decision of legislative leaders to appeal the State Su preme Court ruling that over turned New Jersey's system of financing public schools through local property taxes.

title: Carson Is Released On Bail of $50,000 After Denying Guilt
description: Robert C. (Sonny) Carson and two other men weer released on bail last night after their afternoon arraignment on kid napping, murder and other charges listed in an indictment returned Monday by a Brooklyn grand jury, Mr. Carson's lawyer said.

title: PRICE CONSPIRACY BY 8 OIL CONCERNS CHARGED BY F.T.C. 23Year Bid to Monopolize the Refining of Petroleum Products Is Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Federal Trade Commission ac cused the nation's eight largest oil companies today of conspir ing, over a period of at least 23 years, to monopolize the refin ing of petroleum products.

title: CLASH ON SECRECY Senators in Appeal to President in Spirit of Conciliation
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  President Nixon ordered the Secret Service today to with hold from the Senate Water gate committee all information about secretly made recordings of the President's White House conversations.

title: Judge Throws Out Murder Conviction of One Defendant in Harlem Six Case
description: A murder conviction in the controversial Harlem Six case was thrown out yesterday by Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. in Federal Court here.

title: Afghanistan: In Brief
description: GEOGRAPHY  Afghanistan is a landlocked country lying in the heart of Asia. Her 650,000 square miles are bounded on the north by the Soviet Union, on the west by Iran, on the east by China and on the south by Pakistan. The terrain is rugged, with temperatures ranging from the bitter winter cold of the Hindu Kush mountains of the northeast, to the 120degree summer heat of the south west lowlands.

title: Roundup: White Sox Win In Day and Night at Boston
description: The Chicago White Sox, who have been finding runs hard to come by in the last month, seemed to have dis covered their batting eyes again, despite the absence of Dick Allen from the lineup.

title: The French in South Vietnam Are Seeing Their Influence Revive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. July 17  After years of mutual scorn and bickering, South Vietnam and France have sud lenly become friendlier this summer, and the French are emerging once again as a major influence in their former colony.

title: Mosbacher Named
description: Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., the yachtsman, Republican fundraiser and chief of pro tocol in President Nixon's first administration, was named by Governor Rocke feller as the $65,000ayear chairman of the newly creat ed State Racing and Wager ing Board. Details, Page 25.

title: DOLLAR DECLINES ON THE CONTINENT
description: PARIS, July 17The dollar declined sharply today in Eu rope in what dealers described as a test of the new interven tion policies of the major West ern central banks.

title: Paris Pushes for Closer Saigon Ties
description: PARIS, July 17France has decided to make a serious ef fort to restore her influence in Vietnam, building on Vestiges little noticed during the vast American presence.

title: MRS. RICHARD BOOTH
description: Mrs. Ruth Eleanor Fisher Booth, wife of Richard E. Booth, executive director of the United Fund of Greater New York, died Monday of cancer in the ColumbiaPres byterian Medical Center. She was 52 years old and lived at 51 Flint Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AFTER DARK Lower Manhattan is as devoid of people after dark these clays as it is teeming with humani ty during the day. You may see for yourself how the southern tip slumbers by a walking tour of downtown buildings and parks that starts tonight at 9 from the new, little park office build ing at Broadway and Liberty Street.

title: Federal Law Could Raise Costs Of Struck Coast Transit System
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 17 Operators of the 10monthold Bay Area Rapid Transit system are learning that Federal aid programs, in roundabout ways, can cost money as well as dis pense it.

title: KROGH PLEADS 5TH AT HOUSE INQUIRY First Watergate Witness to Invoke the Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  Egil Krogh Jr., a former White House aide, invoked the Fifth Amendment today, refusing to answer any questions about the Watergate affair.

title: Books of The Times McGill of The Constitution
description: RALPH McGILL, REPORTER, by Harold H. Martin. 344 pp. Atlantic Monthly Press Little, Brown. $10.95.

title: Antioch Student Sentenced
description: XENIA, Ohio July 17 (AP) An Antioch College student has been sentenced to two 60day jail terms after being convicted of assault and battery during a student strike on the campus last May. Robert Singleton, 24 years old, of New York City, will serve the terms concurrent ly. A second student, George Edison, 26, of Cincinnati was found not guilty of the same charge.

title: Transcript of EhrlichmanKalmbach Talk
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Following is a transcript of a telephone conversation at 4:50 P.M. on April 19 be tween John D. Ehrlichman, former assistant to the Pres ident on domestic matters, and Herbert W. Kalmbach, the President's former per sonal lawyer. Mr. Ehrlichman recorded the conversation and provided the transcript lo the Senate Select Com mittee on Presidential Cam paign Activities.

title: Gain Held Possible at Film Concern
description: Herbert A. Allen, the 34year old investment banker, quietly moved into Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., last month and observers of the chronically ailing movie business wonder if his presence will give a revital izing transfusion to a company that has suffered from that rundown feeling.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: No Talk on Succession
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 President Nixon received word today that he could leave the hospital Friday.WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) Vice President Agnew said today that there was no agree ment between him and President Nixon on the question of his, assuming the Presidential duties, should Mr. Nixon be disabled, and that the two had never dis cussed it.

title: People and Business Lord Snowden Gets U.S. Patents
description: Two unusual patents were granted this week in Wash ington. The inventions may have been less than earth shaking, but the recipient, Antony Charles Robert Arm strong Jones, also known as Lord Snowden, husband of Princess Margaret, sister of the British Queen, was granted two patents for self propelled carts for invalids.

title: PRESERVATION BILL ON ISLANDS REVISED
description: TISBURY, Mass., July 17 An article in today's New York Times erred in reporting that the Secretary of the Interior would appoint six of seven members of the three trust commission set up to adminis ter Federal protection to Nan tucket, Martha's Vineyard and the Elizabeth Islands under leg islation proposed by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Museums to Get Briefing on Art Disposal
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, an nounced yesterday that mem bers of his staff would meet shortly with museum officials throughout the state to ad vise them of procedures worked out with the Metro politan Museum of Art on the disposal of art works.

title: Policeman Shot After Scolding Boy Who Disturbed Chess Game
description: A 29yearold offduty police officer playing chess outside a Harlem tenement was shot in the stomach last night after scolding a boy who disturbed the garbagecan cover the chess chess board was on, the police reported.

title: A VICTIM RECALLS BON VIVANT SOUP
description: NEWARK, July 17  Mrs. Grace Cochran of Bedford Vil lage, N. Y., testified in Fed eral District Court here today that there was nothing abnor mal in the appearance of the container or the contents of a can of Bon Vivant vichys soise that killed her husband two years ago and left her paralyzed for months.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Mrs. Mitchell Says Watergate Is Rehearsed and Bores Public
description: GREENWOOD, Miss., July 17 (UPI)Mrs, John N. Mitchell, insisting that what happened to me in California was a heck of a lot worse then anybody breaking into Democratic head quarters, said today that the American public was bored with the Watergate hearings.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Ernest Tordo, former chairman of the Jackson Town ship Zoning Board, was sentenced to six months in jail for having accepted a $400 bribe to influence a vote on reducing the minimum age requirements at a housing com plex for the elderly.

title: 2d Quarter Profit For Merrill Lynch Takes Sharp Drop
description: Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., reported yesterday that second quarter profits fell sharply to $2.76million, or 8 cents a share, from $14.75million, or 46 cents a share, one year earlier.

title: Dance: American Ballet Offers Debuts
description: There are certain pro grams that the American Bal let Theater offers that are so simply entertaining that one wonders why other com panies are not so gloriously and determinedly eclectic. Last Sunday afternoon, for example, at the New York State Theater, it gave Petrushka, Jardin aux Lilas and Etudes. An un likely mix perhaps, yet one full of differences  a pro gram that really gave a shrewd conspectus of 20th century ballet.

title: BEAME IS BACKED BY 13 REFORMERS Most of State Legislators Had Supported Blumenthal
description: Stressing party unity, 13 state legislators allied with the Re form wing of the Democratic party announced yesterday their support of Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor.

title: Dr. Angus M. Frantz, 78, Neurologist at Columbia
description: Dr. Angus M. Frantz, who retired in 1960 as associate clinical professor of neurology at Columbia University and at tending neurologist at Presby terian Hospital, died there on Monday. He was 78 years old and lived at 401 East 81st Street.

title: Jets Center Glad to See Bubba Gone
description: How did big John Schmitt, the effervescent center of the New York Jets, respond to the trade on Monday of Bubba Smith, the Baltimore Colts defensive lineman, to the Oakland Raiders?

title: Watergate Cookbook Published in Boston
description: BOSTON, July 17 (AP) Seven Bostonians have pub lished The Watergate Cook book: Or Who's in the Soup?

title: Nelson Doubleday Weds Mrs. Sandra P. Barnett
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 17Mrs. Sandra Pine Bar nett and Nelson Doubleday, executive vice president of Doubleday & Co., Inc., the familycontrolled publishing concern, were married here this evening at Round Hill Community Church by the Rev. Dr. Paul N. Otto of the First United MethodistChurch of Greenwich.

title: Foreign Revenue Factor
description: The Xerox Corporation, the leader in the copier industry, had the highest quarter and halfyear earnings in its his tory in the three and six months ended June 30, accord ing to the semiannual report issued yesterday from its head quarters in Stamford, Conn.

title: People in Sports: Oops! QuarryBonavena Is Off
description: The report that Oscar Bon avena of Argentina would substitute for Earnie Shav ers against Jerry Quarry in a 12round heavyweight bat tle in Madison Square Garden on July 25 was premature. Teddy Brenner, president of Garden Boxing, said yester day the fighters had not been signed for the bout because the Argentine needed more time to get ready. Bonavena, who hasn't fought since he was outpointed by Floyd Patterson in a 10rounder at the Garden 17 months ago, has beentraining at Atlantic City only two weeks . . . Although there will be no boxing show on July 25, the Garden will keep fight fans happy with a 12rounder on Aug. 4. Billy Backus, former world welterweight cham pion, was signed to meet Miguel Barreto at the Felt Forum in a nationally tele vised bout.

title: Welfare Island to Be Renamed Roosevelt
description: Welfare Island, now getting a new look through the con struction of thousands of hous ing units, will soon be getting a new name  Franklin Roose velt Island.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Joan Hemingway, a grand daughter of Ernest Heming way, is tracking his literary footsteps. The 23yearold daughter of Jack Heming way, the son of the late novelist and his first wife, has collaborated with Paul Bonnecarrere, a French news man, on her first novel, Rosebud. The book, just published in France, has been acquired by Morrow for pub lication here next year.

title: Football Transactions
description: NEW YORK JETSReleased Joe Carbone, Delaware linebacker, 10thround draft choice.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: End to Economic Controls Planned on Industry Basis
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 John T. Dunlop, the director of the Cost of Living Council, dis closed today that the Nixon Administration, which will an nounce its Phase 4 program to morrow, planned to take an industrybyindustry approach to ending price and wage con trols.

title: STONES, WOTTLES PACE U.S. IN TRACK Washington Loses to Italian After Misjudging Finish
