description: TURIN, Italy, July 17 (AP) Dwight Stones, the world rec ordholder, cleared 7 feet 4 inches in the high jump today, helping the United States men gain a 6936 lead over Italy in the first day of their twoday track and field meet.

title: Advertising: Remeeting America
description: One wonders when seeing those welltailored and obvi ously upperincome agency executives and the frequent ly avant garde and some times almost hippie types strolling through their crea tive departments just how Madison Avenue manages to communicate with middle America.

title: Nadjari Opens Study of Koota's Office
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the spe cial state prosecutor, and the State Senate Crime Committee began inquiries yesterday into Federal testimony that two cases had been fixed in the Brooklyn District Attorney's office under a former prose cutor, Aaron E. Koota.

title: Another Giant Sidelined: Evans to Be Out 2 Months
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 17Despite a long and painful rehabilitation period, Charlie Evans will be lost to the New York Giants for most of the exhibition season.NEW HAVEN, July 17 (AP)  The City of New Haven's legal staff has given an offi cial all clear sign for the five New York Giants games in Yale Bowl this fall. Cor poration Counsel Thomas F. Keyes Jr. said today the games would not violate municipal zoning ordinances.

title: Watkins Glen: Super Road Show
description: The World Championship for Makes may be decided in this country for the first time. The occasion is this weekend's program of road racing at Watkins Glen, N. Y., a supershow that com bines the manufacturers six hour endurance race on Sat urday with the third round of

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 18, 1973 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on ap plication for membership of the Bahamas.

title: Mother of Getty's Grandson In Touch With Kidnappers
description: ROME, July 17 (AP)  The mother of J. Paul Getty 3d said today that her 16yearold son had definitely been kidnapped, that the abductors had been in touch with her and that we are ready to negotiate his re lease.

title: Secret Raids on Cambodia Before 70 Totaled 3,500
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 United States B52 bombers made at least 3,500 secret bombing raids over Cambodia in a 14month period beginning in March, 1969, Defense De partment sources disclosed to day.

title: Football Transactions
description: NEW YORK JPFSReleased Joe Carbone, Delaware linebacker, 10th round draft choice.

title: Beauty Experts Get to See Baker in the Flesh
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Grits were optional, but for $13 apiece the delegates to a national hairdressers con vention could have breakfast today with scrambled eggs, both sausage and ham, hard rolls and sweet ones and Sen ator Howard H. Baker Jr.

title: S.E.C. Files New Fraud Counts Against ExChief of Westgate
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Securities and Exchange Com mission filed new fraud charges today against C. Arnholt Smith, a San Diego millionaire and former head of the Westgate California Corporation, as well as of the United States National Bank of San Diego.

title: She Misses Her Rest But Not the Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 She usually makes a sand wich the night before, and packs a piece of fruit with it then so she doesn't lose any time the next morning.

title: Federal Mine Safety Selection Confirmed After Union Protest
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Despite several months of angry demands for his re moval as the Government's coal mine safety chief, Donald P. Schlick has quietly been named the acting director of the newly organized Federal Mining En forcement and Safety Admin istration.

title: Metropolitan Briefs Stamford Drops Welfare Bar
description: Mayor Julius Wilensky of Stamford, Conn., announced that the city would no longer enforce a welfare residency ordinance that was described by a Federal court as an attempt to wall welfare residents out. Last Thursday Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall rejected without comment the city's final appeal. His ruling upheld the find ings of two lower Federal courts. Mayor Wilensky said at a news conference: This brings to an end the litigation and effort by the city to sustain the ordinance.

title: Brazil Dismisses 6 Colonels
description: RIO DE JANIERO, July 17 (AP)Brazil's militaryrun gov ernment has dismissed six army colonels charged in a kickback scandal that threatened to tar nish the regime's anticorrup tion image. The kickbacks are said to have occurred in the purchase of military supplies.

title: At Yoga Camp, There's Not Much Stress on the Word Vacation'
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa.  Uh 000000000. It was 4:30 A.M., and the haunting wail of a conch echoed through the Sivananda Yoga Camp in the Pocono Mountains near here. Yes, Poconos, not Himalayas. It was time to get up and meditate.

title: Britons Worry About Losing Privacy  to Europe, Computers, Detectives and Press
description: LONDON, July I7What connection is there between the channel tunnel, the over enthusiasm of a detective agency specializing in divorce evi dence, aggressive reporters and, the nationwide computeriza ton of medical records?

title: Phone Rates Stir Exchange Comment At S.E.C. Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Securities and Exchange Com mission's hearing of the New York Stock Exchange's applica tion for a $300million increase in the fixed brokerage commis sion rate was all but bogged down today in a discussion of telephone rates and the method of determining the impact of in flation.

title: In the Morning of Flight
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.My mem ories of childhood have the strong lines and contrasting masses of color I see in modern stained glass. I re member my first sight of an airplane on the ground, and the details are as clear as an Evie Hone window.

title: Savings Banks Threaten To Make No Home Loans State Must Lift MortgageRate Ceiling, They WarnGovernor Sees Issue Likely Going to Legislature
description: New York savings banks, which traditionally provide by far the largest portion of home mortgage financing in the state, bluntly threatened yesterday to withdraw from lending here should the Legislature fail to lift the State's present 7 per cent interest ceiling on such loans.

title: Bet Chief Is a Yacht Cup Racer
description: Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr. acknowledges that he knows a great deal more about yacht racing, real estate and oil than he does about horse racing.

title: A 2D LANSKY TRIAL BEGINS IN FLORIDA
description: MIAMI, July 17Meyer Lan sky, the reputed underworld financial figure, went on trial in Federal District Court today on charges of Income tax evasion.

title: Records: 5 Saxophones Play a la Charlie Parker
description: When Charlie Parker was creating the remarkable im provisations that put an in delible stamp on the playing style of an entire generation of jazz saxophonists in the nineteenforties, the flow of his ideas and the virtuosity with which he expressed them seemed beyond the capabili ties of most of his contempo raries. They certainly tried, but the consequence was a plethora of saxophonists who pasted together carefully learned Parker riffs without catching his essential creative spark.

title: Equity Financing
description: A secondary offering of 100,000 common shares of the Connecticut Water Company common $15.75 a share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by the Advest Company. The company's stock, traded on the overthecounter market, closed at 15 bid, 16 asked, up .

title: Others Gain Monsanto Net at Peak
description: In line with projections made last month before securities analysts, the Monsanto Com pany reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the sec and quarter and first half of the year.

title: Kalmbach Says Strangers Got $400,000 From Hint
description: WASHINGTON, July I7  Herbert W. Kalmbach testified today that, under orders from the White House, he provided $400,000 in cash three years ago to men he had never seen before and whose names he still did not know.

title: Four Fingerprinted; Other Pupils Balk In a Jersey Murder
description: NEWARK, July 17  Four former eighthgrade Newark boys have already been finger printed in a murder investiga tion that has involved 50 to 60 pupils at the Martin Luther King Jr. Elementary School here.

title: IRAQ WILL SET UP PARLIAMENT SOON First in 15 Years Planned, With Appointed Members
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17 Iraq is to have her first Parlia ment in 15 years by next Octo ber, it was announced in Bagh dad today.

title: Basketball Transactions NATIONAL ASSOCIATION
description: DETROITSigned Don Adams, forward; Tom Marsh, U. of Detroit guard, and Lin Cole, Eastern Michigan forward.

title: House Passes $407Million Bill For Medical Care of Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)  The House passed by a 421to0 vote today a $407.8 million, fiveyear veterans medical benefits bill similar to one that President Nixon pocketvetoed last fall.

title: Local Marinas Finding Thieves Growing Bolder.
description: Thefts from pleasure boats moored at marinas in the metropolitan area are stirring increasing concern because, while boats are becoming more elaborate and expensive, the police are being diverted from marine patrols to what officials consider more pressing street duty.

title: Rogers Reassures Tokyo on U.S. Troops
description: TOKYO. July 17Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States would consult Japan before re clueing American troop strength in South Korea and Taiwan.

title: SCHOOL CODE IS SENT TO SUPREME SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, July 17The So viet Government presented the draft of a basic education code to the Supreme Soviet today as the national legislature of the Soviet Union opened its midyear session.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: Contract Awards

title: Kennedy to Be Speaker At Byrne FundRaising
description: TRENTON, July 17Sena tor Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts will be the main speaker at the Demo cratic fundraising gala Sept. 6 at the National Guard en campment in Sea Girt, James P. Dugan, state Democratic chairman, announced today.

title: BURNHAM APPEARS WINNER IN GUYANA
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, July 17 (UPI)Prime Minister Forbes Burnham appeared today to have won his third term on the basis of partial but official re turns Opposition parties were all showing losses of votes com pared with the 1968 elections, with onesixth of the votes counted so far.

title: Red Smith Leo at the Bat
description: Leo Durocher says that for years he has entertained growing doubts about the efficacy of batting practice. In his 21 years as a player it never did him any good, and as manager of the Houston Astros he has concluded that hitters like Cesar Cedeno, Bob Watson and Lee May don't need it. Accordingly, he advised the help recently that if they didn't feel like showing up early to swing at the service of some cunnythumbed coach, that would be all right with him. The most interesting thing about this is that it is an exact reversal of Durocher's attitude last March 15. Then he considered batting practice so important he paid $250 out of his own pocket rather than deprive Houston's farm hands of the exercise.

title: Kennedy Had Tapes On Sensitive Talks
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 17 President Kennedy made tape recordings of highly sensitive telephone conversations and staff meetings in the White House, the director of the Ken nedy Library said tonight.WASHINGTON, July 17  When the Shah of Iran, Pre mier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan and Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia visit President Nixon later this month, they will be the first visitors from overseas whose conversations with the Presi dent will be recorded with their foreknowledge.

title: Ramada Inns and Japan To Enter a Hotel Venture
description: TOKYO, July 17 (UPI)  Ramada Inns of the United States will enter a $150million joint hotel venture with a Jap anese trading company, it was announced today.

title: New Books FICTION
description: Body Count, by William Turner Huggett (Putnam, $7.95). A Marine platoon in Vietnam.

title: Disney Empire Is Hardly Mickey Mouse
description: E. Cardon Walker is a mer cantile giant who heads an empire of 17,000 fulltime employes, all of whom owe their livelihood and much of their allegiance to Mickey Mouse.

title: Governor Says Bond Issue Will Help Upstate Transit
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 17Governor Rockefeller said today there was a very good possibility that the state would acquire upstate railroad track age under his new transit bond plan and contract with railroad companies to maintain services for small communities that had no air service.

title: JAMES DAWSON DIES; CIVIL ENGINEER, 79
description: James A. Dawson, a civil en gineer who was coordinator of construction of the United Na tions headquarters on the East River, died Monday in Sharon, (Conn.) Community Hospital. Since his retirement in 1962, he had lived in West Cornwall, Conn. He was 79 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 10353

title: Jersey Aide Says Autos May Not Be Chief Polluters
description: NEWARK, July 18  The automobile may not be the culprit it was thought to, be in causing smog in the New YorkNew Jersey metro politan area, New Jersey's top pollutioncontrol official testi fied here today.

title: American Airlines Reports a Decline In June Earnings
description: American Airlines yesterday reported earnings of $1,039, 000 for the month of June, compared with $5,706,000 for June of 1972.

title: Saigon, Prodded by U.S., Lends Rice to Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18 After much prodding by the United States, the South Viet namese Government has lent 20,000 tons of valuable rice to the embattled government of Cambodia.

title: Executions in Afghanistan Are Reported
description: NEW DELHI, July 18 (AP) Reports reached here today of executions, arrests, fighting and calls for a countercoup in Af ghanistan, where the brother inlaw of King Mohammad Zahir Shah has seized power and proclaimed a republic.

title: MULLIGAN IS BURIED IN SERVICES ON L.I.
description: Hugh Mulligan, reputedly a major bookmaker and briber of policemen, was buried yester day in St. Charles cemetery, Pinelawn, LI,

title: Arthur Daley Three Awaiting Enshrinement
description: If the selection committee for the Pro Football Hall Fame needed a model for setting up behavior patterns, would have to be the Red Queen. She shocked Alice Wonderland by screaming, Off with her head! The guard ians of the gridiron shrine at Canton, Ohio, do an awesome job of mass decapitation every year while weighing the qualifications of those eligible for enshrinement.

title: Slowing the Trident
description: The opening shot in the battle of the defense budget was fired the other day by a key Senate subcommittee which took an unequivocal stand against the Adminis tration's grandiose program to accelerate deployment of the Trident submarine. With a long and contentious path ahead across Capitol Hill, there are promising signs that the foes of defense extravagance are picking up signifi cant support.

title: Notes on People Chiang Called`Cured
description: Exactly one year after his last public appearance, news papers on Taiwan broke a sixmonth silence on the health of 85yearold Presi dent Chiang Kaishek to re port he is now fully cured of pneumonia, which he con tracted last year. The reports quoted a Government spokes man, Dr. Frederick F. Chien, director of the Government information office, as saying that the President is on his way to full recovery of his strength and has been lead ing a normal life for a long time. The press did not dis close that he is still hospital ized, a fact that has never been reported domestically.

title: ROBBERY IS FOILED AT NEWARK BANK
description: NEWARK, July 18Three men were wounded this morn ing in a shootout in downtown Newark following an attempted robbery of a Brinks truck parked in front of the National Newark and Essex Bank on Broad Street.

title: Jets Winner Biding His Time
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 18 Charley Winner is virtually lost in the shadows cast by the linebackers, the Jets unit he is coaching at train ing camp here.

title: Flowers on Kopechne Grave
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., July 18 (AP)  Flowers from Senator and Mrs. Edward M. Kennedy were placed today on the grave of Mary Jo Kopechne in a small cemetery near here, the fourth anniversary of Miss Kopechne's death. Miss Kopechne, who was born in nearby Plymouth, drowned at Chappaquiddick, Mass., when the Senator's car in which she was a passenger plunged from a bridge into a tidal pool.

title: State Food Expert Is Gloomy Over Outlook for Prices and Supplies
description: ALBANY, July 18New York State's leading expert on con sumer prices for food is bit ter about President Nixon's eco nomic policies, appalled at what consumers are paying for fruit, vegetables and meat, and pessimistic about the future for both farmers and con sumers.

title: Despite Dire Predictions, the Couture Carries On
description: ROME, July 18Every body insists that the couture, or high fashion as it's called here, is suffering a protracted James Cagney sort of death scene. Like its fellow enter tainments, the novel and the theater, it hasn't hit the floor yet.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Wood, Field and Stream More Than a Million Expected to Visit 44 New York Campsites This Season

title: TV News Service Is Feeling Strong Growing Pains
description: Back in 1968, Robert R. Pauley left a top executive po sition with the American Broadcasting Company and got the idea of establishing a tele vision news service over and above what the three commer cial networks were providing.

title: Senate Rejects Substitute for Wage Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) Rejecting predictions of a Pres idential veto, the Senate re fused today to scrap a $2.20 anhour minimumwage bill in favor of a scaleddown Repub lican substitute.

title: U.S. Men, Women Teams Defeat Italians in Track
description: TURIN, Italy, July 18 (AP) Rick Wohlhuter of Chicago, the world recordholder at 880 yards, outdueled Italy's Mar cello Fiasconaro and won the 800meter race today as the American men's team trounced the Italians, 14378, in a track and field meet.

title: Those Shoppers Aware of End To Freeze Express Bitterness
description: Interviews with food store managers and shoppers in the metropolitan area last evening indicated a fair amount of non awareness that the freeze on food prices had been lifted, but those who did know expressed discontent and even bitterness over the prospect of big new increases in prices.

title: LaRue and Ulasewicz Plead Ignorant On Who Ordered $450,000 Payments
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Two participants in the Watergate coverup described today, in bizarre details, how they had funneled $450,000 of Presiden tial campaign money to the seven original Watergate de fendants and their lawyers.

title: Ballet: Durable Billy the Kid Is Back Terry Orr Portrays Boyish Outlaw Structural Complexities Heighten Success
description: Eugene Loring's ballet, Billy the Kid, first created for Lincoln Kirstein's Ballet Caravan in 1938, has proved marvelously durable. In part this may be due to Aaron Copland's bouncy score, and the scenery and costumes by Jared French are both at tractive and evocative.

title: Coffee  After Long Years of Decline, Some Hopeful Signs
description: Without being aware of it, American consumers have been on a buying strike against the quality of their coffee for 20 years. During that time, according to people in the trade, quality declined faster than ever until, according to optimists in the trade, it hit bottom. Now there are signs, no larger than home coffee mill, that an upturn may be developing.

title: Advertising: Creating a Word
description: Old Forester is a 103year old premium bourbon brand from the BrownForman Dis tillers Corporation. It is fourth in sales in its cate gory.

title: Louis Caldor, Helped Set Up Grandma Moses in Art World
description: Louis J. Caldor, a New York engineer who was credited with introducing the late Grandma Moses art to the world be yond the farmlands of her up state home, died Tuesday at nursing home near Clarksburg, Md. He was 73 years old.

title: A'TOUGH'PROGRAM New Regulations Go Into Effect Aug. 12 in Other Sectors
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  President Nixon ended the freeze today on prices for health care and food, except for beef, as he outlined the fourth phase of his 23month old effort to combat price and wage inflation.

title: MORTIMER DAVIS DETECTED FRAUDS Credit Executive, 77, Dead Former F.B.I. Agent
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 18Mortimer J. Davis, former executive vice president and chief administrative officer of the New York Credit and Financial Management Associa tion and of its affiliate, the New York Credit Men's Adjustment Bureau, died yesterday after suffering a stroke. He was 77 years old and had lived here since moving from Forest Hills, Queens, on his retirement in 1960.

title: MAGOON CAPTURES POWERBOAT RACE
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., July 18Playing cat and mouse with the rest of the fleet, Robert (Doc) Magoon of Miami won his third Hennessy Grand Prix ocean race today by the mere margin of 3 seconds. Finishing 50 feet behind him after 181 miles was Giorgio Mondadori of Italy.

title: U.S. Concludes Minesweeping In the North, and Navy Departs
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)1  The Pentagon today an nounced the end of United States minesweeping in North Vietnamese waters.

title: WILLIAM B. BICKLEY
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., July 18 William B. Bickley, editor of The Columbia Missourian and professor of journalism at the University of Missouri, died to day, apparently of a heart at tack. He was 60 years old.

title: MRS. ERNEST VAN ZANDT
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 18 Mrs. Rebekah Lytle Van Zandt, widow of Ernest T. Van Zandt, a real estate appraiser, died yesterday in a New Ro chelle nursing home. She was 87 years old and lived at 9 Brooklands Apartments on Pal mer Road.

title: Vote Asked on Forming City Animal Department
description: A campaign will be opened today by Citizens for Ani mals, 900 First Avenue, to obtain 50,000 signatures by Aug. 25 on a petition for a referendum for the city to establish a Department of Animal Affairs.

title: FRIEDRICH NORD, BIOCHEMIST, DIES Fordham Professor Emeritus First Isolated Lignin
description: Dr. Friedrich Franz Nord, professor emeritus of chemis try at Fordham University, died, apparently of a heart at tack, while vacationing in Ver mont last Thursday. He was 83 years old and lived at 333 Westchester Avenue, Mount Vernon, N. Y.

title: Nevadan Captures Opener Of Fireball Sailing Series
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., July 18 Ed Berry of Reno, Nev., fin ished two seconds ahead of Graham Hall of Larchmont, N. Y., today to capture the opening race of the Fireball Class national championship. The sixrace sailing series is to continue through Friday.

title: Young Said to Refuse to Name Ehrlichman in Psychiatrist Raid
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  David R. Young Jr., a former White House aide, reportedly refused today to tell a House subcommittee whether his su perior, John D. Ehrlichman, had approved a plan to burglarize the office of Dr. Daniel Ells berg's former psychiatrist.

title: Noise Ban or No, Many Honkers Get Away
description: With a long, wiglifting horn blast, a cursing, fist shaking driver in an open car squeezed through a crowded downtown intersection yes terday, the perfect example of the raucous hornblower that the city is out to get.

title: MILITARY DISPUTE Ex Secretary Rejects Pentagon Version of Cambodian Issue
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  Former Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird and his retired top military adviser, Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, today criticized the falsification of official reports dealing with the secret bombing of Cambodia and disavowed knowledge of any such actions.

title: F.D.A. TO SET RULE FOR FOOD TESTING Plans Scientific Criteria on Meat and Dairy Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  The Food and Drug Adminis tration, acting on the need keep hazardous substances out of meat and dairy food pro ucts, proposed today a strat egy for determining when zero is really zero.

title: New Jersey Sports In the Swim Again
description: ORANGE, July 18Synchronized swimming is going through a renaissance in its costuming and music and the changes seem to agree with the Nereids of the Orange Young Women's Christian Association

title: 3 Rivals Still in the Stable
description: While Howard Samuels is off and running for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, three potential com petitors haven't even made a final decision to run yet. Still in the mullingitover stage arc Mayor Lindsay, Rep resentative Ogden R. Reid of Pleasantville and Representa tive Samuel S. Stratton of Amsterdam.

title: COMMODITIES LIST IN BROAD ADVANCE Many Items Rise Daily Limit, Anticipating Phase 4
description: The prices of almost all com modities were bid up sharply yesterday in anticipation of the President's Phase 4 antiinfla tionary efforts.

title: Csonka Is Hurt in Practice
description: MIAMI, July 18 (UPI) Larry Csonka, the Miami Dol phins fullback, may miss the game against the College All Stars at Chicago July 27, Coach Don Shula reported today. Csonka, the leading rusher in the Dolphins recordsetting ground attack last season, tore a thigh muscle in practice late yesterday and spent the night at a hospital.

title: A TREK TO CAIRO BEGUN BY LIBYANS Thousands to Try to Force an Immediate Merger
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, July 18 (Reuters)Thousands of Liby ans riding in cars, buses and trucks began a 1,500mile jour ney eastward to Cairo today to try to force the Egyptian leadership to agree to an im mediate merger of the two countries.

title: Kennedy Aides Unaware That Talks Were Taped
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 18 Several high officials of the Kennedy Administration said today that they had no knowl edge of the recordings of Presi dential meetings or telephone calls, despite the announce ment last night by the John F. Kennedy Library that it had discovered 68 Dictabelts of Presidential telephone calls and 125 magnetic tapes of Pres idential meetings.WASHINGTON, July IS (AP)  The Nixon Administration has obtained two sworn state ments that President Johnson installed hidden microphones and taping devices in the White House.WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)  Maj. Gen, Harry H. Vaughan, military aide to Presi dent Truman, said today that President Franklin D. Roosevelt ordered wiretaps placed on the home telephones of his closest aides.

title: 8 MORE STATIONS ARE SUBPOENAED U.S. Payola Inquiry Calls Major Radio Outlets
description: At least eight more New Yorkarea radio stations, in cluding the AM and FM out lets for two of the major net works, have been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury in Newark that is investigating allegations of payola, drug use and involve ment with organized crime in the record industry, This brings the total of metropolitanarea stations subpoenaed in the case

title: Restraints in Peacetime Imposed on Aug. 15, 1971
description: WASHINGTON, July 18On Aug. 15, 1971, President Nixon took the historic step of im posing Federal controls on peacetime economy.

title: REPAIRS ARE SLATED AT JOHNSON LIBRARY
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 18 (UPI) The Lyndon B. Johnson Presi dential Library, completed two years ago at a price of $18 million, will undergo an 18 month repair job costing $2 million to $3million, contrac tors bidding on the repair job have indicated.

title: Hundreds Arrested as Strikers Defy Court to Picket at California Vineyard
description: ARVIN, Calif., July 18 Striking farm workers were ar rested by the hundreds here to day as they angrily carried out a series of noisy and often tense demonstrations that de fied court orders.

title: Dolly Madison Sets Filing Under Bankruptcy Laws
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP)  The Dolly Madison Ice Company will file for bank ruptcy tomorrow, it was an nounced here today.

title: Court Star Flashes Speed at Giants Camp
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 18Rod Freeman, the tallest and least experi enced player in the Giants preseason training camp, sur vived his first test as a pro fessional today: He finished the twomile run in under 15 minutes.

title: Member Firm Criticizes Plans Of Big Board to Increase Fees
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  A member of the New York Stock Exchange said today that a Rig Board plan to raise $300 miliion in revenues by increas ing .brokerage commission rates would only drive more small, investors from the market.

title: Government's Fact Sheet and Calendar for Phase 4
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 Following is a fact sheet and calendar on Phase 4 issued by the White House:

title: State Begins Inquiry On Bids for Gasoline
description: New York State has begun an investigation to determine whether major gasoline com panies conspired to prevent competitive bidding on state purchase of gasoline.

title: Army Transport Collides With a Coast Guard Vessel
description: BALTIMORE, July 18 (AP) The Hickory Knoll, a 338foot Army Reserve transport ship, collided on Tuesday with a Coast Guard bouy tender in Baltimore Harbor just hours after being freed from a sand bar.

title: COMMODORE'S CUP GOES TO M'CREARY
House Passes Bill to Curb President's War Powers
description: WASHINGTON, July 18De spite the threat of a Presiden tial veto, the House of Repre sentatives tonight passed a measure that would limit the power of the President to com mit United States armed forces to hostilities abroad without Congressional approval.

title: Now Phase 4
description: The Nixon Administration has taken the wraps off its Phase 4 program to control wages and prices, disclosing a complex plan that seems designed chiefly to hold the line on prices for a little while longeruntil the entire controls program can be dismantled.

title: House Passes Bill to Curb President's War Powers
description: WASHINGTON, July 18De spite the threat of a Presiden tial veto, the House of Repre sentatives tonight passed measure that would limit the power of the President to com mit United States armed forces to hostilities abroad without Congressional approval.

title: Screen: Hesse's 'Siddhartha' Opens:Fable About a Search Adapted by Rooks The Cast
description: For those who don't believe, no explanation will be satisfactory. For those who do believe, no explanation is necessary.Is that from "The Song of Bernadette"? "Going My Way"? "The Secret Storm"? No matter. It's pretty much the way I feel about Hermann Hesse's "Siddhartha," the fable about a young Brahmin's search for wisdom and spiritual peace written by the Nobel Prize-winning German author and poet who died in 1962 at the age of 85.One either accepts "Siddhartha" with rapture, in the kind of ecstasy that is Novocaine to thought, or one throws up. I say that immediately because it has a great deal to do with my reactions to the simple, solemn film version that Conrad Rooks has made in India, and that opened here yesterday at the Columbia One and other theaters."Siddhartha," originally published in 1922, was first translated into English in the early nineteen-fifties and for the last four or five years has been one of the bigger things in American paperback publishing. Its popularity, on college campuses and off, especially with dropouts, is awe-inspiring, a little depressing, and probably as foolish to fight as a musical adaptation of "Love Story" by Rod McKuen. It's the one book to be read by people who don't read books.Although Hesse has been incorrectly heralded as the prophet of the drug culture, his novel's aggressive anti-intellectualism, enunciated in dime-store prose-poetry, provides comparable escape from social and political responsibility. Don't think, it says, feel. Knowledge can be taught, it says, but wisdom must be experienced. (To which I would add, like death.) Don't try to do anything about the mess in the world around you, find your own peace and to hell with everyone else (unless, of course, they can find their peace simultaneously).Mr. Rooks's film is a fairly faithful adaptation of Hesse's fable, the product of a journey to India undertaken by the author a half-century before the Beatles and Mia Farrow had even booked passage. The time is a mythical past and the conflict is one that continues throughout Hesse's work. Flesh battles spirit to a mystical draw, to the revelation that all things are one: youth, age, sin, grace, life, death, stones, tadpoles.Siddhartha (Shashi Kapoor), accompanied by his lap-dog friend Govinda (Romesh Sharma), leaves his father's house to find wisdom with a troupe of traveling holy men. He learns how to meditate, how to fast, but wisdom eludes him. He seeks out the Gotama Buddha, and learns only that wisdom cannot be taught. He turns to what is called  if only in fiction of this sort  the pleasures of the flesh.Siddhartha becomes the lover of the beautiful courtesan Kamala and, at the same time, a successful merchant. But still  are you ready?  he knows he is missing something. He chucks it all and finally, with the aid of an old boatman, he finds what he is seeking in the river as a metaphor of life.These are more or less the highpoints of the story that Mr. Rooks and his cameraman, the usually celebrated Sven Nykvist, have photographed with a kind of photogenic but plodding piety. Mr. Rooks has resisted any temptation to employ the fractured style of his first film, "Chappaqua," and instead has made a small-scale "Ten Commandments" for flower children.The Gotama Buddha is photographed from the back or the side, the way Jesus and United States Presidents are photographed in movies in which they have tiny parts. There are lots of shots into the sun, which create halos, and there is one love scene that is mostly between a couple of presumably nude silhouettes. Toward the middle you know Siddhartha is getting fed up with earthly pleasures when, at a banquet, he tosses aside a bunch of grapes.If the film does nothing else, however, it does expose Siddhartha's ultimate wisdom to be nothing much more profound than a technical device. When, as an old man he tells Govinda to look into the river and see the cycle of life, we see what Govinda sees. What is it? Plain old superimposition of images. Heck. D. W. Griffith knew how to do this.

title: Brokers to Seek Major Revision In Rules of Evidence on Theft
description: A major revision in the rules of evidence used by state and Federal courts in dealing with stock and bond thefts will be sought by leading Wall Street brokerage firms, it was dis closed yesterday.

title: In Queens the Beames Are Just a Pleasant Couple
description: Strolling along the beach in the Belle Harbor section of Queens, Mary Beame was stopped by a friend who com plained mildly that they hadn't gotten together in weeks and who invited her and her husband over for Sat urday nigt dessert and gin rummy. But Mrs. Beanie had to decline, with apologies, because her husband was too busy running to be Mayor of New York City.

title: `To Be a Little Humble
description: WASHINGTON, July 18It is a rare event when a President of the United States concedes in a public statement that con fidence in our management of our fiscal affairs is low, at home and abroad. Richard M. Nixon made the conces sion today. It is equally unusual when a President, 35 days after he imposed a dramatic price freeze to appease an angry electorate, discloses his mis take by saying that food has given the clearest evidence of the harm that controls can do

title: 2D KILLING LINKED TO BLACK OCTOBER
description: BALTIMORE, July 18In al crime closely paralleling the killing of a member of the Maryland House of Delegates last week, a 32yearold man was shot to death early this morning and leaflets crediting a group called Black October were found near the body.

title: ACTION ON PIPELINE HELD UP IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)  Congressional backers of a 789mile Alaska oil pipeline failed today in an effort to speed House action on a pipe line bill similar to one approved yesterday by the Senate.

title: Dr. Ira WitcheII, 68, Dies; Held Otolaryngology Posts
description: Dr. Ira S. Witchell, an oto laryngologist who had been head of that service at Monte fiore Hospital in the Bronx, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, on his way from his office in the Bronx to his home at 535 East 86th Street. He was 68 years old.

title: AUTO WORKERS WANT A REOPENER CLAUSE
description: DETROIT. July 18 (UPI)  Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers, said today that Government controls had forced the union to seek a reopener clause in any auto contract signed this year.

title: CHURCH RESTORING 44 APARTMENTS
description: JERSEY CITY, July 18 Mayor Paul T. Jordan snipped a ribbon today that symbolized the entrance of an Episcopal church foundation into the area of unsubsidized, privately operated nonprofit housing re habilitation.

title: A COLOMBIAN IS SLAIN IN CAR NEAR KENNEDY
description: A 28yearold Colombian citizen who worked as a park inglot attendant was found shot to death yesterday morn ing in a car parked near Ken nedy International Airport in Queens.

title: Wilderness Survival Building Women Inmates Egos
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., July 18 For nearly three weeks 10 young women have been hiking wearily and surviving in the Connecticut wilder ness. They have experienced the fear and excitement of being thrown from canoes into the swift and turbulent waters of the Housatonic River.

title: A Salon That's Expanding While Others Fold
description: Hairdresser namedropping, like that of designers or res taurants, is always a favorite sport around New York. The name that, bright. young things have been bandying alyout for the last couple of years is Cinandre (See NAHNdreh).

title: Ervin's Grandchildren Encounter a Celebrity
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 Senator Sam J. Ervin's four grandchildren, in town to at tend the Watergate hearings, have learned firsthand what a celebrity the Senator has become.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 11622

title: The Exaltation of the Presidency
description: WASHINGTON  After all, the man was saying back in 1946, the President of the United States is neither an absolute monarch nor descendant of the sun goddess.

title: Consumer Expert Gets HomeFront Experience
description: ALBANY, July 18  Harry M. Appel, the man who keeps track of consumer prices in New York State, does all the food shopping for his family, consisting of himself, his wife and his son. He has been do ing so ever Since he moved to Albany 37 years ago.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SOUTHERN COMFORT There's a new corner for South American birds and beasts in the Bronx Zoo, Fordham Road and Bronx River Parkway (WE 31500) and the names of the tenants seem to come right out of crossword puzzles. There are tapirs, rheas, guanacos, cos corobas, peccaries and brockets, all of which defy definition in limited space.

title: Trapped Worker Dies
description: NORWOOD, Mass. July 18 (AP)James S. DeMenezes, 20 years old, of Tiverton, R.I., drowned yesterday when would be rescuers hit a water main that flooded the construction trench in which he was trapped.

title: U.S. Confirms Intervention to Aid Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 The Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury disclosed today that intervention by the Fed. eral Reserve in the foreign ex change markets to help streng then the dollar had begun July 10.PARIS, July 18The dollar continued to weaken in Europe's currency markets today, but the losses were pared following re ports of modest intervention by central banks.

title: Port Police Vote To Report Today But Not to Work
description: Nearly 200 members of the Port Authority Police Benevo lent Association voted unani mously last night to stand roll call but not work at the tunnels, bridges and airports operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, effective at 7 A.M. today.

title: Texas Publisher Named
description: MARSHALL, Tex., July 18 (AP)Parick E. Bolger, 37 years old, has been named president and publisher of The Marshall News Messenger, Rob ert G. Marbut, president of HartHanks Newspapers, Inc., has announced. Before coming to Marshall. Mr. Bolger was president and publisher of The San Francisco Progress, a 201, 000circulation semiweekly. He succeeds M. Marvin Johnson, who was named president and publisher of The Progress.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 11622

title: S.E.C. BARS DELAY ON A JOINT TAPE
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 The Securities and Exchange Commission swept aside today demands of the New York Stock Exchange that it delay the start of a consolidated tape showing lastsale prices and volume in all markets until they adopt similar rules and regulations.

title: Paterson Police Reluctant Film Stars For Mayor Who Seeks to Make a Point
description: PATERSON, July 18  A group of Paterson policemen starred in a film made yester day by, of all people, the May or of Patersonand they did not appear to relish their roles.

title: Mother Gets Anguished Letter From Missing Getty Grandson
description: ROME, July 18 (Reuters) J. Paul Getty 3d, 16yearold grandson of the American oil billionaire, has written an an guished letter to his mother warning that he is in danger of death at the hands of kid nappers.

title: Soup Mislabeling  Laid to Bon Vivant   In Government Suit
description: NEWARK, July 18Bon Vi ivant Soups, Inc., which is bat tling a Federal Government suit to destroy 1.5 million cans of the company's products seized in July, 1971, was accused in Federal District Court today of mislabeling lobster bisque made prior to the condemna tion order.

title: People and Business Phase 4 Has Executives on Toes
description: Nobody was more eager to learn the facts about Phase 4 yesterday than industry exec utives or their bankers. David Rockefeller, Chase Manhattan Bank chairman, was sched uled to preside at a directors meeting yesterday afternoon. so he assigned John D. Wil son,, Chase senior vice presi dent, to watch the news bulletins and summon him from the meeting if he spot ted a surprise.

title: Seaver and Lyle Are Named To AllStar Pitching Staffs
description: Tom Seaver of the Mets and Sparky Lyle of the Yankees were the New Yorkers named yesterday to the AllStar game pitching staffs. Seaver was picked for the seventh straight time.

title: Last SaigonVietcong Prisoner Trade Being Set
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18 (Reuters)The Saigon Gov ernment said today that it and the Vietcong had reached agree ment in principle to exchange their remaining military and civilian prisoners next week.

title: State Official Disputes Role. Of Autos in Air Pollution
description: NEWARK, July 18  The automobile may not be the culprit it was thought to be in causing smog in the New YorkNew Jersey metro politan area, New Jersey's top pollutioncontrol official testi fied here today.

title: F.T.C. Weighs Divestiture in Oil Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)James T. Halverson, di rector of the Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Com petition, said today the Govern ment might seek a significant divestiture of refinery opera tions to settle its antitrust com plaint against the nation's eight biggest oil companies.

title: Aide Says U.S. Adopts HandsOff Policy on Cambodian Politics
description: WASHINGTON, July 18An Administration official asserted today that the United States had decided against interfering in Cambodia's domestic politi cal situation and was not try ing to bring pressure on Presi dent Lon Nol to down.

title: Dr. Roger A. Harvey Dies at 63; Radiologist Led Cancer Society
description: Dr. Roger A. Harvey, presi dent of the American Cancer Society in 196768, died of the disease Tuesday night in Colo rado General Hospital in Den ver. He was 63 years old and had been professor and chair Iman of the department of radiology at the University of Illinois College of Medicine in Chicago since 1946.

title: A Waldheim Mission
description: Egypt's insistence on resumption of the Middle East debate that was suspended by the Security Council last month is strangely at odds with Cairo's constructive interim suggestion that Secretary General Kurt Waldheim visit the area for talks with principals in the Arab Israeli dispute.

title: OWNER IS CHARGED IN FIRE AT FACTORY
description: The 50yearold Owner of a plastics factory was charged with firstdegree arson last night after he was seen run ning away from the factory building near the Brooklyn Navy Yard as it burst into flames and then exploded with such force that the roof blew off.

title: Alexander's Confirms Report of Offer.
description: Alexander's, Inc., confirmed yesterday published reports that a British retail company may be making a tender offer to acquire control of Alex ander's, a 12store chain based in New York.

title: Business Briefs
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 18Texas oil wells will run at full capacity again in August under the Texas Railroad Commission's proration order adopted after the monthly hearing today. An exception was an increase in the allow able of the KellySnyder Field of Scurry County from 76 to 84 per cent of its ability to produce. The increase will add about 20,000 barrels a day to state production.WASHINGTON, July 18 (Reuters)Soviet gold re serves are worth about $8.8billion at present market prices, the director of the State Department's Bureau of Intelli gence, said today.

title: BON VIVANT LABEL HELD INACCURATE
description: NEWARK, July 18  Bon Vivant Soups, Inc., which is battling a Federal Government suit to destroy 1.5 million cans of the company's products seized in July, 1971, was ac cused in Federal District Court today of mislabeling lobster bisque made prior to the con demnation order.

title: Judge Asked to Dismiss Suit on Sterilized Girls
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 18 (UPI)  Attorneys for two young black girls who were sterlized in a federally funded clinic have asked a Federal Court to dismiss without prej udice a $5million damage suit they previously filed.

title: ROGERS, IN SEOUL, CONFERS ON U. N. Discusses Plan for Entry of 2 Koreas in World Body
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 18Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers conferred with high South Korean officials to day on a joint strategy to gain the admission of North Korea and South Korea to the United Nations as separate entities, pending the country's eventual reunification.

title: Court Curbs Police Sergeant's Drive Against Midtown Pornography Shops
description: A police sergeant who has waged an aggressive campaign against pornography venders in midtown has been prohibited by a State Supreme Court jus tice from making arrests with out warrants at two peepshow theaters.

title: Judge Bids White House Release Tax Case Data
description: WASHINGTON, July 18A Federal district judge asked the White House today to release a broad spectrum of private documents and transcripts of tape recordings pertaining to activist organizations.

description: In what could be a case study on the making of a gu bernatorial candidate, Howard J. Samuels is already waging an intensive, probably unprece dented, behindthescenes cam paign for the Democratic nomi nation next year.

description: Versatilethat's the Sibe rian husky. He's at home in the frozen Arctic tundra. And he's at home with Frank and Phyllis Brayton in the San Joaquin Valley where the temperature soars to 108 degrees.

description: WHITE PLAINS, July 18 Texaco, the second largest oil company in the United States, today announced that it in tended to move half its 2,000 employe work force from cor porate headquarters in New York City to Westchester County.

description: WASHINGTON, July 18 President Nixon ended the freeze today on prices for health care and food, except for beef, as he outlined the fourth phase of his 23month old effort to combat price and wage inflation.

title: A.C.L.U. GETS A WRIT IN FINGERPRINT CASE
description: TRENTON, July 18  The Union County Prosecutor's of fice was ordered today to show cause on Monday why it should not be forbidden to take the fingerprints of more than 40 Newark eighthgrade pupils in a murder investigation.

title: Rock Promoters Expect 150,000 At Watkins Glen Fete July 28
description: More than 80,000 tickets have been purchased at $10 each to the allday rock concert and catiip out on July 28 at the Watkins Glen Grand Prix racetrack upstate near Elmira, and tickets are still selling at 5,000 a day.

title: Vietnam Bonus Backed
description: BOSTON, luly 18 (AP)AF $15million extension to the Vietnam bonus bill gained initial approval in the Massa chusetts Senate today. The bill which could be reconsidered, would provide a $300 bonus for Vietnam veterans and $200 for those who served elsewhere,

title: 2 Socialist Groups Sue Nixon and Aides Over Harassment
description: The Socialist Workers par ty filed a lawsuit in Federal court here yesterday, seeking more than $27million in dam ages from President Nixon and other Government officials on charges of violating the party's constitutional rights with ille gal activities related to the Watergate affair.

title: Westport Will Seek Special Apartments for Elderly
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 18  Leaders of a successful fight to overturn a controversial zoning measure that had allowed apartment houses in this affluent Fairfield County town said today that they would work to establish a limited number of apartment units for the elderly.

title: Pentagon Hoping Iran Will Buy F14's
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The Defense Department hopes to ease its troublesome cost prob lems with a new Navy fighter plane, the F14 Tomcat, by sell ing some of them to Iran and perhaps to allies in Europe such as West Germany.

title: City Pondering Move on a Music Shell That Won't
description: This is the moving tale of the portable music shell that will not move. The Minnie Guggenheimer Shell, which has been used to take Met ropolitan Opera and New York Philharmonic concerts to parks in the five boroughs, sits today in Central Park like a beached blue whale, wait ing for the city to decide what to do with it.

title: Angry Soviet Georgians in Israeli Port City Await Improvements
description: ASHDOD, Israel, July 18 Life in this sprawling port city has been disrupted by four days of hunger strikes and rioting by several thousand angry new immigrants from Soviet Georg ia demanding better jobs and living conditions.

title: War and More War
description: WASHINGTONIt was officially au thorized by act of Congress in August of 1964. It was known then as the Vietnam war. In 1970, when our forces went into Cambodia, it became known as the Indochina war. Now, by act of Congress, it has been authorized again albeit for only 45 daysand it is called the Cambodian war.

title: Albany Session Put Off 2 Days As TransitBond Drive Falters
description: The special session of the Legislature due to begin next week was postponed for two days yesterday after a three hour private meeting at which Governor Rockefeller failed to win the support of legislative leaders for his plan to put a transportationbond issue on the agenda.

title: U.N. Body Backs Bahamas
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18The Security Council voted unanimously today to recommend that the Bahamas be admitted as a member of the United Nations. This rec ommendation will be acted upon in the General Assembly in September. The Bahamas became an independent nation within the British Common wealth on July 10 and made application for United Nations membership on the same day. After approval by the General Assembly, the Bahamas will become the 135th member of the world organization.

title: Bootstrap Doctrine
description: LONDON, July 18The President of the United States is accused of conspiratorial involvement in serious crimes. He turns out to have a large amount of physical evidence that may bear directly on the truth of the crim inal charges. He announces that he is going to keep the evidence secret, that he has a right to do so because he is President.

title: Personal Income Gains; Housing Starts Decline
description: Personal income of American consumers rose to records in June, but housing starts, an other indicator of the econ omy's strength, fell sharply in the month.

title: New State Education Reviewer To Study 2 SlumArea Schools
description: Daniel Klepak, the Gover nor's newly appointed director of educationperformance re view, said yesterday that he would compare two city slum area schools with widely dif fering reading levels to try to determine why one works and the other doesn't.

description: PITTSBURGHRecalled John Morlan, right handed pitcher, from Charleston of Inter national League; optioned Tom DeHore, pitcher, to Charleston on 24hour recall.

description: OXFORD, Miss., July 18 (AP)The University of Mis sissippi has bought Rowan Oak, William Faulkner's home here, for $175,000 and will make it part of the new university cultural center.

title: Music FirstNight Crowd Jams Concert in the Park

description: LONDON, July I8  Jack Hawkins, one of the most dis tinctive and durable British film and stage actors, died here today in St. Stephen's Hospital. He was 62 years old.

description: ATHENS, July 18The Gov ernment today renewed its charges of subversion against deposed King Constantine and ordered an inventory and valua tion of the contents of the royal palaces in Athens.

As a result quite a few business people, such as hotel and motel operators and garagemen, have to wor ry about the broadening im pact of court rulings about due process of law.

description: MANILA, July 18 (UPI)  A domestic passenger ship carrying nearly 700 people sank early Monday in typhoontossed seas about 120 miles southeast of Manila, the Philippine Coast Guard said today.

description: TALLAHASSEE. Fla., July 18 (UPI)  The Florida Supreme Court upheld today a law re quiring newspapers to print re plies :of political candidates whom they criticize.

The metallined boxes in which the diamonds had been packed were found empty when the El Al airliner landed at Lon don's Heathrow Airport, the of ficials said.

description: WASHINGTON, July I8 (UPI) At least 84 persons who worked in President Nixon's executive offices or for his re election campaign have been given Government posts else where in the Administration, 59 of them in independent regula tory agencies, a House com mittee reported today.

title: Phnom Penh Evacuates a Jail Near Front
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July IS (UPI)The Cambodian Government has begun evacu ating 2,000 prisoners from a jail six and a half miles south of Phnom Penh because of fight ing less than a mile away.

The property located 20 miles from Digital's head quarters in Maynard, Mass., in cludes 173 acres of land and 700,000 square feet of manu facturing and administrative space. No figures were avail able on the sale price.

The establishments failed to correct firstinspection viola tions, according to Gordon Chase, the Health Services Ad ministrator, and did not present a valid reason for such failure at hearings held by the agency. title: Auction Markets Stressed by Big Board
description: The New York Stock Ex change issued yesterday a dis cussion paper on the central market system that stresses the preservation of exchange auc tion markets as the essential pricing mechanism for listed securities.

title: Equity Financing
description: An underwriting group managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., and Robert W. Baird & Co., is offering 900,000 shares of Wis consin Public Service Corporation common stock  par value $8 a share  at $16.75 a share. The company will use the net proceeds from the sale of the additional common stock to reduce short term debt incurred for construction purposes. The company's stock closed unchanged at 163/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Comic Relief From the BrownBag Man
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  They brought Tony U back today  and maybe they should make him a regular guest on the nationally tele vised Senate Watergate hear ings.

title: An OomPahPah Band Beats Noon Heat in Park
description: I remember back in the nineteentwenties when bands like this would play on the ships and in the streets greet ing incoming immigrants from Austria and Switzer land, Sue Aaron of Jamaica, Queens, said yesterday above the strains of the Beer Bar rel Polka being played by the oompahpah band in the Central Park Zoo.

title: Sundance In Yacht Lead
description: LYSEKIL, Sweden, July 18 (UPI)  Ernest Fay of the United States, at the helm of Sundance, kept the overall lead in the world 5.5Meter yachting championships today, after placing fourth in the fourth heat.

title: Citibank Unit in Italy
description: MILAN, July 18 (Reuters) Citifin, Citicorp Finanziaria, S.P.A., an affiliate of the First National City Corporation of New York, has announced its formation here. It said it would offer a service of personal loans for up to three months as well as longerterm loans for property buying.

description: Rent Board Blocked by Writ

title: Cat Leads to Discovery Of Strangled Bronx Woman
description: A stray cat led to the dis covery yesterday of a woman apparently strangled to death in her secondfloor apartment at. 350 East 134th Street in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx.

title: Screen: A Vampire's Lot: Scream Blacula Scream' at Two Theaters The Cast
description: Blacula, when last we saw him (late last August, in point of fact), had met his end on the roof of a power station. Undone by morning, as often happens to vampires, he had been reduced to no more than a bag full of bones in the first feeble rays of the smog-filtered Los Angeles sun.Now those bones are made to rise again. Brought back to undeadness through the meddling of a dissident Southern California voodoo priest, Blacula is again condemned to walk the earthin "Scream Blacula Scream," which opened yesterday at the Criterion and Juliet II Theaters, and which is not, as the title might suggest, too much fun for anybody.Blacula never asked for his fate anyway. Originally Mamuwalde, a distinguished African prince, he had been bittenand renamedby Count Dracula as long ago as the 18th century. His current incarnations among jive-talking West Coast dudes and their ladies are not greatly to his taste, and despite some involuntary spreading of his habit (he creates at least six new vampires in the first half hour of the movie), his only real interest is to get himself back whereand whenhe came from. To this end he enlists the aid of Lisa, a non-dissident voodoo priestess of high repute ("When it comes to voodoo, Lisa has more natural power than anyone in the last 10 years.")That's really all the movie is about. Mamuwalde's torment, Lisa's efforts, and, of course, the knuckle-headed failure of the local cops to admit that there are vamires among us. And that simply is not enough. Despite all its blood-letting, "Scream Blacula Scream" fails for lack of incident, weakness of invention, insufficient story.The director, Bob Kelljan, has at least the shadow of an ideathat the vampire's curse really is a curse, all pain and no pleasure, and is as miserable for the vampire as for his victim. In William Marshall (Mamuwalde) and Pam Grier (Lisa) he has two good performerspowerful, ironic, potentially rather complicated. But he hasn't enough for them to do. It is as if the movie had completed filming without their ever having developed the shooting script.But I'll bet there will be another chance for Blacula. I get that feeling from a movie that determines the only cure for vampires to be a wooden stake through the heartand then leaves its principal antagonist suffering from nothing more than a very pesky chest pain.

description: It has been estimated that more than a million people will stay at the 44 campsites within New York State's For est Preserve in the Adiron dack and Catskill Mountains this season.

description: Two cars of a subway train became partially derailed late last night while being switched from southbound express tracks to northbound tracks at the IRT station at 86th Street and Lexington Avenue.

description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 18Though the Cambodian insurgents continue pressing their attacks less than 10 miles from the edges of Phnom Penh despite heavy bombardment by American planes, there is no fear or panic visible in the capital's populationonly dis couragement and helplessness

description: The movement toward an 8 per cent prime rateinitiated on Monday by the First Na tional Bank of Chicago  gath ered steam yesterday amid widespread predictions in the financial community that this new level would become gen eral by the end of the week.

description: ATHENS, July 18'x2014;Greece's Orthodox Church, crippled by one of the worst crises of lead ership in its 123year history, has just been hit by charges of major financial scandals.

description: The special session of the Legislature due to begin next week was postponed for two days yesterday after a three hour private meeting at which Governor Rockefeller failed to win the support of legislative leaders for his plan to put a transportationbond issue on the agenda.

description: ELMIRA, N. Y., July 18 (UPI) Marian Burke of San An tonio, Tex., was declared today the official winner of the 1973 Powder Puff Derby transcon tinental air race for women. Her Cessna 182 covered the 2,542miles from Carlsbad, Calif., to Elmira at an average speed of 163.073 miles an hour.

title: Catrone Doubles His Pleasure
description: Frankie Catrone is u plump, smiling, unassuming trainer who thrusts himself into the picture only when he has to, such as when he wins a Kentucky Derby, or when he has two winners out of two starts. It was in the latter circumstances that he has to, such as when he tographers at At Aqueduct yesterday. Catrone Race handles the East Tracks ern division of Mrs. Ada L.

description: WASHINGTON, July I8Following is the text of President Nixon's state ment outlining Phase 4 of the eco nomic stabilization program:

title: Roosevelt Island
description: Almost three decades after his death, one of the greatest New Yorkers who ever lived is at last to have a fitting memorial in New York City. One can hardly count the noisy, noxious F.D.R. Drive as a memorial to anyone; but it is possible that Welfare Island  rebuilt, renewed and renamed Franklinwill finally express this city's pride in the man who lifted up the country when it was at the lowest point in its history, whose vision saved it from despair and, some historians believe, from revolution.

title: Sihanouk in Exile: Busy, Determined and Unforgiving
description: PEKING, July 18 (Reuters) He rises every day at 9 A.M., dispenses with breakfast al  though he has seven personal cooks, and, despite Peking's atheist environment, says pray ers for half an hour in a small Buddhist shrine within the high walls of his comfortable resi dence, formerly the Chinese Foreign Ministry.

title: Excerpts From Testimony Before the Senate Committee Investigating Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony today on the 23d day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: Cities of Flowers
description: Daisies are in bloom, not only along rural roadsides but even in the city. Look in a neglected corner, at the edge of a rubble heap, in a crack in the pavement on a back street, and you may find them. They may be twisted or broken, their leaves tattered, but there will be a bud or two on even the least of them, and the bud will open into a whitepetaled, yellowcentered flower, a daisy.

title: Office of Cox Is the Calm At Eye of Capital Storm
description: WASHINGTON, July 18If there is a calm at the center of the storm created by the Watergate scandal, it is the fortresslike headquarters of the Government's special prosecu tion force, tucked away in the ninth floor of an office build ing three blocks from the White House.

description: Port Police Vote To Report Today But Not to Work

description: WASHINGTON, July.18 (AP) The Chesapeake & Potomac Telephone Company said today that it was insisting that the White House agree to conform to regulations regarding record ing devices placed on tele phones used by President Nixon.

description: WASHINGTON, July 18Let's see what happens if we give the President the benefit of the doubt on his deci sion two years ago to create The Monster With Total Recall.

description: Private industry took its first step yesterday to get into the business of designing and fi nancing a space rocket, once the sole province of the Fed eral Government.

title: B. P. Opens Budapest Unit
description: BUDAPEST, July 18 (AP) The British Petroleum Company and A for, a Hungarian com pany, have opened their first joint gasoline station in Buda pest. The station is also B.P.'s first in a Communist country.

title: Union Carbide Net Up 43% to Record For First Quarter
description: F. Perry Wilson, chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday that net in come for the first quarter climbed by 43 per cent to a record $76.9million, or $1.27 a share, from $53.9million, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier. The 1972 figures include 3 cents a share for extraordinary items.

title: British Paper Loses Court Suit To Publish Thalidomide A article
description: LONDON, July 17 (Reuters)  A leading British newspaper today lost its court battle to publish an article on children born with deformities after their mothers had taken the drug thalidomide. The paper's editor immediately asserted that the outcome was a blow to freedom of the press.

title: People in Sports: Howell To Sharpen Blades at 40
description: The Golden Blades of the World Hockey Association took a page from out of the past yesterday and brought Harry Howell back to New York. Howell played 17 sea sons with the Rangers and after the 19661967 season was the recipient of the James Norris Memorial Tro phy as the league's out standing defenseman. Howell signed a twoyear contract, reported at $60,000 annually. For the last four seasons he had been playing for the California Golden Seals and the Los Angeles Kings of the National League. Los Angeles released him earlier in the week Golden Blades is the new name for the former New York Raiders.

title: Kaat of Twins Stops Yanks, 30
description: Jim Kaat of the Minnesota Twins buffaloed the New York Yankees, 30, yesterday and forced them to give back half the yardage they had gained the night before in the Ameri can League's Eastern race.

title: LaRue and Ulasewicz Deny Knowing Who Ordered Payments of $450,000
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Two participants in the Watergate coverup described today, in bizarre details, how they had funneled $450,000 of Presiden tial campaign money to the seven original Watergate de fendants and their lawyers.

title: GUARDSMEN TO AID POLLUTION SURVEY
description: TRENTON, July 18New Jersey National Guard troops will be spending part of their drill time over the coming year searching for sources of water pollution by collecting samples from tributaries feeding 13 ma jor lakes and reservoirs.

description: BALTIMORE, July 19 (AP)  Sherman W. Dobson, 20 years old, a ministers son, was charged today with killing a Maryland state legislator under indictment on heroin conspir acy charges.

description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 19 The defending champion, Art Silvestrone, fired a fiveunder par 65 to tie with Pat Schwab for the second round lead in the 53d New Jersey State open championship today at Spring Brook Country Club.

description: Fist fights broke out last night at a community school board meeting on the Lower East Side after a board mem ber punched the board presi dent as the panel was moving to strip the controversial dis trict superintendent, Luis Fuen tes, of much of his power.

description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) President Nixon announced today that he would nominate a former astronaut, William A. Anders, for a term on the Atomic Energy Commission. The term expires June 30, 1978.

title: Kennecott Earnings Up

description: WASHINGTON, July 19 The Nixon Administration will end production controls on basic farm commodities for the first time since the Korean War as part of its Phase 4 economic plan.

title: Betting on Barrera Pays Off
description: When El Espanoleto won Aqueduct's third race yester day at a firstplace payoff of $27.20, the question went up among some of the students in the crowd of 19,710, Where has Laz been hiding this one? The best way to answer that, of course, was to ask Laz himself. Laz happens to be Lazaro Barrera, a 48 yearold Cuban who has estab lished himself as one of the better trainers on the continent. It was Laz who saddled El Es panoleto, a 2yearold Ken tuckybred son of Three Bagger.

title: Librarians Speak Up
description: The American Library Association has filed a petition requesting the Supreme Court to reconsider its recent pornography rulings. The action underscores the libra rians concern over the fact that the Court's majority may have been so preoccupied with the offensiveness of pornographic motion pictures and other public exploi tation of lurid sex that it paid too little attention to the potential effect of the rulings on books and libraries. Only Justice William O. Douglas, in his dissenting opinion, warned that the decisions may be the signal for local vigilante raids on the nation's libraries.

description: WHY JOHNNY CAN'T ADD: THE FAILURE OF THE NEW MATH. By Morris Kline 173 pp. St. Martin's Press. $6.95.

description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 19 The good old boys from the South shattered the suburban quiet this morning with a rebel yell during the Jets practice.

description: LONG TIEN, South Viet nam, July 13For the farm ers of this village in the Mekong Delta harvesting rice is still a risky business, as it has been for years.

description: RICHMOND, July 19 (AP) George Cavich, 41 years old, who received a new heart last week in a transplant operation at the Medical College of Vir ginia Hospital here, died today. Officials said his body rejected the new heart.

title: Judges Bar Police Protest At Tunnels and Airports
description: Hundreds of Port Authority policemen refused to work at the authority's bridges, tun nels and airports yesterday, and there were several traffic tieups, mainly at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and at Newark Airport.

title: KARL PRIBRAM, 95, ECONOMIST, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Karl Pribram, a retired Government economist, author and emeritus professor of the University of Frankfurt, died Saturday in Washington, where he lived. He was 95 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Chuck Connors, the actor, has been given a samovar by one of his fans, Leonid I. Brezhnev. When the Soviet party leader was at the West ern White House recently, Mr. Connors presented him with two 45caliber frontier guns and a Western hat, and Mr. Brezhnev leaped into Mr. Connors's arms. Mr. Con nors was reported to be de lighted with his gifts, but it could not be ascertained whether or not he leaped for joy.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SEA BRIGHT, July 19Ocean racing created interest off Sea Bright and Sandy Hook long before the turn of the century. A spectator fleet of 400 boats jammed with about 50,000 persons sailed forth to watch the 1885 America's Cup battle between Puritan and England's fifth unsuccess ful challenger, Genesta, off the Sea Bright beach.

title: E. F. HUTTON REPORTS LOSS IN 2D QUARTER
description: E. F. Hutton & Co., one of the nation's largest investment houses, reported yesterday that it lost $922,000 in the second quarter of this year, a period of extremely depressed earn ings for the securities industry.

title: SecurityConscious Conservative Robert Charles Mardian
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 A brighteyed, muscular man who looks and growls like George C. Scott, the actor, in Patton, Robert Charles Mardian was one of the most aggressive conservatives in the first Nixon Administra tion.

title: KISSINGER DENIES WHITE HOUSE ROLE IN FALSE RAID DATA
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Henry A. Kissinger declared today that the White House neither ordered nor was i?? aware of any falsification of records on the secret bombing of Cambodia ordered by Presi dent Nixon in March, 1969.

title: Watergate, Watergate Everywhere
description: ISLA NEGRA, ChileMy memory is not too good: so that I cannot tell the day exactly, nor month, nor yearbut I believe that, no more than five years ago, something strange happened in Montevideo, ,capital of Uruguay. Op posite the Soviet Embassy, there was a quietlooking house, several stories high, and surrounded with gardens. But very few residents. In fact, it seemed to be vacant. I don't know just what incident led to the opening up of that rather somber building, What was found there, however, created some thing of a sensation. The whole place was a vast telephone exchange, op erated by a handful of people, quite invisible, who got lost there and haven't been found to this day. Every phone call, private conversation, burst of laughter and even snore of the Rus sians was monitored, taped, indexed and sent off from that building to the C.I.A. in the United States.

title: Open Olympics Openly Arrived At
description: When the international Olympic brass meet in Varna, Bulgaria, in the fall a new eligibility code for amateur athletes will be submitted for adoption. Under the pro posed regulations practices that have not been officially approved in the pastsuch as an athlete's cashing in openly on his reputationwould be permitted. About the only thing forbidden in the liberalized code would be direct cash payments for competition. Without jeopardizing his amateur standing, an athlete could take money for television appearances, for lending his byline to magazine articles or books, for endorsing underwear, spiked shoes or shaving cream, for coaching or for working as camp coun selor. A professional baseball player could qualify as an amateur dikus thrower. A professional in any sport could apply for reinstatement as an amateur in that sport and get clearance after meeting the specified conditions.

title: Time Inc. Sets Dissolution Of Sterling Communications
description: Time Inc. will redeem all of the publiclyheld debentures of Sterling Communications, Inc., for a cash outlay of $3.1mil lion, it was announced yester day. Time, a majority owner of Sterling Communications, will also acquire Sterling's assets and assume its liabilities.

title: Senate Calls Critics to Inquiry on Colby
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Senate Armed Services Com mittee said today that it would reopen public hearings tomor row to hear testimony against President Nixon's nomination of William E. Colby as the new Director of Central Intelligence.

title: KABUL AFTER COUP QUIET, PATROLLED
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 19 (Reuters)Tanks and armored cars remained posted at key points in Kabul today, two days after a coup d'etat that turned Afghanistan from mon archy into a republic.

title: FOOD STAMP BAN IN STRIKES VOTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Despite the threat of a veto, the House passed tonight a gen eral farm bill that included a ban on food stamps for strikers.

title: FUCHSBERG GIVES PLAN FOR BACKLOG
description: Jacob D. Muchsberg, Demo cratic candidate for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals, declared yesterday that, if elected, he would seek the ap pointrnent of 1,000 experienced lawyers as temporary State Su preme Court justices to up the backlog on court calendars.

title: Grain Men Expected to Say U.S. Knew of Soviet Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Top executives of several grain companies are expected to tell Senate investigators tomorrow that they gave the Agriculture Department advance informa tion on Soviet wheat deals that its officials have denied receiv ing.

title: Files Is Glad That Giants Put Him Back in Middle
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 19  After two years of rebellion and resig nation, Jim Files is relieved to be back where he feels he belongs on the New York defense  middle linebacker.

title: Ambush Suspect Is Picked in LineUp
description: Andrew Jackson, a reputed member of the Black Liberation Army, has been identified by eyewitnesses as a participant in the ambush shooting last Janu ary of two policemen in Queens, the police reported yes terday.

title: Mrs. Daniel Riesel Dead; Assistant Attorney General
description: Mrs. Rhoda Schutz Riesel, who was recently appointed an assistant state attorney general in the consumerfraud depart ment here, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital of an an eurysm of the aorta. She was 26 years old and lived at 308 West 77th Street.

title: EDWIN S. MORGAN
description: Edwin S. Morgan, a former stock broker with Shearson Hammill & Co., and earlier an executive with the Lone Star Cement Company, died Wednes day in a nursing home in Plainfield, N. J. He was 88 years old and lived at 155 East 49th Street.

title: World's Greatest Jazz Band Zips Along
description: Five years after its found ing, the World's Greatest Jazz Band has trimmed down from its original nine men to seven and, in the process, has loosened up and found a freshness that was not al ways apparent. At the Half Note, where the band is play ing, the ensemble work is re laxed but beautifully knit, riding easily on the firm, pli ant rhythmic foundation laid down by Bob Haggart's bass and Cliff Leeman's drums.

title: People in Sports: Golf Awaits a New Nicklaus
description: Next week's $175,000 Ca nadian open lost one of its chief drawing cards yester day when Jack Nicklaus sent his regrets to tournament officials in Toronto. The rea son for his withdrawal? He had promised his wife, Bar bara, that he would be at home in Columbus, Ohio, when their fifth child was born.

title: LIDDY SAID TO LINK NIXON TO 71 PLOT
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Robert C. Mardian, a former Assistant Attorney General, testified today that a Water gate conspirator, G. Gordon Liddy, gave him the clear im pression a year ago that Pres ident Nixon had authorized 1971 burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: Upheaval in Kabul
