Mohammad Daud Khan, reflects in part the palace in trigues and tribal rivalries that might be expected in a country which, as one foreign diplomat put it, is about to spring right into the sixteenth century.

title: Ryan Is In and Dick Williams Is Out
description: Nolan Ryan, who was bypassed for the AllStar Game despite a pair of nohitters this season, was named to the American League squad yesterday under a new ruling that added one man to each team. Willie Mays is expected to be the additional National Leaguer selected.

title: Orangutans Learning TickTackToe at Zoo
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP)  Orangutans at the Portland, Ore., zoo are being trained to play electronic ticktaktoe with humans who gape at them from out side their cages.

title: Business Scores Phase 4 And Predicts Price Rises
description: There is no escape from price increases in most of the industrial products we make.

title: BIGGEST MAIL UNION RATIFIES NEW PACT
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) The largest postal union an nounced today that its members had ratified a new contract with the Postal Service pro viding a 14 per cent rise in wages and fringe benefits over two years, plus cost of living raises.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH SLOWED SHARPLY IN JUNE QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The nation's economy grew at the unsually small rate of 2.6 per cent in the AprilJune quarter, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 The Association of American Railroads estimated today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled 15.9 billion ton miles, 15.2 per cent above the 1972 week. Carloadings during the same week totaled 522,517 cars, up 8.9 per cent. The American Trucking Associa tions, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 9.2 per cent above last year.

title: NATO Chief Offers Six  Point Revision Of the Declaration
description: BRUSSELS, July 19Joseph M. A. H. Luns, Secretary Gen eral of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, has pre sented the alliance countries with a set of guidelines for their talks on a new declara tion of principles for the or ganization.

title: Kinzel Assails Panel's Pension Plan As an Endorsement of the Status Quo
description: The chairman of the Perma nent State Commission on Pub lic Employe Pensions yesterday sharply criticized the recom mendations of the Select Com mittee on Pensions.

title: ELKS VOTE TO END BAR TO NONWHITES
description: CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) Delegates to the annual meeting of the Benevolent and Protec tive Order of Elks gave the nec essary twothirds approval today to rescind a whites only membership clause that threatened local lodges with loss of liquor licenses in sev eral states.

title: Goalby and Massengale Tied on 65's
description: ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP) Bob Goalby and Rik Massen gale matched fiveunderpar 65's and shared the firstround lead today in the $210,000 St. Louis Children's Hospital golf tournament.

title: Chargers Thomas  Traded to Redskins
description: IRVINE, Calif., July 21 (AP)  The San Diego Chargers traded Duane Thomas to the Washington Redskins tonight for two high future draft choices, ending a bizarre one year episode in the career of the controversial running back.

title: Davis's Yacht Leads Hall's After 4 of 6 Fireball Races
description: SAYVILLE, L.1., July 19Lee Davis of Birmingham, Mich., and Graham Hall of Larchmont, N.Y., continued today their twoman battle for the Fire ball Class national sailing championship. Davis added a first, a third and a second in that order to yesterday's fourthplace finish and took a slight lead over Hall.

title: Nixon Campaign Committee Sued for Million by Donor
description: CLEVELAND, July 18 A class action lawsuit seeking $1million in punitive damages from the Committee to Reelect the President and its finance committee because of illegal use of campaign funds was filed in United States District Court here today.

title: Lansky Pleads Not Guilty To Tax Evasion Charges
description: MIAMI, July 19 (UPI)Meyer Lansky, the reputed financial adviser to the underworld, pleaded not guilty today to two counts of tax evasion.

title: Aide Asserts Rogers to Remain On Job, Cites Plan for Fall Trip
description: WASHINGTON, July 19A close aide to Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that planning was continuing for Mr. Rogers's schedule this fall, including the trip to New York for the opening of the United Nations General Assem bly in September.

title: Report Links Skylab Trouble to Design Oversight
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Dversights in the design of the Skylab space vehicle, coupled with failures of the men re sponsible for building it to talk to one another, were blamed today for the damage shortly after launch that almost made a total loss of the whole $2.5 billion project.

title: LIDDY SAID TO LINK NIXON TO 71 PLOT
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Robert C. Mardian, a former Assistant Attorney General, testified today that a Water gate conspirator, G. Gordon Liddy, gave him the clear im pression a year ago that Pres ident Nixon had authorized a 1971 burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: Rogers Favors Both Koreas in U.N.
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, July 20The United States be lieves that the admission of both South Korea and North Korea to the United Nations would recognize the reality of the two Governments, Secre tary of State William P. Rogers said today.

title: Records of Evidence
description: The telephone call to Senator Ervin yesterday, pur porting to convey President Nixon's willingness to turn over the secret tape recordings of his White House conversations, was a hoax; the White House says there will be no Presidential decision on the issue of the tapes until the weekend. However, we hope that the earlier false announcement was not really wrong but only premature. The legal grounds are dubious, the practical justifications nonexistent, for the White House to with hold this evidence from public scrutiny.

title: Advertising: A Fear of Rules
description: In some advertising quar ters there is concern that the changes announced by the Federal Trade Commis sion on Tuesday could lead to more rule making.

title: Food Prices Steady Here, but Rises Are Imminent
description: There was no immediate rise in retail food prices in the metropolitan area yesterday following the Government's lifting of the price freeze, but the consensus seemed to be that in about a week or even sooner there would be a num er of increases.

title: Head of Canadian Truce Observers Leaves Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 19Michel Gauvin, head of the Canadian delegation to the International Commission of Control and Supervision, left Saigon today after having struggled for nearly six months to make the commission an ef fective peacekeeping organiza tion.

title: Board Head Struck In Brawl at School; Fuentes Power Cut
description: Fist fights broke out last night at a community school board meeting on the Lower East Side after a board mem ber punched the board presi dent as the panel was moving to strip the controversial dis trict superintendent, Luis Fuen tes, of much of his power.

title: Concert
description: About 50 years ago, while he was conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Leo pold Stokowski formed a 100member concert band called the Band of Gold, which played annual concerts at the Academy of Music. For these programs Mr. Sto kowski translated a number of standard works into band language.

title: Bridge:
Roman Police Report a Threat To Sever a Finger of Getty Boy
description: ROME, July 19The police here said today that people describing themselves as the kidnappers of 16yearold J. Paul Getty 3d had offered two days ago to send one of his fingers to his mother to prove that they were holding him.

title: Colts Take New Shape Without Unitas and His Court
description: TOWSON, Mr., July 19 The new Baltimore Colts practiced in the heat today at their new training camp, Towson State College, under a new coach, Howard Schnel lenberger, and the new player with high visibility was Mike Kaczmarek, who has taken Bubba Smith's place on the defensive line.

title: A Museum Shows Notable Art Fakes
description: MINNEAPOLISReversing the usual process by which one museum tries to wheedle others into lending their fin est paintings and sculptures for temporary exhibition, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts has opened Fakes and For geries, a summer show rep resenting four years of whee dling other museums into lending their most embar rassing acquisitions. Among the 291 objects, which include genuine specimens for com parison with the fraudulent, there are loans  sometimes anonymous  from leading American and European col lections.

title: Dunlea Hurley, Newsman And Publicity Director, 64
description: Dunlea(Pat) Hurley, a news paper man and publicrelations director, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Washington. He was 64 years old and lived in New Hope, Pa.

title: Senate Unit Cuts Missile Projects Sought by Pentago
description: WASHINGTON, July 19A Senate subcommittee has eli minated from the Administra tion's proposed defense budget most of the new strategic weapons programs that the Joint Chiefs of Staff demanded last year as a condition for supporting the agreements on strategic arms control with the Soviet Union.

title: Police Department Eases Punishment Of Gratuity Takers
description: Veteran policemen who are found guilty of accepting minor gratuities will no longer auto matically face dismissal and deprivation of pensions worth hundreds of thousands of dol lars, under a new policy enun ciated yesterday by Police Commissioner Donald F. Caw ley.

title: State Grand Jury Hears Camden Mayor 3 Hours
description: TRENTON, July 19 (UPI)  Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden testified for almost three hours today be fore a state grand jury in vestigating alleged corrup tion in his city.

title: Judge, at Police Forum, Defends LowBail Policy
description: In an unusual appearance be fore a police forum today, Judge Bruce McMarion Wright of Criminal Court in Manhattan defended his policy of setting low bail for defendants that live in or have economic ties in the community in which they are arrested.

title: Europe Pollution Drive Asked By Common Market Nations
description: BRUSSELS, July 19 (UPI) The European Common Mar ket asked its nine member na tions today to begin the first Continentwide attack on pol lution.

title: Second Watergate Grand Jury Is Called
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Judge John J. Sirica ordered today that a second Watergate grand jury be empaneled at the request of the special prosecu tor, Archibald Cox, whose of fice indicated that the volume of material ready for resen tation was more than the origi nal grand jury could handle.

title: SHORT INTEREST SHOWS ADVANCE
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange as of the close of business on July 13, reflecting transactions through the trade date of July 6, in creased to 20,141,505 shares from 18,701,944 shares on June 15. This was the highest since Dec. 15, 1972, when the short interest was 22,390,386 shares.

title: Lamb or Clams for Weekend Chefs
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an aster isk are followed by a recipe.

title: Arab Seizes 17 in Athens, Trades Them for Safe Exit
description: ATHENS, July 19 (AP)A Palestinian with a submachine gun seized 17 persons in a ho tel lobby here today after fail ing in an attempt to shoot up an Israeli airline office. He threatened to kill the hostages, including five Americans, but let them go after being prom ised safe conduct to the Middle East.

title: City's MinorityJob Plan Hailed; Violations by Contractors Cited
description: The Lindsay administration's latest program for increasing minoritygroup employment in the building trades, which goes into effect today, was strongly endorsed yesterday by city of ficials, leaders of minority groups and rankandfile union members at a noonhour rally in City Hall Park.

title: Yanks and Mets Resume Races Tonight
description: The Yankees and Mets rested yesterday a half a con tinent apart before resuming their separate strugglesthe Yankees to hold first place in the American League's East, the Mets to vacate last place in the National League's East.

title: WEED CAPTURES  THIRD SAIL RACE
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 19 Joseph W. Weed, sailing the redhulled International sloop, Mischief, and Mrs. Elaine Keehn's Class S Sloop, Red Witch, remained undefeated at the Larchmont Yacht Club's 75th Race Week today by win ning for the third time when the senior divisions returned after the juniors had sailed for three days. The senior series runs until Saturday.

title: Invitation to Disaster
description: Postponement of the special session of the Legislature almost certainly portends trouble for the historic action that Governor Rockefeller has promised in order to head off an approaching crisis in the state's transportation system. Even before the Governor reveals his plan supposedly by the end of this weekit is apparent that his legislative leaders are balking. Senate Majority Leader Warren M. Anderson says he is concerned about what another huge bond issue would do to the state's credit rating and Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea appears to favor waiting until December, when a newly elected mayor of this city will be ready to take over.

title: Meat Processors Ordered Not to Use Certain Mixes
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) The Food and Drug Adminis tration ordered meat processors today to stop using certain curing mixes for prepared meats because they could pro duce a cancercausing agent.

title: 3 EMPLOYERS CITED IN S.I. TANK BLAST
description: The Labor Department an nounced yesterday that it had cited three employers for al leged violation of Federal job safety standards and proposed civil penalties totaling $27,200 in connection with the Staten Island gas tank explosion that killed 40 workmen last Feb ruary.

title: G.I. Mortgage Bill Passed
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) The House sent to the White House today a bill to allow veterans to obtain home mort gage financing in the tight money market. The bill would life the restrictions that allow the Veterans Administration to approve home loan rates at no more than 6 per cent.

title: CONNORS DEFEATS MOORE IN 3 SETS
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., July 19 (UPI)  Jimmy Connors upset topseeded Stan Smith earlier this week, smashed his way to another victory today, defeat ing Ray Moore, of South Africa, 61, 26, 63, in the United States professional tennis cham pionships.

title: Cloud Over Housing
description: For the family thinking of moving from an apartment to a house, or from a small house to a larger one, these warm, sunny summer days many seem ideal for house hunting.

title: Little Leaguer Wins Right to Play Without Haircut
description: NEWARK, July 19Supe rior Court Judge Irwin I. Kim melman issued an order today designed to give 12yearold Timothy Wirkus of Union Township his chance at the Lit tle League World Series. The result was a 90 victory for the Union Little League team over Milburn, with Timothy playing left field in the sixth and last inning.

title: INTEREST RATES SHOW AN UPTURN
description: Interest rates spiraled to still higher levels yesterday in re sponse to the continuing squeeze on the banking system and a lack of any surprise initiative under Phase 4 to contain infla tion.

title: Aide Declares President Won't Turn Over Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  President Nixon has decided not to give Senate investigators access to the tape recordings of his personal and telephone conversations with Watergate suspects in 1972 and 1973, a White House official said today.

title: 80% of Army Files and Half Of Air Force's Lost in Fire
description: OVERLAND, Mo., July 19 (AP)Officials of the General Services Administration said to day that about 80 per cent of the Army and 50 per cent of the Air Force files on the sixth (floor of the Military Personnel Record Center were destroyed in last week's fire.

title: Stocks Fall, Then Rise; Dow Average Is Up 1.28
description: A rollercoaster stock mar ket went down yesterday morning in its initial reaction to the Phase 4 economic pro gram and then staged a brief, bizarre afternoon rally on a Watergate hearing hoax.

title: Market Place:
description: One of the tragedies of the bear market is the evapora tion of capital pools that have traditionally provided funds for growth of young companies.

title: Chemical Lifts C. D. Rates
description: The Chemical Bank announced yesterday immediate increases on savings rates on certificates of deposit and on its ChemSave Gold Passbook accounts. Certifi cates in amounts of $1,000 to $99,999 held from four to seven years now earn 7 per cent, for example.

title: Collegians in Benefit Game
description: PROVIDENCE, July 19 (UPI)  The United States college allstar team that will compete in the World University Games in Moscow next month will play in a fundraising basket ball game here next Thursday against a team of profession als. Proceeds from the game at the Providence Civic Center will be used to defray the costs of sending the collegians to the Soviet Union.

title: Van Nostrand Beats Garrido In Nassau Tennis, 61, 64
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 19King Van Nostrand of Brightwaters, L. I., defeated Reynaldo Garrido of Woodbury, L. I., 61, 64, today and reached the quarterfinal round of the Nassau invitation tennis tour nament at the Shore Tennis Club.

title: Some U.S. Maccabiah Athletes Thinking of Settling in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, July 19  Jewish sportsmen from 27 countries danced and pranced in the oval of the Ramat Gan Stadium this evening in deliberate con fusion as the Maccabiah torch was extinguished to mark the end of the ninth Jewish Olympics.

title: They Talked Of Everything Except Fashion
description: ROME, July 19Princess Irene Galitzine invited few hundred close friends to her terraced apartment overlooking the Spanish Steps last night. Her cocktail party was sandwiched between her showing and that of Mile Schoen, the other grand lady of the Italian high fashion scene. It gave people who hadn't seen each other in minutes another chance to complain about the heat, the traffic, and the devaluation of the dollar. Nobody talked about fashion.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Museums Support Bill on Fund Aid

title: CAETANO PROMISES MASSACRE INQUIRY
description: LONDON, July 19 (UPI)  Premier Marcello Caetano of Portugal, ending an official fourday visit to London that was marked by protests against his presence, today promised an inquiry into charges that Portuguese troops slaughtered 400 African villagers in Moz ambique last December.

title: HEARINGS START ON L.I. OIL SPILL
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., July 19 About 40 persons, including representatives of town and village governments, environ mental groups and the Long Island Lighting Company, turned out today for a state hearing on the causes of the July 5 spill that washed oil onto beaches from Huntington Bay to Wading River.

title: Biggest Bergen Truck Farmer Sees Steady Prices
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J., July 19Despite what the eco nomists are saying Richard Tice, who runs the biggest truck farm in Bergen County, said today that he thought the retail cost of such summer stories as peaches and corn would not be much higher, if any, than last year.

title: HEALTH CARE COST AT PHASE 3 RATES
description: The Nixon Administration's ruling on health care costs promises to leave the average consumer just where he was before the onemonth interim freeze was announced June 13.

title: Food Prices Steady Here, but Rises Are Imminent
description: There was no immediate rise in retail food prices in the metropolitan area yesterday following the Government's lifting of the price freeze, but the consensus seemed to be that in about a week or even sooner there would be a num ber of increases.

title: Pitcairn Islander Dies
description: GLENDALE, Calif., July 19 (UPI)The death of another member of Pitcairn Island's dwindling population was re ported today, lowering the number of permanent inhab itants to 71. Two years ago there were more than 100 per sons on the small Pacific island settled by mutineers from H.M.S. Bounty and their Tahi tian wives.

title: News of Phase 4 Plans Stirs Gains in Key Markets
description: The Administration's an nouncement that most food prices would be allowed to rise under Phase 4 rules caused a flood of buy orders to inundate the nation's protein markets yesterday.

title: Popular Restaurant That Lacks Taste
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: EUROPE APPROVES DECISIONS BY U.S.
description: PARIS, July. 19Europeans showed mostly positive re actions today to United States moves to fight inflation and defend the dollar. Some money managers suggested the time might be fast approaching for shifting European funds into Wall Street.

title: The Pop Life Stevie Wonder's Most Personal Disk
description: Blindfolded journalists, a whole party of them, board ed a bus in Times Square this weekoff for a sensual pre view, according to the pub licity man in charge.

title: Processors Say Continuation of Beef Ceiling Will Lead to Shortages in August
description: CHICAGO, July 19Angry beef processors charged today that there was nologic in con tinuing ceilings on beef prices, an action they were certain would only lead to shortages in late August and even higher prices after the ceilings were lifted.

title: RAILHAZARD DATA DISCLOSED BY REID
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Representative Ogden R. Reid of New York said today that unions representing employes of the Penn Central's com muter railroads had furnished him with reports of widespread safety hazards that had re sulted in delays, derailments, injuries and fatalities.

title: 3d Defendant in RapeRobberies In the Bronx Is Given 25 Years
description: David Hoover, the third de fendant to be sentenced in a case that allegedly involved up to 18 rapes and robberies in the Bronx, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years impris onment with a mandatory min imum sentence of eight and a third years.

title: Judges Bar Police Protest At Tunnels and Airports
description: Hundreds of Port Authority policemen refused to work at the authority's bridges, tun nels and airports yesterday, and there were several traffic tieups, mainly at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and at Newark Airport.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Medicaid Costs Up 20%

title: People and Business
description: Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president of the Reynolds Metals Company, told a Sen ate Foreign Relations sub committee yesterday that Government  backed insur ance against expropriation of foreign investments serves nations and industry well.

title: Renaming of 3 Places In City Clears Council
description: The City Council yesterday approved unanimously a pro posal to change the name of Welfare Island to Franklin D. Roosevelt Island.

title: DE CARLO INQUIRY SAID TO CLEAR U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  A twomonth investigation by Federal agents has failed to turn up one iota of evidence suggesting offical impropriety in the release from prison last December of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, a leading organized crime figure, according to sources close to the investiga tion.

title: Anybody In Charge Here?
description: Every time it seems exhausted, the Watergate story develops some sensa tional new wrinkle that keeps the whole sordid mess alive. This week it was the disclosure that President Nixon had been recording virtually all his official conversations; so he pre sumably has the power to prove or disprove most charges against him.

title: Urban League Game Set
description: CHICAGO, July 19 (UPI)  Morgan State College and Ala bama State University will play in Soldier Field Sept. 15 in the Chicago Urban League's third annual football game, the league announced today. It will be the first appearance in the game for each team and the first time they have played each other.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 20, 1973 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Middle East.

title: Bonn Drops Bid to Be Included In First Series of Troop Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  West Germany has stopped pressing demand to have some of its own armed forces in cluded in the first round of troop reductions in central Europe to be negotiated by the North Atlantic Treaty Organiza tion and the Warsaw Pact powers this fall in Vienna.

title: ExTrain Engineer Indicted in Fatality In L.I.R.R. Mishap
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 19 Roy W. Tate, a former Long Island Rail Road engineer, was indicted here yesterday on a charge of criminally negligent homicide as a result of an acci dent near the Ronkonkoma station last March 15 in which one passenger was killed and 27 others were injured.

title: MORE FOLLOWERS OF CHAVEZ SEIZED Hundreds Arrested on Coast in Dispute With Teamsters
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 19Across the San Joaquin Valley farm workers were again arrested by the hundreds today as they continued to defy court orders in pressing their strike against grape growers.

title: A RedFaced Ervin Is Victim of Hoax on Nixon Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chair man of the Senate Watergate committee, conceded with some embarrassment today that he had been the victim of a hoax after reporting minutes earlier that the White House would turn over tapes of Presidential conversations.

title: That 1970 Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Of the many Watergate disclosures, one it seems to me has been somewhat mis interpreted. That is the plan for in creased intelligence on internal subver sion which President Nixon approved in July, 1970, and dropped after F.B.I. Director J. Edgar Hoover ob jected.

title: Roundup: Decker Is Up and Twins Win
description: Joe Decker is a 26yearold righthanded pitcher for the Minnesota Twins. He has been up and down the minor league baseball trail since 1965, the year he broke in with Pleasure Valley of the rookie Pioneer League.

title: Senate Votes Bill to Raise Minimum Wage to $2.20
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 The Senate, amid predictions of a Presidential veto, voted today to increase the minimum wage in stages to $2.20 an hour and to extend its coverage to seven million more workers, includ ing domestics.

title: OFFERING PLANNED BY FRANKLIN CORP. Bank Holder Seeks Capital for Acquisition Purposes
description: The Franklin New York Cor poration, the holding company for the Franklin National Bank, said yesterday that it planned an early September offering to its common stockholders of rights to subscribe for some 1,320,000 additional common shares.

title: British Cabinet to Press For Negative Income Tax
description: LONDON, July 19  The British Government announced today that it had decided to introduce legislation that would make the payment of welfare benefits part of the incometax system.

title: Business Briefs O.E.C.D. Says Inflation Problem Grows
description: PARIS, July 19 (UP)  The United States and most of the world's 23 other major developed nations are ex periencing critical inflation problems for which no early solution is in sight, the Organization for Economic Coop eration and Development said today.

title: Sales of Stores Increase
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were esti mated at $917million, 19 per cent above the yearearlier $768million. Total retail store sales were about $9.674million, up 14 per cent from last year's $8.495million.

title: 65,000 GO ON STRIKE AT COAST CANNERIES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (UPI)More than 65,000 Cali fornia cannery workers went on strike today, immediately endangering crops worth $200 million and threatening to drive food prices even higher across the nation.

title: ASHE, CONNORS ARE NET VICTORS
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., July 19 (UPI)Arthur Ashe, quick and confident, defeated Charlie Pas arell and Jimmy Connors beat Ray Moore today in second round matches of the United States professional tennis championships at Longwood.

title: Terrorism Thwarted
description: Yesterday's thwarted terrorist attack on an Israeli air line office in Athens shouldbut probably won'tpro voke some action in the dilatory Committee on Terrorism which was formally convened at the United Nations this week but shows little evidence of serious intent.

title: ASIA HEROIN KING REPORTED SEIZED
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 19 (AP)The mysterious hero in king of Southeast Asia has been reported captured in northern Thailand.

title: A New Apportioning Plan Submitted to City Council
description: A reapportionment plan de signed to make all City Council districts compact, convenient and contiguous, as ordered by the State Court of Appeals, was introduced yesterday.

title: Volcker Terms Dollar Erosion Limited
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Paul A. Volcker, Under Secre tary of the Treasury for Mone tary Affairs, told Congress to day that the value of the dol lar had not declined in recent months against the currencies of countries with which the United States does threequar ters of its trade.

title: Dog's Obituary in Sale Ad
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 19 (UPI)Bargain hunters reading grocery ads in yesterday's StatesItem found an obituary for John Schwegmann's poodle. It appeared between sale prices for round steak and 1966 Chianti in a Schwegmann su permarket ad, and the dog was described as a good mother, an excellent watchdog and a faithful friend.

title: Chile Takes Over 2 Plants As Workers Urge Seizures
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 19 (AP)Leftist workers blocked traffic in the city's industrial area today in a demonstation demanding the Government ex propriate 89 factories seized by employes last month.

title: OILBURNER RULES CALLED TOO STRICT
description: Major oilburner installers said yesterday that they would no longer upgrade or install oil burners because the city antipollution criteria that went into effect July 1 were im possible to meet.

title: Cahill's Mother Dies
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 19 (AP)Mrs. Rose J. Cahill, mother of Governor Cahill, died today at Morven, the Gover nor's official residence here.

title: Rumania Boxers Top U.S.; Chapman, Davis Are Victors
description: BUCHAREST, July 19 (AP)  James Chapman, a medical student from Marietta, Ga., bat tered. Ion Sileste helpless and stopped him in the third round of their heavyweight bout to day in a meet between merican and Rumanian amateur boxers. The Rumanians dominated the lighter weight classes and won 6 of the 11 bouts over all.

title: Road Funds for Mass Transit Backed by HouseSenate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) SenateHouse conferees re ported a major breakthrough today in their deadlock over whether to use money in the Highway Trust Fund for mass transit.

title: 2 SENATORS OPPOSE FUND CURB'S REPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 19A move is under way in the Senate to prevent repeal of a restriction that bars companies and labor unions with Federal Government contracts from raising money from their em ployes for political campaigns.

title: Town, Seeking Latest in Jails, Is Warned on Plan to Bug Cells
description: WILTON, Conn., July 19  The Connecticut Civil Liberties Union warned this affluent Fair field County town today that its plan to build electronically bugged jail cells was illegal and threatened court action if its warning was ignored.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES STATE SMUT LAW
description: NEWARK, July 19 (AP)  A lawyer for a theater chain argued in Federal Court today that New Jersey's obscenity law was unconstitutional even in terms of recent rulings by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: V.F.W. Post Winners Named
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 19 (AP)  Cheyenne, Wyo., Post 1881 is the winner in the an nual community activities con test of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. In announcing the re sults yesterday, the V.F.W, said that Post 1146, St. Clair Shores, Mich., had finished second, and Post 1851 of New ark had finished third.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Issues DogTick Warning

title: Governor Including 35cFare Guarantee In Transit Proposal
description: Some sort of a guarantee of a 35cent fare for the city and comparable promises for subur ban and upstate transit riders will be the keystone of Gover nor Rockefeller's transit sub sidy and bond plan, Albany sources said yesterday.

title: TV Pact Is Put At $200Million
description: TV Pact Is Put At $200Million

title: INQUIRY ON PAYOLA TESTS C.B.S. NEWS
description: Efforts to investigate allega tions of payola in the record industry have run into a curi ous twoway traffic.

title: Literary Tour of the Village Offers a Glimpse of Its Golden Age
description: From the backyard cottage where Edwin Arlington Rob inson had breakfast brought to him each morning by a patroness, to the brown stone where Theodore Dreiser slammed the front door in Sherwood Anderson's face, to the house where a demurely married Edna St. Vincent Mil lay did not burn her candle at both ends, about 300 seekers of literary history cut a wide swath through Green wich Village this week to look at the homes where the nov elists and poets lived who made up the Village's crea tive golden age.

title: MONEY EXPANSION CONTINUES BRISK
description: Monetary expansion con tinued at a rapid rate in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: HONOLULUBen Villaflor, 132 pounds, Philippines, knocked out Kenji Iwata,, 132, Japan, 1 round.

title: Uruguay Wins in Soccer
description: TEL AVIV, July 19 (AP)  Uruguay's World Cup qualify ing soccer team defeated the Israeli national team, 21, to day in an exhibition game.

title: CARS OF POLICEMEN JOIN THE TOWEDOFF
description: The towaway squad under Assistant Chief Inspector Wil liam Bonacum descended on po lice officers' cars in the vicinity of the West 35th Street Station yesterday and hauled away eight of their vehicles.

title: Betting on Barrera Pays Off
description: When El Espanoleto won Aqueduct's third race yester day at a firstplace payoff of $27.20, the question went up among some of the students in the crowd of 19,710, Where has Laz been hiding this one? The best way to answer that, of course, was to ask Laz himself. Laz hap

title: Cloud Over Housing
description: For the family thinking of moving from an apartment to aa house, or from a small house to a larger one, these warm, sunny summer days may seem ideal for househunt ing.

title: Savings Deposits Lag
description: A net deposit loss of $121 million was reported by 27 New York State savings banks for the first half of this month.

title: When Kissinger Goes Calling
description: LOS ANGELES  Whether or not there is any chance that Prince Noro dom Sihanouk will overlook a long series of White House rebuffs and reconsider his refusal to meet Mr. Kissinger in Peking or elsewhere, the fact remains that the exiled former Cambodian Chief of State has now emerged as a major key to an Indochina settlement, and some fresh American thinking about him is in order.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A new reapportionment plan designed to make all City Council districts in New York compact, convenient and con tiguous, as ordered by the State Appeals Court, was in troduced yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STREET SCENE There's a little park up on 106th Street where Broadway meets West End Avenue, and today and tomorrow it will be filled with the fourth annual West Side Music Festival. The two day festival is in two parts each day. From 4 to about 7 each day, there will be a jazz workshop with talk and music by Jothan Callins and the sixmember Sounds of Togetherness.

title: Cost of Eggs Is Rising Here, and Price of 90c a Dozen Is Expected by Next Week
description: The ending of the price freeze has not yet brought dollara dozen eggs in the retail food markets, but 90centsadozen eggs are already in sight, ac cording to market reports for the State Agriculture Depart ment.

title: H.E.W. Chief Issues Guidelines to Protect Rights of Minors and Others in Sterilization Cases
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 General guidelines to be used in drafting regulations to pro tect the rights of minors and adults who have been declared legally incompetent in steriliza tion procedures were issued to day by Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: A HOUSING PROJECT GAINS IN BROOKLYN
description: After a protracted, tangled debate, the Board of Estimate last night approved a housing project in Brooklyn that had been redesigned to segregate lowincome families from mid dleincome families.

title: Needham, Critic of Reform Bill, Is Disputed by Brokers Group
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The New York Stock Exchange told a House financial panel today that a bill the panel has drafted to reform the securities industry would dismantle all stock exchanges and replace the auction market mechanism with a dealer system dominated by large banks and insurance com panies.

title: How the Markets Reacted
description: The reaction of the markets yesterday to the Ad ministration's Phase 4 antiinflationary price program, announced Wednesday afternoon, was as follows:

title: End of Controls Hailed By Produce Merchants
description: For a while I thought everybody was going to have to go into the black market, Sam Orisco, a fruit and vege table buyer at the Hunts Point. Market in the Bronx, said with relief yesterday when he heard that the ceil ing on food prices had been ended.

title: SOUP DESCRIBED AS ADULTERATED
description: NEWARK, July 19  The Federal Government today sought to prove that Bon Viv ant Soups Inc., had adulterated its products with substitute ingredients and had failed to follow its own master formu las, or recipes, in its canning operations.

title: CONCERN ABANDONS BID TO ALEXANDER'S
description: Debenham's, Ltd., the 195 year old, diversified retailer in London, was identified in fi nancial circles here yesterday as the British company that has been considering making an offer to buy control of Alexander's, Inc.

title: Former Cheerleader Now Cheering For the Pro Team She Just Bought
description: Mrs. Eleanor Brown, look ing chic and slender in her yellow Halston Ultrasuede dress, tossed a red, white and blue basketball into the air yesterday at the 21 Club. The ball was caught by Dan Issel, star forward of the Ken tucky Colonels.

title: REV. EUGENE P. MURPHY
description: ST. LOUIS, July 19 (UPI) The Rev. Eugene P. Murphy, founder of the worldwide Sacred Heart radio and tele vision program, died today at the age of 81.

title: 17 I.R.A. MEMBERS SEIZED IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 19  Seventeen Irish Re publican Army members, in cluding the 24yearold chief of the Belfast brigade, Gerry Adams, were arrested today in a big roundup by security forces in Belfast. Seven are among the organization's top men.

title: Volga Tatars Care Little for Genghis Khan but a Lot for Russia
description: KAZAN, U.S.S.R., July 9 A few years ago two Ger man correspondents came for a visit and said to me, Show me a real Tatar,  re called a welleducated man in a business suit. I told them, I am a real Tatar, and they looked at me in credulously.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH SLOWED SHARPLY IN JUNE QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The nation's economy grew at the unsually small rate of 2.6 per cent in the AprilJune quarter, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Dr. John R. Moore, Defoe Scholar Who Taught at Indiana U., Dead
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., July 19Dr. John Robert Moore, an internationally known special ist in the political and literary activities of Daniel Defoe, died here yesterday. He was 82 years old and lived in Madi son, Ohio.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on July 19 were:

title: Ray's Vision of Indian Life Is Reflected in Adversary
description: THE ADVERSARY (PRATIDWANDI), di rected by Satyait Ray; screenplay in Bengali (wild English subtitles) and English by Mr. Bay, based on a story by Sunil Ganguly; directors of Photog raphy, Soumendu Ray and Purmendu Buce; editor, Dulal Dutta; music, Mr. Ray produced by Nepal Dutte and Ahim Dutta for Priya Films; distributed by Audio Brandon Film. Running time: 110 minutes. This film has not been classified at this time. At the First Avenue Screening Room, at 61st Street. Siduhariha Dhritiman Chatteriee With: Krishna Rose, Joyshree Roy, Kal yan Chatterjee and Debraj Roy

title: New Delhi Also Acts
description: NEW DELHI, July I9In dia accorded recognition to the new Afghan regime today.

title: Carrier to Be Scrapped
description: SAN DIEGO, July 19 (AP) The 30yearold aircraft carrier Bunker Hill was towed off to Portland, Ore., today to be torn up as scrap.

title: Soviet Extends Recognition
description: NEW DELHI, July 19 (AP)  The Soviet Government rec ognized the new revolutionary republican government in Af ghanistan today, Radio Kabul announced.

title: Equity Financing
description: A public offering to 6,000 units of The National Housing PartnershipII, a limited partnership formed to invest in Government assisted housing projects by purchasing from the National Housing Partner ship a portion of its interests in about 60 local hous ing partnerships, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Goldman Sachs; Kuhn, Loeb; White, Weld; and Dean Witter. Each unit, offered at a price of $1,000 per unit, consists of two 1973 limited partner ship interests and rights to purchase three 1974 lim ited partnership interests. The minimum investment is five units.

title: KISSINGER DENIES WHITE HOUSE ROLE IN FALSE RAID DATA
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Henry A. Kissinger declared today that the White House neither ordered nor was it aware of any falsification of records on the secret bombing of Cambodia ordered by Presi dent Nixon in March, 1969.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Text of 2 Statements and Letter in Hoax
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Following are the texts of two announcements by Sena tor Sam J. Ervin Jr. this afternoonthat he had been notified that tapes of Presi dent Nixon's conversations at the White House with Watergate witnesses would he made available and that the call had been a hoax; and a letter from acting Attorney General Joseph T. Sneed, saying an investigation had been ordered:

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, JULY 20, 1973
description: International

title: How the Markets Reacted
description: The reaction of the markets yesterday to the Ad ministration's Phase 4 antiinflationary price program, announced Wednesday afternoon, was as follows:

title: Three Killed, Five Injured In a Crash Near Rochester
description: ROCHESTER, July 19 (AP) Three teenagers were killed and five others were injured early today when the car in which they were riding crashed against a house in suburban Henrietta.

title: Dance: Jacob's Pillow
description: LEE, Mass., July 18How nice to be at Jacob's Pillow now that summer's here! This remains America's most ex tended and most important dance festival, and under the artistic direction of its new leader, Walter Terry, it is in some ways extending the general image of dance and dance teaching that its founder, Ted Shawn, gave to the world.

title: Dollar Bills Are Free In Chicago for a Day
description: CHICAGO, July 19 (UPI)  A woman gave money away on Michigan Avenue yesterday.

title: Aide Declares President Won't Turn Over Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 President Nixon has decided not to give Senate investigators access to the tape recordings of his personal and telephone conversations with Watergate suspects in 1972 and 1973, White House official said today.

title: 2 Agencies to Expand Forces to Monitor Phase 4
description: WASHINGTON, July 19En forcement of Phase 4 of the Nixon Administration's eco nomic stabilization program will rest largely with an expanded monitoring force in the Internal Revenue Service and the Cost of Living Council.

title: Governor Including 35cFare Guarantee In Transit Proposal
description: Some sort of a guarantee of a 35cent fare for the city and comparable promises for subur ban and upstate transit riders will be the keystone of Gover nor Rockefeller's transit sub sidy and bond plan, Albany sources said yesterday.

title: Deficit Imperils School Run by Indians in Arizona
description: A halfmilliondollar defi cit is threatening the future of the Rough Rock Demonstra tion School on the Navajo Res ervation in Arizona, the first Indian school in modern times to be operated by Indians.

title: CLARENCE E. LEWIS JR.
description: NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla., July 19Clarence E. Lewis Jr., a retired officer of the Manu facturers Hanover Trust Com pany of New York, died yester day at his home here. He was 62 years old.

title: Giant Cranes Driving Caissons For Sewage Plant on Hudson
description: A swarm of bargeborne cranes on the Hudson near 135th Street has been labor ing for a year to create a roofed, 32acre sewage treat ment plant on a platform above the river.

title: Utility Acquisition Gains
description: The Continental Telephone Corporation announced yester day that the Federal Communi cations Commission has issued an order authorizing Continen tal to acquire control of Tele phone Utilities, Inc., of Ilwaco, Wash.

title: 5 HURT IN JERUSALEM BY BOMB IN MARKET
description: JERUSALEM, July 19 (UPI)  A time bomb, described by police as the work of Arab guerrillas, exploded today in Jerusalem's most popular out door market, injuring five per sons including a young Ameri can.

title: JOSEPH W. ARCIER
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 19Joseph William Arcier, who until his retirement in 1966 was vice president of the CraigCraely clothing manu facturing firm in New York, died of a heart attack today on a visit to Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TORONTO, July 19 (Reuters)The Canadian team has withdrawn from the international squash racquets cham pionships in South Africa next month because of South Africa's policy of racial segregation. In Montreal, the presi dent of the Canadian Racquets Association, Smith Chap man, said the decision was made because of pressure received on the racial matter.

title: Insurgents Said to Press Drive On Phnom Penh From 3 Sides
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 19 (UPI)  Communist forces reportedly increased their pressure on Phnom Penh from the north, west and south today despite heavy air strikes by American B  52 bombers and smaller fighterbombers.

title: France Postpones ATest Because of Bad Weather
description: PARIS, July 19 (Reuters) The first of France's nuclear tests in the South Pacific for 1973 was postponed at the last minute today because of bad weather, the Government radio reported here.

title: Excerpts From Testimony Before the Senate Committee Investigating Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony today on the 24th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times is most inconsistent in its editorials on the illconceived Mad ison Avenue Mall.

title: VIRGINIA DAVID
description: Mrs. Virginia Mohamed Wek selblatt, who sang profession ally as Virginia David, died yes terday of leukemia in Memorial Hospital. She was 47 years old and lived at 988 Sheffield Road, Teaneck, N. J.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on July 19 were:

title: More Prisoner Furloughs Urged by Federal Official
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Norman A. Carlson, director of the Federal Bureau of Pris ons, urged Congress today to permit the bureau greater flex ibility in granting furloughs to prisoners.

title: ELSIE ILLINGWORTH, HUROK AIDE, WAS 87
description: Elsie Illingworth, a concert soprano who became an execu tive in the selling end of the music business, died Wednes day at the Hilaire Farm Nurs ing Home in Huntington, L. I. She was 87 years old and had lived until a year or so ago at 77 West 55th Street.

title: Fraud Alleged in Sickle Cell Telethon
description: The sponsor of two tele thons to raise funds for re search on sickle cell anemia was accused this week of im propriety in the handling of funds by the foundation that was to receive the contribu tions.

title: Spencer in for Yastrzemski
description: BOSTON, July 20 (UPI)  Carl Yastrzemski of the Boston Red Sox was excused tonight from next Tuesday's AllStar Game because of a left wrist injury. Jim Spencer of the Texas Rangers will replace Yastrzemski as a reserve.

title: Religion, or Possibly Gin
description: Here were people with a lust to know everything. They had a vision of total information. They believed in Intelligence with a faith which bor dered on religion.

title: $325,000 FORFEIT IN DRUG CASE HERE Original Bail for Suspected Dealer Was $5Million
description: Federal Judge Anthony J. Travia yesterday ordered the forfeiture of $325,000 bail posted by Frank Matthews, a suspected major drug dealer.

title: 2D CONCERN GAVE ILLEGAL DONATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The Ashland Oil Company of Kentucky admitted today that it illegally contributed $100,000 in corporate funds to President Nixon's reelection campaign last year. It was the second such disclosure by a major

title: BREZHNEV PLEDGE ON JEWS REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Henry A. Kissinger told three prominent Jewish leaders last night that Leonid I. Brezhnev had assured President Nixon that a large number of Soviet Jews who had repeatedly been denied permission to leave the Soviet Union would soon be allowed to emigrate to Israel.

title: The Torture That Goes On and On
description: The following articles concern tor ture in Greek amd turkish prisons. One is a letter written from Athens to a friend in london by an intel lectual closely in touch with the situa tion in Greek jails. The other is by a woman in Ankara who smuggled from jail her story of torture there.

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: GOVERNOR ASKING 3.5BILLION BONDS FOR TRANSIT PLAN
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day proposed to put a $3.5 billion bond plan to the voters this fall to finance new mass transit operations and high ways and to provide $183.8 million in state aid for subsi dizing the 35cent fare and com muter rates for the next two years.

title: BRUCE LEE, 32, STAR OF KUNGFU MOVIES
description: HONG KONG, July 20 (AP) Bruce Lee, the Chinese actor who made a career of karate, kungfu and other martial arts on the screen, died tonight at Queen Elizabeth Hospital after having been found unconscious in his home here. He was 32 years old.

title: FORBES DUNBAR SHAW
description: SCARSDALE, N. J., July 20 Forbes Dunbar Shaw, a partner in the New York law firm of Whitman & Ransom, died today at his home, 12 Stonehouse Road. He was 67 years old.

title: SAIGON PROPOSES 2 VIETNAMS IN U.N.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 (AP)South Vietnam today proposed for the first time that it and North Viet nam join the United Nations while awaiting reunification.

title: MRS. CASIMIR F. REDJIVES
description: Mrs. Ethel Ericson Redjives, a former English teacher at Midwood and Wadleigh High Schools and originator of the city's InterHigh School Poetry Contest, died Thursday at Adel phi Hospital in Brooklyn. She was 79 years old and lived at 881 Washington Avenue, Brook lyn.

title: BOYS LOSE RULING ON FINGERPRINTS Judge Rejects Appeal From Own Order in Inquiry Involving Murder
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., July 20 Superior Court Judge Chester A. Weidenburner rejected an appeal today against his order requiring more than 40 eighth grade boys in Newark to submit to fingerprinting in an Eliza beth murder investigation.

title: Tunnel Civilians Like New Jobs
description: Since Monday, Stuart Jacob son and 42 other civilians have replaced the policemen who normally breath the concen trated automobile fumes while keeping traffic moving inside the Holland Tunnel.

title: Shift in Top Management Is Scheduled by Con Edison
description: The Consolidated Edison Com pany plans a major realignment of its top management next Tuesday.

title: GOVERNOR ASKING 3.5BILLION BONDS FOR TRANSIT PLAN
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day proposed to put a $3.5 billion bond plan to the voters this fall to finance new mass transit operations and high ways and to provide $183.8 million in state aid for subsi dizing the 35cent fare and com muter rates for the next two years.

title: Feminist Parley's 125th Anniversary Goes Unsung in Seneca Falls
description: SENECA FALLS, N. Y., July 20One hundred and twentyfive years after the first women's rights conven tion was called to order near the banks of the Seneca River by Elizabeth Cady Stanton, the only visible commemoration of the an niversary here yesterday was a heartshaped vase cradling three roses that was tied to a historical marker in front of the village laundromat.

title: Job Action
description: Some years ago an article in this newspaper described some of the techniques used by Port Authority policemen stationed on the catwalks of the Lincoln and Holland Tun nels to cope with the boredom that is their chief prob lem. One man sang at the top of his lungs; another recited poetry; still others played licenseplate games, trying to see how many different states they could collect during a twohour shift.

title: Market Climbs Briskly; Dow Average Gains 4.22
description: So far so good. That was the stock market's continuing re action yesterday to the Phase 4 economic program, despite the outlook for a possible level ing in corporate profits next year and the current reality of escalating interest rates.

title: NO. AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
SENATE APPROVES CUT IN WAR POWER OF THE PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 The Senate today overwhelm ingly approved legislation that would limit the power of the President to commit United States armed forces to future hostilities without Congres sional approval. The vote was 71 to 18.

title: A Watch That Takes the Hard Time Out of Telling Time
description: There are always in watches: the Tiffany classic, the Cartier and its trick strap, the cointhin Piaget or the Patek Philippe, which cost more than $1,000. But dear to the heart of the gadget loving man is the watch that does something besides unob trusively tell minutes and hours.

title: Exxon Profit Shows Rise Of 54% in Latest Quarter
description: Net income of the Exxon Corporation, the, world's largest oil company, climbed sharply in the quarter and six months pperiod ended June 30.

title: Skylab Dress Rehearsal Hailed; Mission Extended Three Days
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 20 (UPI)The space agency extended today the planned length of the second Skylab crew's orbital research mission to 59 days from 56 after nearly flawless dress rehearsal cleared the way for launching the astronauts next Saturday.

title: People and Business Potato Chip Shortage Reported
description: The executive director of the Maine Potato Commis sion, Chipman C. Bull, told United Press International yesterday that the nation has a serious potato chip shortage.

title: I.R.S. IS REPORTED AFTER REBOZO FILE
description: The Internal Revenue Service has subpoenad the personal fi nancial records of C. G. Rebozo, a close friend of President Nixon, from a Key Biscayne, Fla., bank that Mr. Rebozo op erates, A.B.C. News reported last night.

title: Gunmen Wound 5 Persons After a Robbery in Jersey
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 20  Three youthful gunmen held up a coffee shop this morning and after getting $1,800 in cash without any re sistance, opened fire with no provocation on a group of nine customers and employes lying on the floor in a back room.

title: Abner Agent and His Silent Partner
description: Still as mysterious and as silent as the wind, Duane Thomas has been traded again, to the Washington Redskins this time.

title: Argentina to Vote For a New Leader During September
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 20 (AP)Presidential elections, in which former dictator Juan D. Pern is expected to run and to win, will be held Sept. 23, the provisional Cabinet announced today.

title: Astros, With 3 Homers, Inflict 62 Loss on Mets
Lottery to Offer Cars To Spur Ticket Sales
description: In the face of declining daily and weekly sales, the New Jersey Lottery Commis sion has announced plans to offer cars to lucky ticket holders. Thomas Maggio, chairman of the commission, said the decision about the cars had been made at a meeting earlier this month. Pennsylvania's lottery is to begin offering autos next month.

title: Saigon Defends the Conditions Under Which Prisoners Live
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 (UPI)The South Viet namese Government issued a 48page booklet today designed to refute news reports of poor conditions in the nation's pris ons, particularly the maximum security facility on Con Son Island.

title: Mardian Says Nixon Told Him to Bring Tap Logs From F.B.I. to White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Robert C. Mardian, the former chief of the Justice Department Internal Security Division, testi fied today that President Nixon personally asked him two year ago to transfer from the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation to the White House the log of telephone wiretaps that the White House had authorized.

title: Amtrak Turbine Train Sideswipes Freight and Burns in Canadian Test
description: MONTREAL, July 20 (UPI)  A $2million turbinepowered train undergoing a final test run before acceptance by Amtrak was burned into a pile of scrap today after it sideswiped a freight train.

title: NearMiss for Ryan, but He's Still Firing Strikes
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 20 Nolan Ryan isn't the sulk ing kind.

title: Notes on People
description: Richard Burton and Eliza beth Taylor (Maybe we loved each other too much) ended their 16day marital separation in a parking lot yesterday. Miss Taylor ar rived in Rome in a private jet after switching planes in London, where she was ac companied by her manager, two dogs and a cat. The pets were accompanied by their own police escort because of quarantine restrictions. When the plane landed in Rome, the doors did not open for 20 minutes while 100 news men and Mr. Burton waited. Then Miss Taylor, dressed in embroidered blue jeans, swept across the airport and climbed into the back seat of her husband's car for the reunion. They kissed; she cried; and the chauffeur drove off.

title: Testimony on Grain Disputes U.S. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, as serted today that one of the first two witnesses at hear ings on the big soviet grain deals had damaged the credi bility of two top officials of the Department of Agriculture in their defense of the han dling of the transactions.

title: AMERICANS TO TRAIN AT SOVIET SPACE CITY
description: HOUSTON, July 20 (UP1) A Soviet space official said to day that American specialists would train in the Russian flight control center near Mos cow for the joint 1975 flight by the two countries. Konstantin D. Bushuyev, leading the group of technicians and eight astro nauts who worked at the John son Space Center for two weeks, also indicated that Western newsmen, for the first time, might witness and report on the Soyuz launching for the ApolloSoyuz mission.

title: Riva Ridge the Horse to Beat
description: Riva Ridge, the million aire 4yearold, was one of the main topics of contem plation at Aqueduct yester day. Another was the labor negotiations being conducted with unions associated quite closely with the operation of thoroughbred racing in this state.

title: Old Friends
description: My neighbor died in a fire, in his apartment, late Friday afternoon. No body knows how it happened.

title: Assuring Farm Inflation
description: With food prices rocketing upward this past year, profits of commercial crop growers have been soaring at a fabulous rate. Department of Agriculture statistics tend to minimize the rate of enrichment of large farmers, but even they give important clues. This year, for example, the department estimates farm profits will exceed $22 billion, i.e., they will be 40 per cent higher than they were as recently as 1970.

title: Trainman Killed, 2 Hurt In Pennsy Crash Upstate
description: DUNKIRK, N.Y., July 20 Two Penn Central freight trains collided here today, killing one trainman and injuring two other railroad employes.

title: Littler's 6Birdie Surge Gains Lead
description: ST. LOUIS, July 20 (AP) Gene Littler sank birdies on six of his last seven holes for a 66 and a onestroke lead today after the second round of $210, 000 St. Louis Children's Hos pital golf classic.

title: Alfred Walker Barr Dies; Commanded Sailing Ships
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 20 Alfred Walker Barr, one of the last sea captains to hold master mariner's papers for squarerigged sailing ships as well as steam vessels, died to day at the Mount Auburn Hos pital here. He was 79 years old and lived at the Hancock Nurs ing Home in Lexington.

title: Jamaica Asks the U. S. to Recall Its Envoy Over Reports of Deal
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 20 (Reuters)Jamaica'' Govern ment tonight declared United States Ambassador Vincent W. de Roulet persona non grata and asked the Secretary of State to terminate his appoint. ment here quickly.

title: Royal Family Is Reported Safe As Kabul Returns to Normal
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 20 (UPI)  The military leaders who overthrew King Moham mad Zahir Shah and set up a republic said today that mem bers of the royal family in the country were safe.

title: Charles Leads Golf by Shot
description: STOCKHOLM, July 20 (UPI) Bob Charles of New Zealand shot a threeunderpar 69 in the second round of the $59,000 Scandinavian enterprise open golf tournament for a two round 138 total today. The left handed Charles took a one stroke lead over Spain's Ange Gallardo, who shot a 68 for 139.

title: Robert Ryan Will Probated
description: Robert Ryan left an estate estimated at $250,000 to $500, 000 at his death July 11, it was disclosed yesterday when the actor's will was filed for pro bate in Manhattan Surrogates Court. Under terms of the 22 page will, made on May 12, 1967, the estate is placed into equal trust funds for the bene fit of two sons, Timothy and Cheyney, and a daughter, Eliza beth. Mr. Ryan died in New York Hospital of lung cancer at the age of 59.

title: Holland Tunnel Civilians Feel Caught in the Middle
description: Since Monday, Stuart Jacob son and 42 other civilians have replaced the policemen who normally breath the concen trated automobile fumes while keeping traffic moving inside the Holland Tunnel.

title: MARCOS MAY BLOCK VOTE IN SOME AREAS
description: MANILA, July 20 (AP) President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he would can cel a referendum set for next Friday, if necessary, in places where there is violence, terror ism or calamity.

title: Excerpts From Testimony Before the Senate Committee Investigating Watergate
description: WASHINTGON, July 20 Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony today on the 25th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: Pornography Legislation
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 20 (AP)Attorney General Warren Rudman said today he would propose new legislation to bring the state's antiobscenity laws into line with recent United States Supreme Court rulings. But he said his office would not use the new guidelines to en gage in a wave of repression.

title: Disabled Veteran Robbed Taking $10,000 From Bank
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP)  Two men robbed a Vietnam veteran on a disability of his $10,000 life savings after he drew it out of a bank here, the police said.

title: STRIKE ALTERS LIST OF N.B.C. PREMIERES
description: Specials and presentations of major films have been scheduled by the National Broadcasting Company's television network for time periods where premi eres of series have been delayed by the 16week strike of the Writers Guild of America, it was announced yesterday by Herbert S. Schlosser, president of the N.B.C.TV network.

title: What's Behind Woes of Dollar?
description: PARIS, July 20  Following are questions and answers on current problems confronting the United States dollar:

title: Giants Lose Gamble as 67 Rookie Gives In to His Basketball Instincts
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 20  Brad Van Pelt shipped nine New York Giants warmup jackets to his parents and relatives to day, which may mean that he plans a longer stay with the club than another rookie, Rod Freeman.

title: BANK OF ENGLAND LIFTS RATE TO 9% Aim Is to Curb Inflation and Strengthen Pound
description: LONDON, July 20The Bank of England's minimum lending ratea basic gauge of the cost of borrowing money  shot up today in the wake of official moves yesterday aimed at dampening inflation and strengthening the pound.

title: Votes in Congress This Week's Tally for Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none. based on the author's subjective judgment of qual ity in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 2 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. (Television  Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 8:30 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Minnesota Twins, at Boston. (TelevisionChannel 4, 2 P.M.)

title: FUENTES BACKERS PLANNING APPEAL
description: Supporters of Luis Fuentes, the superintendent of Commu nity School District 1, said yes terday that they would appeal to School Chancellor Irving An ker or, if necessary, to State Supreme Court to set aside the resolutions adopted by the Dis trict 1 school board Thursday night after the board meeting dissolved into a fistswinging brawl.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Central Park in New York City will be closed to vehicu lar traffic today and next Thursday until midnight be cause of two special concerts to be offered in the Sheep Meadow by the New York Philharmonic. Today's con cert will begin at 9 P.M. and Thursday's at 8:30 P.M. Nor mally, cars are banned in the park on Saturday's only until 7 P.M. and until 4 P.M. on Thursdays.

title: Alphabetical Boycott

Mrs. Matthews said the group would shortly announce a plan to boycott all vegetables and fruits beginning with the letter P.

title: A Musical Double Bill at the Cubiculo

The Cubiculo is supposed to be dedicated to experimental theater. But if these two works are experi mental, Barry Goldwater is flower child.

Business Briefs

title: ' I Could Never Have...,' Greenburg Film, Opens:The Cast
description: Dan Greenburg is a very funny writer ("How to Be a Jewish Mother"), and there are some funny lines and bits of business in "I Could Never Have Sex With Any Man Who Has So Little Regard for My Husband," a title so long that it seems intended as a bit of business in itself. It's the sort of movie you're supposed to start laughing at just from seeing the ads. You could also call it a cocktail party movie: it's funnier to be told about than to sit through.There is, for example, a husband's righteous statement: "I haven't looked at another woman since I've been married. . . . That's 11 months now." Or there's the darling object someone finds in an antique shop: an ancient picture postcard of a shoe factory sent by a man in Newark to his brother in White Plains. And there's the rationale that comes to a would-be adulterer in his sleep: extramarital sex is no more offensive to God than double-parking.According to this rationale, if we lived in a society in which men wore gloves and women wore earmuffs, the big deal would be getting the earmuffs off.Greenburg's wit is not exactly side-splitting, but it's amusing and cheerful in the fashion of a true anecdote recounted at a neighborhood picnic.The film was directed by Robert McCarty, whose first feature this is, and written by Greenburg, based on his novel "Chewsday." It's an East Coast "Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice" about two couples who spend a horrendous vacation together in a rented house on Martha's Vineyard. Being Greenburg people, they have none of the ersatz chic or flair of their West Coast counterparts. Marvin and Laura and Stanley and Mandy are square. They are nice but they are so square it hurts.In the course of the vacation  mostly rain, cold, fog, cocktail parties and sheer boredomMarvin and Mandy develop a full-sized yen for each other. First it's Mandy who wants to "do it" (which is the term they use). Then Marvin wants to do it, and Mandy doesn't. Finally, when their respective mates are out of the house, they decide to give it a try."I'm used to a lot of foreplay," says Mandy. "They only went antiquing," says the desperate Marvin, "not to Europe!"In this kind of fiction, nobody ever really does do it. In fact, the very idea that they have thought about it ultimately strikes them with terror. Virtue is served, not because anyone has any particular scruples but because Marvin and Laura and Stanley and Mandy are so fearful and  dare I even whisper it?  boring. Their libidos are as tiny as their imaginations.The cast includes Carmine Caridi (Marvin), who sometimes looks like Elliot Gould and sometimes like Bob Downey; Andrew Duncan (Stanley), Cynthia Harris (Laura) and Lynne Lipton (Mandy), who plays what on the Coast would be the Goldie Hawn role.The film opened yesterday at the Beekman Theater.

title: JAY G. GILFILLAN, 81, A RADAR DEVELOPER
description: LOS ANGELES, July 20Jay G. Gilfillan, cofounder of Gil fillan Radar Development and Manufacturing Company (since 1964 a division of the Interna tional Telephone and Telegraph Corporation), died Wednesday at the age of 81. He lived in West Los Angeles.

title: Stage: Watergate Humor
description: At times the show  Hot Peaches in The Watergate Scandals of 73is almost as funny as the title.

title: About the Mets:
description: Willie Mays is going to the AllStar game in Kansas City, his 24th, in the embarrassing position of having been done a favorsomething baseball authorities managed to avoid when they named Mickey Mantle and Stan Musial to AllStar squads at comparable stages of their careers  That neither the commissioner's office nor the National League president's office saw fit to put Willie on the team originally has left baseball people shaking their heads. . . . No star in the history of baseball has been as closely asso ciated with AllStar heroics than Mays, and no player now active has an imposing career credentials, and if AllStar means anything, it means a collection of the biggest avail able stars. Mays has a .311 batting average for 74 times at bat in 23 AllStar Games, and has scored 20 runs.

title: House Votes $175Million For Public TV Programing
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPT) The House voted 363 to 14 today to authorize $175million for public broadcasting for the next two years.

title: STATE DECLARED A DISASTER AREA 6 Counties to Get U.S. Aid for 1972 Flood Damage
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Nixon declared New York State a major disaster area today and designated six counties for disaster relief of up to $10million.

title: Ashe, Graebner Reach Pro Tennis Semifinals
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., (UPI) Secondseeded Arthur Ashe, overcoming three match points and the heat, defeated seventh seeded Roscoe Tanner, 46, 64, 75, today and advanced to the semifinal round of the $60,000 United States professional ten nis championships.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC Exchange Index Is Up 0.12 for Fifth Rise in a Row

description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) Senator James B. Allen, Democrat of Alabama, said to day that a move would be made next week to kill a proposed pay rise for members of Congress, the President's Cabinet and the Federal judi ciary.

title: Report Killing at Berlin Wall
description: BERLIN, July 20 (AP)East German guards apparently shot and killed a person who tried early today to reach West Ber lin over the border wall, police sourecs in West Berlin reported. It was not known whether the victim was a man or woman.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The American premiere of Marco da Gagliano's 1608 opera, La Dafne, which was to have been given last night by the New York Pro Musica Antigua at the Caramoor Fes tival in Katonah, N. Y., was postponed because of a delay in the arrival of music and other elements of the produc tion.

description: ROME, July 20The Gov ernment formed two weeks ago by Premier Mariano Ru mor was approved by Parlia ment tonight.

description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 20 (UPI)  State Insurance Com missioner Joe B. Hunt asked the Illinois State Insurance Department today to call a nationwide examination of the Combined Insurance Company of America, whose chairman, W. Clement Stone, has said he donated more than $5million to political campaigns since 1968.

title: Senate Votes for Housing
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The Senate voted today to order the Administration to re sume the Federal housing pro grams halted by President Nixon. The Senate approved legislation directing the De partment of Housing and Urban Affairs to carry out the housing programs to the full extent possible and cease withhold ing funds.

description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., July 20 (AP)The authorities evacuat ed more than 3,000 persons from an affluent west side suburb here today when a rail road tank car loaded with an industrial chemical caught fire and exploded after a train de railment.

description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 20 (AP)  Communistled insurgents attacked Govern ment positions today in at least seven fiercely contested sectors around Phnom Penh, according to the Cambodian high com mand and field reports.

title: PRICE GAINS MADE BY COMMODITIES Futures Being Bolstered by Plans for Phase 4
description: Most commodity futures prices continued to increase yesterday, still reflecting some speculative euphoria about Phase 4. With fewer controls on food, traders apparently be lieve that prices will move higher.

Mackell of Queens and his soninlaw and former deputy chief assistant District Attorney, James Rob ertson, was give a threeyear suspended sentence in State Supreme Court here today.

title: JOHN MOTT, HEADED INTERNATIONAL UNIT
description: John L. Mott, from 1935 to 1954 director of International House, a cultural and educa tional residence center for for eign and American graduate students at 500 Riverside Drive, died Thursday in Waterbury, Conn. He was 80 years old and lived in Waterbury and Litch field, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Art: Metropolitan's 4 Showlets Prove Virtues of Smallness
description: Somewhere along the line during the last few years, the miniexhibition, or show let, has become a staple of American museum programs. It owes its germination, no doubt, to the publicrelations offices, which want to an nounce new exhibitions regu larly. But it also gives sub curators a chance to get into the act, and in the case of museums like the Metropoli tanwell, of course, there are not any others exactly like it, but let us say in the case of museums with copi ous storage binsthe showlet provides an opportunity to bring worthy material up, to the surface for a breather.

description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Senate and House conferees completed action today on a Federal highway bill that had been stalled for 10 weeks by a deadlock over whether to use part of the Highway Trust Fund for mass transit.

Thai Ho Ngan, 53year old deputy chairman of the Hoa Hao Central Council, was shot by communist terrorists, the spokesman said.

description: WASHINGTON, July 20An experimental program estab lishing seven centers to handle consumer complaints on auto mobiles was disclosed today by Mrs. Virginia H. Knauer, the special assistant to the Presi dent for consumer affairs, and representatives of new car dealers.

title: Freedom for All
description: In a decision of potentially great damage to the First Amendment, the Florida Supreme Court has upheld an old statute, long regarded in the state as a dead letter, which requires newspapers to print the replies of polit ical candidates whom they criticize. Six of the court's seven elected justices made the point that the First Amendment was not intended for the benefit of the press so much as for the benefit of us all. Precisely. The corollary is that the courts cannot infringe the free dom of the press without infringing the freedom of all.

title: Meat Stolen From Driver
description: ST. LOUIS, July 20 (UPI) Two men knocked down Don ald Guiot, 58 years old delivery man for the Krey Meat Packing Company during a delivery yes terday, took 40 pounds of meat, put it in a car and fled, the police said.

title: Tourists Lose Place in Christina's World
description: By IVER PETERSON Special to The New York Times

title: New Fuse Burning In Asia
description: This week's coup d'tat in Afghani stan might well change the ultimate power balance in South and South west Asia. The Soviet position is cer tainly convenienced even if there is no known evidence that Moscow played any role in the ouster of King Mohammad Zahir Shah and the crea tion of the first Afghan republic by his cousin, Prince Mohammad Daud.

description: A police officer and a tow truck driver were arrested yes terday and charged with steal ing $100 in marked bills from an automobile illegally parked in Greenwich Village.

description: One of the marks of recent religious history has been a breakdown of traditional sources of authority.

description: BATON ROUGE, July 20 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation acknowledged today that a Black Muslim killed Wednesday by an agent was the wrong man.

title: Medical Diagnosis Uses Ultrasonic Energy
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Dennis Gabor, who discov ered holography more than a quartercenutry ago, has applied the art to medi cal diagnosis. Holography is three  dimensional lenseless photography. Dr. Gabor was granted a patent this week for what is called sonoradio graphy, the use of ultrasonic energy to probe the body and with the aid of laser beams and a reflecting membrane, to produce a pic ture.

description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Consumer prices in June, re flecting increases before the re cent freeze, continued to rise at the fastest pace since the Korean war, the Labor Depart ment reported today.
