Haldeman testified today that the for mer White House chief of staff was advised more than two months before the Watergate breakin that President Nix on's reelection committee had set up a sophisticated politi cal intelligencegathering sys tem.

J., July 20 Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club, Neil Haleen of Wisconsin and Bill Belden of Undine Boat Club qualified to day for the final tomorrow in the Elite singles race to de cide who represents the United States at Moscow Sept. 59. The races were held on the new Albridge C. Smith 3d course on Lake Carnegie.

description: Walter J. Hess, president of the Ridgewood Savings Bank in Queens from 1948 to 1971, died of cancer yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 19318 McLaughlin Avenue, Hollis, Queens.

title: STRAUSS SAYS SUIT MAY START IN FALL
description: DENVER, July 20 (AP) The Democratic party hopes to take its civil lawsuit against the Committee for the Re elec tion of the President into court next fall, Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic National chair man, said yesterday.

title: Joanne Chesimard Pleads Not Guilty in Holdup Here

title: Woman, 21, Slain in Brooklyn Heights

title: 3 Gunmen Open Fire on 9 Persons After Robbing Coffee Shop in Essex
description: WEST ORANGE, July 20  Three youthful gunmen held up a coffee shop this morning and after getting $1,800 in cash without any resistance, opened fire on a group of nine cus tomers and employees lying on the floor in a back room.

title: Amtrak Ordered to Keep 2 Trains Pending Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered Amtrak to day to continue operating its passenger service between New York City and Kansas City, Mo., and between Chicago and Miami, Fla., for four more months.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, JULY 21, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Roundup: Aaron's Magic Number Is 15
description: Henry Aaron must be marching to the same drum mer that propelled Babe Ruth into baseball history.

title: 73 IN ATHENS FACE CONSPIRACY COUNT
description: ATHENS, July 20  The army magistrate who investi gated a navy plot in May to day recommended conspiracy charges against 73 officers and civilians. They are all in cus tody.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Puerto Rico: Target of Ecological Abuse

title: BREW PLEDGE ON JEWS REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Henry A. Kissinger told three) prominent Jewish leaders last night that Leonid I. Brezhnev had assured President Nixon that a large number of Soviet. Jews who had repeatedly been denied permission to leave the Soviet Union would soon be allowed to emigrate to Israel.

title: The Godley Rejection
description: As United States ambassador to Laos, career diplomat G. McMurtrie Godley helped to carry out policies which most Americans now regard as mistaken, if not disas trous. Because of his long and intimate identification with the Indochina fiasco and the apparent enthusiasm with which he dispatched duties that many Americans now find reprehensible, there is good reason for concern over his nomination by President Nixon to an important new assignment in the Asiatic area.

title: Aide Urges P.S.C. To Curtail the Use Of WATS System
description: ALBANY, July 20A Public Service Commission examiner recommended today that the commission authorize the New York Telephone Company to modify a discount service now offered to highvolume business subscribers.

title: U.S. Court Curbs Death Notifications For Missing G.I.'s
description: The military services yester day were restrained for 10 days from issuing death notices to families of the 3,500 service men who are listed as missing in action in Indochina.

title: People in Sports: Houle Hooked
description: The Quebec Nordiques o the World Hockey Associa tion failed to lure Jean Beli veau, one of hockey's great est scorers, out of the Mon treal Canadiens front office and back onto the ice with a milliondollar offer, but suc ceeded instead with a young er Canadien talent. Rejear Houle, the 23yearold for ward who helped Montreal win the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup Iasi season, signed a threeyear contract with the Nordiques,

title: Radio
description: 66:55 A.M., WnyCFM: Sym phony No. 14 in A. Concerto for Two Horns in F flat, Symphony No. 15 in D, Haydn.

title: A Little Knowledge . . .
NIXON DENOUNCES RESIGNATION TALK; TAPING IS HALTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 President Nixon emerged from the hospital today, pale but combative, and immediately denounced suggestions that he resign as just plain poppy cock.

title: WESTINGHOUSE GETS BIG REACTOR ORDER
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday it has received an order for two nuclear reactors and initial fuel valued in excess of $100mil lion. This is the second con tract announced by the com pany this week.

title: Bridge: Two Major Championships Being Played in Washington
ExConvict Held in Murders Of Texas Deputy and Wife
description: NATALIA, Tex., July 20 (AP) A former convict from Hous ton was charged with two counts of murder yesterday after an Atascosa County sher iff's deputy and his wife had been shot to death.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.7% FOR JUNE; FOOD AGAIN LEADS
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Consumer prices in June, re flecting increases before the re cent freeze, continued to rise at the fastest pace since the Korean war, the Labor Depart ment reported today.

title: UTILITY MERGER BARRED BY S.E.C. Administrative Law Judge Rejects A.E.P. Bid
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 In a milestone decision by an Administrative Law Judge, the Securities and Exchange Com mission rejected today a pro posal by the American Electric Power Company to acquire con trol of the Columbus & South ern Ohio Electric Company through an exchange of stock.

title: CLARENCE E. LEWIS JR.
description: NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla., July 19Clarence E. Lewis Jr., a retired officer of the Manu facturers Hanover Trust Com pany of New York, died Wednesday at his home here. He was 62 years old.

title: Slayer of Turkish Envoys Gets Life Term on Coast
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 20  Gourgen Yanikian 78 years old, as sentenced today to life imprisonment on each of two firstdegree mur der counts in the slayings here last Jan. 27 of two Turkish diplomats.

title: NIXON DENOUNCES RESIGNATION TALK; TAPING IS HALTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 President Nixon emerged from the hospital today, pale but combative, and immediately denounced suggestions that he resign as just plain poppy cock.

title: A.B.C. Officials Visiting China; Hope to Set Up a News Bureau
description: Leonard H. Goldenson, board chairman of the American Broadcasting System, Inc., and Elmer W. Lower, president of A.B.C. News, entered the Peo ple's Republic of China yester day for a threeweek working tour of five major cities Peking, Canton, Shanghai,, Nanking and Hangchow.

title: Shultz Is Distressed That Ervin Was Duped
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 (Reuters)  Treasury Secre tary George P. Shultz said today he was distressed that Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. of North Carolina, chairman of the Senate Watergate com mittee, was taken in by a hoax telephone call yester day.

title: BASKETBALL SIGNINGS AMERICAN ASSOCIATION
description: INDIANAPOLISSigned John Ritter of In diana University; Joe Wallace of Denver University; Jim Andrews of Kentucky Uni versity and Mike Edwards of Tennessee.

title: Leslie A. Hohn Bride Of Marshall Adams
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 21 Miss Leslie Ann Hohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerhard Walter Hohn, and Marshall David Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Marshall Adams of Strafford, N. J., were married here this after noon by the Rev. Thomas Upson in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Electronic Vigil Fails to Stem Mexican Alien Influx
description: SAN YSIDRO, Calif., July 21  Sensor No. 139 had been sending out a steady radio signal for two days an obvious malfunction. But when No. 103 began beam ing impulses to a magnetic tape at the Border Patrol sector headquarters here, the desk officer radioed the nearest patrol car.

title: In Mururoa, Paradise Now Has Atomic Aura
description: ABOARD THE FRIGATE OTAGO, in the Pacific, July 21 (Reuters)Once a deserted palmcovered atoll around a coral lagoon, Mururoa has be come the South Seas proving ground for the ultimate weap ons of modern warfare.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: Right Now: Guests are Joseph C. Nichols, United Nations communications of ficial, and R. Louis Halasz, United Nations correspondent, Channel 9, 9:30 A.M.

title: Photography Is This Avant Garde Art?
description: IS there an avantgarde in photography, and if so, what is it worth? The Hudson River Museum in Yonkers raises such questions in its current exhibition en titled Light and Lens, but the answers it gives are not encouraging. I am not even sure what to call the works on display.

title: A DECAPITATED BODY FOUND IN MIAMI HOME
description: MIAMI, July 21 (AP)Police officers using jackhammers broke open a concrete block found in the shower chamber of a home here today and dis covered the decapitated body of a young man inside.

title: An American in Paris Racing Turns Out to Be French
description: PARIS, July 21The scen ery is different here from South Ozone Park and El montthere are palaces and windmills by the race tracks but the story is turning out the same for Angel Penna and Jean Cruguet, a pair of wandering horsemen who are starting all over again.

title: Headliners
description: A Monarch Toppled

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Dirty Money
description: FROM the top floor of Irvine Towers, where Herbert Kalmbach has his office, one can watch the sparkling white yachts bobbing in the Pacific along Millionaire's Row in New port Beach, Calif. Within a sil ver dollar's throw of the twin office towers, some 10 or 12 millionaires live in walled, wellguarded beachfront compounds. And many of those men belong to the Lincoln Club, an exclusive group of California businessmen that over the years has given vast sums of money to Richard Nixon much of it funneled through the President's long time personal lawyer, Herb Kalmbach.

title: Mark Donnelly to Wed Abigail Hourwich
description: The engagement of Miss Abigail Acheson Hourwich to Mark Edward Donnelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Don nelly of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by her father, George Kennan Hour wich. The prospective bride, daughter also of the late Mrs. Hourwich, and her fianc plan to marry next month.

title: Madeleine R. Cresap Is Betrothed
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., July 21 Mr.and Mrs. Stuart MacR. Wyeth have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wyeth's daughter, Miss Madeleine Reed Cresap, to Philip Key Bartow Jr., son of Mrs. Philip Key Bartow of Far Hills, N. J., and the late Mr. Bartow, a former partner of Drexel & Co.

title: Nancy Keefe Will Be Bride
description: MILTON, Mass., July 21 Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Keefe have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Nancy E. Keefe, to Thomas V. Hirschberg, son of Mrs. Edgar T. Hirschberg of Larch mont, N. Y., and the late Mr. Hirschberg.

title: Lynn Merrill, Bennett Alumna, Married to Austen T. Gray Jr.
description: SYOSSET, L. I., July 21 Miss Lynn Merrill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Merrill, was married here this afternoon to Austen Town send Gray Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gray of Roslyn Harbor and Dark Harbor, Me.

title: Miss Tenney Eliminated
description: MEMPHIS, July 21 (UPI) Tenthseeded Patty Schoolman of Fairport, N. Y., meets fourth seeded Kathy May of Beverly Hills, Calif., tomorrow for the United States Lawn Tennis As sociation's girls' 18andunder clay court championship. Miss Schoolman won, 36, 64, 60, from the defending champion, Robin Tenney of Los Angeles, and Miss May took a 62, 57, 64 victory from Betsy Nagel sen of St. Petersburg, Fla., to day.

title: For Phase 4, A New Spirit
description: WASHINGTON  For the fifth time in less than two years the Administration in troduced last week a sweep ing new Federal program of wage and price controls over the American economy. As usual, the program was ac companied by a statement by President Nixon express ing his desire to restore a free market.

title: Jennifer Potter Wed to G. M. Hayes Jr.
description: CLINTON, N.Y., July 21 The Hamilton College Chapel was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Jennifer Potter, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Donald B. Potter of Clinton, to Gordon Millard Hayes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hayes, also of Clinton.

title: RACE WEEK PRIZE GOES TO CORNING
Cruise to Maine: A Once a Decade Event
description: It's just a coincidence, insisted William H. Foulk Jr., race chairman for the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise. The last two times we sailed to Maine was in 1953 and 1963, and this is 1973 all right, but the number 3 has nothing to do with it. It just happened.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saying Time

title: Miss Haber Is Bride of M. L. Quinn
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 21Miss Patricia Luise Ha ber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Haber, and Mi chael Leo Quinn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Quinn of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., were married here this afternoon in the garden of the Haber home.

title: Soviet Bid for Police Role With the U.S. Is Reported
description: PARIS, July 21Authoritative Western officials report that the original Soviet proposal for what became the Nixon Brezhnev agreement to pre vent nuclear war contained a clause that could have com mitted the United States to intervene jointly with the Rus sians anywhere in the world if there was a danger of con flict.

title: HOSPITAL BOMBING IN 1969 REPORTED
The Nation
description: WASHINGTONAs young demon strators flocked to the Capitol three years ago to protest the incursion of American forces into Cambodia, Sen ator Jacob K. Javits complained to aides that he had no legislation pend ing that would give Congress more sayso about warmaking. So, soon after, several of the New York Repub lican's staff, lunching at the Monocle restaurant, drafted a war powers bill on the back of a menu. And last week, a refined version of their effort be came the focal point of a new Con gressional confrontation with Presi dent Nixon.

title: Camera World
description: AFIVEWEEK darkroom workshop course will be conducted by Mel Ettinger, 1557 Gary Street, East Meadow, L.I. on Thursday evenings at 8 P.M. Registration will be limited to five students, and the fee will be $50.

title: Barley Lane Triumphs
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 21 (AP)Barley Lane, $3.60, with stood a strong challenge from Roger's Spitfire in the stretch today to win the $7,500 Shecky Greene Handicap on a sloppy track at Narragansett Park. The winner, ridden by Mike Carroz zella, went six furlongs in 1:12 .

title: The Gay Life: Cartoon vs. Reality?
description: TWO plays about gay life have recently opened in New York. One, The Faggot, would seem to have everything going for itan experienced cast, fine physical facil ities at The Truck and Warehouse Theater, and the muchacclaimed talents of composer, lyricist, author Al Carmines. It's more than a failure. It's an affront.

title: Jobs and City Life Are Urban League's Key Themes
description: Jobs and the complexities of city life will be the main themes of the National. Urban League's annual conference, which opens today in Wash ington.

title: Mailbox
description: To the Editor:

title: Crew of Protest Ship Flown Out by French
description: ALSTEAD CENTER, N.H., July 21 (UPI)The crew of the protest ship Fri was flown out of the French nu clear test zone in the Pacific but the vessel apparently was destroyed in the blast, the father of the boat's skipper said today.

title: DRUG CLINIC WARNED TO DECREASE ROLLS
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that he would stop payments to a Brooklyn addictiontreatment clinic un less the Addiction Services Agency took steps to reduce an over concentration of addicts in the Fort Greene area.

title: C.L.U. Gives Legislature a 48% Rating
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union Issued its third annual review of the State Legislature yesterday, giving the lawmak ers an overall civil liberties rating of 48 per cent, based on whether or not they supported the organization's position on 22 bills that it felt reflected a civil liberties issue.

title: Hunt Is On in Adirondacks For Friend of Slain Camper
description: WEVERTOWN, N. Y., July 21 (UPI)  The state police con tinued hunting today for a 21 yearold Boston University coed whose camping companion was found slain in the Adirondack Mountains.

title: Mimi Bowler Wed to Pediatrician
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., July 21St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mari anne Bowler, a secondyear law student at the Suffolk University Law School, to Dr. Robert Paul Younes, chief of pediatrics at the Carney Hospital in Boston. The Most Rev. Joseph J. McGuire, Bishop of Boston, performed the ceremony.

title: Congressional Report Criticizes Flow of Heroin From Thailand
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) A report by a Congressional committee says that a major share of heroin coming to the United States flows almost freely from Thailand, unham pered by Thai officials or American antinarcotics efforts.

title: Uglification Has Followed Ruin
description: ALL of you who are about to go overseas and have not yet seen Bath in your English travels had better go quickly or you might just miss it. According to the May issue of the British journal, The Architectural Review, the perfect Georgian city is now a city in extremis, and its salvation demands strong na tional measures.

title: Polak's Words Fail, but Not His Motors
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 21 Vasek Polak. The name is not an American household word, and it does not roll easily off the tongue  VASshek POlahk. Still, his competitors respect him as a sort of upcoming Shek the Giant Killer. The drivers and crew who make up his racing team ad mire him as a mechanical gen ius. And at lunch time they recog nize him as a re sourceful cook and solicitous house mother presiding over the 40foot camper that the team uses as a trackside base at CanAm races across the country. To not provide comfort would be bad mis take, Polak says.

title: The View From Illinois
description: MOMENCE, Ill.For two weeks the dressing chains of the Momence Pork Packers have been empty, brought to a halt when the cost of the 3,500 hogs the plant bought each weekday soared past prices the company could charge for the loins, hams, and spareribs it processed. The plant is an example of the trouble that the meat industry in sists is inevitable when the Govern ment freezes wholesale prices and leaves farm prices uncontrolled.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: During his campaign, de spite his refreshing candor on welfare and tax reform, which cost him dearly at the polls, Senator George Mc Govern never disclosed an encompassing plan for infla tion control. Politically, this was understandable for, like it or not, there is simply no way to prevent inflation without curbing excesses in wages and salaries.

title: Psychology of Phase 4
description: Under the looming threat of food shortages, the Admin istration rushed last week into Phase 4 of its highly unstable and unpredictable economic policies, which have unsettled domestic and international confidence in the American economy and increased the danger of another recessionwithout stilling fears of a worsening inflation.

title: JACK LEYDEN
description: Jack Leyden, a retired editor ial artist for The New York Times, died yesterday at North ern Westehester Hospital at the ago of 66. Mr. Leyden had worked for The Times for 23 years before retiring in April. He had previously worked for The New York Sun, He lived on Mills Road in Purdys, N.Y., and is survived by his widow, Mary, and son; Robert.

title: Savings FreeforAll
description: Higher returns on savings, the likelihood of increased mortgage rates, a possibility that no new home mortgages will be available at all in New York State and, above all, confusion confronted sav ers last week. They were getting their first taste of what could be the financial system of the future.

title: Mushroom Brands Sold in Glass Jars Recalled by F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The Food and Drug Adminis tration ordered up to 336,000 glass jars of mushrooms re called today after Canadian au thorities confirmed that a Montreal woman had been stricken with botulism poison ing.

title: Sara McClanahan To be Wed Sept. 8
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 21Miss Sara McClanahan and Robert Vincent Hancox, a commodities specialist and trader with E. F. Hutton & Co., will be married Sept. 8.

title: Israel's Georgians Bitterness In the Land Of Dreams
description: ASHDOD, IsraelClannish, back ward, arrogant, stiffneckedthese are some of the more polite labels many Israelis are applying these days to Israel's newest and most volatile wave of immigrants, the Jews of Soviet Georgia. More than any immigrant group before them, the Georgians are having problems integrating into Israeli society.

title: NIXON CRITICIZED BY 49% IN SURVEY
description: For the first time since he took office four and onehalf years ago, more Americans disapprove of President Nixon's handling of the Presidency than approve, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Allons Enfants! Chefs Mark Bastille Day
description: SPRINGS, L.I.  This is all very simple really, ex plained Craig Claiborne, the food critic and author, as he poked his fork into a morsel of lobster drenched in a spicy mayonnaise  based sauce maison. To his right a former chef for the late Charles De Gaulle, Jacques Pepin, helped himself. to a platter of jambon des Ar dennes while Pierre Franey, former chef of Le Pavillon, reached for a Limoges por celain platter of hardshell crab.

title: Model of 1776 Warship Being Built for Bicentennial
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., July 21  Construction has be gun here on a recreation of the British armed sloop Wel come to sail Lakes Huron and Michigan in the bicentennial year as the original did in 1776.

title: 2 Share Sweden Golf Lead
description: STOCKHOLM, July 21 (UPI) Angel Gallardo of Spain shot a 69 today and tied Bob Charles of New Zealand at 208, two strokes ahead of the field in the $59,000 Scandinavian golf tournament.

title: Camp Provides Summer Fun for Handicapped Young
description: HACKETTSTOWNThir teenyearold Steve Kish grasped his crutches firmly, tossed his fishing line into the water and boasted, I bet any amount of money that I catch a fish in two minutes! But he didn't have his usual luck.

title: Science
description: In 1951 the world's first breeder reactora small, experimental device went into operation at the reactor testing station near Idaho Falls, Idaho. In succeeding years American atomic energy specialists became increasingly convinced that such reactorswhich, in producing energy, manufacture more fuel than they consumeoffer the best hope of avoiding a serious shortage of nuclear fuel, or of energy, until new power sources are developed.

title: Employers Urge State to Link Pensions With Social Security
description: The state's legislators were urged yesterday by an employ ers group to integrate Social Security benefits with public employe pensions when they meet in special session this week to consider pension re forms.

title: Nassau Pays Most For Local Services
description: ALBANY, July 22Resi dents of Nassau County paid more per capita for local government services than residents of any other coun ty in the state in 1971, the last year for which complete records are available.

title: Park Slope Wins a Landmark Status
description: There was a feeling of delight and reliefamong residents of the Park Slope section of Brook lyn last week that the city's Land marks Preservation Commission had, after more than six years of deliberations, designated the area as a historic district.

title: Kelly Park Plan Gains Approval
description: A program of community participation in the revitaliza tion of the vandalized Little Kelly Park in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn won the approval last week of Parks Commissioner Richard M. Clurman.

title: State Expected to Adopt LongAwaited Pesticide Rules Soon
description: TRENTON  Longawaited regulations designed to con trol pesticides in New Jersey are expected to be adopted soon by state environmental officials.

title: U.S. Jury Begins Inquiry On Drug Raids in Illinois
description: ALTON, Ill., July 21 (UPI) A Federal grand jury was em paneled here today to investi gate drug raids in Collinsville, Edwardsville and East St. Louis, Ill.

title: A U.S. Correspondent Is Expelled by Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21Jacques Leslie, a correspondent here for The Los Angeles Times, has been ordered by the Government to leave South Vietnam.

title: Discovering the Other Side of Japan
description: When we accepted an in vitation to go to Tokyo to tell portfolio managers and security analysts about the Squibb Corporation, we did so after only very limited contact with the Japanese in vestment community.

title: Heart Pacemakers Stir Medical Revolution
description: STOCKHOLM, July 21A battery in the abdomen of a Swedish engineer who was the world's first recipient of a per manent cardiac pacemaker has triggered his last 400 million heartbeats and allowed him to fly around the world supervis ing the repair of electrical sys tems aboard ships.

title: Cary From Mae to September
description: Do you have chil dren? asks the softspoken man with snowwhite hair.

title: The New Journalism
description: The title suggests a long es say by Tom Wolfe, ac companied by samples of what the essay is about. What we get are three short Wolfe essays and a Wolfe appendix, adding up to some 49 pages, followed by 339 pages of essays and excerpts. A clear case of the nose wagging the dog. Well, wagging anyway. The dog seems fairly unperturbed. The book's 23 pieces include pre dictable but attractive items like passages from Capote's In Cold Blood, Mailer's The Armies of the Night, Plimp ton's Paper Lion, Thompson's The Hell's Angels and Mc Ginniss's The Selling of the President 1968; like snatches of Wolfe himself. But then there is also Rex Reed on Ava Gardner, Michael Herr on Khesanh, Joan Didion on the Miller murder case in Califor nia, Joe Eszterhas on the Mis souri killings of Charlie Simp son, Terry Southern on the Dixie National Baton Twirling Institute in Mississippi. The writing is remarkable, almost without exception, and if this is the New Journalism, one can hardly be against it.

title: Books: Florida's Builders
description: This book was obviously a labor of love, and anyone who was around in Florida in the boom days nearly 50 years ago is bound to love it.

title: YONKERS TROT WON BY SPART AN HANOVER
Alexander Finley, Harvard 61, Weds Mrs. Katrina R. Bryant
description: NEW HAVEN, July 21 Mrs. Katrina Rauch Bryant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Rauch of Farm ington, was married here at noon today to Alexander Finley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Finley of Tam worth, N. H.

title: Barbara Harry, Timothy Lusk To Be Married
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 21Mr. and Mrs. Rob ert V. Harry of New Canaan have announced the engage. ment of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jean Harry, to Tim othy John Thomas Lusk of Haworth, N. H., and Cold Spring, N. Y. The couple plan to be married next month.

title: A Correction
description: In the Sunday Business and Financial section of July 15, 1973, Aileen Mehle, a director of Revlon, Inc., was mistakenly identified in a picture caption as a member of the Avon board.

title: Mrs. Richardson, Designer, Is Wed
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 21 Mrs. Mary Lyons Richard son was married here in her home at noon today to John Francis Moynahan, also a Stamford resident. The Rev. Donald Fisher Campbell of the First Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony.

title: Waiting for Tanaka
description: The JapaneseAmerican Cabinetlevel conference last week in Tokyo was timed roughly two weeks before the Washington arrival of Premier Kakuei Tanaka for talks with President Nixon. The conference gave both sides chance candidly to explore the major economic issues and mutual tensions that will undoubtedly come up for discussion at the summit in the White House.

title: BOMB IN HARTFORD REMOVED BY POLICE
description: HARTFORD, July 21 (AP) A police bombdisposal unit safely removed a homemade bomb containing at least nine sticks of dynamite from the steps of the Hartford Insurance Group early today after au thorities received an anonymous call alerting them to the device.

title: Sayreville Upset by Apartment Plans
description: SAYREVILLE  The 35,000 residents of this Middlesex County community remind the visitor that Sayreville is the home of nationally known industries. They point out that the factories are well spread out over the 16.5 square miles of the borough and that there still is much land to be devel oped for homes, parks and public buildings, such as schools. And the major issue at this time is the recently adopted Planned Unit Development Ordinance; it would allow construction of highrise and garden apartments in at least two sections.

title: Career Training A Big Effort (In Texas, Of Course)
A fiveyear session with death
description: Once during the war when was little, my mother was ill, and they couldn't get her into a hospital. She lay upstairs for ages abandoning me and being humiliating, a thing, not a per son. I hated her with a black anger that scares me still. When she asked for water put salt in it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article on Coney Is land [They Still Come to Coney to Forget, July 1] was delightful, but just for the record let's go back to the beginning.

title: It's So Bleepful in the Country
description: WHERE do young composers go in the summer for musical stimulation? New Music in New Hampshire is the most re cent and the most forwardlooking answer to this question, though it is not really a new idea. During the late fifties and the early sixties, Darmstadt in Germany was the most important summer center for avantgarde musicians. Boulez and Stockhausen were always there. Pousseur, Mes saien, Cage, Kagel, Berio and others would. usually be on the scene, along with prominent performers of new music, such as David Tudor, Cathy Ber berian and the Kontarsky brothers. For a few weeks every summer this little German town would be almost a convention center for new music en thusiasts, and avantgarde composers would come from all over the world to pick up the latest devel opments, fraternize with other avantgardists and study with the innovators of the day.

title: FLORIDIANS REACH FINALS IN BRIDGE
NO. AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Disabled Man Robbed
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) Two men robbed a Vietnam veteran on a disability of his $10,000 life savings after he had taken them out of a bank here, the police said. Ronald Banks withdrew the money to deposit it in a bank closer to his home. As he left the bank, two men took him into an alley and seized the money, the po lice said.

title: Stringer's Estimate Is Best In Predicted Log Contest
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 21 The 21st annual predicted log contest conducted by the Stam ford Yacht Club and the East ern Cruiser Association for the Mortimer L. Doolittle Memorial Trophy was won today by Rob ert A. Stringer in Candy Jack VI. The winner had a percent age error of 0.92.

title: Robert Ryan 190973
description: ROBERT RYAN was a beautiful actor and an even more beautiful human being. Though his fame was as a film actor, his real love was the legiti mate stage and he would do a good part in a good play any time, anywhere, and for nothingwhich he usually did.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market staged a spirited rally last week despite the uncertainties of Phase 4, the realities of sharply rising interest rates and the prospects for pos sibly level profits in 1974.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: By the time this year is over, Mike Weinblatt's sales men will probably have sold $600million worth of one of the most desired, expensive and perishable commodities aroundnetwork television commercial time.

title: Mrs. Wendy F. Hopkins Is Married
description: GLENS FALLS, N. Y., July 21Mrs. Wendy Falconer Hopkins was married here this afternoon to Pieter Van Cortlandt Litchfield. The Rev. Warren Beaven performed the ceremony in the chapel of Christ Church (United Methodist).

title: Art Fakes, Forgeries and A Benevolent Deception
description: THE Minneapolis Institute of Arts always saves one big show a year for summertime, when that part of the world becomes tourist country. This summer's is called Fakes and Forgeries, to which the publicity release adds a coda and other de ceptions. Modestly, however, no men tion is made of a primary but benevo lent deception inherent in the exhibition as a whole. Seduced by a surefire sub ject (this is bound to be referred to as a fun exhibition), visitors will be letting themselves in for something more serious than they expect. Fakes and Forgeries is a series of exercises in seeing, although I doubt that many people will realize that they are being subjected to an esthetically educating experience.

title: Vietcong Say They Would Keep 4Member Control Commission
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21 (UPI) The Vietcong said today that they want the International Commission for Control and Supervision to re main a fournation body and are trying to find a replacement for Canada, which is withdraw ing at the end of this month.

title: Philadelphia Zoo Fills Posts
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP)  The Philadelphia Zoo an nounced this week the appoint ment of Dr. Stephen C. Jaffe as curator of mammals and acting veterinarian, and J. Kenneth Bowler as curator of reptiles.

title: Two Days of Racial Unrest On Navy Carrier Reported
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 21 (AP)Fighting broke out on two days this week aboard the carrier U.S.S. Franklin D. Roosevelt, a Navy spokesman said today.

title: And in Kansas City There Is No Score
description: KANSAS CITY, July 21 (UPI)The possibility existed today that the Kansas City Royals new $2million score board might not be working for Tuesday night's AllStar baseball game.

title: Memphis Lets New Industries Locate Nearby; Feels City Profits and Remains More Livable
description: MEMPHIS, July 19Ten years ago, no Southern city would have let a new indus trial plant be built in a neighboring town without fighting to get the plant for itself. Every town wanted all the industry it could get.

title: Motorist Strands Wife Thinking She's in Car
description: WHITNEY POINT, N.Y., July 21 (AP)A woman from Ontario was stranded at an Interstate 81 rest area near this community north of Bing hamton today.

title: Downpours Flood Many Roads And Disrupt Some Rail Service
description: Heavy rains Friday night and yesterday closed roads and halted service on subways and commuter trains, ruining plans for many area residents hoping to be outdoors.

title: J. D. Whyte to Wed Wendy E. Marshall
description: MILL NECK, L. I., July 21 Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lyon Marshall Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter. Miss Wendy Elizabeth Marshall, to James Duncan Whyte, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wood Whyte of Locust Valley. A wedding is planned for Sep tember.

title: Major Jewish Groups Set Up World Education Foundation
description: GENEVA, July 21 (UPI) Major Jewish organizations have established the first inter national foundation for Jewish education, with a capital of $5million.

title: Nancy Tobin Fiancee Of Lawrence Kramer
description: NEWTON, Mass., July 21 Mr. and Mrs. Leon Tobin have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Nancy Sue Tobin, to Law rence Stephen Kramer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Kramer of Fair Lawn, N. J.

title: Forest Service Backed
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to the House yesterday a res olution requiring the Depart ment of Agriculture to maintain at least 20,854 fulltime em ployes in the Forest Service this year.

title: STATE TAX CEILING IS URGED IN TEXAS
description: FORT WORTH, July 21  Texas may become the first state to copy the plan of Gov. Ronald Reagan of California to limit the amount of money that a state government may take from citizens in the form of taxes.

title: MATRA IS WINNER AT WATKINS GLEN
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 21It was French all the way todayFrench car, French en gine and French drivers repre senting a governmentsupported French manufacturer whose principal product is missiles.

title: TRAIN IS REPORTED IN LINE TO HEAD E.P.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Russell E. Train, President Nix on's chief environmental ad viser, is soon expected to move to the Environmental Protection Agency as its new administra tor.

title: Fire Bomb Routs Family From Their Queens Home
description: A molotov cocktail was thrown through a window of a home at 6718 Cloverdale Boulevard, Bayside, Queens, early yesterday morning and shattered in flames against the wall of a bedroom where Mrs. Nancy DeVries was sleeping with her baby.

title: Cover and Uncover
description: WHEN Hunt came out of the bath room, he grab bed the white telephone and called Michael Douglas Caddy, a Washington attorney who once worked out of the Mullen company's offices. Then he told Baldwin to pack up all the equipment in the room and take it to McCord's house in Rockville. Get it the hell out of here! Get yourself out of here! We will be in touch. You will get further instructions. As Hunt rushed down the hall toward the elevator, Baldwin cried after him:

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 14939
description: Tickets matching the number win 1$2,500, Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all live numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: N.Y.A.C. TEAMS WIN 3 RELAY CROWNS
description: Mike Keogh anchored the New York Athletic Club to two of its three victories in the Amateur Athletic Union nation al relay championships yester day during a driving rain at Downing Stadium.

title: Caspar Hasselriis Dead at 91; Leader in Danish Affairs Here
description: Caspar H. W. Hasselriis, long a leader of the Danish American community here and former director of the Danish information Office in New York, died yesterday at his home, 7261 113th Street, For nt Hills, Queens. His age was 91.

title: Miss Ann Coleman Plans Bridal
description: The engagement of Miss Ann Coleman to Frederick Anson Lynn has been an nounced by Mr. and Mrs. Martin S. Coleman of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey D. Lynn of Franklin, Mich. A November wedding is planned.

title: CITY YOUTHS FIND COUNTRY DELIGHT
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 21 Ronald Flowers, a 12year old boy from the Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brook lyn, jumped up from his seat as the old New Haven train rocked through Connecticut. I see a swimming pool! he shouted.

title: CENSORS REMAIN FIRM IN RUMANIA
description: BUCHARESTAn agreement to expand cultural exchanges between the United States and Rumania went into effect at the beginning of the year, but senior Rumanian officials have made clear Bucharest's deter mination to continue to submit American cultural offerings to censorship.

title: DARTSUM VICTOR IN LONGFELLOW
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 21 Dartsum demonstrated versa tility by winning the Long fellow Handicap at Monmouth Park today. The morningline favorite when the race was set for the turf, he went off as second favorite when it was changed to the muddy main track after a sudden rainstorm.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 14939
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win S25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second end third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN A RATHER firm rebuff to those businessmen, labor leaders, private economists and others who had been advocating a prompt return to a decontrolled econ omyor, at least, a softer, permissive mechanism in Phase 4, the Nixon Administration opted instead last week for what it described as a tough system of wage price regulation as the next round of its twoyearold stabilization effort.

title: Lucia G. O'Reilly, Student, Marries
description: BIDDEFORD POOL, Me., July 21Miss Lucia Gregg O'Reilly, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. D. Elliott O'Reilly of St. Louis, was married here this morning to Reid William Cole man, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Coleman of Larch mont, N. Y. The Very Rev. Thom Blair, dean of Christ Church Episcopal Cathedral in St. Louis, performed the ceremony in St. Martin's in the Field Chapel.

title: Mondale Pipeline Charge Denied by State Department
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  The State Department has denied a charge by Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, that it deliberate ly misled the Senate into think ing the Canadian Government was uninterested in a Canadian oil pipeline route.

title: Trends
description: DENVERAs history and war mov ies have shown, nothing makes men want to serve and fight like good causes and good leaders. And without a good cause, a leader becomes the cause himself.

title: Virginia's Race for Governor Clouds Regular Party Labels
description: RICHMOND, July 21In a climate of realignment among liberals and conservatives that many here believe is nation ally significant, the former Democratic Governor of Vir ginia is running for that post this year as a Republican, and the nominal Democratic candi date is running as an inde pendent.

title: School Meditation Backed
description: BOSTON, July 21 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate has ap proved a bill allowing for a mo ment of meditation for prayer in public schools.

title: New and Recommended
description: ANTOINE BLOYE, by Paul Nizan. (Monthly Review Press, $6.95.) Workingclass life in France is the subject of this novel by a young French Marxist; first published in 1933 and long considered a master piece, it is now available for the first time in this country.

title: Shuman to Coach at Illinois
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 21 (AP)Bruce Shuman, 22 years old, a former Eastern Illinois University tennis star, has been named tennis coach at the University of Illinois. Shuman succeeds Bill Wright.

title: The Works of Inigo Jones
description: THE arts of Inigo Jones are depicted on a new set of four from Great Britain marking the 400th anniversary of the birth of the architect who revolutionized English archi tecture and set its course for some 100 years in the 17th and 18th centuries.

title: Notes: At Home With The First Americans
description: AGROWING number of vacationers are discovering a new (to them) facet of America by spending some time with the first Amer icans. In other words, they are including Indian festivities on their itineraries. What attracts them are events like the potlatch, snake or crown dance, the powwow, Indian arts and crafts and the Aleutian blanket toss. Furthermore, as Marvin L. Franklin of the Bureau of Indian Affairs points out, the number of tribally owned motels and camp grounds on reservations at which trav elers can stay is on the increase.

title: Van Touring State To Help Veterans
description: NEWARKA van set up by the Veterans Administra tion to provide benefit infor mation to exservicemen is making a tour of New Jersey.

title: Woman With Son Attacked
description: A young woman, accompa nied by her 3yearold son, was robbed and sexually atacked by a youth yesterday on 130th Street in the Ozone Park sec tion of Queens, The police, who declined to identify the woman, said her assailant forced her into an alley after robbing her of $20. He fled when a dog started after him.

title: PiratesPadres Postponed
description: PITTSBURGH, July 21 (UPI) The scheduled game between the San Diego Padres and Pitts burgh Pirates was postponed today because of rain. A make up date has not been selected.

title: The Plumbers
description: SOMETIME in the spring of 1971, John Caulfield noticed that he and Tony Ulasewicz were getting fewer assign ments. For some reason, a former White House aide recalls, it was decided that Caulfield couldn't handle the really heavy stuff. Within a week of the Pentagon Papers publication, the President author ized another extraordinary action: establishment within the White House of a Special Investigations Unit whose task, as the President later put it, was to stop security leaks and to investigate other sensitive security matters. In other words, the heavy stuff.

title: City Bank to Erect A 54Story Tower At East 53d Street
description: One of Manhattan's tallest skyscrapersa $125million of fice tower of aluminum and re flective glass to stand atop 10 story stiltswill be erected on the city's East Side over the next few years by the First Na tional City Bank.

title: Proctor Backs Death Penalty
description: ASBURY PARK  Haydn Proctor, who retired last month after nearly 16 years as a New Jersey Supreme Court justice, is a warm and compassionate man. Never theless, he has reached the firm, if regretful, conclusion that the death penalty is use ful as a deterrent to murder.

title: AROUND THE Garden
Here &
description: CARLISLE, Pa., July 21George Allen, pro football's renowned trader, admitted to day that his acquisition of Duane Thomas, pro football's most ethereal running back, was a riskbut a good risk. Thomas, meanwhile, failed to appear at the Wash ington Redskins training camp here, al though Allen insisted he was not yet concerned.

title: Dirty Tricks
description: DURING the 1962 California guber natorial race, a beaming Richard Nixon posed in San Francisco's Chinatown with children holding campaign posters. Not until later did he learn that the Chinese charac ters on the posters spelled out, What about the Hughes loan?a reference to a dis puted loan from multimillion aire Howard Hughes. The Chinatown caper was the work of Dick Tuck, a Demo crat whose name has since be come something of a trade mark for political mischief.

title: BAHRAIN PLANNING BROADER ECONOMY
description: MANAMA, Bahrain, July 21 (AP)This is where Persian Gulf oil first gushed 41 years ago. Now this tiny nation of 33 islands is planning for the in evitable day when her oil will be gone.

title: Sports Week
description: BASEBALL

title: Recordings `Bizarre, Dreamlike
description: EFFORTS to combine popular and classical music have had a no table history of fail ure. Be they thirdstream jazz or pretentious attempts to mix rock and symphonies, the amalgams stubbornly fail to jell. Either the classical parts of the mix sound self consciously grafted onto an essentially popular and/or improvisatory idiom, or the popular elements are nerv ously given their run in the midst of an otherwise pre cisely notated classical piece.

title: Mirror, Mirror on the Ceiling
description: There was an incongruous happening several weeks ago. Eight thousand librar ians, book editors and publishers, sales men and suppliers of library equipment got together in a typical American city built on faith, industry, integrity and some Howard Hughes moneyLas Vegas. The librarians were there for the week long, 92d annual conference of the Amer ican Library Association. The others were, well, camp followers, there to persuade and influence, to show their wares, hard and soft covers, to demonstrate services and equipment. What follows is a brief odyssey of one observer, snippets of things seen and heard:

title: Discussed Any Good Movies Lately?
description: EVERYBODY talks about the movies but not many people take the trouble to see them, including a lot of peo ple who are pleased by the recent Supreme Court rulings that will save people from be ing degraded by movies they don't see anyway. A lot of other people hate to go to movies because the time they would spend sitting in the theater would be time taken away from discussing them. The following guide is for such nonconsumers who might possibly  in a mo ment of folly  want to see a film, even if they don't make a habit of it. Each film is listed in alphabetical order, followed by the name of the theater in parentheses:

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: WALTER KERR com plains that the Mike Nichols production of Uncle Vanya is too tearful, pushing the sighs instead of the humor. The tears, the tears, the tears, he groans like a char acter suitable to a Chekhov drama. Where? Where? Where?

title: ExHusband Sues to See Dog
description: HACKENSACK  A West New York man has filed an appeal in State Superior Court here in which he seeks the right to visit his best friend, a 9yearold female mongrel named Muschi.

title: DOUG CURTIS
description: LONDON, July 21 (AP) Doug Curtis, a wirephoto oper ator and technician for The Associated Press for more than 30 years, died here yesterday of cancer. He was 53 years old.

title: Le Corbusier Vision of a City Rejected in Zoning Plan
description: The late master builder Le Corbusier once described New York City as a vertical city, under the sign of the times. He said it approvingly, because Le Corbu sier advocated cityscapes of tall slabs set in vast open parks. His ideas have become the keystone of urban planning.

title: Airlines Hefting Extra Load: Ecology Costs
description: Simmering in the minds of airline managements and cer tain to boil into a problem by next year is the vexing question of how their indus try can finance compulsory ecology improvements. At this point, near total confu sion reigns.

title: Food Store Stormed as Freeze Ends
description: In their eagerness to get a bargain, some customers of the Food Warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, have been climb ing over the barricades to the area where food is stored.

title: Debra J. Black Virginia Bride
description: WOODBRIDGE, Va., July 21  Miss Debra Jane Black was married here this after noon to William Bradford Ross Jr., a builder and land developer. The Rev. Robert Allard of the Good Shepherd Lutheran Church performed the ceremony at Rippon Lodge, home of Rear Adm. Richard Blackburn Black, U.S.N.R., retired, and Mrs. Black, parents of the bride.

title: Senate Panel Votes a Cutback For a Support Fighter Plane
description: The new plane the Air Force is developing for close support of ground troops, the Fairchild A10, ran into some potentially serious budget trouble in the Senate last week.

title: World News Briefs
description: All the bombs exploded in County Down in towns around battlescarred Belfast, sealed off from dawn yesterday by more than 5,000 British troops.

title: News Summary and Index
POLICE STUDYING SLAYING ON L.I.
description: Some 50 Nassau County de tectives were conducting an in tensive investigation yesterday into the Friday afternoon death of a 33perold woman who was found bludgeoned in her North Woodmere, L. I., house.

title: Privileged Executive
description: The phrase executive privilege is being bandied about these days as if everyone, or even someone, knew exactly what it is. The concept is not defined in the Constitution, nor in Federal statute. The Supreme Court has never addressed itself directly to the issue. Such a test may now be looming.

title: Miss Amanda Eggert Is Bride Of Michael Wesley Stukenberg
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., July 21Miss Amanda Reed Eggert and Michael Wesley Stukenberg were married here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee, the rector, and the bride's greatuncle, the Right Rev. Frederic C. Lawrence, retired Bishop of Massachusetts.

title: 342 Pounds of Evidence Fails to Impress Jury
description: ASHLAND, Ohio, July 21 UPI)The local drive on alleged pornography result ing from the recent Supreme Court decision was brief and officials plan no further cur rent efforts.

title: Stamps Robinson Jeffers, American Poet
description: ROBINSON JEFFERS, who wrote with un measured power and incredible passion of man's evil and violence, and saw life as a disease of matter, is appearing as the American poet in this year's set of commemoratives de voted to American Arts.

title: Deaths
description: ALLBEEAllen C., on July 20, 1973, beloved husband of Charlotte Mader Allbee. Services at Havey's Funeral Home, Inc., 107 No. Broadway, Yonkers, N. Y. on Tues., July 24 at 2 P.M. Interment Mt. Hope Ceme tery, Hastings, N.Y. Visiting hours 24 & 79 P.M.

title: 10 Sue in Book Raids
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, July 21 (UPI)  A suit was filed in Lucas County Common Pleas Court Monday by 10 persons who say their constitutional right of free speech was violated when of ficials seized alleged porno graphic material from adult book stores. The plaintiffs sought $300,000 damages and a preliminary injunction barring the enforcement of antismut laws.

title: Convict in Yablonski Case Seeks to Force Sentencing
description: PITTSBURGH, July 21 (AP) Aubran W. Martin, convicted in the Yablonski killings, has asked the state Supreme Court to order his immediate sentence in the case.

title: The Region
description: For more than a century and a half the big, cool vaults of the New York area's savings banks have provided a haven for the deposits of small savers. Even the names of those unique insti tutions are freighted with concern for the little man: Emigrant, Seaman's, Dime.

title: Foreign Students End a Year in the U.S.
description: Some 40 foreign students ended a oneyear visit to America last week, and as they traveled to the airport they said that they had enjoyed it but that their faith in the Amer ican political system had been eroded by Watergate.

title: Future Social Events
description: July 25  Horse fever, the unbridled love for the equine world American children develop, can drive parents to the point of distraction. Relax, take the young ones to Old Westbury Gardens and let them see Smokey, la beled the wonder horse, do his tricks at 1 and 2:30 P.M. Refreshments available and picnic if you desire. Cochairmen of rides and games for Chil dren's Day are Mrs. John Trevor, Mrs. John Brokaw and Mrs. Pat Montgomery. Among their aides are Mrs. Christian Boegner, Mrs. Winston Guest and Miss Cynthia Phipps, grandniece of the late John S. Phipps, who owned Old Westbury Gardens. Admission: $1.50 for adults, 50 cents for children 6 to 12, open 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Education fund of gardens to gain. Rain date, July 26.

title: Rhode Island Divorce Rule
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 21 (AP)  A statute requiring a twoyear residency in Rhode Island before a divorce petition can be filed was ruled uncon stitutional this week by a three judge Federal court. The judges said the requirement abridged the fundamental right of free dom of interstate travel and violated constitutional rights of due process and equal protec tion.

title: Judy Harelick Affianced
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., July 21Mr. and Mrs. Nor man R. Harelick have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judy Ellen Harelick, to Donald Howard Birnbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moe Birnbaum of Woodmere. The future bridegroom is an assistant district attorney in the Bronx.

title: YOUTH IS OUSTED BY EAST GERMANY
description: BERLIN, July 21The East German Government, evidently embarrassed by publicity given shootings at the Berlin wall as their international youth festi val approaches, took the un usual step of expelling a refu gee to the West today. He had been caught at gunpoint two nights ago as he attempted to cross the border.

title: LAWYERS SUPPORT RELEASE OF TAPES
description: Constitutional lawyers say President Nixon has no right to withhold White House tapes from the Senate Watergate Committee because they could contain evidence about a crimi nal offense.

title: Mets Win, 53, Despite 2 Rader Homers
pickit Yourselfers Save on Food
description: PEMBERTONThrifty housewives, senior citizens and college students are swarming to the blueberry farms in this section of Burlington County to pick choice fruit at cutrate prices.

title: All's Quiet on Giants Contract Front
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 21Last Tuesday afternoon the New York Giants averted what could have been their first serious confrontation of the season when Ron Johnson accepted the terms of a new contract.

title: Son to Mrs. Topilow
description: WANAMASSA, N.J., July 21A son was born July 7 in the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune to Maj. Arthur A. Topilow of the Army Medical Corps and Mrs. Topilow, Mrs. Topilow and her husband are physi cians. She is a pediatrician known as Dr. Judith F. Topi low. Her husband, an inter nist and hematologist, is as signed to the Walson Army Hospital in Fort Dix. The child has been named Evan Peter.

title: Michael Findlay Becomes Fiance Of Naomi Sims
description: Michael Alistair Findlay, owner of J. H. Duffy & Sons, Ltd., an art gallery in lower Manhattan, and Miss Naomi Sims, a fashion model and cover girl for magazines here and abroad, plan to marry Aug. 4 at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacra ment.

title: Delegates at Consumers Parley Assail Efforts to Stem Inflation
description: MILWAUKEE, July 21  With the Administration's new economic program being an nounced as members of the Consumer Federation of Amer ica met here this week, it might be expected that Phase 4 would dominate their annual meeting.

title: Home Repair Clinic
Thousands of Argentine Leftists March in Effort to Sway Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 21 Some thirty thousand youths representing the left wing of the Peronist movement today marched in search of their leader, the former dictator Juan D. Pern.

title: Linda Kelley Is Bride Of Peter G. Baxter
description: Miss Linda Joan Kelley, daughter of Brig. Gen. Roy S. Kelley, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Kelley of New Orleans, was married here yesterday afternoon to Peter Gordon Baxter, son of Mrs. Robert Eldredge of Sarasota, Fla., and Richard H. Baxter of Grand Rapids, Mich. The Rev. Joseph S. O'Rourke per formed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Coast Guard post chapel on Governor Is land.

title: Who Makes Music and Where
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC CONCERTS IN THE PARKS

title: DeerHunt Hearing Scheduled
description: TRENTONA public hear ing on a proposed special deer hunt. in the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge has been announced by the New Jersey Division of Fish, Game and Shell fisheries.

title: Frieda S. Miller, Labor Official For the State and Nation, Dead
description: Frieda Segelke Miller, who served as director of the Women's Bureau of the Depart ment of Labor from 1944 to 1953, died of pneumonia yester day at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave nue. She was 83 years old and lived at 299 West 12th Street.

title: SPOTLIGHT A Minneapolis Wunderkind in the F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON  What distinguished James Thomas Halverson from other bright young Minneapolis lawyers was an ability to say exact ly what he felt without seem ing abrasive or antagonistic.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: And for the Kids
description: Children's Book Week in the Soviet Union takes place during the last week in March; it is by now a 20 yearold tradition celebrated in every town in the country. Coinciding with it this spring, an unprecedented event: an international conference of children's book writers. Speculations: part of a generalized Kremlin thaw? Or to offset some of the Solzhenitsyn tsouris? Or to launch the new am bivalently regarded copyright agree ment? Speculations remain, but it was a gala week for the participants from the 32 nations represented along with writers from the various republics and languages of the So viet Union.

title: Correction Board Assails City Aides On Tombs Suicide
description: A report of the city's Board of Correction charged yester day that failures by defense attorneys, the Manhattan Dis trict Attorney's office, the courts, Bellevue Hospital and the Department of Correction had led to the suicide last May of a 23yearold man who had confessed to the murder of a schoolteacher here.

title: SHOP TALK Suits in Secaucus
description: SECAUCUSThe man who is pleased with himself, and thinks that perhaps the feel ing deserves a present, might enjoy having a suit made to order by Al Certo, a former Golden Gloves champion whose customers include Jack Dempsey.

title: Princeton Is Encouraging LowIncome Housing
description: PRINCETON  In order to prevent this suburban com munity from becoming a sin gleclass, upperincome one, its officials are attempting to aid in the construction of low and middleincome hous ing projects.

title: Shah of Iran Due in U. S. to Seek Weapons
description: Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi will arrive in Washington to morrow, seeking new and more sophisticated weapons, includ ing the $14.8million F14 Navy fighter, for Iran's rapidly ex panding military forces.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: All that glisters is not goldso goes the Shake spearean adage, and it is particularly true in the cos tume jewelry business. But the manufacturers must use the metal in gold plating, and the rising price of gold has increased costs not wholly recoverable under price control.

title: News Summary and Index
Germans Boost Commuter Rails
description: In West Germany they do more than dig rail com muters; they are digging up vast urban stretches to in stall new commuter rail net works.

title: Evensong: An Unsung Tourist Treat
description: FEW Americans are aware that some of the grandest music in the world can be heard in ca thedrals and colleges throughout England. Though every American tour ist traveling in England knows about the splendid architecture of the old churches and schools, nobody tells him that cathedrals and collegiate chapels reverberate in late afternoon with gor geous sound. Even the guidebooks ig nore the fact that many of these build ings are used daily for Evensong (eve ning prayer) services. Americans and other tourists throng through, gawking at the magnificent architecture, and then depart, often just before Evensong be gins, not realizing that if they stayed they could see and hear a moving re ligious event.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The New York Life In surance Company has sold the east blockfront on Third Avenue between 64th and 65th Streets to Milro Associ ates, which is headed by Robert S. Olnick, the real estate investor and devel oper.

title: State of Siege
description: MAY, 1971, was a time of tor ment in Washington. After weeks of more orderly antiwar protests, the Mayday Tribe de scended on the city determined to stop the Government with an unprecedented wave of civil disobedience and disruption. For days, the motley legion of young demonstrators blocked streets and bridges with automobiles, trash cans, lumber and their own bodies. The Government responded with new get tough tactics, flying in the National Guard and Marines to augment police, arresting some 13,500 demonstrators and holding them for hours in large outdoor stockades. As tear gas swirled around some of the nation's most revered shrines and demonstrators blocked entrances to major Govern ment buildings, the capital was in a virtual state of siege.

title: Woman With Son Attacked
description: A young woman, accompa nied by her 3yearold son, was robbed and sexually atacked by a youth yesterday on 130th Street in the Ozone Park sec tion of Queens. The police, who declined to identify the woman, said her assailant forced her into an alley after robbing her of $20. He fled when a dog started after him.

title: Gardeners Faced By Slug Invasion
description: PARAMUS  Flower and vegetable gardeners have had more than their share of problems with insects this year because of the unusually wet weather. Now they face another pestslugs.

title: U. S. Commander Is Asking Germans to Reduce Rents
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 21 (AP)  An American commander is appealing to West German landlords to come to the aid of the United States cavalry at a highrent post near the East German border.

title: To Break Down The Wall
description: A THEATER in New York must re spond to the reality of what is happening in the city, principally the exodus of great numbers of the white middleclass to the suburbs. It must relate to the indigenous culture and aspirations of the city's residents, whatever their previous relationship to a theater. Real estate and demography are the key factors.

title: Au Soleil Shines as an Authentic Corner of France on the South Fork
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.An authentic corner of France has been established (for the summer season, at least) in this resort village at Au So leil, a restaurant opened the first of July by its chef and proprietor, Charles Chevillot.

title: The Story So Far
description: IN the raw winter of 1970, Richard Nixon looked like a loser. From balmy San Cle mente and Key Biscayne? White House aides strove earnestly to put the best possible face on the returns in that November's midterm elections. But back in Washington a consensus was hardening, like ice on the Mall's reflecting pool, that the election constituted a serious set back for the President and an omi nous portent for 1972.

title: PANEL HEARS IDEAS ON SAVING WATER
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 21 Skim the Hudson River. Tap Lake Champlain or the Great Lakes. Build new dams and divert upstate rivers. Meter New York City's supply. Try desalination or recycling.

title: Tapes and Testimony
description: WASHINGTONIt came out by ac cident. Donald Sanders, an obscure assistant minority counsel for the Senate Watergate Committee, was quizzing Alexander P. Butterfield, a former White House operations man, in a private session. Recalling reports that some Presidential aides had taped conversations, Mr. Sanders routinely asked Mr. Butterfield whether he had reason to believe that recordings of White House Watergate discussions had been made.

title: City to Renovate Camp
description: New York City's Municipal Services Administration yester day announced a plan to mod ernize Camp La Guardia in Chester, N. Y., where old, homeless men, most of them alcoholics, are given lodging, food and rehabilitation serv ices. Milton Musicus, adminis trator, said that contracts total ing over $740,000 had been awarded to various concerns for renovation of the facility, once a women's prison.

title: Summer Songs
description: Maybe the climate is changing, or maybe the birds have got wind of this age of Aquarius, or there is some change in lifestyles. Anyway, birds are still singing, and here it .is the end of July. Those who told us for years that birds sing only to lure mates or to proclaim terri torial rights can't adequately explain it.

title: Bull Strong, Pig Tight, Horse High
description: BULL strong, pig tight and horse high, are simple specifications for a good fence that have been credited to some sage old Westerner. Few readers of these pages may have bulls, pigs or even horses to contend, with these days, but that same formula is still effective against all kinds of fence climbers, fence squeezers and fence jumpers.

title: Special Session The Transit Fares Are Riding on It
description: Like a poker game that never really ends, the State Legislature reconvenes in Albany Wednesday at the bidding of Governor Rockefeller for a special session.

title: DIETZ TRIUMPHS IN SINE SCULLS.
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 21 Jim Dietz continued his domi nation of American scullers today on Lake Carnegie as he won the final qualifying race to represent the United States at Moscow in the European Championships, Sept. 5 through 9.

title: Ambassador's House Isn't a Home  Yet
description: NEW DELHI  When Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Patrick Moy nihan and family moved into Roosevelt House, the official residence of the United States Ambassador here, they quick ly discovered that a house is not necessarily a home.

title: Colonial Herb Plot Given a New Life
description: MORRISTOWN  When the Northern New Jersey unit of the Herb Society of Amer ica was formed three years ago, it had an instant project: The restoration and mainte nance of the garden at Wick House, the 18thcentury farm house in the Jockey Hollow section of Morristown Na tional Historical Park.

title: BOOK OFFERS HELP FOR CITY BLOCKS
description: Hang a banner. Hire a wandering minstrel. Demon strate macrame. Plant a ginkgo tree. Paint a mural. Solicit funds from a foundation. Stage a wrestling match. Placate chil dren with a playground.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
Leaks, Leaks, Leaks
description: 0N the morning of June 13, 1971, the Sunday edition of The New York Times plunked down on door steps along the East Coast bearing a laconic headline at the top of Page 1: Vietnam Archive: Penta gon Study Traces 3 Decades of Growing U.S. Involvement. Inside were three more pages of stories and three pages of documentsthe first installment of what were to become known as The Pentagon Papers.

title: Lucy M. Van Itallie Is Betrothed
description: Dr. Theodore B. Van Itallie, director of medicine at St. Luke's Hospital Center, and Mrs. Van Itallie of Englewood, N. J., and Fenwick, Conn., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Lucy Maria Van Itallie, to Paul Daniel Borge Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Borge of Omaha.

title: And Forget About Charisma
description: WASHINGTONAmerica is reeling from two basically unhappy Presiden cies in succession. And I fear that our sheer genius for bad habits and faulty premises will assure us of a third in 1976.

title: The Ballet: Untraditional Swan Lake
description: For those who care about standards and tradition, American Ballet Theater's Swan Lake, as led by Elea nor D'Antuono and Paolo Bortoluzzi at the State The ater on Friday night, could hardly be held up as a model for other dancers. Yet this was a performance whose ec centricities carried their own fascination. There was room, on this occasion, for some indulgence.

title: STATE PRICE UNIT DRAWS CRITICISM
description: Consumer groups in the state Last week assailed as unneces sary Governor Rockefeller's proposal to seek at the special session of the Legislature start ing next week the creation of a Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy.

title: Professor Marries Electra P. Zolotas
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., July 21 Miss Electra Paula Zolotas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Socrates P. Zolotas of Bur lington and Stowe, was mar ried here today to Theodore Peter Perros, son of Mrs. Peter Perros of Washington and the late Mr. Perros.

title: Alaska Pipeline The Senate Votes to Turn It On
description: WASHINGTONA transAlaska oil pipeline, a gleam in the oil industry's eye since the discovery of huge re serves on Alaska's North Slope in 1968, cleared an important political hurdle last week in a series of dra matic roll calls in the United States Senate.

title: State Aide Sees Rise In 12Month Schools
description: TRENTONThe director of extendededucation programs for the state's Department of Education predicts that at least 25 per cent of New Jer sey's school districts will adopt some form of year round operation by 1980.

title: Countess van Limburg Stirum Engaged
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., July 21  Count and Countess W. A. W. van Limburg Stirum have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Linda Ida Lucile, Countess van Limburg Stirum, to Edward Pels Rycken of The Hague, the Netherlands, son of Mrs. M. R. Dorhout Mees and the late F.M.C. Pels Rycken. The wedding is planned for October.

title: Diane Dunigan Married
description: SOUTH HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 2IMiss Diane Marie Dunigan and Thomas Jeffrey Burgess were married here this morning in St. Eliza beth's Catholic Chuhch by the Rev. Arthur J. Kane. The bride, daughter of Mrs. Charles W. Schwing of Mel ville and the late Robert G. Dunigan, taught in the Haup pauge school system. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Burgess of Paw tucket, R.I. He is assistant to the coordinator of inter judicial affairs at the Feder al Judicial Center in Wash ington.

title: Gwen Verdon Likes Being Just Folks in East Hampton
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I. For an actress a passion for anonymity could prove fatal. But Gwen Verdon is willing to take her chances, at least during the summer when she lives in East Hampton where celebrities are so common they provoke little attention.

title: REBEL FRONT STRIKES IN SPANISH SAHARA
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania, July 21 (Agence France Presse)  The Popular Front for the Liberation of Saguia el Hamra and Rio de Oro (Spanish Sa hara), which was formed last May 10, announced yesterday that it had started its first military operations against the Spanish armed forces, which had struck back.

title: NIXON REPORTED TO FEEL INQUIRY IS AIMED AT HIM
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  President Nixon has told the chairman of the Senate Water gate committee that he will not supply Presidential papers to the Senate investigators be cause he is convinced the com mittee is seeking to incriminate him, reliable sources reported today.

title: New L.I.Performing Arts School Holding Auditions
description: WANTAGH, L.I.  A trio of singers went flat, a trum peter went dry and a drum mer tripped, over a chair, sending his sticks clattering across the floor.

title: Agriculture: A Giant's Woes
description: The nation's biggest indus tryby any yardstickis in deep trouble. It is not trans port, autos, steel or petro leum, varied and serious as their problems may be.

title: A ripoff with genius
description: It's the glossiest of glossy booksthe sexy waifgoddess spread out in over 100 photographs by two dozen photographers plus the Mailer text and all on shiny coated paper. It's a rich and creamy book, an offen sive physical object, perhaps even a little sordid. On the jacket, her moist lips parted, in a color photograph by Bert Stern taken just before her death in 1962, Marilyn Monroe has that blurry, slugged look of her later years; fleshy but pasty. A sacrificial womanMarilyn to put beside Zelda. This glassyeyed goddess is not the funny bunny the public wanted, it's Lolita become Medusa. The book was produced by the same Lawrence Schiller who packaged the 1962 Hedda Hopper story congratulating 20th CenturyFox for firing Monroe from her last picture; now there are new ways to take her. The covergirl face on Marilyn is disintegrating; and the astuteness of the entrepreneurs in exploiting even her disintegration, using it as a Pop icon, gets to one. Who knows what to think about Marilyn Monroe or about those who turn her sickness to metaphor? I wish they'd let her die.

title: Maureen M. Sullivan Is Married Here
description: The Church Center of the United Nations was the set ting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Maureen Merrick Sullivan to Qais Chanen Noaman, assist ant resident representative of the United Nations Develop ment Programme in Free town, Sierre Leone. The Rev. Matthew Campanele of Our Lady of Guadalupe Roman Catholic Church performed the ceremony.

title: Telephone Companies on Coast Solve a Numbers Problem by Adding an Extra Digit
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21As if the threat of food, gasoline and power shortages were not enough, Los Angeles consumers recently faced yet another commodity crisisnot enough telephone numbers.

title: News of the Screen
description: Universal Pictures has joined with Fletcher Knebel, the au thor, and Doubleday & Co. to create a novel that will be the basis for a feature film. The arrangement is similar to the recent deal made by Paramount and Bantam Books with Fred eric Morton, author of The Rothschilds, to write The King's Goodbye, a novel about an international financier.

title: Ties, Themes and Tales
description: JUST by chance, I have re cently seen three eve nings of dance by three specifically English cho reographersAntony Tudor, Peter Darrell and Frederick Ashton. In disparate ways, I enjoyed all three evenings, and I found myself wonder ing whether there was any thing especially English about the three of them.

title: Princeton Theater Reflects the Town
description: PRINCETON  During the winter, Princeton University's Theater Intime functions as a completely studentrun op eration, featuring productions of Shakespeare and the clas sics. Interestingly enough, it draws 60 to 75 per cent of its audience from the town of Princeton, as opposed to the gown segment.

title: Chess: Chickens and Eggs Are Like Titles and Play Invitations
Article 3  No Title
description: BreakIn

title: An OffDuty Court Officer Shoots Suspect on Subway
description: An offduty court officer, robbed at gunpoint on a Bronx subway train early yesterday, jumped off the train at the Tremont Avenue station in pur suit of the two robbers and shot one of them in the shoulder.

title: Democrats Announce Drive For Small Gifts to Party
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The Democratic National Committee, seeking to capital ize on the Watergate affair as a symbol of bad political financ ing, has announced a new di rectmail campaign for small but regular contributions.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Asked what, if any, con tingency plans the Bethle hem Steel Corporation might be making should the Penn Central, Lehigh Valley or other bankrupt railroads in the area cease operations, John C. Howard, vice presi denttransportation, declared We don't think there is an alternative.

title: Social Announcements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Marshel are happy to announce the marriage of their daughter, Judy to Mr. Mitchell Ellner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ellner, on July 7, 1973 at the Sephardic Temple of Cedarhurst, Long Island,

title: Mayor's Power Cut Off
description: GARY, Ind., July 21 (UPI) Mayor Richard G. Hatcher of Gary was late paying his elec tric bill so the power company cut off his lights. A spokesman for the Northern Indiana Public Service Company said yester day that electrical service to the Mayor's home had been cut for two hours Wednesday.

title: Free Theater in 10 Areas
description: HACKENSACK  Resi dents of northern New Jersey will have a chance this sum mer to both watch and take part in a series of free out door presentations being offered by the North Jersey Cultural Council.

title: The Economy
description: Even if it turns out no more success ful than the first three attempts to control the economy, Phase 4 Is clearly more complicated. Federal officials are still involved in working out some of the details. What follows are some of the pertinent questions, and the an swers that are known so far:

title: A Labrador Retriever Turns Into Canine Cinderella
