description: The most diversified ken nel in America is in Middle burg, Va. Owned by Mrs. Robert V. Clark Jr., it has 70 dogs representing 14 breeds. Labrador retrievers dominate with 45.

title: Senegal Says Foreigners Must Yield Jobs to Citizens
description: DAKAR, Senegal, July 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  All companies in Senegal must reg ister a written plan for Sene galization by the end of this year or face legal action, Presi dent Leopold S. Senghor told the ruling Senegalese Progres sive party here today.

title: 218 by Pam Higgins Ties Mrs. Berning For Lead in Open
Whitney Boynton Becomes a Bride
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 21In the Hitchcock Pres byterian Church here this afternoon, Miss Whitney Ann Boynton, daughter of Mrs. William F. Koegel and the late Rodney Boynton, was married to James Thomas Sayre, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry C. Sayre Jr. of War wick. The Rev. Dr. James Seth Stewart performed the ceremony.

title: Publishing, RussianStyle
description: Moscow  Perhaps after the cold war it is inevitable that Western per ceptions of the Soviet literary world are somewhat askew and that Amer icans should wonder skeptically what could possibly be expected from Moscow now that it has joined the International Copyright Conven tion. For the Soviet Union is now known best abroad for the works of literature denied to its own readers.

title: Blue's ThreeHitter Helps A's Set Back Indians, 52
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 21 (UPI)Vida Blue pitched a threehitter for his ninth vic tory of the year and the All Star shortstop, Bert Campa neris, hit a basesempty homer and made three sparkling plays afield today in leading the Oak land A's to a 52 triumph over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Fish Win
description: NORTH LAKE HARBOR, Prince Edward IslandFour teen Atlantic mackerel danced in the wake of our boat as we trolled for giant bluefin tuna in the Gulf of St. Lawrence off the northeast tip of Prince Ed ward Island, and from time to time our marine radio in formed us that one of the other eight boats in the tour nament fleet had hooked a fish.

title: Policemen Take Slum Youths Camping
description: HARRIMAN, N.Y., July 21 The first questions almost invariably are the same.

title: inspection of. Motor Homes Is Urged by Safety Center
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The Center for Auto Safety, saying that as many as 400,000 pickup campers and motor homes may have inadequate suspension systems, urged the government today to inspect all such vehicles for defects imme diately. The group, backed by Ralph Nader, said in a letter to James E. Wilson, acting admin istrator of the National High way Traffic Safety Administra tion:

title: Miss Lazarus Plans Nuptials
description: CINCINNATI, July 21  Fred Lazarus 3d, board chairman of Shillito's a divi sion of Federated Depart ment Stores, and Mrs. Lazarus have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Margaret Ann Lazarus, to Michael Craw ford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Crawford Jr. of Oswego, N. Y. The future bridegroom's father is a member of the New York State Assembly.

title: It's Not a Hilton, Just a Hill, but It's Mine, all Mine
Joan M. Mullin Plans Nuptials
description: GLEN ROCK, N. J., July 21 Dr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Mullin have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Joan Margaret Mullin, to Steven Ray Myers, son of Mrs. Gordon Ray Myers of West Lafayette, Ind., and Newport, R. I., and the late Colonel Myers, U.S.A.

title: Global Demand for Steel Is Booming
description: Booming global demand for steel and the effects of two dollar devaluations have helped lessen the pres sure that domestic steelmak ers have felt from imports.

title: Trevino, on 66 for 199, Takes Lead by a Stroke
description: ST. LOUIS, July 21 (AP) The defending champion, Lee Trevino, fashioned a four underpar 66 today and took the thirdround lead in the $210,000 St. Louis Children's Hospital golf classic.

title: Miss Ann Van De Water Bride Upstate of Donald Reid Parfet
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 21  In the Reformed Church here this afternoon, Miss Ann Peelor Van De Water became the bride of Donald Reid Parfet. The Rev. Her man Harmelink 3d performed the ceremony.

title: Energy: View From Tokyo
description: TOKYO  Joint United StatesJapanese development of Siberian oil and natural gas and future cooperation of the two countries in de veloping China's oil reserves, when China allows It, will be extremely desirable, Yoshihiro Nakasone, Japan's powerful Minister of Inter national Trade and Industry, declared in an interview.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PRESIDENT NIXON lifted the freeze on prices of every thing except beef, effective Aug. 12, but he said new price rules would be set for oil, construction, manufacturing, wholesaling, retailing and insurance. A rise in food prices is expected. . . . The gross national product in the second quarter was $1.27trillion, annual rate, up 2.6 per cent from the firstquarter level. This compared with a rise of more than 8 per cent in the previous two quarters. . . . The Con sumer Price Index in June rose 0.6 per cent, after seasonal adjustment.

title: Hijackers Continue to Hold Japan Jet With 145 Inside
description: DUBAI, July 21  Hijackers continued today to hold hos tage a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet with its 123 passengers and 22 crew members and threat ened to blow up the aircraft if anyone approached it.

title: POLICE PRESS HUNT FOR GIRL'S SLAYER
description: As the police intensified their search for clues in the predawn slaying Friday of a 21yearold Indiana woman in Brooklyn Heights, the victim's parents lauded city and police officials yesterday and then took their daughter's body home to be buried.

title: A Word for the Old Pols
description: By one of those twists that enliven history, the most self  consciously American of all our Presidents, down to the flag on his lapel, has come a cropper by dispensing with that most American of all institutions, the old pol. If Richard Nixon had staffed the White House and his party with poli ticians instead of fanatic devotees and zealous amateurs, his Administration might now be purring along with no more than the normal partisan opposi tionand probably less.

title: U.S. Concerns Exhibit Airport Control Devices in Moscow to Assist Soviet
description: MOSCOW, July 21Twen tyseven American companies have joined to bring highly advanced aeronautical tech nology to a Moscow exhibi tion to help the Soviet Union modernize its admittedly overloaded civil air traffic control systems.

title: The Uncertain Law Privilege Or Hiding Place?
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon was on fairly firm legal, if not moral, ground when he secretly recorded private conversations with his staff, Cabinet and other visitors over the past two years. But his right to with hold all of these records from the Senate Watergate Committee is an other question altogether.

title: Complete Poems, 19131962
description: The odd look on the page of E. E. Cummings's poems is best understood as an attempt to apply the theory of the Symbolists to particles small er than the traditional elements of poetry. Like his Symbolist predeces sors and modernist contemporaries, Cummings will jam words into novel contexts so that peripheral or buried possibilities are forced into promi nence. He will juxtapose heterogene ous elements without providing the trope that yokes them together. He will violate the habits of English syntax so that semantic units can float free of any grammatical setting that might anchor them to single meanings. He will use adverbs as nouns, prepositions as adjectives and articles as verbs. He knows all the devices that for a long time now have led the ordinary reader by his expectations to where the pie will hit him squarely in the face. Cum mings said that he could express his theory of technique in 15 words, by quoting The Eternal Question And Immortal Answer of burlesk, viz. Would you hit a woman with childNo, I'd hit her with brick.

title: L.I. Bridal for Tina Rathborne And Philip Y. De Normandie
description: MILL NECK, L. I., July 21 Miss Tina Nelson Rath borne and Philip Yardley De Normandie, son of Mr. and Mrs. James De Normandie of Lincoln and Cataumet, Mass., were married here this afternoon.

title: Tunnel Jams
description: The normal, fumeridden trip through the Holland and Lincoln tunnels dur ing the morning rush hour got a little worse last week. The men who are supposed to help move traffic along, instead cooperated to tie it up.

title: Key to the Mint Triumphs; Riva Ridge Is Withdrawn
description: Key to the Mint added a heretofore elusive prize to the extensive trophy room of the Rokeby Stable by winning the $109,500 Suburban Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The for midable son of Graustark, bred in Virginia by his owner, Paul Mellon, took the 87th running of the 11/4mile event by 13/4 lengths on the sloppy track in 2:00 4/5.

title: Numismatics Bicentennial Coinage: In the Balance
description: EVEN diehard opti mists have just about given up all hope for massive Federal ac tivity or real signs of leader ship in the celebration of this nation's Bicentennial which is now less then three years away. The only im portant Bicentennial project pending in Washington is the proposal to substitute special 1776  1976 Independ ence designs on our circu lating coinage, and even that project, as presently planned is on the puny side of being massive.

title: James H. Riding Plans to Marry Susan Melinette
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 21  Mr. and Mrs. George Northrop Melinette have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Diantha Melinette, to James Harry Riding, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Riding of Seattle.

title: Texas Bishop's Charity Fund Disputed
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 21A retired Roman Catholic Bishop who put at least $5million into a charitable trust aloof from but devoted to the church is the center of an unusual legal tangle that District Judge Her man Jones is being asked to unravel.

title: Migration of Blacks Analyzed
description: More than onethird of the blacks living in the nine met ropolitanarea counties of northern New Jersey near est to New York City were born outside of New Jersey, according to a Census Bureau analysis of migration trends.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: TWO TEENAGE GIRLS ARE KILLED BY CAR
description: Two teenage girls who lived in a Bronx home for dependent and neglected children were struck and killed by a car last night, according to the police, who said they were dancing on an exit lane of the Pelham Parkway.

title: Ronan Praises Rockefeller Plan For Transportation Bond Issue
description: The chairman of the Metro politan Transportation Author ity yesterday praised Governor Rockefeller's proposal for a $3.5billion bond issue to help mass transit and highways.

title: Mary Hunter, C. H. Judge 3d Wed in South
description: HENDERSON, N. C., July 21The Episcopal Church of the Holy Innocents was the setting here this after noon for the marriage of Miss Mary Bunn Hunter to Curtis Herbert Judge 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Judge Jr. of Larchmont, N. Y. The Rev. Edward Cook Lecarpentier Jr. of Christ Episcopal Church in Raleigh performed the ceremony.

title: ARREST TOLL IS 1,700 FOR CHAVEZ PICKETS
description: FRESNO, Calif., July 21 (UPI) Mass arrests of Cesar Cha vez's defiant United Farm Workers Union pickets reached 1,700 today. Some jails were so jammed that six persons at a time were crammed into two man cells. Most of the arrested pickets slept on the floor.

title: Cleric in France Proposes Tax Protest Against HTests
description: PARIS, July 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Rev. Al bert Finet, former editor of the French Protestant weekly maga zine Reforme, has suggested a churchbacked refusal by Christians to pay a part of their taxes as a protest against nu clear tests. France held its first nuclear test blast of the year in the Pacific today.

title: Expressway Jams
description: One of the traits that make Long Islanders such an independent and hardy breed is their ability to sense an impending traffic jam on the Long Island Expressway and resourcefully navigate alternate routes.

title: Reformed Church in America Emphasizes DriveIn Services
description: GARDEN GROVE, Calif., July 21  The Reformed Church in America has chosen drivein re ligion as its focal point for congregational growth in the nineteenseventies.

title: 3 Carolina Doctors Are Under Inquiry In Sterilization of Welfare Mothers
description: AIKEN, S. C., July 21 In vestigations were started this week into a policy of three lo cal obstetricians that requires welfare mothers with three or more children to agree to steri lization to receive treatment.

title: Stars Attend Hawkins Rites
description: LONDON, July 21 (Reuters) Stars from the film world paid their last respects today to Jack Hawkins, the actor, who died here of throat cancer last Wednesday at the age of 62. Among those who at tended a brief ceremony at a crematorium were David Niven, Peter O'Toole and Lauren Recall. Also present were about 40 close friends and relatives. Mrs. Doreen Hawkins, the ac tor's widow, was accompanied by her two sons.

title: 6MAN JURY RULE BEGINS HERE AUG.1
description: civil cases in the Federal courts here will be decided by juries composed of six mem bers, instead of the traditional 12, beginning Aug. 1.

title: This Jury Will Take to the Air and Fly
description: MUSIC competitions fol low a fairly standard procedure, with con testants converging on a single site. A new entry into the field, the Rhode Island International Master Pianist Competition, is follow ing to some extent the policy of the Metropolitan Opera's National Council by holding regional auditions before the final runoffs take place. It will send a team of judges to screen pianists in Chicago, New York, Paris, Vienna and San Francisco between Nov. 10 and Dec. 2. In each city two distinguished regional musicians will join the traveling jury.

title: Officer Marries Anne T. Starr In Pennsylvania
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., July 21 Miss Anne Townsend Starr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Starr 3d, was mar ried here this afternoon to Lieut. Stephen Stewart Cun ningham of the Air Force, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Cunningham of New York.

title: The Sun Shines on Yankees Rainy Day
description: Despite a daylong rain that can frustrate beach bums and baseball players alike on summer weekend, Ralph Houk felt good yesterday.

title: CHURCH AND STATE CLASH IN AMAZON
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 21 A serious confrontation is tak ing place between church state in the town of So Flix do Arguaia in a remote par of southern Amazonia.

title: ANNIHILATE EM WINS MINUTEMAN
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) Annilhilate Em did just that to 10 rivals in the $58,750 Min uteman Handicap today, win ning the feature at Liberty Bell Race Track by 5 lengths.

title: Disabled Man Robbed
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) Two men robbed a Vietnam veteran on a disability of his $10,000 life savings after he had taken them out of a bank here, the police said. Ronald Banks withdrew the money to deposit it in a bank closer to his home. As he left the bank, two men took him into an alley and seized the money, the po lice said.

title: The Pentagon
description: WASHINGTONIt always seems to begin with a letter, filled with con viction and misspellings. There was ex G.I. Ronald L. Ridenhour's description of My Lai 4. Then Airman Lonnie D. Franks told of Gen. John D. Lavelle's unauthorized bombings of North Vietnam.

title: Free London Bus Rides Set for Senior Citizens
description: LONDON, July 21Free bus transportation for Lon don's estimated 1.2million pensioners has been an nounced by the Greater Lon don Council.

title: Hunt's Symptoms Termed Consistent With Stroke
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The medical director of the Bureau of Prisons said today that E. Howard Hunt Jr. had symptoms consistent with a stroke but was not incapaci ta ted.

title: Kerry Rodgers Is Bride
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 21Miss Kerry Rodgers and Michael A. Anderson were married here this afternoon in the United Methodist Church by the Rev. George Watt Jr. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd D. Rodgers Jr. of Glen Rock, Mr. Rodgers is direc tor of public relations for the Grand Union Company in East Paterson. The bride groom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Anderson of HoHoKus. His father is director of manufacturing in Europe for ColgatePalmolive International, inc., in New York.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 250 book. stores in 110 communities of the United States. The figures in the right hand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Loveladies Feeds Performers First
description: LOVELADIES  The con tracts of all performers ap pearing in the FourStar Con cert Series of the Long Beach Island Foundation of Arts and Sciences this summer contain a clause that must be unique on such docu ments: An invitation to have a preconcert swim and a light supper at the Mana hawkin Bay home of Mar garet S. Lyon, program chairman for the series.

title: Movies
description: IT may be simple paranoia, but there is a growing sense of constriction in the daily developments of our cultural life. If the sixties was an age of explosive looninesspainful, but productivemight not the seventies be the age wherein an asylum was built to contain that looniness? And might not such diverse incidents as Water gate, the CBS News policy abandoning instant analyses of Presidential ad dresses, the recent move in San Fran cisco against North Beach nudity, the suppression in New York of Deep Throat, and the new Supreme Court ruling on obscenitymight not these events constitute the first bars and padded cells of that cultural asylum? If there is one possible genius among 50 madmen, the freedom of the 49 is a small price to pay for the fruition of the one.

title: Patricia Vander Veer Is Married on L. I.
description: SYOSSET, L. I., July 21 Miss Patricia Martha Louise Vander Veer was married here this afternoon to David George Spaulding in the garden of her parents home. The Rev. Robert T. Hollett of Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay performed the ceremony.

title: DROUGHT IS THEE IN SAHARA REGION
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta (UPI)The drought devastat ing West Africa below the Sahara seems almost unreal in this capital city.

title: What's Doing in ROME
description: SPECIAL EVENTSThe Noantri Festival, the closest thing there is these days to a Roman bacchanal, is a lively neighborhood celebration that will continue through early August in the Trastevere district on the west bank of the Tiber. Noantri means we others in the earthy vernacular of Trastevere. Chinese lanterns are strung across the narrow streets, venders loudly praise their watermelons and roast pork, trattoria tables line the side. walks and piazzas, and visitors spin out long lazy dinners until the wee hours with a few liters of Frascati. Meanwhile stentorian singers, ac companied by guitarists, offer not toosubtle couplets in the Roman dialect. Usually, a 1,000lire note will persuade the singers to switch to old Neapolitan favorites.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONA Senate subcom mittee has fired the opening salvo in a Congressional challenge to the Admin istration's new weapons program. Without a dissenting voice, the re searchanddevelopment panel of the Senate Armed Services Committee has voted to slash in half the $1.8billion requested in the 1973 defense budget for speeding the construction of the Trident submarine.

title: Merit Shop Fight Ends in Michigan
description: KALKASKA, Mich., July 21 Peace has returned to this tiny village after six months of often violent conflict be tween construction union mem bers and a Shell Oil Co. con tractor who employs nonun ion labor.

title: Bergen Schedules Outdoor Art Show
description: PARAMUS  The Bergen County Park Commission will hold its ninth annual Outdoor Art Show at Van Saun Park on Aug. 11. The rain date is Aug. 18.

title: Miss Baldwin Becomes Bride
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 21 Miss Elizabeth Deaver Baldwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Barrett Baldwin of Hilton Head Is land, S. C., and Glen Cove, was married here this eve ning to Howard Arthur Tay lor of Southampton, England. The Rev. John Jobson per formed the ceremony in St. John's of Lattingtown Epis copal Church.

title: 100 BROOKLYNITES CALL RENT STRIKE
description: Nearly 100 tenants in four buildings in a middleclass Brooklyn neighborhood are withholding rent from their landlord because, they say, the buildings are ridden with viola tions.

title: QUARRY, WAGNER BATTLE TO DRAW
description: Mike Quarry of San Luis Obis po, Calif., survived an eye cut in the fourth round yesterday and battled to a draw with Billy (Kelly) Wagner of Cleve land in a 12round nationally televised lightweight fight. The bout, before a crowd of 2,178 at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum was for the Ameri can boxing championship.

title: American Composers: The Insulted and The Injured?
description: EZRA LADERMAN is right, of course,to take offense. He and all other American composers should feel insult ed at Lyric Opera of Chi cago's recent decision to commission Krzysztof Pende recki to write an opera in honor of the Bicentennial of United States independence. In his capacity as president of the American Music Center, a kind of composer's trade association, Laderman wrote a letter to The New York Times the other day de ploring what he termed this regrettably alltootypical ex ample of reverse chauvin ism. The offer to Pende recki, the Polish avantgard ist, is hard to justify on any grounds, including musical and patriotic ones.

title: Letters To the Editor Bellow on Berryman
description: To the Editor:

title: Dubassoff Rallies to Capture $117,750 Arlington Handicap and Returns $5
description: CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) Dubassoff, overcoming trouble on the last turn, charged on the outside today to win the 41st running of the $117,750 Arlington Handicap before 26,060 at Arlington Park.

title: Two Drivers Are Killed In Belgian Auto Race
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Bel gium, Sunday, July 22 (Reu ters)  Two drivers were killed and two others seri ously injured in three sepa rate accidents during the Francorchamps 24hour mo tor race early today.

title: Woman May Coach a Men's Diving Team
description: The No. 1 choice for coach of Vanderbilt University's male varsity diving team is Lani Loken, a former national champion. If the 25yearold Miss Loken accepts the offer, she will become the first woman to coach a male var sity team of any kind in the Southeastern Conference.

title: Regina Clipper Engaged
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 21 The engagement of Miss Re gina Mary Clipper of New York to Robert Charles Wil liam Cavanna of Fisher's Is land, N. Y., has been an nounced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Clipper. Mr. Cavan na is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Cavanna of New Dorp. Staten Island, New York.

title: Mobutu Backs Development
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, July 21 (Agence FrancePresse)Presi dent Mobutu Sese Seko yester day ordered an expenditure of $1.2million to modernize the frontier regions of upper Zaire following his recent visit there.

title: 6,874 Tickets Remain For GiantsJets Game
description: The demand for tickets to the New York GiantsJets game on Sunday, Aug. 19, at Yale Bowl has intensified, ac cording to Fred Loeser, chair man of the YaleUnited Way game committee. He said yes terday that 6,874 tickets re mained unsold.

title: Pointers On Door Locks
description: ALTHOUGH a good qual ity door lock will last for many years and costs surprisingly lit tle when compared to the amount of protection it gives, a great many people still en trust the security of their homes or apartments to in effective, easytoopen door locks that even the most in ept burglar could quickly open.

title: The hassle is ideological
description: Our story thus far: Timothy Leary has been busted for pos session, deployment and enjoy ment of the killer weed, the dread cannabis, and salted away in a minimumsecurity Califor nia slammer. With the aid of jailbreak genius freaks, he goes over the hilland, with his wife, seeks asylum with Eld ridge Cleaver and the Black Panthers in Algeria. Symbolic ally, he has shaved his head as part of his escape disguise. Symbolically, because his move is from one prison to another, from the wire camps of West Coast justice to the glum Arab apartments of a revolutionary he'd honored, who proves un able to honor him.

title: Cambodia Wants Bombing to Continue
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 21 (Reuters)Cambodia will ask that American bomb ing be continued after the scheduled cutoff date of Aug. 15, it was announced here to day.

title: AntiLocust Fund Plea
description: NIAMEY, Niger, July 21 (Agence France  Presse)  The Organization Against Locusts and GrainEating Birds has opened an international appeal for funds to help resolve finan cial difficulties. Its administra tive board met here for four days this week and heard from delegations from Cameroon, Dahomey, Upper Volta, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal and Chad.

title: State Legion Elects
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 21 (AP)  William H. Kelley of Cornwall was elected com mander of the New York State American Legion at the 55th annual convention here today. Elected vice commanders were Walter Cublta, Bronx; Albert A. Sarro, Inwood, L.I.; Henry Gurney, Whitehall; David C. Olmstead, Binghamton, and Howard Bushart, Williamson.

title: South Brooklyn Rescues Old Library From Razing
description: Community concern has apparently saved the city's oldest functioning library from demolition.

title: 2 Bills Will Seek Election Reform
description: TRENTONThe Democrat ic party platform for this year's gubernatorial and leg islative elections contends that New Jersey's election laws are unclear, confusing and contradictory, and it promises sweeping revisions of them should the party seize political control of the state in November.

title: Baby Abandoned in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, July 21 (AP)A newborn baby, wrapped in a Tshirt and lying in a whisky carton, was discovered by a priest today at a door of the rectory at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in nearby Lackawanna. The unidentified infant was taken to Our Lady of Victory Hospital where she was listed in good condition.

title: Understanding the Business Culture
description: Jack London in his autobi ographical novel, Martin Eden, reveals a fascinating picture of the businessman and his brush with higher culture.

title: JohnBoy Comes Hometo Manhattan
description: RICHARD THOMAS has been pos ing for Seventeen. Holding schoolbooks, footballs, apples. Wearing overalls  the whole bit, he says a bit contemptuously. For the moment, though, he is off camera, out of costume; he's wearing a blue shirt and brown pants and is sitting in his manager's office. I've come in on the middle of a conversation about Youth and Values and The Good Old Days. The manager is saying that he isn't cut out for businessfor contracts and sig natures and put it in writing; he believes in trust. Richard says Yeah honesty. The corner grocery store where you run down on your bike for a fivepound bag of flour and the gro cer knows your name.

title: Tax Issue Still a Sleeping Giant for Candidates
description: TRENTONCandidates on the statewide level are lis tening for footsteps as they campaign this year. They are hoping that tax reform, the sleeping giant of New Jer sey's governmental problems, will not be revived before the votes are counted.

title: AllStars Glitter Tuesday Night In Royals Shiny New Stadium
description: The manager of the American League team came down with appendicitis, the biggest votegetter in the league suffered a hairline fracture of the leg, the third baseman on the other squad injured his hip and the man who pitched two no hitters this season was originally left out.

title: Ocean's Pummeling Reshapes Fire Island
description: Fire Island has survived another winter of piercing winds and pound ing tides, but the surf in some areas comes 40 feet higher than it did a year ago, and at points the 31mile spit of sand is only 300 yards wide.

title: Up The Ladder, But How Fast?
description: In 1972, the median income of American families rose to $11,120an increase of 8.1 per cent over 1971. In the same year, the median income of black families was $6,860, a substan tial increase over the 1971 black me dian of $6,440.

title: DEMOCRATS MOVE ON 1974 MEETING
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., July 21Leaders of the Democrats, seeking to avert further frac turing and disarray in the party, moved today toward staging a 1974 midterm con vention that would be held after the 1974 elections and would avoid divisive debates over party policy.

title: Ulbricht Has Stroke; Condition Is Serious
description: BERLIN, July 21 (UPI) The East German Chief of State, Walter Ulbricht, suf fered a stroke on Thursday and is in serious condition, the East German press agen cy said tonight,

title: Sports News Briefs
description: THE CURRAGH, Ireland, July 21 (UPI)  Dahlia, a French filly owned by a Texas millionaire, Nelson Bunker Hunt, pulled away in the stretch from the 12 favorite, Mysterious, to win the Irish Oaks today. Dahlia, an 81 shot, was ridden by an Australian jockey, Bill Pyers, for a French trainer, Maurice Zilber. The victory was worth $56,250.

title: Poe With a French Accent
description: IF not one of the best, Edgar Allan Poe was certainly one of the most extraordinary writers who ever lived. Moreover, the history of his reputation since his death in 1849 con stitutes one of the great prodigies of creative influence, the story of a gifted inventor of literary oddities who be came, through his impact on others, a heroic force in the formation of modern art and sensibility. That rela tively little of this posthumous growth was helped along by other Americans is a typical irony of the account.

title: Letters: More Tips On Beating the Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. McGowen Reweds
description: TRENTON, July 21Mrs. Patricia L. McGowen of New York, widow of Walter A. McGowen, was married at the Ewing Township City Hall here this morning to Dr. Rolf Altschul, also of New York, professor of chemistry at Sarah Lawrence College. Mayor Harry L. Darby of Ewing Township performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Lettiere of Trenton. Dr. Altschul is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hugo Altschul of Dusseldorf, Germany. His previous mar riage ended in divorce.

title: Watergate Costing G.O.P. Political Help and Money
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21The political organizers at the Re publican National Committee in Washington cannot afford a secretary.

title: He saw the South as it ought to be
description: President Nixon once de fended his Supreme Court no minee G. Harrold Carswell against a charge that he had made a white supremacy speech in 1948 by pointing out that in 1940 [Ralph McGill] wrote a column in which he came out unalterably against integration of education of Southern schools. He changed his mind later. As you know, he was a very great advocate of integration. That doesn't mean that you question his in tegrity in his late years be cause in his earlier years he; took the position that other Southerners were taking.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayS.C.C.A. CanAm races at Watkins Glen, N.Y., first race at 1:45 P.M.

title: PHILIPPINE DRIVE ON REBELS GROWS
description: ZAMBOANGA, The Philip pines, July 19The conflict triggered by the Philippine Mos lem insurgency is growing in intensity and savagery in this area.

title: Ervin's Witnesses Honorable Men and Evil Times
description: WASHINGTONThis time last year in the summer of 72Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's personal attorney, was crisscrossing the coun try, meeting secretly in public parks, cars and hotel rooms, talking in code words over pay telephones and raising hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash for the Watergate burglars.

title: Nuclear Shutdown Asked
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Friends of the Earth, a con servation group, and Ralph Na der have filed a joint petition with the Atomic Energy Com mission, asking that 20 nuclear power plants in 12 states be shut down immediately.

title: Senate Bill Promoting Recycling Supported
description: MANHASSET, L. I.  Michael J. Tully Jr., North Hempstead Town Supervisor, came out strongly last week in favor of pending Federal legislation that could pro vide his town with as much as $5million for solidwaste disposal.

title: Daniels Perturbed Over Job Picture
description: JERSEY CITY  Safety in youth camps. That's the kind of regulation we've got to get enacted right now, Representative Dominick V. Daniels said the other day. We can't afford to wait un til the summer is over, after thousands of accidents have taken place and all the kids are home. Right now is the time.

title: AILMENT STRIKING YOUNG IN VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Ju ly 21 (AP)South Vietnamese children are battling a tropical fever that attacks their blood streams.

title: JOHNSON LIBRARY IN REPAIR FIGHT
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 21  A low bid of $1,773,771 has been submitted to the University of Texas for repair work to the twoyearold, $18.6million Lyn don Baines Johnson Library.

title: Sabotaging the I.C.C.S.
description: The seventeenday ordeal suffered by two Canadian truce supervisors at the hands of Vietcong captors South Vietnam is, as a senior Canadian officer put it, an outrage beyond comprehension.

title: Essex Fossil Site Now a Landmark
description: ROSELAND  The Riker Hill Fossil Site has been added to the National Regis try of Natural Landmarks.

title: The Theory The Idea Is To Phase Out Phases
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon, conceding with unusual frankness that the recent price freeze had caused more problems than it solved, ended the freeze for food last week and an nounced yet another phase in his everchanging program of price and wage controls. The President was far more modest in his claims and objec tives for his new Phase 4 program than he had been previously, admitting that further significant price increases are ahead, greater than anyone would like.

title: U.S. Breaks World Record For Juniors at Polish Meet
description: WARSAW, July 21 (UP1) The United States set its sec ond world junior relay record in 24 hours otday t the close of a twoday track and field meet against Poland. The mark came in the 1,600meter relay, which the Americans won in 3 minutes, 8.2 seconds. They tied the previous record of 3:11.3 one week ago during a junior meet against West Ger many in Munich.

title: Japanese Sailor, 50, Is Found
description: DAVAO CITY, the Philip pines, July 21 (UPI)A man who identified himself as Ryoji Miki, a sailor in the Japanese Navy of World War II, emerged from more than 30 years of hiding today and said he wants to stay here and become a citizen of the Philippines.

title: Arthur Doctor Dead at 74; Made Women's Clothing
description: Arthur Doctor, a leader in the women's readytowear in dustry here, died Friday at his home, 1025 Fifth Avenue. He was 74 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Clams Shifted to Clean Waters
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Every Monday, Wednesday and Fri day, a 54foot dredge boat called the Senator Sharp plies between Lakes Bay here and Great Bay, 15 miles to the north, in an attempt to save the New Jersey clam from pollution.

title: The fixer of modern camp
description: Ronald Firbank remains one of the most steadfastly unread writers of his generation. Forced to pay for the publication of his own novels during his lifetime, Firbank has not been compensated for his troubles or expensesby posterity; his ec centric work is as little appreciated now as at the time of his death in 1926. No one has ever known what exactly to make of his odd, fragile novels such as Vainglory (1915), Valmouth (1919), The Flower Beneath the Foot (1923) and Prancing Nigger (1924), just as no one ever really knew what to make of the man.

title: Lomas's Stretch Routine Puts Jets in Varied Frames of Mind
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 21The faith healer who once tried to invade the Jets camp is gone, perhaps to the Atlantic league, and Steve Tannen isn't trying acupuncture anymore.

title: the traveler's world
description: CAPE MAY, N. J.  In 1740 Phila delphia newspapers carried adver tisements enticing their readers to resort to Cape May, a cor rect but now slightly archaic use of that word and proof that this southernmost tip of New Jersey is an old oldtimer in the tourist business.

title: College Gets Grant
description: GAINESVILLE Fla., July 21 (AP)Paul Miller, president of the Frank E. Gannett Newspa per Foundation, announced this week that the foundation was making a $1million grant to the College of Journalism and Communications at the Univer sity of Florida.

title: Laotian Communist Troops Said to Seize Valley Area
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 21 (UPI)Communist Pathet Lao and North Vietnamese troops overran a valley area 115 miles southeast of Vientiane, where thousands of refugees have been settled, military sources said today.

title: RULING ON PRESS SETS OFF DISPUTE
description: A ruling by the Florida Su preme Court has touched off what many editors believe to be a new First Amendment crisis by raising the issue of the right of access to news paper columns.

title: BRAZIL TO BUILD  MODEL PRISONS
description: RIO DE JANIERO, July 21 Brazil is to spend $16.6million to reform the country's prison system, which has been severe ly criticized, even by govern ment officials. Fifteen model prisons will be built in the next three years.

title: LINDSAY SCORED ON PROGRAM CUTS
description: A report by a nonprofit agency charges the Lindsay administration with bemoaning Federal antipoverty cutbacks while failing to restore the funding for several social pro grams out of an ample supply of Federal revenuesharing funds.

title: Marjorie Miller Fiancee
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 21  Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Miller have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Joan Miller, to Dennis A. Rot man, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Lee Rotman of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Miss Miller and her fiance were gradu ated in June from North western University.

title: Mrs. Magee, Teacher, Wed
description: NOROTON, Conn., July 21 In St. Luke's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Mrs. Lucinda Baker Magee and Len Cummings Gane, both of Ridgefield, were married by the Rev. Robert Nelson Back.

title: Record Industry on Coast Shaken by Payola Studies
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21The once freewheeling pop record industry has grown tense here after two months of publicity about alleged payola and drug scandals.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A National Guardsman from the Bronx will spend 10 days in the Jefferson County jail because he became im patient yesterday over a long line at a telephone booth at Camp Drum, where he was undergoing two weeks of train ing. The police of Watertown, N. Y., said the man, Richard Kadlec, 23 years old, of 4119 Digney Avenue, in his im patience drove a 2ton Army truck against the phone booth. No one was injured. The guardsman was charged with reckless endangerment and leaving the scene of an accident.

title: LIBYAN MARCHERS IN EGYPT LEAVING
description: CAIRO, July 21Thousands of Libyans who drove into Egypt demanding immediate unification of the two countries headed homeward today after heeding an appeal from their leader, Col. Muammar elQad dafi, to obey Egyptian orders to withdraw.

title: The View From Europe
description: PARISPresident Nixon was not exaggerating when he conceded last week, in announcing Phase 4 controls, that confidence in his management of fiscal affairs was low abroad.

title: James Tracy Marries Mary A. Sullivan
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 21Miss Mary Alice Sulli van, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Redmond Sulli van of Bronxville, was mar ried here this morning to James Alexander Tracy, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Fran cis Tracy of Short Hills, N, J.

title: Quarter Horses To Get a Full Role At Orange County
description: After showing their wares at such stops as Montreal, Lake Placid, Detroit, Cape Cod and Upperville, Va., the equine caravan will arrive at Middletown, N.Y., for the Orange County Fair horse show next Saturday.

title: 600 Get a Complete Summer
description: PASSAIC  About 600 of Passaic's innercity young sters are attending a sum mer day camp that is spon sored by a coalition of clergy men and civic leaders known as the Passaic Interfaith Com mittee for Action. The camp is operated in a school, a housing project and the Boys Club, and uses the swimming pool at the Y.M.C.A.

title: A Backyard Full of Wildlife
description: NEWFIELD  Although most pet lovers are usually content with the antics of a cat, dog or canary, an allout nature buff here is happiest when a wild, but friendly, beaver climbs up on her lap to nibble a proffered poplar twig.

title: THEATER
description: ACTORS CAFETHEATER, 263 Cen tral Avenue, East OrangeA Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Aug. 4). $3.50$3.90; students, $2$2.90. (201) 6751881.

title: MAI TAI TRIUMPHS IN RYE HORSE SHOW
description: RYE, N. Y., July 21Mai Tai, an aged black gelding handled by Mike Margiotta, won all three classes with a minimum of difficulty to win the preliminary jumper cham pionship today at the rain soaked Coach House Stables horse show.

title: An early Christian coverup?
description: Clement of Alexandria lived 18 centuries ago. (Do not confuse him with Clement, Paul's friend, or with Clement, Bishop of Rome. They lived 100 years earlier.) Clement of Alex andria, in Egypt, had once been pagan philosopher. He was converted to Christianity in middle age. He had a keen moral sense, and taught that sound ethics are rooted in sound philosophy. He, like others before him, was troubled by some fringe groups in the church, who claimed to be exempt from normal morality. One of the most blatant of such groups had been started by a cer tain Carpocrates, evidently a near contemporary of Clement. Carpo crates seems to have equated Christ ian freedom with license and with sexual religious rites.

title: Criminals At Large
description: THEY'VE SHOT THE PRESI DENT'S DAUGHTER! (Double day, $6.95.) That title should stop you!

title: Bonds to Buy Creek Park Voted in North Hempstead
description: MANHASSET, L. I.  The North Hempstead Town Board unanimously approved a $270,000 bond issue earlier this month that will be used to purchase Creek Park, a 2acre strip of woodland in Great Neck.

title: Taping Conversation A Common Practice
description: The technology of mag netic tape recording one of many industries that blossomed after World War II  has become so pervasive in the United States and oth er advanced economies that almost anyone can set up a system for monitoring his own, facetoface conversa tions and phone calls.

title: New U.S. Challenge: Exports to the Mideast
description: Most of America's industries appear to be taking this nation's declining self sufficiency in energy and concomitant problems seriously but in stride.

title: Arthur Daley Without Any Designation
description: If Cy Acosta of the White Sox ever reaches the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, it will be only as a tourist. Certain inade quacies in his pitching skills unfortunately prevent him from some day shouldering his way in there among Cy Young, Walter Johnson, Christy Mathewson and the other immortals. Although not many people have noticed it as yet, however, Acosta already is a man of distinction. In this season of the designated hitter, he be came the first pitcher in the American League to come to bat. Prior to that

title: Valuation Cut 4.5Million Without Usual Realty Data
description: The owner of a new 50story skyscraper in Times Square re ceived a $4.5million reduction in assessed valuation last year without having filed the requi site incomeandexpense state ment with the city's Tax Corn mission.

title: Kindness and Benefit To All
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.From a strategic point of view there isn't any doubt that the Trust Territories of Micronesia, whose supervision was awarded to Washington by the U.N. following World War II, have great significance.

title: Can the Lady Save the Lyceum?
description: No one trotting around our town these days in behalf of worthy causes can be more dedicated than Mrs. Daniel Frohman Davison, a wafer thin grandmother who stands no more than 4 feet 10 inches tall and in whose warm blue eyes glow the joy of battle.

title: Dave Anderson Murcer's Lib
description: Bobby Murcer deserves to be liberated. In his career with the New York Yankees, he has followed Mickey Mantle and Joe DiMaggio in center field. But the heritage of his position has become his bondage. Whatever he has dole, it has never been quite good enough. Now he deserves to be recognized for what he isthe best player on what might be the Yankees first pen

title: Village Displays Old Crafts
description: FLEMINGTON  Turntable Junction was probably not the first 20thcentury shop ping center to come wrapped in pseudo18thcentury archi tecture. But the sevenyear old realestate venture here may well be pioneering in its Liberty Village offshoot.

title: To Be a Rock Climber You Need a Good Grasp of the Subject
description: SIXTY fee above the base of the ?? I shifted my weight cau tiously from right foot to left. Both my feet were precariously placed on an outwardsloping niche, which measured about an inch and a half deep by one foot long, The rock was soaking wet from alternate snow and rain. Slowly I lifted my right foot to a thin flake of rock, which would provide a step up. My hands were cling ing to a crack in a mass of overhanging rock. Reaching over this rock and find ing a comforting hold, I scrambled up vigorously, and suddenly I was standing triumphantly beside instructor.

title: Safety Panel Links Fatal Rail Crash To Errors by Crew
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Errors in judgment caused the Chicago train crash that killed 45 persons and injured 332 others last October, the National Transportation Safe ty Board has said.

title: Crash of Amtrak Turbine Near Montreal Investigated
description: MONTREAL, July 21 (UPI) Canadian National Railways said today that investigators still had not discovered the cause of yesterday's collision in which a $2million turbine powered train was destroyed during a final test run for Am trak.

title: Dance: Between Promise and Success
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 21  The Dance Theater of Harlem is currently some where between promise and fulfillment. It has several ex cellent dancers and a service able repertory and seems upon the threshold of an en semble performing style, which, however, it has not yet firmly established. These qualities and others were on view last night at Connecti cut College's American Dance Festival.

title: It's So Progressive in Texas
description: DRIPPING SPRINGS, Tex. AT 3 P.M. on the Fourth of July, Chuck Allen, country music fan and construction worker, was sitting halfway up one of the scrubby hills surround ing a valley just outside Drip ping Springs, Tex. Chuck's Chevy had brought him crawling along four miles of dirt road from Route 290, 10 miles out of Austin, through storms of dust so dense that he couldn't open his car windows to make up for a painful lack of air condition ing, to a parking spot from which he then had to hike another dusty mile to the place where the music was playing. But he was happy.

title: News of the Stage
description: Two of Sir Nol Coward's last short plays, A Song at Twilight and Come Into the Garden, Maud, will be pro duced as a dual bill on Broad way this fall by Richard Barr and Charles Woodward.

title: Television
description: THE television machine generates so much nonsense, both on and off the tube, that when TV occasionally does a sharp job of exposing nonsense, the effect is almost dispropor tionately encouraging. That was the case recently when Mike Wallace dragged Nor man Mailer over the depend ably hot coals of an inter view on 60 Minutes.

title: Disputed HighRises Approved For Bayside
description: The Board of Estimate unanimously approved late last week a highrise apart ment complex in the Bay side section of Queens after the plan was slightly modi fied in an effort to appease angry residents of the com munity of basically one and twofamily dwellings.

title: TOP AWARD AGAIN TO BICHON FRISE
description: CARMEL, N. Y., July 21 Ch. Chaminade's Syncopation, a little Bichon Frise, made history at Farmington, Conn., just two weeks ago when he was named best in show, becoming the first of his breed to ever gain that distinction. Today he won his second top award at the Put nam County event on the grounds of the Kent School. A field of 1,535 competed.

title: Police Offer Free Advice On Preventing Burglary
description: Operating on the premise that an ounce of prevention is worth a week of manhours, the New York City Police Department is attempting to reduce calls for help after the fact by soliciting them in advance.

title: U.S. CONFIRMS TIES WITH AFGHANISTAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (Reu ters)  The United States for mally told Afghanistan's new republican Government today that it intended to continue close and cordial relations be tween the two countries.

title: My Six Parallels
description: For several yearsincreasingly in recent monthsI have had a sense of dj vu. The impression comes from a series of incidents in recent political trials together with disclosures seeping out of the Watergate swamp. I am reminded of parallels with incidents in my Congressional hearings and trials that began 25 years ago next month.

title: 100 Pursue Gunman
description: A drunken gunman was beat en unconscious by a crowd of residents of West 134th Street yesterday morning after he shot and killed one man and wounded two of the dead man's brothers.

title: TURKISH MILITARY MAY PERMIT VOTE
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 20 The political campaign for the election of a new Turkish Par liament has begun vigorously among indications of a quiet armed forces purge of generals inclined toward military inter ference in political affairs.

title: MORE FARM STRIKERS ARRESTED ON COAST
description: FRESNO, Calif., July 21 (UPI) More farm workers were ar rested today in a labor dispute, but in two of three central Cali fornia counties, sheriff's depu ties gave up trying to enforce court orders limiting picketing by Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers after arrests reached 1,700 in five days.

title: Budweiser Triumphs In Gold Cup Regatta
description: PASCO, Wash., July 22 (AP)The Budweiser shot past a deadinthewater Pay n Pak and fought off a chal lenge by the Atlas Van Lines to win the Gold Cup regatta of unlimited hydroplane rac ing today.

title: Prime Minister of Guyana, ReElected, Names Cabinet
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, July 22 (AP)Prime Minister Forbes Burnham, returned to power for the third time, appointed his new Cabinet over the weekend.

title: West Orange Seeks to Put Restrictions On Increasingly Popular Garage Sales
description: WEST ORANGE, July 22 As a result of mounting com plaints. West Orange is scheduled to adopt an ordin ance regulating garage sales, the increasingly popular weekend sport. The ordin ance, proposed by Councilman Harry Bonnet, goes one step beyond those adopted in Ocean County's Pine Beach and Morris County's Montville: it would regulate the re moval of signs within 48 hours after the sale.

title: Instant Essays
description: When the National Security Council made the historic recommendation that the United States get out of the busi ness of bacteriological warfare, it oc curred to those asked to draft the announcement for the President that a good symbolic gesture would be to begin to destroy our stockpile of murderous germs.

title: LITTLER TRIUMPHS IN ST. LOUIS GOLF WITH A 68 FOR 268
description: ST. LOUIS, July 22 (AP) Gene Littler, once a cancer victim whom many thought would never play golf again, capped his comeback with a onestroke victory today in the $210,000 St. Louis Children's Hospital Classic.

title: Canadian Party's Fund Appeal To U.S. Concerns Stirs Dispute
description: OTTAWA, July 22The dis closure that Liberal party fund raisers solicited United States international companies for campaign contributions last year has brought demands on Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau for a Federal investi gation.

title: Police Report Lead in Heights Slaying
description: The police said yesterday that they had their first solid lead in the slaying of Debbie Phemister, the young Indiana acting student who was stabbed to death in the vestibule of her apartment house at 19 Grace Court in Brooklyn Heights.

title: No Intent to Deceive
description: LONDON, July 22When is a lie not a lie? When it deceives only 99.9 per cent of those who hear it.

title: CALIFORNIA WORKERS END CANNERY STRIKE
description: SAN FRANCISCO. July 22 (AP)  About 65,000 cannery workers began returning to work today, ending a threeday harvest strike that paralyzed canneries in northern Califor nia and left fruit rotting on the ground.

title: Muttontown Triumphs, 54, Over Sands Point in Polo
Long Restoration of Jerusalem Church Nearly Done
description: JERUSALEM, July 22After 26 years of interreligious wran gling, 14 years of actual work and expenditures of more than $3million, the longdelayed res toration of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher is nearing com pletion.

title: Book on Joseph Kennedy Brings Nurses Apology
description: HARTFORD, July 22 (AP) The American Nurses As sociation has sent a letter of apology to the Kennedy family for a breach of ethics by the late Joseph P. Kennedy's nurse, who wrote a book about her experi ences, says Jean Bowen, president of the Connecticut Nurses Association.

title: EMERSON B. REID
description: MESA, Ariz., July 22 (AP) Emerson B. Reid, former vice chairman of the Canadian Board of Immigration Appeals, died today in a hospital here after undergoing surgery. He was 71 years old.

title: Namath in Jets Camp; Starts Workouts Today
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 22 (AP)Joe Namath checked into the New York Jets training base at Hofstra Uni versity today and said he was ready to begin twoa day workouts tomorrow with the National Football League club.

title: Holdup Victim Shoots 4
description: A Queens construction work er, who later told the police he was furious at having been beaten unconscious and robbed for the sixth time, went on shooting spree outside his Ja maica apartment house yester day morning, killing one man and wounding three other mem bers of a street crowd he fired on, apparently at random.

title: National League
description: Monday, July 23, 1973

title: . . . Pentagon Horrors
description: A Senate investigation into secret bombing raids Cambodia is beginning to unravel another sordid tale coverup by the Nixon Administration, of contempt for the truth, the law and the Constitution by military and civilian officials extending to the highest levels Government.

title: President of Auto Workers Says a Strike Is Unlikely
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 22 (UPI) Leonard F. Woodcock, presi dent of the United Auto Work ers union has predicted that a strike against the Big Three auto makers or Big Three farm implement corporations is un likely.

title: Gasoline Dearth Spurs Search for Causes
description: The muchpublicized gasoline shortage and recent charges of corporate wrongdoing brought by the Federal Trade Commis sion have thrown a fresh spot light on the close relationships between the oil industry and Government regulators.

title: Black Leader Scores Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The director of the National Urban League charged tonight that the Federal Government had changed the rules of the game by substituting locally con trolled revenuesharing pro grams for federally controlled programs.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Puerto Rican Art At Metropolitan

title: Radio
description: 8:0510 A.M., WNCN. Introduc tion and Variations on Nel cor piu non mi sento, Paganini; Two Catalonian Folk Songs, Anony mous; Lo Speziale: Overture, Symphony No. 1 in D. Haydn; Serenade in C for String Orches tra, Tchaikovsky; Little Sacred Concertos (Book 1, Nos. 714), Schutz.

title: Rogers Back From Far East
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (Reu ters)Secretary of State William P. Rogers returned today after a twoday stopover in Hawaii on his way back front talks with Government officials in Tokyo and Seoul.

title: Aviary's Plan to Reopen Is Plagued by Problems
description: Plans for reopening the Queens Zoo's aviary  once the main attraction at Flush ing MeadowsCorona Park are being hindered by labor shortages, maintenance prob lems and vandalism.

title: Man Shot Dead in Belfast; Blast Kills 2 Linked to I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 22A man was shot dead early today and two terrorists were slain by their own bomb during a night of violence in Ulster.

title: Puerto Rican Visits Hanoi
description: SAIGON, July 22 (UPI) Fermin Arraiza, deputy general secretary of the Puerto Rican Socialist Party, arrived in Hanoi yesterday, North Viet nam's VNA press agency said today in a broadcast monitored in Saigon. Mr. Arraiza is visit ing North Vietnam at the in vitation of a political organiza tion, VNA said.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KANSAS CITY, July 22 (UPI)There won't be a desig nated hitter in the 44th AllStar baseball game here Tues day night, but there will be a designated manager.

title: Rumanian Captures Final In Nassau Tennis, 64, 60
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 22Peter Marmureanu of Rumania defeated King Van Nostrand of Brightwaters, L. I., 64, 60, to win the Nassau in vitation tennis tournament to day at the Shore Tennis Club.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Track Team Off on Wrong Foot for Soviet Meet
description: MINSK, Soviet Union, July 22 (UPI)The United States track and field team, minus several of its top athletes, will have a tough time against the Soviet Union, Coach Jim Bush said today.

title: Hijacked Jet Refueled, but Held Second Day
description: Hijackers and hostages alike sweltered through a second day of torrid desert heat yesterday on board a redandwhite Japan Air Lines jumbo jet that sat motionless on the shimmering tarmac of an airport in the Persian Gulf sheikdom of Dubai.

title: Moslem Battles Moslem in Sulu
description: JOLO, the Philippines, July 20In Mindanao, Moslem in surgency has shattered com munities by setting Filipino Moslem against Filipino Chris tian.

title: For Writer on Presidents, Watergate Meant Opening a Closed Book
description: Hey Ted, hey Ted, there's something for your book watergate! someone said as Theodore H. White, whose fourth The Making of the President is about to be pub lished, scurried across the room toward luncheon at the Century Club.

title: Democrats Vote to Limit 74 Meeting
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., July 22 A leadership body of the Democratic party voted by a narrow twovote majority here today against discussing nation al issues at next year's midterm Democratic convention.

title: Dance
description: Lar Lubovitch's Scherzo for Massah Jack given Sat turday afternoon at the State Theater by American Ballet Theater, is unlike any other work in the company's rep ertory. Its special sardonic quality will not be found in the company's plotless bal lets, 19thcentury classics or the contemporary dance dra mas whose stories are told with straightforward sinceri ty.

title: A River Town in Arkansas Marks Impact Of the Mississippi on Its Past and Future
description: HELENA, Ark., July 19It is difficult, especially in the summer, to see the Mississippi River from any part of Helena, even from the top of Crowley's Ridge, the sandy bluff behind the business district.

title: Personal Finance
description: A damaged Volkswagen has collided with a New York State garageman's lien law, with the result that the law may be declared uncon stitutional. That was the thrust of an opinion handed down early this month by the United States Court of Ap peals for the Second Circuit, which covers New York.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 23, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Holdup Victim Shoots 4
description: A Queens construction work er, who later told the police he was furious at having been beaten unconscious and robbed for the sixth time, went on a shooting spree outside his Ja maica apartment house yester day morning, killing one man and wounding three other mem bers of a street crowd he fired on, apparently at random.

title: Mennonite Dissident Shunned by Church and Wife
description: CARLISLE, Pa., July 22 At 44 years of age, a pros perous, softspoken Mennon ne farmer and father of six, Robert L. Bear seemed oddly cast as a heretic, excommu nicated from his church and angrily challenging the faith of his fathers.

title: Hong Kong Bus Fall Kills 15
description: HONG KONG, July 22 (AP) A bus plunged off a hillside road into a ravine on an island near Hong Kong today. Govern ment officials said that at least 15 bodies had been recovered. Twelve people were listed in critical condition. The accident occurred on Lan Tao Island, a vacation spot seven miles west of Hong Kong.

title: Saigon Says an ExOfficial Will Be Handed to the Reds
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 23 (AP)One of South Vietnam's most promi nent national officials in the late nineteensixties was report edly taken to Bien Hoa today to be released to the Vietcong as civilian prisoner exchanges were being resumed after twomonth delay.

title: Freedom Train Debuts With Excursion Run
description: ABOARD THE AMERICAN FREEDOM TRAIN, July 22 With jets of steam hissing from massive pistons, Steam Loco motive 759 and a string of 20 passenger cars rolled smoothly out of the Erie Lackawanna Terminal in Hoboken at 8:45 A.M. today on an excursion run to introduce the American Free dom Train, a planned bicen tennial exhibition.

title: Theater: Interior Castle
description: LENOX, Mass., July 21 Magic might be considered the theme of this summer at the Lenox Arts Center. The season began with Houdini, and in two weeks there will be a visit from a musical Mandrake the Magician.

title: New Name to Make Calls In Port on Cruise Service
description: A new ship name, the Doric, is scheduled to be added to the liner tonnage active in the port.

title: Books of The Times Current Events in Fiction
description: THE BILLION DOLLAR SURE THING. By Paul E. Erdman. 248 pages. Scribners. $6.95.

title: BICHON PRISE TAKES BEST AT YORK K.C.
TERRAIN HAMPERING EFFORT TO FIND COED
description: WEVERTOWN, N. Y., July 22, (UPI)State police officials said today that heavily wooded terrain in the Adirondack mountain area near here was hampering efforts to search for a Boston University coed miss ing since the body of her camp ing companion and fellow stu dent was found Friday.

title: Yankees Triumph, 20, After a 42 Loss
Mennonite Dissident Shunned by Church and Wife
description: CARLISLE, Pa., July 22 At 44 years of age, a pros perous, softspoken Mennon ite farmer and father of six, Robert L. Bear seemed oddly cast as a heretic, excommu nicated from his church and angrily challenging the faith of his fathers.

title: Despite Change, State Legislature Is Still Flawed
description: ALBANYTwo years ago, a nonpartisan group sur veyed the 50 state legislatures and decided that New York's was second only to California's, a rating that has often been bandied about by many of the state's 210 lawmakers, particularly when they are about to do such things as increase their pay and expense allowances.

title: Youth Arrested as Drunk Found Hanged in Jail Cell
description: TONAWANDA, N.Y., July 22 (AP)A 17yearold youth ar rested on a public intoxication charge early today was found hanged in a jail cell in this Buffalo suburb a short time later, the town police said.

title: Soviet Spaceship May Attempt To Make  Soft Landing on Mars
description: MOSCOW, July 22 (UPI) The Soviet Union has launched an unmanned spaceship on a six  month, 290  million  mile flight to Mars, taking ad vantage of infrequent firing window in an apparent at tempt to set a package of elec tronic gear down softly on the planet.

title: Minor Leagues
description: INTERNATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Badillo is Urged by Gigante To Forgo Race for Mayor
description: The Rev. Louis Gigante, a Democratic district leader in the South Bronx, yesterday urged Representative Herman Badillo to stop circulating peti tions to be listed as an inde pendent in the November mayoral election.

title: War Powers . . .
description: President Nixon's threat to veto the war powers legis lation that was adopted by both houses last week only serves to underscore the need for strong legislation reasserting the essential role of Congress in determining when this country's armed forces should be committed to combat. Mr. Nixon said he would welcome appropriate legislation providing for an effective contribution by Congress, but he has not bothered to say what kind of legislation he would consider appropriate. His vehe ment objections to two unique provisions of the House version betray a persisting unwillingness to accept con stitutional restraint on Presidential warmaking.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Pollution Study of 13 Lakes Starts

title: Aldo Lampredi, 74, Figure In Execution of Mussolini
description: ROME, July 22Aldo Lam predi, reputed to have taken part in the execution of Benito Mussolini, died yesterday, in a hospital at Ljubljana in north western Yugoslavia, the Italian Communist party announced here today. He was 74 years old.

title: 5,000 Indians Cross Border
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., July 22 (AP)About 5,000 Indians from Canada and the United States met in a small park to sing, dance and commemorate the signing in 1794 of the Jay treaty between the United States and Britain. The annual celebration commemorates a treaty that allows free border crossings for native peoples of both countries one day a year.

title: 6 Cited in a Scheme To Forge and Cash U.S. Savings Bonds
description: NEWARK, July 22Six per sons, including three with links to organized crime, have been accused by a Federal grand jury of conspiring to forge and cash United States savings bonds valued at $25,000.

title: MANAGEMENT UNIT SELECTED BY H.D.A.
description: Housing and Development Administrator Andrew P. Kerr yesterday announced the awarding of a twoyear con tract to Relocation Manage ment Services to replace the muchcriticized City Urban Re newal Management Company in maintaining cityowned buildings on urbanrenewal sites.

title: Dr. Blake Asserts White House Aimed At Church Leaders
description: The leaders of every Prot estant denomination in the country have been treated as enemies by the White House for the last three years, one of those leaders contended yes terday.

title: Proposed Sea Level Panama Canal Gets Little Support From Shipping Interests
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  Construction of a proposed sea level Panama Canal, recom mended by a Presidential com mission in 1970, received little support from shipping interests and the Governor of the Canal Zone in a Congressional hear ing last week.

title: RATE RISE SCORED BY THRIFT GROUPS
description: LOS ANGELES, July 22At first blush, it looked as if the Empire Savings and Loan As sociation had invited the neigh borhood in for a party. There was free coffee and cham pagne, but the crowds  occu pying every available chair in the headquarters office in sub urban Van Nuys, Calif., sat pa tiently clutching tickets and waiting for their number to be called, like so many custom ers at a delicatessen counter.

title: FAVORED LE CLE SCORES ON COAST
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 22 (AP)The favored entry of Le Cle and Pallisima finished one, two today in the $83,650 Bev erly Hills Handicap for fillies and mares at Hollywood Park. The winnings entry paid $5.80.

title: SHOWDOWN TODAY LIKELY IN DISPUTE OVER NIXON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The showdown between the Senate Watergate committee and Presi dent Nixon over the commit tee's urgent request for tape recordings made in the Presi dent's office is expected to come tomorrow.

title: Yugoslav Town Reviving a Lake That Pollution Killed
Suit Seeks to Bar New Convention Hall
description: The New York Coliseum and several individuals are filing a wideranging lawsuit in State Supreme Court today, aimed at halting further action on the $200million convention hall on Manhattan's West Side.

title: Safeguard ABM System Incurs Costs the Army Said Would Be Avoided
description: By JOHN W. FINNEY Special to The New York Times

title: Sports Today
description: Atlantic Collegiate League AllStars vs. Cape Cod League AllStars, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 1 P.M.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Raises Purse for International Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 22 Roosevelt Raceway has raised the purse of its International Trot to a record $150,000 $25,000 more than its high of last year. The race, in which Une de Mai, harness racing's leading money winner, is the first entrant, is scheduled for Aug. 25.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Hours are given in Eastern Daylight Time.

title: Cards Wise Picked As an AllStar Starter
description: CINCINNATI, July 22 (AP)  Cincinnati's manager, Sparky Anderson, announced today his starting National League pitcher in Tuesday's AllStar Game would be Rick Wise of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Despite Change, State Legislature Is Still Flawed
description: ALBANYTwo years ago, a nonpartisan group sur veyed the 50 state legislatures and decided that New York's was second only to California's, a rating that has often been bandied about by many of the state's 210 lawmakers, particularly when they are about to do such things as increase their pay and expense allowances.

title: Ballet: Sylphide First
description: We had a strange first in La Sylphide at the New York State Theater Saturday night when Michael Denard from the Paris Opra Ballet danced in the Erik Bruhn staging of the original Bour nonville ballet for the first time.

title: About the Mets:
description: The Astros equaled a National League record by going 11 games without an error until Bob Watson let a ball bounce past him in left field in Saturday night's 53 loss to the Mets. . . . It was an important play during a tworun seventh that gave the Mets a 41 lead. . . . It happened on a single through the left side by Cleon Jones, with men on second and third and one out, and although Jones was eventually thrown out at home trying to go all the way around, the original single would have produced only one run. . . . As it was, the 41 lead was enough to withstand Doug Rader's fourth homer in two games, in the bottom of the seventh, and Jerry Koosman went on to his first victory in three weeks. . . . Harry Parker got the last three outs. . . . Felix Milian, whose 13game hitting streak in May is the longest of the year for the Mets, now has a nine game streak going. . . . Only Tom Seaver and Willie Mays (and Bob Scheffing, the general manager) are going from Houston to the AllStar Game in Kansas City; the rest of the Mets were to fly to New York, but they will have to come back to St. Louis to resume play with a doubleheader Thursday night. . . . Their next Shea Stadium game will be Saturday night against Montreal.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOR SHOW The Jewish holiday of Tisha B'Av, which occurs this year on Aug. 7, is a sad one, a day of mourn ing, because it is associated with so many disasters that befell Jews about that date the destruction of the first and second temples, the ex pulsion from Spain. It has become a day for remember ing oppression.

title: U.S. PLANES BOMB NEAR PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 22 (UPI)American war planes, including B52 bombers, struck guerrilla positions on all sides of Phnom Penh today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The July 13 OpEd article by Alfred S. Julien, former president of the New York Trial Lawyers Association, on the Senate Watergate hearings, de scribing the glories of crossexamina tion, has helped me to understand courtroom practices that once puzzled me. After years of serving on juries and observing the behavior of attor neys, corporation counsels, district attorneys, etc., I now know why I have so little respect for this profession, and I am convinced that the jury system is where justice is done.

title: LATER LICENSING OF DOCTORS ASKED
description: The professional board that advises states on the licensing of physicians has proposed a radical change that would post pone licensing for independent practice until the completion of specialty training.

title: 24% in Gallup Poll Urge Ouster Of Nixon, Up From 18% in June
description: After seven weeks of public hearings on the Watergate case, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday, threequarters of the American people continue to believe that the President was involved to some extent in the case and almost half still con sider it a very serious matter.

title: OCANA CAPTURES TOUR DE FRANCE
description: PARIS, July 22 (Reuters) Luis Ocana of Spain scored a crushing victory in the Tour de France bicycle race today, winning by more than 15 min utes.

title: No Slowdown Seen To Climb in Rates
description: Shortterm interest rates have swept to record high levels in the last two weeks but there seems little immediate prospect that the long advance is at an end. In fact, there are reasons persuasive to most creditmarket ana lysts that point to substantially high er money rates and bond rates as well. Assessing the outlook un der the newly announced Phase 4 last week, duPont Walston, Inc., declared shortterm inter est rates will keep on rising until around October to a high 5075 basis points [ per centage point] above today's levels there is no respite in sight until the Fed backs off at least a little, and until the de mand for funds shows more slackening than is presently evident.

title: George F. Mitchell Dead; Leader in Tea Industry
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 GeorgeF. Mitchell, a leader in the development of the tea in dustry in the United States, died yesterday at the Washing ington Hospital Center. He was 91 years old.

title: SHOP TALK Real, Live Animals Are Used as Part of the Decor for Six Model Rooms
description: Anyone who thinks that a room housing a pair of iguanas has to be something out of Tennessee Williams all drooping palms, derelict wicker and empty tequila glassesis going to be in for a surprise on Abraham & Straus's seventh floor.

title: Ballet: Sylphide First
description: We had a strange first in La Sylphide at the New York State Theater Saturday night when Michael Denard from the Paris Opra Ballet danced in the Erik Bruhn staging of the original Bour nonville ballet for the first time.

title: Smith Assails S.E.C.'s Bid On Westgate Receivership
description: SAN DIEGO, July 22 C. Arnholt Smith has denounced as a devilish and deadly scheme the Government's at tempt to remove him from con trol of his billiondollar busi ness empire in a receivership action to be argued tomorrow in Federal District Court here.

title: Local Workshops to Study Residential Zoning Plan
description: City Planning Commission chairman John E. Zuccotti has announced a series of borough workshops to be held in Sep tember to consider the new res idential zoning proposals an nounced last week. These pro posals are intended to reform the way apartments are built in New York. The present rigid, building heightto openland ratio, re quiring towers and plazas would be changed to a more flexible system that would emphasize human and environmental elements such as privacy, safety, sun light and space, and make low er buildings possible.

title: Marijuana Laws Challenged
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa., July 22 (AP)  Attorneys here defend ing persons charged with mari juana possession say that the state laws may be invalid be cause they ban only one of the three species of marijuana. Once marijuana is smoked, they contend, there is no way to tell from which species it derives.

title: Roundup: Cards Forge Into Lead in East
Freedom Train, a Planned Bicentennial Exhibit, Is Introduced in Jersey
description: ABOARD THE AMERICAN FREEDOM TRAIN, July 22 With jets of steam hissing from massive pistons, Steam Locomotive 759 and a string of 20 passenger cars rolled smoothly out of the Erie Lackawanna Terminal in Hoboken at 8:45 A.M. today onan excursion run to intro duce the American Freedom Train, a planned bicentennial exhibition.

title: Dr. Girolamo Bonaccolto Dead; Was St.Clare's Ophthalmologist
description: Dr. Girolamo Bonaccolto, senior attending surgeon and chairman emeritus of the oph thalmology department of St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center, died there Saturday of a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived at 123 East 61 st Street.

title: 2 Youths Rob Passengers on Bus That Stopped as Motor Failed
description: Two knifewielding youths boarded a disabled bus in Har lem last night and robbed and intimidated several of its 50 passengers until they were routed by four plainclothes police officers.

title: Family Life on Edge of the Everglades
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla.A fragile breeze coursed through the mango groves, stir ring the dense Florida heat.

title: S.M.SCHWARZ, 91, ECONOMIST, DEAD
description: Solomon M. Schwarz, a writer on Soviet politics and economics, died July 15 in Jerusalem at the age of 91. The news of his death was reported here by friends.

title: Parade in Havana Marks The Revolution's 20th Year
description: HAVANA, July 22 (Canadian Press)As Premier Fidel Castro watched, the Cuban Govern ment unveiled its newest mili tary arsenal today in an armed forces parade marking the 20th anniversary of the Castro revolution.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Water Quality Hearings Slated

title: Terminal Probe
description: The Metropolitan Transit Authority's plan for an east side Long Island Rail Road terminal on Third Avenue is being tentatively questioned by the Federal Urban Mass Transit Administration. It should beand severely.

title: Rikers Inmates Swing to Rock Music
description: Every time one of the 200 young women in the auditorium tried to dance in the aisles at the rock show yesterday, she was told to sit down; once or twice an exuberant listener was pushed back down into her seat.

title: Two Interviews and Their Aftermath
description: Not long ago, Gay Talese, the bestselling author, re ceived a postcard from a nun that told him: Your wife and daughters must be proud of youyou filthy, foul lecher. You are not fit to inhabit Christian society.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Hijackers, who said they were proPales tinian guerrillas, and hostages sweltered through a second day of torrid desert heat aboard the Japan Air Lines jumbo jet on runway of the airport in the Persian Gulf sheikdom of Dubai.
