The hijackers, who seized the jet Friday over the Netherlands, have ordered the plane refueled and released wounded member of the aircraft's crew, ac cording to news agency dispatches from Dubai.[Page 1, Columns 14.]

title: OFFICIALS IDENTIFY BODY IN MIAMI CASE
description: MIAMI, July 22 (AP)The authorities today identified a decapitated body found yester day encased in concrete in a Miami house as that of Mark B. Matson, 16 years old, of Wash ington Court House, Ohio.

title: Physical Chemist Honored
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Dr. Paul J. Flory, a physical chemist who helped give the world synthetic automobile tires and clothing fabrics, has been named winner of the American Chemical Society's 1974 Priest ley Medal, the highest honor in American chemistry.

title: NIXON STILL LEANS ON 3 TO ADVISE RIM
description: WASHINGTON, July 22De spite the stresses of the Water gate scandal, the White House staff system has remained es sentially unchanged.

title: Donohue Wins 2 Heats And Glen CanAm Race
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 22Mark Donohue needed to do little more than go through the motions this afternoon to win the Glen CanAm after the virtual disintegration of what competition there was around him.

title: A Pianist With a Touch of Fats Waller
description: Jimmy Andrews, a pianist whose love affair with the music of Fats Waller shines through almost every note he plays, has started a jazz policy at Brew's, 156 East 34th Street, a rambling, colorful rabbit war ren of rooms decorated in a mixture of period styles. With Mike Burgevin on drums and a guest horn man, Mr. An drews plays at Brew's on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays (on Saturdays and Sundays he continues a long standing engagement at O'Con nor's in Watchung, N. J.).

title: Wall St. Is Again Gripped By Serious Financial Crisis
description: Slowly, relentlessly and with surprisingly little public ac knowledgment, Wall Street has slipped into another serious financial crisis that is wiping out profits in the securities in dustry and forcing investment firms out of business.

title: Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Milburn Ties Mark He Set 17 Days Ago
description: SIENA, Italy, July 22 (UPI) The Olympic gold medalist, Rod Milburn of the United States, equaled his world record of 13.1 seconds to easily win the men's 110meter hurdles event in a 10nation track meet today.

title: ExGiant Catcher Is Regent
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky., July 22 (UPI)Hugh Poland of Guth rie, Ky., a former catcher for the New York Giants, has been sworn in to his fifth term as a regent at Western Kentucky University. He is beginning his 17th year.

title: MIKHAIL ISAKOVSKY, RUSSIAN POET, DEAD
description: MOSCOW, July 22. (AP) Mikhail V. Isakovsky, whose songs and poems have passed into Russian folklore, has died at the age of 73, Tass, the gov ernment press agency, reported today.

title: 100 Pursue Gunman
description: A drunken gunman was beat en unconscious by a crowd of residents of West 134th Street yesterday morning after he shot and killed one man and wounded two of the dead man's brothers.

title: Connors and Ashe Gain U.S. Pro Tennis Final
description: LONGWOOD, Mass., July 22 (UPI)Jimmy Connors kept fifthseeded Cliff Richey on the defensive tonight as he stroked his way to a 60, 62 triumph in a 50minute semifinal match at the United States profes sional tennis championships.

title: A Small Town in Summer _ Nightly Ritual
description: SACRED HEART, Minn., July 20Carla Harried came for an ice cream cone. Val Jacobson came to show off Chuck Johnson. Palmer Elia son came to talk about crops. Paul McKenzie bought a root beer. But Debbie Reiten didn't come by at all, so Jerry Agre went to see why. Like the residents of thousands of small towns scat tered about the country, Sacred Heart's 696 peo ple have a regular summer evening hangout for socializ ing once the long day's chores are done.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A gracious reader in Hastings onHudson gently warns us against philistinism (meatandpotatoism) regarding seasonings. This calls for further discussion.

title: American League
description: Monday, July 23, 1973

title: Indian Leader Out on Bail After Fund Raising Tour
description: CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) Vernon F. Bellecourt, the na tional coordinator of the Amer ican Indian Movement, was re leased on $10,000 bond today after being arrested by F.B.I. agents when he arrived here after a twomonth fundraising European tour.

title: New Jersey Sports Courting the Girls
description: LEONIA, July 22The Leonia Sports Boosters Club, in its 11th year, now has four women's teams in addition to eight boys squads.

title: BIG NATIONS WIDEN INFLATION BATTLE
description: PARIS, July 22The United States announces new wage and price controls, Australia slashes tariffs, the West Germans tighten money with a vengeance, and the British start to do the same.

title: Census Finds Rise In Economic Gaps Between the Races
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  Black Americans remained far behind whites in most social and economic categories over a fiveyear period ending last year, and there were indica tions that the gap was widen ing in some areas, the Bu reau of the Census reported to day.

title: Coast Guard Is Attempting To increase Safety in Port
description: The Coast Guard has em ?arked on a series of steps to case ship congestion and in crease safety in the nation's ?usiest port.

title: DEROSE BLOCKING BYRNE IN ESSEX
description: TRENTON, July 22  State Senator Ralph C. De Rose of Essex County, who finished third in the Democratic Guber natorial primary, is reported to be blocking efforts to bring the important Essex Democratic or ganization in line behind Brendan T. Byrne, the party's gubernatorial candidate.

title: LAW TO BAR SPYING ON CIVILIANS URGED
description: The Committee on Civil Rights of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York rec ommended yesterday that Con gress enact legislation gener ally prohibiting all military surveillance of civilian political activities, particularly the com pilation of dossiers and data banks containing information about political and private af fairs of civilians.

title: Fittipaldi Beats Fittipaldi
description: MISANO, Italy, July 22 (UPI) Wilson Fittipaldi of Brazil won the Santa Monica Cup Formula 2 auto grand prix to day, outpacing his brother, Emerson, the world champion, who finished fourth.

title: 5 IN JERSEY FAMILY KILLED ON VACATION
description: MESILLA, N. M., July 22 (UPI)  A pickup truck, its driver apparently asleep at the wheel, slammed headon today into a station wagon carrying five members of a vacationing Clarks, N. J., family. Seven persons died and one person was injured.

title: Strong Bloc Opposed Phase 4 Profit Pinch
description: WASHINGTON, July 22A strong minority of the Govern ment officials who threshed out Phase 4 before President Nixon's final decisions argued for a program that would have imposed less pinch on business profits than the one that merged.

title: ITALY'S CUP TEAM OUSTS SPAIN, 32
description: TURIN, Italy, July 22 (AP) Italy qualified for the Davis Cup European Zone Group B tennis final against Czechoslovakia in Prague Aug. 46, by earning a 32 victory over Spain today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Results of Nearby Yacht Racing
description: EASTOFRYE Y.R.A.

title: SHOWDOWN TODAY LIKELY IN DISPUTE OVER NIXON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The showdown between the Senate Watergate committee and Presi dent Nixon over the commit tee's urgent request for tape recordings made in the Presi dent's office is expected to come tomorrow.

title: INFILTRATION REPORT GIVEN BY TRUCE AIDE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, july, 22 (AP)The leader of a Cana dian truce team said today that interrogation of six North Viet namese prisoners disclosed in filtration into Cambodia and South Vietnam as late as June.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Problems Hinder Aviary's Reopening

title: JERSEY IS PRESSED ON MIGRANT PACE
description: A Federal suit that charges that the State of New Jersey and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico have illegally con doned abuses of migrant work ers by New Jersey farmers is moving toward a resolution.

title: Sihanouk, in North Korea, Said to Reject U.S. Offers
description: TOKYO, July 22 (UPI) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of the Cambodian gov ernment in exile in Peking, said today that he would re ject any solution proposed by the United States to end the fighting in Cambodia, accord ing to a report by North Korea's Central News Agency.

title: GEORGE F. KERR
description: George F. Kerr, director of fleet leasing and special finan cing for the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, died yesterday in the Princeton (N.J.) Hospital after a heart at tack. He was 57 years old and lived at 206B Rossmoor Drive, Jamesburg, N.J.

title: Wall St. Is Again Gripped By Serious Financial Crisis
description: Slowly, relentlessly and with surprisingly little public ac knowledgment, Wall Street has slipped into another serious financial crisis that is wiping out profits in the securities in dustry and forcing investment firms out of business.

title: U.S. Offers Plan to Close India Account
description: NEW DELHI, July 22The United States has placed a com promise proposal before India that seeks to close within 15 years the vast Americanowned rupee account here.

title: Bridge: New  York, Florida Teams  Win at Summer Nationals
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 Teams from New York and Florida scored major victories in last night's play here at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. In the final of the grand na tional teams, Bill Seamon, Russ Arnold and Bob Sharp, all of Miami; Richard Pavli cek and Jim Beery of Fort Lauderdale and Jane Jaeger of North Bay Village scored a comfortable victory by 59 international match points against a St. Louis sextet headed by Jerry Levitt.

title: Lincoln Center Adds Belly Dancing to Cultural Life
description: A 23yearold assistant to the editor of Car and Driver magazine performed the ex otic art of the belly dance for 200 visitors to Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park yes terday afternoon.

title: Height Requirement For Police Officers May Be Eliminated
description: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley indicated yesterday that height requirements might he eliminated for police officers so that men no taller than jockeys could be patrolling the city's streets.

title: Residents Complain of Delays on Calls to 911 for Emergency Help
description: Since the coming of summer, an increasing number of callers to the Police Department's 911 emergency service say they must wait long periodsfrom 5 to 45 minutes on busy Satur day nightsbefore getting a re sponse.

title: OCONEE, PLATTEN UP, HORSE SHOW VICTOR
American Y.C. Fleet Cannot Find Wind And First Run Fails
description: STONINGTON, Conn., July 22 The American Yacht Club's 42d annual cruise had a poor beginning today when none of the boats finished the opening run within the time limit. The run was a 79mile overnight race from Rye, N. Y., to Sea Flower Reef here.

title: Watergate Inquiry Raises Issue of Publicity's Effect
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Has former Attorney General John N. Mitchell been deprived of his right to a fair trial on con spiracy charges because the Senate Watergate committee questioned him sharply about related political matters for two days over national television?

title: Census Finds Rise In Economic Gaps Between the Races
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 Black Americans remained far behind whites in most social and economic categories over a fiveyear period ending last year, and there were indica tions that the gap was widen ing in some areas, the Bu reau of the Census reported to day.

title: Wall St. Is Again Gripped By Serious Financial Crisis
description: Slowly, relentlessly and with surprisingly little public ac knowledgment, Wall Street has slipped into another serious financial crisis that is wiping out profits in the securities in dustry and forcing investment firms out of business.

title: VISIT BY U.S. AIDE CONCERNS TAIWAN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 22 Secretary of Commerce Fred erick B. Dent's current visit here to announce the creation of an American trade center in Taipei reflects the fastgrowing economic relationship between Taiwan and the United States. But many Chinese Nationalists are wondering what it signifies for the political relationship be tween the two countries.

title: MRS. BRADLEY GAYLORD
description: Mrs. Katharine Francis Gay lord, wife of Brig. Gen. Bradley Gaylord, U.S.A., retired, died Saturday of cancer at her home, in Palm Beach, Fla. Her age was 71.

title: Purser Freed by Hijackers, Tells How They Seized Jetliner
description: DUBAI, July 22 (UPI)  We are fitting bombs on each of the doors. If you touch one you will die. If you follow instructions you will be all right.

title: Citizens Council to Advise On State's NoFault Law
description: ALBANY, July 22 (UPI)  Benjamin R. Schenck, the State Superintendent of Insurance, announced today the appoint ment of a citizens advisory council to help implement the state's nofault autoinsurance law, which takes effect Feb. 1.

title: Stage
description: What! And Leave Bloom ingdale's? is the label for a package of four oneact plays about boyandgirl complica tions that tinkle along as pleasantly, aimlessly and transparently as ice cubes.

title: Nixon Adviser Confident Of Stability Under Phase 4
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted today that a recession was not a likely development and that the Phase 4 economic program would lead to high employment and a high level of economic activity.

title: Skylab 2's Crew Relaxes In Houston Isolation Trailer
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 22 (UPI)America's next space station crew relaxed today, do ing only lastminute reviews before attempting man's longest stay in weightlessness begin ning next Saturday.

title: Head of Crime Council
description: The new head of the city's Criminal Justice Coordinating Council is a former beat patrolman who is known as a smooth and strongwilled administrator at his city of fice, but is teased by his wife for being a pushover for children and old ladies. Robert G. Wallace, 35 years old, was appoint ed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay to replace Henry S. Ruth as head of the agency that funnels Federal crimecontrol money into the city's crimi nal justice system.

title: Indians in Maine Sue U.S. For Free Border Crossing
description: BANGOR, Me., July 22 (AP)  Eight Indians have filed a suit charging the Government with violating the Jay Treaty of 1794 by denying them free border crossing privileges be tween Canada and Maine.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Edginess Roils Stocks Abroad
description: It's been very quiet, particularly in the last three months.

title: Civil Service Heads Warn Of Unrest on Pension Cuts
description: The heads of two of the city's largest Civil Service un ions warned yesterday of de moralization and unrest if the Legislature reduced pensions for new public employes.

title: Penn Central Train Crash
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) An engineer was critically in jured and a conductor was slightly hurt early today when an otherwise empty Penn Cen tral commuter train crashed in to a downtown station.

title: RUSSELL HARDIE, 69, CHARACTER ACTOR
description: BUFFALO, July 22Russell Hardie, a featured player in many Broadway shows, as well as a performer in many televi sion plays and films, died yes terday in a nursing home in Clarence after an illness of sev eral years. His age was 69.

title: PEARSON NEARS $1MILLION MARK
description: HAMPTON, Ga., July 22 (AP)  David Pearson, continuing his domination of this year's Grand National event, drove the Wood Brothers Mercury to an easy victory today in the Dixie 500 stock car race.

title: Facility Bombed in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, July 22 (UPI) A bomb was thrown at the PeruvianAmerican Cultural In stitute early today, causing $1,?100 in damage. Police offi cials declined to speculate on who threw it or the kind of explosive device used.

title: ImmigrantsProtestinLondon
description: LONDON, July 22 (Reuters) Thousands of immigrant In dians, Pakistanis and West In dians marched through London today in a demonstration against British immigration policy. The target of the pro test was a recent court ruling that provisions of the 1971 immigration act for deportation of illegal immigrants could apply retroactively.

title: A Postage Stamp Poses Sticky Problem for U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22The United Nations finds itself with a new and troublesome problem, not much larger than a thumb nail.

title: Ulbricht, 80. Still in Coma Three Days After Stroke
description: BERLIN, July 22  Walter Ulbricht, the veteran East Ger man Chief of State who suf fered a stroke on Thursday, apparently continued to be in a coma tonight.

title: Pope Praises Missionaries In Allusion to Mozambique
description: CASTLE GANDOLFO, Italy, July 22Pope Paul VI expressed support today for the cause of missionaries who condemned misdeeds perpetrated against defenless populations.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Diane Scharf
description: WESTON, Conn., July 22 The marriage of Miss Diane Scharf to Herman Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis S. Kaufman of South Orange, N. J., took place here this afternoon. Robert M. Anstett, Judge of Probate in Westport, performed the garden cere mony at the home of Mrs. Leonora Scharf, mother of the bride.

title: Advertising: Continental Testing
description: Remember the old ballad that went What a difference a day makes, 24 little hours? Well, that could easily be the theme for the advertising department of Continental Airlines in Los Angeles.

title: Le Boom
description: PARISIt is surely one of the best kept secrets of the postwar years that the most dynamic economy in Europe, indeed the second most dynamic econ omy in the developed world after Japan, is not West Germany but France.

title: Marchi, Back From Trip, Supports Pension Reform
description: State Senator John J. Marchi of Staten Island returned from a trip to Israel and Italy) yesterday, called for pension, reform and said he backed Governor Rockefeller's trans portation bond bill.

title: Agnew Doubts Value Of Nixon's Aid in 76
description: Vice President Agnew be lieves President Nixon's backing would not mean a great deal for any Presi dential bid Mr. Agnew might make in 1976, according to Stewart Alsop, the columnist.

title: Red Smith Lewis and Clark Never Had It So Good
description: Rod Kvamme steered the helicopter past the sheer rock face of Mount Si, sailed over Hancock Lake and eased down toward Lake Moolock, which lies in a cleft in Wash ington's Cascade Range almost 3,000 feet high. Hovering like a big, noisy dragonfly, the eggbeater settled slowly until the plastic tub slung under its belly was about 15 feet from the lake's surface. Then a trap door opened and water poured from the tub, carrying with it some 4,000 rainbow trout fry the size of fat bobbypins. The chopper climbed on a steep slant and turned back to the Torkil Creek Hatchery for more fish to plant in other lakes. As the white caps created by the downdraft subsided, the new tenants must have headed directly for the shallows, for inside an hour a trout about a foot long was seen in rapacious pursuit of minnows near the shore.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JULY 23, 1973

title: FRENCH ATESTS BRING PROTESTS BY FIVE NATIONS
description: An international protest arose yesterday over the start by France of another series of nuclear tests in the South Pa cific.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: Monopoly of Oil
description: Unless it becomes diverted along the way, the Federal Government has embarked on a thorny new inquiry in the centuryold search for proper relationships between capitalist profits, state and society. No less than this is inherent in the formal complaint filed last week by the Federal Trade Commission against the nation's eight largest oil companies for alleged conspiratorial practices over the last 23 years.

title: DELAYS ARE CITED ON CALLS TO 911
description: Since the coming of summer, an increasing number of callers to the Police Department's 911 emergency service say they must wait long periodsfrom 5 to 45 minutes on busy Satur day nights before getting a response.

title: Drive on Guns for Felons
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP)  A racket in which persons profit by buying guns for con victed felons is the target of a drive begun here by the United States Attorney's office.

title: Whitehead Might Resign By Year's End, Office Says
description: Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy, may leave his post by the end of the year or shortly thereafter, his office said yesterday, confirm ing reports recently published in the broadcasting trade.

title: Dior Was the One With a Bit of Razzle Dazzle
description: PARIS, July 23 Courrges gave up his wild music and dancing girls, Cardin gave up his space clothes. It was all in the interest of real clothes for real women, to show that the couture has a place in the world's work.

title: 4 Foundation Officials Die In West Virginia Air Crash
description: ONA, W. Va., July 23 (UPI) A small airplane carrying four officials of the Chicago based Better Boys Foundation crashed in a field near here this weekend, killing all four.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 23 (UPI)Dazy II was the apparent overall winner today in the 49th Port HurontoMackinac Island yacht race. But a protest could change the outcome. Dazy II completed the 298mile run with a corrected time of 38 hours 31 minutes 7 seconds. Scaramouche was next in the Class A field with a corrected time of 38:38:02.

title: FOODPRICE RISES ARE SHARP HERE; MORE PREDICTED
description: The beginning of what has been? widely predicted as a bulge or peak in food prices following the lifting of the Government's freeze became evident yesterday, as price in creasessome of them extraor dinary  went into effect at the wholesale and retail levels.

title: Intruder in Police Station Shoots 2 Officers, Is Slain
description: An apparently deranged young man with two fire bombs and a revolver in a brown paper bag walked into the 19th Pre cinct police station on East 67th Street last night and shot a sergeant and a lieutenant be fore being killed in a fusillade ol police bullets.

title: LARCHMONT CREW LEADS JUNIOR SAIL
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 23 The Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club crew took the lead today in the qualifying series of the 50th annual junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound. Three races were sailed in light southeast wind off In dian Harbor Y.C.

title: People in Sports: Aaron's Future Mrs. Misses 700th
description: Billye,Williams, the fiancee of Henry Aaron, conducts an early morning television show in Atlanta. Naturally she has to be punctual.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: For Bill Inge
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass.I met Bill for the first time in 1948, and talked to him for the last time the night he killed himself; our friendship over the quartercentury between was light, but it spanned his years from the bad to the good to the bad.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures Climb in Active Trading
Issue and Debate Public Employes Pension Plans on the Legislature's Agenda
description: When the special session of the State Legislature con venes in Albany tomorrow, the 210 Senators and Assem blymen will once again face a question they could not solve earlier this year: the re form of the pension system for state, county and munici pal employes.

title: MRS. WALTER B. EATON
description: Mrs. Margaret Burton Eaton, widow of Walter B. Eaton, stockbroker and industrialist, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hos pital. She was 74 years old and lived at 110 East 57th Street and in Warrenton, Va.

title: SENATE PASSES BILL TO BAR CREDIT BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) The Senate, without a dis senting vote, approved today a bill to prohibit discrimination in access to credit on the basis of sex or marital status.

title: Exiled Constantine Bids Greeks Vote No on Abolition of Monarchy
description: ROME, July 23Constantine, the deposed Greek King, issued a statement today calling on the Greek people to vote no in the referendum, scheduled for Sunday, on the abolition of the monarchy.

title: Junior Mets Triumph, 94
description: Led by Lee Manzelli, the Junior Mets defeated the Junior Yankees, 94, yesterday in the annual Greater New York Alli ance sandlot allstar game at the Yankee Stadium. Manzelli hit a home run, a double and and a single and won the Lou Gehrig most valuable play er award.

title: Monsoon Is Season of Death in the Slums of Calcutta
description: CALCUTTA, India, July 22 This is the season of death in Calcutta.

title: President Based Decision On Two Legal Doctrines
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  President Nixon based his re fusal today to furnish the White House tapes to the Sen ate Watergate committee on the intertwined legal doctrines of separation of powers and ex ecutive privilege.

title: Salesmanship by South Carolina Wins Foreign and U.S. Investors
description: COLUMBIA, S. C.J. Bonner Manly answered the telephone, then cupped his hand over the transmitter and asked a visitor in his office if he would like to eaves drop. The visitor nodded.

title: NabiscoAssociated Link Is Approved by Directors
description: The merger of Nabisco, Inc., and Associated Products, Inc., has been approved by the di rectors of both companies, it was announced yesterday. The transaction will become effec tive by Oct. 1. Associated Products will continue to oper ate separately under its present management.

title: Bonn Acts to Stem Currency Inflows; Mark Rise Slowed
description: PARIS, July 23  The West German Government acted to day to discourage the flow of money into the country. The effect was to check the ad vance of the mark, which gain ed against other European cur rencies. The dollar closed slightly weaker in relatively quiet trading.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Boy, 16, Is Slain for $1 While on Park Pool Job
description: A 16yearold boy who got his first job two weeks ago as a Parks Department sum mer worker was robbed of $1 and stabbed to death yester day morning in the main tenance building of a Lower East Side park swimming pool.

title: CONNORS WINNER IN U.S. PRO TENNIS
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., July 23 (UPI)  Unseeded Jimmy Con nors defeated Arthur Ashe, 63, 46, 64, 36, 62, tonight to win the $12,000 first prize at the 46th United States professional tennis championships at the Longwood Cricket Club.

title: Northeast Counties Gain 23,300 Jobs, While Employment Declines in the City
description: New York City has lost more than 28,000 jobs while its suburbs in New York State Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Countiesgained more than 24,000 and the eight counties of northeastern New Jersey gained 23,300.

title: Notes on People Greeting for Ulbricht
description: Walter Ulbricht, the 80 yearold former leader of the East German Communist party, who suffered a stroke last week, was well enough yesterday to receive a visitor Erich Honecker, who suc ceeded him as party leader. Mr. Honecker visited Mr. Ulbricht at the former lead er's country home near Berlin. ADN, the East Ger man news service, said Mr. Honecker brought Mr. Ul bricht the greetings of the party's highest officials. The news agency said Mr. Ulbricht was still seriously ill, but gave no other details.

title: H.U.D. MUST FREE 3 HOUSING PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  A United States District Court judge here today ordered re sumption of three Federal sub sidized housing programs, which he said had been illegal ly suspended last January.

title: Junior Lift Mark Bettered
description: MOSCOW, July 23 (Reuters) Mikhail Maksakov of the Soviet Union set a world junior lightheavyweight weightlifting record today when he snatched 314.16 pounds at the Moscow regional championships.

title: Urban League Research Director Scores Miscount of 1.8 Million Blacks in 1970 Census
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Statistics took center stage at the National Urban League con vention today and all were a matter of dispute.

title: Intruder in Police Station Shoots 2 Officers, Is Slain
description: A young man with two fire bombs and a revolver in a brown paper bag walked into the 19th Precinct police station on East 67th Street last night and shot a sergeant and a lieutenant before being killed in a fusillade of police bullets.

title: UNION AND CITY U. REACH AN ACCORD
description: Contract negotiators for the City University and its faculty staff union have reached a tentative agreement on a three year contract to cover the uni versity's 16,000 faculty and staff members, the union an nounced yesterday.

title: CARLOS GRIFFIN
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 23 (AP)Carlos Griffin, longtime parttime correspondent for The New York Times in Chile has died in an automobile ac cident in Mendoza, Argentina according to word received here.

title: Saigon Delivers First of Civilian Prisoners to Vietcong
description: BIEN HOA, South Vietnam, July 23  The prisoners came in the early morning, crowded into the backs of more than score of army trucks: feeble men, defiant men, proud wo men, defeated women, young girls, mothers clutching babies.

title: DPF Cites S.E.C. Violations In Moseley and Hanly Suit
description: DPF, Inc., a computer leasing company, has filed suit against two New York Stock Exchange firmsEdwards & Hanly, Inc., and F. S. Moseley Estabrook, Inc.and three individuals for alleged violations of the Se curities Exchange Act of 1934.

title: Killebrew Has Surgery
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 23 (AP) Harmon Killebrew, of the Minnesota Twins, underwent surgery today for removal of torn cartilage in his left knee at St. Mary's Hospital. Offi cials termed the operation a success and said Killebrew could be ready to play in six weeks.

title: Central Park Heavy With Manpower As Police Strive to Cope With Crimes
description: All the permanent resi dents of the 22d Precinct are behind bars. So, for the po lice, life there should be a piece of cake. It is not. The 22d is Central Park and the only permanent residents are the lions and monkeys in the Central Park Zoo, The transients give the police plenty of headaches.

title: VOICE PRINT TRIAL ENDS IN ACQUITTAL
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 23 The voice print is not yet a reliable means of identifica tion for scientists, let alone the courts, a Superior Court judge said today in acquitting a tele phone installer of a bomb threat charge.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Landing Bluefin Tuna
description: BRUDENELL, Prince Ed ward IslandThere are times, when fishing for bluefin tuna, that the angler vacil lates between wishing a fish would hit and wishing he would not, for no other game fish poses a comparable physical and emotional chal lenge.

title: INCREASE GRANTED IN CLOTHING COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The Cost of Living Council has granted to clothing and textile manufacturers a partial exemp tion from the price freeze, a council spokesman reported to day.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Limit Retirement Tax Aid to Professional Corporations
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Senate Finance Committee voted today to change a law under which doctors, lawyers and other professionals have been able to save thousands of dollars of Federal income taxes each year by incorporating and taking large taxfree deduc tions for their own retirement plans.

title: Reserve Aide Says Steep Rises Have Some Way to Go
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested today that the recent steep rise in shortterm interest rates and the lesser increase in longterm rates might still have some way to go. He also said some borrowers would find it increasingly difficult to obtain credit.

title: Dave Anderson The Other Met Who Got Away
description: The scar inside Amos Otis has disappeared now. But the memory remains of when the New York Mets used him at third base, I only played three games there, he says. I got a hit in each game. I only made one error. But I was called a failure. He remembers reading that word failure during the 1969 season when he hit .151 as a rookie and the Mets went on to win the World Series without him, He's not a failure now. With his nohit games, Nolan Ryan of the California Angels has embar rassed the Nets twice this season. But al rassed the Nets twice this season. But al most as nonchalantly as he makes his one handed catches, Amos Otis of the Kansas City Royals has been embarrassing the Mets every day for almost four seasons. In the AllStar Game tonight, he will he the Amer ican League's center fielder. His general manager, Cedric Tallis, calls him perhaps the most complete ballplayer the major leagues right now. He has the legs, the arm, the power, the consistency of contact, and the glove, Yester day, the American League manager, Dick Williams, chose the 26.yearold Royal as his center fielder over Bobby Murcer of the New York Yankees, also a center fielder. Not that Otis cared that much about. preserving his posi lion for the Kansas City clientele.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Sitin Continues at Flatbush School

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Cougar, Shoemaker Up, Scores
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 23 (AP)Cougar II, with Bill Shoemaker back in the saddle, wound up his Hollywood Park career today by winning the $136,350 Sunset Handicap, going the 1 miles on grass in 2:26.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)The Treasury Depart ment said today it had determined that elemental sulphur from Canada was being sold at less than fair value in the United States in violation of United States antidump ing laws.

title: Music: Dafne Premiere
description: It took 365 years for Marco da Gagliana's La Dafne to get to America, and even so it arrived a day late. Although the mem bers of the New York Pro Musica Antigua were in Katonah, N. Y., on time for the planned premiere last Friday, their sets and scores were still en route from Corfu, forcing the first con cert cancellation in the 28 season history of the Cara moor Festival. The first performance was on Satur day, with another newly scheduled for Sunday night.

title: Ford Grants $1.5Million To Coast Public TV Station
description: The Ford Foundation yester day made a grant of $1.5mil lion to station KCET in Los Angeles for production of pro grams to be shown on the sta tions of the Public Broadcast ing Service.

title: SCHUTZ WILL ADD TO ITS FACILITIES
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company announced in Mil waukee yesterday that it would spend $300million in the next five years to expand and mod ernize its beer production. A new plant in Albany, and ad ditions to plants in five other cities are part of the plan, the company said.

title: Balloonist's Flight Put Off
description: TRENTON, Me., July 23 (AP) Bob Sparks, a balloonist, says his planned transAtlantic flight has been deferred until next Tuesday at the earliest. Unfavorable weekend weather forced Mr. Sparks to postpone his waftoff twice within 12 hours.

title: Excerpts From Testimony of Strachan Before the Senate Watergate Committee
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Following are excerpts front the transcript of testimony by Gordon C. Strachan today on the 26th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee MI Presidential Campaign Ac tivities:

title: Festive Crowd Gathers Amid Prosperity
description: KANSAS CITY, July 23 An atmosphere of festive good fellowship, undiluted by any ongoing major contro versy or serious behindthe scenes business maneuvers, surrounded the baseball com munity's annual convention for the AllStar baseball game today.

title: Mullaney of Colonels Reported StarGazing
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 23 (AP)Joe Mullaney, coach of the Kentucky Colonels has accepted a similar position with the Utah Stars, The As sociated Press learned. to night. Both teams are in the American Basketball Associa tion.

title: U.S. and North Vietnam Suspend Talks on Aid
description: PARIS, July 23 (UPI)The United States and North Viet nam announced today that their latest round of talks on aid had produced no final results and that the talks were being suspended tempo rarily.

title: 21 Food Outlets Are Charged With Violations
description: The City Health Department yesterday released the names of 21 restaurants and food stores that have violated the health code.

LARCHMONT CREW LEADS JUNIOR SAIL
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 23 The Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club crew took the lead today in the qualifying series of the 50th annual junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound. Three races were sailed in light southeast wind off In dian Harbor Y.C.

title: Governor Proposes Flexibility in Ceiling On Mortgage Rates
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day proposed giving the State Banking Board the power to set home mortgage loan rates at whatever ceiling it judges necessary for changing market conditions.

title: Ballet: Hoffmann Back
description: It has taken some time for American Ballet Theater to get its new threeact pro duction Tales of Hoffman absolutely fit for public scru tiny. At its first performance, about 10 days ago, it looked underrehearsed, underlit and in a very essential way, underidentified.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Superior Court Judge Gordon H. Brown ordered off duty policemen and firemen pickets in Paterson to stay 100 feet away from any government construction site. The pickets, according to a complaint by Mayor Thomas C. Rooney Jr., were harassing delivery trucks to con struction sites in Paterson for an office building, parking garage and senior citizens apartment house.

title: Shah of Iran Arrives For Washington Visit
description: HAMPTON, Va., July 23 (Reuters)Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and Empress Farah of Iran arrived from London tonight at Langley Air Force Base for an official visit to Washington.

title: Strachan Sure Haldeman Wanted Files Destroyed
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Gordon C. Strachan, a former aide to H. R. Haldeman, testi fied today that three days after the Watergate breakin, under what he believed to be orders from Mr. Haldeman, he de stroyed documents indicating that Mr. Haldeman knew that G. Gordon Liddy was conduct ing a political intelligence op eration with a sizable budget,

title: The French Colossus
description: PARISViewing France whole, re porting France soberly is no easy task for AngloSaxons, as de Gaulle use fully, if inaccurately, dubbed the Americans and Englishmen he believed leagued against him. Americans re sented his abrupt withdrawal from NATO, his sabotage of the Kennedy Grand Design for Atlantic union. The British smarted at his vetoes of their entry into the Common Market. But the surprising truth is that de Gaulle saw himself very much on the defensive.

title: Prison Hostages Released
description: EDDYVILLE, Ky., July 23, (UPI)Five inmates at the maximum security state prison here held three employes hos tage for about an hour yester day after overpowering them in the prison canteen. The prison authorities used tear gas to secure the release of the three from the knifewielding prisoners.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Grand Slam Highlights Collegiate Game
Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker Is Dead at 82
description: Eddie Rickenbacker, a lead ing fighter ace in World War I and retired chairman of East ern Air Lines, died early yes terday in a Zurich hospital.

title: SHOP TALK Summer Doesn't Scare Them
description: It seems as though there are always new shops open ing in New York, even in the doldrums of summer when Sale and Closed on Saturday notices are out all over town.

title: 116 Reported Dead In Two Air Crashes
description: A Pan American jet bound from Tahiti to California with 69 passengers and 10 crewmen crashed in the Pacific just after takeoff yesterday. There was only one known survivor.

title: Iranian Bus Plunge Kills 47
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 28 (AP) A bus plunged off a bridge into a river in northeast Iran yesterday and the driver and 47 other passengers, including 22 children, were killed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Symington Doubts Validity of Raid Fund
description: WASHINGTON, July 23Sen ator Stuart Symington, acting chairman of the Armed Services Committee, declared today that $145  million appropriated by Congress to pay for the secret B52 bombing of Cambodia may have been obtained under false pretenses.

title: Assistant District Attorney Reinstated With Back Pay
description: William G. Schrager, the sus pended Queens assistant dis trict attorney wrongly accused of sexual assaults on six women, was reinstated to his former post yesterday, with full back pay.

title: Fernandez Beats Santiago In Featherweight Bout
description: Vilomar Fernandez of the Dominican Republic kept Eduardo Santiago of Puerto Rico at bay with an accurate left jab and landed solid left hooks and scored a unanimous 10round decision in a feather weight bout last. night at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: Number Employed in the State Rises Along With Joblessness
description: ALBANY, July 24Louis L. Levine, State Industrial Com missioner, has announced that a total of 7,936 million people were employed In New York State in June, an increase of 85,000 over the total for May and 15,000 over the total for June, 1972.

title: 3 Officials Guilty Of Using Workers On Private Project
description: MOUNT HOLLY, July 23 (UPI)A Burlington County jury convicted three Delaware River Port Authority officials today of conspiracy to use em ployes and materials of the authority to build an addition to one of their homes.

title: Jersey Lifeguards Hold Competition in Skills Necessary to Their Work
description: ISLAND BEACH STATE PARK, N. J., July 23Bronzed and brawny young men, urged on by bikiniclad cheerleaders, displayed their mastery of the surf and tide here this after noon as 13 lifeguard teams competed in a program of boat ing and swimming events for medals, scrolls and applause.

title: SPECIAL TEAM WINS 2YEAROLD STAKES
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, III., July 23 (UPI)Fred W. Hoop er's Special Team took com mand in the stretch today and gave the 25 favorite, Thirty One Jewels, her first loss in seven races in the $106,790 ArlingtonWashington Lassie at Arlington Park.

title: Florida Legislator Enters Bill to Aid Press Freedom
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 23 (UPI)A bill to repeal the law forcing newspapers to publish replies of politicians who are criticized in editorials was en tered today in the Florida Legislature.

title: RADICALS IN JAPAN TIED TO HIJACKING
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, July 24 The police here suspect that the Japanese member of a group that hijacked a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet is associ ated with a radical student or ganization at Kyoto Univer sity that has been linked with the massacre at Tel Aviv air port last year.

title: Strachan Sure Haldeman Wanted Files Destroyed
description: Mr. Strachan, who was Mr. Haldeman's political assistant

title: Boy, 16, Is Slain for $1 While on Park Pool Job
description: A 16yearold boy who got his first job two weeks ago as a Parks Department sum mer worker was robbed of $1 and stabbed to death yester day morning in the main tenance building of a Lower East Side park swimming pool.

title: Equity Financing
description: Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Com mission a rights offering of 6,200,000 common shares on a basis of one share for every seven shares held of record Aug. 20. The company's stock closed at 14, up  on the American Stock Ex change.

title: Chess: NeverWases and AlsoRans Have Their Loyal Claques
Aqueduct Is Closed By a Strike Today
description: A strike was called last night by the International Union of Operating Engineers, forcing suspension of racing today at Aqueduct race track.

title: 110 Reported Dead In Two Air Crashes
description: A Pan American jet bound from Tahiti to California with 69 passengers and 10 crewmen crashed in the Pacific just after takeoff yesterday. There was only one known survivor.

title: AMEX PRICES UP FOR 6TH SESSION
description: The American Stock Ex change registered yesterday its sixth straight advance as prices climbed to their highest level in more than two months.

title: President Based Decision On Two Legal Doctrines
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  President Nixon based his re fusal today to furnish the White House tapes to the Sen ate Watergate committee on the intertwined legal doctrines of separation of powers and ex ecutive privilege.

title: 7 Florida State Senators Said to Be Bugging Targets
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 23 (UPI)  The president of the Florida Senate said today that his office and the offices of six other state senators had been the targets of illegal bugg ing attempts during a recent legislative session.

title: France Joins in Treaty to Ban Nuclear Arms in Latin America
description: PARIS, July 23  The French Foreign ministry said today that France signed an interna tional agreement last week to ban the use of nuclear arms anywhere in Latin America or the Caribbean.

title: GOVERNOR BACKS AWARD TO PEROT
description: ALBANY, July 23  Gov ernor Rockefeller has asked Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal to substantiate charg es of profiteering and highly questionable practices that the Congressman made against a computer concern headed by H. Ross Perot, the Texas million aire. Mr. Perot met earlier this year with the Governor after his bid for a computer con tract with the state was re jected.

title: LOWER LOSS CITED BY UNIT OF PENNSY
description: The Penn Central Transporta tion Company yesterday re ported a lower operating loss for June of $9.1million against a loss of $13.5 in June 1972 but also reported a $100million loss for the first half.

title: The Man Who Said No for Nixon Charles Alan Wright
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Charles Alan Wright, the White House lawyer who said no today to the Wa tergate prosecutor's request for tapes of President Nixon's office conversations, is a selfstyled conservative law professor from the University of Texas. His prodigious out put and his spar kling intellect have, however, made him a uni versally respected figure in the American bar and a special favorite of liberals, Nicholas Johnson, a boatrocking Democrat on the Federal Communications Commission, recalled his old teacher to day as perhaps the most brilliant mind I've ever en countered  a man who could cite cases and fine points of legal opinion with out ever taking a note to class and who wrote a path breaking casebook on reme dies in three weeks, work that would have taken any body else three years.

title: Junior Lift Mark Bettered
description: MOSCOW, July 23 (Reuters) Mikhail Maksakov of the Soviet Union set a world junior lightheavyweight weightlifting record today when he snatched 314.16 pounds at the Moscow regional championships.

title: REPORTER EXPELLED BY SAIGON LEAVES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23A correspondent for The Los Angeles Times was expelled from South Vietnam today.

title: Afternoon Races to Begin At Westbury Next Month
description: Afternoon harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I., will be con ducted on the four Satur days in August that the thor oughbreds will be campaign ing at Saratoga. Permission for the activity was given yesterday by Bertram Sara fan, the interim chairman of the State Racing and Wager ing Board. It will mark the first after noon racing of any type in downstate New York while the annual 24 day Saratoga meeting is on. Racing at the Spa this year will start on Monday, strike permitting, and will run through Aug. 25.

title: Bomb Explodes in Times Sq. Bar That Features Topless Dancers
description: A bomb exploded early yes terday morning in a Times Square cafe that features top less dancers. It was the latest of a series of suspicious mis haps that have plagued estab lishments of the Times Square area over the last two years.

title: PRESIDENT REFUSES TO RELEASE TAPES; SENATE UNIT AND COX SERVE SUBPOENAS; WHITE HOUSE EXPECTED TO IGNORE THEM
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 President Nixon refused today to release tape recordings of his conversation about the Water gate case. Both his special pro secutor and the Senate Water gate committee moved at Once to subpoena the tapes.

title: Aqueduct Shut Today
description: There will be no racing at Aqueduct today because of a strike called last night by Local 15B of the International Union of Operating Engineers, Details, Page 23,

title: U.S. TRACK SQUADS TRAILING AT MINSK
Radio
description: 8:0510 A.M., WNCN: Concerto Comique No. 17 for Strings, Cor rette; Questi vaghi concenti, Monteverdi; Concerto in B flat for Strings, Vivaldi; Symphony No. 28 in A, Haydn; Alexander Nevsky, Prokofiev; Robert Browning Overture, Ives.

title: The Walls With Ears
description: It is very contemporary, very American, the tape salesman had said, You will never regret it.

title: The Persian Market
description: The partnership between the United States and Iran, symbolized by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's visit to Washington this week, offers many obvious advantages to this country; but Americans should also be aware of the dangers inherent in this expanding involvement.

title: Buenos Aires: Accent on Nationalism
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 23  The followers of former dic tator Juan Domingo Pern have returned to power in Argentina after 18 years of carrying cultural baggage that already has made a heavy impact on the theatri cal, musical and literary landscape of this capital.

title: BUG FOUND IN '69 AT GRACIE MANSION
description: Security guards discovered a secret eavesdropping device in Grade Mansion in 1969, officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Tanaka to Urge U.S.JapanEurope Link in Nixon Talk
description: TOKYO, July 23Premier Kakuei Tanaka said today that he hoped to advance a new triangular relationship be tween Japan, the United States and Wesern Europe in his dis cussions with President Nixon in Washington next week.

title: CONGRESS IS WARY ON NIXON DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Members of Congress reacted cautiously today to President Nixon's refusal to supply tape recordings of his personal con versations to Watergate inves tigators.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: ON THE HEIGHTS That splendid assortment of mu seums and institutions clus tered in the enclave known as Audubon Terrace, on Broadway between 155th and 156th Streets, in the foothills of Washington Heights, has several current attractions that call for a trip.

title: Oklahoma Crude Gains Honors at Moscow Fete
description: MOSCOW, July 23 (AP)  The American movie Okla homa Crude by Stanley Kramer shared first place for feature films today with So viet and Bulgarian entries at the eighth Moscow Interna tional Film Festival.

title: The Texts of Letters and Statements Pertaining to the President's Refusal to Release Electronic Tapes
description: WASHINGTON July 23 Following are the texts of a letter from the special Water gate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, to J. Fred Buzhardl, Presidential counsel dealing with Watergate; a letter from the President to Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Select Committee; a letter from Charles Alan Wright. a special White House consultant, to Mr. Cox: statement by Mr. Cox, and remarks of Senators Ervin and Howard H. Balzer Jr. fol lowing the President's refusal to make the tapes available:

title: Thailand to Prosecute Captured Heroin King
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 23 (Reuters)A police offi cial said last night that the Thai Government would press charges of trafficking in drugs against Lo Hsing Han, the socalled heroin king of the Golden Triangle, though no other country has offered evidence against him.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: RUTHERFORD, July 23It's a different type of soft ball league. One of the pitcher's names is Agnes. Sharon Wideman follows her mother in the batting order and husbands must patiently watch in the stands and tell their children, We have to wait until mommy gets finished before we go.

title: Lifeguards Compete in Skills Needed for Their Jobs
description: ISLAND BEACH STATE PARK, July 23  Bronzed and brawny young men, urged on by bikiniclad cheerleaders, displayed their mastery of the surf and tide here this after noon as 13 lifeguard teams competed in a program of boat ing and swimming events for medals, scrolls and applause.

title: Stacks Advance Again On Earnings Strength
The Transit Tunnel
description: The great virtue in Governor Rockefeller's $3.5billion bond plan for mass transit, up a full $1 billion from the previous transportation bond issue rejected in 1971 by the voters, lies outside the borrowing scheme altogether. Mr. Rockefeller has linked his bond proposal this time with a commitment for direct state operating subsidies for the fiscally underfueled mass transit systems, in cities and suburbs across the state. These operating subsidies are a belated recognition that farebox revenues alone can no longer assure acceptable levels of service.

title: Deal Avoids a West gate Receivership
description: SAN DIEGO, July 23  A compromise worked out by the Securities and Exchange Com mission and C. Arnholt Smith's Westgate  California Corpora tion today averted, at least temporarily a receivership for the $190million corporation.

title: FOODPRICE RISES ARE SHARP HERE; MORE PREDICTED
KERN ASKS DELAY IN PATH FARE RISE
description: TRENTON, July 23  As sembly Speaker Thomas H. Kean, Republican of Essex, asked the Interstate Com merce Commission today to de lay the proposed fare increase on the PATH commuter line until the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey filed an environmentalimpact state ment in connection with the move.

title: Advertising: Being a P.R. Man
description: Just who are communica tions experts, anyway?

title: Governor Proposes Flexibility in Ceiling On Mortgage Rates
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day proposed giving the State Banking Board the power to set, home mortgage loan rates at, whatever ceiling it judges necessary for changing market, conditions.

title: U.S. Aide Denies Early Data on Grain Deal
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  A top official of the Depart ment of Agriculture denied un der oath today any recollec tion of advance information on the big Soviet grain deal that three officers of the Contin ental Grain Company have tes tified he received last July.

title: Aquarium Is Awaiting A Whale of a Delivery
description: Frances, a white whale at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island, will he going into seclusion next week to await the birth of her second offspring, with aquarium offi cials hoping this one will survive.

title: President vs. Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  President Nixon's refusal today to release the secret tapes of his conversations with central figures in the Watergate con spiracy signaled a determina tion by the President to run the legal and political risks that Watergate poses to his long career. It pitted the President against Congress in a test of their separate powers and was grave enough to move Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Tennessee Republican, to declare that the nation was on the brink of constitutional confrontation. It posed a peril to Mr. Nixon's leadership of the country basic enough to prompt Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. of North Carolina, the Dem ocratic chairman of the Senate Watergate Committee, to assert that Watergate was a greater tragedy than the Civil War.

title: Treasury Bills Rise In the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Yields on United States Treasury bill rose to records in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Redskins Allen Begins Quest for an Edge Early
description: Chuck Fairbanks, coach of the New England Patriots, accepted the invitation while Chuck Noll of the Pittsburgh Steelers passed it by. Each had his reason. The invitation from George Allen was to bring the team to Carlisle, Pa., last Saturday and scrim mage the Washington Red skins, with every thing recorded for posterity on film. The Patriots flew down from Hart ford, Conn., the nearest airport to their train ing camp at Amherst, Mass., at a cost of $11,000 for the charter flight, and sent 75 players against the stronger, better organized and more experienced Redskins. It was one of those multiple scrim mages spread over two fields, with seven against seven in passing drills and seven on seven trying rushing plays as a crowd of 9,000 watched.

title: Du Pont Merger Backed
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) A Securities and Exchange Commission staff attorney urged the S.E.C. today to approve the proposed merger of E. I. duPont de Nemours Co. and the Christiana Securities Com pany while questioning wheth er the companies financial advisers were sufficiently inde pendent.

title: City Loses Over 28,000 Jobs in June While Employment Climbs in Suburbs
description: New York City has lost more than 28,000 jobs while its suburbs in New York State Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Countiesgained more than 24,000 and the eight counties of northeastern New Jersey gained 23,300.

title: Television
description: SENATE WATERGATE HEARINGS

title: People and Business Chairman Quits Kentucky Fried
description: John Y. Brown Jr. resigned yesterday as chairman of the Kentucky Fried Chicken Cor poration, which has annual sales of more than $700mil lion.

title: British Judge Asks Arrest Of Husband of Call Girl
description: LONDON, July 23 (UPI)A British judge issued an arrest warrant today for the 26year old husband of Norma Levy, the call girl linked to Lord Lambton, a Defense under sec retary who resigned last month.

title: Several Banks Offer 10% on Deposits for 3 Months
J. Gilpin Bright, 54, Dies, ExPilot in Flying Tigers
description: J. Gilpin Bright, a former Flying Tiger and a World War II ace who shot down 12 Japanese, German and Italian planes, died Sunday in the Vet erans Administration Hospital the Bronx, after an illness of several months. He was 54 years old and lived at 232 East 83d Street and in Spring House, Pa.

title: $33Million Contract to Q.E.
description: The General Electric Company has received $33.9million in Pentagon contracts, including a $20.3million addition to an Army award for helicopter gas turbine engines. There was also a $9.7million addition to an Air Force contract for F5E engines and parts kits and a $3.9mil lion Navy award for engineer ing services for submarine launched ballistic missiles.

title: Stolen Jet Reported Blown Up,141 Safe
description: CAIRO, Tuesday, July 24 A hijacked Japanese airliner was blown up at Benghazi air port, Libya, this morning, the Middle East News Agency re ported here.

title: Munitions Stored In Haiti's Palace Blown Up by Fire
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, July 23 (UPI)A fire roared through Haiti's presidential palace early today and blew up an ammuni tion dump in the basement, and President JeanClaude Duvalier fled to his summer residence.

title: Books of The Times Their Protestant Highnesses
description: WILLIAM AND MARY. By Henri and Barbara Van Der Zee. 526 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $12.50.

title: JOHNSON PROFIT UP IN 2D QUARTER
description: Johnson & Johnson, world wide manufacturer of medical, consumer and industrial prod ucts, reported yesterday that net income for the second quarter this year reached $36.2 million, cr 65 cents a share, compared with $31.3million, or 56 cents, a year earlier.

title: Letter Sent to S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The American Stock Exchange has told the Securities and Ex change Commission that its very existence as an equity market is threatened by the New York Stock Exchange's proposal to start trading in stock warrants.

title: The Big Lie Requires Big Liars
description: The proper word for the Cambodian bombing story is not dissembling or deceiving or protective reaction or cover story. The proper word is lying. And this long chronicle of lies, per haps more graphically than the Pen tagon Papers, shows the extent to which lying is a respected option at the top levels of the socalled national security establishment, in cluding the White House.

title: Indians in Pakistan for Talks
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 23 A 24member negoliating team arrived in Islamabad to day to represent India in talks with Pakistan. The talks, which open tomorrow, are in tended to resolve problems re sulting from the 1971 war be tween the two countries, in cluding the issue of more than 90,000 Pakistani prisoners of war held by India.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
Multinational Companies Facing a Tax Challenge
description: PARIS, July 23  Authori ties of the Common Market are seeking to put multinational companies under tighter sur veillance to narrow their scope for avoiding or reducing tax ation in Europe.

title: MRS. ROBERT RIKER SR.
description: RED BANK, N. J., July 23 Mrs. Annette Reynaud Riker, retired head of the circulation department of the Orange Pub lic Library, died Friday at her home, 112 McLaren Street. She was 80 years old, the widow of Robert J. Riker Sr.

title: ROBERT SMITHSON, 35, A SCULPTOR, IS DEAD
description: Robert Smithson, a sculptor, was killed in the crash of a light plane on Friday, along with the pilot and a photog rapher, as they were inspect ing one of his Earth works under construction on a ranch near Amarillo, Tex. He was 35 years old and lived at 799 Greenwich Street.

title: No Item Veto
description: When Congress passed the AntiDeficiency Act in 1905, it specifically recognized the right of the President to withhold appropriated funds in order to effect savings whenever savings are made possible by or through changes in requirements, greater efficiency of operations, or other developments. Every Chief Executive has im pounded greater or lesser sums of money because Gov ernment agencies had achieved operating economies or thought it more efficient to defer spending temporarily on particular projects.

title: PROFIT AND SALES RISE AT CHRYSLER
Trial of Ted Patrick Under Way Here
description: An assistant district attorney warned yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court that there would be chaos if we are going to have parents who disagree over the religious doctrine [of their children] allowed to kid nap them.

title: Above Law and Ethics
description: President Nixon has written bad law and disastrous politics in his decision to withhold White House evidence affecting the Watergate affair not just from the Congress but also from the special prosecutor and, by extension, the nation's courts of law.

title: Podell Pleads Not Guilty in Bribe Case
description: Representative Bertram L. Po dell of Brooklyn pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he had accepted $41,350 in bribes to try to obtain an air route to the Bahamas for a Florida airline.

title: Jerome Elias Accountant With Schenley Industries
description: Jerome Elias, assistant man ager of the accounting depart ment of Schenley Industries and a past president of the Vil lage Independent Democrats, was drowned Sunday in heavy surf while swimming at Fair Harbor on Fire Island. He was 37 years old and lived at 55 West 11th Street.

title: Hasenohrl, Rookie Lineman, Leaves Tough Giants Camp
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J. July 23Following the ex ample set last week by Rod Freeman, a Vanderbilt bas ketball star, George Hasen ohrl, a defensive tackle from Ohio State voluntarily de parted today from the New York Giants training camp at Monmouth College.

title: Special Prosecutor Decides to Seek Legal Action Rather Than Resign Over Move to Block His Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox, who said last May 21 that he would either resign or seek some public recourse if any one attempted to block his criminal investigation of the Watergate scandals, ran into a block today. He did not resign. He went to court.

title: Missing Hiker's Body Found
description: ESTES PARK, Colo., July 23 (UPI)The body of a 22year old hiker, missing for more than a year, was recovered yesterday by rangers in Rocky Mountain National Park. He was identified as Gregory Hol zer of St. Louis Park, Minn.

title: U.S. Planes Reported Bombing Within 6 Miles of Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 23 (UPI)  American planes making bomb runs direc tly over Phnom Penh struck at Communist positions today on all sides of the capital. Some bombs reportedly landed within six miles of the city.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 24, 1973 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: NEW ORDERS STEADY FOR DURABLE GOODS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  New orders for durable goods remained essentially unchanged in June at the record May level, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: Trade Group of Record Industry Endorses Payola Investigations
description: The trade association for the record industry yesterday en dorsed the current Federal and local investigations into alleged payola and called on Congress to pass stronger laws against payola.

title: An Empty Subway Train Derails on Lexington Line
description: An empty subway train de railed at 86th Street and Lex ington Aventie on the south bound express track last night, the Transit Authority reported.

title: CAPTURED ARABS TRIED IN ISRAEL
description: LYDDA, Israel, July 23  Re jecting arguments that intern tional law was being violated an Israeli military tribunal ruled today that it was competent to try 10 Arab guerrilla suspects captured last September during an Israeli raid into Lebanon.

title: She Travels Through Vietnam To Study Life in the Villages
description: MY DUC, South VietnamThe fre netic bustle of Brooklyn is a world away from a small isolated agricultural village in South Vietnam's Mekong Delta.

title: State's 524Mile BargeCanal System Offers Idyllic Cruise for Pleasure Craft
description: BREWERTON, N. Y.This tiny hamlet on the eastern edge of Lake Oneida is hard ly the crossroads of the world. Yet it is possible to go from here by water to any port on the globe. Just last week, boats stopped here on their way to Toronto, Chicago, New Orleans and Florida. One even came from England.

title: Botulism Case Is 4th This Year Involving Contaminated Mushroom Products
description: The current episode of botu lism, in which a Montreal woman became ill and a Massa chusetts processor was forced to recall 336,000 glass jars of mushrooms from 10 states, in cluding New York and New Jersey, is the fourth case this year of botulism contamination of commercial mushroom prod ucts.

title: Dominican Mayor Visits City
description: Mayor Juan Rojas of Santo Domingo, capital of the Do minican Republic, met with Mayor Lindsay yesterday to talk about water pollution, law enforcement and drug addic tion. At the private meeting Mr. Lindsay presented Mayor Estrolla with a ceremonial key to City Hall and Mr. Estrolla gave his host an embroidered Santo Domingo emblem.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Hours are given in Eastern Daylight Time.

title: VOLKSWAGEN NAMED IN TWO COMPLAINTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)  Volkswagen came under at lack today on two issues, one involving pollution control de vices on its 1973 cars and the other involving the safety of its new vehicle called The Thing.

title: One Survives as U.S. Airliner Crashes With 79 Aboard in the Ocean Off Tahiti
description: PAPEETE, Tahiti, July 23 (AP)A Pan American jetliner carrying 69 passengers and 10 crew members plummeted into the sea shortly after taking off from here for Los Angeles last night, and the authorities re ported that one survivor and. ??2 bodies had been found.

title: NO. AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
description: SUNDAY'S GAME

title: Ervin Chides Nixon About Tapes and Disputes Argument on Separation of Powers
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., after signing subpoenas today for tape recordings and documents President Nixon has refused to yield voluntarily, declared at the Senate Watergate hearings that the constitutional doctrine of separation of powers did not apply to alleged criminal ac tivities.

title: Downtown Now Means a Shopping Center
description: LONG BEACH, July 23  A group of youths, ranging in age from 14 to 17 years, ran shout ing through the downtown shopping area.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Museum Plans Miro Exhibition

title: KEENELAND FILLY BRINGS $200,000
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 23 (AP)Horatio Luro, bidding for Mrs. Louisa d'Carpenter's Sho shone Farm, paid $200,000 for a chestnut filly by Northern Dancer at the 30th annual Keeneland summer sale of thoroughbred yearlings today.

title: U.S. TRACK SQUADS TRAILING AT MINSK
description: MINSK, U.S.S.R., July 23 (AP)A powerful Soviet team took a 6651 lead over the United States men in the first day of a dual track and field meet today despite the brilliant running of Steve Williams of San Diego.

title: 38 Dead as Plane Crashes In Storm Outside St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, July 23 (AP)An Ozark Air Lines turbojet ap proaching St. Louis in a thun derstorm crashed into a sub urban residential area tonight: A spokesman for the county medical examiner's office said 38 of the 45 persons on board had been killed.

title: The Secret Air War: Some Senators Sense Another Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, July 23Al though no such talk has yet been heard in public, some members of the Senate Armed Services Committee are con vinced that the secret bombing of Cambodia will emerge as another, perhaps more danger ous, facet of the Watergate scandal. Just as the Nixon Administration's fears of dissent and enemies led to secret wire tapping and other illegalities begin ning in early 1969, the argu ment goes, so did fear of Con gressional rejection lead to the carefully coordinated secret bombing campaign. That 14 month campaign was not of ficially known to Congress and the American public until last week.

title: Symington Doubts Validity of Raid Fund
description: WASHINGTON, July 23.....sen. ator Stuart symington, acting chairman of the Armed Services Committee, declared today that $145  million appropriated by Congress to pay for the B52 bombing of Cambodia may have been obtained under false pretenses.

title: THIEU WOULD BLOCK GOODS TO VIETCONG
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (Reuters)  President Nguyen Van Thieu has called for an economic blockade of the areas of South Vietnam con trolled by the Vietcong.

title: CONNORS WINNER IN U.S. PRO TENNIS
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., July 23 (UPI) Unseeded Jimmy Con nors defeated Arthur Ashe, 63, 46, 64, 36, 62, tonight to win the $12,000 first prize at the 46th United States professional tennis championships at the Longwood Cricket Club.

title: One Missing Macaw Found in Briarcliff; Other Still Sought
description: One of the two macaws miss ing from the Central Park Zoo since early Sunday morning was returned yesterday by a woman from Briarcliff, N. Y., who found the bird fast asleep on her roof.

title: CONGRESS IS WARY ON NIXON  DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Members of Congress reacted cautiously today to President Nixon's refusal to supply tape recordings of his personal con versations to Watergate inves tigators.

title: Skylab 2's Crew Cleared Medically
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 23The three astronauts who plan to operate the stillorbiting Skylab space station were cleared medically today for their scheduled launching Sat urday morning.

title: Wise to Oppose, A's Hunter in Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, July 23 The designated hitter will he absentbut Dick Williams, Nolan Ryan, and Willie Mays will he presentwhen base ball stages its 44th AllStar Game here tomorrow night in the new $70million home of the Kansas City Royals.

title: Forum on NoFault Law
description: The State Insurance Depart ment will hold a public forum in New York City on Aug. 1 to prepare for the new nofault automobile insurance law that becomes effective next Feb. 1. The forum will be held at 2 P.M. at the New York County Lawyers Association, 14 Vesey Street.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET RAN ATOMIC TEST
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (Reuters)The Atomic Energy Commission said today that it had recorded seismic signals from a Soviet underground nu clear test yesterday in the Semipalatinsk area of Kazakh stan.

title: 3 Hit by a Runaway car On Avenue of Americas
description: A car traveling north along the Avenue of the Americas went out of control yesterday and struck three pedestrians after mounting the sidewalk at 135th Street.

title: Swami Nikhilananda, 78, Head of Hindu Center Dies
description: Swami Nikhilananda, spirit ual leader of the Rarakrishna Vivekananda Center at 17 East 94th Street, died Saturday at the center's retreat on Welles ley Island, N. Y., in the St. Lawrence River. He was 78 years old.

title: Afghans Seem Happy That King Is Gone
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 23 (AP)The life of the aver age Afghan seems little touch ed by the coup d'etat that overthrew the monarchy last Tuesday, but the prices of many basic commodities have drop ped in Kabul.

title: STEREOTYPERS SEEK STRIKE AUTHORITY
description: Stereotypers Union No. 1 an nounced yesterday that it had voted to ask its international officers for permission to strike the city's four major daily news papers.

title: All's Well With Jets: Namath Arrives
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., july 23 It. was a magic moment in the life of David Knight, wide receiver, lately of Wil liam and Mary.

title: Burke Close to Agreement With Garden on Post as Head of Sports Arena
description: Michael Burke, the former president of the New York Yankees, may be headed for a new career as president of Madison Square Garden. Negotiations are in progress and one Garden exec utive, who preferred not to be named, said yesterday, I would be very sur prised if negotiations fell apart.

title: State Dept. Says Canada Barred Oil Pipeline Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  A high State Department official told Congress today that Cana da had repeatedly refused to negotiate an agreement with Washington for a transCanada oil pipeline from Alaska to the United States border.

title: Amtrak Cut Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) Representative John T. My ers, Republican of Indiana, has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to reject a request by Amtrak to halt passenger rail service to Richmond and Terre Haute, Ind.

title: Exiled Lama Teaches Americans Buddhist Tenets Periledin Tibet
description: BERKELEY, CalifIn two former fraternity houses on the fringe of the University of California campus  far from the remote Tibetan countryside where he was recognized as the reincarna tion of a holy man at the age of 8an exiled Tibetan lama is attempting to preserve cen turies of ancient Buddhist teachings.

title: Nolan Warms Up for Reds
description: CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP) Gary Nolan, Cincinnati's big gest winner last season with 15 victories but currently on the disabled list with a shoul der problem, may make his first appearance for the Reds this season on Sunday, Man ager Sparky Anderson indi cated today. I watched him the other day and it was the best I've seen him throw in four years, said Anderson.

title: QADDAFI RETRACTS HIS RESIGNATION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23  The Libyan leader, Col. Muam mar elQaddafi, announced to night that he was withdrawing his resignation, and said that he would stay on as Libya's head of state until union with Egypt was carried out.

title: Drysdale Is Upset by Owens In Washington First Round
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) Charles Owens, a 21yearold Tuscaloosa, Ala., player, elim inated 11th seeded Cliff Drys dale of South Africa, 76, 62, tonight as the $75,000 Wash ington StarNews international tennis championships began.

title: Torso Found in Harlem
description: A badly decomposed human torso from above the knees to the waist was found yesterday on the first floor of an aban doned building at 223 East 126th Street. The police re ported the torso was cleancut, probably with a buzz saw. There was no blood by the body, the sex of which was not determined immediately.

title: Football Transactions
description: BALTIMORETraded Charlie Stukes, corner back, to Minnesota for a 1974 draft choice.

title: For the Children, City Amusements
description: Films

title: Smith, Okker Victors in Tennis
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) Topseeded Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S.C., defeated Antonio Munoz of Spain, 61, 76, today in the first round of the Wash ington StarNews international tennis tournament.

title: U.S. and Iran: Main Topics Arms
description: In recent years the Iranians have expressed growing concern about maintaining stability in the Persian Gulf in the face of rising Soviet influence in Iraq and Indiaa concern shared by the United States, West Europe and Japan.

title: Indians and Pakistanis Open Talks About War Problems
In Cambodia's Unconventional War, Rebel Pressure Is the Only Certainty
description: PREK HO, Cambodia, July 24An icecream vender stands at the roadside less than 1,000 yards back from the fighting. At the front line, there are sporadic exchanges of smallarms and machine gun fire, and some outgoing mortars.

title: Retaliatory Shopping
description: The most important news out of France in recent weeks, at least as far as American wine drinkers were concerned, was the announcement that Chateau MoutonRothschild had been upgraded to a firstgrowth wine.

title: OUTBREAK QUELLED AT BEACON FACILITY
description: BEACON, N.Y., July 24A minor disturbance involving some 80 youthful inmates at a state correctional facility here broke out tonight, but was brought under control within 45 minutes, officials reported.

title: Rogers Said Our Hands Are Clean on Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  Secretary of State William P. Rogers, who participated in the decision to begin the secret bombing of Cambodia in March, 1969, repeatedly assured the Senate Foreign Relations com mittee more than a year later that the United States was do ing nothing to violate Cam bodian neutrality, excerpts from his classified testimony showed today.

title: PistolPacking Woman Makes Off With $60,000
description: ROSLYN, L.I., July 24A woman in dark glasses en tered a jewelry store after business hours today, pro duced a pistol that she brandished at the proprietor and escaped with an esti mated $60,000 in gems and other merchandise.

title: Savings and Loan Industry Fights CeilingFree Rates
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 The savings and loan indus try has started an intensive lobbying campaign in Congress to wipe out the new permis sion for banks and thrift in stitutions to offer to savers fouryear certificates of deposit with no ceiling on the interest rate.
