title: Soviet Ship Blasts Free Of Floes in the Antarctic
description: MOSCOW, July 24 (AP) The supply vessel Ob, flag ship of the Soviet Antarctic fleet, has dynamited her way free after being trapped months in the ice and is heading home.

title: Quake Jars 2 Coast Cities
description: LAKEPORT, Calif., July 24 (AP)An earthquake rocked the northern California cities of Ukiah and Lakeport today. No injuries or damage was re ported. The tremor was rated at a moderate 3.6 on the Rich ter scale by the University of California Seismographic Stat tion in Berkeley.

title: New Jet Punter Opens His Case
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 24 Who was that tall, hand some blond wearing a clean white jersey at the Jets camp today as his teammates huffed and puffed, hit spring released dummies, or at tempted to muscle one an other out of the way in line action?

title: Bogota Skyscraper Hard Hit In a Blaze Costing Six Lives
description: BOGOTA, Columbia, July 24 (UPI)The 44story Avianca tower building, Bogota's tallest, was badly damaged in a fire yesterday that cost at least six lives and injured 63 persons. Thirty floors were gutted.

title: PARIS BELITTLES ATEST CRITICISM
description: PARIS, July 24 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Michel Jobert said today that there would be more French nuclear tests in the South Pacific, and de clared that the international wave of protests will not prevent me from sleeping well at night.

title: Lobstermen Given Four Months in Jail In Poaching Incident
description: RIVERHEAD, LI., July 24 Two Rhode Island brothers were sentenced today to four months in jail on charges linked to lobster poaching in New York waters.

title: Ankara Court Backs Jail Terms for 21 In Abolished Party
description: ANKARA. Turkey, July 24 A military tribunal here has confirmed the jail sentences of 21 former leaders of the out lawed Turkish Labor party who have already spent about two years in a military prison near here.

title: WITNESS DISPUTED AT LANSKY'S TRIAL
description: MIAMI, July 24 (AP)The Government rested its case today in the trial of Meye? Lansky for tax evasion and Federal District Judge Joe Eator denied a defense motion for a directed verdict of not guilty.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, JULY 25, 1973
description: Watergate Investigation

title: Basketball Transactions
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION DENVERSigned Lament King, guard.

title: Gubernatorial Rivals List Primary Spending
description: TRENTON, July 24 (UPI) Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. spent $10,000 more to win the Republican gubernatorial nomination than Brendan T. Byrne did to earn the Democratic designa tion, financial reports showed today.

title: Sports Today
description: Hamilton TigerCats vs. Toronto Argonauts, Canadian League pre season game, at Toronto, (TelevisionChannel 9, 11 P.M. tape).

title: Nixon Signs Space Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) President Nixon has signed a bill authorizing $3billion for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the White House said today. The measure, authorizing funds for the fiscal year 1974, which be gan July 1, represents an in crease of $485million above the agency's request.

title: A Preventable Ordeal
description: The dreadful ordeal suffered by the passengers and crew of a Japanese jetliner at the hands of a band soldiers of fortune exposes once again the utter in adequacy of international efforts to control air piracy.

title: Aqueduct Shutdown Costs City and State
description: Each day that Aqueduct remains closed New York State loses about $350,000. In addition, the city loses about $50,000 a day as a re sult of decreased wagering with OTB.

title: Bonavena Stops Caldwell After Minute of 2d Round
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 24 (AP)  The Argentine heavy weight, Oscar Bonavena, in his first fight in more than two years, stopped Leroy Caldwell of Milwaukee one minute into the second round of their scheduled 10rounder last night. Caldwell was knocked down twice.

title: Soviet Union Completes Track Victory Over U.S.
description: MINSK, Soviet Union July 24 (UPI)The Soviet Union held off a fastclosing performance by a young but tired United States track team today for a 216163 aggregate victory, their eighth in the 11 dual meets be tween the two nations.

title: ITALIANS HUNTING FOR U.S. NEWSMAN
description: ROME, July 24The Italian police today were investigating the disappearance from Rome last Sunday of an American Broadcasting Company news man who was said to have been working on a report in volving the Mafia.

title: Rome Court Orders Paper to Withdraw Barzini Editorship
description: ROME, July 24  A magis trate here today ordered the owners of the largestcircula tion Rome daily, Il Messaggero, to revoke their appointment of the writer Luigi Barzini as managing editor.

title: New York Printers Win
description: DETROIT, July 24A two run homer by Vin Davis led the New York Printers to a 64 victory today over Boston, the defending champion, in the 65th annual Union Printers In ternational Baseball League championship tournament here.

title: Heidi Dolan to Be Wed to Lawyer
description: WILTON, Conn., Oct. 6 Miss Heidi Dolan, assistant publicity director at Bergdorf Goodman in New York, plans to be married here in Sep tember? to Bernard Coleman Baldwin 3d, an assistant dis trict attorney for New York County.

title: Nearby Golf Results
description: Women's Metropolitan G.A. Event

title: Bridge: Winners of 2 Titles Nearing 3d in Life Master Pair Play
1,470 Gas Ranges Sought For Possible Fire Hazard
description: CHICAGO, July 24 (AP)  Sears, Roebuck & Co., said yesterday it was trying to find 1,470 selfcleaning doubleoven gas ranges that contain a pos sible fire hazard.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SHOW OF HANDS St. Peter's Church is carrying on in temporary quarters even as its old home is being de molished to make way for a new one. It has its services at Central Presbyterian Church, but the lunchtime free entertainment that it pioneered is now being done in St. Peter's Center, 16 East 56th Street (PL 34669). This is a spacious, welllit split level gallerytype location with the shows, Monday through Fridays at 12:30 and 1, on the upper level, where there is a small stage and a dozen tables at which you may eat the lunch that you bring in; holds about 50 peo ple. Robert Molnar is cur rently doing a week of mime here on the twoaday basis. He is a genial handy man who not only is deft at his art but also speaks vocally to his viewers, explaining some of the techniques that go into mime. He moves quickly on from basics to a full story in his 35minute stint and shows how make up is applied as he goes along. Future weeks will bring programs of drama solos and music. It's free, but contributions are re quested, softly.

title: Valenti Says Johnson Recorded Some Calls
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI)Jack Valenti said to day that President Johnson occasionally recorded his tel ephone conversations with out knowledge of the other person but that no White House offices were bugged during the Johnson Adminis tration.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A departmental trial was recessed after two days yesterday in the case against the policemen accused of attempting to cover up for an officer who shot and killed an alleged pimp. When witnesses now on vacation return, the trial will resume, but with the number of defendants reduced from 10 to six.

title: ExAide Says Nixon Felt Office Raid Was Proper
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 John D. Ehrlichman said today that President Nixon felt it was well within both the consti tutional duty and obligation of the Presidency for White House aides to break into the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's for mer psychiatrist.

title: FALSE GRAIN DATA CALLED WILLFUL
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The administrator of the Com modity Exchange Authority testified today that he had evidence that the Continental Grain Company had willfully filed false reports that con cealed the magnitude of its wheat sales to the Soviet Union.

title: Seoul's Foreign Minister To Visit Waldheim at U.N.
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 24  South Korea's Foreign Minis ter, Kim Yong Shik, is scheduled to leave for New York tomor row to talk with Secretary Gen eral Waldheim on the Korean question, which is to be debated in the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Reapportion Plan Upheld For November Elections
description: TRENTON, July 25 (AP) The State Supreme Court ruled today that the current legisla tive reapportionment plan was valid for this year's election, but the court ordered further study that could lead to changes in the plan for future elections in this decade.

title: Two Workers Lock Themselves In Cage and Halt Assembly Line
description: DETROIT, July 24 (UPI) Two disgruntled workers, armed with heavy tools and shielded by sympathizers, bar ricaded themselves in a power control cage today and shut down an assembly line at the Chrysler Corporation's Jeffer son platn for two shifts.

title: Fatal Roller Coaster Plunge
description: SALISBURY BEACH, Mass., July 24 (AP)A woman jumped or fell to her death from the topmost section of a roller coaster at an amusement park here yesterday, the police re ported. She was identified as Mrs. Rose M. Beede, 45 years old, of North Billerica.

title: Marcos Suspends Some Civil Curbs On Eve of the Vote
description: MANILA, July 24 (AP)Pres ident Ferdinand E. Marcos has announced a temporary resto ration of some constitutional privileges to allow what he de scribed as a free discussion of the issue to be resolved in a referendum on Fridayhow long he should continue in power.

title: Gen. Constantine Dovas Dead; Hero in '47 War Against Reds
description: ATHENS, July 24Gen. Con stantine Dovas, an army hero, onetime chief of the king's military household and briefly Premier, died today in an Athens military hospital after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Ehrlichman Disputes Statements of Other Officials
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  John D. Ehrlichman went through some of the central episodes in the Watergate scandal today, rejecting at every turn any implication or assertion of improper activity on his part.

title: The Sad Young Men
description: WASHINGTON, July 24They are Richard Nixon's children, these sad young men who come day after day before the Senate committee. They tell their stories of files neatly kept, of talking papers and action papers, of trips in Air Force One and messages relayed on secure telephones, and of their gradual participation in crime. The end came so swiftly, so unex pectedly. In a few, unraveling months, they moved from the hushed corridors of power to the strained recollections of the grand jury room and the frantic bargaining for immunity.

title: Salvagers Drop Lines To the Andrea Doria
description: FAIRHAVEN, Mass., July 24 (AP)Salvage operations began in the Atlantic today in an attempt to recover a re ported $4million in treasure from the sunken ocean liner Andrea Doria.

title: Watergate Connection
description: In seeking plausible explanations for Watergate, intellectuals speculate on U.S. domestic traditions or the character of leading officials. But they overlook the connection between be havior in foreign policy and in the Watergate affair, a connection that suggests how difficult it is to prevent governments from using at home methods they use so willingly abroad.

title: 2D ATOMIC PLANT SOUGHT BY LILCO
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 24 Still facing an appeal to the Atomic Energy Commission and fresh from a sevenyear battle with the opponents of its first nuclear power plant, the Long Island Lighting Company tonight held the first public hearing on its planned second nuclear power plant.

title: City Agencies Stage Pornography Raids; 7 Films Confiscated
description: Reinforced by recent United States Supreme Court rulings on pornography, agents of the Manhattan District Attorney and the city's Corporation Coun sel seized seven films, made arrests and filed actions against 11 theaters Monday night and yesterday.

title: Puerto Rican Art Show Proves Its Rich Heritage
description: The Art Heritage of Puerto Rico, a joint project of the Museo del Barrio, New York's leading Puerto Rican cultural institution, and the Metropol itan Museum, has moved from the former to the latter, where it opens today. Some what enlarged, but still a miniature show, it stars a new loan from the Louvre, Francisco Oiler's L'Etudi ant.

title: IMPOUNDMENT BILL LIMITED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The House agreed today to a oneyear limitation on its pro posed plan to curb the Presi dent's impoundment of funds appropriated by Congress.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Ban Asked on Razing of 2 Townhouses for a High  Rise
description: The dispute over razing two turnofthecentury townhouses, one on Fifth Avenue and one on East 82d Street, came be fore the Landmarks Preserva tion Commission yesterday as both sides presented arguments about whether the houses should be designated as city landmarks or torn down to make way for a highrise apartment building.

title: Jersey Girl Sues F.B.I. Over Intercepted Letter
description: NEWARK, July 24A dam age suite has been filed in Federal District Court here charging the Federal Bureau of Investigation with intercept ing a letter written by a 15 yearold high school girl as part of a school project and with subsequently investigating her character and activities.

title: Some McDonald's Patties Cited for Short Weight
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 24 The Nassau County Office of Consumer Affairs has found some McDonald's hamburger stands in the county were selling hamburgers, adver tised as made with a quar terpound of 100 per cent beef, at an average of one eighth of an ounce short in weight.

title: INTEREST RATES CONTINUE CLIMB
description: Interest rates pressed still higher yesterday along a broad front in a creditmarket sec sion that produced a number of noteworthy developments. A rate of 10.05 per cent on three month certificates of deposit, touched on Monday, became widespread and reports circu lated that a Chicago bank paid 8% per cent for this maturity. The minimum denomi nation for C.D.'s is $100,000. Mean while, an 8 per cent level of return was offered on two new highquality cor porate bond issuetriple A securities of Cincinnati Gas & Electric Company and double A securities of Northern Indi ana Public Service Company. These are the highest returns on such obligations in about two years.

title: Man Who Invaded Police Station Hit by 20 Bullets in Crossfire
description: An autopsy disclosed yester day that the 25yearold gun man who invaded the East 67th Street station house Monday night and wounded a lieutenant and sergeant was struck by 20 bullets in a police crossfire.

title: An End to Nuclear Tests?
description: Exactly ten years ago today, representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain initialed the Treaty of Moscow, the partial atomic testban accord that took the first giant step toward taming the threat of massive nuclear death and destruction. The wide spread hope then was that the two defects of the Moscow Treaty would soon be rectified.

title: U.S. FINANCIAL FILES FOR REORGANIZATION
description: SAN DIEGO, July 24 (AP) U.S. Financial, Inc., a giant real estate finance company beset by debts and a Securities and Exchange Commission investi gation, has filed in Federal District Court here for reor ganization under Chapter XI of the bankruptcy law.

title: Con Ed Will Offer Bonds in October; Net Is Up for Half
description: The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday a proposed public offering of $150million of first and re funding mortgage bonds in Oc tober and reported gains in firsthalf operating revenues and net income.

title: Italian Rights League Head Found Guilty of Bribery
description: Natale Marcone, president of the Italian  American Civil Rights League, was found guilty yesterday of having paid $4,000 to an Internal Revenue Service agent as a bribe to fix an inves tigation of his personal and corporate income taxes.

title: 17 of the Greek Navy Officers Accused of Plotting Are Freed
description: ATHENS, July 24Seventeen of the Greek Navy officers accused of having participated in an antiGovernment plot last May were unexpectedly freed today. Some of the 17 apparently still face trial, how ever.

title: 10DAY CAR SALES SET RECORD PACE
description: DETROIT, July 24  Auto sales in the United States were at record levels in midJuly.

title: Added Starter for OTB: 9th Finger Lakes Race
Major in Air Force Files New Charges Against 7 P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) An Air Force major who spent nearly five years in North Vietnamese captivity filed new mutiny charges today against seven Army and Marine enlist ed men who recently were cleared of other misconduct allegations.

title: P.S.C. Reaffirms Refusal To Grant Gas Exemption
description: ALBANY, July 24The Pub the New York City air pollu reaffirmed its refusal to grant a special exemption authorizing the use of natural gas for primary burners in incinerators upgraded in accordance with tion control code.

title: Sports Today
description: Hamilton TigersCats vs. Toronto Argonauts, Canadian League pre season game, at Toronto. (TelevisionChannel 9, II P.M. tape).

title: Kerr, Sworn In by Newark, Scores Kawaida Tensions
description: NEWARK, July 24Edward L. Kerr was formally sworn in as Newark's Police Director to day and promptly tried to mute what he acknowledged was the controversy aroused by the appointment of a black man to such a ranking position in a major American city.

title: SAMUEL M. HIRSCH, REAL ESTATE MAN
description: Samuel M. Hirsch, a real estate builder, broker and con sultant active in construction for the textile and garment in dustry for more than half a cen tury, died of an apparent stroke yesterday at his home, 40 East 66th Street. He was 78 years old.

title: Events Today
description: THE MACKINTOSH MAN, a drama starring Paul Newman, Dominique Sanda and James Mason, directed by John Huston, at Loews State 2 and Loews Orpheum Theaters.

title: Quadruplets Born in Mexico On Ranch Without a Doctor
description: TIERRA BLANCA, Mexico, July 24 (AP)Quadruplets de livered on a remote ranch by a neighbor with no training in midwifery were reported in ex cellent condition last night.

title: AIR INQUIRY BEGINS IN MISSOURI CRASH
description: ST. LOUIS, July 24 (AP) Federal investigators examined today the wreckage of an Ozark Air Lines passenger plane that crashed during a violent thund erstorm last night, killing 36 of 44 persons aboard.

title: U.N. URGED TO ACT ON TERROR ISSUE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24Britain and the United States called today for urgent and decisive action against in ternational terrorism.

title: City Agencies Stage Pornography Raids; 7 Films Confiscated
description: Reinforced by recent United States Supreme Court rulings on pornography, agents of the Manhattan District Attorney and the city's Corporation Coun sel seized seven films, made arrests and filed actions against 11 theaters Monday night and yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarty testified he was innocent of gambling charges and said he was recruiting paper boys when arrested with numbers slips last year. Moriarty, tak ing the stand in his own defense in Superior Court here, also denied assaulting Sgt. Robert Sanetilli of the state police when he was stopped on Ocean Avenue in Jersey City on April 18, 1972.

title: Lower Majority Age Gains
description: BOSTON, July 24 (AP) A bill to lower the age of majority in Massachusetts from 21 to I8 received final approval today in the State Senate. The bill would grant full citizenship to per sons up to 20, who already have the right to drink alcholic bev erages and vote instate elec tions. The bill faces a fight in the House.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Here is one citizen who must cry out at last against the mindless invo cation of the shibboleth of the separa tion of powers that we have been treated to in public discussion of the Watergate affair.

title: Priscilla Poinier Wed
description: GLADSTONE, N.J., Oct. 6 Miss Priscilla Webster Poinier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Poinier of Glad stone and Weekapaug, R.I., was married here this noon to James Paul Grainger, son of Dr. Henry B. Grainger, a physician, and Mrs. Grainger of Westerly, R.I. The Rev. David St. George performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. John Belmont.

title: Saigon Throbs With Life, but Scars Go Deep
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, July 24Saigon is a city of illusions and images that often mask the scars of war.

title: WITNESS DEFIANT
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 John D. Ehrlichman clashed with the Senate Watergate committee today as he sought to refute every charge of il legal conduct on my part.

title: B. & W. BUYS 93% OF GIMBELS STOCK
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, a subsid iary of the BritishAmerican Tobacco Company, Ltd, an nounced yesterday that it had purchased about 93 per cent of the outstanding common shares of Gimbel Brothers, Inc. The purchase is the result of a tender offer for $23 a share that was made June 11 and ex pired last Monday. Brown & Wil liamson said it was studying the desirability of acquiring the re maining approximate 510,000 shares of Gimbels common through purchase of stock, merger, purchase of assets or other transactions. The com pany said that it hoped that the price to be paid for the remain ing 7 per cent would not exceed the $23 a share paid in the tender offer.

title: Two Men Rob L.I. Bank And Speed to a Dead End
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 24 Two gunmen ran into a dead end after making off with more than $7,000 from the West Hempstead branch of the Roslyn Savings Bank, a police account of the ill starred exploit showed today.

title: National League Wins, 7 to 1, Hitting Three Homers
description: KANSAS CITY, July 24 The National League won base ball's AllStar game tonight for the 10th time in the last 11 years by overpowering the American League, 71.The game was the 44th in the series and the first in the new $70million Harry S. Tru man sports complex, and it was decided by a barrage of home runs in the middle innings.They were hit by Johnny Bench of the Cincinnati Reds, Bobby Bonds of the San Fran cisco Giants and Willie Davis of the Los Angeles Dodgers. And they were hit in consecu tive innings against Bill Singer and Nolan Ryan of the Calif ornia Angels.

title: Indianapolis Speedway Gets a Safety Message
description: It doesn't seem credible, but the nationwide revulsion over the three deaths and numerous injuries associated with this year's Indianapolis 500 has penetrated the insu larity of Indianapolis Motor Speedway. The management, normally impervious to out side criticism, has begun several projects to improve driver and spectator safety and is considering a couple of others.

title: N.F.L. Suspends Rentzel
description: Lance Rentzel, wide re ceiver of the Los Angeles Rams, has been suspended for the 1973 season for con duct detrimental to the Na tional Football League.

title: Body of Gagged Girl Is Found in a Closet In Burlington Home
description: WILLINGBORO, N. J., July 24The bound and gagged body of a teenage girl was found today in a closet of her home in this Burlington County community.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: If the United States makes the final round of the Davis Cup this year, it will be held indoors and at night. This was confirmed yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association, Reuters said, with the final held in Cleveland Nov. 30 and Dec. 1 and 2. Finalround cup matches have always been played outdoors during day light hours.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: NAVY CHIEF STIRS AN ARMS DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the Chief of Naval Operations, had some Senate aides in for break fast today to sell them on the Navy program but wound up exasperating some by re portedly suggesting that the Soviet Union had developed a MIRV warhead for its mis siles.

title: Loss of a Leg Is No Bar to Ballplayer, 12
description: ORADELL, July 24 Twelveyearold Grant Dan zer is like many boys his age: He is full of energy, dis likes school and has a tre mendous interest in sports, especially baseball.

title: No Evidence, No Trial
description: President Nixon has now asserted a legal position which could prevent any successful prosecution of the Watergate conspirators.

title: City Reopens Case of Girl Who Got Fatal Methadone
description: Dr. Milton Helpern, the Chief Medical Examiner, has re opened the case of Dafna V. Malka, a 16yearold Queens girl who died at Elmhurst city hospital last December after having been given 70 milli grams of methadone, a poten tially lethal dose.

title: Canada Is Seeking Texas Gulf Control
description: The Canadian Government moved yesterday to gain effec tive control of Texas Gulf, Inc., a huge United States metals and sulphurproducing company with major mines and process ing plants in Canada.

title: Pensions and Transit
description: The list of topics to come before the special session of the State Legislature which convenes today in Albany continues to grow. It could still grow even more, as Governor Rockefeller is solely responsible for fixing the agenda of a special session and can add further items at his pleasure. But there are already two major topics that will provide essentially similar tests of courage for individual lawmakers against the pressures of special interest groups.

title: Some Familiar Chanel Touches Gone, but Not the Look
description: PARIS, July 24A jaguar coat in its natural colors brought only a halfhearted hiss at the Chanel showing, the bluedyed jaguar no re sponse at all. It could indi cate that the people attend ing the fall couture showings here are even less responsive than the ones in Rome last week to the plight of the en dangered furbearing species.

title: Rogers Said Our Hands Are Clean on Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  Secretary of State William P. Rogers, who participated in the decision to begin the secret bombing of Cambodia in March of 1969, repeatedly assured the Senate Foreign Relations com mittee more than a year later that the United States was do ing nothing to violate Cam bodian neutrality, excerpts from his classified testimony showed today.

title: Plan for Skyscraper On Lexington Ave. Detailed by Citibank
description: Detailed plans of the new skyscraper that the First Na tional City Bank will build on Lexington Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets were disclosed yesterday.

title: Astronauts Ready to Erect New Sun Shield on Skylab
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 24In the best fixit tradi tion of Skylab 1, the Skylab 2 astronauts are prepared to make some repairs on the giant orbiting space station they plan to accupy after their launching Saturday morning.

title: White House Hints Nixon Will Accept a Court Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 The White House indicated to day that President Nixon would abide by the ultimate decision of the courts in his historic struggle to prevent the release of the recordings of his pri vate conversations on Water gate.

title: Rockefeller Will Help City Raise Funds to Hold Fare
description: On the eve of the special ses sion of the Legislature, Gover nor Rockefeller met yesterday with Mayor Lindsay and City Controller Abraham D. Beame and said later that he would help the city seek financing for its half of his proposed state city subsidy plan for holding the 35cent transit fare.

title: Anaconda to Cut August Copper Deliveries
description: Soaring demand, frozen prices, strikes in Chile, Zambia's border dispute wtth Rhodesia, heavy buying by the Chinese and Jap anese and the instability of the dollar have all combined to bring chaos to the copper in dustry,

title: Phoebeann Jaeger to Wed
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 6Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. Jaeger have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Phoebeann Jaeger, to Anthony S. Previti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Previti of New Britain. A De cember wedding is planned.

title: Notes on People
description: The first woman commis sioner of the United States Court of Claims will be Char lotte P. Murphy, who has been working on tax litiga tion in the office of the chief counsel of the Internal Rev enue Service since 1960. Miss Murphy, who is 45 years old, is scheduled to be sworn in to the post on Aug. 5 in Washington. There are 15 commissioners on the court; they serve as trial judges and are paid $36,000 a year. In an interview in Washington, Miss Murphy declined to speculate on whether she might ever be considered for a nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: HOUSE STANDS FIRM ON BAN ON HANOI AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)  The House decided today to stick by a proposal to prohibit aid to North Vietnam under the FoodforPeace program as it voted to send the farm and food stamp bill to a compro mise conference with the Sen ate.

title: EDWARD J. SOMMERS
description: Edward J. Sommers, a re tired police officer who was second vice president of the Conservative party's executive committee in Queens, died yes terday at La Guardia Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 56 years old.

title: TRANSIT PENSIONS SCORED BY LEVITT
description: State Controller Arthur Lev itt accused the Transit Author ity yesterday of loose manage ment that allowed retiring em ployes to send pension costs soaring through overtime work in their last year.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: OffDuty Policeman Slain by Gunman In a Harlem Bar
description: An offduty police officer was fatally shot in a crowded bar in Harlem early today by a noisy, and apparently drunk en, patron whom he had tried to quiet down, the police re ported.

title: India Expresses Desire to Broaden Relations With U.S.
description: NEW DELHI, July 24  The Indian Government bluntly ex pressed a yearning today to broaden ties with the United States and spur a new eco nomic relationship with Wash ington.

title: Six Months Also Gain
description: Slightly improved second quarter earnings were reported yesterday by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, reflecting continuing progress in execut ing a turnaround following its costly troubles with the C5 military transport and the L 1011 jet airliner.

title: 2 Embassies Indicate Phnom Penh Is Unsafe
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 24 (UPI)The British and Australian Embassies urged their nationals today to leave as air and ground activity intensified against insurgent troops threatening the capital.

title: NIXON UNIT TOLD TO REVEAL FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  Common Cause won its suit today to force disclosure of campaign expenses and contri butions by the Finance Commit tee to Reelect the President.

title: COURT REJECTS PLEA IN HEROIN SMUGGLING
description: DENVER, July 24 (AP)  Three men convicted of con spiracy in smuggling $10million worth of heroin from Thailand to the United States aboard a military transport plane have lost an appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit.

title: Treasury Bills Climb At Monthly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Gov ernment's monthly competi tive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: TED PATRICK TRIAL HEARS HIS LAWYER
description: The defense for Ted Patrick contended yesterday that Mr. Patrick was justified in helping a couple seize their 20yearold son last January becaust they had good reason to believe he was being harmed by his mem bership in a conservative re ligious group here.

title: White House Hints Nixon Will Accept a Court Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The White House indicated to day that President Nixon would abide by the ultimate decision of the courts in his historic struggle to prevent the release of the recordings of his pri vate conversations on Water gate.

title: Wall St. Finns to Merge
description: Thomson & McKinnon Auchincloss, Inc., and Kohlmeyer & Co., both member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday they had agreed in principle to combine their businesses.

title: Drama Student Slain Here Buried in Indiana
description: I PORTLAND, Ind., July 24 This is the town in which Deborah Ann Phemister had everythinggood looks, a pros perous family, good clothing, a budding dramatic talent and friends everywhere.

title: Pilot Describes Hijacking and Moments Before Blast
description: The following dispatch, dis tributed by United Press Inter national, is by Capt. Kenji Konuma, pilot of the hijacked Japan Air Lines jumbo jet that was blown up early yesterday by hijackers.

title: Costa Rica Refuses To Extradite Vesco
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 24 (AP)The Costa Rican Supreme Court upheld today a lower court refusal to ex tradite Robert L. Vesco to the United States to face fraud charges.

title: Medical Examiner Orders Inquiry Into Death of a Girl, 16, From Methadone
description: Dr. Milton Helpern, the Chief Medical Examiner, has reopened the case of Dafna V. Malka, a 16yearold Queens girl who died at Elmhurst city hospital last December after having been given 70 milligrams of methadone, a potential lethan dose.

title: The Shah and Empress of Iran Are Feted at a White House State Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 The Shah of Iran, who has more oil than he needs but not as many jet fighters as he would like, was honored at a White House state dinner tonight that featured a clutch of oil men, a sprinkling of members of Congress, four ambassadors and three wines.

title: Advertising: A Volunteer Feat
description: There she was, in a corner of a public room in the Amer icana Hotel  a bedraggled young woman, a leather belt tight around her upper arm and a hypodermic needle in her hand, getting ready to give herself a fix.

title: Canada Is Seeking Texas Gulf Control
description: The Canadian Government moved yesterday to gain effec tive control of Texas Gulf, Inc., a huge United States metals and sulphurproducing company with major mines and process ing plants in Canada.

title: Nixon and Shah Exchange Praise, Confer in Oval Office
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 While hundreds of tourists and White House employes waved small American and Iranian flags on the White House lawn this morning, President Nixon and Shah Mohammed Riza Pah levi of Iran exchanged lavish praise at the start of the Shah's fourday state visit to the United States.

title: TAXIAD PROPOSAL ASSAILED BY LAZAR
description: Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Com mission, charged yesterday that, as now worded, a City Council bill allowing taxicabs to carry exterior advertising was a giveaway to the taxi industry.

title: NEW DELAYS SNAG PRISONER TRADES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 24 (Reuters)  The prisoner exchanges in South Vietnam ran into new trouble today, four days before the deadline for completion laid down last month in talks at Paris.

title: Giant Fullback? Clements Knows
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J. July 24There is much discussion here at the New York Giants Monmouth Col lege training camp on who will be the starting fullback, but all of it is meaningless to Vin Clements's way of thinking.

title: Leadbelly Is Served Well by New Playboy Record
description: It has been more than 20 years since the virile, billow ing voice of Huddie Ledbet ter, who was known as Lead belly, could be heard singing his remarkable collection of blues, work songs, hollers, children's songs and fun songs at the Village Van guard and other places in Greenwich Village.

title: West Side Youth Seized In FireBombing Incident
description: A 15yearold West Side youth was arrested last night and charged with juvenile de linquency in connection with the firebombing of a five story apartment building at 457 West 50th Street.

title: TrillionDollar Phaseout Chapter 1
description: Paul E. Erdman, an econo mist with a Ph.D. (summa cum laude) from the University of Basel, spent 10 months in Swiss prison after the collapse of the United California Bank in Basel, of which he was pres ident.

title: The Dance:Billy the Kid
description: The current American Bal let Theater at the New York State Theater is remarkable for a number of things  among them the rise of two young male dancers, Fer nando Bujones and Daniel Levins. On Sunday night it was particularly Mr. Levins's opportunity for he was ap pearing the first time in New York in the title role of Eugene Loring's Billy the Kid, and also played two leading roles in the first per formance of the season of At Midnight.

title: Radio
description: 8:0510 A.M., WNCN. Italian Ser enade, Wolf; Concerto No. 5 in A minor, Stanley; La Son nambula: Ahl non credea mirarte, Benini: Sinfonia No. 3 in F, C. P. E. Bach; Sonata a Quattro No. 3, Rossini; Symphony No. 4, Brahms.

title: Full Pension Rights In 15 Years on Job Voted by Senators
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI)  The Senate Finance Committee voted unanimously today to give employes full rights in private pension plans after working for a company 15 years.

title: DR. B. B. ROSENBERG, LED JEWISH CHARITY
description: BOSTON, July 23 (AP)  Dr. Benjamin B. Rosenberg, executive vice president of the Combined Jewish Philanthro pies of Greater Boston, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospi tal after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: COURT PLACES LIMIT ON INHERITANCE TAX
description: TRENTON, July 24 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the state transfer inheritance tax could not be applied to assets that were transferred at least three years before the death of their owner.

title: Iranian Flood Toll Rises
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 24 (AP) The death toll in floods in central Iran rose to 46 today as more bodies were recov ered.

title: Freezing of Prices For Three Months Is Decreed in Italy
description: ROME, July 24The new Italian Government issued to day antiinflation decrees freez ing most manufacturers and retail prices for three months starting tomorrow.

title: RETRIAL IS ORDERED ON SWINDLE COUNTS
description: A state appeals court yes terday nullified the grand lar ceny conviction of a former Westchester County lawyer in an alleged $250,000 apartment house swindle and ordered a new trial.

title: FALSE GRAIN DATA CALLED WILLFUL
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The administrator of the Com modity Exchange Authority testified today that he had evidence that the Continental Grain Company had willfully filed false reports that con cealed the magnitude of its wheat sales to the Soviet Union.

title: Thomas Joins Redskins And Goes Right to Work
description: CARLISLE, Pa., July 24 (UPI) Duane Thomas completed his first workouts with the Wash ington Redskins today and pleased coach George Allen with his attitude.

title: Business Briefs Foreign Customers Buy More U.S. Stocks
description: Participation by foreign customers in the United States stock market rose to a high last year of $31billion, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday.

title: 60 SPYING EFFORT LAID TODEMOCRATS
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  George Bush, chairman of the Republican National Committee, charged today that John F. Ken nedy's Presidential campaign spied on Republicans and may have used illegal wiretaps to advantage in the 1960 debates against Richard M. Nixon.

title: Europe's Nightmare Dream
description: DENVER  Finlandization has been a code word for years in West Europe. It implies gradual neutraliza tion, largely precipitated by bilateral superpower dealings, that would re duce American defense strength on Europe's side of the Atlantic and im plicitly weaken the degree of United States commitment to protect that area.

title: LIMIT RISES SET IN WHEAT FUTURES
description: Grain exporters, their order books full, again helped bid up all wheat futures by the daily permissible limit of 10 cents per 60pound bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Coast Fire Destroys New Bob Hope Home
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., July 24 (AP)Bob Hope's desert home here, under construc tion at a cost estimated at $3million, was destroyed by fire today.

title: Excerpts From Ehrlichman's Testimony Before Senate Committee on Watergate
Red Smith Elegy Written in Steelhead Country
description: KELSO, Wash.The waitress in the allnight coffee pot surveyed the customers straddling stools at her counter. A pretty kettle of fishermen they wereNorm Nelson, from the Weyerhaeuser Company's public affairs department; Will Yolen of New York, the Baron von Rich thofen of kite flyers, and Jack Murphy, the bright, partic ular star of San Diego journalism. They had asked the waitress for coffee and her prayers. She consulted a man down at the end of the counter, who may have been the only resident besides herself abroad at that unearthly hour before sunrise. Think they can catch some steelhead? The local au thority answered without looking up: With a du Pont spinner, maybe, or a net. In pis catorial circles in the Pacific Northwest, du Pont spinner is a euphemism for dynamite.

title: Stocks Stage a Turnaround To Close With 5.57 Gain
description: The stock market started to topple yesterday for the first time in seven sessions, but it turned around abruptly in the early afternoon and closed with another solid gain.

title: FACULTY PROTESTS LUTHERAN ACTIONS
description: ST. LOUIS. July 24  A majority of the faculty and staff at Concordia Seminary said today that they would not abide by conservative doc trinal policies adopted two weeks ago by the 1973 con vention of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod.

title: Sterilization Policy Denied
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., July 24 (UPI)  One of three Aiken County physicians whose treat merit of welfare patients is un der investigation said today he had no policy on sterilization of welfare mothers, Dr. Niles A. Borop Jr. said in a telephone interview that his recommenda tion on sterilization depend en tirely on the individual patient.

title: Loss of a Leg Is No Bar To Star Ballplayer, 12
description: ORADELL, N.J., July 24 Twelveyearold Grant Danzer is Iike many boys his age: He is full of energy, dislikes school and has a tremendous interest in sports, especially baseball.

title: Wholesale Price of Eggs Rises; Beef Shortage Predicted Soon
description: For the third time in eight days, wholesalers yesterday raised the price of eggs.

title: PRICES MOVE UP ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices perked up slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday with trading volume also advancing a bit as the ex change posted its seventh con secutive gain. Prices in the overthecounter market also advanced.

title: Citibank Discloses TheftofHalfMillion In Travelers Checks
description: Travelers checks worth $500,000 were stolen from the First National City Bank branch at 399 Park Avenue on July 9, the police disclosed yesterday. The bank confirmed the loss but would say only that the checks had 'disap peared somewhere in transit about 10 days ago.

title: BADILLO IS URGED NOT TO MAKE RACE
description: Topranking leaders of the Liberal party urged Represent ative Herman Badillo yester day not to run for Mayor and told him that if he did he would divide the liberal and independent forces in the No vember election.

title: Huntington Hartford Alleges Conspiracy and Sues 3
description: Huntington Hartford, heir to a Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company fortune, filed suit yes terday charging a consipracy to take advantage of his 'illiquid position to wipe out his hold ings in Paradise Island in the Bahamas.

title: Armco and Anaconda Earnings Climb
Presidential Subpoena Upheld in 1807
description: WASHINGTON. July 24 Thomas Jefferson the only President other than Richard M. Nixon to be served with a subpoena, refused to make the court appearance that the legal paper ordered, but his refusal was never challenged in court.

title: Cement Worker Killed
description: WEST CONSHOHOCKEN, Pa., July 24 (AP)An employe of the Allentown Portland Cement Company was killed yesterday when the frontend loader he was operating tumbled down a 76foot embankment. The vic tim was George O'Brien, 58 years old, of Plymouth Meeting.

title: MOBIL AND GETTY REPORT NET INCOME
description: The Mobile Oil Corporation and the Getty Oil Company an nounced yesterday sharply higher operating profits for the latest quarter.

title: JAMES PRESTON
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 24 James Preston, president of United States Mica Company in Stamford, was killed last night when a car he was driv ing near his home at Rowayton Beach here struck a utility pole. He was 61 years old.

title: FRENCH OBJECTIONS IN TRADE TALK EASED
description: PARIS, July 24  France made two conciliatory gestures toward the United States today, improving prospects for the multinational trade negotiations that are to open in Tokyo in September.

title: New 3Year Pact For City U. Faculty Accepted by Board
description: The Board of Higher Educa tion voted unanimously last night to accept a threeyear contract governing the salaries and terms of employment for the 16,000 faculty and staff members at the City University.

title: County Grand Jury Won't Study Sullivan Airport
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 24 Sullivan County District At torney Louis B. Scheinman said today that his office would not conduct a grandjury investiga tion into alleged wrongdoings in the building of the Sullivan County International Airport.

title: WORKING COUPLES HELD TAX VICTIMS
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Witnesses before the Congres sional Joint Economic Com mittee agreed today that the family units that suffered the greatest discrimination under the current tax law were mar ried couples in which both the husband and wife work.

title: State Halts Credit Card Sale of Admittedly Phony British Degree
description: Want an honorary doctor ate in law, music, divinity or almost anything else? For $25 to $100, depending on which magazine you read, you can get onealong with a disclaimer saying that it is absolutely useless and that it is definitely im moral, probably illegal, and maybe even fattening to pretend that it is real.

title: People in Sports: Bengal Eats Like Tiger
description: According to the New York City Consumer Affairs De partment, it cost an average of $7.54 a day to feed a fam ily of four last week. A Cin cinnati restaurant owner has calculated the rock bottom daily cost of feeding Pat Mat son, the 246pound Cincinnati Bengal guard, at $18.25.

title: ExAide Says Nixon Felt Office Raid Was Proper
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 John D. Ehrlichman said today that President Nixon felt it was well within both the consti tutional duty and obligation of the Presidency for White House aides to break into the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's for mer psychiatrist.

title: Television
description: SENATE WATERGATE HEARINGS TELEVISION

title: The New Highway Towns Nice Places to Go Through
description: AT THE INTERSECTION OF INTERSTATE 90 AND SOUTH DAKOTA 63, July 22 This town is officially nameless. It is unincorpor ated. It is on no map. But it could be a city of the future.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, July 24As a recreation vehicle the bicycle has enjoyed a surge of popularity in recent years. But the great mass of people who ride bicycles for fun should not be confused with the smallbut also growing band of hardy athletes who endure the rigors of organ ized bicycle racing.

title: CHILDREN SPURN A BLIND WIDOW, 71
description: Special to The New York Times

title: AQUEDUCT STRIKE HELPS MONMOUTH
Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: KENNEDY HAILED BY URBAN LEAGUE
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Speeches by Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan received opposite reactions today from a national Urban League con vention that is seeking new solutions to old problems in housing, education, health and jobs.

title: 9 Die in Scotland Hotel Fire
description: OBAN, Scotland, July 24 (Reuters) Nine persons died and 40 were injured when fire swept through a hotel in this western highlands town early today, the police said. At least 10 of the injured were reported to be in serious condition.

title: Italy Freezes Prices
description: ROME, July 24 (AP)  The Italian Cabinet today approved a decree putting a temporary freeze on a wide range of food and industrial prices and broad ening a rentfreeze law. The measure will stay in effect for 60 days.

title: Bonn to Open Talks on Ties With Bulgaria and Hungary
description: BONN, West Germany, July 24 (Reuters)  West Germany and Bulgaria are to open nego tiations here next week on es tablishing diplomatic relations, the Foreign Ministry said to day.

title: Beyond B. F. Skinner?
description: At one point in his controversial polemic, Beyond Freedom and Dignity, B. F. Skinner threw dust in our eyes. While addressing himself to various critiques of behaviorism, Professor Skinner dismissed Arthur Koestler's merely by observing that Koestler's paraphrase of behaviorist learn ing theory as a system of stimulus

title: Dairy Official Says Kalmbach Requested Gift After Trust Suit
description: CHICAGO, July 24 (AP)An official of the nation's largest dairy farmer cooperative said today that there was a striking coincidence of timing between a Justice Department antitrust suit against the cooperative and the cooperative's refusal to con tribute more money to Presi dent Nixon's reelection cam paign.

title: ExCuban Aide Is Seized On CocaineSelling Charges
description: A wtalthy former Cuban Government official who was granted asylum in Puerto Rico has been arrested for allegedly selling $2million worth of co caine to an undercover agent.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Hours are given in Eastern Daylight Time.

title: De Laurentiis to Shift His Base Here
description: The chauffeurdriven Rolls Royce purrs up to the door. Out springs Dino De Lauren tiis, movie mogul par excel lence, in an immaculate yel low suit, opennecked em broidered shirt and sunglass es. He is paying a rare visit to the set of his movie Ser pico, now being filmed in the Great Hall of New York's Chamber of Commerce build ing.

title: Handcuffed Boy, 12, Shot Dead In Squad Car by Dallas Officer
description: DALLAS, July 24  (AP) A 12yearold boy, handcuffed and seated next to a policeman in the front seat of a squad car, was shot to death today by an officer seated behind him, the police said.

title: Jersey Girl Sues the F.B.I. Over an Intercepted Letter
description: NEWARK, July 24A dam age suit has been filed in Federal District Court here charging the Federal Bureau of Investigation with intercept ing a letter written by a 15 yearold high school girl as part of a school project and with subsequently investigating her character and activities.

title: Senate Confirms 2 Aides
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nominations of Stanley B. Thomas of New York as an Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, and William L. Gifford of James town, N.Y., as Deputy Under Secretary of the Treasury. Mr. Thomas succeeds Patricia Reilly Hitt, who resigned, and Mr. Gifford succeeds James E. Smith, named Controller of the Currency.

title: Canadian Legislators Offer Congressmen a Proposal for Preventing Oil Spills
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  A Canadian Parliamentary del egation suggested to Congress today that Canada might meet the future crudeoil needs of American refineries in the Puget Sound area if United States tankers from Alaska would skirt the area and unload in California.

title: Major League Baseball Wednesday, July 25, 1973
description: American League

title: WITNESS DEFIANT
BLAST DAMAGES UNION QUARTERS Hospital Group Had Leased Space to ProCastro Unit
description: A powerful explosion in the Times Square area last night shook a labor union headquar ters where a proCastro group is to hold a fourday political and cultural exposition start ing tomorrow, a national holi day in Cuba under the govern ment of Premier Fidel Castro.

title: A New Kind of Watergate Witness
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Maybe there really are two Ehrlichmans, as a former White House associate in sists, but the Senate Water gate committe certainly saw only one of them today.

title: SAIL RACE HONORS TO FAIR AMERICAN
Text of Memo to Ehrlichman From Young on Plans for Investigation of Disclosure of Pentagon Papers
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Following is the text, as re leased by the Senate Water gate committee today, of a memo to John D. Ehrlich man from David R. Young Jr., who with Egil Krogh Jr. was in charge of the White House special investigating unit known as the plumb ers:

title: Instant Homes Even Spare Buyers the Decorating Problems
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.,  The buyers at a new $100 million waterfront housing complex here called Marina Pacifica won't need to pick out furniture before moving into their new homes. They won't have to choose dishes, place mats, silverware, ash trays, flower arrangements or painting for the walls either.

title: Rickenbacker Rites Set
description: A memorial service for Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, retired chairman of Eastern Air Lines and a World War I fighter ace, will be held at 2 P.M. on Fri day at the Key Biscayne (Fla.) Presbyterian Church. He died in Zurich on Monday at the age of 82. Survivors include his widow, Adelaide; two sons, David E of Upper Montclair, N. J., and William F., of Briar cliff Manor, N. Y.; two brothers, Louis and Albert W., and five grandchildren.

title: Peron's New Coalition: Even Old AntiPeronists Are Welcome as He Seemingly Abandons Left Wing
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 24He lives secluded in his suburban mansion visited only by his closest aides and the highest military leaders and Govern ment officials.

title: 2Strike Homers Draw Raves From an Old Hand
description: KANSAS CITY, July 24  Gene Mauch, who has been managing major league base ball teams longer than any one now active but Walter Alston is still able to get ex cited by a ball game, even when the game looks any thing but exciting to the naked eye.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 31859
description: Tickets matching the number win ??2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Earnings Climb 28.4%
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company rea lized a 28.4 per cent increase in secondquarter earnings on a sales gain of 22.3 per cent, bringing the halfyear gain for profit to 24.1 per cent and to 19.3 per cent for sales. The quarter's results set records, the company's report stated yesterday.

title: Aqueduct Shut Again Today; Strike Talks Show Progress
description: To the surprise of many ar riving customers, there was no racing at Aqueduct yesterday. And there will be no racing again today while represent atives of the New York Racing Association and the Interna tional Union of Operating En gineers, Local 15B, try to settle the workers strike, which be gan at midnight Monday.

title: HIJACKERS SEIZED AS THEY FREE 137 AND BLOW UP JET
description: BENGHAZI, Libya, July 24 Four men who hijacked a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet over the Netherlands and finally blew it up at the desert airport here were arrested by Libyan authorities today. The 137 passengers and crew members who had been hostages for three and a half days were taken to a resort hotel to rest.

title: Rockefeller Will Help City Raise Funds to Hold Fare
People and Business Patman Predicts Record Rates
description: We are headed toward period in which we will see the highest interest rates in the history of this nation, Representative Wright Pat man, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said yesterday.

title: Shortage of 10,000 Specialists in Public Health by 1980 Is Predicted in Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  A serious shortage of special ists in key areas of public health can be expected by the end of this decade, a professor who has made a nationwide study of this kind of manpower testified today.

title: Beame Garners Endorsement of 12 of City's Congressmen, but Not Badillo's
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor of New York, has won the endorsements of 12 of the 17 members of the city's Con gressional delegation after an unusual campaign of personally soliciting the support of most at the members.

title: U.N. Delays Mideast Meeting
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24The Security Council canceled its meeting on the Middle East today as members consulted with each other and their Governments on a resolu tion. The consultations sought a formula acceptable to Egypt that would avoid a United States veto. The meeting has been rescheduled for 10:30 A.M. tomorrow.

title: WHITE HOUSE FUND FACING ABOLITION
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The House Appropriations Commit tee voted today to wipe out the White House's traditional $1.5 million special projects fund, from which the Nixon Adminis tration paid, among other things, the $100aday consulting fee of E. Howard Hunt Jr., the con victed Watergate conspirator.

title: Colonels Choice
description: Spokesmen for the ruling junta in Greece have warned that a no vote in Sunday's referendum would lead to direct military dictatorship.

title: 2 IN NORWAY KILLING TIED TO ISRAEL UNIT
description: OSLO, Norway, July 25  Police officials said here to night that two of five foreign ers arrested for the murder of a Moroccan in the town of Lillehammer last Saturday had stated that they belonged to an Israeli counterterrorist organ ization.

title: Bergen County Inmates Are Finally Getting a Place Under the Sun
description: HACKENSACK, July 25 Prisoners in the Bergen County Jail are finally get ting a place in the sun. Sher iff Joseph F. Job, a frequent critic of the 63yearold in stitution's lack of recreation al facilities, has had an out door area created where the prisoners can look at the sky through the leaves of a tree rather than iron bars.

title: All Eyes on Aaron's Assault On Ruth HomeRun Record
description: ATLANTA  The great est sports story in history is taking place in Atlanta, says the press booklet on Henry Aaron issued by the Atlanta Braves.

title: Phnom Penh Outskirts Shelled by Reds
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 25  Communist forces shelled the outskirts of Phnom Penh tonight, in what appeared to be a terror attack on the civilian population. Some of the shells landed inside the capital itself in the western sector. Early reports indicated that at least seven people had been killed and 20 wounded, but these reports were incomplete and the toll was likely to rise.

title: Youth Corps Bill Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) About 100 teenagers filled a Senate committee room to day to urge approval of a bill expanding the Youth Conserva tion Corps from 3,500 to 150, 000 youths. The corps was es tablished in 1971 to provide summer jobs for youths aged 15 to 18.

title: TONE IS SOFTENED
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  John D. Ehrlichman categoric ally denied today a series of charges linking him to the Watergate coverup and insist ed that he never sought Presi dent Nixon's pledge of execu tive clemency for the conspira tor E. Howard Hunt Jr.

title: Ervin and Lawyer in Clash On Powers of Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The testimony of John D. Ehrlich man before the Senate's Water gate committee was delayed for nearly an hour today while the committee chairman and Mr. Ehrlichman's lawyer conducted a scholarly debate on wheth er a President had the inherent power to break the law to de fend the nation against a threat to its security.

title: MEYER HALPERN
description: Meyer Halpern, a New York lawyer and president emeritus the New York Civil and Criminal Courts Bar Associa tion, died yesterday. He was 75 years old and lived at 5 Tudor City Place.

title: 2 JETS GO TO LIBYA FOR PASSENGERS
description: BENGHAZI, Libya, July 25 (AP)Two Japan Air Lines jet liners were directed to Libya today to pick up 137 persons who went through a threeand ahalfday air piracy that ended with their plane's being blown up here.

title: ALFRED BENO OSHINS
description: Alfred Beno Oshins, a knit wear manufacturer, died, appar ently of a heart attack, Sunday. He was 60 years old and lived at 1050 Park Avenue and in Westhampton Beach, L. I.

title: AFGHAN PLEDGES NO SUBSERVIENCE
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 25 (AP)  The head of Afghani ztan's new republican Govern ment said today that his re gime would not be subservient to any other country. He em phatically denied that his coup last week was prompted by the Soviet Union.

title: 4 Busy Percussionists Excel At Philharmonic Park Concert
description: The third week of New York Philharmonic concerts in the park opened with a bang at the Sheep Meadow on Tuesday night, not to mention the as sorted thunks, bongs and whirs that are a prime feature of Wil liam Kraft's Concerto for Four Percussion Soloists and Orches tra. The program, conducted by Henry Lewis, also contained two folkinfluenced favorites, Dvorak's E minor Symphony, From the New World, and Bruch's Scottish Fantasy, which had Berl Senofsky as violin soloist.

title: Chess: Defying All Snafus, Interzonal Stumbles to a Start in Brazil
description: PETROPOLIS, Brazil, July 25The second Interzonal chess tournament for world championship aspirants, scheduled to begin here last Sunday, has started off as a huge game of Kriegspiel.

title: Ehrlichman Says Hoover Should Have Been Ousted
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  President Nixon should have dismissed J. Edgar Hoover as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation early in his Presidency, John D. Ehrlichman asserted today.

title: ST AUTNER LEADING JUNIOR SAIL SERIES
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 25  The Indian Harbor Yacht Club crew, captained by John Stautner, took a twopoint lead today in the 50th annual junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound. The first four races in the final series were sailed off Indian Harbor, with one more to be sailed tomor row.

title: Designer Declares It's Time To Relax
description: PARIS, July 25Yves Saint Laurent really should hold classes to show other design ers how it's done without dancing girls, music or other histrionics. And then he should adapt the lesson plan for women who are distracted and distressed by the crazy world of fashion.

title: Zwach Won't Run Again
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  Representative John M. Zwach, Republican of Minne sota, said today that he would retire at the end of his current term, his fourth in the House. An important factor in my decision not to seek reelection ?? the doctor's order to reduce my strenuous pace, Mr. Zwach, 66 years old, said. To do the job right demands tremendous input.

title: U.S. ADMITS IT HAS AIDES IN CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) The State Department ac knowledged today that Ameri can civilian officials were operating in Cambodia to pro vide information on the military situation there, but it denied that they were engaged in any paramilitary activities.

title: A Family Argument Over Salary Rises Divides the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 The United States Senate spent a long afternoon today in a family argument about money  its own members $42,500ayear salaries. In a fourhour freeforall all, there were no winners.

title: Law and the President
description: LONDON, July 25President Nixon's argument against letting the Water gate investigators hear his secret tapes rests, in the end, on the premise that the President must decide on his own where the public interest lies. He has played the tapes and given his judg ment. His discretion must be absolute.

title: Educator Scores Fellow Blacks For Failure to Take Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 The dean of a black school of social work said today that black persons had a share of blame for their lack of control in their own communities.

title: Soviet Crackdown Deplored by Boll, Nobel Prize Writer
description: BONN, July 25  Heinrich Bll, the West German Nobel Prizewinning author, has spoken out sharply against what he sees as a renewed cam paign of repression against in tellectuals and writers in the Soviet Union and is now warn ing his readers of the dangers of fellow traveling with cold warriors.

description: MARSEILLES, France, July 21 (AP)The Government of this Mediterranean port city has approved construction of a subway system to be com pleted by 1977. The system will have 12 stations and five miles of track.

Y., July 25  Eight nations intro duced a resolution in the Se curity Council today that de plored Israel's occupation of territories taken in 1967 and expressed serious concern at Israel's lack of cooperation with Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the special representative of Secre tary General Waldheim.

description: CINCINNATI, July 25 (AP) Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds claimed today that Bill Singer of the California Angels threw four straight spitballs in last night's AllStar game. Rose said he protested to Nestor Chylak, the plate umpire.

description: BUENOS AIRES, July 25 On a recent afternoon, a group of friendsall of them middle class young professionals and fervent leftwing followers of former Argentine dictator, Juan D. Pernsat down for a bar becue on the lawn of a sub urban house here.

description: WASHINGTON, July 25 The twoincome family pays the most in Social Security taxes and, proportionally, gets the least back, a witness be fore the Joint Economic Com mittee of Congress said today.

title: Moncada Plus 20
description: Fidel Castro and the Cuba he rules celebrate today the twentieth anniversary of his abortive attack on the Moncado Army Barracks in Santiago de Cuba, the date that is now conventionally taken as the start of the Castro movement. There will be a great celebration in Cuba and no doubt much militant rhetoric from Fidel himself. The emotions involved were unfortunately echoed in the heart of New York night before last when a bomb exploded in a building where proCastro forces planned to hold a political and cultural exposition to mark the Moncada anniversary.

title: Tourists See Suicide
description: LAS VEGAS, July 25 (Reu ters)  Dozens of tourists watched a man strip to his underpants and leap to his death over a cliff last night. The police said the man plunged 300 feet from the cliff overhanging the Colorado River. His body has not been recovered.

description: The stock market climbed sharply yesterday in the heav iest trading in five months. The DowJones industrial average rose 14.30 points to close at 933.02. Page 53.

The participants were John J. Wilson, the attorney for John D. Ehrlichman; Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. and Senator Howard H. Baker Jr.

description: HALEDON, July 25Denise Wood is quite an athlete. She doesn't have a coach and many times practices in her backyard.

The daily selling rate of 34,492 cars compared with 30,475 last year and the 1971 record of 32,624. Ford's dealers sold 69,136 cars, off 12 per cent from 78,544 a year ago.

description: NEWARK, July 25  A re quest for a temporary injunc tion to halt the scheduled fingerprinting of more than 40 eighthgrade boys in a murder investigation was denied today by a Federal judge.

title: A 'Spaghetti Western' Without Meat:The Cast
description: "Deaf Smith & Johnny Ears," the Italian-made, English-language horse opera shot in Spain that clattered aimlessly into local houses yesterday, is as limp an example of the so-called "spaghetti Western" as has turned up in recent memory. Anthony Quinn and Franco Nero are the titular heroes who stop Franco Graziosi, as a would-be dictator, from taking Texas from President Sam Houston in 1836. They are ineffectually involved in an ersatz adventure that is neither as explosive or as funny as most movies in the genre it tries to emulate or lampoon.The gimmick here, if you have not already guessed, is Mr. Quinn playing a deaf-mute whose "ears" are supplied by his tough sidekick, Mr. Nero. As a veteran movie vaquero, Mr. Quinn is properly saddle-weary and weath-erbeaten in a floppy sombrero and a worn, dusty Prince Albert frock coat. He is also handy with his fists, sticks of dynamite, a Gatling gun and rudimentary sign language. Unfortunately, neither he nor the action has much to communicate to a willing viewer.Mr. Nero, handsome if unshaven, projects an overacted machismo that is pointless, especially when it is channeled toward comedy that rarely registers and Pamela Tiffin is merely naive as a pouting, babyish blond prostitute. "Deaf Smith & Johnny Ears" also has a couple of scenes in an ornate bagnio seemingly inspired by Toulouse-Lautrec, but they are no reason to visit this simulation of frontier Texas.

title: Theodore, Injured Met, Discharged by Hospital
description: George Theodore of the Metz, who suffered a dislo cated hip in an outfield col lision with Don Hahn during a game July 7 in Shea Stad ium, has been released from Roosevelt Hospital.

The par ents wanted Daniel to sever his ties with the New Testament Missionary Fellowship, a religious group.

title: The Soviet Grain Deal
description: The dramatic confrontation this week in Washington between the Department of Agriculture and the major grain exporters leaves the question of responsibility for the Soviet graindeal fiasco very much up in the air. Depending upon whom one chooses to believe, the depart ment either knew all about the huge Soviet grain pur chases a year ago and chose to hide the facts from the public and the farmers, or the department was duped by the grain exporters who not only kept secret the Soviet purchases but even filed false reports to maintain their security. The contradictions are as vivid as any thing in the conflicting testimony being heard about Watergate; like Watergate, the full facts about last year's Soviet grain purchases need to be brought out into the open.

description: The Secretary General of the Organization for Eco nomic Cooperation and De velopment said yesterday na tions that buy American grain should have a voice in decid ing how it will be allocated during periods of shortage.

title: One Morning at Moncada
description: LONDONThe revolution was born at Moncada, said Celia Sanchez, who has been Fidel Castro's closest asso ciate since the guerrilla days of the Sierra Maestra. She was referring to the desperate attack against almost hopeless odds led by Castro against the Moncada Barracks in Santiago de Cuba twenty years ago, on July 26, 1953. Cuba is having one of its big gestever celebrations today.

title: U.S. Judge Calls a Truce in L.I. Sound Fishing War
