title: Huston's 'Mackintosh Man,' Espionage Film, Opens
description: John Huston's new film, "The Mackintosh Man," is an espionage melodrama torn from the headlines20 years late.It's about a secret agent (Paul Newman), employed by British intelligence to capture a master spy whoit turns out quite early onis an influential Member of Parliament, a law-and-order Tory (played with great charm by James Mason) who rants on about complacency and permissiveness and the ebbing of traditional values.The trap requires a lot of planning (some of it so cryptic as to be intentionally comic), several carefully manufactured false identities, a spectacular prison break and locales that shift from London to Ireland to Malta (though the editing is so odd you may not be immediately aware that a shift has been made)."The Mackintosh Man" is, technically, an espionage melodrama, but it strikes me more as a memory movie. It's not about memory, heaven knows. Nothing so fashionable. Rather it seems to have been made from memory, recalling, as it does, Burgess and MacLean, the cold war and especially cold war movies, every possible variant on which has already been made, including the post-cold war movie like "Scorpio" (about spies who no longer care).The screenplay by Walter Hill, adapted from Desmond Bagley's novel, "The Freedom Trap," has very little to do with character and motivation and everything to do with the incidents and the mechanics of the spy trade. All of which seems to inhibit Huston's talents as a director, as well as those of most of his actors. They must express themselves entirely in terms of physical action and expository dialogue that, here, aim for complexity and arouse only confusion.Part of this confusion may be the result of the soundtrack. Three-quarters of the way through the film I was ready to admit that wax had impaired my hearing. That is, until Dominique Sanda, who also plays an intelligence agent, reading aloud from a newspaper reported that a reception would be held for diplomatic and "shersh dig-nah-TREES," which turned out to be her way of saying "church dignitaries.""The Mackintosh Man" may have you sitting on the edge of your seat from time to time. More often, I suspect, you'll be cupping a hand to an ear.The film opened yesterday at the Loews State 2 and Loews Orpheum theaters.

title: New Housing Plan Rouses Wyandanch
description: WYANDANCH, L.I., July 25 Last Sunday at a nearby Ro man Catholic Church, a young woman spoke from the altar in favor of a housing plan for this mostlyblack community. Mean while, a young man outside was collecting signatures from white parishoners against the plan.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: KING LEAR, the New York Shakespeare Festival production. At the Delacorte Theater, Central Park and West 81st Street, 8, through Aug. 26.

title: Notes on People Gov. Holton's Haunted Mansion
description: While it is common enough to assume a politician has skeletons in his closet or bats in his belfry, it is un usual for a Governor to re port that there is a ghost in his executive mansion. Gov. Linwood Holton of Virginia gave the ghostly ex planation for footsteps he said he heard the other night in the north side of the man sion at Richmond. He said he left his bedroom to investi gate the noise, but found no one, and that on returning to his bedroom he found that several paintings had been in explicably moved. One of the Governor's aides noted that other governors of Virginia have also reported ghosts in the mansion. Governor Hol ton said he had no plans for the removal.

title: Screen: 'Badge 373,' With Eddie Egan:Ex-Detective Has Role, but Not of Himself The Cast
description: As you might guess from the title, "Badge 373" is a police melodrama. According to the distributors, Paramount Pictures, it is based on the "real-life career" of a former New York City detective, Eddie Egan  whose real-life career has been the basis of movies before this.I suspect it is also based just a bit on some real-life fantasies. Eddie Egan is featured in the movie not as himself  a suspended New York cop named Eddie Ryanbut as a police lieutenantScanlon  who might have been the real-life Eddie's boss. Pete Hamill, the reporter who wrote the screenplay, also shows up. He plays a sympathetic reporter named Pete.These performances, especially the lackluster one by Eddie Egan, provide an aura of amateurishness for "Badge 373," an aura that neither Robert Duvall, as the cop Eddie, nor Verna Bloom, as his girl Maureen, nor Henry Darrow, as the villainous Sweet William, does anything at all to dispel.Sweet William, who may very well be the worst-written role in recent movies, is a Harvard-educated Puerto Rican who quotes Gide; makes his living from whores, drugs and contraband machine guns; and occupies a secret sumptuous book-lined palace hidden inside a wholesale meat plant right on the edge of the Hudson River.This last location introduces an intentional unreality, in contrast to the unintentional unreality of everything else in the movieas if the people who made "Badge 373" were unsure whether they wanted to rip off "The French Connection" or "Dr. No."The former more than the latter, I should think. The movie is full of gratuitous authenticity (the vehicle in its inept big chase sequence is a 14th Street crosstown bus), with fears and prejudices right off the city streets. All the evil is perpetrated by Puerto Ricans, either innocent but violent revolutionaries who run around shouting "Puerto Rico Libre!" or the uninnocent but equally violent nonrevolutionaries who manipulate them. Against such forces, Eddie the hard-nosed cop has only the instincts of his personal bigotry to guide him. And invariably the instincts of his personal bigotry turn out to be right.There is absolutely nothing to praise in "Badge 373"from Howard Koch's helpless direction to the dumpy performances by all the castbut Pete Hamill's screenplay has at least the interest of its overblown prose (Sweet William gets all the lines; nobody else can manage much more than monosyllables) and its curiously devious intentions.At some level, the screenplay means to make use of racial prejudices, expressing them but not endorsing them, and enjoying a free ride through current anxieties that ought to be worth something at the box office. This strategy fails completely. The potential tragedy of conflicting cultures becomes the exploitation of one and the debasement of the other. And unless you care to hate Puerto Ricans (or Irish cops) I don't see how the movie can have anything for you."Badge 373" opened yesterday at the Loews State I, Loews Cine and neighborhood theaters.

title: Connally Resigns as Adviser to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  President Nixon announced to day the resignation of former Gov. John B. Connally of Texas as an unpaid, parttime Presi dential adviser.

title: People in Sports: Healthy Mackey Retires
description: I'm walking away from this game healthy, noted John, Mackey as he an nounced his retirement from a 10year pro football career. One of the most familiar sights of the 1960's was Mackey taking a short pass from John Unitas, then bouncing off or bowling over five or six tacklers on his way to the end zone.

title: Other Producers Gain
description: Stewart S. Cort, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corpo ration, reported yesterday that net income for the second quarter this year totaled $57.9 million, or $1.32 a share, up sharply from a net of $36.9 million, or 83 cents a share a year earlier.

title: Dayton Tire Recall
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 25 (AP) The Dayton Tire and Rubber Company announced today the recall of 5,013 tires in an ef fort to find an estimated 724 that the firm said might be defective. The company de scribed the tires as Thorobred Premium 78, 2  plus  2 belted small tires in sizes A7813 C7814, G7814 and G7815. It listed tires bearing these serial numbers as defective: HXF5H NL063, HFX5HNL073, HFX5 HNK073, HXLIHNK063, HXL IHNK073, HXL9HNK063, HXL 9HNK073 and HXVVHNLO63.

title: NIXON MAY APPOINT RUCKELSHAUS TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  William D. Ruckelshaus will be nominated tomorrow by the White House to become the Nixon Administration's third Deputy Attorney General, ac cording to Justice Department sources.

title: Secretariat and Linda's Chief: A Match?
description: The possibility of a match race between the Triple Crown winner, Secretariat of the Meadow Stable, and Linda's Chief, will be dis cussed at Aqueduct today. Mrs. John (Penny) Tweedy, who directs the racing activ ities of the Meadow Stable, will attend the discussions.

title: Bubba Smith Brings Smile From the Sphinx
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., July 25Bubba Smith, carrying a svelte 255 pounds on his 6 foot 8inch frame, charged. The offensive line bent and broke. Smith, who could claim to be the best defensive line man in football, has arrived in the West and now wears the silver and black of the Oakland Raiders, a team with au dacious Super Bowl pretensions.

title: Books of The Times
description: In quite a few recent novels, I've noticed a growing impatience with human nature, a tendency to try to plumb it by way of shortcuts, using the sort of ellipsis that certain drugs are supposed to encourage. It has become a common thing for an au thor to push his characters to their ex tremist limits without passing through the gradations of behavior that would enable them to arrive there with a degree of credi bility. You might call this new style a literature of ontological leaps. Every char acter a kangaroo. Just as few people walk these days if they can ride, so few authors wish to be seen slogging from here to there. Cinematic cuts and shorthand psyches are all the rage. Like the biscuits mother used to bake, the oldfashioned, fullblown, homemade personality is be coming a thing of the past.

title: POLICE SUSTAINED ON FINGERPRINTS U.S. Court Says Pupils Must Comply in Jersey Inquiry
description: NEWARK, July 25  A re quest for a temporary injunc tion to halt the scheduled fingerprinting of more than 40 eighthgrade boys in a murder investigation was denied today by a Federal judge.

title: PORT AUTHORITY GIRDS FOR TIEUP
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yes terday that it was taking steps to prevent a shutdonw of Ken nedy, La Guardia, and Newark airports tomorrow if a walk out threatened by the author ity's police force is carried through.

title: Judge Here Rules Raids On Cambodia Are Illegal
description: A Federal District Court Judge in Brooklyn ruled yester day that the Government must halt the American bombing of Cambodia on the ground that it is unauthorized and unlaw ful.

title: Times Declares Dividend
description: A quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share was declared yesterday by The New York Times on its Class A and B common stock, payable Sept. 26 to holders of record on Sept. 12. A $1.375ashare dividend was also declared on the 5 per cent cumulative prior preference stock, payable Oct. 1 to stockholders of record on Sept. 12.

title: With Facts, Jokes and Moralizing, Local Lawyers and Judges Woo 350 Law Students to Practice Here
description: Dozens of local judges and lawyers tried yesterday to con vince 350 law students from around the country to return to New York City next year to practice law.

title: Big Refiners Report
description: Oil company earnings reports continued to provide an em barrassment of riches for the industry as sharply higher prof its were announced yesterday by a number of companies.

title: Confirmation Plan Backed
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) The Senate passed, 91 to 2, today a bill requiring that Presidential appointments of six Interior Department offi cials be subject to Senate con firmation. The officials af fected are the head of the Min ing Enforcement and Safety Administration, the Commis sioner of Reclamation, the Governor of American Samoa and the directors of the Bureau of Land Management, the Na tional Park Service and the Bureau of Outdoor Recreation.

title: Bond Prices Tumble as Pressure Rises on Interest Rates
CITY FACING LOSS OF EDUCATION AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 New York City stands to lose millions in Federal funds for educationally deprived children in the 1974 fiscal year under budget restrictions imposed by the Nixon Administration.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Hours are given in Eastern Daylight Time.

title: Cotton Leaves Hospital
description: HANOVER, N.H., July 25 (AP) Senator Norris Cotton was released from Mary Hitchcock Hospital today, five days after he had been admitted for fa tigue and anemia. A hospital spokesman said the New Hamp shire Republican was in good health and would return to Washington Monday.

title: Rickenbacker Base Urged
description: LOCKBOURNE AIR FORCE BASE, Ohio, July 25 (AP)0f ficials here say they have been asked to change the base's name to the Eddie Rickenbacker Air Force Base to honor the World War I hero who died this week at the age of 82.

title: MUCH U.S. WHEAT LISTED FOR EXPORT
description: The Government shocked the nation's grain traders again yesterday by announcing that more than half the expected American wheat crops this year had been booked for ex port as of July 6. The wheat crop year starts July 1.

title: FUMING L.I. TELLER SNUFFS OUT A FUSE
description: GREAT NECK, LI, July 25 A young woman bank teller who became annoyed after her bank was robbed today for the second time in less than two months dashed from the bank to stamp out the lighted fuse of a pipe bomb that had been left at the entrance by the flee ing robber.

title: Fish War on Sound Is Halted by Court
description: NEW HAVEN, July 25  A temporary truce was called here today in a battle between commercial fishing interests and sports fishermen over whose right it is to fish close to the Connecticut shore in Long Island Sound. At stake is the future of the state's growing sportfishing industry.

title: Women's Club Names Head
description: BOSTON, July 21 (AP)A Florida court reporter has been named 197374 president of the Pilot Club International, a service club for women. Mrs. Mary Ruth Hauser of Coral Gables, Fla., was installed Thursday night. The club held its 52nd annual convention here.

title: Injury Puts A's Hunter Out 10 Days
description: KANSAS Cm', July 25 Dick Williams, the manager of the world champion Oakland A's, left the scene of baseball's 44th AllStar Game today with two setbacks: His Amer ican League team lost for the 10th time in 11 years and his Oakland team lost Jim (Cat fish) Hunter for two weeks.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Former Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was slightly injured when his car hit a guardrail on the New Jersey Turnpike, authorities said.

title: EXAIR SECRETARY DISCLAIMS A ROLE IN SECRET BOMBING
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The former Secretary of the Air Force and the fourstar gen eral who was serving as the Air Force's Vice Chief of Staff in 1969 told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that they had not been informed of the secret B52 bombing raids in Cambodia.

title: SMITH AND OKKER ADVANCE AT NET
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)Topseeded Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., had little difficulty today in disposing of Brian Gottfried, 63, 63, in the second round of the Washing ton StarNews tennis tourna ment.

title: MOSES ACCLAIMS JERSEY CITY PLAN
Powell Refuses to Block Mrs. Ryan's Extradition
description: United States Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. re fused yesterday to block ex tradition of Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, the Mas peth, Queens, housewife want ed in West Germany on charges of crimes against in mates of concentration camps in World War II.

title: More Analysts Think Rally Will Last
description: The stock market stretched out its best rally of 1973 yesterday as Wall Street pondered this puzzler: Is the rally for real?

title: Winner's Moves Put Spirit in Jet Defense
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.. July 25 The oneness that Joe Namath said he detected on the Jets defense this training camp is as much spiritual as it is, physical.

title: HARRY R. FARDWELL
description: Harry P. Fardwell, who re tired in 1968 as secretary and treasurer of the Otis Elevator Company, died Tuesday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 71 years old.

title: F.B.I. ACTION HELD PERIL TO STUDIES
description: MENDHAM, July 25  The social studies department chair man at West MorrisMendham High School said today that an alleged investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of one of his pupils could hinder his students desire to seek out answers to political questions.

title: Ervin and Lawyer in Clash On Powers of Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The testimony of John D. Ehrlich man before the Senate's Water gate committee was delayed for nearly an hour today while the committee chairman and Mr. Ehrlichman's lawyer conducted a scholarly debate on wheth er a President had the inherent power to break the law to de fend the nation against a threat to its security.

title: King Kong Is Recast For a Tourist Show
description: Just 11 blocks front the Empire State Building, where King Kong was shot down for the love of Fay Wray, is the fourstory gray factory of Messmore and Damon, and it is here that the great ape is being reborn.

title: Radio
description: 9:0610 A.M., WQXR: Piano Per sonalities. Dame Myra Hess and Alfred Cortot. Piano Sonata in A flat (Op. 110), Beethoven; Waltzes, Nos. 10 through 14, Chopin.

title: NET INCOME RAISED BY NEW YORK PHONE
description: The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday higher net income and operating revenues for the second quarter ended June 30. Net totaled $76.6million, or 41 cents a share, compared with $65.5mil lion, or 40 cents a share in the same quarter of 1972.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 7:30 P.M.

title: Expansion of AsianAmerican Studies on U.S. Campuses Reflects Growth of Ethnic Consciousness
description: At a time of rising ethnic consciousness, studies in the, experience of Asians in America are appearing on campuses throughout the country.

title: Expert on the Constitution Studies Executive Privilege
description: CONCORD, MassRaoul Berger thinks of himself as a Dutch housemaid sweeping out dark corners of the Con stitution. Impeachment, for example, was a dark corner until Mr. Berger wrote the first comprehensive book about it. Now the dust is flying around executive privilege.

title: HOUSE ACTS TO CUT PRESIDENT'S RIGHT TO IMPOUND FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 25A bill to curb the President's power to impound funds ap propriated by Congress cleared the House late today after two days of lively debate. The vote was 254 to 164.

title: Dave Anderson Mike Burke: Image, Irony and Intrigue
description: With his mod mane of silver hair, Mike Burke will be inaugurated today as the president of Madison Square Garden Center in the famous arena's Hall of Fame lounge, surrounded by plaques of nearly 100 athletes and pro moters. To those in the Garden clientele who watch only the scoreboard, Mike Burke won't really be that important. To them, Willis Reed and Brad Park and Muhammad Ali represent the Garden, not someone behind a desk, no matter how fashionable his tailor may be. But to those in the Garden clientele who also watch the stock market, Mike Burke represents hope. Especially for that anonymous little man at the Garden stockholders annual meeting two months ago. He had come to hear Irving Mitchell Felt, the board chairman, seek ap proval for a reverse 1for5 split to improve the image of the Garden stock, then selling at less than 2 to anyone daring enough to buy it. Free coffee and doughnuts had been provided for the stockholders, perhaps to keep them swallowing and chewing instead of shouting. But at his seat in, oddly enough, the Felt Forum, the anonymous little man stood up to complain of mismanagement, since the Garden stock had been at a high of 14 six years ago before the transfer to the new building. As he spoke, he held a cup of coffee.

title: Gasner's, on Foley Square, Closes Doors
description: The auctioneer held up a green glass  Lot 44  and resumed his machine  gun patter.

title: Thanom Criticizes U.S. Report Linking Thai Officials to Drugs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 25Thailand's Premier, Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn, has formally criticized a United States Congressional report that accused Thai officals of at least tacit complicity in the huge narcotics traffic here.

title: 5 in Coast Guard Here Accused of Plot to Kill Agents
description: Five Coast Guard enlisted men stationed on Governors Island were charged yesterday with having conspired to mur der two Coast Guard intelli gence agents. The agents were investigating the five in con nection with the illegal sale of narcotics, the Coast Guard said.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A children's circus, direct ed by a priest, will begin a fourmonth tour of the Unit ed States, Canada and Mex ico in September. Called Los Muchachosthe Internation al Boys Circus, it is being presented by A.B.C. Enter tainment, the entertainment division of A.B.C. Television, and the Shubert organization. Herbert Wasserman is the producer. This is the group's first North American visit after numerous European ap pearances.

title: The Dance Ballet Influence Noted in Cubiculo Program
description: No surer proof of the con cluded war between ballet and modern dance could be given than the Cubiculo's final summer program on Tuesday evening. Of the six pieces presented by modern dance choreographers, four showed use of the ballet vo cabulary to a greater or lesser degree.

title: Fund Law Puzzles Jersey Candidates
description: TRENTON, July 25Candi dates for public office in New Jersey began filing their first reports this week under a cam paign disclosure law that pleases no one.

title: Giants Nitka Puts a Foot Into Picture
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 25Rookies in pro sports usually come in two categories: shy, inarticulate and lacking confidence or brash, articulate and over confident.

title: Judge Here Rules Raids On Cambodia Are Illegal
description: A Federal District Court Judge in Brooklyn ruled yester day that the Government must halt the American bombing of Cambodia on the ground that it is unauthorized and unlaw ful.

title: Title I Federal Aid Approved Here. Under a Formula Excluding 37 City Schools
description: The Board of Education yes terday approved the allocation of Federal Title I funds for the coming year under a new for mula that drops 37 schools from the program, which aids institutions with large numbers of children from poor families.

title: MILTON QUINN DEAD; A REALESTATE AIDE
description: Milton Quinn, vice president of HelmsleySpear, Inc., the realestate organization, died at New York University Hos pital, on Sunday. He was 55 years old and lived at 137 East 36th Street.

title: ADOLF HOFFMEISTER, CZECH ARTIST, DEAD
description: PRAGUE, July 25 (Reuters) Adolf Hoffmeister, a lead ing Czechoslovak cultural fig ure, officially held in disgrace since 1968 because of his support for the liberal reforms of Alexander Dubcek, died to day of a heart ailment. He was 70 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 7:30 P.M.

title: Gasoline Supplies Are Up For Third Week, A.A.A. Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) The American Automobile Association said yesterday that gasoline supplies to service sta tions across the United States increased for the third consecu tive week last week.

title: Chris Evert and Linda Tuero Gain in Cleveland Tennis
description: CLEVELAND, July 25 (AP) Chris Evert and Linda Tuero advanced today to the quarter finals of the $25,000 Marie O. Clark memorial tennis tourna ment.

title: Fire Kills 30,000 Chickens
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., July 25 (UPI) A fire yesterday destroyed 30,000 chickens and 72,000 eggs on a poultry farm in northern Illinois. The fire swept through a 366footlong building housing the entire eggproducing opera tion at the Fruin poultry farm near Stillman Valley, about 10 miles south of here.

title: Ellsberg Denies FatherinLaw Was Ever a Friend of Hoover
description: Dr. Daniel Ellsberg said last night that his father  in  law, Louis Marx, had never been a friend of J. Edgar Hoover, the late director of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation, which is contrary to the statements by John D. Ehrlichman that their friendship had caused Mr. Hoo ver to curtail investigating the Ellsberg case.

title: Cleveland Mayor Accused of Assaulting a Policeman
description: CLEVELAND, July 25Mayor Ralph J. Perk was charged to day with assault and battery on a Cleveland policeman and will appear before Judge Lillian Burke in Municipal Court to morrow or Friday.

title: Advertising: 2 for Recreation
description: Two magazine publishers on opposite coasts are cary ing out their pieces of the burgeoning recreational mar ket. For Ronald Hagen of San Francisco, it's the bi cyclist, while William Kems ley of New York is after the overnight hiker.

title: Volcker Sees Little, 'If Any, Net Cash Financing Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The Treasury offered today a new 20year bond bearing 71/2 per cent interest, the highest of any Federal Government bond now outstanding, available to the general public for a mini mum purchase of $1,000.

title: RACIAL STRIFE ISTIED TO MELEE AT PRISON
description: A disturbance involving about, 160 youthful Inmates at the Correctional Center for Med ical Services in Beacon, N. Y., may have been caused by dif ferences between black groups or by differences between blacks and Puerto Ricans, Dr. Paul C. Agnew, superintendent of the facility said yesterday.

title: Senate Panel Backs Budget Reform Bill; Changes Study Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 A Senate subcommittee ap proved today a budget reform bill aimed at giving Congress, tighter control over its spend ing decision,s, and thus, at giv ing the President fewer oppor tunities and reasons for over riding Congress on spending matters.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND, CanadaIt is difficult to talk of trout and salmon in a gathering of big game an glers just back from a day of trolling for giant bluefin tuna, but it was finally ac complished, and H. Arthur Smith, a biologist for the province's Fish and Wildlife Division, volunteered to take Jack Samson of Manhattan and me flyfishing on the Morrell River.

title: Equity Financing
description: Virginia Electric and Power Company yester day announced plans to sell about $90 to $95million in common stock in a negotiated public offering, comanaged by Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch, on Sept. 26. The company's stock closed at 19, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CUBA EXPOSITION SET FOR TONIGHT
description: Sponsors of a proCastro po litical and cultural exposition vowed yesterday that the event would open on schedule this evening, despite an explosion Tuesday night that seriously damaged the midtown union headquarters building where it is to take place.

title: Britain Plans Insider Dealing Rules
description: LONDON, July 25  The British Government announced today that it planned to revise the Companies Act to outlaw insider dealings and provide stockholders with information about the finances and prequi sites of the directors of their companies.

title: London Times, in Shift, Scores Nixon on Not Releasing Tapes
description: LONDON, July 25  Presi dent Nixon's refusal to release the tape recordings of his con versations about the Watergate case was criticized today by The Times of London, which had been one of his most sym pathetic supporters in the controversy.

title: PENSION DETAILS EMERGE IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, July 25Pensions for government employes based on their final three years aver age salary were called for to day by the State Senate major ity leader, Warren M. Anderson of Binghamton, as he disclosed details of a pension reform package expected to be passed at the special session of the

title: Nothing Like Pro Football To Whet One's Appetite
description: The more than 10 million fans who saw National Football League games last season, con sumed more than 5 million hot dogs.

title: OneWeek Rise in Pork Prices Called the Largest Since 1966
description: The State Department of Ag riculture and Markets yesterday reported the steepest and broadest advances of pork prices in the metropolitan area in a one week period since it began issuing consumer infor mation reports in 1966.

title: CON EDISON VOWS STORM KING START Says It Will Break Ground for Project in November After 10Year Fight
description: After a heated 10year legal battle with environmentalists, Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that it would break ground in Novem ber for its controversial Storm King hydroelectric power plant on the Hudson River 40 miles from New York City.

title: WEISKOPF ATTAINS WINNING OUTLOOK
description: MONTREAL, July 25  I don't expect a letdown, as serted Tom Weiskopf, recent winner of the British Open as he prepared for tomorrow's start in the Canadian open golf championship. There's no doubt in my mind now that I can winn all the major cham pionships.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., said yesterday that it had re ceived an order valued at about $55million to supply a 1,000 megawatt nuclear steam sup ply system and associated fuel to the Washington Public Power Supply System of Rich land, Wash.

title: VIETCONG REFUSE DISSIDENT GROUP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25The Government tried but failed to turn over Tran Ngoc Chau, a former legislator and friend of many American advisers, to the Vietcong on Monday, according to sources familiar with the case.

title: Byrne Is Endorsed by Williams And 7 Democratic Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Pledging to create a close co operative spirit between Tren ton and Washington to shake the Federal money tree, Bren dan T. Byrne, Democratic can didate for Governor of New Jersey, won endorsements and pledges of campaign support today from Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. and seven of the states eight Democratic members of the House.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 Twentytwo years after the great debate over sending American troops to Europe, another fundamental debate has arisen in Congress over bringing some of them back.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: Sacramento, Calif.  Monroe Brooks, 135 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Juan Collad, 135, Mexico, 1 round.

title: MRS. HARRY A. GILLEN
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., July 25  Mrs. Margaret Gallaudet Sherman Gillen, widow of Harry A. Gillen, a photoengraver, died today in Franklin General Hos pital. She was 79 years old and lived at 525 Dubois Avenue.

title: A Friend of American Presidents
description: For Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who saw President Nixon again yesterday for a second round of talks since the Iranian Emperor's arri val Monday, meeting with American Presidents must seem like a bit of djvu.

title: PUBLIC MAY HELP REVIEW OF FOODS
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The Food and Drug Administra tion invited the public today to participate in the agency's safe ty review of 533 food ingre dients that have been generally recognized as safe.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: STOCKHOLM, July 25 (AP)Emiel Puttemans ran the world's secondbest two miles at an international track meet today, beating Ben Jipcho of Kenya. The 26yearold Belgian star was clocked in 8 minutes 16.32 seconds, 2.4 seconds above the record set here last year by Lase Viren Of Finland. Viren finished seventh today in 8:35.5.

description: RUTLAND, Vt., July 25 (AP) A Burlington television re porter was held in contempt by a judge today when he re fused to reveal his sources.

description: Both the Yankees and the Mets go back to work today after an AllStar vacation for most of their members. Although they stand at op posite ends of their respec tive divisions, their situations are not quite that different.

description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) The Senate has passed a bill to revamp Federal job training programs and continue Federal funding of community action antiproverty projects.

description: Ben Grauer began announc ing for the National Broad casting Company in 1930, when radio staffers wore tux edos for evening shows be cause they were going into the American home, unseen but heard.

title: IndiaPakistan Talk Put Off Until Bhutto Can Participate
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 25 Talks between Indian and Pakistani officials aimed at set tling issues arising from their 1971 war and the formation of the state of Bangladesh out of what used to be East Pakistan were postponed today. The talks opened yesterday in Isla mabad, capital of Pakistan. An official statement said that leaders of the two delegations had decide to put off the talks until tomorrow.

title: Impoundment: Beyond the Law
description: WASHINGTONIn a year filled with Congressionalexecutive conflicts, the boldest assault on Congress con stitutional power to govern has come in the wholesale impoundment of appropriated funds. Impoundments strike at the very heart of Congress power of the purse, jeopardizing the explicit constitutional right of Con gress to appropriate monies.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FAIR WEATHER This is the time of year for fairs, usually in a dusty plain on some otherwise unused rural acres. It's always dan gerous to say that something is a first, but it's fair to say that the first fair to be held downstairs at the Hallmark Gallery, Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, (5829130) is now in full swing. Cityfair is an actual fair plus an exhibi tion about fairs. The gallery has been opened up and strewn with stalls where craftsmen are working on ceramics, enamel, jewelry, leather, metal, needlework, paper, textiles, all of which is on sale, as are plants, bread and herbs. Also, during lunch period, free entertain ment. You may walk into the fair free from 9 to 7 Mondays through Fridays (opens Satur days, too, starting Sept. 8). The crafts people come from all over and their booths are tastefully deployed, convey ing a genuine fair atmosphere in this first Hallmark ex hibit to have its wares up for purchase. You may buy a loaf of wholewheat dilly bread for 90 cents, leather bags for from $25 to $40, pottery from about $5 to $100. The amusements will consist of folk singing, fiddle fleckers, puppets, mimes.

title: Maintenance Workers End 2Day Strike, Racing Will Resume Today at Aqueduct
description: The twoday strike at Aque duct ended last night and rac ing will resume today.

title: Inouye Whispers Liar! After Ehrlichman's Replies
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)Soon after John D. Ehrlichman, the former White House adviser, finished an swering questions today by Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii whis pered, What a liar!

title: Insurer Maps Big Outlay In Wildcat OilGas Venture
description: The $6.9billion Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Com pany, one of the most conser vative insurers in the country, disclosed yesterday that it was investing nearly $60million on an oil and gas wildcatting venture off the coast of Louisiana and Texas.

title: Pentagon Inaugurates EnergySaving Rules
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)The Defense Depart ment put into effect yester day new regulations designed to cut energy consumption 7 per cent in the Pentagon, the world's largest office building.

title: As Freeze Runs Out, Run on Freezers Starts
description: Americans have started a record buying run on home freezers and are hoarding food in anticipation of higher priceswhen the ceiling on beef prices ends Sept. 12 and a meat shortage, a sur vey showed today.

title: A Billion in Health Funds Found Unspent by H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 During the last year, the Nixon Administration did not spend nearly $1.1billion in funds Congress had intended for ma jor health programs, according to figures obtained by the House Commerce Committee.

title: Sex Bias Charged in Military, Jobless Benefits and Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The unemployment compensation system discriminates against women, the armed services dis criminate against women and the welfare laws of many states still encourage fathers to desert their families, the Joint Eco nomic Committee of Congress was told today.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saying Time
A Flexible Record
description: Reading Supreme Court decisions is a good deal like reading tea leaves. You can always find what you're look ing for. With that caveat, it may be useful to notice that last year's deci sion by the Supreme Court in the Caldwell case found the four Nixon appointees subscribing to a doctrine which could decide the coming liti gation over the Ervin and Cox sub poenas to Nixon. This is the doctrine that no one, not even the President, is immune to judicial process.

title: A Billion in Health Funds Found Unspent by H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 During the last year, the Nixon Administration did not spend nearly $1.1billion in funds Congress had intended for ma jor health programs, according to figures obtained by the House Commerce Committee.

title: Mistaken Drug Raid Frightens a Mother And Two Children
description: OXNARD, Calif. July 26 (UPI)Narcotics officers on a court  authorized noknock raid broke into the wrong house, confronting a frightened mother and her two children.

title: KISSINGER DELAYS HIS TRIP TO PEKING TILL AFTER AUG.15
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Henry A. Kissinger has post poned his trip to Peking for talks on Cambodia and other subjects until after Aug. 15  the date that American bomb ing of Cambodia is scheduled to end  Administration officials said today.

title: Thomas P. Jahnige Dies; Professor at Smith College
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Mass., July 26 (AP)Thomas P. Jahnige, associate professor of govern ment at Smith College, died Tuesday in New Haven, He was 35 years old.

title: 13,000 U.S. Tax Returns From State Lost by I.R.S.
description: HOLTSVILLE, LI., July 26 As a result of the mysteri ous disappearance of at least 13,000 tax returns, taxpayers from New Jersey are filing duplicate returns for 1972.

title: Man: More Than a Trousered Ape
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va.Concluding the Gifford lectures at Edinburgh in 1947, the historian, Christopher Daw son, declared that the recovery of moral control and the return to spir itual order have become the indis pensable conditions of human sur vival.

title: 2 MEN ARRAIGNED IN WOMAN'S DEATH
description: Two brothersinlaw were ar raigned yesterday on charges of having kidnapped a 57year old Queens woman and of hav ing killed her despite her pleas for mercy.

title: Books of The Times Ambitions and Generations
description: THE CONGRESSMAN WHO LOVED FLAU BERT. And Other Washington Stories. By Ward Just. 178 pages. AtlanticLittle, Brown. $5.95.

title: 1,000 in Wyandanch Turn Out To Debate U.D.C. Housing Plan
description: WYANDANCH, L, I., July 26  A crowd of 1,000 people surged into the gymnasium of Wyandanch High School on this muggy night to debate the hottest issue here in many yearsa proposal for 182 units of housing for moderate and lowincome families and the elderly.

title: Dollar Declines in Trading Abroad
description: PARIS, July 26  Unusually high interest rates in West Germany pulled more money into marks today and con tributed to weakness in the dollar and the pound in what some experts warned could be the beginning of a new round of currency disorder.

title: THREE TEAMS TIE IN WOMEN'S GOLF
description: OSTERVILLE, Mass., July 26 (AP)Three unheralded teams moved into a tie for the lead today in the opening round of the 54hole $30,000 Lady An gelo's Ladies, Professional Golf Association fourball golf tournament on Cape Cod.

title: Napoli Reneges on Pledge To Reveal Mafia Secrets
description: TRENTON, July 26One re puted Mafia figure reneged to day on a promise to tell the State Commission of Investiga tion all he knew about orga nized crime.

title: O'Brien Is Traded by Colts To Lions for Draft Choice
description: BALTIMORE, July 26 (UPI) Jim O'Brien, whose field goal with 5 seconds to play won the 1971 Super Bowl game for the Baltimore Colts, was traded to the Detroit Lions tonight for a future draft choice. The trade returned to the Colts the draft choice they had traded to the Lions for a defensive tackle, Joe Schmiesing.

title: Housing Planned in Shelter I. Preserve
description: Plans were announced yes terday to convert onethird of Shelter Island from a game pre serve to one of the largest de velopments in the metropoli tan region.

title: Shell Also Shows Gain in Net for Quarter and Six Months
description: Texaco, Inc., and the Shell Oil Company announced yester day sharply higher profits for the threemonth and sixmonth periods ended June 30, continu ing the parade of booming oil industry earning reports.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city's Parks Department learned that a bird in the hand is worth two in a tree, when a pet macaw flew away as its owner was donating it to the Central Park Zoo. Richard M. Clurman, the Parks Administrator, was thanking Gerard Wolfe, a language professor at New York University, for his gift when Mac, the professor's vocal macaw, flew into a nearby tree and refused to come down even as tape recordings of its voice were played to entice it. After an hour in the tree, the bird, a brightly colored species of parrot with a vocabulary of 100 words, flew away and has not been seen since. I've always had that effect on pretty birds, Mr. Clurman said ruefully.

title: Patrick Trial Told Fellowship Altered Youth's Personality
description: A Dartmouth student who de scribed himself as a close friend of Daniel Voll's told a jury yes terday that his friend under went a complete change in personality after joining the New Testament Missionary Fel lowship, a religious group, and became a person who ignored me and was cold.

title: People and Business
description: John W. Gardner, whose Common Cause citizen's lobby has campaigned for various publicinterest pro grams in the past, has a new theme: urging coporate di rectors to determine wheher their companies have made any illegal campaign con tributions.

title: Scotland Yard Head Makes Strong Case For Civilian Review
description: LONDON, July 26The Com missioner of London's police. Sir Robert Mark, came out strongly today for the estab lishment of an independent re view body to deal with com plaints against policemen.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn July 26 were:

title: A.B.C. Team to Go to China In ProgramExchange Deal
description: An agreement with China's Central Broadcasting Bureau providing for an exchange of television news, documentaries and sports programs was an nounced yesterday by the American Broadcasting Com pany.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: When Mr. Nixon, addressing 200 re porters and members of his staff on July 20, said in a mood compounded of petulance and arrogance, What we were elected to do, we are going to do, and let others wallow in Watergate, we are going to do our job, he was belittling an honest and muchneeded investigation of his own corrupt Ad ministration.

title: Bill on Oil Companies
description: ters)  A bill requiring major oil companies to separate their production, refining, marketing and transportation activities was introduced today by Sena tor Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah. The bill would reequire the companies to divest them selves of all but one of these activities within three years after the bill became law.

title: Men in the Street Copy That Man in the Pool
description: The hair is tousled and dark and long ish  long enough to cover the ears, but not, repeat, not, long enough to touch the shoulders. The mustache is thick and grows downward. The eyes are smoldering brown. The teeth, ideally, are as white as newfallen snow.

title: Howfield Kicks In Best of Times
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 26 It strikes Rocky Turner as amusing that he is the lead ing candidate to hold the ball for Bobby Howfield's place kicks.

title: Main TransitRoad Plans
description: ALBANY, July 26Following are highlights of the package of transit and highway proposals, some old and some new, offered by Governor Rockefeller today as poten tial benefits from his $3.5billion bond proposal:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two New York couples sued Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and Manu facturers Hanover Corpora tion, the bank's holding com pany, in Federal Court yes terday on charges that the bank practiced sex discrimi nation in refusing to grant the couples mortgage financ ing.

title: People in Sports. Norton Drills Mind, Too
description: Ken Norton apparently thinks he needs more than just his fists for his fights with Muhammad Ali. Before Norton beat Ali last March he made a habit of saying and writing, I will beat Muhammad. I must have done it 80 times a day, he said. He did beat Muhammad and for his rematch with Ali on Sept. 10 at Inglewood, Calif., Norton studies phil osophies of success between daily workouts. He is taking a complete course on gaining wealth and of mind.

title: 23 COACHES PLAN TO QUIT CLIFTON
description: CLIFTON, July 26  The president of the Clifton Board of Education said today that the board would probably hire replacements for 23 of the school system's 26 athletic coaches if they make good on resignations filed to be effec tive next fall.

title: 21 Eating Places And Food Stores Violate Health Law
Radio
description: 9:06.10 A.M., WQXR: Piano Personalities. Ingrid Haebler and Lorin Hollander

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
U.A.W. Aide Shocked By Ford Profit Surge
description: DETROIT, July 26 (UPI) Ken Bannon, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, said today Ford's surge in profits for the first six months of this year was shocking, almost unbeliev able. He said he was aghast at the amount.

title: Lower Rents Held Legal On Substandard Housing
description: TRENTON, July 26 (AP) The New Jersey Supreme Court today established the precedent that tenants may pay reduced rents to landlords who refuse to provide adequate housing.

title: SENATE VOTES LID ON POLITICAL AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Senate voted today to limit an individual's campaign con tributions to a Presidential or Congressional candidate to $3,000 in each election, placing what may become the first ef fective curbs in American po litical history on the influence of the rich on government.

title: Vote on Liddy Contempt Citation Delayed in House
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Young members of the House Armed Services Committee forced a delay today on con tempt  of  Congress action against G. Gordon Liddy, a con victed Watergate conspirator.

title: Corporate Earnings Soar 30%
description: The secondquarter aftertax profits of 926 United States corporations soared 30 per cent from yearearlier levels to $7.3billion compared with a 28 per cent gain recorded by the same group in the first quarter, the First National City Bank reported yesterday in a preliminary survey.

title: WILLIAM L. WHITE, WRITER, 73, DEAD
description: EMPORIA, Kan., July 26  William L. White, editor and publisher of The Emporia Ga zette, author and former for eign correspondent, died today in Newman Memorial County Hospital, where he had been under treatment for cancer. He was 73 years old and lived at 160 East 66th Street, New York.

title: Koota Asserts His Own Integrity In Reply on Alleged Case Fixing
description: State Supreme Court Justice Aaron E. Koota, who was Brooklyn District Attorney at the time two cases were alleg edly fixed, said yesterday that he was completely satisfied with my own integrity.

title: Lawyer Jailed 4 Days For Sarcastic Remark
description: PATERSON, July 26A Clifton lawyer was sentenced today to four days in jail for a sarcastic remark in con tempt of court at the end of a robbery trial.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: COLLINGSWOOD, N. J., July 26The Cooper River Yacht Club keeps indoctrinating youngsters in the skills of sailing. Its program, which also is sponsored by the Camden County Park Commission, is held on the fivemile long Cooper River, a stream so narrow that a 20foot sloop would find navigation on it almost impossible.

title: EQUATION TAKES TOP SAIL HONORS
description: PADANARAM, Mass ., July 26  Equation, the record breaker and overall winner in last month's AnnapolistoNew port race, won top honors in Class I today in the New York Yacht Club race from Newport to Padanaram.

title: Leslie Cornell Is Bride of Joel Goodman
description: Miss Leslie Karen Cornell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Al bert Cornell of this city and Centerport, L. I., was mar ried here yesterday evening

title: B52 Raids Aimed At Cambodian Site Of Shelling Attacks
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 26 (UPI)  An area less han five miles south of Phnom penh was bombed by. Ameri can B52's today in the belief that it was used by insurgents yesterday for a shelling attack on the capital.

title: Truce Violations Are Charged By North and South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 (UPI)Charges of truce violations were made today by North Vietnam against the United States and by the Gov ernment in Saigon against the Vietcong.

title: U.M. Measure Criticizing Israel Vetoed by the U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26The United States today vetoed a Security Council res olution that strongly de plored Israel's continuing occu pation of Arab lands taken during the 1967 war.

title: NIXON CONTESTS SUBPOENAS, KEEPS TAPES; HEARING SET  AUG. 7 ON HISTORIC CHALLENGE
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 President Nixon refused today to comply with subpoenas re quiring him to furnish to the Senate Watergate committee and the special prosecutor tape recordings of his conversations about the Watergate case.

title: Bridge: Top Teams in Spingold Play Seem to Face Little Trouble
Brezhnev Optimistic on Crops, But Record Yield Isn't Forecast
description: MOSCOW, July 26Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev today gave a moderately optimistic forecast for this year's Soviet harvest, but stopped short of predicting the record yield the Kremlin wants in order to re cover from last year's farm dis aster.

title: A Bit Much
description: Libya's fanatical young leader, Col. Muammar el Qaddafi, some time ago indicated that he would resign if he could not achieve his allconsuming goal of merging his tiny, oilrich nation with Egypt.

title: Chicken Cooked With Fresh Vegetables
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an aster isk are followed by a recipe.

title: Yankees Subdue Brewers in 12th, 10, On Munson's Fourth Hit Off Colborn
BYRNE DISAGREES WITH EHRLICHMAN
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26The judge at the Pentagon papers trial, William Matthew Byrne Jr., has disputed a statement by John D. Ehrlichman, the for mer White House aide, that he showed strong interest in the post of director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation while the trial was in progress.

title: In Sirica's Court, History Is Shaped In Dry Language
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 It was history without. Trap pingsa few dry words spoken in a courtroom with the defendant's table empty.

title: In Paris, They Argue Over Which Fashion ShowWas the Least Attractive
description: PARIS, July 26The game people are playing at the fall couture fashion shows this week is, What is the worst collection you've seen so far?

title: Pension Bill Is Passed in Both Houses
description: ALBANY, July 26In votes generally along party lines, the Republican majority in the Legislature late today pushed through a pensionrevision bill setting a minimum retirement age of 62 years for most civil servants hired after July 1, 1973, with benefits based on the average salary of the three highest consecutive years.

title: Newport Opens Festival of Forgotten Composers
description: NEWPORT, R. I.,July 26 Tanglewood and Saratoga are the festivals mostly of Bee thoven and Brahms. Ravinia this year is the festival of Mendelssohn and Berg. The Mostly Mozart is the festival of you know who. But New port is the festival of the likes of Devienne, Vos, Spindler, Ries, Czerny, Kittl and Rhein berger. The fifth Newport Fes tival began last night, and through Aug. 5, three times a day, there will be, as in pre vious seasons, a parade of forgotten 19thcentury com posers unknown even to most specialists.

title: COURT IS PERPLEXED BY OBSCENITY LAWS
description: State Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff admitted yesterday that he was faced with a difficult problem in determining whether the show ing of alleged pornographic films violated the obscenity statutes.

title: Roundup: Rogers, Expo Rookie, Hurls a OneHitter
description: Steve Rogers, a 23year old righthander who joined the Montreal Expos 10 days ago, allowed only one hit an infield single by Jose Pagan in the fifth inning and pitched the Expos to a 40 triumph over the Phila delphia Phils last night in Veterans Stadium.

title: Sports News Briefs Pro Tennis Adds Third Tour
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)World Championship Tennis will expand from two to three tours with a total of 84 players in 1974. Each tour will play eight tourna ments for $50,000 each, with all 84 players competing in the $100,000 United States pro indoor championship at Philadelphia in January. This was confirmed today by Jack Kramer, executive director of the Association of Tennis Professionals, during the Washington Star News tourna ment. Two years ago, the circuit consisted of one 32man tour. A year ago, it was expanded to two 32man events.

title: CONNECTICUT SUES 20 OIL COMPANIES
description: HARTFORD, July 26Con inecticut has brought a Federal lawsuit against 20 major oil companies and three subsidiar ies, charging them with violat ing Federal and state antitrust laws.

title: PORT AUTHORITY SET FOR WALKOUT
description: All of the Port Authority's airports, bridges and tunnels will be operating today, author ity spokesmen promised last night, although its policemen plan a mass walkout at 11 A.M.

title: U.S. Reports Sharp Gain In Trade Balance in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The nation's foreign trade bal ance improved sharply in June, with imports exceeding exports by only $15.5million, the Com merce Department reported today.

title: DR. ROBERT WARREN, ORTHOPEDIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Robert Fiske Warren, director of orthopedic surgery at BrooklynCumberland Medi cal Center and at Long Island College Hospital, died Wednes day at the Albany Medical Cen ter. He was 65 years old and lived at I Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, and in Northville, N. Y. His office was at 200 Hicks Street, Brooklyn.

title: Plan Seeks to Lure Small Investor
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 A spokesman for a new organiza tion of mediumsized compa nies whose stocks are publicly traded asked Congress today to provide some new tax ad vantages for relatively small investors to lure them back into the stock market.

title: Screen: Expose of U.S. Aid Workers
description: Jorge Sanjines's Blood of the Condor, reportedly the first Bolivian feature film to be commercially released in this country, is like a lot of mid20thcentury revolution ary art that has its roots in the guiltridden middle classes of underdeveloped countries.

title: Colby GetsApproval Of Senate Committee As Director of C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved the nomination of William E. Colby as director of Central Intelli gence.

title: Watkins Glen Story: Racing Cars Yield To the Rock Stars
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 26Under the watchful eyes of hundreds of sheriff's deputies and state policemen, more than 5,000 young people camped out here today to await the start of Saturday's daylong rock fes tival at the Watkins Glen Grand Prix race track.

title: Junior Meet Opens Today
description: ODESSA. U.S.S.R., July 26 (UPI)A twoday meet be tween the Soviet and United States junior track and field teams opens here tomorrow in the 43,000seat Central Sta dium.

title: Peron Hailed by Throng At a Mass for Late Wife
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 26 Several thousand supporters converged on the central plaza here today to cheer former dic tator Juan Domingo Pern in his first official public appear ance since his return to Argen tina last month after 18 years of exile.

title: Chinese Once More Giving Foreigners Chance to See Kweilin Scenery That Inspired Ancient Artists
description: KWEILIN, China  A high level decision to broaden the scope of life for foreigners in China, coupled with the end of the war in Vietnam, has re sulted in the reopening of this ancient city to foreign visitors. It has long been celebrated as the site of the best mountain and river scenery in this land of mountains and rivers.

title: Texts of Letters and Orders on Nixon Refusal to Respond to Subpoenas on Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Following are the texts of President Nixon's letter to Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., de clining to respond to a sub poena for tapes and papers relating to the Senate Water gate inquiry; a colloquy on the President's letter between Senator Ervin and Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., includ ing a resolution by Senator Baker to seek court action; President Nixon's letter to Judge Sirica declining to re spond to a subpoena by the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox; a petition by Mr. Cox for a court order directing the President to show cause why he should not produce the re quested material, and Judge Sirica's show cause order:

title: Legislators Place Cost Above $3.5Billion
description: ALBANY, July 26  A mam moth package of old and new transit and highway proposals was unveiled today by Governor Rockefeller as he detailed his proposed $3.5billion transit bond issue.

title: Share Figure Highest in Company History Sales Climb 17%
description: The Ford Motor Company's secondquarter share earnings were the highest for any quar ter in the company's history, while sales and earnings for both the quarter and the half reached record levels, the com pany reported yesterday.

title: Dolphins vs. AllStars: A Tale of Two Coaches
Consumer Advocate Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  Twenty  six Congressmen have asked President Nixon to name a forceful consumer ad vocate to an upcoming va cancy at the Federal Trade Commission. Representative Bob Eckhardt, Democrat of Texas, who circulated the let ter, said the consumers' voice must be carried inside the F.T.C.

title: TwoPronged Struggle
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The confrontation between Presi dent Nixon and Congress today touched off a historic legal struggle that could affect the political prestige and authority of their two branches of gov ernment for many years.

title: The System Responds
description: While the crisis in the executive branch continued to deepen this week as a result of the latest developments in the Watergate investigations, two less spectacular but no less significant actions in Congress and the courts gave evidence of the fundamental health and resiliency of the American constitutional system. These two coequal branches of the Federal Government both took far reaching steps toward reining in the Executive.

title: Skylab 2
description: Tomorrow morning, if all goes on schedule, the three astronauts of the Skylab 2 crew will blast off for a record 59day mission in the orbiting American station in space. Successful completion of these astronauts assignment will represent another milestone passed toward attaining the capability for longterm manned space flight, whether in orbit as with Skylab or on some future crew's flight toward Mars, Venus or Jupiter.

title: U.S. Reports Sharp Gain In Trade Balance in June
description: WASHINGTON, July. 26  The nation's foreign trade bal ance improved sharply in June, with imports exceeding exports by only $15.5million, the Com merce Department reported today.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 14%
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 The Department of Commerce reported today that depart ment store sales last week were an estimated $920million, up 12 per cent from the year earlier $822million. Total re tail store sales were about $9.693billion, up 14 per cent from last year's $8.537billion.

title: CAMPAIGN FINANCES REPORTED BY BAKER
description: NASHVILLE, July 26 (AP) Senator Howard H. Baker Jr has released a list of previously undisclosed contributors to his reelection campaign, showing that he collected $264,000 and spent about $80,000 before a new Federal law requiring full disclosure took effect April 7, 1972.

title: Pension Bill Is Passed by Senate, 3722
description: ALBANY, July 26The Re publican majority in the State Senate late today pushed through a pensionrevision bill setting a minimum retirement age of 62 years for most civil servants hired after July 1, 1973, with benefits based on the average salary of the three highest consecutive years.

title: SECRECY UPHELD BY EHRLICHMAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  John D. Ehrlichman said today that the special White House intelligence unit undertook in 1971 a mission so important to national security that it justi fied President Nixon's efforts to hide the group's existence.

title: Two Women Join Fire Volunteers
description: MANTUA, N. J., July 26 (UPI)  Gloucester County has its first two women fire fighters because there were no men around during a re cent daytime blaze.

title: Giants Are Ready For Squad Game
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J. July 26The starting offen sive and defensive units for the New York Giants intra squad practice game here Saturday morning at the Monmouth College training camp are virtually set. The final twoaday practice ses sions will be held tomorrow.

title: STOCKTON UPSETS SMITH IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) In a stunning upset, 12th seeded Dick Stockton of Port Washington, LI., defeated top seeded Stan Smith today in the third round of The Wash ington StarNews international tennis championships. The scores were 6.2, 36, 64.

title: Business Records
description: Petition Filed by:

title: CAHILL APPROVES RAILROAD REPAIR
description: TRENTON, July 26 (UPI)  Governor Cahill today ap proved the spending of $440, 000 this year to make repairs on the New York and Long Branch Rairoad.

title: The Shah Takes 500 Friends to a Theater Party
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 The Shah of Iran and his Empress, having discharged their official social obliga tions  that Is, they have been to dinner at the White House, and the Nixons have come to themrelaxed a bit tonight and took about 500 of their friends and acquaint ances to the theater.

title: CHINESE MISSION TO BUY 2 HOUSES
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Chinese liaison mission to the United States, which has been living at a downtown hotel since its arrival nearly two months ago, has finally found a home for its top members.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Cahill announced that the state's tripleA credit rating, the highest given, had been renewed by Moody's Investor Service, a major bond rating service.

title: KISSINGER DELAYS HIS TRIP TO PEKING TILL AFTER AUG.15
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Henry A. Kissinger has post poned his trip to Peking for talks on Cambodia and other subjects until after Aug. 15  the date that American bomb ing of Cambodia is scheduled to end  Administration officials said today.

title: Mandate for Marcos?
description: When President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law in the Philippines last September in order, he said, to defeat a Communist insurgency and institute sweeping reforms, he declared: This is temporary and we will go back as fast as we can to normal constitutional processes.

title: Secretariat, Riva Ridge to Run Match Race at Belmont Sept. 15
description: Madison Avenue has dis covered horse racing and has come up with a quartermil liondollar match race. A sponsor, not particularly pre ferring to remain anonymous, has put up a trophy called the Marlboro Cup and the sum of $200,000 for a most egregious contest between Secretariat a n d Riva Ridge. The sponsor will have to sell an awful lot of cigarettes to get the $200, 000 back. The other $50,000 will be put up by the New York Racing Association.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: LINDA'S CHIEF PAYS HIS FIRST DIVIDEND
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 26  Linda's Chief, who was sold for $2million yesterday, earned a mere $9,000 today for his new owner, Aaron Jones, as he won a nonbetting threehorse race at Monmouth Park.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.8 billion tonmiles, 10.5 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Car loadings in the same week totaled 523,409 cars, 8.0 per cent above last year. The American Trucking. Association, Inc., reported in tercity truck tonnage was 7.8 per cent above last year.

title: TV: Program on Returned P.O.W.'s
description: Two men of deep experi ence, racial and war, speak with impressive and contrast ing conviction in a halfhour documentary news special at 9 tonight over the Ameri can Broadcasting Company. See this program and listen sharply. The title is P.O.W.'s: The Black Homecoming.

title: 104 ExHostages Aare Flown From Libya
description: ATHENS, July 26 (AP)A relief plane today flew 104 pas sengers of a, hijacked Japanese jumbo jet here from Benghazi, Libya. After a brief stopover it took off for Tokyo.

title: Bond Prices Show Big Drops; Treasury Issues OH Sharply
EDGAR STEHLI 89, VERSATILE ACTOR
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.Y., July 26Edgar Stehli, one of the oldest and most versatile actors of stage, screen, radic and television, died last night at his home, 540 Highland Ave nue. He was 89 years old.

title: PHILIPPINE VOTING WILL BEGIN TODAY
description: MANILA, July 26  Little public opposition was being dis played to President Ferdinand E. Marcos's martiallaw regime today as Filipinos prepared to vote tomorrow and Saturday in a referendum designed to test national feeling about the regime.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: ROME, July 26The Italian Senate last night approved a more modern and democratic statute for the 80yearold Venice Biennale to put an end to the disputes and violence that have wracked the oldest and most prestigious of the international art and film shows for the last five years and longer.

title: Television
description: SENATE WATERGATE

title: Major League Baseball Friday, July 27, 1973
description: American League

title: A Case for the Courts
description: The constitutional impasse created by President Nixon's rejection of subpoenas, from Congress and from the Government's special prosecutor, for Watergate related tape recordings and documents has quite properly been referred to the Federal courts.

title: EHRLICHMAN CALLS SECRECY JUSTIFIED
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  John 11 Ehrlichman said today that the special White House intelligence unit undertook in 1971 a mission so important to national security that it justi fied President Nixon's efforts to hide the group's existence.

title: U. N. Measure Criticizing Israel Vetoed by the U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26The United States today vetoed a Security Council res olution that strongly de plored Israel's continuing occu pation of Arab lands taken during the 1967 war.

title: ISAAC ALLEN,LAWYER, LED ZIONIST COUNCIL
description: Isaac Allen, a lawyer and Talmudic scholar, died Wednes day of lung congestion in a nursing home in Hartford. He was 98 years old and lived at the Hotel Ansonia, Broadway at 73d Street.

title: RUSSELL TRAIN NAMED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  President Nixon, still reshuf fling his Administration in the wake of the Watergate scandal, made two new nominations today for top Government po sitions.

title: Jacqueline Radin of Newsday Is Drowned Trying to Save Son
description: Mrs. Jacqueline Radin, editor of the Living section of News day, drowned Wednesday in a canal at Ste. Tallaye, France. She was 34 years old.

title: Ballet: Return of Agnes de Mille Work
description: THREE VIRGINS AND A DEVIL, written by Ramon Reed; choreography, Ag?es ce Mite; music, Ottorino Resoighi (Antique Dances); scenery and cos ??mes, Motley; costume supervision, David Guthrie; lighting, Nananne Por ??her; conductor, Akira Endo. Presented by the American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater.

title: LINDSAY REPORTS 100MILLION SAVED
description: The Lindsay Amdinistration said yesterday that its pro ductivity program for munici pal agencies, now one year old, had produced a budget saving of $100million and had re moved the need for 16,000 ad ditional city employes.

title: RESERVE LIMITS FOURYEAR C.D.'S
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 The Federal Reserve Board imposed on commercial banks today a limit on the amount of the new highinterest four year certificates of deposit they can issue to savers.

title: Business Briefs
description: Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that the company was entering a joint venture with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation to develop a practical zincchloride rechargeable battery that could be a power source for a modern electrical automobile.

title: Indian Movement Begins Religious Rites
description: WHITE OAK, Okla., July 26 The American Indian Move ment, which has been talking about expanding into a world wide movement in behalf of Indian rights, began traditional; religious ceremonies today in preparation for its national convention.

title: Red Smith
description: ETHEL, Wash.The Cowiitz River is formed by ice water from the Cowlitz Glacier on Mt. Rainier. It flows southwest to the Oregon line, where it joins the Columbia for the last leg of the journey to the sea. Partly because of the generosity of nature, partly because of Tacoma's demand for hydroelectric power and partly because of the biologists and engineers of the Washington Department of Game, it has become the most productive steelhead river in the world. In 1972, anglers took 46,000 of these seagoing rainbow trout from the Cowlitz and in the record month of December, 1971, the catch was 19,000, which is more than the state's number No. 2, the Skigit, produces in a year. The spawning run of most steel head comes in the late fall, but instinct brings some back to freshwater in the summer. By trapping and breeding these nonconformists, the game department has greatly increased the summer runs, This work is done at a hatchery the city of Tacoma built here to compensate for the damage its two power dams did to natural spawn ing waters upstream.

title: Dolphins vs. AllStars: A Tale of Two Coaches
description: CHICAGO, July 26With out three, and possibly four of their best players, the Mi ami Dolphins will oppose the College AllStars here tomor row night in a duel of coach es who were undefeated last seasonDon Shula of the National Football League champions and John McKay of the University of Southern California.

title: Dr. Hans Albert Einstein Dies; Physicist Was River Authority
description: FALMOUTH, Mass., July 26 (AP)  Dr. Hans Albert Ein stein, son of the late Dr. Al bert Einstein, died today at Falmouth Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Equity Financing
description: Ideal Basic Industries, Inc., yesterday said it had authorized repurchase of up to 1,000,000 of its common shares. The company's stock closed un changed at 14 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Dow Closes Up 1.51 Volume Brisk
CONFEREES AGREE ON WAGE OF $2,20 Minimum Would Be Applied to Eight Million More
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  SenateHouse conferees agreed today on an increase in the minimum wage to $2.20 an hour for most workers by next July 1 and an extension of its coverage to eight million more workers, including domestics.

title: 2 Couples Accuse Bank Of HomeLoan Sex Bias
description: Two couples angered by the alleged refusal of bankers to consider a wife's income in an application for mortgage finan cing filed a sexdiscrimination suit in Federal Court in Man hattan yesterday against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the bank's holding company.

title: SENATORS PERK NAVY F14 HOPES
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee voted yesterday to direct the Navy to consider development of a new light weight fighter to round out its carrierbased force after pur chase of a limited complement of $14million Grumman F14's.

title: Soviet Lofts 2d Craft to Mars; Arrival Due in MidFebruarys
description: MOSCOW, July 26 (AP) Two unmanned Soviet space probes are speeding toward Mars to study the red planet and space conditions around it.

title: A Mail Concern Hired by McGovern Was Run by Associates of Kalmbach
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26In one of the odder incidents of the 1972 Presidential campaign, several law partners of Herbert W. Kalmbach, then President Nixon's personal lawyer, owned part of a computer mailing company that worked for Sen ator George McGovern during the California primary.

title: 3 Men Arrested As Violence Flares Outside ExpoCuba
description: Violence flared briefly at an antiCastro demonstration yes terday outside the midtown union headquarters where a bomb was set off Tuesday, apparently in an effort to fore stall the opening of a proCastro political and cultural exposition on Cuba.

title: Mets Records
description: BATTING

title: FOOD PRICE RISES CONFIRMED HERE
description: Another major report of soar ing food prices was issued yesterday, confirming that the cost of pork, bacon, chicken and eggs in New York City was up sharply since the Gov ernment instituted Phase 4 of its economic program July 13, ending the ceilings on food prices.

description: Films

title: Mr. Nixon's S. S.
description: By late October, 1971, Attorney General John Mitchell, exasperated by his difficulties with J. Edgar Hoover, had persuaded President Nixon to fire the elderly and cantankerous F.B.I. director. An appointment for Mr. Hoover was made at the Oval Office; unaware of what was in store, he went over to talk to the President.

title: Net Almost Doubled At Delta Air Lines During Fiscal Year
description: ATLANTA, July 26 (AP) Delta Air Lines reported today that it fell just short of doubling its profits in fiscal 1973.

title: Beyond Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Three years ago, John N. Mitchell, then the Attor ney General and President Nixon's closest political adviser, was over heard to say at a cocktail party: This country is going so far right you are not even going to recognize it.

title: In Silica's Court, History Is Shaped In Dry Language
description: WASHINGTON, July 2?? It was history without tr??p pingsa few dry words spoken in a courtroom with the defendant's table empty.

title: Iran and Ashland in Innovative Venture
description: The first small but signifi cant step toward participation by an oilproducing country in American industry was an nounced Wednesday by the Shah of Iran who disclosed at a news conference in Wash ington a joint venture between his country and Ashland Oil, Inc., in refining and marketing operations in the United States.

title: Wells Cleared in Fight
description: OAKLAND, July 26 (AP) Warren Wells, once a leading wide receiver in the National Football League, has been cleared of charges filed against him after a quarrel with two policemen at a Berkeley Calif. cafe last May 5.

title: GREECE FREES MORE HELD AS AGITATORS
description: ATHENS, Ally 26  Three days before a nationwide plebi scite intended to confirm Greece as a republic, the military po lice have freed professors, law yers and students rounded up last spring in a bid to curb student agitation.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
Widow of Marcus Garvey Is Dead in Jamaica at 77
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 26 (AP)Amy Jacques Garvey, widow of Marcus Garvey, black leader of the backtoAfrica movement in the nineteen twenties, died Sunday at her residence at Mona, Kingston. She was 77 years old.

title: NIXON CONTESTS SUBPOENAS, KEEPS TAPES; HEARING SET AUG. 7 ON HISTORIC CHALLENGE
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 President Nixon refused today to comply with subpoenas re quiring him to furnish to the Senate Watergate committee and the special prosecutor tape recordings of his conversations about the Watergate case.

description: ALBANY, July 26  A mam moth package of old and new transit and highway proposals was unveiled today by Governor Rockefeller as he detailed his proposed $3.5billion transit bond issue.

title: Landless Untouchables in a Poor Area Start to Protestand Die
description: CHOURI, India, July 21 The dusty lanes in Chouri are silent now. Outside the mud huts the silence at midday is broken by whining dogs and the feeble wails of old wo men.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SPRING AND TWIG The flower market with the pret tiest location in town lies across the street from the United Nations and its ad jacent park. It's on the strip of concrete park on the south side of 47th Street between First and Second Avenues, closer to First.

title: Peterson Named Chief Executive of Lehman Brothers
description: Peter G. Peterson, former Secretary of Commerce and most recently President Nixon's roving trade ambassador, will become the new chairman and chief executive of Lehman Brothers, Inc., one of the world's most prestigious Investment banking firms.

title: SENATE VOTES TOP ON POLITICAL GIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Senate voted today to limit an individual's campaign con tributions to a Presidential or Congressional candidate to $3,000 in each election, placing what may become the first ef fective curbs in American po litical history on the influence of the rich on government.

description: Connecticut has filed a Federal lawsuit charging 20 major oil companies and three of their subsidiaries with violating Federal and state antitrust laws. Page 39.

description: FICTION
