description: OSTERVILLE, Mass., July 26 (AP)Three unheralded teams moved into a tie for the lead today in the opening round of the 54hole $30,000 Lady Angelo's Ladies Professional Golf Association fourball golf tournament on Cape Cod.

title: Iakovos Criticizes Greek Government
description: In what he described as a personal act of conscience, Archbishop Iakovos, Greek Orthodox Primate of North and South America, has crit icized the Greek Government and American policy toward it.

title: The Pop Life The Return of Etta James
description: ??a James is on her way back. For those who've for gotten or don't know, she has been a star several times, ?arting with the 1954 hit Dance With Me Henry.

title: Reagan Helps Raise Funds
description: CHICAGO, July 26 (UPI)  Gov. Ronald Reagan of Cali fornia keynoted the first major Republican fundraising dinner of the year in Illinois last night. He spoke at a $125anlate din ner that organizers estimated raised $141,000 for the 1974 election campaign

title: Bowa of Phillies Breaks Ankle
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (UPI)The Philadelphia Phil lies lost the services tonight of Larry Bowa a shortstop, prob ably for the season with a broken bone in his left ankle.

title: Cawley, After P.B.A. Protests, To Start NameTag Plan Slowly
description: Facing strong protests from rank and file policemen on his plan to require them to wear name plates on their uniforrms, Commissioner Donald F. Caw ley agreed yesterday to carry out the plan in stages.

title: U.S. Asks Stay of Court Ruling That Cambodia Raids Must Halt
description: Government attorneys asked an appeals court yesterday for a stay to block a district judge's Decision that the United States must stop bombing Cambodia by 4 P.M., today.

title: Weekend Fishing Outlook
description: The usual midsummer dol drums have slowed striped bass fishing along much, of the east coast from southern New Jersey to Cape Cod, but in many areas, Long Island Sound among them, large bluefish have moved in.

title: SENATE BILL BLOCKS FOREIGN VOTE ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The Senate passed a bill to day providing criminal penal ties for offering funds to a United States Government em ploye or agency to influence a foreign election. Acceptance of such money would also be a crime.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon, defying subpoenas, re fused to produce the White House tapes; Judge John J. Sirica ordered the President to show why he shouldn't be ordered to release the tapes to the Watergate prosecutor, and the Senate Watergate committee voted to start a separate court action to secure the recordings of the President's conversations with Watergate figures. A White House spokesman said that the President would abide by a definitive Supreme Court de cision. [Page 1, Column 8; Texts, P. 9.]

title: Scowls Now Smiles, Hisses Now Silence
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  It wasn't exactly a love feast, but John D. Ehrlichman and the Senate Watergate com mittee seemed today to have decided to at least stop kick ing sand in one another's faces.

title: Papp's Plays to Get Philadelphia Tryout
description: For an old theatrical ne cessity, Joseph Papp has found a classic answer two weeks in Philadelphia.

title: Constantine Georgakopoulos Head of Greek Red Cross, 82
description: ATHENS, July 26Constan tine Georgakopoulos, president of the Greek Red Cross for a quarter of a century and briefly Premier, died here yesterday at the age of 82.

title: Israel Denies Any Role In a Murder in Norway
description: JERUSALEM, July 26 Israel today denied any asso ciation with the five persons arrested for the murder of a Moroccan in Lillehammer, Norway, last Saturday. Two of the five have reportedly said they are members of an Israel counterterror group trying to prevent Palestinian attacks on Israeli installa tions in Scandinavia.

title: Some Boys Pass Up Fingerprinting
description: NEWARK, July 26Despite a noon deadline requiring more than 40 eighthgrade boys to be fingerprinted in a murder investigation or risk being held in contempt of court, the police said today that they did not know how many had complied.

title: Service Secretaries Have the Title but Little Else
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The civilian secretary of a mili tary service rates a 19gun salute and can command a per sonal airplane, a limousine and a few aides around him. But he no longer has control over the operations of the troops that he is supposed to raise, train and equip.

title: Lost Tax Returns From Jersey Make Many File Again
description: HOLTSVILLE, LI., July 26 As a result of the mysteri ous disappearance of at least 13,000 tax returns, taxpayers from New Jersey are filing duplicate returns ror 1972.

title: A Holiday Is Given In Effort to Reduce Los Angeles Smog
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26  Thousands of Federal employes in five southern California counties were asked to stay home from work today as part of a twoweekold Federal plan to reduce dangerously high smog levels. The aim was to reduce traffic.

title: Housing Planned in Shelter I. Woods
description: Plans were announced yes terday to convert onethird of Shelter Island from a game pre serve to one of the largest de velopments in the metropoli tan region.

title: Oil Antitrust Suit Filed
description: Connecticut has filed a Federal lawsuit charging 20 major oil companies and three of their subsidiaries with violating Federal and state antitrust laws, Page 39.

title: Suit Filed to Block Big Sports Complex In Meadowlands
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 26 A suit was filed in Federal Court today to block the Hack ensack Meadows Sports Com plex on the ground that if it went into operation as planned, it would violate the Federal Clean Air Act by creating un acceptable pollution from heavy automobile traffic.

title: Strong Start in Cricket
description: LONDON, July 26 (Reuters)  The West Indies cricket team, with C. Lloyd registering 132 runs not out, scored 275 for four wickets at the Oval today on the first day of the first test match against. Eng land.

title: When It's Time to Leave
description: Replying to Senator Baker's ques tion, Herbert Porter of the Committee to ReElect the President, said that he had not spoken up against his bosses wrongdoings probably because of the fear of group pressure that would ensue, of not being a team player. He went on to explain that loyalty to the President and his team had taken precedence rover loyalty to principles or to country.

title: Kelley Defends Hoover On Ehrlichman Opinion
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation, defend ed the late J. Edgar Hoover today against reported feel ings by the Nixon Adminis tration that be should have retired before the Watergate investigation.

title: Fire Kills 4 in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU July 26 (UP1) Four members of a family were burned to death today in an earlymorning fire. The police said a 45yearold woman, her 18 year old daughter  in  law, her 9yearold son and her 2 yearold grandson perished. They would identify only the lone survivor, Charles Lee, 21, who lost his mother, wife, brother and son.

title: Irwin's Record 65 Leads at Montreal
Judicial Farce
description: The judicial conventions being held today by political parties in New York City make a mockery of the law. They expose again, if further exposure were needed, the evils of leaving the judicial selection process to the backroom wheeling and dealing of partisan leaders who dispense patronage at the expense of justice. Judgeships become pawns in a seedy game plan for expanding power.

description: Dr. Beatrice F. Hyslop, pro fessor emeritus of history at Hunter College and an author, died Monday on a visit to Rochester. She was 73 years old and lived at 7505 35th Ave nue, Jackson Heights. Queens.

description: WASHINGTON, July 26In the view of some constitutional experts, the White House's most recent interpretation of executive privilege has in creased the likelihood that the courts will force President Nixon to release the Watergate tapes.

title: Cambodian Rebels Date U.S. Raids to 63
description: PARIS, July 26Supporters of the deposed Cambodian chief of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, charged in a state ment issued here today that the Americans and their lackeys had been bombing Cambodia since 1963.

title: STOCKTON UPSETS SMITH IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) In a stunning upset, 12th seeded Dick Stockton of Port Washington, L.I., defeated top seeeded Stan Smith today in the third round of The Wash ington StarNews international tennis championships. The scores were 62, 36, 64.

title: 5% RISE IN AIR FARES ON ATLANTIC URGED
description: LONDON, July 26 (UPI)  Officials of the International Air Transport Association have recommended a 5 per cent in crease in transAtlantic sched uled fares next year, a spokes man said today.

title: Moynihan Twits State Dept. On Buildings
description: NEW DELHI, July 26Am bassador Daniel P. Moynihan has sent an impish and mock ing cable to the State Depart ment, gently threatening to re sign, deploring American archi tecture overseas and castigat ing Washington officials,

title: GROWTH PERSISTS IN MONEY SUPPLY
Notes on People New Education Chief for U.S.
description: The new United States Commissioner of Education is Dr. John R. Ottina, whose nomination by President Nix on was confirmed by the Sen ate yesterday. The 41year old Dr. Ottina succeeds Dr. Sidney P. Marland Jr., who left the post last year to be come assistant secretary for education.

title: 3 in Blue Angels Killed in Collision Of 2 Phantom Jets
description: LAKEHURST, N.J., July 26 Two Phantom jets flying in for mation with the Blue Angels, the Navy's precision flying team, crashed into each other during practice maneuvers over the Lakehurst Naval Air Station here this afternoon, killing three of the four fliers in the two planes. The fourth escaped with only minor injuries.

title: 73 U.S.Spending Is Below $250Billion Nixon Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Nixon Administration re ported today that the Govern ment spent $246.6billion in the fiscal year just endedwell be low the President's target ceil ing of $250billion established about a year ago and reaffirmed last January.

title: ExGreen Beret Says U.S. Still Hides Actions in War
description: WASHINGTON, July 26A former Green Beret sergeant accused the Pentagon today of continuing to cover up the ex tent of secret United States military operations in Laos and Cambodia. He also charged that Government officials had deliberately understated the number of Americans killed on those operations.

title: An Ancient Cuisine That's Still Here
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable estab lishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Toda
All That Digging in Streets Has Interior Motive
Woman on C.B.S. Radio
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System radio network will preempt all regularly sched uled programing, except for newscasts, this weekend to present a marathon series of broadcasts under the umbrella title of The American Wom an. Among the 30 programs in the series will be The Feminist Movement, Working Women, Women as Sex Symbols, and The Life of Woman, the last featuring Bette Davis and Elizabeth Jane way, the novelist.

title: Rumors of Export Curbs Unsettle Futures Markets
description: The nation's major commodi ties exchanges were unsettled late yesterday by rumors that Washington was preparing to restrict exports of basic raw materials.

title: PRICES ON AMEX MAKE SLIM GAIN
description: Despite some profit taking, continuing earnings gains pushed prices slightly higher yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Prices in the overthecounter market moved in the opposite direction.

title: Federal Panel Invalidates Obscenity Law in Jersey
description: NEWARK, July 26  A spe cial threejudge Federal panel ruled 2 to 1 today that New Jersey's antiobscenity law was unconstitutional.

title: Yonkers Will Build Malls In Converting Downtown
description: YONKERS, July 26  This city, the fourth largest in the state, has decided to convert a major portion of its congested downtown district into an area of treelined shopping malls serving a new retail center.

title: Advertising: Ego Gratification
description: What the advertising busi ness sorely needed was a historic event not connected with Government regulation, Congressional legislation, consumer demonstration or selfflagellation.

title: FOREIGN AID BILL PASSED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) Rejecting an effort to cut off all American military assistance for Cambodia, the House to night approved a $2.8billion foreign aid bill, concentrating $650 million on the needs of poor countries.

title: Skylab Scientists Feel Confident of Important Discoveries
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July, 26(AP)Skylab scientists feel con fident that, with the data re turned by the first astronauts to operate the orbiting space station, they are on the verge of important new discoveries about the sun's upper atmos phere.

title: FOOD PRICE RISES CONFIRMED HERE
description: Another major report of soar ing food prices was issued yesterday, confirming that the cost of pork, bacon, chicken and eggs in New York City was up sharply since the Gov ernment instituted Phase 4 of its economic program July 13, ending the ceilings on food prices.

title: Capital Punishment Upheld By Florida Supreme Court
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 26 (AP)The State Supreme Court upheld, 5 to 2, Florida's new capital punishment law today.

title: WILLIAM AUCHINCLOSS
description: William S. Auchincloss, board chairman of the Schnell Pub lishing Company, died Thurs day at Overlook Hospital, Sum mit, N. J. He was 73 years old and lived in Short Hills, N. J., and Bridgehampton, L. I.

title: C.B.S. Sues Two More Record Aides
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. yesterday filed suit charging two more of its former C. B. S. Records Group employes with diverting com Pany funds to their own use.

title: EHRLICHMAN SAYS HE BRIEFED NIXON ON PLOT APRIL 14
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  John D. Ehrlichman, offering a detailed White House rationale for the Watergate coverup, swore today that President Nixon did not get a thorough briefing on the Watergate con spiracy until April 14 this year.

title: People in Sports: What a Shot!
description: Some people wait all their lives for a holeinone. Andrew Haley ended the long wait last week at the ripe old age of 7.

title: Judge Tells White House to Show Him Milk Files
description: WASHINGTON, July 27In a preliminary setback for Presi dent Nixon's theory of execu tive privilege, a Federal judge ordered the White House today to show him its files on the 1973 increase in Government milk price supports.

title: The Seesaw Tilts Left
description: ASPEN, Colo.One interesting para dox of contemporary politics is the rise in strength of the socalled left virtually on the heels of the split in Communist unity. This has not been a sudden development. It has followed a zigzag period during which relatively conservative forces seemed to be re asserting themselves in many coun tries. Now the tide shows signs of reversing direction.

title: UNION CHIEF'S AID SOUGHT BY HEATH
description: LONDON, July 27  Prime Minister Heath  his Govern ment shaken by inflation, the weakening of the pound and political reverses  sought the cooperation of trade union leaders today on Britain's economic problems.

title: SPARTAN HANOVER WINS REALIZATION
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 27 The horse that Billy Haughton gave up on last year and sold to a Swiss importer returned to the United States tonight and almost made Haughton second guess himself.

title: Marcos Is Amassing Heavy Yes Vote
description: MANILA, Saturday, July 28 Early returns from a referendum on whether Ferdinand E. Marcos should continue as President of the Philippines beyond this year indicate that a huge yes vote is being amassed.

title: RAFFAELE MATTIOLI, ITALIAN BANKER, 78
description: ROME, July 27  Raffaele Mattioli, president of the Banca Commerciale Italiana, one of Italy's major banks, died here last evening. He was 78 years old.

title: CrazyQuilt Council
description: Unless the scheme concocted this week by City Coun cil for reapportioning itself is substantially modified, it deserves Mayor Lindsay's veto. If passed over his veto as was the previous gerrymandered plan, it, too, ought to be challenged in the courts, where it will in all proba bility also be declared unconstitutional, as was the last one.

title: BLIGH A. DODDS
description: GOUVERNEUR, N. Y., July 27 (AP)  Bligh A. Dodds, a longtime leader of agricultural fairs in New York State, died yesterday at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: U.S. Army Is Said to Spy On Its Critics in Germany
description: BONN, July 27United States Army intelligence has begun a program of offensive counter intelligence against antiArmy civilian groups in West Germa ny  tapping their telephones, photographing their meeting places and trying to infiltrate them, according to some of the participating intelligence agents.

title: Bridge: New York Has 10 Teams In 3d Round of the Spingold
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 New York was strongly rep resented in the third round of Spingold knockout team play at the American Con tract Bridge League's Sum mer Nationals here this after noon.

title: New Jersey Sports A Weighty Problem
description: BELLEVILLE, July 27Bob Racioppi won the Amateur Athletic Union's National Junior Olympics wrestling championship last month in the 126pound division and his chief opposition didn't come onto the mat.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of qual ity of comparable establish ments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as ex cellent and four as superb.

title: Thieu Visit to Thailand Off; Cooling of Ties Indicated
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 27  The scheduled visit to Thailand by President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam next week has been postponed indefinitely, apparently as a result of cooling in relations between the two countries.

title: McIntire Renews Radio Plea
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  The Rev. Carl McIntire, a fundamentalist radio preacher, is asking a Federal court again to keep his Media, Pa., radio station on the air, the Federal Communications Commission reported today. The agency originally denied a license re newal to the station on the ground that it failed to comply with the fairness doctrine and the personal attack rule.

title: Andray Neal Wed To R. S. Silverman
description: SUDBURY, Mass., July 27 Miss Andray Louise Neal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis F. Neal of York, Me., was married here this after noon to Robert Steven Silver man, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Silverman of Chestnut Hill.

title: DEMOCRATS NAME JUDGESHIP SLATES
description: Organization Democrats in All five counties easily over rode opposition from Reform Democrats yesterday and nomi nated their own choices for 16 seats on the State Supreme Court.

title: Soft Drinks, Beer or Iced Tea: They All Carry Taste of Profits for Industry
description: Whether at the beach or the ballpark, an American on a hot summer weekend is likely to slake his thirst by gulping everincreasing quan tities of soft drinks, beer or iced tea.

title: JACK WARD
description: Jack Ward, an associate or ganist at Radio City Music Hall, died Thursday in Leroy Hospi tal. He was 75 years old and lived in Hewitt, N. J.

title: Bear Stearns, Widens Horizons
description: While most houses in Wall Street are crying wolf these days, Bear, Stearns & Co. is singing a differentand more optimistictune.

title: Wheat Gypsies Follow The Harvest Northward
description: PLATTEVILLE, Colo., July 26Ronaid Work jerked the steering wheel of the Allis Chalmers Model L combine hard right, and eased it around until its 24foot cut ting edge dipped full into bleached yellow heads of wheat. Then he rammed the giant machine into second gear, and began gobbling up Sam Barclays wheat like a giant grasshopper.

title: QUEEN'S CUP RACE GOES TO EQUATION
FELLOWSHIP ROLE IS CITED IN TRIAL
description: Daniel Voll underwent a day long crossexamination yester day by the defense attorney for Ted Patrick, who sought to show that Mr. Voll, a mem ber of the New Testament Mis sionary Fellowship, had taken cues from the religious group in making decisions.

title: MISSES FERRARIS, LITTLE LEAD GOLF
Philip Hartung, Film Critic For Commonweal, Is Dead
description: Philip T. Hartung, film critic for Commonweal magazine from 1938 to 1973 and for other pe riodicals, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 70 years old and formerly lived in the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Elizabeth G. Blank Bride in England
description: Miss Elizabeth Grayson Blank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Edward Blank of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian Rogerson Hartley of Leeds, England, who is director of archeologi cal studies at the University of Leeds. The bride is keeper of archeology at the York shire Museum in York, Eng land, where the ceremony was performed in St. Co lomba's United Reformed Church by the Rev. J. R. Wal lace, Presbyterian pastor of the church.

title: Campaign Reform Bill Loses Momentum in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, July 27A postWatergate drive in the Senate to add new and tougher reform provisions to the 18 monthold Federal campaign fi nance law lost momentum today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Antiques: The Popularity of Glass Paperweights
description: Twentyone years ago it seemed as if the overthrow of King Farouk of Egypt would smash to smithereens the frenzied collecting of French 19thcentury paper weights. It didn't And judg ing by events of recent years, an auction last March and the scheduled publication of yet another formidable book on the subject, these fragile looking bibelots are emerg ing as rocksolid investments.

title: 8 IN NARCOTICS RING ARE CONVICTED HERE
description: Eight members of a narcotics ring that allegedly had planned to distribute $10million worth of heroin in the metropolitan area were convicted yesterday after a twoweek jury trial in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Texas Man's Body Is Found in House With His 39 Dogs
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 27 The body of a retired geolo gist was discovered today at his home in an upper middle class suburb of San Antonio. There were 39 dogs in the house, the authorities said.

title: COSMOS 31 VICTORS AS FINK SCORES TWO
description: ATLANTA, July 27 (AP) Joe Fink scored two goals as, the New York Cosmos regis tered a 31 victory over the Atlanta Apollos tonight in a North American Soccer League game.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NEWCOMERS The inter national music that comes out of the United Nations is often discordant and hard on the ears. The music that will come out of Central Park at 5:45 tomorrow will also be made by people from many lands but, it may be hoped, will be distinguished by more harmony. The free concert in the bandshell on the Mall, near 72d Street and Fifth Avenue, is called An Evening of International Music, and consists of a number of recitals by musi cal artists from other coun tries, most of whom, but not all, left their homelands as refugees. Two violinists and four singers will perform.

title: H. HARVEY PIKE DIES; IMPORTER OF SUGAR
description: H. Harvey Pike, long a lead ing sugar importer here, died Thursday at his summer home in Ledyard. Conn. He was 85 years old and lived at 320 East 72d Street.

title: U.S. Army Is Said to Spy On Its Critics in Germany
description: BONN, July 27United States Army intelligence has begun a program of offensive counter intelligence against antiArmy civilian groups in West Germa ny  tapping their telephones, photographing their meeting places and trying to infiltrate them, according to some of the participating intelligence agents.

title: U.S. REPORTS DROP IN PRODUCTIVITY
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 The Labor Department re ported today a small decline in productivity, or output per manhour, in the second quarter but a senior Treasury Depart. ment economist promptly said the figures were unintentional ly misleading.

title: F.B.I. Man Says Gray Was a Paper Shredder
description: ROGERS, Ark., July 27 (AP)  Ray Faisst, special agent in charge of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation office in Little Rock, said today that L. Patrick Gray 3d, former acting director of the bureau, was a paper shredder who dumped the White House trash.

title: New Mushroom Recall
description: BOSTON, July 27 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had asked for a recall of two additional mushroom products manufac tured by Wirth Food Products, Inc., of Lawrence, that are sus pected of containing botulism toxin. The products were be lieved to have been distributed only in Rhode Island under the brand name of ChefARoni. One type is mushrooms mari nated in sherry in six ounce glass jars. The other is mush rooms marinated in herbs in six ounce, 16 ounce and 32 ounce glass jars.

title: Car Plunge Kills 8
description: NASHVILLE, July 27 (AP) Eight persons were killed be fore dawn today when their automobile went off the 100 foot Silliman Evans Bridge here. Only a child survived. Sgt. Larry Loftis of the police said that the driver of the car, which bore Arkansas license plates, apparently went to sleep behind the wheel.

title: ITALY SETS DEPOSIT ON OVERSEAS FUNDS
description: ROME, July 27 (Reuters) The Italian Government today announced a 50 per cent non Interest paying deposit require ment on funds used for invest ment abroad of any kind.

title: Business Puts on a Show To Depict Its. Role in Art
description: Art + Business = People. That is an equation that the Arts and Business Council of New York City uses to de scribe its exhibition illus trating corporate involve ment in New York commu nity projects.

title: Thieu's ExFriend Spurns Amnesty Offer
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27A former army officer and legislator who was jailed four years ago after he advocated negotiations to end the war has been told that before he can be released from prison he must publicly confess Commu nist ties and renounce them.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: About the Mets:
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, and all those around them, seem sure they are going to wind up winning the Eastern Division race. . . . On May 8, their wonlost record was 520. . . . Since then, through Thursday night's game, they had won 48 games and lost 25, a .658 pace, good enough to win most pennants, maintained over almost half a sea son. . . . In contrast, the Mets, who were 1915 on May 18, have been 2338 since, through Thursday night, and they haven't done that poorly for that long a stretch since before they won the pennant in 1969. . . . Helping to turn the Cards mound have been some newcomersKen Reitz and Mike Tyson, rookies playing third and short, and Bernie Carbo as the right fielderand Joe Torre as the first baseman. . . . Meanwhile, the two longestservice CardinalsBob Gibson and Lou Brockare adding impres sively to their career records. . . . In Thursday night's 131 victory, Gibson hit a grand slam homer and, in pitching a sixhitter, moved one ahead of Juan Marichal for the honor of being the topwinning pitcher now active. . . . The victory was his 236th, and this year he is 119, after a 14 start.... Gibson remains second only to Walter Johnson in career strikeouts (he has 2,918) and has had 256 consecu tive starting assignments (that is, with no intervening. relief appearances), a major league record. . . . His homer was the 22d of his career and half the 16 nonpitchers who started that have fewer.

title: Lillian Reis and Six Men Indicted on Drug Charges
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury has indicted Lillian Reis, the former entertainer and night club operator, and six men on charges of conspiring to buy and distribute the drug me thamphetamine.

title: McNally Suffered Fracture Of Jaw When Hit by Ball
description: BALTIMORE, July 27 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles disclosed today that Dave McNally, a pitcher, suffered a hairline frac ture of the left jaw when struck by a line drive in the first game of yesterday's twilight  night doubleheader against Cleveland.

title: U.S. Using Latin Pawns, Castro Says
description: HAVANA, July 27 (Reuters) Cuba's Premier, Fidel Castro, has accused the United States of using the most reactionary and corrupt regimes in Latin America to isolate the conti nent's progressive governments.

title: Greece's Premier Will Stay In Even if Voted Out
description: ATHENS, July 27George Papadopoulos closed his un opposed campaign for the presidency of the new Greek republic today by saying he would continue to rule even if rejected at the polls on Sun day.

title: Radio
ROBERT H. MERTENS
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., July 27 Robert H. Mertens, controller of Zuckerman Smith & Co., a New York stockbrokers, died yester day. He was 69 years old and lived here.

title: Pollution Steps Delayed By Delaware River Panel
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 27The Delaware River Basin Commis sion voted today to postpone until its next meeting in Sep tember any action to force Cam den and several smaller cities in Camden County to stop pol uting the river.

title: Hydro Races Start Today
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 27 (AP) A field of nearly 150 has entered the inboard national hydroplane championships for tomorrow and Sunday at East wood Lake. The races also will include ski boats and inboard runabouts.

title: City Studying Allegations Of Kickbacks by Morticians
description: Nicholas Scoppetta, the City Investigations Commissioner, is looking into the alleged pay ment of kickbacks and gra tuities to employes of the Medical Examiner's office by funeral directors seeking busi ness and favors.

title: CARNATION BIDS FOR HERFF JONES
description: H. E. Olson, chairman of the Carnation Company of Los Angeles, and A. J. Hackl, presi dent and chief executive offi cer of the Herff Jones Com pany of Minneapolis, announced yesterday an agreement in prin ciple for the merger of Herf?? Jones into Carnation. Herf?? Jones, a manufacturer of class rings, yearbooks and related prod ucts, reported ?? net income o?? $2,095,000 on sales of $43,496,000 for its fiscal year ended June 30 Carnation, a multinational proc essor of foods, reported earn ings of $55.8million on sales of $1.24billion in 1972.

title: Parking Unit Aide Named
description: The appointment of Harry W. Voccola to the post of dep uty director of the Parking Violations Bureau was an nounced yesterday by Manuel Carballo, Acting Transporta tion Administrator, Mr. Vocco la, 33 years old, is a computer expert. His salary will be $29, 000 a year.

title: Prof it TakingClips Rally In Stocks, but Dow Is Up
description: The surging summer rally in the stock market finally was clipped by profit taking yester day and prices closed on the fence in quiet, preweekend trading.

title: Artificial Larynx Allows Speech That Is Effortless
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 A little instrument invented by a member of the New York Medical College faculty promises the immediate res toration of effortless speech for a person whose larynx, or voice box, has been removed in surgery. Patent 3,747,127 was

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, JULY 28, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: A 1973 Woodstock Jams Watkins Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 27The Summer Jam rock festival shaped up this evening as the largest out door gathering of young people in the East since Wood stock four years ago as thousands and thousands of campers swarmed into the Grand Prix race track area here for a day of music set to begin tomorrow morning.

title: Nix on's Refusal to Yield His Tapes Could Jeopardize Some Watergate Prosecutions
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 President Nixon's refusal tc yield the tape recordings of his Watergate conversations could, if sustained by the courts, jeop ardize the prosecution of some suspects in the case.

title: Kicker Signs With Raiders
description: CHICAGO, July 27 (UPI)  Ray Guy, a punter and place kicker from Southern Missis sippi, the No. 1 draft choice of the Oakland Raiders, signed a threeyear contract with them today for more than $200,000. Guy was the National Colle giate punting leader last year with a 46.2yard average on 58 kicks. He also booted a 61 yard field goal.

title: Equity Financing
description: JennAir Corporation, Indianapolis, yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an initial public offering of 245,000 common shares to be made through an underwriting group managed by Shearson Hammill.

title: Yanks Overcome 3Run Deficits Twice, Beat Brewers, 76, on Blomberg Single
59Day Space Trip Starts Today
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 27The countdown for Skylab 2 entered its final hours tonight as three American astronauts prepared to embark on what would be man's longest voyage in space to date, a 59day mis sion aboard a laboratory in earth orbit.

title: Fingerprinting of 8thGraders Delayed
description: NEWARK, July 27 More than 40 eighth grade boys ordered fingerprinted in connec tion with a murder investiga tion were given the right to appeal the court order today. But they were told to present themselves for fingerprinting to the Essex County Sheriff's office no later than noon next. Friday, or risk being charged with contempt of court.

title: POTATO FUTURES DROP DAILY LIMIT
description: On the New York Mercantile Exchange here yesterday the key May delivery contract for potato futures closed at 8.25 cents a pound, down the daily permissible limit of 40 points from 8.65 the previous day. Other deliveries also were down the limit.

title: Cox and Committee Seek To Head Off Court Test
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Archibald Cox, the special pros ecutor, and leaders of the Sen ate Watergate committee tried today to head off a constitu tional collision over the Presi dential tape recordings in the Watergate affair.

title: Big A Fans Not Excited Over Coming MatchRace
description: The early reaction to the announcement of the match race between Secretariat and Riva Ridge fell noiselessly into the dull thud department at Aqueduct yesterday. Few people seemed aware or in terested in the proposed meeting between the colts, both owned by the Meadow Stable. Their meeting at 1 miles is listed for Belmont Park on Sept. 15, a pro motion of Philip Morris, Inc., maker of Marl boro cigarettes, in conjunc tion with the New York Rac ing Association. A random

title: Hughes Urges Senate to Resist Pressure to Extend Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Senator Harold E. Hughes urged his colleagues today to resist what he said would be the Nixon Administration's inevi table pressures to bludgeon Congress and the American people in an attempt to con tinue bombing Cambodia after the Aug. 15 deadline.

title: Business Briefs
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 27 (UPI)Venezuela raised her crude oil and refined products prices today by an aver age of 36 cents a barrel. The move was the third increase the South American oil producer has decreed in less than a year.

title: Look Back in Sentiment
description: WASHINGTONIt's a boom all right. We can tell because nostalgia record companies and movie houses are raking in dollars like they're going out of style. If dollars do go out of style, they will become objects of nos talgia themselves. The only qualifica tion for the feeling is that it be di rected toward something remote and irrecoverable, thereby making every thing in our experience available to it.

title: People and Business Cornfeld Writes of Life in Jail
description: Bernard Cornfeld, the 45 yearold American financier and founder of the collapsed Investors Overseas Services financial empire, has written a circular letter to his friends from a Swiss jail stating that he was not as unhappy as I would have expected.

title: U.S. WILL STIFFEN OIL AND GAS RULES
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  John A. Love, the Nixon Ad ministration's new energypoli cy director, said today that he would announce next week a revised, stiffer version of the Government's voluntary pro gram for allocating supplies of oil and gasoline.

title: City Studies Alleged Kickbacks By Funeral Homes to Officials
description: Nicholas Scoppetta, the City Investigations Commissioner, is looking into the alleged pay ment of kickbacks and gra tuities to employes of the Medical Examiner's office by funeral directors seeking busi ness and favors.

title: Raid on  W eird Commune Here Turns Up $30,000 in Fake Bills
description: The Secret Service yesterday announced that it had seized $30,000 in counterfeit bills and printing presses at a weird commune where young women venerated a man as Om Eternal and denounced money as the main cause of corruption and crime.

title: BIG 6HOUR BATTLE REPORTED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27 (Reuters)The South Viet namese command reported to day that Government and Com munist troops fought one of their most intense battle in months north of Saigon yester day.

title: Rocky's Road Shapes Up as Smoother One With 2 Seasons of Orientation Behind Him
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 27Rocky Thomp son, kickoffreturn specialist and reserve halfback for the reserve halfback for the New York Giants, has big plans both for the football season and next winter's pro track tour.

title: Football Transactions AMERICAN CONFERENCE
description: CLEVELANDReleased Don Madden, running back from Eastern Michigan

title: DEMOCRATS NAME JUDGESHIP SLATEs
Part Way on Pensions
description: The pensionreform plan for public employes adopted by the State Legislature in special session at Albany sets up so many different categories of workers and contains such liberal benefits for all of them that it hardly qualifies as reform or a plan. Savings to burdened governmental units flowing from the legisla tion are so modest that they will have little immediate budgetary impact.

title: COLUMBIA EXPECTS A SUBSTANTIAL LOSS
description: Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., which announced a major realignment of its top echelon this week, announced yester day that it expected to report a substantial loss for the fiscal year ended June 30, resulting from several factors. A loss from operations is also expect ed to be shown for the fourth quarter, the company said.

title: U.S. PRESSES EUROPE ON DEFENSE DEFICITS
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States was pressing its West European allies to partici pate in developing special monetary arrangement to re duce the deficit in the Ameri can balance of payments re sulting from the stationing of troops in Europe.

title: The Last American Hero Arrives Here
Witness Criticizes Drinking in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 John D. Ehrlichman sternly de fended today the Nixon cam paign's practice of spying on opposition political candidates, saying that politicians had an affirmative obligation to in vestigate and expose the drink ing habits and personal morals of other candidates.

title: DR. LAN JEN CHU, 59, M.I.T. ENGINEER DIES
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., July 27 (AP)Dr. Lan Jen Chu, prof. of electrical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Tech nology and holder of more than 25 antenna patents, died Wed nesday at the age of 59.

title: HOLCOMB LEAVES WHITE SOX POST General Manager Quits After Disputes With Tanner
description: CHICAGO, July 27 (AP)  Stu Holcomb resigned today as executive vice president and general manager of the Chicago White Sox in what apparently was a power conflict with Ro land Hemond and Chuck Tan ner, whom he hired three years ago.

title: Black TeenAger Crowned
description: Miss Edna Hill of Columbia, Md., was crowned Miss Black Teenage American last night at the Broadway Theatre. The 15 yearold Miss Hill, who is 5 feet 6 inches tall and weighs 123 pounds, gave an original recita tion called My People's Herit age, in which she traced the history of the black people since the Emancipation Procla mation.

title: ROBERT E. HENRY JR.
description: Robert E. Henry Jr., who re tired in 1954 as president of the Associated Industrials Corpora tion, an investment company here, died Thursday in Burling ton, Vt. He was 67 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla., and Hague, N. Y.

title: CHASE IS LEAVING HEALTH SERVICES
description: Gordon Chase, the first non physician to head the city's Health Services Administration, announced yesterday that he would resign Oct. 1 after nearly four years in the post.

title: Canadian Group, Deploring U.S. Example, Fights the Wrecker's Ball
description: MONTREAL, July 27A group of citizens are fight ing the proposed demolition of a stately Victorian man sion here in a battle that reflects new concern among Canadians about the future of their cities.

title: Shortages of Beef Loom As More Packers Close
description: CHICAGO, July 27  Shop pers will have to look even harder Monday to find their favorite cuts of beef because cattle feeders and packers have begun reducing the supply.

title: The Baton in the Iron Fist
description: ORPHEUS IN THE NEW WORLD: The Sym phony Orchestra as an American Cultural Institution. 562 pages. Illustrated. By Philip Hart. Norton. $15.

title: Macaw, Lured by Apple, Recaptured
description: A motley macaw named Macwho took the occasion of his own presentation to the Central Park Zoo Thursday to fly awaywas captured in the upper reaches of a lofty Central Park sycamore yes terday afternoon by an agile Dominican youth with a tempter's apple and a spiel of soothing, cooing Spanish.

title: Rough Passage
description: The House signaled another rough passage for foreign aid legislation the other day when it narrowly adopted a curtailed version of the imaginative new economic assistance program that had emerged from its Foreign Affairs Committee.

title: WINE TALK In France, Quite a Few of the Local Vintners Also Preside at the Synagogue
description: Several weeks ago, there appeared in this space some notes about Emil Koenig, a Lutheran winemaker in Al sace who annually turns his plant over to a rabbi from Strasbourg. The rabbi, with the aid of some theological students, then proceeds to make some 5,000 cases of kosher Alsatian wine.

title: Football Players Union Goes to Bat for Rentzel
description: CHICAGO, July 27  Ed Garvey, executive director of the National Football League Players Association, dis closed today that his group and Lance Rentzel of the Rams would file a Federal antitrust suit in Los Angeles next week in an attempt to overturn Rentzel's suspen sion by Commissioner Pete RazeIle.

title: Meeting of Soviet Allies In Crimea Is Indicated
description: MOSCOW, July 27Leonid I. Brezhnev flew to the Crimea today amid mounting indica tions that the Communist party leaders of Eastern Europe, Mongolia and pos sibly North Vietnam are gath ering for a meeting there to review the Soviet leader's latest personal diplomacy in the West.

title: Fire Ruins Detroit Theater
description: DETROIT, July 27 (UPI)A fivealarm fire destroyed the 70 yearold Follies Theater last night.

title: NOSTALGIA LURKS AT FOLK FESTIVAL
description: VIENNA, Va., July 27  Since it is a prime purpose of the 35yearold National Folk Festival to present traditional, homegrown or regional music in as undiluted a form as possi ble, it was not surprising that the first evening of the annual fourday festival last night at Wolf Trap Farm Park should lean heavily toward musicians and singers in their sixties and seventies.

title: FRANZ MATSCH 74, DIPLOMAT, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Franz Matsch, Austria's first Ambassador to the United Nations and a wellknown dip lomatic figure at the United Nations and the League of Na tions for many years, died Wednesday at his home in Vienna after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and made his home in this country in Larch mont, N.Y.

title: MORIARTY GUILTY IN GAMBLING CASE
description: JERSEY CITY, July 27 (AP) Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarty, ac cused of operating a $6million ayear numbers lottery, was convicted today of gambling conspiracy, possessing lottery slips and assaulting a police man.

title: Jail Escape Is Foiled, Officials Report
description: An attempted escape from the fifth floor of the Brooklyn House of Detention by four in mates, including an alleged member of the Black Liberation Army, was thwarted shortly after midnight Thursday by a surprise sweep of the cellblock by prison guards, according to officials.

title: Consumer Notes Protein Shopping Can Cut Costs
description: Twentyfive years ago, the average American family spent 25 per cent of its in come for food. Now the fig ure is 16 per cent, according to the Extension Service of Cornell University, but the pendulum is starting to swing the other way, partly because the food production and distribution industry cannot offset higher costs through greater efficiency as much as it has in the past.

title: Once a Stationhouse, Now It Resounds With the Laughter of Children
description: The music and laughter emanating these days from the fortresslike building at 150 West 68th Street are, no doubt, about the happiest sounds ever heard coming from the red brick structure.

title: Back Into Balance
description: The nation's foreign trade account was virtually in balance in June, with imports exceeding exports by only $15 million. During this year's AprilJune quarter, the United States had even a modest trade surplus of $23 millionthe first quarterly surplus in over two years.

title: Music: War and Water
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 27 During the morning there was music for war and in the afternoon there was music for water. The Newport Mu sic Festival always comes up with concerts like these. At night the musicians settle down for a more serious, though not necessarily bet ter, kind of music making. Certainly the water program, sung by members of the Met ropolitan Opera Studio, was as charming and imaginative a concert as would satisfy the most jaded listener.

title: CORYDON CHAMBERLAIN
description: Corydon S. Chamberlain, who retired as New York regional vice president of the F. W. Woolworth Company in 1944, died Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 90 years old.

title: Roundup: Palmer Downs Indians on 1 Hitter, 90
description: In 1964, when Jim Palmer broke into organized base ball, he established his po tential with an 8.0, nohit game against DuluthSuperior in the Northern League.

title: Radino Is Named to Head Byrne's State Campaign
description: The Democratic State Com mittee announced yesterday the appointment of Representative Peter W. Rodino of Newark to serve as chairman of a new state campaign committee.

title: SAMUEL D. FABER
description: Samuel D. Faber, a retired printing broker and color coun selor, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 7 West 16th Street.

title: BANK OF ENGLAND RAISES LOAN RATE TO RECORD 11%
description: PARIS, July 27  Lending rates in Britain were lifted to day to their highest levels in history, and in West Germany a tight monetary squeeze was eased somewhat in moves that helped halt the slide of the dol lar and the pound in the inter national currency markets.

title: CALVIN FRIZER
description: Calvin Frizer, vice chairman of the Brooklyn chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality, died Sunday in Brooklyn. The cause of death was not im mediately known, although Mr. Frizer suffered from asthma and emphysema. He was 54 years old and lived at 144 Mac Dougal Street, Brooklyn.

title: Revered Guru,15, Brings His Mission Here
description: Guru Maharaj Ji, the boy his followers call Lord of the Uni verse, King of Kings, the one perfect master on earth at this timewho has inspired one of the fastestgrowing religious movements in this country to daysat on a gold velvet sofa and told a visitor, I'm just a I5yearold kid.

title: Blum Rides 4,000th Winner of Career
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 27 Walter Blum became the sixth jockey to win 4,000 horse races when he rode Student Lamp to victory in the seventh race at Mon mouth Park today, just two days short of the 20th an niversary of his first victory. That one was achieved at the old Jamaica track in New York.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Despite new preventive programs and the increased availability of counseling, suicides are on the increase in city prison facilities, ac cording to a report by the Board of Correction.

title: 59Day Space Trip Starts Today
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 27The countdown for Skylab 2 entered its final hours tonight as three American astronauts prepared to embark on what would be man's longest voyage in space to date, a 59day mis sion aboard a laboratory in earth orbit.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Profound changes are taking place on the world economic scene, and there has never been a time when international economic cooperation was more essential.

title: In Cambodia's Second City, Smugglers and the Peace of Centuries
description: BATTAMBANG, Cambodia, July 20On a tree at the edge of the Sangker River little children, all arms and legs, swing out wide on a rope hung from a lower branch and, with gleeful shouts, fall splashing into the river.

title: France Is Increasing Her Nuclear Force
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  France is expanding her nu clear force by constructing sites in southeastern France for a third group of intermedi ate range ballistic missiles with thermonuclear warheads, ac cording to authoritative United States sources.

title: Books of The Times The Baton in the Iron Fist
description: ORPHEUS IN THE NEW WORLD: The Sym phony Orchestra as an American Cultural Institution. 562 pages. Illustrated. By Philip Hart. Norton. $15.

title: G.M. Reports Records
description: Record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of 1973 were dis closed yesterday by the Gen eral Motors Corp. Page 31.

title: TEXASGULF GAINS 10DAY HALT IN BID
description: Texasgulf, Inc., obtained a court order yesterday halting for at least 10 days a drive by the Canada Development Cor poration, a wholly owned arm of the Canadian Government, to acquire effective control of the major United States con cern, which has extensive min ing operations in Ontario.

title: INDIA PLAYER, 19, ELIMINATES LAVER
description: BRETTON WOODS, N. H., July 27 (AP)Young Vijai Am ritraj of India seeded seventh, upset topranked Rod Laver of Australia in the $25,000 Volvo tennis tournament today and advanced to the semifinals.

title: Ellen Levy's Bridal
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., July 27  Miss Ellen Joan Levy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton J. Levy, was married here this evening to Emanuel Dahari, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Dahari of Flushing, Queens, and Tel Aviv. Rabbi Steven Pinsky performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Phnom Penh Reports Infiltration And Orders Residents to Arm
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 27 (AP)The military com mand ordered the people of Pnom Penh today to take up arms against the possibility of attack by antiGovernment rebels it said had infiltrated the city.

title: Saratoga Gets Sample Of Secretariat's Speed
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 27 (P)The Triple Crown winner, Secretariat, un officially bettered two Sara toga track records during practice runs over a sloppy track today.

title: By Robert K. Davis and Carole Grossman
description: BALTIMORE  Several major oil companies have run a series of news paper advertisements which propound this message: We have an energy crisis; cheap energy is essential; environmentalists are hostile to growth and are preventing us from supplying everyone's energy needs.

title: Fire Ruins Detroit Theater
description: DETROIT, July 27 (UPI)A fivealarm fire destroyed the 70 yearold Follies Theater last night.

title: Metropolitan Briefs Family Planning Clinics Investigated
description: Commissioner of Investigation Nicholas Scoppetta said he was investigating the hiring practices of the city's Human Resources Administration familyplanning clinics following the arrest of a 20yearold former Army medic charged with falsely representing himself as a physician and sexually abusing women patients. The defendant, Jesus M. Lopez of 1053 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, applied July 2 for a position as a physician with the H.R.A. and was assigned to the Action for Progress Family Planning Clinic at 57 Rivington Street and the Staten Island Com munity Health Clinic. He was charged with sexually abus ing patients while checking their sexual responses.

title: Kassulke Slightly Improved
description: ST. LOUIS PARK, Minn., July 27 (AP)  Karl Kassulke, the Minnesota Viking defensive back who was critically injured in a motorcycle crash last Tues day, was reported by a Meth odist. Hospital spokesman today to be slightly improved.

title: Dave Anderson Another Soap Opera for the Cubs
description: CHICAGO, July 27The baseball romance that sur rounds the Chicago Cubs belongs in a soap opera. It's conducted by the people here in the afternoons because Wrigley Field doesn't have the lights that would create a primetime drama. It thrives on the heartbreak of false hope. Less than a month ago, the Cubs were leading the National League East by eight games. Now they're strug gling to stay in second place. Tomorrow they open a four game series with the St. Louis Cardinals, who have streaked past them into first place. In their recent history, the Cubs have been unable to regain first place. Three years ago, they wasted a fivegame lead in June, pulled to within percentage points of first place, then lost 13 of their next 25 games. Four years ago, with a 9game lead in August, they lost 25 of their last 41 games as the New York Mets won the pennant.

title: Unions Vow to Win Back Losses From Newly Voted Pension Bill
OHLSSON PERFORMS AT CONCERT IN PARK
description: Backstage at Thursday night's concert by the New York Phil harmonic in Central Park, Gar rick Ohlsson said that the Brahms First Piano Concerto was one of his favorite works and that he felt particularly lucky in being able to play it in his debut with the orchestra. For it was not an originally scheduled performance; he was replacing another pianist, Ho ratio Guttierez, who could not appear that night.

title: Witness Defends Spying in Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 John D. Ehrlichman sternly de fended today the Nixon cam paign's practice of spying on opposition political candidates, saying that politicians had an affirmative obligation to in vestigate and expose the drink ing habits and personal morals of other candidates.

title: Congress Urged to Cancel Plans for August Recess
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Congress was urged by a cit izens organization yesterday to cancel its scheduled August recess because of the confron tation with President Nixon over Watergate evidence.

title: Tanaka to Meet Brezhnev
description: TOKYO, July 27 (Reuters) Premier Kakuei Tanaka and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, will open their first talks in the Kremlin Oct. 8 and 9, Foreign Ministry sources here said to day. Mr. Tanaka, who leaves Sunday for Washington to see President Nixon, will visit Mos cow on his way home from tours of France, Britain and West Germany from Sept. 26 through Oct. 5, the sources said.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: Research  Cottrell, Inc., re ported its Canadian subsidiary has received a $10  million award for installation of a hot electrostatic precipitator for Calgary Power, Ltd., at its Wabamum plant site.

title: Legislature Defers Action On Transit, Citing Fatigue
description: ALBANY, July 27The Leg islature deferred action on Gov ernor Rockefeller's $3.5billion transportation bond proposal this evening and recessed the special session until Monday.

title: Migrants'
description: SWEDESBORO, N. J., July 27 Venerando (Henry) Marino plans to leave his farm on Stone Meeting House Road north of here next Monday for an important day in court.

title: South Africa Student Leader Placed Under House Arrest
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 27 (Reuters)  The new leader of the nonwhite South African Students Organization, has been placed under house arrest, a spokesman for the South African Ministry of Jus tice said today.

title: Excerpts From Ehrlichman's Testimony Before Senate Committee on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony by John D. Ehrlichman today on the 30th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign activities:

title: Oklahoma Convicts Seize 21 Hostages; 3 Inmates Are Slain
description: McALESTER, Okla., Saturday, July 28Rioting convicts, some of them said by the prison of ficials to be hopped up, seized control of Oklahoma's major prison here last night and began systematically to burn it.

title: Dr. Milton Hoffman, 87, Headed Reformed Synod
description: MIDDLEBUSH, N. J., July 27 The Rev. Dr. Milton J. Hoff man, president of the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America in 1931 and pro fessor of church history at the New Brunswick Theological Seminary from 1925 to 1956, died today in a nursing home in Franklin Township. He was 87 years old and lived here.

title: Port Police Return To Jobs After Judge Renews Strike Ban
description: JERSEY CITY, July 27  About 250 Port Authority po licemen went to court today most having walked off the job only to hear a judge renew until September an injunction against walkouts or any disrup tion of the authority's facili ties.

title: Cox and Committee Seek To Head Off Court Test
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Archibald Cox, the special pros ecutor, and leaders of the Sen ate Watergate committee tried today to head off a constitu tional collision over the Presi dential tape recordings in the Watergate affair.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Association of Ameri can Publishers, in a 33page brief filed yesterday, has asked the United States Su preme Court to reconsider its June 21 antiobscenity rulings on the ground that the jus tices have reduced the rule of law to a matter of taste.

title: Inouye Finds a Way To Halt Slips of Tongue
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  Senator Daniel K, Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, who was embarrassed Wednesday when a micro phone caught him muttering What a liar in response to John D. Ehrlichman's testi mony, thinks he has found a to avoid future slips.

title: Susan Schuchardt's Nuptials Held
description: TRENTON, July 27In the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart here this afternoon, Miss Susan Anne Schuchardt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Schu chardt of Princeton, became the bride of Lawrence de Quesada Kuser, son of Mrs. Walter G. Kuser of Borden town and the late Mr. Kuser.

title: About the Mets:
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, and all those around them, seem sure they are going to wind up winning the Eastern Division race. . . . On May 8, their wonlost record was 520. . . . Since then, through Thursday night's game, they had won 48 games and lost 25, a .658 pace, good enough to win most pennants, maintained over almost half a sea son. . . . In contrast, the Mets, who were 1915 on May 18, have been 2338 since, through Thursday night, and they haven't done that poorly for that long a stretch since before they won the pennant in 1969. . . . Helping to turn the Cards around have been some newcomersKen Reitz and Mike Tyson, rookies playing third and short, and Bernie Carbo as the right fielderand Joe Torre as the first baseman. . . . Meanwhile, the two longestservice CardinalsBob Gibson and Lou Brockare adding impres sively to their career reedits. . . . In Thursday night's 131 victory, Gibson hit a grand slam homer and, in pitching a sixhitter, moved one ahead of Juan Marichal for the honor of being the topwinning pitcher now active. . . . The victory was his 236th, and this year he is 119, after a 14 start. . . . Gibson remains second only to Walter Johnson in career strikeouts (he has 2,918) and has had 256 consecu tive starting assignments (that is, with no intervening relief appearances), a major league record. . . . His homer was the 22d of his career and half the 16 nonpitchers who started that game have fewer.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4)Modern Farmer

title: Market place In Acquisitions, Money Isn't All
description: When a selfmade man de cides to sell an attractive, thriving business, the acquir ing corporation usually has to pay top dollar. Right?

title: MRS. BELA VARKONYI
description: Mrs. Louise Krisanich Var konyi, a voice teacher and con cert singer in Europe and New York, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived in the Hudson View Gardens.

title: `Canuck Letter Sought From Paper by F.B.I.
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., July 27 (UPI)Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion asked The Manchester Union Leader today to turn over the Canuck letter that attributed an ethnic slur to Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine while he was campaigning for his party's 1972 Presidential nomination in Florida.

title: A Man of La Mancha Sued Over Swordplay Incident
description: Howard Keel, the actor, was sued for $1million yesterday by a couple who charged that the actor had struck them with a sword during a performance of Man of La Mancha last summer.

title: Mrs. Houghton Married Here
description: Mrs. Elizabeth McCall Houghton and Walker O. Cain, both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. William A. McQuoid performed the ceremony in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Pres byterian Church. He was as sisted by the Rev. Dr. John C. Coburn, rector of St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: Polywater's End
description: Most news about science concerns accomplishment: an astronomical discovery, the finding of a cure for a dis ease. But another fundamental feature of science is that it has a selfcorrecting mechanism, a formal means of mak ing sure that when a mistake has been made it will be found out and revealed.

title: Theater
description: How is Ionescopade? De licious. What is it? A bril liantly devised crazyquilt of flying bits, pieces and char acters from Eugene Ionesco's contributions to the Theater of the Absurd. Here is a beau tiful, hilarious show, as pro jected by the New Repertory Company (like a labor of love), nimbly stitched with four new tunes and deft choreography and played to the hiltand lunatic fringe by a marvelous repertory cast. Call them mimes, clowns, athletes or whatever, these girls and boys are artists.

title: Mary Lawrence Golf Victor
description: ITHACA, N. Y., July 27 (AP) Mary Lawrence of Canton de feated Nancy Kolln of Kingston, 2 and 1, today to win the New York state junior girls golf championship.

title: Notes on People Laird, a Stayer, Denies Rumors of Quitting
description: Melvin R. Laird, the White House domestic affairs ad viser, said published specula tion that he was planning to quit as an aide to President Nixon was not accurate. Mr. Laird told reporters in Wash ington that he considered himself a stayer on the White House staff. He said the speculation on his depar ture might be attributable to his candor in speaking to newsmen. In recent weeks, the former Defense Secretary has said publicly that Ronald L. Ziegler should be removed as White House Press Secre tary, and that the President should release the Watergate related tapes. My advice has not always been followed, Mr. Laird said. Mr. Laird also told newsmen that he is the secondhighestpaid person in the Federal government, after the President, who receives a $200,000 a year salary. Mr. Laird said he receives $30,000 a year from his pension as a former Representative (17 years service) and $42,500 a year as the President's ad viser.

title: The Cold War Virus
description: The Government no longer pretends to be embarrassed when it is caught lying. This is progress, no matter what moralists tell you.

title: Divers Seek Treasure in Andrea Doria Grave
description: ABOARD THE PUMP'R SINK, Off the Nantucket Shoals, July 27Full 40 fathoms and more below these green waters rests the liner Andrea Doria, the vic tim of one of the worst dis asters of recent maritime history.

title: Roundup: Palmer Downs Indians on 1Hitter, 90
description: In 1964, when Jim Palmer broke into organized base ball out of Towson State College in Maryland, he es tabilshed his future potential with an 80, nohit game against DuluthSuperior in the Northern League.

title: ARMY SECRETARY DEFENDS P.O.W'S
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) secretary of the Army How ard H. Callaway said today that Army enlisted men had no legal obligation to obey orders from Air Force officers in North Vietnamese prison camps.

title: J. D. Morton Weds Mrs. Grace Harrison
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 27 Mrs. Grace Dobson Harri son of Chappaqua, daughter of Mrs. Harry M. Dobson of Rockville Centre, L.I., and the late Mr. Dobson, and Joseph Daviess Morton of Thorn wood, son of Mrs. Henry J. Morton of Batavia, Ill., and the late Mr. Morton, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Alfred Moore, a Congregational minister, per formed the ceremony at his home.

title: Couture Scorecard: Good Is Quite Good
description: PARIS, July 27For those who are keeping scorecards, there were plenty of good collections in the couture openings, enough to balance the obviously poor ones. Yves Saint Laurent, as is his wont, tends to head the good guys group.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Many Congressmen, individuals and groups who support substantial tax reform have urged the House Ways and Means Committee to greatly re duce or eliminate the many Federal income tax deductions and credits which directly benefit the oil industry. The Treasury Department and many other antitaxreform Congressmen have opposed any change in the tax benefits to the oil industry, citing as a major reason for their opposition our nation's current petroleum shortage.

title: DOLPHINS DEFEAT ALLSTARS BY 143
Children's Pajamas Must Be Fireproof Under Federal Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The manufacture of chil dren's sleepwear that is flam mable, blamed for more than 300 infant deaths and up to 6,000 serious injuries each year, will be prohibited after today by Federal regulations.

title: Ban on Port Police Strike Extended Until September
description: JERSEY CITY, July 27  About 250 Port Authority po licemen went to court today most having walked off the job only to hear a judge renew until September an injunction against walkouts or any disrup tion of the authority's facili ties.

title: VIETCONG ASSAILED BY CANADIANS AGAIN
description: OTTAWA, July 27 (Canadian Press)  Canada's External Af fairs Minister said today that two Canadians held prisoner by the Vietcong in South Viet nam had been treated as ene mies or spies even though it was clearly understood that they were members of the In ternational Commission of Con trol and Supervision.

title: Ehrlichman Notes Indicate Plan to Limit Hunt Impact
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 John D. Ehrlichman's cryptic notes about a meeting April 13 with Charles W. Colson, an other former White House aide, indicate that they discussed way for President Nixon to head off the impact of any pos sible disclosures by E. Howard Hunt Jr., a convicted Watergate conspirator.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The former state Republican chairman, Nelson G. Gross, moved yesterday for a dismissal of his Federal tax perjury indictment on the ground that he had been unfairly prejudiced before the grand jury that charged him. Mr. Gross was indicted last May 22 on charges of conspiring to commit income tax fraud and of pressuring a grand jury witness to lie about alleged irregularities in fund rais ing for Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign.

title: Hanoi Will Allow U.S. To Recover P.O.W. Dead
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  The United States will be allowed to recover the bodies of 23 Americans who died as prisoners of war and were buried just out side Hanoi.

title: Auto Production Shows a Decline For Latest Week
description: DETROIT, July 27 (AP) Domestic auto production de clined this week as more plants shut down for the annual model changeover, according to Automotive News.

title: Lightning Kills Arizonan
description: TUCSON, Ariz., July 27 (AP) One man was killed and four other were injured when struck by lightning in a thunderstorm here last night. The authorities said that Jedro Rios, 41 years old, of Tucson, died several hours after he and two com panions were injured by light ning as they stood under a tree in a city park. Two others were injured in separate incidents.

title: Beef Shortages Expected As Packing Plants Close
description: CHICAGO, July 27  Shop pers will have to look even harder Monday to find their favorite cuts of beef because cattle feeders and packers have begun reducing the supply.

title: BANK OF ENGLAND RAISES LOAN RATE TO RECORD 11%
description: PARIS, July 27  Lending rates in Britain were lifted to day to their highest levels in history, and in West Germany a tight monetary squeeze was eased somewhat in moves that helped halt the slide of the dol lar and the pound in the inter national currency markets.

title: Seaver Beats Cards Wise, 21
Ballet: Artistic Growth
description: Some of the excitement of attending repertory perform ancesas in balletcomes from the opportunity to watch an artist grow from performance to performance or year to year.

title: Mary Lawrence Golf Victor
description: ITHACA, N. Y., July 27 (AP) Mary Lawrence of Canton de feated Nancy Kolin of Kingston, 2 and 1, today to win the New York state junior girls golf championship.

title: Blum in a Select Circle Headed by Shoemaker
U.S. Aid Prevents Vietnam Fuel Crisis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27Thanks to American aid, South Vietnam has avoided the shortages of gasoline and scrap steel that have plagued the United States.

title: Conferees Agree on Compromise 4Year Farm Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  SenateHouse conferees reached tentative agreement to day on a new fouryear farm bill including a price support escalator clause.

title: DOLPHINS DEFEAT ALLSTARS BY 143
description: CHICAGO, July 27Two touchdowns by Larry Csonka and too many mistakes by the College AllStars enabled the Miami Dolphins to preserve their prestige as National Foot ball League champions tonight with a 143 victory before 54,103 spectators and a nation al television audience.

title: Green and Fezler, at 138, Lead in Canada by Shot
David Bienstock, Curator Of Films at Whitney, Dies
description: David Bienstock, curator of films at the Whitney Museum of American Art, died of a self inflicted revolver shot Tuesday evening. He was 29 years old and lived at 107 West 82d Street.

title: Appeals Court Delays Ban On Bombing in Cambodia
description: An injunction to bar the American bombing of Cam bodia was blocked yesterday when the Government ob tained a stay in the United States Court of Appeals here.

title: G.M. Reports Records
description: Record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of 1973 were dis closed yesterday by the Gen eral Motors Corp. Page 31.

title: Conferees Agree on Compromise 4Year Farm Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  SenateHouse conferees reached tentative agreement to day on a new fouryear farm bill including a price support escalator clause.

title: The Turk Perils Rookies of Jets
Kassulke Slightly Improved
description: ST. LOUIS PARK, Minn., July 27 (AP)  Karl Kassulke, the Minnesota Viking defensive back who was critically injured in a motorcycle crash last Tues day, was reported by a Meth odist Hospital spokesman today to be slightly improved.

title: MRS. BARTHOLOMEW
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 27 Mrs. Evelyn Richardson Bar tholomew of Greenwich Lodge, wife of the choral director Mar shall Bartholomew, retired pro fessor of music at Yale Univer sity and longtime member of the Yale Glee Club, died today at Greenwich Hospital, She was 86 years old.

title: Remote Indian Tribe in Mexico Eats a Grain Grown in the Sea
description: Scientists have found that one of the few peoples still sur viving on food obtained by hunting and gathering have long used as a staple of their diet a grain grown in sea water.

title: CITY JAILS REPORT RISE IN SUICIDES 9 Inmate Deaths Are Listed in First Half of This Year
description: Despite new preventive pro grams and the increased avail ability of counseling, suicides are on the increase in city pris ons, according to a private re port by the Board of Correc tion.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on bill limiting power of President to commit United States forces to hostilities in for eign nations to 30 days without Congressional approval, which passed, 72 to 18, July 20.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yeater day was: 95305
description: Tickets matching the number win 62,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win 3225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers In sequence Win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2,50.

title: AETNA LIFE PROFIT UP 5% IN QUARTER
description: The Aetna Life and Casually Company, the nation's largest investorowned insurance enter prise, reported yesterday net income for the second quarter of $47million, $1.76 a share up 5 per cent from $44.7 million, or $1.67 a share, in the yearearlier period.

title: Screen Hail to the Chief
G. M. Reports Record Profits and Sales For the Second Quarter and First Half
description: DETROIT, July 27  The General Motors Corporation reported today record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of 1973.

title: Macaw, Lured by Apple, Recaptured
description: A motley macaw named Macwho took the occasion of his own presentation to the Central Park Zoo Thursday to fly awaywas captured in the upper reaches of a lofty Central Park sycamore yes terday afternoon by an agile Dominican youth with a tempter's apple and a spiel of soothing, cooing Spanish.

title: St. Laurent Lies in State
description: QUEBEC CITY, July 27 (Reu ters)  Louis St. Laurent's fel low citizens paid tribute today to the man who was Prime Minister of Canada from 1948 to 1957. Mr. St. Laurent, who was lying in state at the Quebec Na tional Assembly, died Wednes day at the age of 92. He will be buried in Compton, Quebec, tomorrow.

title: Brazilian Mercedes Set Here
description: As a result of recent mone tary changes that have made imports from West Germany into this country more expen sive, MercedesBenz of North America will begin marketing this fall a line of diesel trucks made for the United States market by MercedesBenz do Brasil, S.A., the company an nounced yesterday.

title: HOLCOMB LEAVES WHITE SOX POST
description: CHICAGO, July 27 (AP)  Stu Holcomb resigned today as executive vice president and general manager of the Chicago White Sox in what apparently was a power conflict with Ro land Hemond and Chuck Tan ner, whom he hired three years ago.

title: Alaska Pipe Dream
description: MONTREALOne fine day like the day after tomorrow while the Canadi an Energy Minister was minding his own business by saying the Alaska oil pipeline was really an internal matter in the U.S.A. and not for Canadians to jump into, one fine day in the not too distant future while the Energy Minister was talking he suddenly noticed that one leg of his trousers was wet, and hoping it was not what he thought it was, he reached down and determined that in fact it was not an internal matter at all but an ex ternal matter of oil, and yet not pure oil for when he inspected his hand he found it not only oily but bloody, and when he rushed to the lab to find out why blood was mixed with oil and whether or not it was his blood mixed with their oil or their blood mixed with his oil or whatever, he was in formed by the laboratory hired by the oil company that there was really nothing to worry about at all, since the blood would the oil from working perfectly in American war machines and automobiles, not to mention the Mayor of Montreal's auto mobile, and in any case the blood was not the Canadian ministry's blood and it was not the American people's blood, it was simply the blood of one billion waterfowl who had been unable to feed in the tundra which had been disrupted by the perfectly innocent pipeline, and it was simply the blood of one billion fish in Canadian water ways and one billion fish in Canadian seaways who were no longer able to eat the plankton now flavored with salted oil, and it was simply the blood of one billion deer in the Northern Territory and one billion other wild animals in other frozen territories in the Siberia of Canada which had grad ually become unfrozen for the first time in recorded time due to the world's largest oil spill which had re sulted from earthquake pipeline rup turings which caused a great wash of hot underground oil to pour eastward from Alaska all over the geologic un derground strataface of Canada, so that the St. Lawrence dripped both oil and animal blood into the water sup ply of Montreal, but this was strictly an Internal American Matter, and we were not concerned at all, at all . . . .

title: B52 Flier to Cite Religion in Refusal To Bomb Cambodia
description: Donald E. Dawson, an Air Force captain who is facing a possible courtmartial for re fusing to fly a bombing mission over Cambodia, said yester day that he would defend his action on the ground of sincere religious objection to any fur ther participation in war  the war in Cambodia or any other war.

title: DEXTER N. SHAW
description: WAYNE, Pa., July 27Dex ter N. Shaw, a lawyer and for mer president of the Philadel phia Patent Law Association, died Wednesday in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: 7% CUT IN TROOPS BACKED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The Senate Armed Services Com mittee, in an economy move designed ultiimately to save $1.6billion a year in defense spending, voted unanimously today to impose a 7 per cent cut in military troop strength in the coming year.

title: Divers Seeking Treasure in Andrea Doria Grave
