description: ABOARD THE PUMP'R SINK, Off the Nantucket Shoals, July 27Full 40 fathoms and more below these green waters rests the liner Andrea Doria, the vic tim of one of the worst dis asters of recent maritime history.

title: STATE TO ENFORCE DISCLOSURE LAW
description: TRENTON, July 27  Many candidates who ran in the April primary election are in danger of being fined up to $1,000 as the result of failing to meet the first reporting deadline under New Jersey's new campaign disclosure law.

title: FACING FACTS
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shca Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M.

title: The Grain Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Speculators were calling it a little Watergate, for the Senate inquiry into the Soviet grain deal was falling into a pattern made familiar by the televised hearings on the bugging scandal. Even the phrases were the same: Did there come a time. To the best of my recollec tion. Those recollections were often strangely weak. And the con flicts piled up as the testimony ac cumulated.

title: State Acts to Spur Donations of Blood
description: TRENTONThe day is ap proaching when New Jersey residents in need of blood may no longer have to resort to that supplied by com mercial banks.

title: United Nations
description: The Nixon Administration, in con trast with its predecessors, has taken pains to make clear that it is not afraid to use the veto in the Security Council of the United Nations. Last October, Secretary of State William P. Rogers warned that the Americans would exercise the veto whenever they felt it was necessary.

title: San Francisco Without Its Cable Cars Would Be Like a Kid
description: ALL right. We agree. The 100th anniversary of the San Francisco cable car can't hold a candle to something like the nation's bicentennial on July 4, 1976  but still, it wouldn't be right for us to blithely ignore the cable car's moment of glory, would it?

title: Sarah Caldwell Meets the Don
description: SARAH CALDWELL re members her mother speaking admiringly of Massenet's Don Quich otte, which the latter had seen in Chicago. Now the founderdirector of the Opera Company of Boston is going to give it one of its rare productions in this country, and she will open her forth coming season with it. While the work has heels treated unkindly by many critics, Miss Caldwell insists that it's going to be exciting. It is, she says, in a kind of way Massenet's Falstaff, be cause it is one of his last operas and is written with great economy. I think it is a great piece.

title: . . . Or Doctor's Decree
description: To the Editor: I am writing in regard to the July 12 editorial Sterilization in Alabama.

title: Luxury on GinzaFord or Mercedes
description: TOKYOIncreasingly the Japanese are finding there's a Ford in their futurea top oftheline Ford, the Lincoln Continental Mark IV, in many cases.

title: PATH Fare Rise Is Debated
description: JERSEY CITY  The Port Authority's plan to raise fares on its PATH tube trains from 30 to 50 cents in the middle of next month means, in effect, that it would charge train riders twice as much as regular daily automobile commuters pay to use its facilities.

title: Blight Area Riles Newark
description: NEWARK  Should a 146 acre tract in the heart of a growing transportation com plex, an area worth possibly as much as $100,000 an acre, be declared blighted and therefore, eligible for special tax abatement as an incen tive to development?

title: The Constant of the Dolphins
description: CHICAGO, July 28He had scored both of the Miami Dolphins touchdowns in their 143 victory over the College AllStars, and he had run for 76 yards. But now, alone in a deserted corner of the locker room, half hidden by a cement pillar, Larry Csonka resembled a casualty in a disaster who had been treated and abandoned. He was sprawled on an empty blue canvas equipment bag. Attached to him were three bulg ing plastic bags of ice, each wrapped in an elas tic bandageone on his right calf, another on his Sports of The Times right big toe, the third on his left elbow.

title: Lee Tries to Keep Arm 2 Steps Ahead of Mouth
description: Bill Lee knows how his baseball career will end. The year that I'm an average pitcher, said the Red Sox lefthander, 'the club will tie me up, put weights around my feet and dump me into the Charles River.

title: New Trends in Russia?
description: SCORES of actors, direc tors, critics and aca demicians from over 40 countries descended upon Moscow May 27June 1 for the Fifteenth Congress of the International Theatre In stitute, and for them it was a rare Moscow spring. On hand were People's artists from the Moscow Art Theater and the Vakhtangov, old ac tors and directors from the Maly and the Mossoviet The ater; younger ones from the Taganka and Sovremennik. Even theater students from the distant Uzbek and the Ukraine turned out.

title: Business Index Falls
description: Adjusted for seasonal variations: Estimated normal: 100

title: Journal Sq. Hopes for New Life
description: JERSEY CITY  Urban planners here hope that the perennial proposals to bring new life  and money  to Journal Square will get a boost within the next few weeks. Specifically, they are awaiting the results of a study designed to determine the feasibility of construct ing a 2,000car garage and commercial center in the heart of what is now a transit hub in drab surround ings.

title: Weiskopf Takes Shot Lead
description: MONTREAL, July 28Tom Weiskopf did not miss many shots today as he took the 54 hole lead in the Canadian open golf championship by one stroke at 208. But he missed, by less than a minute, being engulfed in a thunder storm that swept the Richelieu Val ley Country Club course.

title: Making it?
description: To the Editor:

title: M'GREGOR ASSAILS EHRLICHMAN VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Clark MacGregor, the former director of President Nixon's political organization, has sharply disputed suggestions that John D. Ehrlichman pressed for full disclosure of the Watergate affair during the ??residential campaign last year.

title: Antique Vehicles On View at Fair
description: FLEMINGTON  Admirers of old cars will be in for a treat at the Flemington Fair this year, for an antique automobile rally and parade are scheduled for the first time.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, Tuly 28 (UPI)The world driving champion. Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, escaped with a badly bruised ankle today when his Lotus Ford crashed at 120 miles an hour in practice for tomor row's Dutch Formula One Grand Prix. Fittipaldi's brother, Wilson, helped in the fiveminute battle to free him from the wreckage of the car after a wheel broke and he swept into the pit stretch.

title: 2d Indian Petroglyph Is Found
description: PARSIPPANYAn arche ologist's discovery of crude figures painstakingly chipped Into stone here centuries ago has extended a little further the knowledge of Indian rock carving. It also has caused a problem for town Ship officials, who want to preserve the carving.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENIsaac. We record with sorrow the passing of our revered member, Isaac Allen, who conducted our Talmud class for many years. Heartfelt condolences to the family.

title: United Farm Workers
description: The Guimarra Vineyards In Delano are the largest in California's San Joaquin Valley, where 40 per cent of the table grapes in United States are grown. Three years ago, Guimarra, like most of California's grape grow ers, signed contracts with Csar Chavez's United Farm Workers. after the years of struggle to bring union representation to the migrant farm workers which became known as La Cause, The Cause.

title: 3 SERIES WINNERS GET SAIL AWARDS
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., July 28 Crackerjack, Pflumli and Tur key were confirmed tonight as series champions of the 42d American Yacht Club Cruise at the windup dinner at Nantucket Yacht Club.

title: Literary odds and ends, fine and failed
description: The centerpiece of Edmund Wil son's final literary chronicle, The Devils and Canon Barham, is a witty polemic, The Fruits of the M.L.A. Never one to suffer fools mildly, Wilson attacks academic ped antry and in particular the inepti tude of [the Modern Language Asso ciation's] pretensions to reprint the American classics in a format that reduced them to an appendage of the bibliographical and textual appa ratus. Wilson was not belittling scholarshiphe was, after all, a re markable autodidact whose passion ate literacy was carefully grounded in factbut hermetic learning, the absurd caperings of the mandarin mentality. He believed, as Harry Levin says, in the old notion of a republic of letters where men speak a common language in spite of dis tances and relate to one another through ideas and books.

title: U.S. AND CAMBODIA SIGN AID AGREEMENT
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 28 (UPI)With the sus pension of American bombing in Cambodia less than three weeks away, Washington and Phnom Penh have signed a new economic aid agreement total ins $24.6million.

title: Miss Jane Dickson Married in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 In the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in George town at noon today, Miss Jane Dickson, daughter of Mrs. Lu Thompson Dickson of Sewickley, Pa., and the late Mr. Dickson, became the bride of Theodore Minton Ford. He Is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ford of Cohasset, Mass.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Robert F. Mathieson in Technology: Road to Eco nomic Progress (July 15) correctly pointed out that the problem of the business cycle has not been solved.

title: Failing Coconuts Kill Baby
description: HONOLULU, July 28 (UPI) A twoyearold girl was killed and her 26yearold aunt was injured yesterday in a hail of coconuts falling from a 50foot palm tree in Waikiki. The po lice said the 57 coconuts fell at Kapiolani Beach center. Leanne Keiko Fujinaga was dead on arrival at a hospital.

title: THE BIG TEN
description: Sleuth 1,134

title: U.S. to Meet Chile in Davis Cup Play Friday
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 28 (AP)  The United States is taking no chances and will send its No. I ace, Stan Smith, and its strongest supporting cast against Chile in the Ameri can Zone Davis Cup tennis final here Friday.

title: Article 1  No Title
Television
description: IN a recent conversation, a network executive outlined some program ing plans that, at least in sketchy form, indicated television might be ad vancing several additional inches toward more seri ous, more adult, more so phisticated content in the broad area of entertainment. The executive offered sever al possible explanations for the development.

title: Music
description: IT was on Feb. 4, 1977, that President Agnew banned drama critics on all American newspapers from going to the office after a premiere and writ ing a review. This was followed, the next week, by an edict forbidding music critics to write a review until at least a week had passed. We have had enough of instant analysis, said President Ag new. The people have a right to make up their own minds without the inter vention of elitist intellectuals manipulat ing the public response. President Ag new also pointed out that there was nationwide revulsion against instant analysis. The Constitution of the United States was not written in a day, he said.

title: Child to Mrs. Schlesinger
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Schles inger on July 1 In Mount Si nai Hospital. The child, the couple's third, has been named Lauren Kim. Mr. Schlesinger, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Julien, Litz & Schlesinger, is a director of the New York State Trial Lawyer Associa tion. His wife is the former Miss Linda Weiss.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayUSAC 500mile stock car race at Pocono Raceway, Long Pond. Pa., 1 P.M.

title: Gardens
description: WORKING In a garden gives almost everyone a feeling of wellbeing and renewal. Today, in many hospitals, horticulture can offer a therapeutic tool for reha bilitating the physically handicapped, the mentally ill and the retarded.

title: Nonexistent Moslem Priests
description: To the Editor: I was surprised and dismayed to see In your July 20 editorial Upheaval In Kabul the expression Moslem priests. Although Islam has religious institutions and personnel, any begin ning student knows that it has no priesthood as such. The concept is in fact inimical to the religion's basic teachings and is therefore misleading in the context of your editorial. The American public is sufficiently misin formed about the institutions of foreign peoples without respected periodicals using terms indiscriminately. One would expect better of you.

title: DEMOCRATS URGE DISCLOSURE LAW
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 28 State Democratic leaders called here today for strict state laws to cover the financing of cam paigns for all state and local public offices.

title: Shane T. O'Neil Will Marry Miss Maureen R. Boscarelli
description: Dr. and Mrs. I. Frank Bos carelli have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Maureen Regina Boscarelli, to Shane T. O'Neil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. O'Neil of Greenwich, Conn.

title: 13Dav Gas Fire Out
description: TIOGA, Pa., July 28 (UPI) A team of experts extinguished a 13day natural gas fire today near this north central Penn sylvania town. A crew from the Red Adair Company of Houston blasted the oxygen out of the fire with a charge of nitro glycerin. Workers from the North Penn Gas Company then moved In to plug the leak.

title: Diminishing returns
description: As a postscript to Anthony Burgess's terse and telling piece on pornography (For permissiveness with misgiv ings, July 1), let it be entered in the minutes of all meet ings in and out of court on public morality that an excess of exposure to anything, in cluding the obscene, the erotic or what you will, con tains the dragon's seed of its own destruction.

title: colby Tuition $3,000
description: WATERVILLE, Me., July 28 (AP)Tuition at Colby College will be $3,000 a year as of September, 1974, up from $2,500. Higher costs were cited by Colby's president, Robert E. L. Strider, announcing the $500 increase.

title: DIRECTOR TO LEAVE HURRICANE CENTER
description: MIAMI, July 28 (AP) Dr. Robert Simpson announced this week that he was quitting as head of the National Hurri cane Center because of disputes over the operation of the fa cility

title: CANADA HONORING LESTER PEARSON
description: OTTAWA, July 28  Ever since the death of Lester B. Pearson last December, Canada has been seeking some impor tant way to honor the former Prime Minister, whose skills as an international diplomat earned him a Nobel Peace Prize.

title: The Cloud of Watergate
description: A few pieces of masking tape spotted on the doors of a Washington office building have now led to a test of momentous constitutional precepts that have gone undefined for two centuries of the American republic. It has been an arduous path these last thirteen months, and the end of the ordeal in national life is not yet in sight. Whatever the eventual judgments of the court system, the political viability of the 37th President of the United states remains squarely at issue.

title: Motorists to Hunt Deathtraps In New State Roads Survey
description: TRENTONThousands of New Jersey motorists will be looking for booby traps on their state highways and county roads during the com ing year.

title: Protests Close Expo Cuba a Day Early
description: Expo Cuba, a proCastro festiVal of revolutionary change, ended yesterday, 24 hours ahead of schedule, be cause of daylong demonstra tions, a latenight bombing, egg and brick throwing and re peated bomb threats.

title: Trenton Race Canceled
description: TRENTON, N.J., July 28  The Northern 300, a stock car race scheduled for next Sunday at Trenton Speedway, has been canceled.

title: Lindsay Is Inviting 2030 in Shanghai To Visit New York
description: Mayor Lindsay has invited 20 or 30 citizens of Shanghai, representing workers, educa tors, municipal administrators, artists and writers, to visit New York, preferably this year at a time to be arranged by mutual agreement.

title: Greece's Hydra: A Cubist Painting In the Aegean Sea
description: THE brilliant, maddening light, like a great interrogator's lamp, is everywhere evident in Greece, but nowhere more than on Hydra. A whole generation of artists and photographers have come to this island to picture it. Moviemakers, too, filming Boy on a Dolphin and Phaedra against the amazing sub tleties of color and shade.

title: A Correction
description: In an article last week on Park Slope, it was incorrectly reported that the area desig nated as historic by the city's Landmarks Preserva tion Commission ran from Fourth Street along Prospect Park West. The area starts at Fourteenth Street.

description: Adler

title: SaintGaudens Out of Storage
