title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Zippy Do Wins at Calder; Favored Hickory Gray 4th
description: MIAMI, July 28 (AP)Zippy Do closed with a rush and de feated I'm Adorable by 1 lengths in the $18,000 Cotillion Handicap at Calder Pace Course today.

title: BLACK U.S. COALITION PUSHES DROUGHT AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 28A coalition of 18 black organiza tions has announced plans to apply political pressure on the Federal Government to in crease aid to the drought stricken nations of the southern Sahara.

title: Watkins Glen, Used to Crowds, Likes the Longhairs
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 28  This is an area that draws big crowds.

title: Shop the resorts
description: Summer clothes are hard to find now that summer's here. Frustrated shoppers will do well to check the boutiques at the summer resorts of their choice. These little shops are still stocked with cool clothes shirts and shorts and weekend fantasies.

title: Brokers Wary on Mortgage Squeeze
description: With mortgage money harder to come by or much more expensive, real estate brokers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were watching the financing squeeze last week with attitudes that ranged from wariness to grim discouragement.

title: Social Announcements
description: Weddings

title: A monument to American misbehavior
description: On the good side, this big fat book about American criminals will keep people home and out of trouble; as an easy choice they will prefer it to booze, gambling and sex; and it will not lead them into crime, be cause they will never get through reading it in time to pull anything off. It will instruct readers in Amer ican history and fill them with pa triotism. On the bad side, it will keep them from doing the dishes, shopping and homework and will keep them reading after bedtime. They will totter to work with reading hangovers. Fortunately the book is too big to sneak into the office.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Highlights of the Flight
description: Following are the key events listed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the Skylab 2 mission:

title: Three U.S. Judgeships Unfilled Here a Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Three Federal judgeships in New York have been unfilled by President Nixon for a year, mainly because the bar associa tion's screening committee has rejected as unqualified a candi date proposed by Senator Jacob K. Javits, a RepublicanLiberal, in a package deal with Senator James L. Buckley, a Conserva tiveRepublican.

title: Article 3  No Title
A Celebration for Robbins (and Visconti)
description: SPOLETO, Italy. THE sight was decidedly moving. Halfhidden in a darkened box in Spoleto's Teatro Nuo vo, Luchino Visconti, now unable to walk (after suffer ing a stroke last year), sat rigidly still, and directed Puc cini's Manon Lescaut, the major opera presentation of the Festival of Two Worlds. For a man accustomed to mov ing about the stage amidst his singers, showing them the minutest detail of action and characterization, the experi ence cannot have been any thing but painful. But with a verbal precision that aston ished even himself, Visconti called out his ideas in so lucid and psychologically penetrating a manner that everyone, from conductor Thomas Schippers to the last member of the chorus, suc ceeded in transforming this first and least popular of Puc cini's full  length operas into an out and out triumph.

title: 3 ASTRONAUTS LINK CRAFT WITH THE SKYLAB STATION AND START 59DAY MISSION
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 28Three American astronauts embarked today on man's long est planned journey in space, rocketing from earth in an Apollo spacecraft and linking up with the nation's stillorbit ing Skylab space station.

title: Dressage Horse Is Found At Last by Mrs. Stephens
description: Mrs. Lois Stephens started searching for a horse to re place Fasching more than three years ago. She finally found one a couple of months back.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: Loewenheim's estimate re flects the excellence of the book he is appraising. The re joinders of the seven historians Maddox discusses (which you printed as a kind of endless coda to the review) are as in ventive as their books. I will take just one example, D. F. Fleming's defense of his 1961 work, The Cold War and its Origins.

title: SECRET AIR RAIDS EXTENDED TO LAOS, SENATORS BELIEVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Senate Armed Services Com mittee has evidence that the falsification of the records of bombing missions in Southeast Asia extended to numerous raids on Laos and continued into last year, wellinformed sources said today.

title: James R. Schieffelin to Marry Miss Deborah Ann McDermott
description: ARMONK, N. Y., July 28 Miss Deborah Ann McDermott and James Ross Schieffelin, a descendant of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, plan to be married. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. McDermott Jr. of Armonk and Stanfordville, N. Y.

title: Dance
description: ABALLETGOER of some years' standing, Lillie Rosen, the other day in a Playbill for the New York State Theater and I forget the actual quote and with my wife away I rannnt find anythingsug gested that one of the un derestimated pleasures of balletgoing was the oppor tunity it offered to indulge in nostalgia.

title: Mets Score 5 in First, Crush Expos, 113; Milner Hits Slam
Caroline Vose Has Nuptials
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 28 Miss Caroline Alden Vose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Al den Hampton Vose Jr, was married here this afternoon to George Thomas Smith Jr., son of Mr. Smith of Harbor Oaks, Fla., and the late Mrs. Smith.

title: Senate Votes More Funds To Pay Amtrak Expenses
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The Senate approved today, 79 to 1, a $7.9billionappropri ation bill that includes $115.5 million for operating and con struction expenses of the Na tional Railroad Passenger Cor poration.

title: Divorce, like marriage, has its limitations
description: As the author of several books of nonfiction, Dan Wakefield has presumably learned the lessons of his craft. But as a novelistin this his second novelhe comes on like a new boy who arrives three hours late for the party, nervously drinks too much, puts his feet on the furniture and finally passes out. Yet, while you wish he'd polish his social graces, you invite him again because he was funny, compassionate and often amusing before he crashed.

title: Soviet Publicly Assures Its Allies That the New Accords With U.S. Do Not Jeopardize Their Interests
description: MOSCOW, July 28The So viet. Union has publicly as sured its allies and friendly neutrals that the burgeoning SovietAmerican accommoda tion and economic cooperation will not jeopardize their inter ests.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Steel Pellets
description: Substituting steel pellets for lead in shotgun shells when hunting water fowl may result in as many or more ducks being lost by crippling than are presently killed by lead poisoning, says WinchesterWestern in a long awaited report.

title: Life Expectancy Rose To 71.2 Years in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)The average life ex pectancy of Americans reached an alltime high last year, but deaths due to the biggest killerheart disease also went up.

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA, A BIT OF MIXING
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 28 (AP)South African officials have begun attending multiracial diplomatic parties, ??asing a nineyear ban on such appearances, although apart heid, or separation of the races, remains official policy here.

title: MARSHALL IN 1947 CAUTIOUS ON C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  George C. Marshall, while Sec retary of State, told President Harry S. Truman in 1947 that he had severe doubts about plant to create the Central In telligence Agency because the powers of the proposed agency seem almost unlimited and need clarification.

title: Sub and Tanker Collide
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 28 (AP)The Canadian sub marine Okanagan and a British tanker collided off the Scottish coast early today, officials re ported. A Canadian military spokesman in Halifax said there were no injuries aboard the submarine, which had been run ning submerged off the mouth of the River Clyde. There also were no reports of injuries aboard the tanker, the Grey Rover.

title: Cambodians Yield a Strongpoint South of Capital to Communists
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 28 (AP)Communist troops today swept into the town of Saang, an important strong point in Phnom Penh's south ern defenses, after a month long siege and an allnight battle, reports from the field

title: Bronx Man Killed in Fa
description: GRAND TETON PARK, Wyo., July 28 (UPI)Gordon Woulff 21 years old, of the Bronx, fell 50 feet to his death while climbing in Grand Teton Na tional Park, rangers said today. A park spokesman said Mr. Woulff fell when a support fixed in a rock above him gave way.

title: Music: Newport Offers ColeridgeTaylor Quintet
description: NEWPORT, R. 1., July 28 In view of the interest in black accomplishment during the last decade, it is surpris ing that musicians have not paid more attention to Samuel ColeridgeTaylor. The New port Music Festival, in pre senting the Clarinet Quintet by ColeridgeTaylor at its late afternoon concert yester day, focused attention on thisallbutforgotten com poser, and the result was something of an eyeopener. For if the rest of Coleridge Taylor's music is of this qual ity, its neglect is undeserved.

title: No Way to Get There From Here
description: MONTOUR FALLS. N. Y., July 28Woodstock this isn't, said one coed from Montreal who could not make her way through the crush of people and vehicles from this small crossroads town to the festival seven miles from here. You can't recapture an ethereal spirit, and they didn't even plan how to handle the mobs.

title: At 23, Fading Star Believes in His Arm
description: HALESITE, L. I.A couple of years ago, Y.A. Tittle said that Gary Wichard may have the best arm I've ever meen. Today, the former C.W. Post quarterback can still fling a football in a per fect spiral for 70 yards, but he makes his living selling used cars on his brother's lot in Manhasset.

title: Outlay for Nixon Security May Come to $10Million
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The General Services Administra tion will disclose next week the spending of considerably more than the nearly $2million al ready reported on President Nixon's properties in Florida and California. reliable sources reported.

title: `21 Over 60 Show Talent Is Ageless
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I. To some of the artists par ticipating in 21 over 60, Guild Hall's current exhibi tion featuring the works of artists who are at the peak of their career and are in their seventh decade, the title conveys just another excuse for holding a show.

title: FRANCE SETS OFF 2D ATOMIC BLAST
description: ABOARD THE FRIGATE CANTERBURY, off Mururoa Atoll, Sunday, July 29 (Reuters) France exploded another nu clear device at her testing ground at Mururoa Atoll today, sending a mushroom cloud boil ing high above the South Pa

title: News of the Camera World
description: A NEW edition of the Leica Manual, sub titled The Complete Book of 35mm Photog raphy, has just been pub lished by Morgan & Morgan, Inc., 154 Palisade Street, Dobbs Ferry. N.Y. 10522. Al though the beginning of this book is devoted primarily to the Leica and Leicaflex cam era systems, this new vol ume ($20) is actually a very. comprehensive and wellor ganized manual that comes very close to fulfilling the promise inherent in its sub title.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: New and Recommended
description: THE OTHER ONE, by Julian Green. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $6.95.) Copenhagen before and after World War II becomes a medieval hell where a man and a woman play out the battle of spirit and fleshthe 12th novel by the American who recently became the first foreign member of the French Academy.

title: The World's Turnabout on Food
description: The universal shortages of basic foodstuffs now plagu ing the more industrialized nations of the world is trig gering the most profound changes in their agricultural economies since the end of World War II.

title: Beth Greer To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Greer of Bayside, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beth Greer to Robert Youdin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Youdin of Fresh Meadows, Queens. The wedding is planned for Oct. 7 in the Fresh Meadows Jewish Center.

title: 7 Persons Killed In Turnpike Crash Near Cherry Hill
description: Seven persons were killed in a fiery crash yesterday when a tractortrailer collided with a campertype vehicle on the New Jersey Turnpike near Cherry Hill. N. J.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: Loewenheim's review states that the memoirs of Presidents Truman and Eisenhower were unavailable this spring from the publisher. He adds that Dou bleday, which could not afford to keep these important books in print, could apparently af ford the time and talent to pub lish The Essential Stalin, edit ed by H. Bruce Franklin.

title: GRAVESEND HOLDS ITALIAN FESTIVAL
description: Sausages steamed on the griddle and sandwiches dripped eggplant parmigiana. Over amplified rock music roared past the ropedoff three blocks along Highview Avenue in Gravesend, Brooklyn, where the Gravesend Americans of Italian Nationality yesterday sponsored a cultural festival.

title: Hospital Enlarges Visiting Nurse Plan
description: HACKENSACK  Five Hudson County communities have signed contracts with Hackensack Hosoital to pro vide visiting nursing care and physical therapy services to bedridden and ill residents in the five communities.

title: Violence Reerupts at Oklahoma Prison
description: McALESTER, Okla., July 28 Prison officials reported to night that rioting had broken out anew at the Oklahoma state prison here, where at least two inmates have died and more than 50 have been injured. The authorities reported that gangs of convicts were roaming the maximumsecurity facility, hurl ing gasoline firebombs.

title: A Sense of the Inevitable
description: When the week began, President Nixon had before him requests by both Senator Sam Ervin's Senate investigating committee and Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox for phone and tape recordings of conversations between the President, his aides and others concerning the Watergate scandal. When the week ended, informal requests had turned to formal demands, court action and a Constitutional dilemma headed for the United States Supreme Court. This was the sequence:

title: Pullman's Journey to the East
Charity Will Be Winner of Westchester Classic
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 28 The $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic comes to town next weekend with a new idea for raising money for charity.

title: Gains of the CeaseFire Are Air Vietnam's Loss
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28The Paris agreement may not have brought peace to Vietnam, but it is suc ceeding all too well for Air Vietnam, the overworked lit tle airline that for years provided the only safe way to get to many of the coun try's isolated towns.

title: Point of View
description: Are we to believe that in a free market, using the latest advances in building technology and land that costs less than $500 a dwelling unit, we cannot build a twobedroom apart ment that will rent for less than $800 a month?

title: Watkins Glen
description: Watkins Glen, N.Y., has joined Woodstock and Altamont in the an nals of rock culture: The number of young fans gathered at the Summer Jam festival yesterday was con servatively estimated at between 350,000 and 400,000. And a state policeman, trying to calculate all those jammed in miles of motionless traffic, said there were as many as 600,000 in the area.

title: British Cover Poster Breast
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, July 28 (UPI)A poster adver tisin g a sculpture exhibition went back on display yester day after a slight alteration. The Bournemouth bus company had removed the posters from its buses because it showed a photograph of a woman's breast. The poster now shows the breast covered with black ink.

title: Middle East Veto
description: It is unfortunate that the Middle East resolution which was offered in the Security Council last week by Egypt's friends was so blatantly biased that the United States had no honorable alternative but to veto it. While re affirming support for Resolution 242, this latest Arab gambit so distorted the language and spirit of that basic United Nations formula that it could have seriously compromised any future effort by the world organiza tion to promote peace in the area. That would not nave served Egypt's true interests any more than those of Israel.

title: Joan A. Latchis, Daniel Amory Engaged to Marry in October
description: DUBLIN, N. H., July 28 Miss Joan Ann Latchis and Daniel Amory, law clerk to Judge Gus J. Solomon of the United States District Court in Portland, Ore., plan to be married here in October.

title: Stop the Game for Tea? It's Just Not Croquet, Sir
description: LONDON, July 28 (UPI) If you think cricket is the epitome of everything Eng lish, you should see croquet.

title: Pop
description: IN THE late 1940's, an oddly assorted jazz band, Bob Wilber's, was often in residence at Boston's Savoy which did not in the least resemble the expensive, highenergy London hotel of that name Our Savoy was a long, narrow night club which served as a relaxing, taleswapping refuge for some of the black people in the neighborhood and a broad spectrum of jazz buffs (from a local landlord and a bank vicepresident to di verse hustlers, within and beneath the law). There was also a sizeable contingent of college students, particularly during those years when Wilber's combo spent much of its time there. Many of the young then had a seem ingly insatiable thirst for New Orleans and Dixieland jazz; and Wilber's combo played it, but in rather dif ferent and sometimes un settling

title: News of the Screen
description: Michelangelo Antonioni, the noted Italian director, who has not made a theatrical movie since Zabriskie Point in 1970, is back in production again.

title: State Department Fights Move to Force It to Give Secret Papers to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Nixon Administration and Congress seem to be headed for another bitter confronta tion over a measure that would force the State Department to turn over any secret docu ments requested by either the Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee or House Foreign Af fairs Committee.

title: INDIA IS SEEKING EMERGENCY FOOD
description: NEW DELHI, July 26India, facing a severe and immediate food shortage, is seeking to buy emergency food from the United States.

title: U.S. Population Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP1) The United States grew by an estimated 127,000 persons in May, bringing the nation's population to about 210,284, 000 on June 1, the Census Bu reau said this week. This was about 0.8 per cent, or 1.6 mil lion, more Americans living than a year earlier.

title: MEW or NEW, How Does the Economy Grow?
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassWhat ever else may be said about the environmental movement, it has raised dis turbing questions about the desirability, of unrelenting aconomic growrth.

title: World Church Unit Presses Its Drive Against Apartheid
description: GENEVA, July 28 (AP)The world council of Churches, pursuing its campaign against apartheid policies, has prepared a new list of international companies doing business in or with South Africa.

title: Miss Stevens Has Marriage
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., July 28 Miss Mary Margaret Ste vens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Antoni Stevens of Ro selle, was married here this morning to Bernard Christo pher Brady, son of Mrs. Ber nard C. Brady of Elizabeth and the late Mr. Brady.

title: the traveler's world
description: IN October, 1970, Congress voted to set up a National Tourism Resources Review Commission and directed it to make a twoyear study of the coun try's tourist industry and the resources required to meet its needs now and by 1980. President Nixon appointed Charles S. Thomas, former Secretary of the Navy and former president of Trans World Airlines, to chair the 15member commission of leaders from the private and government sectors of the coun try's travel industry.

title: Renee Brody Is Betrothed
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., July 28Mr. and Mrs. Martin Brody have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Renee Jan Brody, to Laurence Howard Kahn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Kahn of South Orange. The wed ding is planned for June.

title: Nixon at Camp David
description: CAMP DAVID, Md. July 28 (AP)  President Nixon re laxed today at his mountain top retreat with Mrs. Nixon and his friend Charles G. Re bozo.

title: CITY'S CHILD CARE IS TERMED LAGGING
description: New York City may not be able to comply adequately with a recent landmark court de cision mandating treatment for hundreds of troubled young sters, according to the admin istrator of the city's be leaguered childcare system.

title: VietnamBut First a Commercial
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The third occasion for a favorite theme, the perilous testing of man against man
description: Like Mailer and Pyn chon, Thomas Mc Guane makes the page, the paragraph, the sentence itself a record of continuous imaginative activity, the capturing and organizing of the bits and pieces a deteriorating culture throws off or up:

title: A HEARING IS SET IN BOMB CUTOFF
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court has sched uled arguments for 2 P.M. to morrow on whether to rein state an injunction against continued United States bomb ing in Cambodia.

title: About the Mets:
description: There may be more complex trips than the one just completed by the Mets, but none comes to mind. They played 13 games in four cities over a 17day stretch, with a threeday break last Week for the AllStar game in city No. 5. After all that, they landed from St. Louis at 3 A.M. yesterday and reached home in most cases after 4. . . . Tom Seaver did all that and also pitched an inning in the AllStar game in Kansas City, with these results: a 31 defeat in Cincinnati, 122 victory in Atlanta, 32 over Hous ton, 21 over St. Louis. And he struck out Joe Torre three times, besides. . . . John Milner was stumbling along at .206 when he caught fire in Atlanta the night the Mets scored seven runs in the ninth. Since then he has hit 484 and came home at 241. . . . Willie Mays and Cleon Jones con vinced me I was pulling away from the ball, if you want to get technical about it, said Milner, getting technical about it.

title: Article 2  No Title
New Idea for Troops Shifts Puts the Savings in Billions
description: WASHINGTON, July 28In the repetitious debate over withdrawing American troops from Europe, a relatively new argument has been introduced that the United States could save several billion dollars by reorganizing rather than re ducing its forces in Western Europe.

title: Say It With Flowers Brightens Hofstra Gallery
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.  The how is called Say It With Flowers and to accommo date the exhibition, which includes minor works by ma jor artists, the Emily Lowe Gallery at Horstra Univer city has been transformed into an area that its director says is happy, sentimental, humorous, trivial and alive with the images of humor. To accomplish this, David Littman, the director, has made the gallery a garden, complete with chirping bird sound effects.

title: Fulton Ferry Shaping Up as a Landmark
description: The ghosts at night and the trailer trucks during the day, which now dominate the somewhat seedylooking Ful ton Ferry waterfront can ex pect changes soon. On land and on sea, plans for restora tion of the area and for re sumption of the ferry line between Manhattan and Brooklyn are moving forward.

title: Dee Mzee Wins, Pays $9
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 28 (AP)Dee Mzee closed fast in the stretch today and won the featured $7,500 Block Island Handicap at Narrangasett Park by two lengths. The winner, ridden by, Daryl Brown, paid $9, $5.80 and $3.20. Running Bear was second and Circus Flea was third.

title: The Man Whose Mother Was A Pirate
description: Can it be that the son of a pirate woman clocks into the office at 9, leaves at 5, and has nary a dream in his heart? Aye, ayethat is the situation of Sam who has never seen the sea. Apparently Sam's mother has been remiss in passing on to her son his pirate heritage. In any case, one day the call of the sea comes to her and she insists Sam leave his boss and push her in a wheelbarrow to the sea. On the way she talks to him of the seaof its voices and faces, colors and songs.

title: Trends
description: WASHINGTONIn 1971, a mile stone was passed all but unnoticed. For the first time, more than half of the married women in the United States worked in paid jobs for at least hart of the year.

title: Cambodian War
description: WASHINGTONThe Indochina war was less than three weeks away from its official end, at least as far as direct United States military involvement was concerned, but events were still proceeding normally last week: The Nixon Administration continued to sustain combat losses on the battle field and political losses in the Senate.

title: World News Briefs
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 28 (AP)  Cyprus's Minister of Justice was kidnapped from his home here by two armed, masked men during the night, an official announcement said.

title: Harry Hershfield in Hospital
description: Harry Hershfield entertain ment figure noted for his wit, was admitted to Beth Israel Hospital on Friday night, hospital spokesman said yester day. Hershfield, who is 87 years old, was listed in satisfactory condition. The toastmaster and raconteur was dubbed Mr. New York by Mayor Robert F. Wagner in the nineteenfifties.

title: Redoubtable Samuelson
description: Man often competes with the past as well as with the present. This year, in many areas, new distances are be ing marked. In baseball, Hank Aaron is chasing Babe Ruth's over the fence record. In another sport. Paul A. Samuelson has published his ninth edition of Economics and so moved one ahead of the master, Alfred Marshall, whose eight editions of Principles gave the eco nomics profession its first set of handy tools.

title: WORLD ARCHERY WON BY U.S. MEN'S TEAM
The Judges'
description: WASHINGTONThe three branches of the United States Government inter act upon each other in many ways: The President appoints judges; Congress must approve certain Presidential nom inations; the courts can declare laws unconstitutional; and the President can veto bills Congress passes.

title: Connie Cottrell's Boats Always Finish in the Pink
description: Think pink.

title: Watergate Panel to Query 5 More in Public Sessions
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The present plan of the Senate Watergate committee is to hear five more witnesses and then end its public hearings on the Watergate burglary and its coverup, according to commit tee officials.

title: Knicks Schedule Five Saturday Matinees
description: The world champion New York Knicks have scheduled the earliest opening in the club's 28year history of com petition in the National Bas ketball Association. Red Holzman will lead his players against the Detroit Pistons at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday evening, Oct. 9th.

title: East Flatbush Acts For Block Groups
description: The East Flatbush Neigh borhood Action Program is encouraging block associa tions in its area to form fed erations in an effort to re tain the block association principle in the event that city aid to these groups is discontinued after this year's mayoral election.

title: Court Denies Prisoner's Bid to Visit His Dying Mother in Canada
description: TRENTONFor the second time in two months, a Superi or Court judge has denied the request of a State Prison in mate for permission to visit his dying mother in Canada.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To criticize building su perintendents as Judith C. Lack did in her article on the life of the tenant [For a Renter or a Homeowner There Are Frustrations, July 8] is to act without charity or understanding.

title: DR. T. IVAN TAYLOR, CHEMIST, 63, DEAD
description: Dr. T. Ivan Taylor, professor of chemistry at Columbia Uni versity since 1949, died Friday of pneumonia at The Colum biaPresbyterian Medical Cen ter. He was 63 years old and lived in Leonia, N.J.

title: He asked the subject to sit like an apple
description: In the study of art there appears from time to time a work of loving scholarship that takes us significantly closer to the artist and his work; one of its most admirable forms is the catalogue raisonn. This one, of Czanne's drawings by Adrien Chap puissorupulously compiled, rich in pertinent information, modestly as serting no claims to absolute author ity  treats a great painter with just the respect, not to say reverence, he so sadly missed in his lifetime. Having it to hand one feels disposed to offer a quiet prayer to the depart ments of scholarship and criticism for a general moratorium on historicism and polemics until the job is done for every artist whose works posterity has thought fit to preserve.

title: Letters: Medieval Baggage Handling
description: New York's JFK Airport has a unique approach to baggage handling. Most air ports in the world give the passenger the choice of carrying his own baggage, or hiring someone else to do it. Many airports make life easier for the passen ger doing his own carrying by supplying shopping carts, with which the passen ger can wheel his baggage from the pickup point to the bus or taxi he takes to leave the airport. JFK is alone in the world, in my experience, in coming very close to requiriing the passenger both to carry his own baggage and to hire someone else to carry it for him, with shopping carts thrown in for good meas ure. The Alice in Wonderland humor of this situation is not always appreciated to the full by the tired and chronologi cally dislocated traveler.

title: L.I. Housing Is Planned by N.A.A.C.P.
description: CORAM, L. I., July 28  Sponsorship of the building of 200 singlefamily houses for moderateincome families was announced today by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored Peo ple National Housing Corpora tion.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: Some observations and tentative conclusions arrived at by a reporter who's spent 20oddor perhaps 20 odd years on the advertising news beat:

title: ALSO DUE THIS WEEK
description: MAURIEDaniel Mann's drama, written by Douglas Mor row and starring Bernie Casey, Bo Svenson and Janet MacLachlan, Wednesday at Loew's State II and Cine.

title: Vacations, Too, Cost More, So Many People Cut Back
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The tourists Jamming Fisherman's Wharf these days are finding that for a family of four it costs close to $30 for a mod est seafood dinner, at least $3 more than last summer.

title: Samuel Pepys Could Still Find His Old Way Home
description: IF Samuel Pepys, the famed 17th century diarist, were alive today, he would undoubtedly fill his Diary with detailed comments on how the London he knew 300 years ago had changed and grown. Whether the city's rising skyline, busy traffic and sprawl ing suburbs would, to use his own Ian guage, please him mightily or much trouble him (probably the latter), is open to conjecture. But one thing is cer tain: Pepys (usually pronounced Peeps), energetic and resourceful fellow that he was, would still be able to find his way around the heart of London that he knew. Many of the streets, churches and other landmarks still existeven if hemmed in now by tall buildings.

title: SOVIET PRESSES RESEARCH BY U.S.
description: MOSCOW. July 27Soviet officials have urged key mem bers of Congress to provide funds for SovietAmerican col laboration in the development of magnetohydrodyamic (MHD) techniques to produce electric power to help alleviate future energy shortages, it was dis closed yesterday.

title: Death
description: LISTONThemes J. Beloved son of Mary Liston and the late James Liston and brother of John. He was killed in an air Plane crash off the island of Tahiti on July 23, 1973. A Memorial Mats will be held at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church, North Fullerton Ave., Montclair N.J. at 11 am on Thursday, August 2nd.

title: Key Position In Campaign Is Accepted By Rodino
description: TRENTON  Representa tive Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of the 10th Con gressional District, will head the newly formed State Democratic Campaign Com mittee for the November general election, it was an nounced yesterday by James P. Dugan, State Democratic Chairman.

title: The Nation
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla.In the last episode in the adventures of Skylab, the big space station out in orbit, the astronauts encountered one problem after another. The roof was damaged and had to be covered with a giant umbrella. A solarpower wing had to be released during a daring space walk.

title: Cards Sink Cubs, 72, and Lift Lead to 2  Games
Traffic Is Stilled in the Heart of Rome, and CoinTossers at the Trevi Fountain Find a New Quiet
description: ROME, July 28All pri vate vehicles were barred today In a large area of central Rome in the first step ??oward a gradual closing to traffic of the noisy and pol luted city center.

title: Recordings
description: EARLY warning analysts of the music scene, suspicious of musical fads (the baroque boom, the Satie and Mahler trips, the MoogArp epidem ic), are already predicting the Imminent demise of the medieval/Renaissance music revival  a period roughly covering the 450 years from Perotinus (11601200) to Mon teverdi (15671643). These analysts assume and proph esy an inevitable satiation point with regard to the pub lic's current interest in the exotic timbres of instruments like the shawm, sackbut, krummhorn, and cornett; the cheerful chirping chansons of Jannequin; and the lan guorous strains of madrigals like The Silver Swan.

title: Queens Woman Is Shot At; Father Killed 5 Months Ago
description: A Queens woman narrowly escaped injury early yesterday when she was attacked by a gunmanfive months after her father was fatally shot on a Flushing street corner.

title: Greeks Voting Today on the Abolition of the Monarchy
description: ATHENS, July 28  Greeks vote tomorrow on the abolition of the monarchy after a one sided campaign that has left many Greeks angered and raised serious concern among American officials over the Government's tactics.

title: Wajda, 39, Is Critical After Rockingham Fall
description: SALEM, N.H., July 28 (AP) Henry Wajda, a 39yearold jockey, was injured critically today when he was thrown under his mount and kicked in the chest at the start of the second race at Rocking. ham Park.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Con Edison
description: When New Yorkers turn on their light bulbs in a few months, it will probably cost them a few more cents. Consolidated Edison, once more, is asking for an electricity rate hike. It wants an additional $181 million  which would raise bills an average of 16 per cent above what they were in December of 1972. A state Public Service Commission examiner has recommended that $161 million of this request he granted, and tomor row at the World Trade Center the commission will hear oral arguments on his recommendation.

title: No Crime Found in VoteBuying Case
description: ROCKY HILL, Conn., July 28  An investigation of al leged votebuying in a refer endum in Rocky Hill last month has reportedly failed to turn up sufficient evidence for prosecution or a grandjury inquiry.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I went to Nantucket and took a bicycle ride.

title: Hail and farewell
description: John Lindsay, City Hall, Jan. 1, 1966. On his first day in office he sits at his desk, smiling va cantly, his hair short, sideburns guillotined at the tops of his ears, his face unlined, a portrait of youthful innocence.

title: Controls That Work
description: The fact is that dollarandcent con trols at all phases of production were effective during the wartime O.P.S. and O.P.A. programs. Not only is such a program of real controls the only way to check the rapid devalua tion of the dollar, it must be applied now, for we are in the midst of a classic runaway inflation, and in no time at all the dollar will go the way of the Weimar mark and the Mexican peso.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: Francis Loewenheim's praise of the Maddox book is addi tional evidence that an un healthy movement is beginning against NewLeftrevisionist historiography. Unless the trend is checked, it promises to make the 1970's a repeat per formance of the 1950's. Legiti mate criticism is always accept able. Overt and oblique partisan and personal polemics upon the integrity of such reputable his torians as Williams, Gardner, Fleming, Kolko et. al. can only harm the free flow of in formation.

title: INDIANS ARE SNUBBED IN PLEA FOR A HERO
description: TAOS, N. M., July 28A movement to strip Kit Carson, the famed frontiersman, of, some of his historical honor in order to memorialize a Taos Pueblo Indian who died In a Japanese prisoner of war camp met official disdain here this week.

title: Met Games This Week
description: TodayMontreal at Shea Sta dium, 2:05 P.M.

title: Lutz Is Out, Tourney Is Off
description: COLUMBIA, S. C. July 28 (UPI)  The recent knee in jury sustained by the tennis pro, Bob Lutz, has forced the Palmetto Tennis tournament, scheduled to begin Aug. 10, to be postponed until Sept. 21 through 23. Two other tourna meats are scheduled on the pro tour for the date originally set for the Palmetto. With so lit tle notice, it was impossible for us to get a wellknown player to replace Bob Lutz, a tourney spokesman said.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: THANK you for Victor L. Cahn's analysis of The Changing Room, for although we sat in the eighth row orchestra center, I am awed and as tonished by his ability to glean all this meaning from a play in which 90 per cent of the dialogue is in comprehensible, Indeed, with the exception of the madden ing use of the word bloody, the only phrase clearly under stood and repeated as often as the bloody bloody, was what'd he say? This last swelled from the ranks of the audience like a whisper ing campaign.

title: Miss Blair Miner Kendall Is Married
description: SHREWSBURY, N. J., July 28Miss Blair Miner Ken dall, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allen B. Kendall, was married here today to R. Bruce Enterline, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Enter line Jr. of Canfield, Ohio.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Anaconda Wire & Cable Co., a division of the Anaconda Company, will re locate from New York City to Greenwich, Conn., in November.

title: Congress Urged to Raise Spending to CutHeartToll
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 The longawaited report to Con gress on diseases of the heart, circulatory system and lungs recommends sharp increases in research funding with strong emphasis on studies of arterio sclerosis as the under??ing vil lain in the nation's foremost health problem.

title: Deaths
description: SASIENELillian, beloved wife of Alfred, de voted mother of Barbara, adored grand mother of Michael Paul and Nancy. Serv ices Park West, 79 St. and Columbus Ave, today, 1:45 P.M.

title: 600,000 Rock Fans Make Watkins Glen Biggest Festival Yet
Beyond Stonehenge
description: In 1965, Gerald S. Hawkins, an astronomer affiliated with the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, published (with John B. White) a book Stone henge Decoded, elaborating a new theory on the purpose and function of the legendary circle of megaliths that have brooded over Salisbury Plain and teased the imagination of viewers since time immemorial. Though claimed by romantics as Roman, Druid or Celt, the construction had finally been dated back be fore any of these, to 20002200 B.C. by radiocarbon estimates. That was Stone Age still in Britain, and Hawkins declared, to a startled public, that what Stone Age man had built was an astronomical observatory.

title: SHOP TALK
description: CLIFTON  One has to see A & M Surplus, also known as The Mustache, to believe it.

title: POWER CUT DELAYS DIVERS EXPEDITION
description: FAIRHAVEN, Mass, July 28 (AP)  The diving expedition seeking to salvage the riches held in the sunken liner Andrea Doria, suffered a setback today when a power failure occurred.

title: FAISAL GIVES U.S. SUBTLE WARNING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 During a diplomatic reception for the visiting ruler of Bahrain in Saudi Arabia last week, King Faisal of Saudi Arabia made a place beside him in the receiving line for another visitor, Yasir Arafat head of the palestine Liberation Organ ization.

title: INDIANS WIN ONE AT FOLK FESTIVAL
description: VIENNA, Va., July 28It was a day of reunion for the cele brated Carter Family yesterday at the 35th National Folk Fes tival at Wolf Trap Farm Park. But a group of American Indi ans stole much of their thunder.

title: About the Jets:
description: Joe Namath completed 9 of 13 passes during the after noon scrimmage, including two for touchdoWns. Rich Caster, a tight end, caught a 9yard touchdown pass and Tony Lomax, a rookie wide receiver, grabbed one for 49 yards. . . . Don Maynard, 36 years old and the top pass receiver in National Football League history, arrived in camp during the night and was in uniform for both practice sessions. He did not work out. 1 really don't see any problem to missing two weeks of training, said Maynard, who appeared fit, as usual. I have been working out in El Paso [Tex.].. . . The chief topic of discussion among the coaches at breakfast, was the play of Burgess Owens, the No. 1 draft choice, for the College AllStars. Friday night Owens played right cornerback and the coaching staff liked the way he handled himself defending against Paul Warfield of the Miami Dolphins. . . . Owens arrived camp yesterday with the two other AllStars, Robert Woods, the No. 2 draft choice, and Bruce Bannon, the No. 5 pick. Bannon, a 6foot3inch, 225pound linebacker, sacked the Miami quarterback twice. . . . All three underwent physical examinations, and will begin working out tomorrow. . . . Owens had a little memento of his contact with Warfield a sizable lump his cheekbone.

title: Criminals At Large
description: It was bound to happen, and in THE ACUPUNCTURE MUR DERS by Dwight Steward (Har per & Row, $5.95) it has. Mur der by acupuncture, and why not? We all have read of mys terious cures out of China. Needles are inserted, needles are twirled, and Western sci ence stands aghast. Not so well known are certain darker as pects of acupuncture  those forbidden points, say, where insertion means death.

title: HANDICAP IS WON BY SHECKY GREENE
description: CHICAGO, July 28 (AP)  Shecky Greene, the favorite, took the lead from Three Mar tinis and Moonsplash at the top of the stretch and scored a 4length victory in the $28,650 Midwest aHndicap at Haw thorne today.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Getoutoftown time is upon the land, the peak of the year for business in terests at beach, lake, moun tain or meadow vacation complexes.

title: ARIZONA PUTS OFF TEXTBOOK RULING
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 28 The Arizona Board of Educa tion, under heavy fire from all of the state's major educator groups, has tabled a plan that could have forced publishers to delete sections of textbooks to be used in Arizona.

title: DIETZ CAPTURES SINGLES SCULLS
Fans Waive Loyalty at Sports Clinic
description: When a sports clinic spon sored by Dr. Pepper, the soft drink, and featuring players for the Nets and Islanders arrived at Kings Plaza Shop ping Center in Brooklyn, the young fans temporarily switched allegiance from the Knicks and the Rangers to the Nets and the Islanders.

title: POLITICIAN, FED UP, SEEKS HONEST JOB
description: Declaring that he was fed up with the declining image of politics and tired of being blamed for problems over which he had no control, As semblyman Seymour Posner, a DemocratLiberal from the Bronx, has advertised his avail ability for honest employ ment in some community ac tion agency.

title: E. H. Morse to Wed Barbara R. White
description: The engagement of Miss Barbara Rose White, daugh ter of Mrs. Swagar Sherley of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Richard Sherman White of New Canaan, Conn., to Ed mon Harmon Morse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmond Nor throp Morse of Darien, Conn., has been announced here by the future bride's parents.

title: His arrest created a stir that refused to die down
description: In A Shuttle in the Crypt, the collection of poems Wole Soyinka wrote in prison, there is a remarkable one called Gulliver. On the face of it, the poem is a sharp and some times elegant retelling of that part of the plot of Gulliver's Travels in which the narra tor visits Lilliput. Yet, from the beginning (Once upon a ship(of state)wreck) to the end (the sentence calling for the blinding of Gulliver, that proven cure for all/Abnormali ties of view . /Called vi sion), the poem is about Soy inka among his fellow Nigeri ans, a wouldbe peacemaker in a nation disintegrating into civil war, tribal massacre.

title: Divorced Fathers Seeking Reforms
description: LINCOLN PARKA di vorcereform movement, whose goals are to amend the laws and to provide a forum at which disaffected spouses can help each other, has been launched by a Lincoln Park man.

title: Elegance sans effort
description: Chilled soups that can be made in a hurry are a boon in the hot old sum mertime. Cooks who care can accom pany them with crunchy corn melba, a cross between a cracker and melba toast with a corn flavor. The blender does most of the work in the two Soups outlined here  a cold straw berry soup that is a natural for Sun day brunch and a dilled, chilled cu cumber soup that could start a luncheon or a late supper with easy elegance. Consistency and flavor will vary slightly according to the yogurt used  homemade or commercial (and there's a new wholemilk yogurt on the market for cooks to try).

title: Theory on Use of Stone Tools Before Last Ice Age Is Doubted
description: A Texas geology professor has expressed serious doubts regarding claims of the late Louis S. B. Leakey and other persons that man was making stone tools in California before the last ice age.

title: Evoking Long Island's Black History
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.  The weight of a leg iron worn by a slave transported from Af rica can give a black subur ban youngster a sudden glint of what his forefathers suf fered.

title: Deaths
description: DIETRICHCatherine C. Of 582 Long Hill Road, Gillette, New Jersey, on July 26, 1973. Beloved wife of Charles H. and mother of Peter K. and Mrs. Hannah Berry. Service will be held at the Gallaway & Krane Funeral Home, 101 South Finley Ave., Basking Ridge, N.J. Monday at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions In her name to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated. The family will receive friends at the Funeral Home Sunday 3.5 and 7.9 P.M.

title: Essex to Mark Tercentenary
description: NEWARK  The Essex County Cultural and Her itage Commission has begun making plans for two major observances: the bicentennial of the American Revolution and the tercentenary of Es sex County.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 30yearold man was shot and killed during a dispute in a Brooklyn bar and grill. The dead man, Stanley Fufaro of 252 East 89th Street, Brooklyn, was found in a car at Albany Avenue and Avenue D in the Flatbush section, four blocks from Skee's Inn, where he reportedly had been in volved in a heated argument. Another Brooklyn man was fatally stabbed, and the police charged his roommate with the murder. Joseph Mack, 38 years old. died when he was stabbed in the chest during an argument in the apartment he shared with Herbert Fennel, 37, at 474 Waverly Avenue. An offduty Long Island Rail Road policeman shot and killed a man who the Suffolk County Police said was threatening patrons of a bar with a rifle. The shooting took place at the Colony Lounge, 338 Depot Road, Huntington Station, after the suspect turned as if to shoot at the policeman. The police declined to identify either man immediately.

title: Flex Coaches Are In, Thick Muscles Out This Year
description: Like other athletes, the pro football player is going through changes away from what was long regarded as his norm  the heavy muscled brute. Evidence in several of the training camps this summer is the presence of a new kind of coach the flex coach. Flex would stand for flex ibility and these coaches are attempting to stretch their muscles, to try to achieve full flowing body movements. The trend is away from the bulky muscled, tight and inflexible athlete.

title: MARCOS GETTING PROVINCIAL VOTE
description: MANILA, July 28President Ferdinand E. Marcos held about 80 per cent yes votes tonight in early returns in a referendum he called to test the public attitude toward his 10monthold martiallaw Gov ernment.

title: French Test Series
description: PARISFrance exploded the first atomic device of her 1973 test series over Mururoa atoll in the South Pa cific a week ago, and the masscircu lation FranceSoir ran the headline, French minibomb: The reactions make more noise than the explosion.

title: Racing Driver Puts a Panegyric To Men and Machines on Film
description: It's no bed of roses, Mar io Andretti says of his pro fession. Still, I love to go to work. . . . Sometimes it doesn't come cheap, but sometimes you get away with it Mario's rambling bit of philosophical expression is the curtain line for The Speed Merchants, a 103

title: Wider Agenda Discussed By Governor and Duryea
Movies
description: WHEN Hollywood was a boom town, the studios had a knack for turn ing out lively, unpretentious genro movies. During the present nostal gia craze filmmakers are trying to recap ture the spirit of those old movies, but they can't find the secret; most of the new Pictures are mechanical reproductions of vintage Hollywood schlock. An exception is The Last of Sheila, a stylish, literate, marvelously entertaining diversion in the classic tradition of the goodbad movie. It combines two hardy but unfashionable genresthe whodunit and the Hollywood expose, And Then There Were None crossed with The Bad and the Beautiful.

title: Linda Sullivan,Patrick Maddox, Students of China, Are Married
description: NASHUA, N. H., July 28 Miss Linda Frances Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lawrence Sullivan, and Patrick Gaynor Maddox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gaynor Maddox of New York, were married here this morning by the Rev. George Majka in St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church. Immediately after the ceremony Dr. Charles Chu, professor of Chinese at Connecticut College, played a Chinese love song on an ancient Chinese huch'in, a violinlike instrument. The bride and bridegroom are both China scholars.

title: Park to Open Atop Mountain
description: PATERSONThe Passaic County Park Commission is in the midst of its first ma jor project in 30 years, Rifle Camp County Park. The 160 acre yearround recreational facility, which will be opened in September, will be situat ed atop Garrett Mountain and will be part of the exist ing 570acre Garrett Moun tain Reservation.

title: Correction
description: In the review of J.M.G. Le Clzio's novel War (Book Review, July 15, 1973), the name of the translator from the French  Mr. Simon Watson Taylor  was inadvertently omitted.

title: Miss Audrey Andrepont Is Married
description: Miss Audrey Mary Andre pont. daughter of Mrs. Paul E. Andrepont of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Ma jor. Andrepont, U.S.A. and Edward W. Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Weiss of Dayville, Conn., were mar ried yesterday afternoon in Riverdale in St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. William Fogarty.

title: Senate Confirms Garrett As a Member of the S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The Senate confirmed today Ray Garrett Jr. as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He will be the commission's new chairman.

title: N.B.A.'s Stokes Award Is Won by Knicks Reed
description: Willis Reed, captain of the New York Knicks and the most valuable player in the 1973 championship playoff series, has been named the winner of the Maurice Stokes memorial award.

title: Nixon's Former Law Office Rejected as a Landmark
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 28 (AP)President Nixon's former law office in Southern California has been rejected as a state historical landmark.

title: The World
description: OTTAWATo counteract increas ing American domination of Canadian industry, Ottawa has been trying since the early 1960's to encourage Canadi ans to invest more in developing their country's resources. To channel and foster such investment, the Canada Development Corporation was formed two years ago. At first the infant seemed slow in getting onto its feet, but last week it took a giant stride.

title: THE LITTLE CHURCH NOW A LANDMARK
description: New York's Little Church Around the Corner (consider ably less wellknown as the Episcopal Church of the Trans figuration) got its 125th birth day present the other day, three months ahead of time.

title: Coal Mine Fatality Rate Lowest in Five Decades
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., July 28 (AP)The nationwide rate of fatalities in coal mining mishaps last year dropped to its lowest point since the late nineteentwenties, according to the West Virginia Coal Asso ciation.

title: Candidates Await Debates in the Fall
description: TRENTON  Although a major dispute remains un resolved, Democratic and Re publican campaign officials are confident that the de bates that have traditionally marked New Jersey's guber natorial elections will take place again this fall.

title: Bridge
description: Computer paranoia

title: The Writing on the Wall
description: LONDONWE ARE THE WRITING ON YOUR WALL. This sprayed callig raphy pinned me to swirling centrif ugal Hyde Park Corner traffic in London last year. I stopped my taxi to photograph it, but is is now gone.

title: We cannot see our time and we know little about our lives
description: A few years ago in a car we shared town airport, a museum director told me how all fakes are ultimately de tected. The faker is an artist in his own time, and try as he will cannot keep the mannerisms of his own time out of the work, because neither he nor anyone else knows what they are But one day, inevitably, his time becomes the past and those manner isms grow insistent. An Etruscan horse faked in France in 1890 seems unmistakable 1890 French sculpture. The Etruscan component, once so very persuasive, is reduced to a gamut of amusing gestures, like the pastiches in Ulysses.

title: Reid Tells Hearing New Pennsy Cars Are Fire Hazards
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 28  Representative Ogden R. Reid today called the new Penn Cen tral commuter cars frighten ing fire hazards that could trap commuters inside.

title: 22 URGE SUSPENSION OF ERVIN PANEL AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)  Twentytwo Republican Sen ators asked the Senate Water gate committee to suspend its chief investigator, Carmine S. Bellino, and to look into charges that he illegally bugged Richard M. Nixon's 1960 campaign for the Presidency.

title: LONDON COMPANY VICTOR ON GRASS
description: Laffit Pincay thrilled the get awayday crowd at Aqueduct yesterday by steering the Chance Hill Farm's London Company to victory in the $59,350 Lexington Handicap at 13/16 miles on the turf. The success was the third of the afternoon for the Panamanian rider, whose accompishments were roundly cheered.

title: Adrienne Ames Wilds Engaged
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 28Mr. and Mrs. Charles Manly Wilds of Belle Haven have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Adrienne Ames Wilds, to Fergus Kirkpatrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Kirk patrick, also of Belle Haven. The wedding is planned for Sept. 8 at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Auto Show Scheduled
description: The second annual Greater New York Automobile Show will be held Oct. 20 to 28, at the New York Coliseum, it was announced by Edward Soukup, president of the Greater New York, Long Island and Westchester Auto mobile Dealers Association, which will sponsor the show.

title: Saint Defense Scores
description: HATTIESBURGH, Miss., July 28 (UPI)  The New Orleans Saints defense defeated their offense, 149, in a scrimmage today by stopping 10 drives and recovering two fumbles.

title: Headliners
description: As Treasury Secretary during President Nixon's first term, Democrat John B. Connally had free entree to the White House and was seen by many as one of the most influential men in Washington. Later the former Texas Governor returned to his lucrative law practice in Houston, but was said to harbor Presidential ambitions. This theory was strengthened when, on May 2, he switched to the Republican party and soon returned to Washington as an adviser to the President. By late June, it was clear that Mr. Connally did not have the clout he anticipated. John talked tough to the President about Watergate, a friend said. The President doesn't like that. So the President doesn't seek him out any more. John doesn't like that. Last week, with little advising to do, Mr. Connally quit.

title: Captain Eddie As a Dreamer
description: MIAMI  Ten thousand years after some neolithic unknown put the wheel to work for mankind, Edward Vernon Rickenbacker did the same thing with the wing.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: May I use this space to pro test the conclusions drawn by Robert J. Maddox in The New Left and the Origins of the Cold War, which Francis Loewen helm reviewed in a recent is sue? By any criterion of histor iographical or ethical judgment, this is a malicious book.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market rallied decisively last week in rising volume as investors shrugged off the continued increases in interest rates and the distracting influence of the Watergate hearings in Washington.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Betsy Volonte Married Here
description: Mrs. Betsy Bingham Vol onte of Burlingame, Calif., was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert George Davis, who is with the mar keting division of Trane & Co. in LaCrosse, Wis., an engineering firm for heating and airconditioning of large structures. The Rev. Alan Egly of the Community Church performed the cere mony at the home of Mrs. Evelyn Feakes Bingham, mother of the bride.

title: What's Doing in PARIS
description: ART MUSEUMSThe major event of this season is the exposition of treasures from China which con tinues through Sept. 2 at the Petit Palais, avenue Alexandre III. None of the pieces had been out side of China before, and many of them were excavated only in recent years. The Chinese are making a political point in export ing the display, of course; it is their effort to show that even dur ing the Cultural Revolution mod ern China attended to its history and its art. As a result, most of the pieces have more archeological and historic than esthetic inter est. Some, however, particularly the firstcentury bronze horse, are breathtaking. (Note that the Petit Palais is closed on (Tues days.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Elm City K.C. allbreed and obedience, Bethway Kennels and Stable show grounds, Carrington Road, Bethany, Conn., 1,147 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Education
description: The view from the office of Luis Fuentes, the 44yearold school superintendent in District 1 on the Lower East Side of New York, takes in no more than a couple rows of drab, crowded tenements. But to Mr. Fuentes, it is a view worth fighting for.

title: Notes: Canada Rolls Welcome Mat Into Jail
description: THE Canadian Government is mail ing personal letters to 14 million residents of the United States, in viting them to spend their vaca tions in Canada this year. And if the response to this campaign runs true to form, redfaced tourist officials will soon be getting unexpected replies to letters that have wound up in such unlikely places as state penitentiaries and psychiatric clinics.

title: An aerobody born of a computer
description: John McPhee is the author of eight previous nonfiction books, one of which is Levels of the Game, an account of a cham pionship tennis match between Arthur Ashe and Clark Graeb ner. It is the best sports book I've ever read. Tennis is a hard sport to project because its substance consists of a cum ulation of details, many of them subtle. McPhee brings indi vidual strokes to vivid life. His prose is as graceful and as dramatic as the action he de scribes  but the accomplish ment is this: a future reader will not have to know who Ashe or Graebner were. He will not even have to know what tennis is all about. He will still be clawed by suspense  as he will be in The Deltoid Pump kin Seed.

title: U. S.,in Shift, Views Peron As Argentina's Best Hope
description: WASHINGTON, July 28In a reversal of attitudes, the United States Government has come to view Juan Domingo Pern not as a menace but as Argentine's best hope for polit ical stability and economic progress.

title: Congress
description: WASHINGTON  If Congress ever succeeds in recapturing governmental power comparable to that of the White House, historians may well look back to the fourth week in July of 1973 as the turning point in the course of legis lative resurgence.

title: Governor Names New Aide
description: ALBANY, July 28 (UPI) Peter J. Wallison of New York City has been named as a spe cial assistant to Governor Rockefeller, the Governor's of fice announced tonight. Mr. Wallison will be responsible for matters connected with the

title: I Need My Fix of Mary Tyler Moore
description: PROBABLY, because you are all se rious people, you missed the item in Sports Illustrated two months ago: A man in a mobile home in California got so furious at the re sult of a baseball game that he fired 17 shots from a .30 calibre rifle into his television set. Later, after kicking out the back window of a police car because it was too hot, he asked his custodians: Didn't you ever want to shoot your TV?

title: Two Forms of Guilt
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN CRITICIZE BLACK CAUCUS MEN
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Men of the Congressional Black Cau cus have been invited to satis fy their curiosity and hear tapes of a program in which women members of the caucus chided the men for not treating them as equals.

title: Mussels for the Scooping
description: Perhaps in some future dec ade, when science has de spaired of trying to persuade the population to eat soy beans and seaweed, one great neglected food source will be tamed.

title: Shoemaker Wins Five, Is 2d Twice at Del Mar
description: DEL MAR, Calif., July 28 (UPI)  The careerriding champion, Bill Shoemaker, rode five winners at Del Mar today, including a 1length victory on Expression in the $21,925 Oceanside Handicap.

title: They ate mice, dogs, rawhideand each other
description: The story of the Donner Party seems embedded like a stinger in the nation's imagina tion, perhaps because it dem onstrated early how easily the American Dream could turn into a nightmare. It is a har rowing tale of disaster, super human bravery, and suffering: in 1846 a group of pioneers started for California, but be cause of misinformation, mis takes and bad luck, they were trapped for the winter by snow in the Sierra Nevada. When their supplies ran out, they ate mice, dogs and rawhide. Many died, and the survivors turned in desperation to cannibalism. Evidence suggests that some murdered others and butchered them for meat.

title: THE LITTLE CHURCH NOW A LAND MARK

description: HADDONFIELD, N. J., July 28Jack N. Breckman, en gineerinventor who held more than 500 patents, died of can cer today at his home here. His age was 51.

title: Arab Friendships
description: CAIRO  They came streaming across the desert, some 20,000 Libyans in 5,000 trucks and other vehicles, with a manifesto written in the blood of Libyan women demanding instant merger with Egypt. A bulldozer smashed down a barrier at the Egyp tian border and the demonstrators pro claimed the merger an accomplished fact.

title: Jacqueline Fien Is Wed
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., July 28  Miss Jacqueline Mary Fien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Fien, and Fred Louis Schwanwede, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Schwan wede of Palisades Park, N. J., were married here at noon today at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. John Moyne, the Rev. Joseph Meehan and two cousins of the bride, the Rev. Gerard Fien and the Rev. Joseph Fien, officiated at the ceremony.

title: INDIAN MOVEMENT IS SHORT OF FUNDS
description: WHITE OAK, Okla., July 28 That Wounded Knee was the last stand for the American In dian Movement is the unspoken fear at the American Indian Movement's national conven tion here where the militant Indian group is trying to re organize itself.

description: Miss Betsy Busch, who is in her third year at the Tufts University School of Medi cine, plans to be married on Sept. 2 to Dr. John Joseph Szlyk, a graduate of that medical school and resident in psychiatry at the New England Medical Center Hos pitals in Boston.

title: Moscow Is Planning a Festive Treat for World University Games
description: The 1973 World University Ganies are getting tremen dous publicity from the Mos cow press as the Aug. 15 opening day ceremonies ap proach. Moscow sports writ ers are referring to the Games as little Olympics. They cite the 4,400 topflight competi tors representing 70 countries

title: COSMOS WIN, 10, ON GOAL BY FINK
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 28 Joe Fink looked exhausted be fore a New York CosmosMiami Toros game tonight, but that did not help the Toros in the least. The Cosmos first draft choice this year did, again, what he was supposed to do as a strikerscore.

title: EDELWEISS VICTOR IN JUMPER STAKE
description: READINGTON, N.J., July 28 That, said Carol Hofmann, who has ridden horses of all mariner, shape and tempera ment, is a tough horse to ride.

title: 195,000 Jobs Eliminated By Nixon Cuts in Bases
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP1) A total of 154,000 civilian jobs at home and 41,000 abroad have been wiped out by the closing or reducing of the size of United States military bases since President Nixon took of fice, according to the Pentagon.

Group Formed to Bar Expansion of Merritt Parkway
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 28 Plans for modernization of stretches of the winding Mer ritt Parkway have stirred Fair field County residents, who fear the scenic roadway might be expanded into an eightlane super highway.

description: Modular constructionthe process of building apartments in factories, then hauling them to a site to be stacked up and fastened togetheris about to make its debut in the city.

title: Jersey Bridal for Lisa Lawrence
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 28  Miss Lisa Porter Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Porter Lawrence of Princeton, was married here this afternoon to Ward Kevin Mooney, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Paul Mooney of Bar rington, R. I., and Westport, Mass.

title: Lionel Hampton Plays His Biggest Benefit Yet
description: Lionel Hampton's apartment is un mistakably that of a successful jazz musician: a high floor in a West Side luxury tower, sleek chrome furnish ings, piano, elaborate tape system and, in the center of the living room, the famous vibraharp. Along the walls are framed awards and several letters from President Nixon commending the band leader on his many benefit performances and goodwill missions abroad.

title: 3 AIRLINES ALLEGED TO BE OVERCHARGING
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The three United States airlines that fly across the Atlantic have been charging fares higher than those permitted by President Nixon's freeze on prices, ac cording to a complaint filed yesterday with the Civil Aero nautics Board.

description: The recent widely publi cized Federal Trade Commis sion complaint accusing the nation's eight largest United States oil companies of monopolistic practices covers 22 years.
