title: Japan Cancels Ship Test
description: TOKYO, July 28 (AP)The Government, facing protests by fishermen, decided today to postpone test runs of Japan's first nuclearpowered merchant ship, officials said. The ship, the 8,350ton Mutsu, had been scheduled to leave her home port of Mutsu tomorrow on an 18day test cruise, but the fish ermen threatened to block her with their boats. They say she could ruin fishing grounds.

title: Brownsville Opens Poetry Workshop
description: As a drum beat gently and a flute crooned softly in the background, Kai Lee, with much emotion, recited from a poem he had written:

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: SEED PERENNIALS

title: Rue and Tansy Protect Crops As Natural Insecticides
description: RUE and tansy, both hardy perennials, act as natural insecticides in a garden. Immune themselves from attack by pests, they help protect near by crops that might be sus ceptible.

title: THINK, SELL, GROW
description: ARMONK, N. Y. Recently Dr. Ralph Gomery, the boyishlooking Princeton Ph.D. who is director of research at the bucolic I.B.M. laboratories a few miles from here, sat down to lunch with two secre taries, a scientist studying laser beams and a maintenance man to talk about their jobs. At about the same time, several hundred employes of the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation filed into a Man hattan hotel ballroom for a twohour discussion of the company's global problems and prospects.

title: Article 4  No Title
Three sons in search of a father
description: All in their twenties, Paul Spike, William Burroughs Jr. and Peter Reich were early introduced by their fathers to extreme experience. Ur gently, generously, and with some residual bewilderment, they now in troduce their experiences to us.

title: Rob Roy Carruthers, Navigator In MacArthur Evacuation Flight
description: Rob Roy Carruthers, who navigated the bomber that flew Gen. Douglas MacArthur, his family and staff in March, 1942, from the Philippines to Aus tralia as the Japanese took control of the islands, died Thursday of cancer in Phelp?? Memorial Hospital, North Tar rytown, N. Y. He was 52 years old and lived in Scarborough Manor.

title: Governor Recasts His Transit Plans
description: ALBANYGovernor Rocke feller has rewrapped a large number of metropolitan area transit packages shelved two years ago when the voters rejected his $2.5billion tran sit bond proposal.

title: About the Yankees:
description: When the Yankees arrived yesterday in Milwaukee aboard a chartered plane, Manager Ralph Houk took no chances with Sam McDowell, his $150,000 purchase. He waited for the pitcher to arrive at the escalator near the terminal's exit. When McDowell got to the escalator, the manager grabbed his hand and held it while McDowell rode down the moving stairway. The mock display of concern was prompted by McDowell's sprained ankle sustained while riding down a department store's escalator in Minne apolis recently. . . . Ron Blomberg continues to be the Yankees' biggest walking advertisement for lemonade. He orders the beverage every time he dines. . . . Bill Dickey and Andy Carey are the latest exYankees to accept invita tions for OldTimers Day at the Stadium.. . . Felipe Alou is happy his brother Matty also is playing in New York this year, if only because it simplifies his mother's annual itin erary. She comes north once a year during the season, explained Felipe. When Matty was playing with St. Louis, and me with the Yankees, and my third brother Jesus with Houston, she had traveling problems.. . . Thurman Mun son continues to hit at a merry clip. In the 14 games that preceded yesterday's, he was batting 451.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  In ac cusing the State Department of misrepresenting Ottawa's position on a Canadian oil pipeline, Senator Walter F. Mondale has obscured the real obstacles to rerouting the proposed transAlaska line.

title: Miss Wendy Hoge Fiancee of Student
description: Miss Wendy Cunningham Hoge, a graduate of North eastern University, plans to be married in September to Philip Mason Marvel Jr., a student at Northeastern's Col lege of Engineering.

title: Margot Bosshard Wed
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., July 28In St. Joachim's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Margot Bos shard and Dennis Di Giovan ni, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aldo Di Giovanni of Woodmere, were married by the Rev. J. J. D'Angelo. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Bosshard of Zurich, Switzerland. The couple met last January when they were students at the Euro Center School of Languages in Florence, Italy.

title: St. John'sWort
description: Saint John'swort shows its bright yellow flowers now and will continue to do so well into September. It is a weed common to waste places, with undistinguished foliage, small green leaves dotted with small reddish spots. Its flowers are only about half an inch across, simple fivepetaled yellow flowers marked with black lines on the back. It has no special fragrance. But it does have an unusual history.

title: Home Repair Clinic
State Egg Output Dips To 11Year Jane Low
description: ALBANY, July 28 (AP) An 11year record low for June egg production has been set in New York State, ac cording to the New York Crop Reporting Service of the state Agriculture and Mar kets Department.

title: The Shah's Visit
description: WASHINGTONAt a reception in Teheran recently, a Soviet official was reported to have mischievously asked an Iranian Minister: Aren't you an noyed that the Americans sent Rich ard Helms, the C.I.A. chief, as Am bassador here? Well, at least the Americans sent their best spy. the Minister was said to have replied.

title: He took giant steps
description: Abraham Lincoln was low born, uneducated, melancholy; but he was sophisticated, pro phetic, humoroushe was not a simple man. Nobody knows this better than Elton True blood, who, for eight years be fore he wrote this book, studied in depth the writings and the speeches of our 16th President. Now, although Lincolniana al ready fills shelves of books and even whole libraries, room must be made beside the works of Lincoln scholars such as Ida M. Tarbell, Carl Sandburg, Reinhold Niebuhr, for True blood's unique and important contribution.

title: Saigon Troops and Communists Battle for Highway a 3d Day
description: SAIGON, July 28 (UPI) North Vietnamese and South Vietnamese troops today fought for the third day in a row northeast of Saigon.

title: BURNS, COURVILLE IN MET GOLF FINAL
Dance: A Blending of Humor and Guts
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 28Before winding up its season next weekend with a usual series of proscenium performances, the American Dance Festival here has de cided to give its audience and visiting critics a run for their ticket. Five young dance companies are spread ing out all over the Connec ticut College campus this weekend, and the onlooker who hopes to keep up with each performance will have to scurry from lakeside to studio to indoor pool to see the show.

title: Support of High Court Up Among Police and Public
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The popularity of the Supreme Court among law enforcement officials has risen considerably during its four years under Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, while the public at large views the Court only slightly more favorably than it did the less conservative Warren bench, two new surveys indicate.

title: FEARS EXPRESSED ON MINORITY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 28A planned reorganization of the Nixon Administration's minori ty capitalism program has caused concern that the pro gram may be effectively weak ened.

title: Harman W. Nichols Dead; United Press Columnist
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) Harman W. Nichols, former Washington feature columnist for The United Press, died to day at the age of 65.

title: Law
description: LONDON  Imagine that a British general election is on and that agents of the Committee to Reelect the Con servative Government have been caught installing bugs at Labor party headquarters. Scotland Yard investi gates, and in due course the burglars are prosecuted. The Labor party brings a civil suit for damages against the Conservative committee.

title: Baseball AllStars Fell on Attleboro 50 Years Ago
description: ATTLEBORO, Mass., July 28 (AP)Baseball's AllStar Game this week revived memories of an earlier var sion here, where the greats of the two major leagues played in the postWorld War I years.

title: WAGES NOT ISSUE IN CHAVEZ STRIKE
description: LAMONT, Calif., July 28 Oddly, money is the one thing that is not an issue in the farm workers strike that has now spread across much of the San Joaquin Valley.

title: Art
description: IF you are going to learn to love Lilly Martin Spencer, an American Victorian artist who is the subject of a whole sale resurrection at the National Col lection of Fine Arts in Washington, you are going to have to learn not to gag at pictures like a pair that show, first, a very rich little girl, all dressed up, who is having her hair curled, entitled Beauty and Barbarism, and, in the companion piece, a very poor little ??, barefoot and with her raggedy dress slipping off her shoulders, who is having her curls chopped off around the edge of a bowl placed atop her cranium, entitled Beauty Barberized. You are going to have to have a generous tolerance for pictures of children and kit tens, and you roust believe in the sweet ness of old men and the nobility of dogs. You must be immune to discomfort on one hand or hilarity on the other when con fronted with We Both Must Fade, a large painting in which a sumptuously gowned young beauty is stirred to gloomy philo sophical comparisons by the drooping blossom she holds in her hand.

title: Cuba Captive's Mother Tells of a Call to Jail
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 28 (AP)After two months of high diplomacy that failed, Mrs. Rose Clemmons says she has finally learned that her son was imprisoned in Hava na by calling the jail and ask ing if he was there.

title: Dance Programs
Miss Caffrey Married
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., July 28  The marriage of Miss Christine Constance Caffrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Caffrey, to Stephen Richard Buchner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Buchner of Matawan, took place here this morning. The Rev. Michael Kelly, a faculty member of Seton Hall University performed the Roman Catholic cere mony in the university's Im maculate Conception Chapel.

title: Bank Finds It Has Asset In Airborne Saucers
description: ELIZABETH  Should res idents of Brick Town notice a helicopter hauling a flying saucershaped object some time in the next few weeks, they should not call the local or State Police, Trenton, the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cen ter in ?ouston or Orson Welles.

title: Fishing for the Nonfanatics
description: MONTAUK, L.I.Aboard William B. Butter's 50footer, the Captain Willie, is a sign that may become the battle cry of those nonfanatical fishermen  and women  who have often wondered why it is necessary to get up before the sun to Induce a fish to take bait.

title: Defense Earns Webster's Cheers But Offense Also Gets Its Kicks
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 28Bob Grim said he felt comfortable and re laxed, which may have char acterized the controlled, yet confident mood of the New York Giants preseason, in trasquad football game today at Monmouth College.

title: Savannah's Busy Beehive
description: After his years at Middlesex School in Massachusetts, at Harvard, in the Navy and in an Atlanta bank, Mills B. Lane IV knew what he wanted to do: settle down in his native Georgia and publish hand some, useful and interesting books about his state and region. Now from a restored brick, antebellum mansion on Savannah's Pulaski Square, the 30yearold founder, sole owner, editor and only fulltime em ploye of the Beehive Press is doing just that. And doing it very well.

title: SEVENTH AVE.
description: Seventh Avenue exerts a strong attraction for the young entrepreneur who is convinced that the profit lev erage of the garment indus try will make him rich in short order.

title: 3 Killed in War Games
description: BRIGHTON, England, July 28 (AP)  Three British soldiers hiding from a hypothetical enemy in a railway tunnel near here during a wargames exer cise were killed today by an express trainn. The tunnel, at Clayton, is on the main line from London to Brighton, a south coast resort on the Eng lish Channel. The three men were from a reserve unit of 80 troops out for traininng.

title: Mrs. Lucille Heller Is Married
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 28Mrs. Lucille Heller of Mamaroneck and John W. Adams Jr. were married here this morning in St. Augus tine's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John Daley, pastor of the church.

title: ANGELS OUTBURST ROUTS ROYALS, 198
InBrooklyn, The Poor Get Special Court Help
description: A communitybased legal services office, supplement ing the work done by the Legal Aid Society, has been set up in Brooklyn to pro vide more complete legal service to the poor.

title: Transit Plan
description: ALBANYIt was, some cynics joked, perhaps a new high in the pennywiseandpoundfoolish school of political salesmanship: Spend $3.5 billion and save the 35cent fare.

title: New & Novel
description: Stand Like Men

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: A MAN is entitled to his opinion, even if his opinion is a little out of touch with reality. That's how I felt after read ing Vincent Canby's review of A Touch of Class, which to my way of thinking is one of the funniest romantic com edies in years.

title: Elizabeth Is Battling Rising Street Crime
description: ELIZABETH  The traffic unit of the Police Depart ment here has been disband ed, and its 45 men have been shifted into highcrime areas in order to fight an increase in armed robberies, muggings and store thefts.

title: News of the Stage
description: Jules Irving, whose eightyear directorship of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center comes to an end today, will start his career as a commercial producer with A Streetcar Named De sire, which he presented as the repertory company's final offer ing or the season.

title: FOOD PRICES RISE; NEW GAINS LIKELY
description: Food prices across the na tion edged up last week, with the sharpest increases in eggs and pork products. And some store managers had trouble finding wholesalers with beef to sell.

title: Crew Is Accompanied By Spiders and Mice
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 28 When the Skylab 2 asto nauts left the earth today, they were accompanied by a menag erie of tiny creaturespocket mice, minnows, vinegar gnats, flies and two female spiders.

title: Stamps
description: CANADIANS for the most part were rather casual about the visit, but the Canadian post al service is doing its bit for the Queen and tradition.

title: Copter Crashes in East River, Killing Jersey Investment Aide
description: The owner of a mutual fund investment company was killed yesterday when the fivepas senger helicopter that he was piloting to his home in Middle town, N.J., crashed into the East River shortly after taking off from the 60th Street heli port.

title: Rote Heads For the Top As a Rookie
description: For Kyle Rote Jr. of the Dallas Tornado, attention and applause came in the first game of this North American Soccer League season, against Toronto, and continued through the 16th game, played against Roches ter in Dallas last week., The former schoolboy football star got his first pro soccer goal in the season opening victory and Dallas fans got their first homegrown hero on the eve ning of May 5. Before last night's game against Mont real, Rote was the third lead ing scorer in the league with 19 points. The son of the former New York Giants football great is a strong candidate for rookieofthe year honors.

title: Monstrously apt
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess:
Philippine Jets and Troops Sweep an Island for Moslem Rebels
description: BASILAN, the Philippines, July 21The Government of fensive against insurgent Mos lems has turned this beautiful tropical island of oil palm, coconut, rubber, hemp, coffee and cocoa plantations 10 miles off the Zamboanga coast into an arena of sporadic savage conflict.

title: G.I.'S IN GERMANY GET COSTOFLIVING RAISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)  About 107,000 American serviceman in West Germany will get costofliving payments as high as $8.60 a day to help offset dollar devaluation and inflation.

title: Student Weds Lucinda Cyert
description: PITTSBURGH, July 28 Miss Lucinda Carol Cyert, daughter of Dr. Richard M. Cyert, president of Carnegie Mellon University, and Mrs. Cyert, was married here this afternoon to Eugene Quirn Steffes 3d, son of Brig. Gen. E. Q. Steffes Jr. U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Steffes of Offutt Air Force Base in Omaha.

title: Emphasis on Jewish Heritage Permeates Life of Youths at Special School
description: Eighty college students, many a whom have ex perienced the manifestations of contemporary culture leftwing political activity, the religions of the Orient are now finding their roots in the Lubavitch Movement.

title: Catherine Healey Becomes a Bride
description: Miss Catherine Healey and Richard Gerard Sheehan were married yesterday morning in the Roman Cath olic Church of the Immacu late Conception in Jamaica, Queens, by Msgr. Joseph A. Healey, uncle of the bride. The Rev. Dennis J. Burns celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Chester Theater Finds a New Horne
description: CHESTER  The Black River Playhouse, whose theater in this town has been condemned by the Board of Health, the Fire De partment and the Building Inspector, has at last found a temporary home for its summer production of Car ousel.

title: Curtain Time: 7:30? 8? 8:30? 9?
description: IT was a brief letter. Just 300 unimpassioned words in which I, on behalf of the League of New York Theaters, asked theatergoers to write us list ing the times at which they preferred Broadway curtains to rise.

title: Home Improvement
description: ELECTRIC bug killers that attract and de stroy flies, mosquitoes and other flying in sects have long been used by dairy barns, tobacco growers, horse stables, food process ing plants and other commer cial establishments where foods, crops, animals or peo ple must be protected against insects without the use of po tentially dangerous pesticides or other chemicals. These electric devices were all fairly large and expensive and, as a rule, not par ticularly attractive looking or really suitable for use around the average home grounds. However, in recent years a number of manu facturers have introduced smaller, more attractive look ing units that are specifically designed for home use and that are reasonably priced enough for most homeowners afford.

title: Nanette Weitman Will Be a Bride
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., July 28Mr. and Mrs. Norman Weitman have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Nanette Suzanne Weitman, to Joseph Baylies Mantell. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Mantell of Allentown, Pa. A wedding in December is planned.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: O'Reilly is a bloody phe nomenon.

title: Indians'
description: CLEVELAND, July 28 (UPI)  Robert J. Farrell was ap pointed today as business man ager of the Cleveland Indians. Farrell recently headed ticket operations for the AliStar game in Kansas City.

title: LIBERALS SELECT JUDICIAL SLATES
description: The state's Liberal party yes terday selected 11 candidates of it's own party, including two women, for election in Novem ber in judicial districts in New York City.

title: WALL STREET
description: Motor carrier stocks are something of a chartist's de light; they move uphill and downhill like so many speed ing trucks.

title: Job Market
description: Out on the flatlands of Suffolk County, where mostly scrub pine used to grow, the gleaming new Internal Revenue Service center stretches across several acres of sandy soil. Every workday, the 2,400 employes park their cars within five minutes of their desks and spend their work ing day in sight of trees, albeit small ones, and sky.

title: BRILLIANT
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Construction Is Resumed On Project Over
description: Construction has resumed on the controversial high rise middleincome housing project over the Long island Rail Road tracks in the For est Hills and Kew Gardens section of Queens.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television pro grams was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: Common Market to Press 2 Nations on Women's Pay
description: BRUSSELS, July 28 (UPI) The European Common Market plans to start proceedings against the Netherlands and Luxembourg because those na tions do not guarantee equal rights for woman.,

title: When Newport Came to Harlem
description: BRINGING the Newport Jazz Festival to Har lem's Apollo Theater is, at best, an ironic gesture. For, who could imagine that a music shaped out of the experience of cul tural outlaws would find its way to Rhode Island's gold coast in the first place? (Only to be forced out, a few years ago, by invasions of rich hippies demanding free admission.)

title: Prices
description: FOOD: Can We Afford it? asked a huge headline in a Rhode Island newspaper supplement last week. The answer for almost everyone was, in creasingly, Not very well, as the first shock waves of Phase 4 of the Administration's economic game plan reached the consumer.

title: Wolves Named Silver
description: Over the past decade the wolf, his language, social life and relationship to the land, has come under intensive study by animal behaviorists and ecologists. Happily this information is being passed down to the children in three recent books. Michael Fox's THE WOLF (Coward, McCann &Geoghegan, $4.95), is unique in that the author is one of the scientists involved in the behavioral studies of wolves, dogs and other canids; it is a splendid event when a scientist writes for children.

title: The Woman Who Hated Cat Dancing
description: SHE is one of those Babe Paley type of women, stunning, silverhaired, 50ish, the kind of woman who really does get better instead of older, the kind men flock around at parties even when the room is filled with longhaired young things with legs that never quit. Handsome, you would probably call her, and charming, and cerebral and, most re cently, an angry feminist.

title: What we were, what we are, what we'll be
description: Daniel J. Boorstin has always done very interesting things with the ma terials of the American past. Trained as a lawyer, with the sympathies of a historian and the instincts of a sociologist, he has looked at the fa miliar from unexpected angles. More often he has prospected on territory that others in search of more ob vious ores have left unclaimed. Less attracted by past politics than many of his brethren, he has increasingly concentrated his attention on what he calls the American experience. By this he means the way people in this country have lived out their daily lives as, over the years, dra matic changes have occurred in our means of production, communication systems, population distribution and cultural sanctions.

title: Area Fans Get 3Show Circuit
description: For 24 years the Perkio men Valley Club has been holding its show the last Sunday in August. This year it shifted its date, and the silveranniversary fixture will take place on Friday. The site will be the same, the grounds of the Chukker Valley Polo Club, on Routes 73 and 663, in Gilbertsville, Pa. With the shift, metropolitan fan ciers now have a threeshow cir cuit. Penn Ridge stages its 16th event Saturday at the Nvic Association Field in Hilltown, Bucks County, Pa., and next Sunday, Hunterdon Hills is at the Fairgrounds, on Route 31, in Flemington, N. J.

title: A's Recall Pitcher
description: OAKLAND, July 28 (UPI) The Oakland A's announced tonight they had recalled Glenn Abbott, a righthanded pitcher, From their Tucson farm club in the Pacific Coast League. To make room for Abbott, who will pitch one of tomorrow's two games against the Texas Rang ers, the A's shipped Allan Lewis. the pinchrunning spe cialist, to Birmingham of the

title: John Henry Rosenwald, 59, Brokerage Partner Here
description: John Henry Rosenwald, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of L. F. Roths child & Co., died yesterday of a heart attack In White Plains Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Rye, N. Y.

title: How to Get There
description: From Tappan Zee Bridgeuse Interstate 287 (Cross Westchester Expressway), to Exit 10 at Purchase Street (Route 120), Rye. Follow Purchase Street to Club.

title: Misses Blalock, Palmer Win FourBall Golf Again
description: NEW SEABURY, Mass., July 28 (UPI)Sandra Palmer sank a 7foot putt on the first sud dendeath playoff hole today to give Jane Blalock and herself their second straight Lady Angelo's Ladies Professional Golf Association fourball cham pionship.

title: Crenshaw Gains Semifinals In Western Amateur Golf
description: BENTON HARBOR, Mich., July 28 (AP)Ben Crenshaw, the medalist, shot a three underpar 69 to win his first match and sank an 18foot putt to take the second and gain the semifinals today in the 71st Western amateur golf cham pionship.

title: BatteryPowered Bus Service Is Cut
description: LANSING, Mich., July 28 Major reductions in service were ordered this week for the nation's first battery powered bus system, which has been plagued by lack of patrons and mechanical problems.

title: The Godley Rejection: An Indispensable Step
description: To the Editor: Your July 21 editorial and Mr. Kohl's July 22 letter criticizing the rejection of the nomination of G. McMurtrie Godley for Assistant Secretary of State for the Far East require a forth right reply.

title: Benjamin Rothman, 76, Dead; Yiddish Stage, Film Producer
description: Benjamin Rothman, a Yid dish theatrical press agent and a stage and film producer, theater operator and publisher, died Friday at the New York Infirmary. He was 76 years old and lived at 311 West 24th Street.

title: A Baedeker for the Hamptons Beaches
description: WHY are the Hamptonsthat series of South Shore communi ties on Long Island that stretch 30odd miles along Route 27 on the way to Montauk Point preferred as beach resorts by discrim inating New Yorkers? Some say it's be cause the Hamptons have always had a reputation for being chic.

title: PLAN AGAINST VETO APPROVED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) A resolution giving Congres sional leaders the power to re call Congress during the August recess, which begins Friday, was approved by a voice vote in the Senate today and sent on to the House.

title: HotAir Ballooning at New Height of Popularity
description: INDIANOLA, Iowa, July 28 Anyone weary of the de lays, dangers and discom forts of travel by ordinary means might be interested to know that there is another possibilitythe hotair bal loon.

title: Inigo Jones, Old England's Universal Man
description: TO be able to hold an exhibition commemo rating the quadricen tenary of a great man's birth in a building that he himself designed, and that modern authorities regard as his masterpiece, is indeed a stroke of good fortune. Such an exhibition The King's Arcadia: Inigo Jones and the Stuart Courtwas opened not long ago at the Banquet ing House, half way down London's Whitehall, just op posite the famous Horse Guards (the work of another celebrated architect, William Kent) and the Scottish Office, with its no less elegant fa cade, from which, when it was still a private residence, that exasperating young wom an, Lady Caroline Lamb, once eloped to join her recalcitrant lover, Lord Byron.

title: We have this terrible power
description: Outwardly, Lewisburg Penitentiary presents a pastoral facade: a 1,000  acre campus on a rise overlooking miles of neatly contoured Penn sylvania farmland, the Alleghenies a lush green in the distance. On the grounds, just down the road from the walls, sits a cluster of tidy, white clapboard houses, homes for the guards and prison staff, some of them on the banks of a rushing stream. Bikes are on the front lawns, tires for swinging hang from backyard trees: a nice Norman Rockwell print.

title: James MasonIs He Better Than Ever?
description: IN THE better films of the better directorsHitch cock, Rohmer, Truffaut, Mankiewicz, Kubrick, to name just a few who come to mind for no particular rea sonit's difficult to tell where the work of the direc tor (or the screenwriter) leaves off and that of the actor begins. A good film is all of a piece. It's an entity. It has no seams. It's possible for the critic to describe such a film, to try to communicate its effect as accurately as possible, and to give some idea of what it means, but the critic can get into trouble when he tries to distribute blue ribbons. He may even feel a little silly, as I some times do. It's like pinning the tail on the donkey.

title: Red Cross Has 5Year Plan To Help the Amazon Indians
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 28 (UPI)The International Red Cross plans to spend $5million to help Amazon Indians in the next five years.

title: Bellevue Goes Without Water 15 Hours During Main Break
description: Most of the wards In Belle vue Hospital were without run ning water for 15 hours yester day because of a main break.

title: ASHE, OKKER GAIN WASHINGTON FINAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  Thirdseeded Arthur Ashe easily defeated Tom Gorman today in the semifinal round of the $75,000 fifth Washington StarNews international tennis championships.

title: Schools Are Urged to Find and Develop the Artistically Gifted
description: TRENTONAmong the no tions rarely embraced warmly in New Jersey have been those calling for public edu cation to go beyond benefit ing the masses and seek out gifted students.

title: CURB ON NEWSPRINT HURTS INDIAN PRESS
description: NEW DELHI, July 28Be cause of a serious newsprint shortage, many Indian news papers may have to close down or reduce the number of their pages.

title: Miss Rennie, TV Producer, Will Be Bride
description: MILWAUKEE, July 28 Miss Milbrey Tower Rennie, an associate producer with the Public Broadcasting Tele vision System in Washington, and David Hendrickson Tay lor Jr., plant manager with WilkinsRogers. Inc., a mill ing firm in Washington, have made plans to be married here on Sept. 15.

title: 49ERS WIN, 207, IN FAME CONTEST
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 28 (AP)Joe Reed, who appeared in only one National Football League game last season, led San Francisco to two second quarter touchdowns today and a 207 triumph over the New England Patriots in the Hall of Fame game.

title: Correction
description: Woody Klein's heartwarming letter re my book mentions its subtitle only. The full listing should have been No Island Is an Island: The Ordeal of Mar tha's Vineyard.

title: Price Rise Seen as Commodity Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, July 28A week abo Mrs. T. DuBarbieri of Montreal was rummaging through a storage room in her house and came across a copy of The New York Times dated Jan. 28, 1972. She gave it to her husband, a retired United States Army colonel.

title: Jazz Show Lacks Only on Audience
description: NEWARK  Don Carter is a drummer with a dream. He is trying to establish in Newark something that he thinks of as like the New port Jazz Festival.

title: Congressmen Urged in Russia to Fund Research
description: MOSCOW, July 27Soviet officials have urged key mem bers of Congress to provide funds for SovietAmerican col laboration in the development of magnetohydrodyamic (MAD) techniques to produce electric power to help alleviate future energy shortages, it was dis closed yesterday.

title: Mr. Nixon and the Dropout Strategy
description: TORONTOMr. Nixon's situation today is not remarkably different from that of any eminent executive. The speedup of services and information for decisionmaking releases civil war in any large organization. New serv ices and new environments of in formation blur old patterns of power and identity and inspire new struggles for patterns of power and identity. Today, information technology pro motes wars within large corporate structures which are exhibited as dramas in the press and on TV and in our living rooms. I have written elsewhere: Today, the Commander in Chief, President Nixon, is looking rather fragile and inadequate simply because his advisers are so brittle and specialist. Long accustomed to liv ing in the relative security of their niche in a hierarchical organization, they suddenly find themselves in the very unhappy hunting grounds of newly wired planet.

title: Miss Mortimer Is Bride of John Tracy
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 28  Miss Marilyn Metcalfe Mor timer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Watson Morti mer of Riverside and Cole brook, was married here this afternoon to John Michael Tracy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Tracy of Streamwood,Ill

title: Standard Poode Best In Show Among 1,014 Dogs at Barrington
description: BARRINGTON, R. I., July 28 Ch. MikeMar Superstar, a 3yearold white standard poo dle, captured the top award yesterday at the 65th annual Providence County Kennel Club show. The poodle is owned by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords Jr. Michael Wolf and Pamela Hall of oNrth Babylon, L. I. She was selected in the final judging by George E. Brodie of North Easton, Mass.

title: 110YearOld Upstate Track Is Touched Up for Comfort
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 28  For the 106th time in a 110year span that has encompassed six American wars. many hairstyles and the impeach ment of one President, racing returns Monday to Saratoga, the dowager queen of American tracks. Thoroughbred rac ing, that is; standardbreds have been pounding nightly around the halfmile oval of Saratoga Raceway for the last 2 months. This keeps first things first, for Saratoga had seen famous harness horses like Lady Suffolk and Flora Tem ple long before Honest John Morrissey brought the runners to town.

title: 3 Apprentice Jockeys Give Tracks an Oriental Flavor
description: Three Oriental apprentice jockeys who have suddenly appeared at New York race tracks this season may herald a new trend in an area in which Spanish speaking riders have been so prominent.

title: Defiant, Loyal, Blameless
description: WASHINGTONFor months, John D. Ehrlichman had been under attack, accused by the press and many of his former colleagues in the Nixon Ad ministration, where he once sat at the throne of power, of a wide variety of roles in the Watergate scandal. Last week, it came his turn to talk, and, unlike the contrite witnesses who pre ceded him before the Senate Water gate Committee, John Ehrlichman fought back. Scowling, snapping, point ing his forefinger at his interrogators, giving karate chops to the witness table, he admitted neither illegalities nor errors of judgment. He was, he testified, innocent of any complicity in the Watergate burglary or the sub sequent coverup.

title: Car That Gangsters Died In Is Auctioned for $175,000
description: PRINCETON, Mass., July 28 (AP)The 1934 Ford in which the gangsters Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow died was sold for a record $175,000 to day.

title: Anne Blanchard, A. F. Freihofer, Plan Wedding
description: CONVENT STATION, N.J., July 28  Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Blanchard have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Forbes Blanchard, to Albert Frederick Freihofer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Freihofer of Troy, N.Y.

title: What's at the Movies?
description: SIDDHARTHA, directed and written by Conrad Rooks, got six favorable reviews (Archer Winston, Post; Rex Reed, News; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Jef frey Lyons, WPIXTV; Chris Chase, New York; William Wolf, Cue), two mixed (Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Frances Taylor, Newhouse News papers) and seven negative (Vincent Canby, Times; Jer ry ??ter. News; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; Penelope Gilliatt, New Yorker; Jay Cocks, Time; John Simon, New Leader).

title: Grand Jury to Rule on Question Of Deputies'
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 27A Westchester County grand jury will soon be asked to determine if the killing last week of a suspected drug seller by Sher iff's agents was justifiable homicide.

title: For Those Who Missed . . .
description: MADISON, Wis., July 28 (UPI)More than 400 persons who did not make the White House enemies list given to the Senate Watergate commit tee have received enemy cer tificates. Donald Von Rase, a Madison nubile relations man. began offering the certificates for $1 each less than a month ago. The certificates state that the person is an enemy of Richard Milhous Nixon and that the above personage, due to bureaucratic bungling, was inadvertently omitted from the famous Enemies List.

title: Senate, in Shift, Agrees to Limit Individual's Total Campaign Gifts to $25,000
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Senate changed its mind today and agreed to a demand by election reformers that in dividual contributors to Pres idential and Congressional campaigns be limited to total gifts of $25,000 to all candi dates and causes in each elec tion year.

title: Photography
description: WHEN two books on the same subject appear at virtually the same time, the urge to explore them side by side is difficult to resist. Such is the case with Crys tal K. D. Hule's Dark Hol low, published by the pho tographer (available from Light Impressions, P.O. Box 3012, Rochester, N. Y. 14614; $2.50 paperback), and Eugene Richards's Few Com forts or Surprises: The Ar kansas Delta (MIT Press, $9.95 hardbound).

title: Visions and revisionsthree new volumes by America's first poet
description: History: dustjacket in rustic brown, midnight blue, muddied cream, ready for the deprivations of history. Over 360 poems, 80 new, the rest revised. Brief dramatic pos sessions of Roman tyrants, Dante, Goethe, Stalin, Capone cannibal isms of difficult temperaments, of

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercialagricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available.

title: After Two Years, Promoter of Forest Hills Festival Dreams of a Revival
description: A music festival that for 13 years drew top recording starsand traffic, noise and complaintsto the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium has been inactive for the past two summers, but its spark still glows.

title: Numismaties
description: THEY may not be the largest in the number of lots offered; they may not be the biggest in the total amount of mon ey spent by winning bidders; but the auction sales con ducted at the annual con ventions of the American Numismatic Association are unquestionably Number One in prestige among all the many sales held in this coun try each year. The firms se lected to conduct the sales invariably are big names in their own right, adding their worldwide and national prestige to that of the A.N.A.

title: The cost of dissent in Russia
description: The last day of Andrei Amalrik's three  year prison sentence for spreading falsehoods deroga tory to the Soviet state has arrived. The 35year old scholar, writer and critic of the Soviet regime has paid dearly for insistence on what he has described as the freedom which allows the author ities to do much to a man, but which renders them Powerless to deprive him of his moral values.

title: Highway Lobby Triumph
description: After more than two months of negotiations, House Senate conferees have agreed upon a threeyear exten sion of the Highway Trust Fund. Nominally a compro mise, the bill constitutes a major victory for the highway lobby.

title: 125 ATTEND A RALLY TO AID 117 HAITIANS
description: About 125 people attended a rally yesterday to raise money for the defense of 117 illegal Haitian immigrants who are seeking political asylum in the United States. The rally was held in the Riverside Church assembly hall and the members of the audience paid $1 each.

title: Milan Offices Bombed
description: MILAN, Italy, July 28 (AP) Two bombs, apparently planted by rightwing extremists, went off early today in the offices of Mondadori, a leading publish ing concern, and of Edizioni Sapere, a publisher of leftist books and magazines. Leaflets found near the Mondadori of fice said the bombing there was the work of SAM, an acronym for Mussolini Action Squads.

title: Tourists May Have a Long Wait in GasDry Colorado
description: DENVER, July 28Forget about Colorado. No gas.

title: Study Finds Pollution Rising in South Bay
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.  Are the halcyon days of the Great South Bay over? Will the underwater reaches off Long Island's south shore ever be used as dumping grounds or as sites of offshore oil wells?

title: They Hope 75 Will Be a Vintage Year
description: CUTCHOGUE, L. ISmack in the mid dle of the North Fork, which produces the nation's third largest crop of potatoes, Alexander Hargrave is raising 20 acres of such grapes as cabernet sauvignon and pinot chardonnay, and making plans to build a winery.

title: A PRODUCER REPLIES
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Future Events
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless other wise indicated.

title: SORORITY IS WON BY IRISH SONNET
Thais Anxiously Debate a New Course: To Cut or Strengthen U.S. Military Ties
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 28Thailand, traditionally the cornerstone of American mili tary policy in Southeast Asia, has been badly shaken by the eclipse of American armed strength ih the area, notably the current crisis in neighbor ing Cambodia.

title: City Unsure of Savings in Pension Bill
Liberals, Demons And Nixon
description: Down in Columbia, S. C., the other day, Harry Dent spoke out on Water gate to the West ColumbiaCayce Chamber of Commerce. Publications such as The Washington Post, The New York Times, and Time magazine, said Mr. Dent, were out to get the President and are making a trial out of the whole affair.

title: Arms And the Soviet Man
description: ASPEN, Colo.  One fascinating aspect of the present world tendency toward gradual integration and multi nationalismdespite continuing rivalry of ideological and nationstate systems is the repeated demonstration that all societies increasingly reflect each other Obviously this has been made both possible and inevitable by im mense improvement in global commu nications.

title: MRS. MITCHELL SEES RIGHT TO TESTIFY
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) Martha Mitchell, angered by testimony of John D. Ehrlich man, the former Presidential adviser, said tonight that she was demanding to be heard by the Senate Watergate commit tee.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ONE of the marvels of the American economy is the collection of giant corporations that make up the oil industry. No one else, not even Germany or Japan, has anything remotely like it. indeed, these giants, with short signboard names like Exxon, Texaco, Gulf and Mobil. dominate the oil business not only in this country but in Western Europe, the Pacific and Latin America as well.

title: Dahlia, AmericanOwned Filly, Captures Richest English Race
description: ASCOT, England, July 28 Nelson Bunker Hunt's filly, Dahlia, rallied from last place to win the $292,500 King George and Queen Elizabeth Stakes by six lengths today in the richest race in En elish history.

title: They Can't Tackle What They Can't See, 59 Adamle Asserts
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 28The Jets training camp at Hofstra is an autograph seekers haven. In front of the dormitories that house the players, the clubhouse and practice field, young and old, male and female, wait nope or an autograph.

title: Miss Wells Married to C. H. Milton
description: ERIE, Pa., July 28In the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Paul here this afternoon Miss Catherine Anderson Wells, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. E. Buist Wells, was married to Christopher Hull Milton, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Milton Jr. of Short Hills, N. J., and South Conway, N. H. The Very Rev. Frederic Murray, dean of the Cathedral, per formed the ceremony.

title: Russell Byers Weds Miss Beacham
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 28Miss Laurada Beacham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ed win Brand Beacham Jr. of Bronxville and Key Biscayne, Fla., and William Russell Grace Byers were married in Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon. The bride groom is a son of Mrs. Au gustus G. Paino 2d of Old Westbury, L. I., and the late J. Frederic Byers of Sewick ley, Pa., and a greatgrandson of the late William R. Grace, founder of W. R. Grace & Co. and twice Mayor of New York.

title: Cause Party a Lasting Tradition in East Hampton
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. Hello, Leonard. You're look ing good.

title: Connecticut Bird List Ready
description: FAIRFILD, Conn., July 28 The Connecticut Audubon So ciety has announced that its first published check list of the birds of Connecticut since 1913 is available at its headquarters, 2325 Burr Street here, Zip Code 06430, for 10 cents plus a stamped, selfaddressed en velope. The society asked to be informed of any new sightings or nestings.

title: What to Do After the Racing Ends? Race Again
description: What does a fleet of near ly 200 fancy yachts do after the Southern Ocean Racing Conference ends and the skippers find themselves in the Bahamas with no more races? All they used to do was sail blithely homeward and talk about what hap pened. Not any more. A new ocean sail ing race start ing in Nassau has been added to the interna tional circuit, probably just for that rea son.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayThe Hill, Route 124, North Salem, N.Y. Green, ama teurowner, junior local, and chil dren's working hunters; open pre iminary and junior jumpers; po nies, equitation. 8 A.M.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: MAJOR BANKS have raised their prime rate to 8 per cent, a new high.The Bank of England raised its lending rate from 9 per cent to 11 per cent.The First National City Bank reported that aftertax profits of 926 American corporations rose 30 per cent from yearearlier levels.The Treasury will take bids through Wednesday for 20year, 7 per cent bonds in units of $1,000. The Federal Reserve Board has imposed a limit on commercial banks on the amount of new highinterest certificates of deposit they can accept.

title: Teacher Wins Case Against Principal On SexBias Charge
description: The City Commission on Hu man Rights, ruling in what it described as an out and out case of pure unadulterated male chauvinism, has ordered the principal of Seward Park High School in Manhattan to pay $1,750 in compensatory dam ages to an English teacher to whom he gave an unsatisfac tory rating after the teacher had charged him with sex dis crimination.

title: Priests Who Charged Killings Propose a Visit to Mozambique
description: MADRID, July 29A group of seven Spanish Roman Cath olic priests, who were mis sionaries in the Portuguese African territory of Mozam bique, have offered to send back two of their number to confirm their allegations of massacres committed on the local population by Portuguese soldiers.

title: MRS. WILLIAM IGOE
description: SEAFORD, L. I., July 28 Mrs. Catherine Igoe, widow of William Igoe, a member of the deliverydepartment staff of The New York Times, died Friday at Good Samaritan Hos pital, West Islip. She was 72 years old and lived here at 392 Ferris Road.

title: Haiti Exiles Delay Soccer Here
description: About 150 Haitian exiles repeatedly marched into Downing Stadium on Ran dalls Island yesterday after noon during the soccer game between the national team of Haiti and Millonarios of Co lombia and caused a delay for almost three hours.

title: 2 SENATORS SEEK TAPE COMPROMISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The leaders of the Senate Water gate committee suggested to day, in a compromise move, that President Nixon permit a private audition of tape recorded conversations dealing with the scandal.

title: 30,000 Scouts to Attend JamboreeWest in Idaho
description: FARRAGUT STATE PARK, Idaho, July 29 (AP)Bob Hope is scheduled to open it on Wednesday and Mark Spitz will close it a week later. In between, 30,000 boy scouts will work and play at the 1973 National Scout JamboreeWest here in northern Idaho.

title: Cornered Rebel Band Fights Tenaciously in South Philippines
description: COTABATO, the Philippines, July 23  Fighting with tac tics and tenacity reminiscent of some Vietcong units, a tough little band of Moslem insur gents dug in on the Cotabato seacoast in Mindanao is the chief remaining pocket of what appears to be fading resistance in the Moslem uprising against the Government in this area.

title: Trevino Has to Skip Westchester
description: MONTREAL, July 29Lee Trevino announced today that he would not compete in the $250,000 Westchester Classic that starts Thursday at Harrison, N.Y., because his wife, who expects a baby within a few weeks, wants him home in El Paso.

title: The Astronauts Aboard Skylab 2 Alan Lavern Bean
description: Navy Capt. Alan Lavern Bean, 41 years old, made his last previous flight in space aboard Apollo 12 in Novem ber, 1969. It was a dramatic, 10day trip to and from the surface of the moon's Ocean of Storms, to gather infor mation about the early his tory of another planet.

title: Saratoga Is Still a OneMonth Town
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29 The annual fuel collection in St. Peter's Church on South Broadway will be taken up on the second and third Sundays in August as usual. That's the day after the Alabama Stakes and the day after the Travers when, experience has shown, horseplayers are at their godliest and most generous, especially the winners. Like most of the 15,000 residents of this agree able city, Msgr. Daniel R. Burns learned long ago to rely on August for the bulk of the year's income, for in Augusts the Beautiful People arrive with their beautiful horses and attractive dollars.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENIsaac. We record with sorrow the Passing of our revered member, Isaac Allen, who conducted our Talmud class for many years. Heartfelt condolences to the family.

title: Lasers Cut Through Ranks of Musicians
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 29 It was last night that the Newport Music Festival went modernmodern not only in sound, with a demonstration of electronic music, but also modern in equipment. In the balcony of The Breakers was laid out tons, seemingly, of equipment, most notable of which was a C5000 high power pulsed nitrogen laser with dye capacity, borrowed from the AvcoEverett Re search Laboratories.

title: Skylab Crew Nauseated
description: The Skylab 2 astronauts are suffering from nausea caused by motion sickness. As a result, efforts to acti vate the space station have been slowed. Page 12.

title: Skylab Crew Nauseated
description: The Skylab 2 astronauts are suffering from nausea caused by motion sickness. As a result, efforts to acti vate the space station have been slowed. Page 12.

title: Kill and Overkill
description: WASHINGTONIn a scholarly paper of six years ago, the new Secretary of Defense propounded an insightful proposition for coping with uncertainty in military acquisition.

title: WindowSill Marijuana Found by Police on Roof
description: A roof safari by two police men with powerful field glasses yesterday turned up marijuana growing in five flower pots of mint on a fourthfloor window sill in Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: JOSEPH G. M'KENNA, IONA EXPRESIDENT
description: Brother Joseph G. McKenna, former president of Iona Col lege, died Saturday of a heart attack on a vacation in San Francisco. He was 51 years old.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED IN BAY AREA STRIKE
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 29 (AP)The general manager of the Bay Area Rapid Transit System has announced a tenta tive agreement to end a 27day strike by 1,100 employes.

title: Guru's Peace Talk Called Fantastic By Disciples,Unconvincing by 0thers
description: Guru Maharaj Ji, the Indian youth whose followers say he is the incarnation of God, re faxed with his disciples at his house in Old Westbury, L. I. yesterday after a wellpubli cized appearance that got mixed reception.

title: Towns in Hudson County Protest Plan to Raise PATH Fare to 50c
description: JERSEY CITY, July 29 Several Hudson County com munities are fighting the Port Authority's plan to increase fares on its PATH tube trains to 50 cents from 30 cents on the ground that it defies Fed eral policy on cleanair stand ards and on price guidelines.

title: MOUNTING TENSION GRIPS PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia July 29 Tension is climbing noticeably in Phnom Penh as more and more Cambodians be gin to believe that this time perhaps for the first time in the three years of war here, the enemy pressure around the city is the real thing.

title: TOWNS FIGHT PLAN FOR 50C PATH FARE
description: JERSEY CITY, July 29Sev eral Hudson County communi ties are fighting the Port Au thority's plan to increase fares on its PATH tube trains to 50 cents from 30 cents on the ground that it defies Federal policy on cleanair standards and on price guidelines.

title: Legislative Leaders Hope For Bond Vote in Day or So
description: ALBANY, July 29The Re publican leaders of the Legis lature and aides to Governor Rockefeller said today they expected to finish the special session in the next day or two with a strong bipartisan en dorsement of Governor Rocke feller's $3.5billion transit bond.

title: Henri Charriere, Author of Papillon
description: MADRID, July 29 (Reuters) Henri Charrire, author of the bestselling book Papillon, died today in a hospital here, a spokesman for his publishing company said. He was 66 years old.

title: Stan Kenton's Hot Tenor Sax Is a 20YearOld Woman
description: When tenor saxophonist Mary Fettig sleeps on the Stan Kenton bus, she seems to be a pixieish 4 feet 6 inches. Curled up in her seat, with a blanket wrapped around her hair and eyes, she is a little feminine bundle that goes almost unnoticed.

title: Soviet Dominates Canoeing
description: TAMPERE. Finland, July 29 (Reuters)The Soviet Union and Hungary dominated the final day of the 1973 world canoe and kayak championships on Kaualtjarvi Lake today. The 50man Russian team swept to victory in seven events to day and Hungary had three triumphs.

title: MERCURY DETECTED IN ICELAND VOLCANO
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) The volcano that drove 5,000 people from their homes on Iceland's Heimaey Island early this year also aggravated the world's mercury pollution prob lems.

title: Child Psychotherapy Is Increasing Rapidly
description: By most standards, 11year old Paula was a model child. She was a bit quiet and intro spective by comparison with the other children in her well todo suburban community in the Middle West. But she was studious, obedient and never a bit of troubleuntil the day she began looking at the floor and refused to say anything at all.

title: WEISKOPF VICTOR, PASSES $200,000
Report Says California Bar Voted Nixon Inquiry
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 (AP)President Nixon and five California lawyers allegedly linked to the Watergate affair will be investigated for possible disciplinary action by the State Bar of California, The San Francisco Examiner reported today.

title: Youth Killed by Bean Bag
description: GRANTS, N. M., July 29 (AP) An autopsy report today said a Grants youth had been killed when struck by a socalled bean bag projectile fired from a police crowd control gun de signed to inflict pain but not serious injury. Melvin Ortiz, 18 years old, was killed as police tried to disperse more than 150 youths involved in what the police termed a gang fight yes terday.

title: Nixon, Following Orders To Relax, Goes Swimming
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., July 29 (AP)  President Nixon spent today in the seclusion of his mountaintop retreat, and aides reported that he was following his doctor's orders to relax by swimming and taking walks.

title: Washington Asks Hanoi For Help on the Missing
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) The United States appealed again today to North Vietnam for swift help in determining the fate of more than 1,300 Americans still listed as miss ing in Southeast Asia.

title: Charles R. Van Anden, 83, Retired Insurance Official
description: NAPLES, Fla., July 29 Charles R. Van Anden, a retired senior vice president of the New York Life Insurance Com pany, died yesterday at the Naples Community Hospital after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and had lived here for six years.

title: News Summary and Index
description: An agreement has been reached between the Vientiane Government and the Com munistled Pathet Lao on the broad lines and almost all questions of principle for a political and military settlement of the Lao tian conflict, sources close to the Govern ment said. The report was confirmed by the political organization of the Pathet Lao, the Neo Lao Flak Xat. The agreement on the main principles for a new government has not been signed or initialed, but the two sides were reported to be working out its final wording and details. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: KLECATSKY WINS 4 ROWING RACES
Camp, Zaveral Win Canoe Regatta 3d Year in Row
description: CALLICOON, N.Y., July 29 For the third successive year the Sullivan County Up per Delaware River canoe re gatta championship went to Al Camp from Otego and Bob Zaveral from Unadilla, who made the 25mile test today from Hancock to Callicoon in 4 hours 11 minutes.

title: Richard M. Gelb And Gail Kleven Wed in Boston
description: BOSTON, July 29Miss Gail Kleven, a member of the Education Task Force of the Governor's Commission on the Status of Women in Massachusetts, was married here today to Richard Mark Gelb, who is a candidate for a Master of Law degree in taxation at New York Uni versity.

title: Isaac Hayes, in Concert, Shows Command of Self and Audience
description: Isaac Hayes, to say the least, doesn't have your ordinary run ofthemill soul music act. He may wear chest chains and red tights, and both fists might be clenched in a power salute, and he may move adeptly from organ to piano to alto saxo phone, soulfully shouting over each and all, moaning and grunting. There's also some long soulphilosophical rapping, basically concerning lost love and malefemale chauvinism, which could possibly fit into the soulsinger pattern.

title: Festival at Watkins Glen Ends in Mud and Elation
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 29What had been a mammoth muddy outdoor dance hall for more than 15 hours yesterday turned into an immense garbage dump today as 600,000 fans streamed away from the site of the largest rock festival ever held in the United States.

title: Huge Debt Perils Future Of Vietnam Truce Panel
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 The International Commission of Control and Supervision is bankrupt and has accumulated debts of over $10million, authoritative com mission sources say.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: MOUNTING TENSION GRIPS PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 29Tension is climbing noticeably in Phnom Penh as more and more Cambodians be gin to believe that this time, perhaps for the first time in the three years of war here, the enemy pressure around the city is the real thing.

title: Huge Debt Perils Future Of Vietnam Truce Panel
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29  The International Commission of Control and Supervision is bankrupt and has accumulated debts of over $10million, authoritative com mission sources say.

title: Munich. New and Magnificent Mozart
description: MUNICH, West Germany As the capital of Bavaria, Munich places a great deal of importance on preserving the past and, in the summer months, celebrating It with an opera festival. This sea son's hit is a magnificent new production of Mozart's Don Giovanni, which opened the festi val July 12. Rug gero Raimondi as Don Giovanni, the rest of the cast and the Bava rian State orchestra outdo themselves, moving the very formally dressed crowds  Miincheners seem to come as much to show off their for mal gowns and tuxedos in the elegant, palatial sur roundings of the national theater as to savor the opera to ecstasies of applause.

title: Shah Is Welcomed Home
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 29 (UPI)More than a million Iranians turned out today to line the streets to welcome home Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and Empress Farah on their return from a fourday visit to the United States, according to Government fig ures

title: Festival at Watkins Glen Ends in Mud and Elation
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 29What had been a mammoth muddy outdoor dance hall for more than 15 hours yesterday turned into an immense garbage dump today as 600,000 fans streamed away from the site of the largest rock festival ever held in the United States.

title: A Difficult Transition Ahead for Laos
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 29 The Laotian Government ap pears to have resigned itself to accepting most of the condi tions that its Communist enemy had been demanding for the last five months.

title: Brezhnev's Trip Leaves Ivan Eager to Visit U.S.
description: MOSCOW, July 29Among ordinary Soviet people, the success of Leonid I. Brezhnev's trip to the United States last Month has intensified two palp able urges  the demand for American consumer goods and the itch to have a look at America for themselves.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: LONDON, July 29Every time the British economy seems to be doing well, someone comes along and forecasts imminent disaster. Usually they are right.

title: Some Lines for Babe
description: DRESDEN, MeBabe, our loving, quickly beloved new dog (mostly Border Collie), was killed by a hitand run driver last evening in front of our eyes. It had been gray and lowering all day until about six o'clock, when the skies cleared and the sun shone bravely. I went into the front room to read by the window, but the light was so lovely over the river and the far hill that I kept looking out the win dow. My wife, Mary, was out front restaking the delphiniums. Sunday evening traffic was heavy, but the dogs seemed content to wander around the yard with Mary, barking only at passing kids on bicycles, on horses, or on foot.

title: Greek Vote Strongly Backs Government
description: ATHENS, Monday, July 30 Greeks voted yesterday to en dorse decisions already made by their leaders to abolish the monarchy and install George Papadopoulos as the President of the new republic.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Transportation Department announced it would begin Wednesday to distribute to senior citizens in formation brochures and applications for reduced bus fares.

title: Dance: Nuits du Louvre
description: PARIS, July 29  In the past, Paris has never been summer festival. In August in particular, so many of the best restaurants close, some hotels become sullen, and huge segments of the Parisian population head somewhere else, Ike lemmings. The town is left to the tourists, who do not know quite what to do with it.

title: PUERTORICO CHIEF GUEST OF NEWARK
description: NEWARK, July 29 (UPI) Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson was host to the Governor of Puerto Rico at a breakfast meeting to day, after which the 36year old Governor, Rafael Her nandez Col6n reviewed the city's Puerto Rican Day parade.

title: 2 Wolves, Conservationist Celebrities, Fatally Poisoned in Brooklyn Trailer
description: Two wolves who had traveled the country as ambassadors in the cause of preventing the ex tinction of their speciesap pearing on national television, in schools and in the halls of legislatures and Congress were killed in Brooklyn yester day by a poisoner.

title: Gerry Nadel Weds Marion Schonbrunn
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 29Miss Marion Sue Schon brunn, a nurse practitioner who runs a povertyarea adult health clinic in Boston, was married here today to Gerry Nadel, Boston bureau chief of Fairchild Publica tions.

title: Beef Companies Refusing To Supply City Aug. 617
description: The city's regular meat sup pliers have refused to sign con tracts for a twoweek supply of beef106,000 poundsnor mally used in municipal hospi tals, jails and other institutions, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

title: JERSEY REQUESTS MORE U.S. JUDGES
description: NEWARK, July 29  The Federal judiciary in New Jer sey, beset by a rising number of civil and criminal cases, is involved in a muted struggle with Washington over the need for more judges.

title: In Chinese Game, U.S. Is Still Villain
description: PEKING, July 29 (Reuters) Strike a telling blow at U. S. imperialismadvance to 26.

title: RAZKALLA E. KEYLOUN
description: Razkalla E. Keyloun, a for mer New York manufacturer of lounge wear for women, died Saturday in Miami. He was 83 years old.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, JULY 30, 1973
description: An agreement has been reached between the Vientiane Government and the Com munistled Pathet Lao on the broad lines and almost all questions of principle for a political and military settlement of the Lao tian conflict, sources close to the Govern ment said. The report was confirmed by the political organization of the Pathet Lao, the Neo Lao Hak Xat. The agreement on the main principles for a new government has not been signed or initialed, but the two sides were reported to be working out its final wording and details. [Page 1, Col. 8.] Tension is climbing noticeably in Phnom Penh as more and more Cambodians begin to believe that this time, perhaps for the first time in the three years of war in their country, enemy pressure around the city is at a critical stage. Almost every conversation with a Cambodian now is the samehe says he is afraid that when the American bomb ing support is cut off on Aug. 15, the ex hausted, badly led and demoralized Govern ment army will collapse and enemy troops march into the city. [I:6.]

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Stamford, Conn., announced last week that it would give up attempts to enforce its controversial oneyear resi dency requirement for wel fare applicants, in the face of recent Supreme Court actions. But the city has reduced its welfare costs.

title: TV: For Late Viewers
description: Judging by Geraldo Ri vera: Good Night, America, a 90minute program in the American Broadcasting Com pany's Wide World of En tertainment slot tonight at 11:30, it might be a good idea indeed to have this young man around these late evenings. Several more such specials are understood to be on the way. Let's hope so.

description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29 The annual fuel collection in St. Peter's Church on South Broadway will be taken up on the second and third Sundays in August as usual. That's the day after the Alabama Stakes and the day after the Travers when, experience has shown, horseplayers are at their godliest and most generous, especially the winners. Like most of the 15,000 residents of this agree able city, Msgr. Daniel R. Burns learned long ago to rely on August for the bulk of the year's income, for in August the Beautiful People arrive with their beautiful horses and attractive dollars.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: For All the Wrong Reasons by John Neufeld (Norton, $5.95). The story of a teenage marriage.

title: CURB ON EARNINGS BY AGED ASSAILED
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  Should Social Security pay ments become just another pen sion plan paying the elderly without regard to their working income or should the program retain its original purpose of providing a form of insurance against the loss of earnings after retirement?

title: National League
description: Monday, July 30, 1973

title: Brezhnev's Trip Leaves Ivan Eager to Visit U.S.
description: MOSCOW, July 29Among ordinary Soviet people, the success of Leonid I. Brezhnev's trip to the United States last month has intensified two palp able urges  the demand for American consumer goods and the itch to have a look at America for themselves.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WINDSOR, England, July 29 (AP)The United States continued its domination over England in Coronation Cup polo today, using a penalty goal in the last seconds for a 76 victory before a crowd of 10,000 that included Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip.

title: Books of The Times Hindsight on a Quadrennial
description: THE MAKING OF A PRESIDENT. By Theodore H. White. 391 pages. Atheneum. $10.

title: Taxless Ocean Grove Fights to Make Ends Meet
description: OCEAN GROVE, July 29 The demand for space in this famed refuge from a sinful and intrusive world is so great these days that wouldbe residents must wait for periods of up to two years for the opportu nity to rent and up to 10 years for a chance to buy even a modest small cottage here. But, at the same time, the association that governs this town of 7,000 per manent and 35,000 summer residents on the Atlantic Ocean just south of Asbury Park is having trouble making financial ends meet.

title: AirRights Deal Saves South St. Seaport
description: The South Street Seaport has been rescued from insolvency by a complex series of reales tate transactions involving the air rights over several city blocks.

title: Bridge: Waldmann and Eowen Teams Register Spingold Upsets
Greek Vote Strongly Backs Government
description: ATHENS, Monday, July 30 Greeks voted yesterday to en dorse decisions already made by their leaders to abolish the monarchy and install George Papadopoulos as the President of the new republic.

title: About the Mets:
description: When the annual Banner Day is unfurled next Sunday, only those signs and banners that can be carried by a maximum of two people will be permitted. We've had some banners that stretched to centerfield and took 40 people to carry them, said a Met official. . . . John Milner, who batted only once, was stopped after nine games in which he hit at a .486 clip (17 for 35). . . . Felix Millan has hit in 14 straight, a season mark for the team.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS GET RACE ORDER
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 29 (AP)A Federal District Court judge declared today that all white, private schools could not deny admission to blacks be cause of their race.

title: Mrs. Beard Hospitalized
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., July 29 (UPI)Mrs. Dita Beard, a con troversial figure in last year's Senate hearings on the Interna tional Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, has been hospital ized at Rochester Methodist Hospital. Details were not dis colsed.

title: Mrs. Ford Gets Music Post
description: INTERLOCHEN, Mich., July 29 (UPIMrs. Henry Ford 2d has has been appointed a member of the board of trustees of the internationally known National Music Camp and Interlochen Arts Academy. W. Clement Stone of Chicago, board chair man of the camp groups, said Mrs. Ford would be a tremen dous asset. The camp is in its 46th season, with about 2,500 students.

title: 4 to 6 Giant Companies Being Picked As Federal Target on Discrimination
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is selecting for special, concentrated attention four to six giant national cor porations and 20 to 40 some what smaller companies that are alleged to be among the nation's most discriminatory employers.

title: FALLOUT OF ATEST NOTED IN PACIFIC
description: HONOLULU, July 29 (UPI) Prime Minister Norman Kirk of New Zealand, plainly angered by France's latest nuclear ex plosion, says scientists have al ready detected a slight increase in radioactive fallout over South Pacific islands.

title: Average Family's Food Bill Is Highest in 3 Months Here
ExFootball Player Killed
description: NATCHITOCHES, La., July 29 (UPI)A former University of Mississippi football player Wil liam Earl Basham, was killed yesterday when his small plane crashed on takeoff. Basham, 34 years old, played in three bowl games for Ole Miss from 1960 through 1962. He had been an assistant professor of speech at Northwestern Louisiana Uni versity in Natchitoches.

description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

description: WASHINGTON, July 29The leaders of the Senate Water gate committee suggested to day, in a compromise move, that. President Nixon permit a private audition of tape recorded conversations dealing with the scandal.

title: One Group Chose Campsite 2 Weeks Ago
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 29Six months ago, Kip Kappesser heard an announc er on the Syracuse University radio station say that there would be a large outdoor concert near here in July, and he decided he had to be there.

title: Guru's Peace Talk Called Fantastic By Disciples,Unconvincing by Others
description: Guru Maharaj Ji, the Indian youth whose followers say he, is the incarnation of God, re laxed with his disciples at his, house in Old Westbury, L. I., yesterday after a wellpubli cized appearance that got a mixed reception.

title: IndianPakistani Talks
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 29 Talks between Indian and Pakistani officials on issues arising from the 1971 war have entered a decisive stage, con ference sources said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your July 22 Week in Review article on the warpowers bill restates as a fact almost verbatim a claim made by the bill's sponsors that:

title: JULIO RIVERA, 52, OF EL SALVADOR President From 1962 to 1967 DiesWas Envoy to U.S.
description: SAN SALVADOR, July 29 (UPI)Julio Adalberto Rivera, President of El Salvador from 1962 to 1967, died today of a heart attack at his country home in the suburb of San Jose Guayabal. He was 52 years old.

title: City Approves Plan By the Guggenheim To Alter Its Building
description: The City Board of Standards and Appeals has approved a revised plan of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum to make streetlevel alterations of its Frank Lloyd Wright building on Fifth Avenue.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: PRELATE'S ATTACK STARTLES ATHENS
description: ATHENS, July 29The Gov ernment voiced shock and dis belief today at reports that Archbishop Iakovos, Greek Or thodox Primate of North and South America, had denounced the Greek Government as a tyranny in which people could not express their free will.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: when the Mets batted in the striking out on a curveball in the first inning.

title: Allende Will Meet Foe Today in an Effort to End Crisis
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 29 Despite an increasingly troubled atmosphere, President Salvador Allende Gossens will meet to morrow with the leader of his principal Opposition, the Chris tian Democratic party, to seek some way out of this country's political crisis.

title: Quarrel Over TrashCan Seat In the Village Ends in Slaying
description: A quarrel over who would sit on a garbage can yesterday evening is Manhattan's East Village led to a fatal stabbing, after which witnesses chased the slayer for nearly three blocks into the arms of two policemen, the police said.According to the police, Wil liam Cole Williams, 48 years old, of 315 Bowery, was sitting on a garbage can in front of 195 East Second Street, near Avenue B. When Mr. Williams briefly left his seat, it was taken by a resident of the building, Guy Conner, 46, and a quarrel ensued, during which Mr. Williams pulled out a pock etknife, the police said.Mr. Conner went to his apartment and returned with a steak knife. After more heated words, Mr. Williams allegedly opened the 4inch blade of his knife and the two men began slashing at each other. They then wrestled on the ground, where Mr. Conner was killed by multiple stab wounds to the body, the police account said.

title: Wendy G. Reisman Is Married Here
description: Miss Wendy Gay Reisman and Stanton Schuster were married here yesterday in the Cottage of Hampshire House by Rabbi Sheldon Zimmer man of the Central Syna gogue.

title: E.P.A. to Propose Rules On Jet Noise Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Aircraft noise regulations that could reduce the number of flights into some of the na tion's busiest airports will be (proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency Tuesday.

title: STRIKES WIDENED BY CHAVEZ UNION
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 29The strike against Califor nia table grape growers spread across the entire San Joaquin Valley today when the United Farm Workers Union failed to renew its contracts with grow ers in the Delano area.

title: Libya Will Try Hijackers Who Blew Up Japanese Jet
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29 (UPI)Libya has decided to try the hijackers who blew up a Japanese jetliner at Benghazi airport last Tuesday, Informa tion Minister Abu Zeid Durdah said today. It would be the first time that hijackers are tried by an Arab country.

title: POLICE AND YOUTHS HIT IT OFF WELL
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 29To listen to the policemen today, it was almost as if 600,000 people assembled here solely to honor the nation's lawenforcement officers.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON SETTLEMENT IN LAOS CONFLICT
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 29 An agreement has been reached between the Vientiane Govern ment and the Communistled Pathet Lao on the broad lines and almost all questions of principle for a political and military settlement of the Lao tian conflict, sources close to the Government said today. The report was confirmed by the political organization of the Pathet Lao, the Neo Lao Hak Xat.

title: Jersey Judiciary Pleads For More Federal Judges
description: NEWARK, July 29The Fed eral judiciary in New Jersey, beset by a rising number of civil and criminal cases, is in volved in a muted struggle with Washington over the need for more judges.

title: Waida, Jockey, Is Dead Of Injuries in Spill
description: METHUEN, Mass., July 29 (UPI)Henry Wajda a jockey who was thrown from his mount at Rockingham Park at the start of the second race yesterday, died this morning of internal injuries.

title: Without Shame
description: LONDON, July 29Looking at Washington from a distance in these days of serial horror, one is struck by a generality even more devastating than the particular disclosures of crime and arrogance. It is the failure of the men who committed these acts to show the slightest consciousness of wrongdoing.

title: New Jersey Sports A Good Situation
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 29Rutgers has not decided exactly how to operate its intercollegiate athletic program for the next few years. University officials are not certain whether the Scarlet Knights should go bigtime in major sports, continue on the fringe of highpressure college athletics or drop off to a truly small athletic stature.

title: $202,600 Stolen at Drake From Led Zeppelin's Box
description: Cash receipts from the Mad ison Square Garden concerts of the Led Zeppelin rock group, said by the police to total $202, 600, were reported stolen yes terday from a safety  deposit box at the Drake Hotel, 440 Park Avenue, in an asyet un explained manner.

title: Troops in Europe
description: For nearly three decades the United States has main tained an expeditionary force in Western Europe, which has been blessed for a generation with peace, prosperity and relative stability. So much is evident fact; a strange situation has now arisen in which this historical truth is being cited to support both sides of a debate resuming on Capitol Hill for the third year running.

title: Militants in Cyprus Raid 2 News Plants; Police Unit Bombed
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 29 (UPI)Militants blew up a po lice station and ransacked two newspaper plants in Nicosia today.

title: Hildegarde Hoffman Becomes a Bride
