description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., July 29  Miss Hildegarde Hoffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Hoffman, and Henry Agatstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Agat stein of Flushing, Queens, was married here this morn ing at her parents' home by Rabbi Hal Firestone.

title: JOHN J. PHILLIPS
description: John J. Phillips, founder of the John Phillips Funeral Home in Middle Village, Queens, died Saturday of a heart attack in Clearwater, Fla., where he had retired because of health four months ago. He was 53 years old, a son of the late James A. Phillips who was Queens County Democratic leader.

title: Once an Encounter Group, Now They Share Each Other's Lives
description: GARRISON, N. YA few years ago, six couples were in an encounter group to gether, sharing one another's thoughts and feelings. Today they all live in this small Hudson River town sharing one another's lives.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WINDSOR, England, July 29 (AP)The United States continued its domination over England in Coronation Cup polo today, using a penalty goal in the last seconds for a 76 victory before a crowd of 10,000 that included Queen Elizabeth II, and Prince Philip.

title: Yew Yorkers Play Reminiscent of Earlier Era
Teacher Wins Case Against Principal On SexBias Charge
description: The City Commission on Hu man Rights, ruling in what it described as an out and out case of pure unadulterated male chauvinism, has ordered the principal of Seward Park High School in Manhattan to pay $1,750 in compensatory dam ages to an English teacher to whom he gave an unsatisfac tory rating after the teacher had charged him with sex dis crimination.

title: Personal Finance: Tighter Safeguards
description: The unwary consumer often finds that he has been defrauded on home improve ments.

title: Uniformed Police in Prospect Park Pedal Their Beats
description: Uniformed patrolmen in Prospect Park pedaled their beats yesterday in a new offensive against bicycle thieves.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
Reviving Mass Transit
description: The State of New York is at a transportation cross roads. Governor Rockefeller has proposed a fundamental change in public policy  the state subsidization of mass transit operating costs on a continuing basis. He has linked this proposal, however, with another for a massive $3.5 billion transportation bond issue that would contribute not only to improvement of deteriorating mass transit systems in cities and suburbs but also to the construction of less needed highways.

title: ENSEMBLES STAR AT FOLK FESTIVAL
description: VIENNA, Va., July 29  Al though American folk music is usually thought of and heard as the work of individual minstrel  singers who accompany themselves or have some mini mal form of instrumental as sistance  the fourday Na tional Folk Festival at Wolf Trap Farm Park this weekend pointed up the growing number and variety of regional instru mental groups that are scat tered around the country.

title: Stamford Undeterred by Court's Relief Decision
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Court actions striking down Stam ford's controversial oneyear residency requirement for wel fare clients will not hamper this Fairfield County city in trying to keep indigents out of town and off the welfare rolls, city officials said in the wake of a Supreme Court ruling this month.

title: Crime Rates in Precincts And Census Data Studied
New Yorkers Play Reminiscent of Earlier Era
Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Mrs. March Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Mrs. Myrna March and Dr. Arnold Roufa took place here yesterday afternoon at the bridegroom's apartment. Judge Manuel G. Guereiro of the Family Court performed the ceremony. The couple's previous marriages ended in divorce. The bride, an ASCAP songwriter, heads her own musicpublishing companies in New York, Makemusic Productions and March on Music, Ltd. Dr. Roufa is assistant attending physician at Women's Hos pital of St. Luke's Hospital Center.

title: Robert L. Koch Weds Miss Linda Joyce Leeb
description: Miss Linda Joyce Leeb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Leeb of this city, was married here yesterday at noon to Robert L. Koch, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Koch of Perth Amboy, N.J. The ceremony was per formed in the Cottage Room of Hampshire House by Rab bi Max Schenk.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight SavingTime
description: Today, July 30

title: Russian Will Direct Stockholm Orchestra
description: STOCKHOLM, July 29 (Reu ters)The Cultural Ministry of the Soviet Union has given permission to Gennady Rozh destvensky to be the next director of the Stockholm Philharmonic Orchestra, a Swedish newspaper said yes terday.

title: Amritraj Tops Connors in Final
description: BRETTON WOODS, N., H., July 29 (AP)India's Vijay Am ritraj, 19, capped a string of upsets today by rallying to down Jimmy Connors, 75, 26, 75, in the final of the $25,000 Volvo international tournament.

title: McGrath Rallies and Leads Jersey Bowling Qualifiers
description: PENNSVILLE, N.J., July 29 (AP)Mike McGrath of El Cerrito, Calif., rallied from sixth place to the lead today as qualifying play ended in the $47,500 Home Box Office open professional bowling tour nament.

title: TAX RETURNS AUDIT OF PRESIDENT ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, July 29A public interest law group called today for an audit of President Nixon's tax returns for the last three years on the ground that Mr. Nixon may have taken an illegal deduction for some personal papers he is turning over to the National Archives.

title: Dirks Counts Cost of His Moment of Truth on Equity
description: Raymond L. Dirks, the stock sleuth who triggered the collapse of the Equity Funding Corporation of America four months ago is just beginning to find out how dearly his brief moment of truth has cost him.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SUMMER RERUN The Mostly Mozart Festival is a nice rerun, one of those that brings something new each time it comes around, as it is doing for its seventh year from today through Aug. 25, or 24 concerts later.

title: Little League Snack Bar Is a Big Hit With Fans
description: NEWARK, July 29The subject of food and prices being a sore one, it is pleas ant to be able to report one enterprise that has nothing but satisfied customers in these inflated times. Or did until this weekend.

title: SOCIAL DIFFERENCES OF BLACKS SHOWN
description: WASHINGTON, July 29So cial differences between South ernborn blacks who have migrated to Northern urban areas and Northernborn blacks in the same areas are indicated by a Census Bureau report re leased today.

title: Air Show Is Held Without Its Stars The Blue Angels
description: LAKEHURST, July 29What Navy officials had billed as this year's biggest air show on the East Coast was held at the Naval Air Station here yester day despite the loss of its star attractions, the Blue Angels, because of a fatal air crash.

title: Gainesville Eight Trial
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., July 29 (AP)Seven members of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War and a sympathizer, known as the Gainesville Eight, will go on trial Tuesday on con spiracy charges, accused of plotting to disrupt the 1972 Republican National Convention with violence.

title: PETTY CAPTURES RACE AT POCONO
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., July 29 UPI)Richard Petty, a four time NASCAR grand national champion overcame nearly a onelap deficit today and won the 200lap 500 United States Auto Club stock car race at Pocono International Raceway.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PARIS, July 29  West Germany is going through one of the most extreme  bankers there use the word savagecredit squeezes in its history as the authorities try to check rise in the cost of living that is now ap proaching a quartercentury high of 8 per cent a year.

title: City Approves Plan By the Guggenheim To Alter Its Building
description: The City Board of Standards and Appeals has approved a revised plan of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum to make streetlevel alterations of its Frank Lloyd Wright building on Fifth Avenue.

title: ANNE KERR, 48, DEAD; A FORMER LABOR M.P.
description: LONDON, July 29 (UPI) Anne Kerr, an outspoken former Labor member of Parliament who carried her leftwing convictions across the Atlantic to the 1968 Demo crtaic National Convention in Chicago, died today at her home in suburban Twicken ham. She was 48 years old.

title: Mary Dwyer Bride Of N.B.C. Official
description: WOODBURY, L. I., July 29 In Fox Hollow Inn here this afternoon, Miss Mary Alice Dwyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Dwyer of St. Louis and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married to Leon Dobbin, son of Mrs. George Granath of Freeport and the late Philip Dobbin. Judge Patricia D. Collins of the Nas sau County District Court performed the ceremony.

title: COMMUNIST ATTACKS KILL 15, SAIGON SAYS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 (AP)  Rocket and mortar attacks killed at least 15 gov ernment soldiers in scattered fighting during the 30hour period ended at noon today, the Saigon command said.

title: Mary Ellen Chase, 86, Dies; Prolific Author of Windswept
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 29 (AP)  Mary Ellen Chase, author of two dozen books, in cluding novels and biographies, and professor emeritus of Eng lish literature at Smith College, died yesterday at a nursing home here. She was 86 years old.

title: YOUTHS SEIZE MAN WITH MARIJUANA
description: About 15 West Village teen agers who have attended police antinarcotics lectures seized a 27yearold Virginia man Sat urday night as he allegedly offered them marijuana on a Hudson River pier.

title: Madrid Is Planning To Ease the Penalty For Draft Resisters
description: MADRID, July 29Conscien tious objectors in Spain will get some relief from punishment but no legal status, according to legislation drawn up last week by the Government.

title: HitandRun Driver Kills Girl
description: A latemodel yellow Ford struck and killed a 7yearold girl and critically injured her 4yearold sister Saturday night as the two girls were trying to cross the street in front of 757 Park Avenue, Brooklyn. The westbound auto, moving at a high speed, hit them and drove away, the police said. Barbara Towner of 200 Throop Avenue was killed. Her sister, Patricia, was in critical condition with multiple fractures at Cumber land Hospital.

title: Kohoutek's Comet
description: WASHINGTON, July 29A hundred years from now, how will our great, great grandchildren remember 1973?

title: Army Says Poor Recruiting Cost U.S. $73Million in 72
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) improper recruiting practices, fraudulent enlistments and in adequate entrance medical ex aminations resulted in more than 29,000 unsuitability dis charges during the fiscal year that ended June 30, 1972, and cost the Government $73mil lion, the Army reported today.

title: Williams Backs StockFee Rise On Condition That S.E.C. Acts
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said today that he had be come convinced that an in crease in the commissions charged on stock transactions should be granted promptly but only if a key condition is met.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON SETTLEMENT IN LAOS CONFLICT
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 29 An agreement has been reached between the Vientiane Govern ment and the Communistled Pathet Lao on the broad lines and almost all questions of principle for a political and military settlement of the Lao tian conflict, sources close to the Government said today. The report was confirmed by the political organization of the Pathet Lao, the Neo Lao Hak Xat.

title: But Sharp Drop in Optimism Ends, Survey Finds
description: American consumers have lowered their sights on pur chases of homes and cars in the months ahead, according to a survey made by The Con ference Board and released over the weekend. The board reports, however, that the sharp decline in consumer optimism which occurred last spring has leveled off to a considerable extent.

title: The British Turn
description: LONDON  British policymakers have turned in a more European direc tion because of the changing position in the United States itself. Embroil ment in Vietnam and the divisive effect of this at home, superimposed on what must in any event have been a period of mounting social tension, have made the United States a more difficult country with which to be involved in a relationship of intense intimacy.

title: More Records Set for Machine Tools in Six Months
description: The machine tool industry continued to set records in most operations through June 30, according to figures re leased over the weekend by the National Machine Tool Buiders Association.

title: Labor Department Approves OneYear Apprentice Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)  Labor Secretary Peter J. Brennan said today that the Labor Department had ap proved its first oneyear ap prenticeship program.

title: Homosexual Family Units
description: BOSTON, July 29 (AP)  Homosexual couples have been recognized as family units by the Massachusetts Red Cross Blood Program. About 100 pints of blood were donated by such couples this weekend af ter the Red Cross issued an emergency appeal. When the Red Cross agreed to recognize the couples as family units they became eligible to receive blood from the program for any children of either partner.

title: ExManila Aide Plans Test Fight Against Deportation From U.S.
description: A former official under Pres ident Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines who was denied political asylum here and or dered to leave the United States by Aug. 16 says he will resist deportation to make a test case for fellow refugees from the Marcos Government.

title: LUCE GROUP TO SEND 15 SCHOLARS TO ASIA
description: A program to send young American college graduates to Asia for a year of study and work was announced yesterday by the Henry Luce Foundation, Inc.

title: Rosalyn Levy Wed To Gary F. Jonas
description: Miss Rosalyn E. Levy and Gary F. Jonas, both of Wash ington, were married here yesterday afternoon in the Tavern on the Green in Central Park. Rabbi Edward Klein of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue performed the ceremony.

title: Yankees Lose, 72 and 63, to Brewers; Expo 3Run Rally in 8th Tops Mets, 64
NADER GROUP URGES ALKASELTZER BAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)  The Ralph Nader backed Health Research Group, accusing the makers of AlkaSeltzer of withholding data from a Federal panel that declared the antacid safe and probably effective, asked the Government today to ban sales of the product and to censure the manufacturer publicly.

title: City to Keep Giving Out Bags for Trash in Park
description: The Parks Department will expand its program of provid ing plastic trash bags to con certgoers and ballplayers who use city facilities.

title: Briton, 25, Is Killed in Crash On Controversial Dutch Track
British Troops in Belfast Break Up Violent Protest
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 29 (UPI)  British troops today dispersed civil rights demonstrators near downtown Belfast, an army spokesman said.

title: Roundup: Wood Wins No. 20 While Sitting in Locker Room
description: Wilbur Wood was sitting by his locker in the visiting team's dressing room in Bloomington, Minn., yester day when word reached him that he had become the ma jor league's first 20game winner.

title: MARCOS VOTE SEEN AS OVERWHELMING
description: MANILA, July 29 (AP)The martial  law Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos has reportedly won overwhelm ing support in the Philippine national referendum.

title: In Paris, a Famous Restaurant Closes
description: PARIS, July 29  Georges Garin served nothing special Friday night.

title: Creatures of Gravity
description: For the man in the street, manned space travel is beginning to approach the routine. Last Saturday, when the Skylab 2 astronauts blasted off from Cape Kennedy there were only about 100,000 present to watch the launching, the smallest crowd ever to assemble for the beginning of an American manned space flight.

title: Child Psychotherapy Is Increasing Rapidly
description: By most standards, 11year old Paula was a model child. She was a bit quiet and intro spective by comparison with the other children in her well todo suburban community in the Middle West. But she was studious, obedient and never a bit of troubleuntil the day she began looking at the floor and refused to say anything at all.

title: New Records Seen For Interest Rates In the Weeks Ahead
description: Shortterm interest rates seem likely to continue to set new record levels in the weeks ahead and rates on bonds, still well below 1970 peaks, will probably be swept along.

title: Stout Recommends a Merger Of Pennsy and Jersey Central
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 29  Railroad passengers will not get efficient service until the two separate lines serving this area over the tracks of the New York and Long Branch Railroad are merged, State Senator Richard R. Stout of Monmouth, chairman of the Senate Transportation Commit tee, said yesterday.

title: 99 Spend Long Day Running in Sun
description: Tom Childers, a Marine captain sta tioned at the Quantico, Va., base, won the Road Runners Culb pentathlon yes terday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Captain Childers won the mile run in 4 minutes 36.4 seconds, the five mile (25:38.8) and the twomile (9:30.8). He finished second in the 440 and third in the halfmile.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
MRS. GRAHAM TELLS OF THREAT TO PAPER
description: The publisher of The Wash ington Post disclosed yesterday that after the Supreme Court decision allowing the publica tion of the Pentagon papers, the Justice Department had threatened her newspaper with criminal prosecutions if it did not return the top secret doc uments.

title: Crime Rates in Precincts And Census Data Studied
description: For the first time, crime rates in each of the city's 71 police precincts have been compared in a statistical study that re lates the racial composition, economic levels and age group ings of the people in those pre cincts.

title: HitandRun Driver Kills Girl
description: A latemodel yellow Ford struck and killed a 7yearold girl and critically injured her 4yearold sister Saturday night as the two girls were trying to cross the street in front of 757 Park Avenue, Brooklyn. The westbound auto, moving at a high speed, hit them and drove away, the police said. Barbara Towner of 200 Throop Avenue was killed. Her sister, Patricia, was in critical condition with multiple fractures at Cumber land Hospital.

title: Storm in Pennsylvania
description: SMETHPORT, Pa., July 29 (AP)Local officials said dam age would exceed $1million in a 20minute wind and hail storm that hit this northwestern Pennsylvania borough yester day. No serious injuries were reported in the storm.

title: CREW OF SKYLAB 2 SLOWED BY NAUSEA Astronauts Told to Rest Plans for a Space Walk Are Delayed One Day
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 29The Skylab 2 astronauts suffered bouts of nausea today, the result of motion sickness, and it has slowed down their efforts to activate the space station that is to be their or bital home for 59 days.

title: Advertising: The Birthday Lady
description: The birthday lady of Amer ican business is Etna M. Kelley, birdlike and grey haired, constantly on the search for founding dates of corporations but very hush hush about her own.

title: Ballet:Fernando Bujones Artist Displays Technique in 3 Diverse Roles by Lander, Robbins and Tudor
description: Aside from their profes sionalism, the choreographers Harald Lander, Jerome Rob bins and Antony Tudor make wildly differing demands on those dancers who interpret their ballets. Fernando Bu jones of American Ballet Theater tried one work of each, and emerged credibly if not completely convincing ly in each, on Friday and Saturday at the New York State Theater.

title: Polo at Darien
description: SubstitutesOx Ridge: Art Melervey, Bill Crawford. Farmington: Larry Smith, Buster Vinnick, Andy Katz.

title: Marchi Reconsiders His Support of Malls
description: State Senator John J. Mar chi of Staten Island, the Re publican candidate for May or, said yesterday that he was reassessing his previous support of pedestrian malls for New York.

title: TV: For Late Viewers
description: Judging by Geraldo Ri vera: Good Night, America, a 90minute program in the American Broadcasting Com pany's Wide World of En tertainment slot tonight at 11:30, it might be a good idea indeed to have this young man around these late evenings. Several more such specials are understood to be on the way. Let's hope so.

title: Inquiry Into Grain Deals Focusing on One Concern
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 The Commodity Exchange Au thority has investigated four large grain companies on sus picion of manipulation of wheat trading on the Kansas City mar ket but apparently has nar rowed its focus to one corn pany.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor appointed by Governor Rockefeller last September to inves tigate corruption in New York City's criminal justice sys tem, said he thought that corruption was slowing down here as a result of the fear of prosecution by his agency. Mr. Nadjari appeared on Channel 7's Eyewitness News Conference, where he also said he could not think of any judiciaryselection system that is more rotten than the one we have now. To be nominated for the State Supreme Court, he said, all you have do is to be the favorite of the district leader.

title: Radio
description: 66:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Orches tral Trio in C, j. Stamitz; Horn Concerto No. 1 in D, Haydn; Symphony No. 18 in F (K. 130), Mozart.

title: About the Mets:
description: When the annual Banner Day is unfurled next Sunday, only those signs and banners that can be carried by a maximum of two people will he permitted. We've had some banners that stretched to center field and took 40 people to carry them, said a Met official. . . . John Milner, who batted only once, was stopped after nine games in which he hit at a .486 clip (17 for 35). . . . Felix Millan has hit in 14 straight, a season mark for the team.

title: Louise Kaplan Has Nuptials
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 29Miss Louise Sara Kap lan was married here this afternoon in her parent's home, to David S. Weinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Weinberg of Havertown, Pa. Rabbi Hirshel Jaffe per formed the ceremony.

title: Misdirected Subsidy
description: An odd coalition, united in its high regard for the memory of President Eisenhower, is lobbying for a bill that would provide millions of dollars in United States Treasury funds to Eisenhower College, a small, 5year old liberal arts institution in Seneca Falls, N. Y. George Meany, members of the Eisenhower family, prominent bankers and industrialists and Generals Lauris Norstad and Alfred Gruenther have joined forces to push for passage of a measure that would order the Treasury to donate to the college one dollar for the sale of every com memorative Eisenhower silver dollar. The coins are cur rently sold by the Treasury for $10 each.

title: CITIBANK TO SET UP 4YEAR SAVING PLAN
description: The First National City Bank has announced a new savings plan aimed at small depositors and designed to provide them with interest rates normally available only to large investors and corporations.

title: Divers Waiting for Repairs
description: FAIRHAVEN, Mass., July 29 (UPDTwo divers on a treasure hunt for more than $2million from the sunken ocean liner Andrea Doria arrived in Fair haven today with their under water living chamber in tow and hoped to resume their adven ture later this week pending re pair of a power failure.

title: Reputed National Distributor of Smut IsShot to Death Near Home in Nassau
description: A man identified by the police, as a major national dis tributor of pornographic films was shot to death yesterday in an alley near his home in Nas sau County.

title: CITY INSTITUTIONS FACE LACK OF BEEF
description: The city's regular meat sup pliers have refused to sign con tracts for a twoweek supply of beef106,000 poundsnor mally used in municipal hospi tals, jails and other institutions, Mayor Lindsay announced yes terday.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Saratoga Waters Termed Unsafe if Taken Steadily
description: People who have been drink ing the mineral waters of Sara goga Springs for years in the belief that they were good for health are now being warned not to drink more than one glassful a week because the waters have a high content of radium, which has been identi fied as a potential cause of cancer.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)United States exports to the Soviet Union during the first six months of 1973 exceeded twoway trade between the two countries for all of 1972. Commerce Department trade data showed today that United States exports to the Soviet Union from Jan uary through June totaled $693.4million. Imports from the Soviet Union totaled $86.5million.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Policeman Arrests a Man Who Allegedly Shot at Him
description: A Harlem police officer shot at 10 days ago when he inter rupted a Bronx supermarket holdup, seized the alleged ring leader of the holdup gang yes terday morning when he saw him walking along Eighth Ave nue, the police reported.

title: Steel Production Off 1.6% in Week; Year's Total Is Up
description: Steel production last week fell 1.6 per cent to 2,780,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yester day. The index dipped to 113.9 from 115.8 in the preceding week, when output stood at 2,826,000 tons.

title: Scott Says That Nixon Will Come Out Fighting
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)The Senate minority leader, Hugh Scott of Penn sylvania, said today that President Nixon was the vic tim of unfavorable public opinion built by his ousted counsel, John W. Dean 3d. Mr. Scott predicted that Mr. Nixon will come out fight ing soon after the Senate Watergate committee recess es in August.

title: WHEELER ASSERTS BOMBING SECRECY WAS NIXON'S WISH
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, retired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a Senate committee today that President Nixon per sonally ordered the secret bombing of Cambodia to be conducted under the tightest security measures possible.

title: Philadelphia Club Accused Of Racial Discrimination
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP)  A downtown Philadelphia nightclub has become the object of a controversy over racial bias.

title: JOHN G. SUCCA
description: John G. Succa, retired presi dent of the Triboro Coach Cor poration, died yesterday in Terrace Heights Hospital, Queens. He was 78 years old and lived at 19645 McLaughlin Avenue in the Holliswood sec tion of Queens.

title: American Dance Festival: All of Campus Is a Stage
description: NEW LONDON. Conn. The idea that all the campus, if not the world, is a stage, was taken firmly to heart by the American Dance Festival at Connecticut College dur ing its past mlange weekend.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Where can you find a woman wallpaper hanger exterminator, caterer, photo retoucher, publicist, to say nothing of doctor, lawyer, stockbroker? Where can you obtain a credit card that lets you call yourself Ms. or enroll in a nonsexist class in martial arts (you know, things like karate and judo)?

title: NO FOUL PLAY FOUND IN PANTHER'S DEATH
description: Dr. Milton Helpern, the city's medical examiner, said yester day that an autopsy indicated no signs of foul play in the death of Lonnie B. Epps, a former member of the Black Panther party whose body was found face down in a fish hatchery pond in Pennsylvania last week.

title: S.I. Man Jumps to His Death As Fire Sweeps Apartment
description: A Staten Island man leaped to his death at 3:30 A.M. yester day from a sixthfloor window to escape a threealarm fire that had engulfed his apart ment, fire officials reported.

title: Albany Votes Bill to Create Panel on Cost of Living
description: ALBANY, July 30The Sen ate gave final legislative ap proval today to a bill, proposed by Governor Rockefeller, creat ing a temporary commission to study the cost of living and the econonmy.

title: Cahill to Hold Briefing For Two Candidates
description: TRENTON, July 30 (AP) Governor Cahill announced today that he would meet with the two major guberna torial candidatesRepresen tative Charles W. Sandman Jr., Republican, and Brendan T. Byrne, Democratto dis cuss the state's transporta tion needs.

title: Public Works Funds Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 30. (AP) The House passed a $4.75 billion appropriation today cov ering hundreds of water and power and other public works projects. The vote was 375 to 90. The measure, a compromise between versions passed earlier by the House and the Senate, now goes to the Senate for final Congressional action.

title: Talking Picture Wins as Saratoga Opens
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 30Talking Picture of the Elmendorf interests sped to a thrilling success in the Schuy lerville, the sixfurlong dash for 2yearold fillies that featured today's opening program of Saratoga's 106th thoroughbred racing season. The daughter of Speak John flashed a brilliant closing rally to overtake they Brookfield Farm's Imajoy a few yards before the wire to score by a nose in 1:10 45.

title: Genesco Sets Up Reserve To Cover Division Shifts
description: Directors of Genesco, Inc., voted yesterday to set up a reserve of $60,146,000 in the fiscal year ending today to cover losses which may be in curred in restructuring, discon tinuing or selling certain oper ating divisions.

title: Two Drown Off Nantucket
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., July 30 (AP)Two doctors drowned yesterday while swimming off Nantucket, the police said. The victims were identified as Char les P. Izzo, 61 years old of Ridgefield, Conn., and Richard Shapazian, 50, of Belmont.

title: Hare Krishna Seeking Midtown Site
description: The Hare Krishna sect  whose chanting, bellringing, saffrongowned young devotees have become an eyecatching fixture on the streets of New York and other American cities has become so successful that it is about to buy an expensive Manhattan property for its new international head quarters and New York center.

title: Bibby Hurls A NoHitter Against A's
description: OAKLAND, July 30 (UPI) Jim Bibby, whose career was threatened by major surgery only three years ago, pitched the first nohitter in Texas Ranger history and the fourth laf the American League season tonight when he beat the Oak land A's, 60.

title: Police Chiefs Seeking Raise
description: BOSTON, July 30 (AP)The police chiefs of 12 Massachu setts communities have filed court suits seeking pay in creases under a 1971 state law that says their pay must he up to twice that of their highest paid staff member. Most of the suits have been taken under advisement by Superior Court judges.

title: U.S. IS BOLSTERING DRUG FORCE HERE
description: WASHINGTON, July 30At torney General Elliot L. Rich ardson today initiated a series of steps that will nearly double the size of the Federalstate city joint antinarcotics task Force.

title: Crawling Up Everest
description: Crawling Up Everest

title: Businessmen, Confused by Phase 4, Now See, Uh . . .
description: More than 1,500 business men, many of them confused by Phase 4 of the Nixon eco nomic stabilization program, crowded into the Town Hall yesterday for a briefing by Administration officials. But most of them found little clarification of their complex problems during the halfday session, and many of them left the hall unhappy about the day's performance.

title: 2 Held, 1 Sought by F.B.I. In a BabySelling Scheme
description: PITTSBURGH, July 30 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investi gation says two persons have been arrested and a third is sought on Federal charges in connection with an alleged fraudulent interstate babysell ing scheme.

title: Grenada to Get Full Independence
description: LONDON, July 30 (UPI) Britain has agreed to give the Caribbean island of Gre nada full independence on Feb. 7 next year.

title: Westchester Roles Gained By 17 Golfers
New Lottery Prize: A Station Wagon Loaded With Food
description: TRENTON, July 30 (AP) Beginning in August, the State Lottery Commission will give away 35 station wagons, each loaded with $500 worth of food, it was announced today.

title: Optimism Glittering for Jewelers at Show
description: Despite upward pressure on prices in the jewelry in dustry, fed by rising gold costs and a shortage of sil ver, retailers report record sales and optimism about the future, Victor Paul, chairman of the Retail Jewelers of America, said yesterday.

title: DAHAB WINS STAKE AT ORANGE COUNTY
SKYLAB 2 WALK POSTPONED AGAIN
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 30The Skylab 2 astronauts fell further behind in their work aboard the orbiting space station today as they continued to be troubl'ed with motion sickness.

title: JIMMY RADCLIFFE
description: Jimmy Radcliffe, singer, com poser and record producer for Black Patch Productions and for the corporation of his own name, died Friday of a kidney ailment in the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 36 years old and lived at 441 West End Avenue.

title: Link to Mafia Is Sought in L.I. Slaying
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 30 Nassau County and New York City policemen were trying to determine today whether or ganizedcrime figures were in volved in yesterday's slaying of a Long Island man described by the police as a major national distributor of pornographic films.

title: WEINBERGER SEES FLAWS IN QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that he did not believe in any kind of mechanistic, statistical ap proach to ending discrimina tion in employment.

title: GAINS REPORTED FOR EL PASO GAS
BLOOMFIELD SUED BY FACULTY GROUP
description: BLOOMFIELD, July 30The Bloomfield College chapter Of the American Association of University Professors filed a breach of contract suit today in Superior Court in Trenton asking that the college be pre vented from dismissing 13 faculty members and putting the rest of its teachers on one year contracts.

title: ROCKEFELLER BILL ON MORTGAGE RISE STALLS AT ALBANY Democrats Balk at Increase in Ceiling to 8%Action on Bond Plan Snagged
description: ALBANY, July 30Governor Rockefeller's bill to permit an increase in mortgage interest rates was stalled last night in parliamentary maneuvering and legislative histrionics.

title: Millions Reported Falsely Paid To Auto Insurance Fraud Ring
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP)An insurance fraud ring based on phantom cars has been disclosed by investiga tors from the Pennsylvania State Police, the Federal Bu reau of Investigation and in surance companies.

title: $1Million Storm Damage
description: SMETHPORT, Pa., July 30 (AP)  A violent 20minute wind and hail storm damage estimated at $1million in thisi northwestern Pennsylvania com munity over the weekend. About a dozen persons suffered minor injuries.

title: Hulse Wins Picken Trophy In Great South Bay Sail
22Million Offered By Liberty National For Rockford Life
description: The Liberty National Life In surance Company of Birming ham, Ala., announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Rockford Life Insurance Company of Rock ford, Ill.

title: Oil Companies Compliance On Allocation Found Lagging
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) John A. Love, the new White House energy chief, said today that oil company compliance with the voluntary petroleum allocation program had deteri orated noticeably in the last three weeks. He said he hoped to announce a decision this week on whether the program would be replaced with a man datory system.

title: RULING DUE SOON ON BOMBING STAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court said today that he would rule in 24 to 48 hours on whether there should be an immediate halt in the United States bomb ing of Cambodia.

title: DE GUSTIBUS If Salad Has Vinegar, Can the Meal Still Have Wine?
description: A reader asks what we think of serving a party meal that includes both wine and a salad with vinegar or lemon juice. She has been told the two don't go to gether.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Golf Scholarship Set Up for Black

title: People and Business Mays Named O.P.I.C. President
description: Marshall T. Mays is a South Carolinian, a Republican, a graduate of the United States Naval Academy and a law yer. As of yesterday, he has also been designated presi dent of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation by President Nixon, subject to Senate confirmation.

title: 50 Million Try Luck Fishing as Ancient Sport Enters Golden Age
GOING OUT Guide
description: OFF DUTY Gilbert and Sullivan told us what the felon does when he's not engaged in his employment; he has great capacity for innocent enjoyment. But what does a noted lawyer do when he's finished arguing and looks for surcease from tension? If he's Louis Nizer, he turns artist (unless he's writing a book, such as My Life in Court or The Im plosion Conspiracy). Mr. Nizer knocks about in off hours with brush and paint. The result of his artistic expression is the subject of a oneman show at Hammer Galleries, 51 East 57th Street (PL 80410).

title: A.T. &T. IS ACCUSED BY MICROWAVE MAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company was ac cused today of anticompetitive practices which could en danger the lower costs and bet ter service that competitive microwave companies promise.

title: EHRLICHMAN GETS A BAKER APOLOGY
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., vice chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, apolo gized today to John D. Ehrlich man for suggesting that he had been party to an irregular pro cedure in helping arrange for Maurice H. Stans, former Com merce Secretary and director of the Finance Committee to Re elect the President, to avoid a grand jury appearance in the wiretapping case.

title: PHILIP KLEIN
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 30  Philip Klein, president since 1938 of the Mohawk Sav ings and Loan Association of Newark, died yesterday in Co lumbia  Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. He was 79 years old and lived at 1309 Mercer Place.

title: Bridge  QuarterFinal Match Brings  An Exact Tie in the Spingold
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  One of the most dramatic mo ments in the long history of the Spingold knockout team championship occurred here in the small hours of this morning. Play in a tense quar terfinal match between teams led by Bob Ewen of New York and Bud Reinhold of Highland Park, Ill., was de layed for about an hour be cause one of Reinhold's play ers, Dr. Richard Katz of Los Angeles, was called away to a medical emergency.

title: Sniper Captured in Midtown After an Hour's Siege
description: For nearly an hour yesterday afternoon, a sniper on West 38th Streetarmed with a 12 gauge, singlebarreled shotgun and the bravado of an after noon of drinkingheld scores of police officers at bay.

title: Profit Up at United Aircraft and Boeing
description: Earnings of two aircraft pro ducers  the United Aircraft Corporation and the Boeing Company  were up sharply in this year's second quarter and first half, they reported yesterday. The gains reflected in part larger amounts of com mercial business.

title: 5 TOP WEIS OFFICERS PLEAD NOT GUILTY
description: Five top officers of Weis Securities. Inc., a former New york Stock Exchange firm now in liquidation pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of falsifying their records by more than $3million to conceal a $1.5million deficit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: EHRLICHMAN ENDS ON LOYALTY NOTE
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  John D. Ehrlichman ended to day his five days of testimony before the Senate Watergate committee as he had begun last Tuesday, by insisting that neither he nor President Nixon was involved in any aspect of the Watergate coverup.

title: NIGHTCLUB OWNER IS SLAIN IN QUEENS
description: The manager of a Queens nightclub was found murdered and his apartment ransacked early yesterday in the Corona section of Queens.

title: RIVAL PARTY LEADER MEETS WITH ALLENDE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 30 Chile's Marxist President, Sal vador Allende Gossens, began talks today with the leader of his principal opposition, the powerful Christian Democratic party, in what has been termed a lastditch attempt to save the country from civil war.

title: Burglars Drag AwaySafe, Burn Off Door for $2,500
description: SYRACUSE, July 30 (AP) Burglars dragged a 400pound safe down a winding stair case, wheeled it away and burned it open to get. $2,500 in cash early today, the po lice said.

title: DOMINICK TO QUIT RETAIL BROKERAGE
ROGERS, A ROOKIE, WINS FOR EXPOS
description: The Mets got encouraging performances from two key pitchers last night, but they failed to get any timely hits and dropped a doubleheader to the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium.

title: Congressional Game Won Again by G.O.P.
description: BALTIMORE, July 30 (AP) The Republicans scored their 10th consecutive victory in the annual Congressional baseball game, today whip ping the Democrats 12 to 4 behind the pitching of Robert H. Michel and William S. Cohen.

title: Youngsters Who Are Happy to Be in School for the Summer, Too
description: You'd think that when school ended in June all the boys and girls would bid it a delighted goodby.

title: WHEELER ASSERTS BOMBING SECRECY WAS NIXON'S WISH
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, retired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a Senate committee, today that President Nixon per sonally ordered the secret, bombing of Cambodia to be conducted under the tightest security measures possible.

title: HALDEMAN SAYS HE AND NIXON HAD NO WATERGATE KNOWLEDGE; HEARD TAPES PLAYED RECENTLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 30H. R. Haldeman declared today that he and President Nixon were innocent of any involve ment in the Watergate breakin or coverup, but that they had been badly misled by John W. Dean 3d and others.

title: Next French Atom Blast In September, Radio Says
description: PARIS, July 30 (UPI)The next nuclear detonation in the 1973 series might not come until September, the French Government radio said today.

title: AMEX PRICES EASE IN SLOW TRADING
description: The 10day rally on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market ended yesterday as prices eased in slower trading.

title: Delayed Bhutto Visit to U.S. Is Put Off Again, to Sept. 18
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 30 (Reuters)President Zulfi kar Ali Bhutto's visit to the United States has again been postponed by a week at Pakis tan's request and will begin Sept. 18, it was announced to day.

title: Rentzel Case Taken to Court
description: FULLERTON, Calif., July 30  The National Football League Players Association will seek an injunction in the California courts on Wednes day, restraining Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L. commissioner, who has suspended Lance Rentzel from playing with the Los Angeles Rams this season.

title: Buckley Denounces Records Industry
description: LOS ANGELES, July 30  Senator James L. Buckley leveled charges of drugola and underworld connections against the recording industry today at a Los Angeles press conference.

title: ROCKEFELLER BILL ON MORTGAGE RISE PASSED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Tuesday, July 31 The Legislature passed Gover nor Rockefeller's bill to permit an increase in mortgage interest rates early today after rejecting a batch of Democratic amend ments that had been designed to defeat the bill.

title: Ignorance of Drug Laws JailsU.S. Travelers
Conservationists Say Poisoning Of Wolves Won't Stop Campaign
description: The conservationists who toured the country with two wolves to promote the preser vation of endangered species said yesterday that their edu cational programs would con tinue despite the wolves death Sunday, apparently at the hands of a poisoner.

title: . . . Time Out
description: The Senate Watergate committee and its staff have been working in recent weeks at a rugged pace. The examination in recent days of Mr. Ehrlichman has re flected this physical and psychological pressure. Ques tioning has sometimes seemed ragged and unfocused, leaving some matters inadequately explored. The brief flareup between majority and minority counsel at yes terday's hearing was an unwelcome sign of fatigue.

title: Tolling the Bridges
description: Governor Rockefeller's welcome proposal for provid ing operational subsidies for ailing mass transit systems in cities and suburbs requires local governments to put up matching subsidies of their own.

title: Kickbcak Conviction Upheld
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit upheld today the conviction of former city Commissioner Mau rice S. Osser on charges of receiving kickbacks on city printing contracts. Osser was sentenced last year to six years in prison and fined $19,000 on convictions of seven counts of mail fraud, one of conspiracy and one of obstructing justice.

title: PILIC AND RIESSEN WIN IN LOUISVILLE
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 30 (UPI)Thirdseeded Nikki Pilic, fourthseeded Marty Riessen and. fifthseeded Manuel Or antes scored easy victories to day in the opening round of the $75,000 First National Bank tennis tournament. Sixthseeded John Newcombe advanced by default.

title: PHONE UNION SUING EXHEAD FOR FUNDS
description: The local that struck the New York Telephone Company two years ago asked a Feder al court yesterday to compel its former president to ac count for $609,314 in what were described as question able expenditures made dur ing the sevenmonth walkout.

title: Mason Outpoints Sosa In Main Event at Forum
description: Vern Mason suffered a cut over his right eye in the sev enth round of his welterweight bout against Roberto Sosa of Argentina last night, but that didn't seem to bother him as he won a unanimous decision in a 10round bout at the Felt Forum.

title: Nixon on Evening Cruise
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) President Nixon went for a cruise aboard the Presidential yacht Sequoia tonight, accom panied by his foreign affairs adviser, Henry A. Kissinger.

title: A MISSING REVOLVER FOUND ON GUNMAN
description: A .38caliber service revolver reported missing last February by a captain in the Depart ment of Correction was re covered last night from a 24 yearold man who was ob served entering a grocery store in Harlem with the re volver drawn, the police re ported.

title: PIKE H. SULLIVAN
description: Pike H. Sullivan, who retired in 1967 as manager of the patents and licenses depart ment of the Standard Oil Com pany of Indiana in Chicago, died Saturday in Tucson, Ariz. His age was 70.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, JULY 31, 1973
description: H. R. Haldeman, the former White House chief of staff, declared that he and President Nixon were innocent of any involvement in the Watergate breakin or coverup, and that they had been badly misled by John W. Dean 3d and others. He told the Senate Watergate committee that he had listened to the secret tape recordings of two of the President's meetings with Mr. Dean, the de posed White House counsel. [Page 1, Col, 8.]

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The American Biscuit Company plant employing 425 people in Passaic announced yesterday it would cease operations by the end of the year. The closing of the plant is the third shutdown of a major company in Passaic this year. Earlier, the Uniroyal Company, with 1,400 em ployes, and the RaybestosManhattan Company, with 1,200 workers, ceased operations. The closing of the biscuit plant was reported in a twosentence announcement by D. McMullen, general manager. There was no explanation for the shutdown.

title: Irving Loses Appeal for Parole; Board Plans Review in January
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) Clifford Irving, who was convicted of attempting to write a bogus autobiography of Howard Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, was denied parole today by the United States Parole Board.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose to record highs in the Government's weekly sale of these short term securities.

title: U.S. Five Trounces Poland
description: WARSAW, July 30 (UPI) David Thompson of North Car olina State led a team of Unit ed States collegians to a 9764 triumph over Poland today in an exhibition basketball game. He had 22 points.

title: 2 Seized in L. I. Holdup After LandAir Search
description: Two alleged Nassau County robbers led the police last eve ning on a fivemile, 60milean hour car chase into the Laurel ton section of Queens until they were captured finally in the vi cinity of Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Prosecutors Press MitchellStan Trial And Agree to Separate One for Sears
description: Federal prosecutors moved yesterday for a prompt trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Secre tary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans on charges that they ob structed a major fraud investi gation in return for a secret political contribution.

title: HOUSE THWARTS PAY RISE ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 The House slammed the door today on a possible immediate pay rise for members of Con gress.

title: Escaped Convict Caught
description: ALBION, N.Y., July 30 (AP) An inmate at the Albion Cor rectional Center escaped from the prison yesterday but was recaptured a few hours later, the state police said. The troopers arrested Robert W. Rice, 25 years old, of Buffalo about 17 miles from the prison and charged him with escape.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES FUNDS FOR U.S.I.A. Chairman Drops Proposal for Big Budget Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 The House Subcommittee on State Department Organization today gave the United States Information Agency about $215million, most of what it had originally asked for its 1974 operations.

title: Union Oil Profit Soars by 44% in Quarter
Chess : Down Petropolis Way, It's Two Down for Ljubojevic
description: PETROPOLIS, BrazilLju bomir Ljubojevic zoomed into the lead of the Interzonal tournament by defeating Peter Biyiasas of Canada in the third round after taking his secondround game with Shi mo Kagan of Israel. The 23 yearold Yugoslav is expected to make it three in a row when his adjourned game with Werner Hug of Switzer land is played off.

title: Whitlam, in U. S., Stresses Own Course
description: WASHINGTON, July 30Aft er meeting for more than an hour with President Nixon, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia said today that his Government wished to remain a friend of the United States but had independent interests that could lead to further dis agreements with Washington.

title: DEVIL'S TIE CITED AT PATRICK TRIAL, Group Said to Have Urged a Break With Parents
description: A young man who was de programed by Ted Patrick and reunited with his family testified at Mr. Patrick's trial yesterday that leaders of the New Testament Missionary Fel lowship had told young mem bers that their parents were be ing used by devils and that they ought to break ties with them.

title: E.P.A. Official Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, July 30. (AP), The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Alvin Alm of Washington to he assistant administrator of (he Environ menial Protection Agency, He succeeds Thntrinc E. Carroll.

title: The Ehrlichman Thesis
description: An air of unreality hung about the testimony of John D. Ehrlichman before the Senate Watergate committee. It was as if he thought he had been asked to testify about the governing of a hypothetical country and had a clean slate to write upon. He expounded theories about Presidential power, national security and individual rights which bore at best only a tangential relationship to the United States Constitution, Supreme Court prece dents, Federal laws, and political practices.

title: GANGLAND KILLER GETS LIFE TERM Alleged Gambino Gunman Sentenced in Monticello
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., July 30 (AP)An alleged gunman for the Carlo Gambino crime family was sentenced today to life in prison. He was convicted July 11 by a Sullivan County Court jury of the murder of a reputed mobster, Carlo A. Lombardi.

title: OIL REFINERS CITED IN TRUST SUIT HERE
description: A $54billion antitrust suit was filed in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday against five major oil and gasoline corpora tions.

title: Japan at Once SelfConfident and Unsure As Nixon and Tanaka Go Into Their Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Japan symbolized by Premier Kakuei Tanaka as he prepares to meet with President Nixon tomorrow is a nation with more selfconfidence than at any time since World War II and a nation with little sense of direction.

title: Liquor Stores Laying In Stocks in Half Gallons
description: With the sale of liquor in halfgallon bottles becoming legal tomorrow in New York State, liquor stores through out the city were reported busy yesterday laying in stocks in the larger size con tainers.

title: SHORTAGE OF BEEF IS GROWING HERE
description: The beef shortage became more serious in this area yes terday as retailers reported in adequate supplies and meat processing plants laid off work ers.

title: CAR MAKERS GIVEN POLLUTION DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Environmental Protection Agen cy allowed the nation's auto makers today to delay from 1976 until 1977 the production of cars that would meet strin gent emission standards for nitrogen oxides, the third pol lutant for which a year's ex tension has now been granted.

title: Senate Votes Election Spending Reform With Tight Curbs on Big Contributions
description: WASHINGTON, July 30For the second time in less than two years, the Senate adopted today an important package of reformssome of them very stringentin one of the most crucial but unseen areas of the democratic process: the financ ing of campaigns for elective office.

title: Wood, Field and Stream New Hampshire Natives Have 2 Days to Hunt Deer in Relative Privacy
description: New Hampshire natives will have a twoday deer hunting season of their own this year.

title: Upstate Flood Losses Surveyed To Determine the Repair Costs
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., July 30  From Bash Bish Falls in Columbia County near the Mas sachusetts line to Cadosia on Rattlesnake Creek in Delaware County near Pennsylvania, Fed eral and state engineers are in the field surveying damage caused by the floods of June.

title: FARM PRICE RISE STEMMED IN JULY
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP The prices farmers get for their raw products were un changed in July from the month before and averaged 35 per cent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Cahill Hopes Successor Keeps Summer Youth Plan
description: SEA GIRT, July 30Gover nor Cahill, who lost his bid to be a candidate for reelection this year, today expressed the hope that his successor would carry on and expand the sum mer youth program he estab lished two years ago.

title: FARM MIGRANTS OPPOSE EVICTION
description: CAMDEN, July 30  To pre vent what its president called chaos in agriculture, the New Jersey Farm Bureau came to the defense today of a member farmer charged with evicting 11 migrant workers from his labor camp last September without notice.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Galt McDermot has been signed to compose the musi cal background score for the film version of Rhinoceros. The adaptation of Eugene Ionesco's play, directed by Tom O'Horgan and starring Zero Mostel, is one of eight movies of noted plays to be presented on a subscription basis by the American Film Theater in association with American Express Films in more than 500 United States and Canadian theaters, start ing October 29.

title: Books of The Times
description: PEARY AT THE NORTH POLEFACT OF FICTION? By Dennis Rawlins. 320 pages Illustrated, Robert B. Luce. $8.95. WINNER LOSE ALL. Dr. Cook and the Theft of the North Pole. By Hugh Eames. 346 pages Illustrated. Little, Brown. $8.95.

title: Excerpts From Ehrlichman's Testimony Before the Senate Watergate Committee
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony today by John D. Ehrlichman on the 31st day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: Rebels Drive Cambodian Force From a Village Near the Capital
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 30 (UPI)Sharp clashes were reported today as close as five miles from Phnom Penh as advancing Communist troops routed 200 government soldiers from a position east of the Bassac River.

title: At This Point in Time
description: Mr. Chairman, members of the com mittee, at this point in time, just before I deactivate my testimony, I would make a statement in the nature of negative on this type of idea you can read in the press that says, well, those are just a lot of lies they have been telling down there in Washington.

title: WHITE SOX APPOINT GENERAL MANAGER
description: CHICAGO, July 30 (UPI) Roland Hemond, the personnel director credited with engineer ing many of the deals that built the Chicago White Sox into a pennant contender, to day was appointed general manager of the team to suc ceed Stu Holcomb.

title: Con Edison Says It May Ask the State For Yet Another Electricity Rate Rise
description: The Consolidated Edison Com pany asserted yesterday that its earnings were at starvation level and that it would prob ably seek a new increase in electric rates here in the next 14 months in addition that sought in a pending application.

title: Loyal ExChief of Staff Harry Robbins Haldeman
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 One day several years ago, a subordinate received from H. R. Haldeman, then the White House chief of staff, a memorandum that the sub ordinate had drafted. In one corner Mr. Haldeman had written, in his precise hand, TL When he was asked what that nota tion meant, the often curt and unbending Mr. Haldeman replied, Too little, too late. Mr. Haldeman's friends hope that the same comment will not apply to his attempt to clear himselfand, not incidentally, the President whom he served with such fervor for more than four yearsof any implication in the Watergate case and the ensuing coverup. That at tempt began today, when he took the stand before the Senate investigating commit tee on Capitol Hill.

title: Richard Nader Sees Trend in Music
description: Five years ago, when Richard Nader looked into the future of the music busi ness, what he saw coming was a revival of the rock n roll music of the nineteen fifties.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 30A ministeriallevel meeting of the Committee of 20 nations nego tiating world monetary reform began here today, but with no decisions or announcements ex pected.

title: Truce Unit Plans to Mark Time With the Exit of Canada's Team
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 31 (UP1)The Vietnam international peace keeping team will come to virtual standstill with the de parture of Canada, according to the chief Hungarian delegate.

title: EHELICHMAN ENDS ON LOYALTY NOTE
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  John D. Ehrlichman ended to day his five days of testimony before the Senate Watergate committee as he had begun last Tuesday, by insisting that neither he nor President Nixon was involved in any aspect of the Watergate coverup.

title: Anderson Takes First Place In 22Caliber Pistol Shoot
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, July. 30 (UPI)Army Sgt. 1st Cl. Her shel Anderson of Tracy City, Tenn., won the 22caliber pis tol competition today and gained the firstround lead in the threeday national pistol championship.

title: Mets Bow, 10, 52
description: BOSTON, July 30The New York Yankees have not won game in Boston in a year, and Manager Ralph Houk knows why. Because of that short leftfield fence, the Red Sox make you play their game and they ruin yours, he said.

title: 2 Laotian Sides Cautious on Pact Details
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 30 (Agence FrancePresse)  Al though all main questions of a Laotian peace settlement have reportedly been agreed on, the details of the accord were the subject of difficult negotiations today.

title: In Crucial Delta Province, A War of Sorts Goes On
description: VI THANH, South Vietnam, July 24Six months after the signing of the Vietnam truce, the war goes on here in the heart of the Mekong Delta.

title: Watkins Glen Called SuccessAnd Last of Its Kind
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 30The officials and business men who handled the 600,000 rockmusic fans at the largest festival ever held in the United States said today that they thought the event was an over whelming success but that they would never permit another one.

title: DAHAB WINS STAKE AT ORANGE COUNTY
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 30A handsome dark chestnut gelding named M. H. Aswed Dahab, owned by the Tiffany Arabian of Stanfordville, N. Y., won the Arabian Western pleas ure horse championship stake today at the Orange County horse show.

title: Fish in Hudson Died Naturally
description: The hundreds of dead silvery fish found floating on the Hud son River in the last few days were not killed by any ecolog ical enemy but have completed their natural life cycle, accord ing to the city's Environmental Protection Administration. A spokesman for the agency said yesterday that the fish, appar ently chubs, had been washed up from the ocean and were expected to wash out again.

title: Talmadge Is Reported To Have Accepted Trip
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, who is a member of the Senate Com mittee investigatng the Water gate scandals, was reportedly flown to the Caribbean for a midwinter vacation early this year by a major Government contractor.

title: Football Transactions AMERICAN CONFERENCE
description: BUFFALOAl Davis, running back, and Torn Martin, safety, were cut.

title: SHORTAGE OF BEEF IS GROWING HERE
description: The beef shortage became more serious in this area yes terday as retailers reported in adequate supplies and meat processing plants laid off work ers.

title: THALIDOMIDE CASE SETTLED IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, July 30 (AP)A High Court judge approved a $50million award today to compensate children who were born deformed after their mothers took thalidomide.

title: Time Lost to Strikes Is Lowest in 9 Years
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Vincent F. Albano, chairman of the New York County Republican committee, has submitted the name of Elrich A. Eastman for approval as the committee's designee for the City Board of Elections. The nomination of Mr. East man, a 50yearold Harlem lawyer, replaces the committee's previous choice of Vincent J. Velella, whose name had been submitted along with nine other designers from the various county organizations. The nine others were approved earlier this month, but Mr. Velella asked that action on his nomi nation be deferred in the light of allegations, denied by Mr. Velella, that he had underworld connections.

title: Paper Gives F.B.I. a Copy Of Disputed Canticle Letter
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., July 30 (UPI)Ralph Sullivan, an attorney for The Manchester Union Leader, has turned a photographed copy of the dis puted Canuck letter over to the Federal Bureau of Inves tigation, the managing editor, Paul Tracey, said today. The F.B.I. went to the newspaper offices Friday and was referred to counsel.

title: Penguin Born in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 30 (UPI)A penguin was born to day to a 3yearold king penguin at the Ocean Underworld Ex hibit in Atlantic City. Ornith ologists said it was the first time in New Jersey and ex tremely rare in the world that an egg of a penguin had hatch ed in captivity. The mother, which had been called Peter until last week, had its name changed to Patricia after its keepers discovered their mis take

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 20920
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers In reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order Win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with ail five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Television
description: SENATE WATERGATE HEARINGS TELEVISION

title: 4 Elmwood Park Teachers Learned a Lesson in Jail
description: ELMWOOD PARK, July 30Four teachers who were released from the Bergen County jail last week after being sentenced to 30 days for leading an illegal strike here, found that even prison can offer an education of sort.

title: PAROLEE HUNTED IN CAMP SLAYING
description: A former convict suspected of the fatal stabbing Sunday of a teenaged camper bound to a tree in the Adirondacks State Park was made the subject of a nationwide alarm yesterday vhile at least 100 lawmen searched for him in the upstate woodlands.

title: Radio
description: 8:0510 A.M., WNCN. Polifemo: Overture, Bononcini; L'Amore Industrioso Overture, Carvalho; Carmen: Micaela's Air, Bizet; Villanella, Respighi; Le Roi d'Ys Overture, Lalo; Eine Kleine Nachtmusik, Mozart; Symphony No. 7 in D minor, Dvorak. 9:06.10, WQXR: Piano Personali ties. Walter Klien and Beatrice Klien; Jeux d'Enfants, Bizet, 10:0612 Noon, WQXR: The Listening Room. Robert Sherman, host. Alexander Schneider, vio linist.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Saratoga Waters Termed Unsafe if Taken Steadily
description: People who have been drink ing the mineral waters of Sara goga Springs for years in the belief that they were good for health are now being warned not to drink more than one glassful a week because the waters have a high content of radium, which has been identi fied as a potential cause of cancer.

title: 20Seat Seaplane Being Put Into Wall StreetPhiladelphia Service
description: Downtown Airlines, which operates a scheduled sea plane service between Wall Street and downtown Phila delphia, will introduce a 20 passenger float plane on the route this Thursday.

title: Anderson Takes First Place In .22Caliber Pistol Shoot
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, July 30 (UPI)Army Sgt. 1st Cl. Her shel Anderson of Tracy City, Tenn., won the .22caliber pis tol competition today and gained the firstround lead in the threeday national pistol championship.

title: Roy Shuman, Actor, 48, Dies; Played TV and Theater Roles
description: Roy Shuman, an actor known for his role as the villainous Dr. Shea in the television serial As the World Turns, died yesterday of a heart attack in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived at 161 West 54th Street.

title: Beverage Data Attributed
description: Figures on soft drink con sumption appearing in The New York Times last Saturday was supplied by Beverage Industry, a trade magazine. The maga zine was inadvertently referred to as Soft Drink Industry, the former name of the publication that has not been in use for the last two years.

title: Equity Financing
description: The First Pennsylvania Mortgage Trust an nounced yesterday that it will buy up to 400,000 of its warrants in the overthecounter market dur ing the next year. The real estate investment trust, which is run by a subsidiary of the First Pennsyl vania Corporaton, has 1,611,974 warrants outstand ng to purchase 805,987 shares of common stock at $20 a share. The common closed at 19 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: A Rock Guitarist Is Given Probation on Drug Charge
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 30 (AP)  Jerry Garcia, lead guitarist of the Grateful Dead rock group, was placed on one year conditional probation to day on charges of possession of narcotics.

title: Cluttering Taxi Tops
description: The taxi industry is pushing a summertime sneaker bill to allow the sale of space on minibillboards that will be affixed to either side of taxi roofs. The bill will come up in City Council for a vote todaywith virtually no warning and totally inadequate public discussion.

title: GOV. MANDEL SIGNS A DISCLOSURE LAW
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 30 Expressing doubts over the le gality of the legislation, Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland signed a measure today requir ing complete financial disclo sure by all elected officials and most ranking appointed govern ment employes.

title: Stolen Goods Bring Arrest
description: The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation arrested Samuel E. Cohen, 60 years old, of Valley Stream, L.I., yesterday on a charge of possession of goods stolen in at least two armed truck hijackings in northern New Jersey in the last six weeks. He was said to have clothing worth $15,000, stolen from a truck hijacked June 22 in North Bergen, and clothing worth $20,000 stolen from an other truck hijacked July 20 in Jersey City,

title: Dialogue in Chile
description: In a nationwide broadcast last week, President Allende of Chile called for direct talks with the opposition Chris tian Democratic party as a supreme effort to avert a civil war. Even before Mr. Allende spokeon June 29 there had been an abortive revolt by part of an armored regiment, which cost 22 lives before it collapsed. Mr. Allende's appeal brought agreement for the talks he wanted, and they began yesterday. But, in the days fol lowing the broadcast and before that informal dialogue started, the President's chief military aide had been mur dered by unknown gunmen and a strike by 50,000 truck owners, threatening economic chaos as it cripples the national transportation system for essential commodities, had begun.

title: Jetailer Opener Friday 1s Tryout for New Faces
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 30 The Jets and the Houston Oilers will use their pre season opener Friday night at the Astrodome as a try out for new faces, but their objectives will not be the same.

title: A.B.C. Loses Its Suit on TV Basketball
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice dismissed yesterday an American Broadcasting Com pany suit to prevent televising of National Basketball Associ ation games by the Columbia Broadcasting System in the upcoming season.

title: Albany Democrats Delay Debate on Transit Bonds
description: ALBANY, July 30The Re publican majority's hope to de bate and pass Governor Rocke feller's $3.5billion transit bond proposal with bipartisan sup port became snagged on Demo cratic resistance tonight. The issue was deferred until tomor row with some concessions con sidered likely to be made.

title: AMERICANS SCORE IN FINNISH TRACK
description: HELSINKI, July 30 (UPI) Jim Boulding, Chuck Smith, Dwight Stones and Al Feuer bach of the United States were winners today in the opening of a twoday track and field meeting in which a couple of New Zelanders dominated the distance events.

title: PILIC AND RIESSEN WIN IN LOUISVILLE
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 30 (UPI)Thirdseeded Nikki Pilic, fourthseeded Marty Riessen and fifthseeded Manuel Or antes scored easy victories to day in the opening round of the $75,000 First National Bank tennis tournament. Sixthseeded John Newcombe advanced by default.

title: New Jersey Sports Backstretch Gospel
description: OCEANPORTThe Rev. Homer Tricules has resigned as pastor of the First Baptist Church of neighboring Long Branch. The reason? To bring faith to the backstretch tenants of New Jersey's three thoroughbred racing tracks Monmouth Park, Garden State and Atlantic City.

title: Dave Anderson
Mother Regains 2 Children After a 6Year Fight
description: A Brooklyn woman has been reunited with her daughter and older son after six years of ef forts, which included her arrest by the Federal Bureau of In vestigation on a charge of having kidnapped another girl in Italy who resembled her daughter.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on International Terrorism10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NEGRO Members Seize Harlem Man On Charge of Theftl
description: Members of Dr. Thomas W. Matthew's black selfhelp group NEGRO made a citizen's ar rest yesterday of the owner of a Harlem sandwich shop whom they accused of having induced drug addicts to steal checks be longing to Dr. Matthew's Inter faith Hospital in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Morocco Begins Trial of 80 Accused of Plot Against King
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco, July 30The trial of 80 leftists charged with plotting the vio lent overthrow of the Moroc can monarchy began in a crim inal court here today.

title: TURKISH ORDEAL FOR 7 AMERICANS
description: ANTIOCH, Turkey, July 27 There were tears and curses from the seven young Ameri cans in the prisoner's dock as a Turkish judge set heavy bail in a trial for drug smuggling that began eight months ago.

title: Two 15YearOlds Seized in Queens In HitRun Case
description: Two 15yearold boys were arrested yesterday in connec tion with a hitandrun acci dent in which a Queens girl was struck by a stolen car and dragged across an intersection.

title: CAR MAKERS GIVEN POLLUTION DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Environmental Protection Agen cy allowed the nation's auto makers today to delay from 1976 until 1977 the production of cars that would meet strin gent emission standards for nitrogen oxides, the third pol lutant for which a year's ex tension has now been granted.

title: Tantalum Oxide Price Is Raised by Chemalloy
description: Chemalloy Minerals, Ltd., an nounced yesterday at Toronto that it had raised its posted price for tantalum oxide to $10 a pound, effective immediately. Previously the price of tantal um oxide ranged from $7 to $8 a pound depending on quality and contract conditions. The new price was said to reflect both an upsurge in demand for the metal which is used in coat ing steel as well as rising costs.

title: Wounded Holdup Victim Shoots Assailant With His Own Gun
description: A confrontation between a 61yearold twogun holdup man and the 57yearold owner of a Harlem restaurant last night wound up at ColumbiaPresby terian Medical Center where both were treated for bullet wounds of the stomach.

title: Creative Monumentality
description: Henry Moore, giant among the world's living sculptors, marked his seventyfifth birthday yesterdayby sculpt ing. He is not counting the candles. Busier than ever this summer, he is carving in the marble mountain region beyond Viareggio in Italy where Michelangelo quarried much of the stone that he, too, turned to life.

title: Santa Clara Women Sweep In Synchronized Swimming
description: PASO ROBLES, Calif., July 30 (AP)The Santa Clara Aqua maids dominated the Amateur Athletic Union outdoor syn chronized swimming champion ships yesterday and retained their national titles in every event.

title: SOL ATLAS DIES; BUILDER WAS 66
description: Sol G. Atlas, builder of sky scrapers and shopping centers, died of a stroke yesterday at the North Shore Hospital, Man hasset, L. I. His age was 66 and he lived in Kings Point, L. I.

title: Suit Accusing Clawson Of Lobbying Dismissed
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)A Federal judge to day dismissed a civil suit by a Ralph Nader group that charged Ken W. Clawson, di rector of commmunications for the White House, with illegally trying to influence the outcome of legislation.

title: Hoffa Takes Volunteer Job To Press Prison Reform
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) James R. Hoffa opened an office here today to seek prison reform, with an acknowledg ment that it won't hurt in his quest to recapture the presi dency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: SCHOOLS IN STATE FACE CUT IN ROLLS
description: TRENTON, July 30 (AP) Public school enrollment in New Jersey will decrease this year for the first time since the end of World War II and then decline steadily over the next decade, according to esti mates announed today by the Department of Education.

title: Court Says Polluter in Jersey Can Be Fined for Killing Fish
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J., July 30 New Jersey today won the right to collect damages from polluters in a precedentsetting decision that is expected to in spire new rounds of litigation against those found guilty of damaging the state's waterways and marshlands.

title: La Roche to Take Drug Pricing Case To House of Lords
description: LONDON, July 30  The Court of Appeal today re versed a High Court ruling that would have allowed a drug company to raise the price of its tranquilizers in de fiance of a Government order.

title: Rates Continue Rise To Record Levels For the Short Term
Barbara Walters Signed To 3Year N.B.C. Contract
description: Barbara Walters has signed a new longterm contract to continue appearing on the Na tional Broadcasting Company's Today television show.

title: PERON SPURNING MOVEMENT'S LEFT
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 30  During a visit to the powerful labor confederation that has been his main source of politi cal strength for three decades former dictator Juan Doming?? Perin called today for a re jection of the left wing of his movement.

title: People in Sports: Scene To Shift for Crenshaw
description: Ben Crenshaw, whose style of play has often been com pared with Jack Nicklaus, will make his debut as a pro on the golf tour Aug. 16 in the $200,000 United States industries classic at Sutton, Mass. The 21yearold Texan, winner of the Western ama teur on Sunday, will make his final amateur appearance in the Porter Cup competi tion starting Thursday at Niagara Falls, N. Y. Cren shaw, who will be honored as a member of the allAmerican golf team tonight at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel, en joys being compared with Nicklaus.

title: Greek Regime Hails Its Victory in Vote
description: ATHENS, July 30  The Greek Government rejoiced to day over its triumphant vic tory at the polls although the results were challenged by many Greeks and questioned by diplomats.

title: DoNothingism
description: After two freezes and three phases, the economy is in an inflationridden shambles. Nobody seems satisfied with Phase 4 and even its promulgators ex hibit scant enthusiasm for it. We have come full circle. The costs of controls in terms of economic distortions and restricted output have finally outstrip ped whatever imagined benefits the controls were supposed to have.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers In reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Work on Landmark Begins
description: The start of a yearlong re habilitation and modernization project of the Hamilton Grange Branch Library, a historic land mark at 503 West 145th Street, has been announced by the Municipal Services Administra tion. The $879,479 project, scheduled to be completed next July, involves the renovation of the basement and first and second floors of the fourstory building.

title: U.S. DENIES SPYING IN WEST GERMANY Some Intelligence Work Is Acknowledged by Army
